file: SUBC - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 28April2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The challenging industry conditions have not changed since we spoke to you in March. The timing of new awards  to market is still uncertain as clients continue to limit investments in major new self-developments, due to the oil  price environment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the North Sea, offshore activity levels and vessel utilization were low, reflecting the decline in activity resulting  from the low oil price, as well as seasonal weather conditions. We are addressing this by forming new ways of  working and collaborating with our clients and partners to lower the overall cost of field de velopment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Offshore Brazil, we completed the BC-10 project; and our newest PLSV, Seven Rio, started her long-term day-rate  contract, as planned. We achieved high levels of vessel utilization for all our PLSVs working o ffshore Brazil.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We do not expect to sustain the hemisphere's margin at this level, because the mix of early stage to near - completed projects will change overtime. Also, our pricing today is already factoring in our new lower cost base  with the associated savings being shared with our clients, to help make projects viable in the low oil price  environment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Let's turn now to slide 14. We are delivering solutions for our clients, but are lowering the  cost of development and enabling projects to progress at the lower oil price.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving to slide 15, I would like to share with you some details on three projects that illustrates the changes we are  driving to reduce costs.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Firstly, West Nile Delta Phase I, a fast-track domestic gas project offshore Egypt. Our longstanding relationship  with the client supported better ways to work together; it eliminated unnecessary administration and reduced  man hours. In addition, numerous innovative engineering ideas were implemented. One example: one cost saving  we identified was a change to the PLT protection cover design to reduce its weight and enable hourly access. I  could list a number of other examples.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In 2015, we launched a cost reduction program and resizing program to reduce the capacity and cost of our fleet  and workforce. This program was successfully completed in the first quarter of 2016, and, as I mentioned earlier,  we are already seeing the financial benefits in our reported results.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The market outlook has not changed, with many projects pushed to the right, despite the progress we are making  to lower the cost of the projects. As a result, we will be implementing additional cost reduction measures in 2016.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We remain focused on our long-term strategic objective, and our cost reduction measures reflect this.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the northern hemisphere and life-of-field business units, the market-wide cost challenge in the North Sea  remains. Improving weather conditions are expected to result in better utilization and activity levels over the  second and third quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our joint venture, SHL, remains well positioned to capture additional work in the renewables sector.

file: SUBC - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning first to the highlights on Slide 4, revenue was $897 million in the quarter, 20% higher than the prior year  period. We progressed well with the Beatrice wind farm project, which more than offset the lower activity on oil  and gas projects.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The challenging industry conditions have not changed since we spoke to you in March. But what is encouraging is  that we are working on early engineering studies and seeing increased client engagement. As we have said  before, the [indiscernible] (3:30) recovery is expected to be gradual. We believe many offshore projects are viable  at the lower oil price, enabled by the process made by the industry on cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore Egypt, the West Nile Delta Phase One project was substantially completed in the quarter with first gas  achieved ahead of schedule. The platform extension and tie-in project of Burullus and the Atoll project both  progressed well.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore Australia, the Persephone Phase Three project was essentially completed. In the U.S. Gulf of Mexico,  the Stampede and Coulomb Phase Two project progressed well. The Beatrice wind farm project also progressed  well with procurement and fabrication.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to Slide 7 to look at our backlog, we ended the first quarter with order backlog of $5.7 billion. This  reflects the inclusion of $285 million of renewable backlog gained through the acquisition and consolidation of  Seaway Heavy Lifting. And the cancellation of $106 million related to the PLSV Seven Mar.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 8 lists some of the larger project tenders that we expect may be awarded to the market in the foreseeable  future. In Norway, we are engaging FEED studies for the Pil and Bue project for VNG as well as Skarfjell project  for Wintershall.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In South America, the Liza and Peregrino projects are currently being built. The Zinia and Zabazaba in West  Africa, and Golfinho gas project in East Africa are being evaluated by the respective clients.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We remain positive on the development outlook for gas for domestic consumption in India, with Reliance plant for  KG-D6, and ONGC's plant for Block 98/2. i-Tech Services is seeing improving condition for IMR and frame  agreements in the North Sea. Renewables and Heavy Lifting activity remain centered on EPIC opportunities for  offshore wind farms installation.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We have introduced a new Business Unit this quarter for our Renewables and Heavy Lifting activity. The results  generated from Seaway Heavy Lifting are included in this Business Unit, having previously been reported in our  Corporate segment. Renewables and Heavy Lifting generated revenue of $220 million compared to $2 million in  the prior-year period. This was mostly from the Beatrice project, which progressed the procurement and  fabrication phases in the quarter. We've reported a net operating loss of $4 million due to the low utilization of the  two heavy lifting vessels in the winter months.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: For reference, we have provided re-presented segmental results by quarter for 2016 in the Appendix to this  presentation. SURF and Conventional, and i-Tech Services have been re-presented to include their share of  offshore resource management and asset impairments, which were previously categorized under the Corporate  segment. The Renewables and Heavy Lifting segmental results included Seaway Heavy Lifting on an equity  accounting basis for the year.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Let us turn now to slide 15. We are delivering good performance as a result of our decisive  and early action to adapt to the lower oil price environment. We are engaging earlier and delivering better lower- cost solution for our clients. We have announced our market-leading capabilities invested in our fleet and  extended our presence in the Renewables and Heavy Lifting market.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to slide 17, which covers the growing offshore renewable market. Offshore wind farms are delivering  clean energy solutions at increasingly competitive price per megawatt hour. We believe this market will continue  to grow, supported by government policies and the need for alternative power sources to replace aging  generation capacity. Economies of scale are driving change with more turbine spare wind farm and a trend  towards larger turbines, each with greater power generating capacity. The complexity and size of the installation  are increasing the needs for turnkey solutions and the larger foundations required higher specification heavy  lifting vessel.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Seaway Heavy Lifting has installed hundreds of wind turbine foundations, with experience of monopile and jacket  solution. Seaway Heavy Lifting also has an enviable record in installing offshore substations on many European  wind farms. Our increased presence in this growing market [indiscernible] (20:09) client profile, that enables  Seaway Heavy Lifting to grow its market share.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The long-term outlook for offshore energy is intact. The changes we have made to lower the cost of offshore  development have been highly effective and the improvements do not stop here. We believe integration, early  engagement and innovation will deliver the sustainable cost reduction needed to remain commercial in a low oil  price world.

file: SUBC - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 26April2018 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I turn now to slide 5 to look at some of our current project and operation in more detail. In the first quarter, pipeline  activities commenced on the West Nile Delta GFR Phase Two project with the arrival of Seven Borealis, Offshore  Egypt in March. In Australia, the Sole project began onshore preparations for 64 kilometers of pipe that has to be  installed this summer for Cooper Energy. The integrated Mad Dog 2 project continued with engineering from our  global product center, working hand in hand with [indiscernible] (00:04:14).

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Oda project, which we're executing on their partnership agreement with Spirit Energy, progressed with  fabrication at the Vigra spoolbase in Norway. The Tyra project offshore Denmark completed offshore operation  with Seven Borealis laying to pipelines supported by Seven Pacific. Our PLSVs remain active offshore Brazil, with  six vessels working on their [indiscernible] (00:04:40) contract. In April, after the quarter ended, Kommandor 3000  completed its contract, and we leave Brazil to be recycled.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In renewables and heavy lifting, we're continuing in the three [ph] fabrication (00:04:54) yards on the Beatrice  Windfarm foundation and half of the jackets are now being installed offshore. In i-Tech Services, we continued to  win and execute work, including [ph] drillship (00:05:07) campaigns, inspection services and pipeline repairs.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the first quarter, we were awarded the Johan Castberg project offshore Norway by Statoil and the Nova project  by Wintershall on the back of successfully completing the very cost-effective Maria project for them last year. The  $3 billion project offshore Saudi Arabia was awarded under the long-term agreement with Saudi Aramco. This  conventional shallow water project, which we are executing in consortium with Larsen & Toubro, was our first  award under the LTA since acquiring ECS last year. We see future opportunities in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Momentum has continued into the second quarter with the announcement of another two awards in April. The  PUP Project offshore Nigeria is a shallow water conventional project and is the first new project to be awarded in  this country for some time. Local presence was a key differentiator for this project and it will be executed by  NigerStar 7, our Nigerian joint venture. The Alligin project offshore UK is a two-well tie-back project for BP which  we'll use pipe-in-pipe flowline systems.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 9, we are confident in the long-term outlook of offshore energy. Our strategy is to develop our  presence in key markets worldwide. We have already made good progress on these through counter-cyclical  acquisition and investments in organic growth.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our first quarter EBITDA percentage margin of 13% reflected these trends and was also impacted by seasonally  challenging weather that affected our activities in the North Sea. We expect the second quarter to be sequentially  better than the first quarter. Net loss of $18 million included the tax credit of $12 million and resulted in a loss per  share of $0.03.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Net operating loss was $4 million for the quarter. Renewables and heavy lifting generated revenue of $173 million  compared to $220 million in the prior year period. Revenue was generated mostly from the Beatrice and Borkum  II wind farm projects. The net operating loss of $4 million was partly due as expected to the lower – the slower  progress on foundation installation for offshore UK during the winter months.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Subsea 7 is a specialist offshore contractor to the energy industry. Our expertise and experience includes project  managing, engineering, planning, and executing projects in all the major offshore energy locations. We have a  wide range of offshore capabilities, including pipe lay and construction in addition to diving, heavy lifting, and ROV  services.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We are strategic partners to our clients on renewable energy development as well as oil and gas field. Our track  record is safe and reliable execution supports long-term collaborative relationships. We are enabling a cost- effective technology which unlocks projects that might otherwise be impractical or too expensive to execute. [ph]  This point of differential serves (00:18:34) and help us to win work.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Projects have certain attributes that can impact the duration, complexity, scale, and value of our [indiscernible]  (00:18:42) such as water depth, region, market conditions, scope and technology, to name a few. For instance, a  project in a remote location with challenging seabed topography and soil conditions may be more costly even if  the lands are [ph] proline (00:18:57) or a number of Christmas trees are relatively low. Likewise, any big project  with a high proportion of procurement and fabrication will be significantly larger in size than the transport and  installation project, although the vessel offshore companies might be similar.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We have over 150 jobs and projects in our backlog today; some small and some large. The diversity of this work  and the scale of our worldwide operations enable us to schedule our onshore and offshore operation efficiently,  maximizing our profitability, and enabling us to tender more effectively. When we bid for new work, each project's  risk, value, and contribution is assessed independently, but if they pronounce an impact on our portfolio is also  important, and can influence our decision on the level of acceptable margin. The repricing on newer wells remain  challenging. But as we look ahead to a recovery in offshore oil and gas activity, we expect this to improve.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 16. These two charts, sourced from Rystad, illustrate the market trends for oil and gas activity.  Capital expenditure approvals by our clients reached through in 2016. In 2017, we took the first signs of recovery  as lower project cost, and the higher oil price encouraged project sanction.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Looking ahead, we continue to expect a valuable recovery in market activity, with around 70% of non-sanctioned  offshore resources breaking even at the $50 to $60 oil price. These forecasts are encouraging and are backed up  by the conversation we are having with our clients who are keen to capture the benefits from lower price supply  chains and supplier availability at this point in the cycle.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to slide 17. I will conclude with our view of the outlook for market awards by business unit starting with  the SURF and Conventional outlook. We continue to see positive momentum on tenders for large gas  development, including the Mamba and Golfinho projects offshore Mozambique; the Gorgon Phase 2 projects  offshore Australia; and the 98/2 project offshore India.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore Brazil, tenders for the first Libra project known as Mero have just been issued to market. This project  required bespoke steel catenary riser technology due to the pre-salt water there and [indiscernible] (00:22:12)  production.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and heavy lifting tendering is ongoing from transport and installation activity for both renewables and  oil and gas, as well as EPIC wind farm projects offshore Europe, Taiwan, and the U.S. For i-Tech Services,  tendering is focused on IRM activity in the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico as well as ROV Support for [ph]  drillings (00:23:02) in the North Sea and Asia.

file: SUBC - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 2May2019 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The PUPP project continues to execute work in the shallow waters offshore Nigeria. On the slide, we can see the  shore approach of this 24-inch pipeline with Seven Antares laying pipe on the horizon. Spools and riser were also  installed in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Aerfugl project which is due for offshore operation next year is an Electrically Heat Traced Flowline solution.  By helixing electrical cables around the pipeline, we are able to improve the flow characteristic of the pipeline  allowing for increased [indiscernible] (00:04:32). This quarter, progress was made with pipeline [indiscernible]  (00:04:35) which are the key milestone in preparation for the exploration next year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Middle East, work progressed well on the Hasbah project which nears completion. In the quarter, pipelay  was completed by the Seven Champion. Seaway 7, our Renewables and Heavy Lifting brands, continued work on  the Hornsea One wind farm project over the course of the UK.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Life of Field, we successfully delivered a hyperbaric welding system for Dolphin Energy emergency repair  system, allowing for intervention and recovery at short notice on damaged pipelines. We also commenced a five- year IRM frame agreement offshore Norway for Equinor using our hybrid-powered vessel, Seven Viking.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Over 80% of our backlog is attributed to SURF and Conventional work as we have seen an increase in awards in  line with market recovery trends. We announced three awards in the quarter, a five-year IRM contract for BP for  work in their North Sea portfolio, this is the fourth announced award for BP in the 12 months; the Arran project for  Shell, which is a 60-kilometer pipe-in-pipe shoreline buy back, adding to our growing portfolio of project for them  in the North Sea; and the Berri-Zuluf project under our LTA with Saudi Aramco.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving to slide 7. In the first quarter, Subsea Integration Alliance, our integrating offering with OneSubsea, we  announced two FEED contract by Woodside for greenfield project in Senegal and Australia. The further Woodside  award in Australia was also awarded on a stand-alone SURF basis to Subsea 7.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I would like to share with you some of the details of this project. SNE Phase 1 is a large greenfield oil  development offshore Senegal [indiscernible] (00:08:38). Our flexible riser solutions and specialized  [indiscernible] (00:08:43) reel flowlines will connect the 23 Christmas trees back to the new FPSO. Scarborough  and Julimar, our gas fields offshore Australia that will eventually tie back to existing onshore LNG facilities. LNG  has become increasingly important on the supply curve [indiscernible] (00:09:02). Our solutions are adaptable to  either oil or gas production and Subsea 7 has therefore been able to benefit from the increased activity in LNG.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our Renewables and Heavy Lifting business unit generated $53 million in revenue compared to $173 million in  the prior year period. This significant decline was in line with the expectations and reflected lower levels of activity  for the heavy lifting vessels following the substantial completion of the very large purchase wind farm project last  year.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Seaway Moxie and Seaway Aimery, our two vessels involved in cable laying, we're well utilized in the quarter,  making good progress on the Hornsea 1 wind farm project. The commissioning phase progressed on the Borkum  II wind farm project which is now over 95% complete. The net operating loss for Renewables and Heavy Lifting  was $9 million in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our vision is to lead the way in the delivery of offshore projects and services for the energy industry. We did it  through our values which define who we are and how we behave. In 2019, we added sustainability as a fixed  value, having previously included it implicitly within our [indiscernible] (00:19:47). We are committed to our values  in all that we do. In the quarter, we rolled out a new safety program to 1,200 leaders across the company,  including the whole executive team, as we seek to make every day a good safety day.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We are reliable in our performance and execution, making us a trusted partner. Our clients, new and old, choose  to work with us based on this reliability. Creating the right solution is fundamental at Subsea 7. Our extensive  technology portfolio means that we can deliver the most effective solution for our clients. For example, our  Electrically Heat Traced Flowline solution is about to install for the first time on the Katmai and Aerfugl projects.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our longstanding Pipeline Bundle solution continue to be highly effective, with Penguins and Buzzard Phase 2  projects being awarded last year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving now onto slide 16. Our differentiators are why we are confident that we will continue to win work and, over  time, improve our margins. We expect the offshore oil and gas market will continue to gradually recover, and we  agree with Rystad's prediction of a trough in 2019 for subsea pipeline installation. In our own backlog, 2021 is  already becoming a busy year for real pipelay projects around the world and, in particular, Australia. An industry  indicator for offshore installation activity is Christmas tree activity. Pipeline installation lagged behind Christmas  tree installation with trough in 2017, and have seen increased activity in 2018.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Renewable and Heavy Lifting, there are several projects being tendered and awaiting FID. This include the  HKZ offshore wind farm projects where we have already been selected by Vattenfall as its T&I partner with FID  and contract award anticipated later this year. Competition for wind farm awards has intensified with the arrival of  some of our peers from an oil and gas background, but we remain confident in our competitive position.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: So, to summarize, we remain confident in the gradual oil and gas market recovery. Competition on new SURF  awards is still challenging, but as volume increase, pricing is starting to show signs of improvement from the very  low level in 2018.

file: SUBC - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 10August2011 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: This was a good quarter in which we have delivered a strong set of financial results. A few comments on the key  drivers of these results. In the North Sea, as expected, results have improved although we continue to see the  effects of the lower margin on work awarded in 2010, some of which have been executed during the quarter. We've  seen vessel utilization improving since the first quarter, in part due to the usual seasonality, but also because  clients have been keen to progress with both their salt development and Life-of-Field activities. Our operational  performance has been good although affected by difficult weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Simon Crowe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning now to the income statement overview on slide number eight. Admin expenses were $97 million for the  quarter with $15 million of integration costs included in this total. SapuraAcergy and NKT performed it in line  with expectations, and as expected, SHL's result was positively impacted by the timing of the Sheringham Shoal  Wind Farm Project.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Gulf of Mexico, in spite of some progress regarding permits for deepwater drilling, this has yet to manifest  into a significant increase in Subsea installation activity. As such visibility regarding the timing of projects  remains limited, we do not believe that we will see a return to Subsea construction activity level pre-Macondo in  2012.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Asia-Pacific markets remain competitive, but we have been pleased to see the first of last SURF contract  finally come to award. We expect further gas-driven projects in Australia to come to market award later this year  and early 2012, resulting in more offshore activity in 2013 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: And finally in Brazil, we see more opportunities ahead for the industry in both the traditional deepwater through  additional PLSVs as well as the pre-salt developments. For pre-salt development, technology is key, and strong  engineering and project management resources are needed. Subsea 7 is clearly one of the few companies which

file: SUBC - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 9August2012 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I'm pleased with this quarter results. Year-on-year, improved profitability was driven by increased activity in the  North Sea albeit mitigated by poor weather experienced early in the quarter. This was another good quarter in  West Africa as the results were as far as our expectation and, as previously indicated, scheduled dry-docking had a  negative impact on Brazil. Also good result achieved by SHL and SapuraAcergy joint venture.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Gulf of Mexico, we are starting to see signs of an increase of activity following the re-commencement of our  water-drilling permits. We should see more contract awards to the market in the late 2012 with execution in late  2013 and 2014 in an improving business environment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: And finally, Brazil. There have been a lot of comments over the last few months regarding Petrobras' revised  activity plans as some of their projects are expected to be rescheduled. We have seen a large amount of approved  projects and this does not change our positive views on this market. We continue to see more opportunities ahead  in traditional deepwater in the Campos Basin, as well as with pre-salt developments. More larger, big projects for  pre-salt developments are likely to come to market award in the second part of 2012 with operation from 2014 to  2016.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Thank you, Jean, and good afternoon, everyone. The results of the second quarter 2012 were encouraging with
texts.text: Turning to slide nine, I'll now run through the performance of the territories. The North Sea, Mediterranean, and  Canada delivered revenue of $713 million and net operating income of $93 million for the quarter. Although  activity improved compared with the first quarter, it was affected in the North Sea by initial weather-related  delays. Good progress was made, nevertheless, on a number of projects, including Visund Sør, Jasmine, Skuld,  Alta, and Draugen. Life-of-Field operations under frame agreements, including those with Shell, DSVi, Statoil,  ConocoPhillips, Total, and BP were executed satisfactorily throughout the quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: During the quarter, we also acquired a 50% stake in the Normand Oceanic, which was previously on long-term  charter with us. The Normand Oceanic is a heavy construction vessel, one of the key enabler of our fleet.

file: SUBC - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 14August2013 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Production advisor at Ubu our spoolbase is now progressing well and is not on the project critical path. We have  moved into the main offshore phase of the project this quarter with Seven Polaris and the Seven Oceans deployed  on location. Weather conditions remain challenging and having an impact on installation operation. As we  commented in June, we expect the difficult weather condition to continue until the Brazilian winter season is over  in the first quarter – in the fourth quarter. So overall the projects remain challenging.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The second quarter net operating income margin of 19.3% compares favorably to the prior period margin of 13.1%.  With Knarr project moved into the offshore phase in the second quarter, and Martin Linge passed to the 5  percentage of completion threshold. Projects substantially completed in the quarter include B11 and Yeta, while  commercial close-out was achieved on a number of smaller projects. The Seven Oceans move to Brazil for 2013  and this partly explains why revenue was slightly down on the prior year quarter despite high activity levels.  Overall, the execution of more recently tendered higher margin projects continues to benefit the territory's  profitability.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. I would like to provide some additional guidance by territory on slide 11 and 12. In NSC, we  expect normal seasonal vessel utilization in Q4 and I must remind you that the Seven Oceans has moved to Brazil  which impacts NSC revenues in 2013.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Brazil, the Guará-Lula project, as I mentioned earlier, is in offshore installation phase but we expect weather to  continue to impact progress until the end of the Brazilian winter period. We are making progress in implementing  our business strategy for PLSVs. So Lochnagar to be retired in early Q3 and we expect that discussion with  Petrobras for the renewal of the Seven Mar and Kommandor PLSV contract will be completed later this year.

file: SUBC - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 31July2014 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: So let's move to operations, first. We had good execution across our project portfolio and made significant  progress on a number of major projects. Among the larger projects in offshore phase were OFON 2, Block 31 GES  and CLOV in West Africa, with CLOV achieving first oil in June ahead of the client schedule.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Lastly, the corporate segment had net operating income of $30 million compared to $32 million in the previous  year period. A reduced contribution from the Seaway Heavy Lifting joint venture caused by the completion of the  Stanislav Y udin dry-docking, and lower renewables activity in the North Sea, was partially offset by lower  operating costs.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Demand for the Life-of-Field remains strong, particularly in the UK sector of the North Sea but IOCs and  independents continue to invest in existing fields. Uncertainty remains on the timing of new project awards in  Nigeria, in shallow water, where our conventional business is.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: For example, one large project in Egypt which had been canceled by the IOC in 2013 may be awarded to market  late 2014 or early 2015. I also mentioned earlier the slowdown in the shallow water conventional market in  Nigeria. Tendering activity, particularly for larger projects, is currently very limited, and it's uncertain when the  situation will change.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 18. In recent months, I've been talking for the last months with the oil operators focusing on  optimizing their cash flow and the cost of their project. We are seeing some softening of pricing in the fabrication  and equipment market from our suppliers which allows us to pass savings to our clients.

file: SUBC - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Offshore UK, the Montrose project made good progress with pipelay completed successfully by the Seven Navica,  and pipeline trenching and backfilling undertaken by the Skandi Skansen. Also in the UK, the Catcher project  progressed well, with pre-installation service completed and the first strip of pipes put on the Seven Navica at the  end of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Offshore Norway, the Aasta Hansteen project completed fabrication and starting installation, and the Martin  Linge project completed the installation of flexible flowlines, fiber optic cables and power cables.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our pure play Subsea strategy aligns us closely with our clients to drive down the cost of producing deepwater oil,  and the Maria award is a good example of our collaborative approach. By using the manual options embedded  within the contract, we were able to offer Wintershall a highly cost-effective solution with standardized content,  with allowing them flexibility to take alternative choice as the project progress such as best scope work  specifications.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the Northern Hemisphere, activity in the North Sea has been particularly affected by the lower oil price,  especially in the Norway sector where short- and medium-term award sanctions continue to face delays. Life of  Field activity is low, although the spot market is becoming more buoyant as expected in the summer months.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The demand for domestic gas is supporting projects such as West Nile Delta in Egypt, where the award to market  is anticipated this summer, and in India, tenders have been submitted for that system. Also, large awards to  market expected in the medium term include Bonga South West and ETAN in Nigeria as well as Golfinho and  Coral FLNG in Mozambique.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: It is too early to provide guidance on 2016. The environment remains challenging, and the timing of awards is  highly uncertain.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. So let's turn now to slide 19. It's Subsea 7's vision to be acknowledged as a leading strategic  partner in the seabed-to-surface offshore engineering energy industry. Our clients need from us a partner who can  execute cost-effective technical solution that will safely deliver complex projects at a lower cost.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This complementary alliance creates a more formal structure which allows Subsea 7 to work closely with industry  leading partners to drive better and lower-cost solutions for our clients. We believe this will not only strengthen  our competitive position but also deliver sustained improvements in the economic of deepwater oil and lead to a  recovery of industry activity over time.

file: SUBC - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 28July2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Backlog was $7.1 billion at the end of June. Order intake in the quarter was $1.6 billion, most of which related to a  major wind farm award. We have the limited number of oil and gas awards to the market in the quarter despite  some oil price improvements since January. The timing of awards remain uncertain and we expect few large  scale project to be awarded to the market before the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we are making good progress towards sustainable lower project cost based on our leaner  organization, better ways of working, early engagement and innovation. We are having more frequent discussion  with our clients on early engagements and way of working and we are confident in the long-term outlook for  deepwater development.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Offshore UK, we completed three Bundle installations for Premier Catcher's project. Offshore Norway work  progressed on the Aasta Hansteen project of Statoil. We used Seven Oceans to complete BuBi pipe reel-lay and  installation of Steel Catenary Risers and this is the first application for both these technologies in Norway. Also,  off shore Norway, we have made good progress on the Martin Linge project, installing the loading buoy and  connecting mooring lines in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the Maria project, water injection and gas lift pipelines are ready for rollout and we have successfully applied  new ways of working. We are achieving our planned saving. Offshore Egypt, we have progressed with fabrication  for the West Nile Delta Phase 1 project and are ready to commence offshore operation using Simar Esperança  and Seven Borealis.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the East Nile Delta project, first gas has been achieved on schedule and the final offshore work is due to be  completed by our diving support vessel Rockwater 2 in September. The TEN project of Tullow offshore Ghana is  now substantially complete with the conclusion of our offshore operations and the mobilization of our vessels.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have concentrated our EPIC capability in the SURF and Conventional segment where we utilize the expertise  and experience of our project managers and engineers to deliver complex projects in all water depths.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: i-Tech Services provides engineered services and products across the whole life of offshore oil and gas fields  worldwide. It includes inspection maintenance and repair of operational fields, ROV services that operate  independently of our vessels mostly on drilling rigs and decommissioning services. By combining our Life of Field  and ROV expertise into the single segment, our objective is to expand our geographic reach and create growth  opportunities.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Lastly, our Corporate segment. We have included our renewables and heavy-lift business here, which today  comprises our Seaway Heavy Lifting joint venture and the Beatrice Windfarm projects we were recently awarded.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking now at slide seven. For the second consecutive quarter, our order intake exceeded the values of order  executed. We ended June with backlog of $7.1 billion, $600 million higher than at the end of March. The bright  spot this quarter came with renewables with the award of the Beatrice Windfarm project. This $1.3 billion project  will be run in collaboration with our joint venture company, Seaway Heavy Lifting, and involve the installation of  foundation for 84 wind turbines off the coast of Scotland.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Slide eight summarizes our view of the foreseeable future. Industry-wide tendering and award activity for new oil  and gas project remains low, as client minimize non-essential expenditure. We are making the necessary  changes to stay competitive in this challenging market, but remain disciplined on the project risk profile. We're  having more frequent discussions with clients regarding early engagement on solution to offset decline rates in  production with a particular focus on our alliance, technology and innovation that support extended buybacks and  marginal field developments.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We list on the slides several project that we believe may be awarded to market within the next year or so. We  continue to see better opportunity on gas project than for oil, particularly those for domestic end markets. Our i- Tech services business is expected to benefit from the consolidation of life of field and ROV services. And we are  pursuing opportunities to expand our geographic presence. We are currently tendering for work not only in the  North Sea but also in Gulf of Mexico, Brazil and Australia.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There are additional opportunities for SHL also in the renewable sector. And now, I will hand over to Ricardo to  review our financial performance in more details.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As shown on slide 14, our new build program is in its final stages. The first two vessels to be completed the  Seven Waves and Seven Rio were delivered ahead of schedule. They are on long-term contracts with Petrobras,  although the Seven Waves is currently undertaking other work in the North Sea, while the damaged lay-tower is  repaired.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Slide 19, shows our focused investment in technology. Our market driven and cost effective technology is  enabling step changes in field development and cost of production. We are concentrating our research and  development effort on five strategic programs where we see the greatest commercial potential in the near future.  To give you some example of our recent technology advances include Electrical Heat Traced Flowline, longer and  specialized bundles and collaboration with OneSubsea Schlumberger on the development of integrated Subsea  processing technology.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Large and major projects can take a year to 18 months of planning and engineering before offshore work  commences. Subsea 7 is taking the necessary actions to protect its business in the downturn, and offer our  clients cost effective solution enabled by innovation and early engagement. Long-term, we are confident in the  outlook for deepwater projects, based on the growing global demand and industry wide progress on lowering the  cost at deepwater production.

file: SUBC - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 26July2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting activity increased compared to the prior year with significant progress on the  Beatrice wind farm project and several substation installation. The Beatrice picture show 5 of the 84 jackets in one  of the fabrication yard. To give you an idea of the scale of this construction, each of them weighs approximately  1,200 tonnes and stands 80 meters tall.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting revenue was $325 million, mostly related to the Beatrice project, which began  offshore operations in April. Work has progressed well with approximately half of the piles installed and jacket  installation due to commence in August. Net operating income was $53 million. Both revenue and net operating  income benefited from the full consolidation of SHL following its acquisition in March this year.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The ECS businesses are consolidated from the date of acquisition within our SURF and Conventional Business  Unit.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 12 shows our progress on capital allocation. Firstly, we are investing to grow and strengthen our business.  Our targeted approaches increased our presence in the renewables market and accelerated our growth strategy  for the Middle East. We've also invested in our modern and flexible fleet and maintained a leading position in  development of new technology.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 13, I will conclude with our updated guidance. We have updated our guidance to include the  addition of ECS and to reflect our year-to-date performance. We now expect 2017 revenue to be higher than in  2016. We have not changed our guidance for adjusted EBITDA percentage margin, which is still expected to be  lower than the record 32% reported last year.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Now let's turn to slide 14, which shows some of our key achievements in the beginning of 2015. We have  delivered well through the downturn. We have achieved this by identifying the challenges of a lower oil price and  taking strategic decision to strengthen our position. By acting fairly and focusing our attention on our  differentiators, we were able to reduce capacity quickly. This reduced our operating costs, helped us to win more  work and protect our earnings.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the first quarter, we acquired the remaining 50% of SHL, doubling our exposure to the fast-growing offshore  wind market. In the second quarter, we acquired certain businesses of ECS, accelerating our plan to develop our  presence in the Middle East. I shall talk more about ECS in a moment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 15 summarizes our acquisition of ECS from Chapter 11. ECS was a competitor with a strong conventional  business in Saudi Arabia and some capability for last project in certain geographies. It was placed under Chapter  11 in February 2017.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: To meet existing operational commitments, we have chartered two ECS vessels. The Lewek Constellation on a  short-term charter and Lewek Champion on a multi-year charter. We didn't acquire any old vessels owned by  ECS. In our view, the technical specification of Lewek Constellation would not have fulfilled our new technology  implementation, such as larger diameter pipe-in-pipe or electrically heated pipes.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The opportunity presented by the ECS acquisition accelerated our strategy and replaced our earlier plans. Our  LTA is held in consortium with Larsen & Toubro. In addition to the engineering and project management we both  provide, we supply the fabrication that is necessary for projects in this country and we provide the installation  capability.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 17 illustrates the market outlook. So far this year, we have seen an increase in offshore projects being  sanctioned. We have also experienced an increase in tendering activity in part due to earlier engagements as our  clients adopt way of working that supports lower cost solutions. Our clients have lowered the breakevens for their  portfolio of projects. And the recent oil price uncertainty does not appear to have materially impacted their  development plan.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Active tenders in Africa includes the Tortue project, a relatively large gas development offshore Mauritania and  Senegal for BP; the Mamba project for Eni, offshore Mozambique; and Total Zinia project, offshore Angola.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The outlook for Renewables and Heavy Lifting is steady. Oil and gas heavy lifting is predominately located in the  Middle East and Egypt. Decommissioning is focused in the North Sea. There are a number of wind farm tenders  in progress. Most of the renewables activity is in European waters, but we also see opportunities emerging in  Taiwan.

file: SUBC - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our operational performance in the quarter was good and we progressed well on our SURF and Conventional  projects. We had lower levels of vessel activity in the renewables and i-Tech Services business units compared to  the prior-year period with lower IRM and ROV services execution. The Beatrice wind farm project neared  completion as per plan and we expect to conclude on remaining commercial discussions in Q3.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: While larger greenfield projects are taking longer to sanction than tie-back contracts, visibility on the timing of FID  of this project is improving. It makes me confident that while big margins remain low for short cycle project, we will  see an improvement in the medium term when the volume of offshore activity increases.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 5 to look at some of our current projects and operations. We operate in all major geographies for  offshore energy around the world. We are capable of working in all water depth and have an extensive network of  local offices, operational bases and fabrication yard.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The West Nile Delta Phase Two GFR project, offshore Egypt progressed well with Seven Borealis laying piping in  S-lay and J-lay configuration adapting to the changing water depth. This is a significant phase of the project and  Vessel Seven Pacific, Seven Seas, Seven Eagle, and Simar Esperança were also used in the most recent  offshore campaign.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Snorre project which was signed at the end of last year progressed well with procurement and fabrication at  our Pipeline Bundle facility in Scotland. This will be Subsea 7's 87th Bundle project, showing the longstanding  competitiveness as its innovative technology.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our strategy to expand our presence in targeted geographies has continued successfully. A long-term contract  with BP in the Caspian was one in the first quarter, and in May, we added chartered vessel MMA Pinnacle to our  fleet for IRM activity offshore Australia and Asia. Offshore UK, the Beatrice wind farm project is nearing  completion. 82 of the 84 foundation have been installed by the quarter-end, and the remaining two were installed  in July.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The second cable-lay campaign is underway, using Seaway Aimery, and we should – and should be completed  before year-end. We have started offshore installation on the Borkum II wind farm project, offshore Germany.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Jean, and good afternoon, everyone. Let's first look at the income statement highlights on slide 7.  Second quarter revenue of $1.2 billion was up 13% from the prior-year period. This reflected increased activity in  SURF and Conventional, mostly due to the execution of projects taken on with the ECS acquisition made at the  end of the second quarter last year. Revenue from i-Tech Services and Renewables and Heavy Lifting was lower  year-on-year with reduced activity levels in both business units.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Net operating income was $62 million, down from $163 million in the prior-year period. We have fewer SURF  projects in the final stages of completion and those projects we are currently executing were awarded with lower  margins. In addition, this is a reflection of our change in mix of activity as conventional projects in the Middle East  typically achieve lower margins than deepwater oil and gas projects in the other geographies.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting revenue was $257 million, a significant proportion of it's related to the Beatrice  project which neared completion with almost all the foundations installed by the end of the quarter. Renewables  net operating income was $5 million. Activity levels were lower than in the prior-year period as the Beatrice project  [ph] wind (00:13:49) down and there was insufficient transport and installation activity to fill the gaps between  scheduled offshore campaigns on the Beatrice and Borkum II projects.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 10. On the April 10, we completed the acquisition of Seaway Offshore Cables in a related party  transaction. The addition of cable-lay capability has increased our offering in renewables and help to de-risk our  EPCI services. We can now provide our clients with a full balance of plant service, meaning that we can do  everything in a single contract, except for installation of the wind turbine generators. The initial consideration of  $164 million was paid in the second quarter. This included $117 million related to the two vessels and associated  equipment. Excluding contracts awarded to SOC by Subsea 7's subsidiaries, we added $95 million to our order  backlog as a result of the transaction.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 12, I will conclude with our guidance, and how our expectations have evolved over the course of  the quarter. Our guidance for 2018 revenue and adjusted EBITDA percentage margin is unchanged from the first  quarter, and our view of the outcome for the year has not deteriorated in the period. Based on our firm backlog  and results year-to-date, we are confident that we will achieve 2018 revenue broadly in line with the level reported  in 2017. This includes a full year's contribution from the ECS acquisition, offset by lower expected revenues in  Renewables and Heavy Lifting, as the Beatrice wind farm project reaches completion.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Turning now to slide 13. We aim to create sustainable value by supporting our clients across  the whole lifecycle of the field. We have delivered on this in the second quarter by investing in cable-lay capability  to extend our renewables offering for comprehensive balance of plant services. We are developing our  relationship with Schlumberger to evolve our Subsea integration alliance into a joint venture agreement offering  fully-integrated projects and Life of Field services. Our differentiated technology continue to drive better and more  efficient solutions and our pipeline bundles are set for another busy year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our investment in composite pipeline technology is expected to deliver significant cost and design advantage for  our clients in the years to come. I will take each of this in turn and start with our strategy for renewables on slide  14. Subsea 7 and SHL have been involved in the provision of transport and installation services for offshore wind  farms since 2009. Our capability and experience enable us to deliver safe and reliable project execution. Over the  last 10 years, we have installed hundreds of turbine foundation and lifted many jackets topside, substation and  Subsea structures.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our recent investment in cable-lay capability position us in a leading balanced a plant for service provider able to  offer holistic EPCI solution as well as transport and installation services. We have a team of over 1,000  experienced people and four specialist vessels for the Renewables and Heavy Lifting market. By growing our  presence in renewables, we are enlarging our addressable market and adding structural growth. We are engaging  in the energy transition and positioning ourselves for future in with renewable energy resources are increasingly  important for society. Our experience in Renewables and Heavy Lifting as well as EPCI project delivery is helping  to lower the cost and risk associated with offshore wind farms developments worldwide.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving to slide 17, our technology initiatives are delivering good results targeted on areas that bring most value to  our clients. Our bundle technology has advanced a long way since the first bundle was installed in 1980. Our  bundles are enabling development of higher pressure and higher temperature for fields which were previously too  costly to [ph] proceed (00:25:46). We are continuously pushing the boundaries of this proprietary technology [ph]  just now our bundle (00:25:51) will be the longest and heaviest we have installed to-date.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our bids are submitted with the right terms and condition and adequate contingency on a cash-positive basis. We  are seeing good levels of tendering activity and visibility of FID for the larger greenfield projects is improving, the  visibility of the FID and the larger greenfield project is improving. Offshore India, the Integrated 98/2 project for  ONGC is expected to be awarded to market in the second half of this year. Offshore Brazil, the Mero 1 project is  anticipated either in Q4 or Q1 and offshore Mozambique, the Golfinho project is likely to be awarded to market in  2019. Conventional project in the Middle East under the LTA with Saudi Aramco remain in focus and we continue  to tender for new awards.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The long-term outlook for EPCI project in Renewables and Heavy Lifting is positive with tenders ongoing in  Taiwan, Europe and the U.S. So the first of EPCI wind farm project in Taiwan has been awarded to a competitor,  but there are other opportunities in the region that we continue to tender for. In Europe, some of the larger  renewable projects are taking longer than expected to be awarded due to changes in project ownership and  governmental approval schedule, but we are still confident this will come to market in due course.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: To give you some examples, three large EPCI wind farm projects in France and the UK which were initially  planned for execution in late 2019 and are now likely to be developed in 2020, early 2021. We are targeting  transport and installation work to utilize capacity in the near-term, but this will not be sufficient to compensate for  the delayed project. In i-Tech Services, the level of tendering has increased for spot work and the outlook for  utilization is improving. However, there are no large awards expected into market near-term and activity and  pricing remains relatively low.

file: SUBC - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 2November2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: PazFlor, Block 18 GEL and Angola LNG have all completed most of their operation during the quarter. On  PazFlor, through good cooperation between the project teams, the first oil has been achieved ahead of scheduled  to the satisfaction of our client Total. We expect that all remaining commercial discussion on this project will be  finalized in Q4.

texts.speaker: Simon Crowe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Operational delays in some projects in the North Sea during the quarter arising from problems on vessels and  adverse weather have also impacted, resulting in lower than scheduled progress and additional costs.

file: SUBC - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 19November2012 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Gulf of Mexico, we're also starting to see signs of an increase in activity following the recommencement of  award of drilling permit some time ago. We should see more contract award to the market within 2013 and  execution in late 2014 improving business environment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: And finally Brazil, continue to see significant opportunity ahead in traditional deep water in the Campos Basin as  well as with pre-sold developments. In 2013, we expect to see further PLSD contract awards for new-build  contract in both Brazil and internationally built yards, as well as renewal of existing contracts. More large epic  projects for pre-sold developments are likely to come to market award over the next year.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: So in summary, we have seen a continuation of the positive momentum that we talked about in August. The  robust oil price and rising tendering activity around the world reinforces our view that the outlook for our industry  remains positive. We continue to see growth opportunity in all of our markets and we remain focused on building  quality backlog and ensuring that we maintain a disciplined approach from both risk and pricing perspective.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Vessel utilization in 2012 has benefited from particularly high utilization in the North Sea as clients who are  willing to take weather risk in Q1 to complete work carried over from the previous year. 2012 was a bit of catch-up  year for our clients in the North Sea, and it remains to be seen if 2013 will enjoy similarly high Q1 utilization.

file: SUBC - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 18November2013 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: But first, a brief update on the Guará-Lula project. We've been experiencing difficult offshore weather condition  for the last three months during the winter season. The difficult condition had an impact on the buoy installation  operation during the quarter, but this is not a surprise as we had identified this challenge when we talked to you  earlier this year. Our views have not changed in July. We still believe that the full-life project loss previously  announced remains appropriate.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In West Africa, we have seen the long awaited T.E.N. project in Ghana sanctioned and awarded to a consortium  Subsea 7  Technip. We are also seeing a number of project award being delayed for various reason. I will also  mention a potential temporary slowdown in the shallow water conventional market in Nigeria to local  administration's challenges.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Vessel utilization in the North Sea was robust at 92% for the quarter, but lower than the 99% achieved in the third  quarter of 2012. This was due to the cancellation of the Fram project early in the year. In addition, no project  revenue was generated in the territory by the Seven Oceans as it was deployed on the Guará -Lula project during  the quarter.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Australia, progress was made in the preparation for the offshore scope of the Gorgon heavy lift and tie -ins  project which will start in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Lastly, the corporate segment generated net operating income of $24 million in the quarter, compared to a loss of  $1 million in the same period of 2012. The segment benefited from lower administrative expenses and an  improved contribution from the joint venture Seaway Heavy Lifting, which continued to be active in the North Sea  in wind farm installation.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I would also caution that the Seven Oceans, we'd be mobilizing to Africa after Guará-Lula in Brazil and won't be  returning in the North Sea in 2014. The Skandi A cergy which has been active in the North Sea in 2013 will also be  mobilizing to Asia as planned for Gorgon and will not return to NSC in 2014.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I also mentioned earlier the possibility of a temporary slowdown in shallow-water conventional market in Nigeria.  This could mean somewhat less variation orders on existing commercial work, but it's too early to conclude.

file: SUBC - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 12November2014 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net operating income in the North Sea and Canada was adversely impacted by an $11 million provision relating to  lease costs on the building we recently vacated in Norway with the objective of reducing future administration  expenses. Lastly, the Corporate segment had net operating income of $10 million compared to $24 million in the  previous year period. The decline was primarily due to a reduced contribution from the Seaway Heavy Lifting joint  venture, caused mainly by lower renewables activity in the period.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Let's turn now to slide 13. The uncertainty of further timing of market awards on SURF  project that we have been speaking about all year continued in the third quarter. The oil price weakness that we  experienced throughout the third quarter adds to the uncertainty.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: While we are cautious on the near-term outlook for this territory, we should bear in mind that the longer-term  prospects remain good, particularly for development in the harsher climates of Norway and Eastern Canada.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to slide 18, I would like to provide you with some tangible examples of leading technology we are  employing on major projects. It's clearly a differentiator for us. We are proud of track record in utilizing advanced  technology solution developed by us to help our clients achieve more competitive projects. As mentioned, we are  currently completing the Guará-Lula project where we're installing the last Steel Catenary Risers. This riser  includes the first reeled installation of Bubi mechanically lined pipe. But that doesn't stop there. We are also going  to be installing this pipe on the complex Aasta Hansteen development in North Norway in 2015. In both of these  examples the installation of the pipelines and risers, utilizing this technology, has been a key driver in the  commercial viability of the developments. We continue to work in collaboration with BUTTING to further develop  this pipe for reeled installation including high-strength steel options for ultra-deep water and higher pressure  application.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In addition to the increasing demand for corrosion resistant pipeline, the more significant technology requirement  for the development of the complex reservoirs encountered today is the requirement for high performance Pipe- in-Pipe solution. This includes the requirement to heat the product, and our efficient electrically heated-traced  flow line technology offers one of the most thermally efficient pipeline systems. We are offering this technology on  the last project we are tendering in West Africa and really believe that this technology is key for the commercial  viability of the project.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And our Seaway Heavy Lifting Joint Venture installed the largest float-over wind-farm topside substation in 2014,  which is an example of technology developed in the oil and gas industry being successfully applied to the  renewable energy sector by our associate – Subsea 7, our partners with SHL.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now regarding 2015, we are in discussion with our clients to understand their views on the impact of the recent  drop of the oil price. We feel that some of them are still assessing this new situation. Uncertainties on timing of  project awards to market we continue during the first quarter of the year in 2015 and in 2016. We note that the  market has projected a revenue decline for $0.57 in 2015. We have similar view.

file: SUBC - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 11November2015 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at the Northern Hemisphere and Life of Field business in more detail, several projects made significant  progress in the quarter. In the UK, the Montrose and Catcher projects completed offshore activities for 2015, and  the Mariner project made good progress with high levels of offshore activity supported from our offices in both  Stavanger and Aberdeen. In Norway, the Aasta Hansteen project completed all major fabrication, and on the  Gullfaks project, we completed trenching. In the Gulf of Mexico, the Heidelberg project was successfully  completed, and work commenced on the Stones project for Shell. Life of Field activity remained low particularly in  the North Sea.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the Southern Hemisphere and Global Projects Business Unit, Seven Borealis commenced pipe lay activity on  the TEN project in Ghana, and the Exxon's Erha North project in Nigeria was substantially completed with first  order achieved in September. The Lianzi SURF and Topside projects in Angola are almost complete with  umbilicals installed and flow lines prepared on schedule.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I would also like to give you an update on our 550-ton class new-build PLSV, Seven Rio. In April this year, we  signed a two-year contract for Seven Seas with Petrobras. However, this vessel had already been allocated to work  on the Stones project in the Gulf of Mexico.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We agreed with Petrobras earlier this year, but in order to make Seven Seas available, the new-build Seven Rio  would work on the Stones project before mobilizing to Brazil to start her five-year PLSV contract.
