Towards the end  of the quarter, Seven Rio joined our fleet, and she will transit to Brazil once the work in the Gulf of Mexico has  been completed.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking ahead to next year, we expect the environment to remain challenging with lower levels of offshore activity  and fewer projects progressing to their offshore phase. With few and large projects reaching completion in 2016, it  is unlikely that the financial benefits of good execution, risk mitigation and commercial closeouts will be as  significant as we have seen so far in 2015.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our cost reduction program is on track to deliver approximately $550 million of annual cost savings, but we do  not expect this fully to compensate for the decline in activity. As the result, our guidance for 2016 is for both  revenue and adjusted EBITDA percentage margin to decrease significantly compared to 2015.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I will now pass you back to Jean to comment further on our continuing cost reduction measures, our initiatives in  response to the current market and our outlook.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Moving to slide 16, we have taken a number of steps to ensure Subsea 7 can develop and  strengthen through the downturn and be ready to take the opportunity to grow when market activity recovers. We  were only to recognize the pressure on project returns for our clients and started to reorganize and downsize our  capacity in 2014 with the result that when the oil price halved last year, we had already embarked on the changes  necessary to lower our cost.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to slide 18. Our line objectives to lower the project cost are changing the way we are working with  our clients. We are engaging earlier, collaborating more, and being increasingly open with each other. This will  drive solution that facilitate project function at lower oil prices.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have signed a similar arrangement with Premier last week. It covers early-stage engineering and CapEx, OpEx  and decommissioning activities in the UK, Southern Atlantic and Norway. With MOL, we also have an agreement  to work together on their North Sea requirements.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: To sum up on slide 19, I would like to offer some comments on the outlook. The market remained depressed as a  result of sustained low oil price. The tendering activity is competitive and the timing of new awards to market  continues to be uncertain. In the Northern Hemisphere, there are few short-term new opportunities in the North  Sea and it has been particularly impacted by the downturn due to the structurally high development cost. This has  also impacted our Life of Field business as clients hold back on non-urgent maintenance expenditure.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the Southern Hemisphere, the timing of last project award is still very difficult to predict, but the number of  project are expected to progress in 2016. These are mostly gas projects, particularly for domestic markets as these  are less affected by the oil price.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Altogether, we have listed some of the active market opportunities which include Bonga South West, Coral FLNG,  Rotan, Golfinho, Vashishta and West Nile Delta phase 2.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So to conclude, times are challenging, but we are acting on what we can control. I strongly believe that the  initiatives that we started to take as early as 2014, combined with our proactive cost reduction measures, would  allow us to navigate through the downturn while building a stronger company for when the business environment  improves. We are concentrating on finding cost-effective solutions which enable our clients to progress with  deepwater field development. We have already identified significant savings and with collaboration with our  clients and suppliers, we can deliver more.

file: SUBC - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 10November2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning first to the highlights on slide 4. We have delivered another quarter of strong operational and financial  performance in a business environment, which remains challenging due to this difficult downturn in oil and gas  investments.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: During the quarter, we took delivery of our new-build PLSV, Seven Sun, which has since commenced its long- term contract for Petrobras. Normand Seven was returned to its owner at the end of its contract and we sold  Seven Petrel to a buyer outside the oil and gas industry. Including vessels that are stacked or under construction,  we have a total fleet of 36 vessels, 8 lower than at the peak of 2014.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Looking ahead over the next 18 months, we believe that the better oil price and continued progress on  sustainable cost reductions could drive more project awards to the market.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: On the Aasta Hansteen project, we have concluded our third offshore campaign with all flowlines and control  cables connected, readies for the final hook-up with the topside when it arrives in 2018. Aasta Hansteen is the  deepest development in the Norwegian Sea to-date and involves the world's largest SPAR platform.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore UK, we have been installing the riser system on the Catcher project and bundled installation for Premier.  This riser system was challenging and required an innovative buoy system. The riser system comprised 10  flexibles and 3 umbilicals, supported by three mid-water arches, one of which you can see on here on the slide. It  was installed by our crews on the Normand Seven over two campaigns lasting 80 days. Our work on this project  is due to complete in 2017 with hook-up and commissioning, which involves an extended diving company.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The phasing of our backlog was altered somewhat compared to the last quarter due to the scheduling of work on  the Beatrice Wind Farm project. Approximately two-thirds of the revenue related to this project is now expected to  be recognized in 2017.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our Corporate business unit includes renewables and our share of Seaway Heavy Lifting's net income. It also  includes the operating and depreciation charges pertaining to our stacked vessels. This business unit contributed  revenue of $30 million in the quarter. This increase in revenue compared to the prior year was due to the  commencement of the $1.3 billion Beatrice Wind Farm project, which was awarded earlier this year.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Firstly, our margin has been boosted by our prompt action on costs. We began to reduce the size of our workforce  in 2014 as our clients were already highlighting the need for savings even before the oil price started to fall. We  have implemented two major cost reduction and resizing programs; one in 2015, promising $550 million of  annualized savings; and one in 2016, with another $350 million in expected annualized savings.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In August, we announced the acquisition of Swagelining. We have worked with Swagelining for a number of  years. In the last few years, we have installed over 150 kilometers of water injection pipes in the North Sea with  Swagelining's polymer lining, the most recent case being the Maria project for Wintershall. It's our belief that we  can introduce this technology to projects worldwide. In addition to its existing commercial application to lower the  cost and improve corrosion resistance of water injection pipes, we have the opportunity to develop this technology  for future application in production pipelines.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The reaction of our clients have been positive, with high levels of interest leading to [ph] Subsea's (22:35)  opportunities to investigate the potential application of an integrated solution. From this subsea engagement, we  have already carried out eight paid early engineering studies, delivering detailed analysis of the subsea  architecture and installation, and we expect project awards in the near future.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to partnership on slide 18. As a specialized contractor concentrated on offshore oil and gas, we can  get closer to our clients and be more flexible in our approach than larger conglomerate service providers. Our  growing collection of client-partnership agreement is evidence of this. We have formed collaborative long-term  arrangement with several clients to engage early and help them to find the right solution for their field  development needs.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 19. The near term outlook remains challenging and the timing of new awards to market is  uncertain. However, the rise in the price of oil and lower project costs have encouraged our clients to review their  future projects. Assuming that these factors can be sustained, there is cause to believe in an increase of awards  to market within the next 18 months. We do not expect a V-shaped recovery and are prepared for a slow climb  back to more normal levels of activity.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: As illustrated by this list, some offshore areas are more favorable for near term development than others. We  continue to see momentum on projects to develop gas for domestic consumption, we have already captured  significant work offshore Egypt, and we are now looking towards India for the next wave of large development  projects including block 98/2 and KG-D6.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We have not yet included in our list any new EPIC projects offshore Brazil; expanding remains uncertain. Brazil  has potentially low project breakevens due to the high production of the pre-salt fields. And we have a long track  record of working offshore Brazil and look forward to engaging with our clients when the opportunities arise.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We remain active in renewables and heavy lift services mostly through our joint venture company, Seaway Heavy  Lifting. There are a number of substantial renewable energy awards to market expected in 2017 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: To conclude, we are doing what is needed to remain strong and competitive in this challenging market. The  industry-wide challenges in development costs and rebalancing of oil supply and demand are enabling some  projects to move forward towards final investment decision.

file: SUBC - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 9November2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Starting on page 4 of the presentation. We have achieved another quarter of strong execution and continued cost  discipline in all three of our business units, and this was reflected in our group results. Our revenue of $1.1 billion  was 15% higher than the same period last year, driven by renewables activity; in particular, the Beatrice wind  farm project.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 5. We have illustrated some of the projects that has contributed to our performance. Offshore  Egypt, we made good progress on the West Nile Delta Phase Two project for BP. In the third quarter, we  completed the shore approach, installation of three pipelines. The shallow water installation was carried out using  Seven Antares and followed most of engineering and preparation.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Also, in the North Sea, the Western Isles project for Dana was substantially completed. This project was awarded  in 2012, but with the significant portion of the scope delayed to 2017 due to the timing of the FPSO arrival. Since  2012, we have designed and fabricated two Pipeline Bundles, managed the design and fabrication of 2 mid-water  arches and installed 11 risers.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore Australia, our i-Tech Services business reached the final stage of EPRS, Emergency Pipeline Repair  System project. The system is ready to deploy solution involving several technologies developed by i-Tech  Services that enables an expedient terminal repair to different types of pipeline damage, minimizing production  shutdown of the operator.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In our Renewables and Heavy Lifting, the Beatrice project made good progress. All the 84 sets of profiles have  been fabricated, and by quarter end, 78 sets have been installed. During August and September, the heavy lift  vessel, Oleg Strashnov, installed the first 24 steel foundation jacket. This is 37th largest ever project in the North  Sea and our largest ever project in renewables.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 6. We reported backlog of $5.3 billion at the end of September. During the third quarter, we were  awarded $538 million of renewables and escalations. We announced the award of $250 million, relating to the  expansion of three long-term direct contract for PLSVs offshore Brazil. This took our PLSV backlog to $1.5 billion  at quarter end. Over 90% of this fits with the [indiscernible] (07:57) vessels that joined our fleet since 2014.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: On the last day of the quarter, the Fortuna project was awarded by [ph] OFEG (08:07) to Subsea Integration  Alliance. Our alliance with OneSubsea Schlumberger enabled us to offer the client with fully integrated solution  benefiting from our combined expertise and technology. This project is substantial in size at between $150 million  to [ph] $300 million (08:26) for the combined [indiscernible] (08:28) but only the expected Subsea 7 share of the  revenue was reported in our backlog. Unannounced project included smaller SURF awards in the North Sea and  U.S. Gulf of Mexico, various awards for i-Tech services and the six station installation award for Renewables and  Heavy Lifting.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Jean, and good afternoon, everyone. I will begin on slide 7 with the key highlights from our income  statement. Third quarter revenue of $1.063 billion was up 15% from the prior-year period as the increase in  revenue from our renewables business more than offset the declines in our revenues from SURF and i-Tech  services.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting revenue was $232 million, mostly related to the Beatrice project, which progressed  well with pile and jacket installation in the quarter. Net operating income was $45 million. Year-on-year  performance reflects the consolidation of Seaway Heavy Lifting, which was equity accounted for in 2016, prior to  the acquisition of the remaining 50% interest in March 2017.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I move now to slide 11. It's been 4 months since we acquired EMAS Chiyoda Subsea or ECS from Chapter 11. In  that time, we have started work on the project. So, we're already in the ECS backlog, and so far, they have  progressed as expected. We are in the process of integrating the 1,000 people approximately that have joined us  from ECS, helping to align them with our values and processes. We've integrated Lewek Champion into our fleet.  We have it on a long-term charter for conventional work in the Middle East and are in the process of renaming it  Seven Champion. We have a short term charter in place for the Lewek Constellation, which is working on the  OCTP SURF and TVEX projects, and we will return this vessel to its owner early next year.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thirdly, we have acquired [ph] phenomenal (16:54) consideration, the remaining shares in our Normand Oceanic  joint venture. This transaction was completed on October 31 and brings the heavy construction and flex-lay  vessel, the Normand Oceanic, into our fleet as a fully-owned asset.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Turning now to slide 14. Our strategy is founded on providing a differentiated service and  working with our clients as a long-term partner for the creation, development, maintenance, and eventually  decommissioning of their asset. We are differentiated by our skilled and experienced people, our innovation and  technology, and our well-developed fleet of vessels. These trends are complemented by our alliance and  partnership and our local presence in all the major offshore markets. We are helping to transform our industry with  integrated solutions and new technology that deliver the step-change in cost and productivity. We have invested  in our capability and the line capacity to meet our client's need and executed well. This has helped us to win work,  as well as make better returns on the projects that we were awarded before the oil price decline.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Subsea 7 had installed over 80 pipeline bundles. The same patented, controlled two installation method that we  use for bundles can be used to install large subsea structures. Many recent project have been based on our cost  effective bundle solutions, including Western Isles, Catcher, Callater, and Montrose. We are working to develop  and commercialize new cost effective pipeline materials for using offshore oil and gas field.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: For example, higher trend steel can reduce pipeline weight and cost. Corrosion resistant alloys and polymer  linings are cost effective integrated solution. And in the future, composite pipe could be used to overcome cost  limitation in [indiscernible] (23:12) developments. Cost-effective provision is not just about the capital investment  of a development. Increasingly, our clients are looking at the total field cost of projects. Our i-Tech services  business is developing better data management system to announce our Life of Field solutions.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We did see some of the active SURF project tenders that we expect to see awarded to the market in the near to  medium term. The most active market today is Norway where several clients are moving ahead with the final  investment decision and project sanction. In particular, we foresee progress on Snorre, Skarfjell, Snadd and  Johan Castberg projects. Larger projects of South Africa are likely to take more time as the Golfinho, Mamba and  Tortue project listed here are not likely to be awarded before mid-2018. Other sizable projects that the market is  waiting for, include the first of the ultra deepwater Libra project of Petrobras and the second phase of the Gorgon  gas project offshore Australia.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We are tendering for several conventional projects in Saudi Arabia under the LTA with Saudi Aramco acquired as  part of the ECS acquisition. We were unable to participate in new tenders while ECS was chapter 11, but we are  quickly catching up on lost time; i-Tech Services is seeing a gradual increase tendering activities in the North Sea,  U.S. Gulf of Mexico, and Asia.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the renewables and heavy lifting market, we continue to build a number of foundation and substation  installation projects in UK, Poland, and Germany, and are tendering foundation opportunities in both U.S. and  Taiwan. Offshore renewable energy is an important area of growth for us, and we remain committed to  strengthening our presence worldwide.

file: SUBC - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 8November2018 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I will begin with our quarter highlights, Ricardo will present our third quarter financial results and I will then  conclude with an update on our renewables strategy and business outlook.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We achieved total vessel utilization of 85%, our highest quarter since 2014. The third quarter is usually our  busiest operationally due to favorable weather condition in the North Sea. However, the weather at Offshore  Germany has been more challenging than expected causing some delays on the Borkum II wind farm project. We  announced four awards in the quarter resulting in $800 million of awards and escalation and book-to-bill ratio of  0.7.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Seven Seas, Seven Pacific and Seven Eagle have finished their campaigns with only Simar Esperança remain in  country to complete her scope. In Australia, the Cooper Sole project has commenced its offshore phase with  Seven Oceans transporting 64 kilometers of 12-inch pipeline. Skandi Acergy will install the associated umbilical  later in the year. The Greater Western Flank project, also in Australia, made good progress too.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We announced the award of the Aerfugl project, Offshore Norway, late last year and also offshore operation do  not done until 2019, good progress has been made in upgrading our [indiscernible] (03:45) base to accommodate  Electrically Heat Traced Flowline, one of the new technologies developed by Subsea 7.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore Germany, the EPCI Borkum II project continued with monopod installation, but progress was hampered  by adverse weather. 17 of the 32 pipes were installed in the quarter with Seven Borealis intervening after the  quarter-end to accelerate operations and mitigate the impact of challenging weather conditions. This is a very  good example of the versatility of the fleet between SURF and Renewables business units which is one of our  competitive advantage.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Offshore UK, the final 6 jackets and 33 inter-array cables were installed on the Beatrice wind farm project, which  was substantially completed in the year. Commercial discussion with our client on this project have also been  successfully completed.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Within our i-Tech Services business unit, good progress was made in the quarter on our Life of Field contract in  the North Sea and Offshore Azerbaijan. One of our technology focus area is on autonomy and remote ROV  operation. Our new onshore pilot centers will be soon operational in Stavanger and Aberdeen. This will enable  offshore ROV operation to be piloted by onshore personnel. It will not only have a significant impact on cost  reduction for our clients, it's also one of the key components of our sustainability program which aims at reducing  emissions and the potential impact of offshore operation on climate change.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The four new projects announced in the third quarter illustrates the wide range of solutions that Subsea 7 can  provide to its clients. The Buzzard Phase 2 project, a bundled solution of Offshore UK was awarded by Nexen.  Also, of the cost of the UK, the Triton Knoll wind farm projects was awarded to Subsea 7's Renewables and  Heavy Lifting business unit. We have also announced the award of a substantial conventional project. However,  due to contractual obligation, we are unable to share any further detail on the award at this time.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Net operating income was $17 million, which included allowances for additional weather-related installation delays  on the Borkum II contract. This adversely impacted profitability of the project and the business unit in the quarter.  A $3 million loss was reported in the corporate business unit.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Capital expenditure of $74 million included a milestone payment of approximately $50 million relating to Seven  Vega, our new reeled pipe lay vessel which is under construction. The vessel is due for delivery early in 2020 in  time to meet the increased demand for reeled pipe lay campaigns already booked in our backlog.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We expect absolute adjusted EBITDA to be lower than 2018 inclusive of the uplift of between $100 million and  $110 million applied to 2019 as a result of the implementation of IFRS 16. The forecast reduced adjusted EBITDA  reflects the impact of lower pricing on projects signed in the downturn and minimal contribution from Renewables  and Heavy Lifting following completion of the batteries and Borkum II projects.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Turning to slide 12, I would like now to provide further insights into our Renewables and  Heavy Lifting business. Offshore wind projects follow similar contracting models of the oil and gas industry. Most  contracts can be categorized as either an engineering, procurement, construction and installation contract, EPCI,  or the transport and installation contract, T&I.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Historically, the predominant model has been T&I, but we expect to see more EPCI contracts in the future. This  quarter, the Beatrice project was substantially completed. This multiyear EPCI project was the largest to be  executed in the North Sea by Subsea 7 at over $1 billion. Its success was confirmed by our clients, achieving first  power as scheduled in July.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We hear from our clients that our ability to project, manage and derisk this last projects, while ensuring on-time  delivery, is one of the key differentiators of Subsea 7 in the renewable market. The outlook for 2019 is  challenging. For various reasons, the last project awards to market have been delayed and we do not currently  expect to be active offshore on any large EPCI renewable project next year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: There are some prospect next year for T&I projects, but we are forecasting much lower revenues compared to  recent years and low EBITDA. As we have shown previously in our oil and gas business, we are proactive and  plan to reduce our capacity in renewables to adapt to this near-term market conditions.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Capacity and cost reduction will be achieved while protecting our capability and expertise. This approach will  position our renewable business well to capture opportunities when the activity increases in the not-too-distant  future, and I remain optimistic regarding medium- and long-term prospects as we are seeing momentum on  projects, in particular in the UK, France and Taiwan.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In our business model, we anticipate signing one large EPCI project every couple of years. The composition of  our reported revenues and profits will fluctuate depending on the type of work we are executing. New EPCI  awards won in 2019 are most likely to be executed offshore before second half of 2020.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to slide 13, the offshore wind market is growing at a healthy pace with double-digit average growth  forecast to Europe and worldwide supported by the lower levelized cost of energy. The 7 megawatts wind turbine  generator, which is the size we installed on the Beatrice field, will be superseded by a 10-megawatt turbine that  will be available to market in a few years, and even larger turbines under developments.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Larger turbine sizes require larger foundations. With a top lifting capacity of 5,000 ton, our fleet is well positioned  to take advantage as the enlarged scale of this turbine foundation differentiating Subsea 7 from our competitors.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I will conclude with a review of our outlook. We have seen continued momentum in tieback projects being  awarded to the markets throughout 2018. Volume is recovering, and we expect this trend to continue in the years  to come. Looking into 2019, larger greenfield market awards are expected to complement this brownfield  development project. Improved utilization will follow 12 to 24 months after these awards when the offshore phases  commence, which will translate into pricing and margin improvements.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In SURF, we have greater visibility on the timing of greenfield awards as invitations tender our receipt. Expected  awards to market include Mero, Sepia and Buzios project Offshore Brazil, SURF Golfinho and Rovuma Offshore  Mozambique, and the Bonga Southwest Project Offshore Nigeria. We also expected award to the market of some  large tiebacks project in 2019 including the Ichthys 2, Scarborough and Julimar project Offshore Australia. We  anticipate the next tranche of commercial projects Offshore Saudi Arabia to be awarded to the market in the next  two quarters.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: To summarize, Subsea 7 is well positioned for the cyclical recovery of the offshore oil and gas market later in  2019 and for the structural growth in offshore renewables. We provide our clients with first-class all-in  engagement and engineering to enable them to take profitable investment decision. We have successful alliance  and partnership to enable us to win more work on a negotiated basis. And our bespoke technology and efficient  cost base enable us to be competitively and win our fair share of markets award.

file: SUBC - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 23February2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Going to the SURF market, robust oil price and rising tendering activity around the world underpins  order book momentum. Execution and activity levels are expected to rise although contracts signed  in more challenging market conditions will impact negatively the Group’s adjusted EBITDA margin  in 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the North Sea, we are seeing renewed activity albeit in a pricing environment for short-term work  will still remain competitive. A number of large SURF contracts in Australia, Brazil, West Africa and  other countries are still expected to come to market award in 2011. The offshore installation phase  of this new project will commence beyond 2011.

file: SUBC - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 16March2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: So, what did happen in 2011? We progressed very well the engineering testing and procurement of the system. We  are pleased that we are building what we set out at the tender stage with full approval from our clients. But we  relied wrongly on the information we had from the authorities regarding the award of the environmental license  for Paraná spool and logistic base. You may remember that we got a preliminary license late 2010. This should  have lead to an automatic award of the final license. It did not happen. So, spooling operation will now be  performed in the Ubu base in 2012 and 2013, but at a higher cost, and with a negative impact on the project  schedule. All that has been including in the losses that we provisioned for in the $50 million.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We are working well with Petrobras to develop the best option. The new executive management of Petrobras, in a  meeting we had in Rio two weeks ago with José Formigli, made very clear that they consider Subsea 7 as one of  the key solution provider for their ambitious subsalt development plans.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Gulf of Mexico, the recommencement of the award of drilling permits should see an increase of activity with  contract award to the market in late 2012 and execution in late 2013 and 2014 in a market which remains  competitive.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning now to Asia-Pacific, this is, as you know, a diverse territory from a geographical perspective. It is a market  which has had high expectations for many years and 2011 saw the award of the first of this large gas-driven project  Australia and Malaysia, I expect it in 2012 in a market, which remains competitive. We will remain selective on  the project we tender to ensure that we achieve the right returns.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Brazil, we continue to see more opportunities ahead. In traditional deepwater in the Campos Basin as well as  with pre-salt developments. We expect to see further PLSV contracts award to the markets both for existing  contract renewal and new vessels to be built in Brazil. More largely, big project for pre-salt developments are  likely to come to award – to the market in 2012 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We have in house today the next pre-salt tender which covers up to four fields. This is expected to be awarded to  the industry in the second part of 2012 with operation in 2014 and 2015. After which, a further run and tenders for  the next pre-salt development is expected to be issued by the client in late 2012. We believe that the buoy system  that we have designed for Guará-Lula and the experience acquired on this project positions us well to submit  competitive proposal with a right margin and acceptable risk level.

file: SUBC - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14March2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We also made significant progress on our fleet enhancement program. The highlight was the addition to the fleet  of the Seven Borealis for SURF operation. She was delivered on budget and on schedule to start operation on the  CLOV project offshore Angola. She had already completed the first phase of project pipe-laying scope with six  lines installed in 1,400 meter water depth.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In Corporate, there was a positive contribution driven by high activity level at Seaway Heavy Lifting, which was  active on the 20 more offshore wind farm. Brazil, in contrast, incurred a net operating loss. We increased the  estimated project-life loss on Guará-Lula by approximately $52 million. This was driven by two main factors.  First, the commercial dispute with our clients, which emerged during the last quarter; and revised contingency to  take into account risk associated with the timing of delivery from some of our subsea equipment suppliers.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: One trend to highlight is a growing importance of technology in these new awards. We are one of the key  technology leaders in the subsea industry and our ability to develop and implement new technologies plays the  key role in contract awards. For example, the Aasta Hansen project will see the first installation of the steel  catenary risers and the first real installation of mechanically lined pipe in the North Sea.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Asia Pacific performed strongly, in large part, due to our Malaysian joint ventures, while the Corporate segment  made a positive contribution, as restructuring costs declined and Seaway Heavy Lifting experienced high activity  in wind farm installations in the Irish Sea.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I would like now to provide some additional color on the outlook. Slide 13. Levels of tendering remain strong with  improved pricing. Structural driver means that the offshore oil and gas CapEx is likely to increase over the  medium and long term and we should be well positioned to benefit.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Seven Oceans will be transferring from the North Sea to Brazil in 2013, where she will operate on the Guará- Lula project. This redeployment will reduce the available Subsea 7 fleet in the North Sea. Q1 results will also be  impacted by a number of planned dry-docks.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Finally, in Brazil, we expect tendering activity to high, but Brazil remains a challenging environment.  Our Brazilian business is in two parts. We have the flexible PLSV business and EPIC and lump-sum projects,  which are largely driven by Petrobras' pre-salt development. Starting my comments with the PLSV, it's mainly a  day-rate business with limited project execution risk. We expect this market to grow in the coming years as  Petrobras needs more vessels for flexible pipe installation, both for their pre-salt and post-salt projects.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: On the riser system, the pipe production in Germany is complete, and coating is under way in Brazil. Our  spoolbase at Ubu is ready to commence production of the riser system in early Q2.

file: SUBC - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 5March2014 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In terms of remaining milestone, the third buoy is expected to be installed by the end of Q1 and a fourth buoy in  Q2. In fact, we are presently lowering the third buoy on the field. The offshore  phase of the riser installation is  currently anticipated to be completed by Q4 2014. All this is consistent with the revised plan agreed with  Petrobras.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The additional full-life project loss provision of $49 million was due largely to the decision to mob ilize an extra  vessel in 2014 on the project to accelerate project execution during the Brazilian summer season. It also takes into  account the updated riser installation schedule for the Seven Oceans that we have discussed with Petrobras. While  all our focus is on mitigating the chance of further delay on the projects, risk remain until the offshore phase of the  project is fully completed.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In NSC, we executed a broad range of SURF projects as well as Life -of-Field work. In the UK sector, the Otter  project was completed and in the Norwegian sector, the Knarr and Oseberg Delta S2 projects progressed well. In  Canada, we completed the Terra Nova project. Life-of-Field work for a range of clients continued apace in spite of  challenging weather conditions. We're also well underway with the project management, engineering and  procurement phases of the Martin Linge, Aasta Hansteen, Western Isles and Montrose projects.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Capital expenditures in 2014 are expected to be higher than 2013, ranging between $900 million and $1 billion,  primarily as a result of payments due on the six vessels we currently have under construction. Further multiyear  guidance on our vessel newbuild program is provided on Slide 15 and you will note that it is expected to wind  down significantly by 2016.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our diverse portfolio of business and resources should ensure another strong year in the North Sea, but  it should  be remembered that the Seven Oceans and the Skandi Acergy will be deployed outside of the territories  throughout 2014, which has an impact on territory revenue. We recently won an award for work on the Hebron  Field offshore Canada that we will manage from our [ph] St. John's, Newfoundland office.

file: SUBC - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4March2015 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As a result, adjusted diluted earnings per share was $0.61, up from $0.23 in 2013. The goodwill on our balance  sheet resulting from the combination in 2011 was impaired by $1.2 billion in the quarter due to  the change in  near-term outlook for the oil service industry resulting from the lower oil price. This non-cash, non-recurring  impairment charge is excluded from our adjusted EBITDA and adjusted earnings per share.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, we successfully completed the offshore phase of Guará-Lula offshore Brazil in the fourth  quarter with the last of the 27 risers installed in December. Only low-risk final commissioning work is left to  complete in 2015. The project demonstrated successfully the application of new technology with our innovative,  cost-effective riser design and reef corrosion-resistant pipe. Petrobras is very satisfied with the final results.  Setting aside the overall financial outcome, we are proud of the turnover achieved by the project team in 2014,  enabling the release of $100 million provision through the year as the project has been substantially de -risked.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to our backlog on slide eight, we ended the year with $8.2 billion of secured orders in our backlog, down  from record levels at the start of the year, reflecting the deterioration in market condition compounded by the  collapse in oil price.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our reported annual net operating loss of $254 million included $89 million in asset impairment charges taken in  the fourth quarter relating primarily to Seven Polaris and some mobile equipment. Income from joint ventures  was down in the year, and notably low in the fourth quarter as a result of lower activity levels particularly for  Seaway Heavy Lifting following a downturn in offshore wind farm installation project.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So let's turn to slide 21. I would like to offer some comments on the market condition we are experiencing today.  In late 2013, we identified the softening of the market as our clients look to reduce the cost of new field  development. This trend continued throughout 2014 and accelerated in the second half of the year as the oil price  fell to around half its level at the peak. This fall in the oil price has introduced a new period of unce rtainty for the  Subsea sector and our ability to help our clients find cost effective solutions is key to winning new work.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are not anticipating a near-term improvement and our plan for the near- or medium-term are based on this  assumption. That said, the long-term fundamentals for the development of deepwater oil and gas reserve remain  intact and we will protect our cost trends to stay differentiated and drive outperformance when the market  environment improves.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As set out on slide 23, we have already taken action on our cost base. We identified the softening of the market in  late 2013. Since that time, we have taken decision to reduce our head count in Brazil and No rway and, as a result,  we have around 500 fewer people in these two locations combined. This alone with other restructuring effort  worldwide has reduced our overall head count to around 13,000 people by year -end from 14,000 in 2013. We will  continue to adapt our organization on a country-by-country basis to suit lower levels of activity triggered by the  lower oil price environment.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on to the near-term outlook on slide 24. We continue to see tendering activity for new contracts, and there  are some major projects that we expect to be awarded in the market this year. However, the timing of awards to  the market remains highly uncertain, and we continue to see delays to final investment decision driven by the  present low and volatile oil price.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Life of Field activity has been steady as there is no change to the outlook. Our reputation for safe and reliable  execution is a competitive advantage and our new organizational structure will help us to expand this offering into  new geographies. The outlook for conventional shallow water activities is moderate with the Satellite Phase 2 field  offshore Nigeria still expected to be awarded late this year. Finally, the outlook of our largest two joint ventures,  SapuraAcergy and Seaway Heavy Lifting remain subdued.

file: SUBC - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2March2016 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I'll first start with the 2015 highlights on slide 4. We delivered a very good operational and good financial results  in a very difficult market with declining levels of industry activity as our clients reduced expenditure due to the  low oil price.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Returning to operational performance on slide 6. We executed well and draw significant progress on complex  projects in both hemisphere in the fourth quarter. Offshore Norway, the Gullfaks project, which included the  installation of the first wet gas compressor [indiscernible] (5:25), was substantially completed and the Maria  project progressed as per plan with engineering and procurement. In the Gulf of Mexico, the newly built PLSV  Seven Rio successfully installed umbilicals on the Stones project and has subsequently commenced a day -rate  work under its long-term contract for Petrobras offshore Brazil.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Also, offshore Brazil, the BC-10 project made significant progress. Offshore Angola, the Lianzi SURF project was  substantially completed using leading-edge technology to install the world's deepest electrically heated pipeline.  So, Lianzi Topside conventional project is also near completion.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Life of Field Business experienced reduced offshore activity levels compared to the fourth quarter 2014,  reflecting the prevailing market conditions. Our joint venture, Seaway Heavy Lifting, reported an increase in  contribution compared to the fourth quarter 2014 due to higher activity both in oil and gas and renewable  projects.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, we recognized the partial impairment of goodwill which has resulted from the combination  in 2011. This impairment was in response to the low oil price environment and lower -for-longer market outlook.  The $521 million non-cash charge did not impact our adjusted EBITDA but affected our net operating income and  net income figures, as well as earnings per share. Excluding the impairment, we generated net operating income  of $665 million, net income of $484 million, and adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.45 in 201 5. Slide 10  provides more detail behind the income statement.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Using slide 13, I'd like to reflect on the changes to our cost base in 2015. Our operating expenses are  approximately one-third lower than the prior year, as we optimize costs across all our operations worldwide and  the mix of our work changed as we completed projects. Our procurement and direct project costs in 2015 were  $1.6 billion, approximately 40% below the prior-year figure as we targeted supply chain efficiencies and some of  the large projects we were executing came to a close. This downward trend is expected to continue in 2016, albeit  at a slower pace, as the proportion of EPIC projects in our workload reduces.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Slide 19 summarizes our view of the outlook for 2016. Low oil and gas price continue to  depress industry activity. The outlook for awards to the market is uncertain and clients delay new projects. Some  medium and smaller projects are still achieving final investment decision particularly where substantial cost  savings have been identified by early engagement and new ways of working. Timing of sanction for large SURF  projects is more uncertain.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Conventional and Hook-up segments offshore West Africa is expected to continue to suffer low activity levels  in 2016, and we have taken steps to minimize our local cost base until activity resumes. Life of Field and i-Tech  experienced lower levels of activity in 2015, and this is expected to persist in 2016. Our Seaway Heavy Lifting joint  venture had a good end to 2015 and we see some potential for renewables activity in the North Sea. In Asia, our  joint venture SapuraAcergy has limited prospect for new awards in the near term.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to slide 23, we formed two strategic alliance with leading industry partners in 2015. Both alliances  provide a framework for long-term collaboration. We believe this alliance strengthen our competitive position and  enable us to deliver sustainable improvements in the economics of deepwater oil and gas projects. We do not  claim to have a silver bullet cure for the challenges our industry is facing. But by working together to jointly serve  our clients, we can unlock new solutions that substantially reduce the cost of production.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our concept engineering and FEED alliance with KBR and its subsidiary Granherne combine the best-in-class  engineering capability with our technology, engineering and installation expertise. Together, we have a market - leading offering in early engagement. We are already working together on several concepts and FEED studies  where early engagement significantly improve these cost efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Collaboration brings mutual benefits by driving down cost and developing better solution through early  engagement. As a result of this approach, today, we are working on the FEED at the Premier Sea Lions project in  the Falklands.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Slide 25 illustrates our strategic technology programs. We have delivered technology adv ances in a number of  areas in 2015, such as Electrical Heat-Traced Flowline, high-pressure/high-temperature Bundles, automatic  welding, and ultrasonic inspection technology. We have been laying bundles for over 35 years but our technology  had not stood still. In 2015, we qualified a high-temperature/high-pressure Bundle solution and also developed a  new low-friction model components to reduce manufacturing costs.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Life of Field, our technology team have been adapting ultrasonic and imaginary technology d eveloped to  inspect aircraft frames for stress and faults to support IMR work on subsea pipelines. The result is reduced in - water time and quick and simple imaginary internal coercions and cracks without extensive training or equipment  thereby saving time and money. We will continue to invest through the cycle to develop new enabling and cost  reducing innovation which will help our clients address key subsea development challenges.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to slide 26. In conclusion, the environment for our industry is very challenging, even more challenging  than it was four months ago. We can't influence the oil price, but we can move decisively and proportionally to  strengthen our place in the top tier and help our clients to find new ways to make project work at a lower cost  despite the headwinds we all face. The fundamental long-term outlook for deepwater oil and gas remains strong,  and activity is expected to recover when the market rebalances. We are proactively building on our capacity, on  our capability and adapting to industry conditions while staying focused on our strategic priorities.

file: SUBC - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 2March2017 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Order intake in the year was $3.4 billion, 0.9 times revenue reported for 2016. Our cost competitiveness,  innovative technology and track record of good execution allowed us to capture a significant share of the market.  Even so, SURF order intake was significantly lower than in 2015 reflecting the cyclical downturn in offshore oil  and gas activity.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our largest award was in renewables for the development of the Beatrice offshore wind farm project. We are  delivering this together with Seaway Heavy Lifting, our joint venture company which operates two specialist heavy  lift vessels. The Beatrice projects affirms our presence in the growing offshore renewable energy market. It relies  on the expertise of Seaway Heavy Lifting, which are significant transport and installation experience, having  previously installed several hundred wind turbine foundations.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning now to slide 7. Industry conditions remain challenging. Operators and suppliers have taken measure to  adapt to lower oil and gas prices developing more cost effective solutions and reducing capacity. By taking strong  action to reduce our costs and engaging early with our clients, we were able to maintain a strong performance  through the downturn while protecting our capability and grow our competitive position.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The oil price has achieved a degree of stability in recent months as it has helped our clients to move forward with  some project sanctions based on sustainable low cost solution we have helped to design. There is evidence of  positive momentum on offshore projects, and our conversation with clients give us cause to believe that SURF  projects awards to the market could increase within the next 12 months.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 9 summarizes our business unit outlook. We are actively tendering a number of SURF projects. It remains a  very competitive market, but we have a strong offering and our discipline on the right project risk profile hasn't  changed. The award listed on this slide represents some of the largest and most likely awards to the market, but  timing of this remains uncertain. Domestic gas projects and tie-back developments remains the mostly likely  projects to proceed near term.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our i-Tech Services Business Unit continues to expand its footprint, it's tendering for frame agreements in Angola,  Brazil and the U.S. Gulf of Mexico as well as maintaining its market-leading presence in the North Sea. We  continue to look for the diversification in offshore renewables and our joint venture company, Seaway Heavy  Lifting remains very competitive in this sector.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I will talk more about our vision for renewables later on, but now I will hand over to Ricardo to discuss the 2016  financial performance in more detail.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I will now turn to slide 13 to cover the fourth quarter performance for each business unit, excluding the goodwill  impairment charge in both 2016 and 2015. Fourth quarter revenue was $932 million, down 9% compared to the  prior year period. 2016 revenue included $142 million revenue from our Corporate segment, which was mainly  related to the Beatrice wind farm project. This project will continue to have a significant impact on our results in  2017 and 2018 with a further $1.1 billion of backlog due to be executed over that period.

texts.speaker: Ricardo H. Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: At the start of 2017, we made a binding offer to acquire the remaining 50% ownership interest in Seaway Heavy  Lifting which, if accepted, will increase our presence in the growing renewables and heavy lifting markets. This  week, we committed to providing some debtor-in-possession financing for EMAS CHIYODA Subsea as it  commenced its Chapter 11 proceedings. There's a secured loan with limited downside risk. By participating in this  vein, Subsea 7 is able to explore more value-adding opportunities. Subsea 7 has not taken an equity position and  does not have any operational exposure to the contracts being delivered by ECS in the subsea market.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 23 illustrates the importance we place on technology and innovation. Subsea 7 owns one of the largest and  more recent group of patents in our market segment. Being first to market with a new concept, can give us a  competitive edge of first mover advantage that over time can be converted into order intake and better margins.  We have concentrated our investment in five strategic programs which are compelling commercial advantages.  An example of this is our strategic investment in pipeline technologies which has led the development of  Electrically Heat Traced Flowlines to enable longer tie-backs.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 24 details our investments in our fleets. Subsea 7 has a modern and diverse fleet of vessels. The scale,  capability and versatility of our fleet is a competitive advantage. It enable us to meet our clients' needs more  efficiently and effectively. To retain our competitive advantage and to meet the evolving needs of deepwater and  harsh environment activity, we have invested in the addition of six new vessels. This program of investment  started in 2012 and was completed in January 2017. It cost us $1.8 billion (sic) [$1.9 billion] (31:45) which is lower  than the original guidance as a result of good project management and commercial discipline.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 25. We operate in a dynamic industry. One of the fastest growing and developing offshore energy  sector is renewable energy. We have been working with clients on wind farm foundation for many years. Our joint  venture, Seaway Heavy Lifting, owns two specialist vessels that meet the rising wind needs – [indiscernible]  (32:16). And last year, 95% of its revenue come from wind farm installations.

texts.speaker: Jean P. Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our alliance with OneSubsea has gained momentum during the year. Our teams are working well together and  our clients are interested in the combined solution we have been proposing. Our Subsea Integration Alliance was  awarded its first SPS and SURF Integrated EPIC award in 2016, and we are presently competing on a number of  other integrated tenders.

file: SUBC - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 1March2018 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I shall start with our highlights for the year on slide 4. We reported the $1 billion revenue for the fourth quarter.  Our full-year revenue was almost $4 billion, 12% higher than the prior year helped by the increase in activity in  renewables. Fourth quarter net operating income was $28 million, with $581 million for the full year. As expected,  our adjusted EBITDA margin of 26% was lower year-on-year. This reflected fewer projects in the final stage of  completion, lower offshore activity levels, and reduced pricing on project awarded in the downturn. These  headwinds will continue to affect us in 2018.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 5 shows some of our recent projects. In the first quarter, the Atoll project was substantially completed  helping BP to achieve first gas seven months ahead of schedule. And we made good progress on the West Nile  Delta GFR Project both offshore Egypt. We also completed the Maria project offshore Norway delivering a highly  cost effective solution for a client base on a more flexible and efficient agreement for project management.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our major renewable project, Beatrice Offshore Windfarm progressed with fabrication and installation. 33 of the  84 jackups were installed by the end of December. I-Tech Services performed well with Life of Field projects and  some agreements.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, we saw an increase in awards offshore Norway. Statoil awarded the Snorre project, which  renewed our proprietary Pipeline Bundle technology, and we announced the Skogul and Aerfugl project for Aker  BP. Aerfugl is the first project to use our Electrically Heat Traced Flowline technology, which we expect to install  using our new-build rigid reel-lay vessel.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In addition to the $5.2 billion backlog reported as at the end of the year, we were awarded the Johan Castberg  project with Statoil in January. And earlier this week, we were awarded the Nova project by Wintershall. The Nova  project uses Swagelining's integrated liner system, which is a highly cost-effective, anti-corrosion pipeline  technology. Both the Nova and Johan Castberg projects are located offshore Norway and the awards will be  included in our 2018 first quarter order intake.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 8. Many of our clients have published data showing the improvement in project portfolio  breakeven cost. Project values are sometime less than half that earlier estimate for the same fields. Since the fall  in oil price, our industry has implemented many change to drive down costs, most of which are sustainable for the  long-term.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We have identified six main drivers of lower projects costs. These six main drivers are as follow: Our clients are  engaging earlier, enabling the introduction of latest technology and integrated solution. This is also an opportunity  to optimize full lifecycle cost of the field with solution that optimize total expense, including maintenance and  decommissioning costs.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Second point is closer collaboration with suppliers and clients is helping to lower the risk profile and reduce the  time to first oil and gas. Our partnership with Aker BP has been particularly effective in this regard. We are also  seeing strong evidence from Subsea Integration Alliance that SURF and SPS collaboration can substantially  lower the project cost.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: There is no strong sign that the prices are recovering yet. But with rising activity, we expect a gradual margin  improvement. Our industry has successfully adapted to and remain competitive in the lower oil price environment.  These six drivers have all contributed to sustaining the long-term future of offshore oil and gas project in a market  that is challenged by cheaper alternative source of supply. However, we believe the margin pressure and supply  chain deflation would largely reverse over time.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Jean, and good afternoon, everyone. Slide 9 shows the highlights from our income statement. Fourth  quarter revenue was $1 billion, taking the full-year 2017 to $4 billion, up 8% and 12% respectively compared to  2016. This was mainly due to additional conventional activity following the acquisition of ECS in June and an  increase in the renewables activity as we executed the Beatrice Windfarm project.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting reported a net operating loss of $3 million in the quarter. This was due to the  scheduling of future activities on the Beatrice project with additional costs booked in the quarter for which the  related revenues cannot yet be recognized. In 2016, SHL was equity accounted for so the prior-year performance  is not directly comparable.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Procurement costs are a function of the volume, mix and phasing of our activities. In 2017, we saw a $700 million  increase in our procurement costs largely related to our renewables business. Our depreciation and amortization  costs were $51 million higher than in 2016, reflecting the arrival of new vessels in our fleet.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thirdly, our EBITDA margin is impacted by our mix of work and the market environment at the time the contract is  awarded. At the top of the cycle before the oil price fell in 2014, there was more demand for our services than  there was supply, and this was reflected in the value of the awards at the time. In contrast, the scarcity of awards  in the last three years has led to increasing price competition to secure work. On certain projects, we may accept  a price that does not fully cover our forecast costs at the time of tender. However, it would be usual for us to  improve on this position as the project progresses and we always look for a positive cash contribution.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 14 shows our cash flow waterfall for 2017. We generated $209 million of operating cash in the year. This  included working capital-related outflows of $724 million as our net operating liabilities decreased, mostly due to  the timing of cash flows on the Beatrice project to former ECS projects in the Middle East and to the completion of  certain projects.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ricardo. Turning now to Slide 16. As a leading strategic partner in the offshore and energy industry,  we aim to generate long-term value for all our stakeholders, our clients, people, shareholders and the society in  which we work.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 19. Working in an integrated way, Schlumberger and Subsea 7 will increase to improve the full life  productivity of the field and optimize the total CapEx or OpEx investment by our clients. We have already been  achieving this with Subsea Integration Alliance as a transition to a formal joint venture. We'll announce this with  the additional focus on the OpEx phase as a field life cycle.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving to slide 20, earlier (sic) [early] engagement is key to supporting our clients to achieve the optimal field  solution on integrated as well as segregated projects. Subsea 7 announced a 60% investment in a leading energy  consultancy, Xodus, forming a joint venture with Chiyoda, who will retain 40% stake. Xodus will continue to offer  objective and unbiased engineering and advisory solutions. This new relationship will supersede the KG7 alliance  with KBR and Granherne, although we will continue to work with them on a project-by-project basis.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Slide 21 shows the increasing importance of renewable energy activity to Subsea 7. Subsea 7, through its  subsidiary SHL, has been involved in offshore wind farm installation for many years, applying our skills and  competence in heavy-lifting to the installation of wind turbine foundations in shallow water. Building our  established presence in this sector, we announced today an agreement to acquire Siem Offshore submarine  power cable business and the two Siem Offshore vessel that enable this activity. By adding cable lay capability to  our EPIC service offering, we expect to increase our market share and offer the clients a more comprehensive  service.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: I shall conclude on slide 22 with our outlook. The oil and gas market have seen a gradual increase in activity with  the growing volume of sanctions in the world. However, our present pricing is challenging, and we expect margin  to remain low until excess capacity is utilized. We are addressing this through our lower-cost solution using our  experience and technical expertise to drive out inefficiencies. We see some of the active project tenders that we  expect to see awarded to the market in the near to medium-term. The timing of awards remain uncertain and may  be timed unevenly through the year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We continue to bid a number of renewable project around the world with medium-term opportunities in Europe,  Taiwan, and the U.S. We are currently bidding on EPC wind farm foundation project in France, Le Tréport and  Noirmoutier. The bulk of the offshore installation activity related to the wind farm tenders is scheduled for 2020 or  later.

file: SUBC - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 28February2019 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Isabel Green
texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our full year adjusted EBITDA was $669 million with a margin of 16% for both the full year and the first quarter in  2018. Total vessel utilization was 70% in both the quarter and the year, an improvement of the respective prior  year periods, as the oil and gas market started to recover. A total of six vessel retrofits and four joint as we  balance the fleet to meet our needs.

texts.speaker: Isabel Green
texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We were active on the Snorre Expansion project in Norway in the quarter with the fabrication of pipeline bundles  in our facility in Wick. The first of the Snorre project bundles will be installed later this year via our low-cost  controlled depth tow method. So, West Nile Delta Phase 2 project, offshore Egypt, reached a significant milestone  at the end of the year. Always in the Giza and Fayoum fields reached mechanical completion and we handed over  to BP, where our first gas has now been achieved. We will continue to work on the project in 2019 with one of our  [ph] flexible-lay (00:5:12) vessels installing pipe on the Raven field later this year.

texts.speaker: Isabel Green
texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Our key milestone was reached in the quarter with a cutting of the 36-inch pipeline enabling Shell to commence  decommissioning this historic platform. When complete, the Hornsea One wind farm will be the largest off the  coast of the UK.

texts.speaker: Isabel Green
texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, five awards were announced and a total of $0.9 billion was awarded. In the Gulf of Mexico,  the Manuel project was awarded by BP, the second project to use our Electrically Heat-Traced Flowline  Technology. In the North Sea, we were awarded the Shearwater project for Shell and the renewal of our DSVi  frame agreement which was extended to include additional – an additional Seven's client. In Africa, we were  awarded the Turret Remediation project for Tullow, offshore Ghana. And in Asia, our Renewables and Heavy  Lifting business was awarded the Yunlin wind farm project, offshore Taiwan, where we'll be completing the peak  work related to the inner array grid and export cable system in 2020. And just yesterday, we announced a five- year frame agreement for Life of Field services in the West of Shetland, our 19th year of services for BP on this  arrangement.
