texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In addition, the four PLSVs on long-term contracts with Petrobras achieved high levels of utilization. Renewables  and Heavy Liftings revenue in the quarter were significantly lower compared to the prior year period. The Beatrice  project was materially completed in 2018 and the Borkum II project is in the commissioning phase. As work on  these large projects comes to an end, we face a reduction in offshore Renewables activity.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Renewables and Heavy Lifting reported a $13 million net operating loss in the quarter with slower progress than  planned on the Borkum II project due to poor weather. The $17 million net operating loss in Life of Field included  a $12 million impairment charge related to ROV. For the full year, net operating income was $200 million with  income from SURF and Conventional and Renewables and Heavy Lifting activities partly offset by losses on the  Life of Field and Corporate business unit.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We continually look for ways to be more efficient with our fleet, saving costs, as well as reducing greenhouse gas  emissions. As an example of this is our Clean Operations initiative with over 3,600 recorded measures taken to  lower energy use on our vessels in 2018, with an associated cost saving of approximately $3.1 million.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Procurement costs are a function of the volume, mix and phasing of our activities, and the pricing environment for  procurement. In 2018, we saw a $300 million increase in our procurement costs, mostly related to an increase in  SURF and Conventional project activity. In 2018, there was no measurable impact from supply chain price  inflation. But this risk will become more prominent as the industry-wide recovery in offshore oil and gas projects  continues.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Moving on to Slide 11, Subsea 7 is a cash generative business and we have clear priorities on how it should be  invested. We are a top tier partner for our clients and to maintain this position, we have made targeted  investments in our people, our technology and our fleet throughout the downturn. We have also strategically  invested to strengthen the group's capabilities with acquisitions of businesses and vessels to support growth  areas such as offshore wind and conventional oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Ricardo Rosa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In 2018, we acquired Seaway Offshore Cables and two related vessels for our Renewables and Heavy Lifting  business unit. This additional capability has already led to the award of approximately $200 million of Renewables  work with transport and install contracts offshore Taiwan and the U.S. both new wind markets for Subsea 7.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to slide 13, I would like to take some time to review our strategic highlights. We have invested throughout  the downcycle in strategic opportunities, helping accomplish our vision in leading the way in the delivery of  offshore projects and services for the energy industry.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We continue to increase our position in the renewable energy sector with the acquisition of Seaway Offshore  Cables and two associated vessels. The integration of Seaway Offshore Cables has progressed well. And our  strategy was rewarded with the award of project in Taiwan and the East Coast of the U.S. The Beatrice and  Borkum II EPCI projects were substantially completed, with all foundation installed by the end of the year. The  ability not to – the ability to not only install but also engineer, procure and manage the fabrication of these large  projects is clearly a key differentiator. Although we do not expect to work offshore on a new EPCI project in the  renewable sector this year, we foresee a strong future activity in the sector as we are tendering from several  projects scheduled for execution in later years.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: We actively manage our fleet, ensuring we have the right capabilities and capacity to meet long-term market  requirements. Because of targeted investment and fleet discipline, our average vessel age has reduced to 10  years, making it one of the youngest amongst our competition. Along with introducing new vessels to the fleet, we  also make modification when appropriate to existing vessels. Seven Viking was upgraded with battery capability,  making her our first hybrid vessel. This upgrade will not only reduce fuel consumption cost, but should also cut the  vessel's carbon dioxide emission by up to 20%.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: At the end of 2018 and the start of 2019, Subsea Integration Alliance was awarded two sole-supplier integrated  FEED studies by Woodside Oil and Gas for large greenfield project; Scarborough, offshore Australia; and SNE  Phase 1, offshore Senegal. These were of particular significance because, upon FID, these FEED studies will turn  into project awards which we will execute.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to page 15. I would like to share an update on the success of Subsea Integration Alliance to date. We  have now delivered over 70 concept studies and [ph] pre-set (00:25:50) FEEDs with our alliance partner,  OneSubsea. Integrated project solution allows for a single service delivery for project and risk management,  engineering, manufacturing and offshore installation, and is one of our operational model which reduces cost for  our clients.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Subsea Integration Alliance has successfully completed two fully integrated project, Dalmatian and Otter,  and we  have six more underway. I would specifically like to highlight the momentum of the work we're undertaking in  Australia on integrated projects. We have a long history in the region, and recently our integrated offering has  achieved success with the West Barracouta project for ExxonMobil as well as a Scarborough FEED for  Woodside.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: On Pipeline Bundles, our pump – Pipeline Bundles continue to be the right solution for numerous clients who seek  a low cost tieback solution. Two new Pipeline Bundle project were announced in 2018, the Penguins and Buzzard  projects both offshore UK. We continue to develop Pipeline Bundles by enhancing them for deeper waters, higher  temperatures and higher pressures along with including more monitors and sensors in the two heads as part of  our digitalization program.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The Snorre Bundle, which is currently under fabrication, incorporates a newly DNV-qualified linear bridge  connector. This connector allows for a simplified and more efficient connection of our Swagelining polymer lining  pipe. This connector has now enabled Swagelining technology to be applied to reel-lay projects. [indiscernible]  (00:28:43) project, we'll use this connector later in this year.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: The final technology I want to highlight is our Electrically Heat Traced Flowline. The photo on the presentation  was taken at our [indiscernible] (00:29:18) where the pipe for the [ph] (00:29:21) project is soon to be lined with  electrical cables, [indiscernible] (00:29:24) on to our new-built reel-lay vessel, Seven Vega.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In the Renewables market, I expect to see more opportunities from the changing dynamics as technologies  advance, but also challenges as new players join the market. I'm confident that our experienced teams in Seaway  7 (sic) [Subsea 7] (00:30:15) will successfully navigate their way through this evolution, remaining cost-disciplined  and client-focused to beat the profitable project portfolio.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In 2019, we expect to see our first Electrically Heat Traced Flowline project executed at our onshore control  centers for our [indiscernible] (00:31:08) operation. And finally, with six ongoing integrated project in 2019 and  many more being tendered, the strength of commitment of Subsea Integration Alliance will ensure Subsea 7  position as a leading provider of integrated offshore services.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: Turning to our final slide on page 19, to review the expected outlook for each of our business units. This time last  year, I named eight large greenfield project, which I expected to come to market in the near-term. Of those eight,  seven has been – have been awarded to market, with Subsea 7 winning two. Although some of this market are  still subject to FID – although some of these projects are still subject to FID, sorry, this positive momentum and  increased visibility are encouraging trends for a market in recovery.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In a market where we may still see some oil price volatility, the majority of project we are tendering for today have  a breakeven price  below the medium- and long-term oil price expectation.

texts.speaker: Jean Cahuzac
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Subsea 7 SA
texts.text: In our Renewables and Heavy Lifting business units, we see limited new opportunities for substantial offshore  campaigns this year, but on the horizon, in 2020 and beyond, there are good opportunities that we are tendering  today. This includes transport and installation work in Taiwan and medium-sized EPCI project in Europe. The  outlook for the Renewables market is positive, with forecasts by leading third-party sources showing growth.

We have expanded our  capacities but also our capabilities in Brazil and India by not only adding some capacity in factory  space, but very much also increasing the capacities of test beds and other facilities included in the  machining houses in those countries.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Turning to slide number 10, we can proudly say that we’ve issued our fourth sustainability report. It  has been audited by external auditors, and we have again as you see in the left bottom corner of  this slide, obtained the highest GRI rating possible for the sustainability report that we’ve shown.  On the right you see one chart, which is the health and safety chart – one of the health and safety  charts out of that report, and it shows that during the course of the 2009, we’ve again lower our  accident frequency rate, a very relevant indication of safety inside our employee base to a number  below six, and we’re seeing year-to-date that these numbers have good potential to be improving  further.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Very differently, the later cycle segments of Sulzer have behaved. The oil and gas upstream,  downstream and the power generation side have been the late-cycle segments. They’ve kept us up  in 2008 and 2009, and they clearly showed a downturn in order intake, which is now reflected very  much in our sales volumes over the first half-year 2010.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The upstream oil and gas business is still a business where people are not investing in any  significant way. The oil majors in the aggregate with the exception of Petrobras and Exxon Mobil  have clearly indicated that they would be spending less CapEx in the aggregate. Also OPEC has  indicated that they would be spending less CapEx in the aggregate, and although there is activity in  the segment, it is not showing any strong signs of recovery during the course of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The power generation one has been our latest cycle segment and has clearly been strong in 2009.  We have indicated already then that we expected it to reduce in activity in 2010, and we can clearly  confirm that that’s what’s taking place. So with oil and gas and HPI staying relatively constant at  their new level and with power generation still having a downward pressure in terms of its activity,  we don’t feel that there will be an quick recovery in any of these three markets as we see it today..

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we move further to slide number 13, we are at the Sulzer Pumps individual division section,  Sulzer Pumps being the largest divisional Sulzer with about 50% of the general order intake. And  what you see at Sulzer Pumps is that they still see a further reduction in order intake in line with  what I mentioned in the previous slide very much driven by the power generation segment into the  new equipment side of the business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ton Büchner, Chief Executive Officer  Thank you, Peter. The upstream oil and gas activity came  down quite significantly in 2009. It still has, in certain regions, strong downward pressures, but  overall in the aggregate, we believe that the oil and gas upstream market is stabilizing as we speak  for Sulzer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 The HPI market also showed a significant downturn in 2009, and also there we believe that it’s  stabilizing – both those oil and gas markets are stabilizing at a very, very different level than they  were in the hay days of 2008 and 2007.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The power generation is still further reducing inactivity, still being strong in 2009. We do see a  reduction of project activity during the course of 2010. Interestingly enough, the pulp and paper  segment as an early segment is clearly growing again with projects visible in China and in Latin  America in the respective paper and pulp development markets that are out there, and we even see  some activities again in the European market. Those are, of course, of much smaller nature.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We believe and are convinced that Sulzer is well positioned for future success based on its five  core focus areas, its adaptation measures taken early and its strong financial situation that we still  have even after acquiring Dowding & Mills.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Sulzer had a strong start of 2011, and we'd like to elaborate during the course of the
texts.text: The late-cycle segments have had a more variant behavior. The Oil & Gas segment, which we expected to grow  when we spoke to you at the beginning of the year, has indeed grown, has indeed shown increased project activity.  And it's basically taking the direction that we provided to you at the beginning of the year. That is the early  segments – the late-cycle segment that has recovered and is further recovering.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Sulzer had a strong start of 2011, and we'd like to elaborate during the course of the
texts.text: We cannot say that yet from the Hydrocarbon Processing and Power Generation segment. The Hydrocarbon  Processing segment shows some large projects in some selected areas, but they're spotty and they're certainly not  a trend. And that means that the overall segment is principally still in a relatively stable environment at a low  level.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody. Sulzer had a strong start of 2011, and we'd like to elaborate during the course of the
texts.text: The Power Generation segment has continued to decline a bit, has a found a stabilization at this point in time; but  the postponement of many nuclear projects that were in the pipeline due to the incident in Japan, have certainly  delayed the original revival and growth of the Power Generation segment as it was originally anticipated. And at  this point in time, we believe that a recovery of the Power segment is unlikely to occur before the beginning of next  year.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, the expectation of the full enterprise line translating into project activity, we expect to continue. The  Hydrocarbon Processing Industry will probably cease of the large projects, but as an overall segment will remain  stable at a relatively low level. And the Power Generation segment has now reached bottom, and is expected to at  least, for this year, remain stable at its low level at this point in time.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: There will be a revival of various technologies that Sulzer is present in for future power generation; but at the  moment, people are doing lots of recalculations, both on the basis of the political deterioration of popularity of the  nuclear type of power generation; and, of course, to see if coal and/or gas are true alternatives for either the  stations that have been switched off or for future expansion supplying to the power requirements in the  populations in the various geographical areas in the world.

texts.speaker: Ton Büchner
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, growth is expected. But at this point in time, people are going over the books to reassess the composition of  their power generation assets, both in the near future as well as in the long-term future.

file: SUN - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 23July2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We have taken actions and initiated tailored measures to improve the profitability, especially in the second half of  2013. We have also decided to concentrate on three key market segments, oil and gas, power, and water. These are  very attractive markets driven by megatrends.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The EBIT shrank by CHF 45 million or 23% on a year-over-year view. This is clearly something which we are not  comfortable with. As a result from lower volumes in some businesses, capacity utilization was certainly poo r and  in combination with the changed business mix and higher restructuring charges, it has led to a significant  decrease in our operation operating income. Most of this decrease came from the wastewater business and the  electromechanical business in the UK and Australia. For the full year 2013, we expect the profitability to be  slightly lower than in 2012.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If we look at Pumps, lower sales and lower margins, especially in the wastewater business, led to the  underutilization of capacities and these were the main drivers for the profitability drop. The engineered pumps  business, and this is something which I would like to stress, are performing very well. We have combined also  therefore the so-called process pumps and the wastewater pumps under one combined business unit called now  configured solutions.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, let us jump into the figures, order intake first. Three of our four divisions grew compared to last year. The  biggest growth was reported, as you can see on this slide, in Sulzer Pumps and in Sulze r Chemtech. Both divisions  were supported by larger orders in the oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's move on to our divisions and have a closer look there. Pumps first. We had a good order intake development  for Sulzer Pumps, up 5%. And as I said already, this was supported by some larger orders for oil and gas  applications, for instance, fire fighting systems for the oil ex ploration and also pipeline pumps and here especially  North America.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We were also able to sign new strategic partnerships with customers like Sinopec in China, for instance. And you  might remember we reported that together with the annual results that we had last year signed this important  collaboration agreement with FMC Technologies for the subsea pumps applications, one of the technologies for  the future.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Also here, Q2 in order intake was much stronger than Q1. We also see a good momentum building up here in  Turbo Services. In addition, the first six months of prev ious year included some larger orders in the power  business that could not be repeated during the first six months. The division continued to develop its business for  these long-term service agreements, which are in the power market, especially for gas tur bine services. And we  have currently several potential new service orders under negotiation.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now as I mentioned, today, I would like to add an additional item to our strategy in terms of focusing on three key  attractive markets. And this is what we want to do, we want to focus our activities in these three key markets,  meaning oil and gas, power and water. And as also mentioned before when I started, as a consequence, therefore,  we are exploring the divestment of our Sulzer Metco division with half of its sales in the automotive and the  aviation market and one-third in the general industries market.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: But now, I would like to really explain to you our new bullet point, which we added, and this is the focus on three  key markets. We, Sulzer, made a strategic decision to concentrate on three attractive key markets: oil and gas,  power and water. These are, obviously, attractive growth markets that will benefit from the global development  and the megatrends like population growth, the urbanization, increased energy demand and scarcity of wa ter.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If we place the focus on those three key markets, you can see that the share in these markets will clearly increase.  Oil and gas will go up from 40% to 48%, power from 15% to 16%, and water from 12% to 15%, and  our exposure to  the general industry will go down from 24% to 21%. So this is going to be an important focus on those key markets  which we believe are very attractive.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now let me come to the outlook and the summary, where we are. And I think if I would like to summarize the  market development in the first six months and what do we expect for the remainder of the current year, let me  maybe start with our largest key market for oil and gas segment. And as you know, presently, t his market accounts  roughly for 40% of Sulzer. And for us this market overall has developed in line with the expectations and had  showed a very good growth in selected areas and regions. The main drivers for us are to be found upstream with  very good activities in FPSO, and in midstream, where we have positions with pipeline pumps, specifically North  America, and obviously, this is driven by the fracking initiatives there.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Here, in this space, we have recorded some major projects in the first six months. A nd the oil price, at this current  level, is also very much supportive for most of those projects. Activities for us in the downstream sector are mainly  driven by investments in the chemical sector and here is where Chemtech is very much in the space less t han for  example the pumps' business. And obviously, what we expect based on what we know that this market will  continue at this current high level for our space.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In the power, in this account, as you know, for 50% of Sulzer today, we have not seen really a pick-up in this space  and we don't expect this to happen in the other way. The level of activity, specifically, on the newbuild side  remains generally low in most of our regions. And having said this one, although the number of new projects  increased, in particular, for us in Asia Pacific for coal and nuclear, we do not expect a big recovery in H2, and  therefore, we expect the similar levels to continue at this level as before.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Water, the next important market segment accounted for some 12%, is mainly se rved by the Pumps division. This  has clearly decreased compared to the previous year, particularly driven by the low levels in Europe. What we see  here though is a slowly picking up trend, specifically, in the wastewater side and overall, we forecast this market to  be at a very similar level for the full year.

We will also  give you more details on this topic later in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's start with Pumps Equipment on slide 13. Transformation of the PE division from a regional to a market - oriented organization is in progress. texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In February, we signed an agreement for the acquisition of 7 5% stake in Saudi Pump Factory. This acquisition is in  line with Sulzer's focus on the key markets, oil, gas, power and water. On an adjusted basis, our order intake  dropped by 5%, mainly on a very high basis in the first half of 2013. Just to remind you, we had some very large  orders in the second quarter of last year with the two larger of them being together about CHF 50 million.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, over to Rotating Equipment Services or how we call it RES on slide 14. Here we created the RES division by  integrating pump services into the old turbo service business. We believe that with this partnership, Sulzer has a strong foundation  for securing business in this rapidly developing market.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We focus on three key markets, oil and gas, power and water, and we'll also remain active in some selected other  industries where we have a strong position. On the equipment side, we focus on equipment for flow management,  separation and process technology. At the same time, we are a leading service player with a comprehensive service  offering for own and third-party equipment.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We said that we want to focus on three key markets. So what have we done? We sold Metco to Oerlikon. We  created a new business unit, water, as part of our Pumps Equipment division, where we integrated the old Cardo  business; and the Engineered Water business.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We are working on setting up the business units, oil and gas and power within our Pumps Equipment divisions so  that they are ready at the beginning of 2015. We said that we want to create one company and be more customer- focused to leverage our existing capabilities and assets.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, again, what have we done? We have set up a new division called Rotating Equipment Services, RES, which  combines the former Turbo services businesses and the old Sulzer Pump Service Organization, and we created  central group functions to support the new organization.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: On slide 24, you can see our key market assessment for the second half of 2014. Based on the present knowledge  and excluding major changes in the general economic conditions, we expect activity levels for parts of the oil and  gas market to remain solid, in particular, in the Americas.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Based also on positive development in selected regions such as the Americas, some recovery is expected for the  water market and activity in the power industry and in the general industry are expected to remain on a similar  level.

file: SUN - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 28July2015 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Christoph. Good afternoon and also welcome from my side. I would like to go directly to the market  update starting on slide four. Overall, it can be said that oil price predictability remains low, resulting in project  delays, re-bidding and also pricing pressure.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Upstream, international oil companies, national oil companies and EPCs continue to push for cost reductions  throughout the supply chain. We expect some movement in FPSO project in West Africa and Brazil this year,  although in that specific segment there is an overall considerable lower level of activity compared to previous  years. In the aftermarket business, we see the impact of cancellations and postponements of non-essential  purchases. We also see a slowdown in decision-making processes with longer tendering to order placement  conversion phases.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's now have a look of the macro environment we are working in on slide five. On the upper left chart you see  the oil price development. Prices have fallen sharply, recovered somewhat, and now are trending down again.  Looking at forecast it seems that the tightening of supply and demand is expected to lead to higher prices over  time but not in the short time. The lower left chart shows the development in Downstream where the HPI  Boxscore indicates a lower but currently more stable level of activity.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Turning to slide six, the Power and Water markets showed double-digit growth for H1 for us. In Power we have  seen good activity levels in India and in China in both conventional and nuclear segments after the Indian  government's proposal for new mega projects and the Chinese government's announcement to restart the nuclear  program. However, the conventional segment continues to see pricing pressures as the low activity levels in oil  and gas drive competitors to be more aggressive on opportunities in the Power market. We see constant activity  levels in the U.S. driven by gas and combined cycle projects. We also expect some investments showing up in Latin  America in the second half year. The EMEA region continues to be slow and the activity is mainly driven by the  Middle East.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Turning to Water, here we see good activity levels in municipal wastewater in the U.S. and China, a steady market  in EMEA and a slow market in Brazil. We see growing market for dewatering on the construction side, but  dewatering business for mines remains weak. On the engineered water side, we see active desalination markets in  Middle East and also in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to order intake by quarter on slide nine. In Q2, all divisions contributed to order intake growth. Pumps  Equipment in Q2 grew by 13.3% year-on-year as strong growth in Water, Power and the spare parts business  overcompensated for a small year-on-year decline in oil and gas. These are clearly positive effects from the  market-oriented structure in our Pumps Equipment division and the restructuring of the Water business unit.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: One comment on sequential order intake. The sequential order intake development from Q1 to Q2 in oil and gas  has been on a group level a negative high single-digit percentage number, but for the Pumps Equipment division  the Q1 to Q2 development was positive, helped by a larger order from the North Sea region.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to slide 10 now, sales in the first half 2015 were negatively impacted from the suspensions of previously  received orders in oil and gas in our Pumps Equipment division. Of the previously mentioned CHF 114 million,  CHF 75 million impacted the sales volume in H1 in Pumps Equipment. This shortfall was only partially  compensated by the Water and Power businesses.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Klaus will go into more detail on the Sulzer Full Potential program in a moment. Here are the effect on the H1  results. The first driver of the CHF 5 million profit contribution of SFP were the right-sizing measures taken at the  Chemtech division, followed by procurement savings from electric motors, machine castings, logistic services,  insurance and travel. In G&A contributions came mainly from IT and some other areas.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Within Pumps Equipment contributions came from adapting our factory setup in oil and gas in China and in  Brazil. Further in Pumps Equipment, we changed route to market in the wastewater business by switching from a  direct sales force to distributors in certain markets. Overall we expect SFP to yield a 0.6 percentage point  contributions on the operational EBITA margin for the full year 2015, which supports our profitability.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving to slide 16, I would like to give you an update on the Water business. We mentioned earlier that the Water  business is doing well. As you'll recall from our Capital Markets Day in February, we have restructured the Water  business in 2013 and 2014 in several rounds. All in all we closed three factories, reduced head count by 15%,  aligned the product portfolio and changed the route to market where appropriate. Today, we are pleased to report  that we are seeing the results of these restructurings coming through. Order intake in the Water business  increased by 16% in the first half 2015 over the previous year's period and the business is profitable on an  operational EBITA level.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What you also see on the chart is the expected cost of the program. Overall, we expect the program costs to be  between 1 times and 1.5 times profit contributions. As the programs ramps up, we will incur more cost this year  and we will have the benefits in the following years. For this year we expect the program to deliver a profit  contribution of 60 basis points in operational EBITA margin, which should help us to keep that margin on a  similar or slightly lower level than in 2014 despite the adverse impact from the oil and gas market.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We expect the oil and gas market to continue to be weak and the good performance in water and power to  continue. Main driver for the reduced activity in general industry was our Rotating Equipment Services division  and there the electromechanical business in Europe and Australia.

file: SUN - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 26July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, if I go to page – just checking my page numbers. All right, I've got different page numbers. So, I'll call out the  right page numbers, my apologies. If I go to page 5, the oil market's downturn is continuing. That's no surprise to  any of you guys. The investments in oil and gas continue to decline. We are estimating that the markets for oil  and gas CapEx is going to be declining by around 20% in 2016. That's from crossing a number of outside forces  with some of the data we have internally. So, oil and gas CapEx dropping by 20% in 2016 versus 2015.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: No surprise, upstream is impacted harder than any other segments with the decline of close to 40% as a market.  And therefore, it should come as no surprise if you look at the figures that we're showing that the upstream part of  our order intake has declined significantly. Last year, it was 16% of orders, now it's 10%. Midstream and  downstream have also been impacted but less so.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: You should keep in mind, though, that if you look at our 29% downstream exposure, it includes about 7% that  comes from the chemical processing industry. That's in Chemtech, obviously, and that could also be classified  under general industry.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to the next page, all other market segments are up or flat. Sulzer is more than oil and gas, and power,  water and general industry have been resilient to growing. So, as I said, if you look at the slide, the majority,  precisely 54% of our order intake, is generated in markets other than oil and gas. We've been growing in these  markets which have been flat to slightly up.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And the power market competition has increased with the decline of the oil and gas market. Essentially, it's the  price pressure from oil and gas that's translating to power as people look for ways to fill their factories. Growth is  driven primarily by Asia-Pacific, so India, China and also the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we talk about the gas turbine service markets of our Rotating Equipment Service division, we see pricing  pressure from the OEMs. The OEMs are quite aggressive. They have clear strategies for recapturing or protecting  service market share.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had the nice growth in the water markets, which we would attribute to the successful launch of new products.  Overall, the water market is stable with growth rates in line with GDP. And as we mentioned previously, our  rebound in water is continuing. We're happy with the direction our business is taking.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, let's go to the Sulzer Full Potential section, page 8. So, on this slide, what we see is – well, it's a slide that you  know. It's a split per bucket, I can put it that way, of Sulzer full potential. CHF 200 million is the target, as you  know. I'll remind you once again that direct procurement has been excluded from this CHF 200 million of cost  reduction, excluded because it's not that we're not saving significantly in direct procurements, but in a down  market, most of that goes to customers. And therefore, we are not reporting that as part of the Sulzer Full  Potential number.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Chemtech, we announced the closure of our manufacturing facility in Oberwinterthur, not far from where we're  sitting. As you know, this was not an easy decision, but we are in a very competitive market in separation  technology, and the low oil price environments and if you add to that the Swiss franc, our position had become  untenable in Oberwinterthur.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, really, when I look at this, I'm not so worried about the CHF 200 million number. I'm really focused on timing  or main risk is timing. We don't want to slip. We want it to accelerate. And that's what we're focusing our energy  on. You also see on this slide that we have SFP cost of CHF 31 million for H1 2016.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Order intake in the first half of 2016 was down by 9.1% on an adjusted basis compared to the same period last  year, mainly driven by headwinds in the oil and gas market. However, looking at it by quarter, Q2 order intake is  up 8% quarter-on-quarter.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Order backlog, as you can see, was slightly up, and sales and operational profitability, operational EBITA, that is,  were flat on last year. Cost savings from our Sulzer Full Potential program have offset these effects, including  significant price pressure from the oil and gas market downturn.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to sales by division on slide number 13. First half year sales were up in Pumps Equipment mainly on  oil and gas. This reflect the still healthy oil and gas order intake from H1 a year ago, which was now being created  and turned into sales this year as projects were being delivered to customers.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In RES, sales were flat in oil and gas but down in general industry. The latter is mainly a result of a weak  performance in our electromechanical business in the UK. Chemtech sales in H1 were down in oil and gas but up  in general industry, thanks to a strong performance of Sulzer Mixpac Systems, the business unit within Chemtech.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And now moving on to operational profitability on slide 14. Here you see that in H1, we were able to fully offset the  oil and gas market headwinds of about 2.6 percentage points with savings from our Sulzer Full Potential program,  thus, keeping our operational EBITA margin at 7.1%, on par with last year.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The two main headwinds, as you can see, were the margin effect due to significant price pressures in oil and gas,  mainly in Pumps Equipment, and under-absorption in our factories. Obviously, as part of Sulzer Full Potential, we  are restructuring our manufacturing network to reduce under-absorption. But you always have a time delay there,  and in H1, factory utilization has still been dropping faster than we were able to reduce capacity.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Volume and mix had overall negligible effects on flat sales year-on-year. And as Grég had mentioned before,  these negative impacts were fully offset by savings from our Sulzer Full Potential program which is running at full  steam.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Pumps Equipment, operational profitability was broadly flat, helped by stable volumes year-on-year and the  SFP savings, which fully offset the price pressures from the oil and gas market. In Rotating Equipment Services,  operational profitability improved despite decreasing sales due to the positive effects from Sulzer Full Potential  restructuring measures mainly in the Europe, Middle East, Africa region. And Chemtech benefited from the better  business mix due to the good performance of Sulzer Mixpac Systems in H1 and significant SFP savings coming  through.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil and gas orders, by the way, in Q2 are up versus Q1. Now, having said that, it's way too early to declare vict ory  in any way, shape or form. The market is still quite volatile, very difficult. And we will continue to fight for all the  good orders that we can get in a very competitive and challenging market. So, it's nice that it's heading in the right  direction, but we're not, in any way, portraying the fact that H2 is going to be easy.

file: SUN - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 27July2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If I move to water, orders in the water market have come down a little bit, but the market is still very healthy. The  downwards trend for H1 in orders in water is really mainly due to a very high baseline for engineered water in H1  2016. Engineered water, these are bigger projects and when you get one, it kind of moves the needle We did  lower order intake – we generated lower order intake in engineered water in H1 2017, but once again, a high  baseline in 2016 and the municipal water market continues to be very healthy.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Moving to power. The power market developed well for us despite an already relatively high base in 2016 and  aggressive competition as a result of low project activity in oil and gas. Asia-Pacific remains the most active part  of the world in power. On gas turbine side, which we also report as part of power, the increase of the installed  base in renewables results in gas turbines being used for peak rather than load. This means that the turbines are  running less hours, but they are also cycling more, which shortens the service intervals. The market is healthy.  The price pressure is significant. And this is mostly driven by the OEMs that are very, very aggressive currently in  this market.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Moving to oil and gas. The market continues to be challenging. The lower-for-longer scenario is clearly prevailing  at this point. CapEx expectations for big oil companies show stabilization at a low level, but no meaningful  rebound so far. Downstream and CPI are picking up. Upstream continues to be very difficult.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: There are some signs of life though in upstream. I mean if I give you data points, there are seven offshore  projects that are planned to pass the final investment decision second half of the year. I think the equivalent  number for last year was zero. So things are shaping up but you can't really see that in our pipeline, and you can't  see that in our order intake at this point. Downstream will remain difficult for a while. As I said, upstream will  remain difficult for a while, my apologies. Downstream and CPI are more active as I said. There, we see early  stages of recovery in the U.S. and activity in Asia-Pacific. And the – okay.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In H1 2017, we were able to fully compensate the market impacts, the headwinds that we're facing in oil and gas  and power to a certain extent, fully compensate that with the SFP cost savings. We would expect that to continue  in H2 with SFP cost savings above market headwinds contributing to a net positive to the bottom line.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's go to page 8. The savings, SFP savings per category, there are two. What you see here is that the Sulzer  Full Potential plan in Chemtech and RES, pretty advanced. Both of them are mostly done with their plan. We still  have some work to do in procurement and SG&A and in Pumps Equipment.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: I explained the drop in sales volume in Pumps Equipment a minute ago. And on this slide, you see the impact of  that lower sales volumes and competitive pricing in the oil and gas market on the operational EBITA margin of  Pumps Equipment. Those two things hang together. With higher volumes in the second half of the year, we would  expect Pumps Equipment to breakeven for the full year, which when you think about it, for a new equipment  business in our industry at the bottom of the cycle is quite okay for now.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Moving on to slide 14, I'll walk you briefly through the operational profitability bridge from H1 last year to H1 2017.  As you see, savings from our Sulzer Full Potential program of 2 percentage points more than offset the market  headwinds of about 1.5 percentage points. The market headwinds come in two forms. First is a volume effect of  CHF 33 million due to the lower order intake in oil and gas in 2017, resulting from the lower backlog at the  beginning of this year. And secondly, the lower sales volume also results in under absorption in our factories  shown here as other costs.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Candidly, overall, I feel we have done a decent job balancing pricing pressures to maintain order win rates versus  cost of under absorption in the factories. We've been thoughtful and decisive on where and when to give in on  price to sell our factories. The margin column is positive as our water and pumps services businesses  compensated for the margin deterioration in oil and gas and power.

file: SUN - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 25July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: You all followed the Wild Boars, the football team in Thailand, and Sulzer is not always very good at marketing  itself. We don't do the mini-submarine thing, but actually most of the pumps, most of the new watering pumps that  were involved in taking the water level down in the cave in Thailand were actually Sulzer pumps. And this is what  you see on these pictures. These blue pumps are the watering pumps. The reason why they were chosen is that  our local distributor was very reactive and diligent and went up to help, but also because their light aluminum  structure and the challenge was that you needed pumps that could take out huge volumes of water but that were  also light enough to be transported by people into a remote place and this is what you see on pages 2 and 3. So,  once again, a very touching story that ended well and Sulzer was happy to play a small role in all of this.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Okay. So, let's go to the highlights of H1 2018. We've seen a continuation of the recovery of the oil and gas  upturn, continuing the recovery of oil and gas downstream, which started last year, and a rebound in oil and gas  upstream, which started in 2018. All our other markets performed well with the exception of the power markets.  This resulted in an order intake that increased by 11.6% including acquisitions and 6.5% organically.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: All right. Let's go to page 6, starting with our Pumps Equipment division. The order intake for Pumps Equipment  increased by 21% including acquisitions and by 12% organically. The main driver was the strong development in  oil and gas, which was up by 45%. Within oil and gas, upstream more than doubled from what was a very low  basis in H1 2017. H1 2017 was probably the trough, so up – more than doubled, but once again, from the trough.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We've received less orders in the power market. We're down about 3% in power. Organic orders from the water  business and from the industry businesses were up about 4% for both of them, showing solid growth. And the  acquisition of JWC, the grinder, screen, wastewater business that we bought early this year, further strengthened  our position in wastewater. And JWC, in terms of performance, is trending ahead of plan. So, so far, so good.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's turn to Rotating Equipment Services, page 7. Okay. RES, the order intake in Rotating Equipment Services is  up 6.5%, or 3.1% organically. Orders for Pumps Services and Spares increased by 16%, and orders for  Electromechanical Services were up 4%. As you know, as you see in the donut on that page, our business is  really three product lines; it's Pumps, it's Turbo and it's Electromechanical. So, Pumps, 16% up;  Electromechanical, 4% up. Turbo is under a little bit of pressure. We've seen lower volumes in Turbo Service  particularly in gas turbine services. You see that we're down 7% versus the same period last year on turbo  services.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, 7% is a good performance in the market context because you know that the gas turbine market has been  down in the last couple of years, resulting in more competition on the installed base and the installed gas turbines,  the ones that are already in the field are cycling less and therefore, requiring less service. You see that in the  Siemens and the GE numbers very clearly. But 7% down, but we're resisting very well and we'll continue to do so.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, what that means is that we're – Tower Field Services, in terms of order intake, is down double-digit. I mean,  you can do the math, going from 30% of – [indiscernible] (00:13:23) Chemtech, 20% is healthy double-digit  decline, which means that the Separation Technology business is actually growing really fast, and it's our  products business and it's the proxy of that oil and gas downstream or chemical processing industry recovery. It's  continuing to be very, very healthy, and this is also the impact that's improving our margin on order intake.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Oil and gas, I would say that the volume recovery is underway. Downstream started last year. Upstream started  this year, but the pricing recovery is not underway, yet. I think we'll still see a depressed pricing environment in oil  and gas in 2018 because factories are not full or anywhere near full yet, and people are continuing to grab the  volume that they can. So, it's still pretty much a buyer's markets, but I think that will start shifting in 2019.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, to wrap this up, summary on next slide. The oil and gas market recovery is underway; once again, volume at  this point; hopefully, pricing next year. All the Sulzer markets are healthy apart from the power markets, which is  about – at this point, about 13% of our volume.

What we see, though, is that very few licenses certainly in the West  were provided during the course of 2009. And that gives us a relatively clear indication that the  project activity in the power generation segment will in the Western world at least come down quite  clearly. In the Eastern and emerging world, it still continues but also at a lower pace in comparison  to what we’ve seen in the past.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, whereas we see the oil and gas segment stabilizing at a lower level, the refinery segment here  and the power generation segment still on the new CapEx side have some way to step back during  the course of 2010. The other three segments have shown lights of recovery. They have shown  lights where we see that there is life in these segments coming back, but of course, at a very  different level in comparison to the record years of 2007 and 2008. The good part is that in all these       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Here you see in sales what the share has been of these segments. And you see that the HPI has  still been the largest proportion of it. What you see as well is that the power generation segment,  which was clearly the third largest segment in the past, has actually now matched the oil and gas  segment in terms of the percentage of our portfolio. On the order intake, as I indicated to you, the  power segment surpassed the oil and gas segment in 2009. Below it, you see which segments --  which divisions are active in which segments, and you see with the power generation segment  being the one that’s covering virtually all divisions, it’s been certainly good in terms of a support to  the Sulzer business in 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It is also this division that will see the biggest impact of the two project segments that are still going  to make a step back in 2010. The Power Generation segment is quite significant for Sulzer Pumps,  the refinery segment is quite significant. So, those two will implement the order intake going  forward. And the minus 27% that you see over here, we’ll see reflected in the sales volume going  forward. Therefore also showing the expectation that we do believe that sales will be coming down.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You see though, that Sulzer Pumps still has a very significant order backlog at 1.4 billion, an order  backlog that certainly still needs to be delivered to our customer base, which means that we need  to time our cost adaptation measures with the products that leave the door according to the  promised delivery times that we’ve given to our customers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sulzer Metco, this picture is our facility in Shanghai, where we have created a facility which is quite  unique for Sulzer Metco. We do the thermal-spray activities, we sell the equipments, we sell the  powders, we also have the plasma nitriding heat treatment activities, we have the thin film activities  there and we have the automotive friction systems.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Overall, if you look at the distribution, you see that general industry here is the one that most  contracted for Sulzer Metco, that the actual power industry is the one that benefited Sulzer Metco  quite a bit. You see the run of sales followed by tough contraction in 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: One reason why that’s not being the case, is because the large customers of Sulzer Metco are still  primarily western, the big gas turbine and the big aero engine manufacturers have not moved their  capacity to Asia. They’ve kept it here for technology and other reasons and as a result Sulzer  Metco is serving them from the European locations.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you can see on the right-hand side of the slide, the biggest portion of the order backlog relates  to the project related businesses of Sulzer Metco and Sulzer Chemtech. For 2010, we expect the  order backlog to further reduce due to sales volume expected to exceed order intake.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: During the course of 2009, the early cycle segments weakened further, but the clear weakening  took place on the project on the 65% of Sulzer driven by oil and gas, upstream and downstream  and the power generation segments. What we believe will happen in 2010 is that the project  segments will make another step back and what we also clearly see is that the early cycle  segments have actually found a stabilization point where they are stable, but at a very different  level than what we’ve seen in the record past.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So from that, we have concluded that both specifically on the HPI and on the power generation  side, the project activity will still reduce and that has made us -- kind of come to the statements that       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Coming back to the five focus topics, not only do we make pretty annual reports that are based on  some of these topics, we also very much have strong drives through the organization that have it  truly impact in building additional flexibility and making this a safer place to work and having  incredibly exciting innovations coming through the system by building factories in emerging markets  and acquiring and building Greenfield service operations while we go. They’ve served us well, we  will keep them in place, they will serve us well going forward and they’ve really become part of the  DNA of Sulzer.

file: SUN - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 24February2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As presented at our last Capital Market Day in October, Sulzer contributes to a lower greenhouse  gas future in various areas.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before I hand over to Ton, allow us to show you a 5-minute movie about some of our energy  efficient solutions that our division colleagues offer to their customers. Enjoy.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Health and safety has and will always be a very important topic for any supplier into the oil and gas  industry. And in 2010, we were able to reduce the accident frequency rate with 20%. If you look at it  since 2006-07, we’ve actually reduced the accident frequency rate with 60% and it clearly shows  that we’ve made Sulzer a significantly safer place to work.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sustainability is one of the topics and I’ll step through a few of these topics during the course of this  presentation. We look at it in three aspects. On the one side, we want to know our own footprint,  how much energy do we use, how much water do we use, how much waste do we generate, how  much CO2 do we exhaust as an organization. We measure it. We manage it and we do it so well  that when external auditors come by we get a score of A+, which is the highest score that you can  actually get for such measurements and management focus on theme of sustainability.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: What we’ve now subsequently added is the fact that we’re actually measuring the footprint of the  products that we supply to our customers. That means, if we supply thermal spray guns to our  customer through Sulzer Metco, if we supply pumps into our customer base we can actually over  the lifetime of the product, all the way from sourcing the material, the operational phase in a refinery  or a power plant or in the dismantling of the product, actually show what the footprint is and I’ll  show you an example later in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As a third block, we spent quite a bit of money on innovations that also contribute to looking for  alternatives that help us to become a little less dependent on the oil and gas and coal resources  that we as a world have and that we as Sulzer of course are also quite dependent on. All of these  products I’ll show later as initial customers that are quite excited using these applications of Sulzer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Coming to the product declarations, we have basically taken a number of our products, we have  calculated the footprint, we’ve done it according to ISO norms. It’s an international EPD Corporation  on how this should work. We’re one of the first companies that is actually doing that for our type of  equipment. In the laundry machine business, you have your A, B, C and D’s in nice colors as you  have with cars, but in our industry it’s still unique that a customer can come to us and ask us what  the footprint of the equipment is when he installs it in his location.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our EPDs, or environmental product declarations, as they are called, are externally certified by an  independent party and you can look them up on the internet and see what the footprint of those  products are, an additional sales argument out in the market with our increasingly sensitive  customer base regarding this topic.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the innovation side, I’ve already showed a few of innovations in the sustainable area, they are  all innovations that are in relatively early stages, but they are already providing us with double digit  million businesses in many of its aspects. In biofuels, in the first generation Sulzer was number one  in the area of pumps and extraordinarily strong in the areas of structured packings, and is today       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 involved in all of the development for second and third generation biofuels. Biofuels that are not  going to be competing with the food chain anymore, but will be based on things like grass, wood  and cellulose type products.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Bioplastics, you’ve seen it in the video, customers are extraordinarily excited about our technology.  The bioplastics of the historical bioplastics were never able to withstand high temperatures, and  Sulzer together with its partner has been able to develop bioplastic with a temperature resistance  up to 200 degrees Celsius and with that it opens a completely new world of applications that the old  bioplastics could never fulfill.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The first customers are there, as you saw in the video, they are excited, they are producing. We  have a producing pilot plant here in Oberwinterthur as well and we have a very high interest from  people to see if they want to initially mix bioplastics with the existing plastic base and later on  maybe fully replace their normal oil-based plastics with a bioplastic derivative.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: CO2 capture and storage can be argued with a lot because you’re fighting the symptoms of  CO2and not the source of generating CO2, but people believe that it will be part of our mix of  dealing with greenhouse gases and Sulzer has already delivered significant size structured  packings to actually capture CO2, and a large number of pumps that allow to bring it together, to  transport it through a pipeline and later on inject it into an old gas field for another area where it can  actually safely be stored.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Last but not least, thermal solar power. Many people when you hear solar power they think about  the photovoltaic kind of cells on top of your roofs. Here we’re talking about solar thermal power,  basically heating up a boiler with concentrating sunlight on a specific point, heating up oil, heating  up molten salt that can actually even work as a thermal battery. The large advantage of these solar  power plants that are thermal based is that they cannot only create a large capacity, they can  actually also continue to produce energy when it’s extraordinarily cloudy and many of these plants  are able because of the thermal storage to generate electricity through the night. So they don’t go  silent on the production during the night because they can store some of that thermal heat during  the course of the night and continue producing.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We’re playing in all of these applications, they are not yet the significant part of Sulzer. We are still  a very traditional oil and gas and coal based company when it comes to our core market segments,  but with the alternatives being developed, we certainly want to be part of it and these are just a  small number of examples that have already given us initial market successes with highly excited  customers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Looking at our key market segments, as I indicated to you earlier the three market segments you  see on the screen at this moment in time, the oil and gas upstream, the hydrocarbon processing  and the power generation segments, they are our late segments and they comprise of close to 60%  of the Sulzer exposure in the market. Whereas they were very late in coming down in the cycle,  they are at this point in time at a relatively low level compared to the peak of 2008.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The only one of the three that shows clear light at this point in time is the upstream oil and gas  segment where people are doing a significant number of FEED studies, Front End Engineering  Studies, at the contractor base, which generally over time with quite a time delay, then result in  access projects, which then potentially order at Sulzer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The hydrocarbon processing industry is stable, but at a relatively low level and does not show the  same level of life that the oil and gas industry seems to have shown recently, and the power  generation in 2010 actually still contracted quite significantly. We do expect it to stabilize in the next  months to come.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: You’ve seen new innovations – innovative solutions. Chemtech very much participating in the  bioplastics, the CO2 and the biofuel applications that we’ve shown as part of the video and  previous slides during this presentation. Sulzer Chemtech naturally believes that their sales will  benefit from the increased order intake of 2010. So therefore they do believe that both sales and  operating income will grow during the course of 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If you look at order intake, you can see that the order intake in total increased by 9% compared to  2009 or adjusted by currency differences and by acquisitions by 7.5%. The positive impacts here  mainly came out of the two divisions: Sulzer Chemtech and Sulzer Metco, who were both benefiting  from the good development in the early cycle markets. In Turbo Services, of course, we could see  the positive impact through the acquisition of Dowding & Mills. Sulzer Pumps on the other side was  still decreasing mainly due to the still lagging behind of the late cycle markets like oil and gas,  power and hydrocarbon processing.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Coming to the outlook and the conclusions, we – you can see very well on the slide addressing the  individual market segments of Sulzer how the individual cycles have travelled through and how  different they have been for the individual six key market segments of the Sulzer Corporation. You  see here that the late cycle segments have been rather weak during the course of 2010. The oil  and gas segment is trickling up for growth again whereas the other two late cycle segments are not  expected to significantly return to growth, certainly not the power generation industry who after a  clear contraction in 2010 is still trying to find the bottom as we speak.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We’ve seen drastically less large projects and large projects were the ones where the amount of  competition was generally less because customers like oil companies don’t generally give large  orders to smaller players. At this point in time the number of large projects has seriously and very  significantly reduced and as a result on the remaining projects there is a high number of  participants that could actually take these much smaller projects on as part of their business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The result of that is price pressure in some of our segments, clearly different payment conditions,  and as we saw in 2008 with very high commodity prices that we could in many cases pass on to the  customer. We’ve seen those prices of nickel, of stainless steel reduce significantly and as a result  also there we see a completely different raw material leverage than we had during the peak of the  cycle.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Thank you very much. I suggest with these pictures on the screen that not only show nice things  that are truly renewable or part of the innovative solutions that we’ve driven, we suggest it’s a great       corrected transcript
