texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Klaus, for the introduction. Now what was the major challenge for Sulzer in 2011? What has  Sulzer stand for in 2011? You will see from the figures that we stand for strong growth in the business year 2011  and also substantial acquisition, which has given us now access to the attractive water market. This acquisition,  however, also imposes a strong challenge to our organization with regard to integration into the existing business  and it also has an impact on the financial figures, and I will highlight those when we go through the presentation.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: How did our markets do in 2011? What is the share of our markets compared to the total turnover of the  company? You see that the water segment, which is now also listed on this slide, contributed to us about 8%, or if  you go on a full year pro forma basis about 13% of total sales to our portfolio. The hydrocarbon processing market  still being the highest in volume with about 25%, but followed by power with 18%, and oil and gas upstream with  about 14%. Automotive wit 6%, and aviation with about 4% are a bit weaker in sales contribution but, of course,  nevertheless, very attractive market segments for Sulzer.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: How did the markets perform in 2011? The oil and gas segment had a very strong 2011. Here the main growth  drivers were some bigger projects for pipelines and FPSOs, which we booked in the first half of the year. Region- wise, the U.S., South America, Middle East but also West Africa were contributing to this development.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The hydrocarbon processing industry, the demand for our product was also strong but this segment had different  dynamics for our two divisions, Sulzer Chemtech and Sulzer Pumps. [ph] There is also (10:45) Sulzer Chemtech,  the services in this segment mainly related to the chemical processing industry was higher and showed a year-on- year growth. In Sulzer Pumps, the level was reduced a bit and did not show any growth.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The refinery business is still suffering from overcapacities and we could only see newbuilds in that business in  some selected countries. The power generation market showed, as expected, a decline to previous year and, of  course, this decline is also driven by the fact that this segment is, first of all, late cycle and also because of the  negative impacts from the nuclear accident in Japan which, of course, did not give a push to the market.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Overall, however, we see a stabilization in the course of the second half of last year. Then let us talk about the  water segment a little bit more. The main contributor to this segment today, Sulzer Pumps, with the newly  acquired Cardo Flow Solutions business, which is mainly active in the waste water business, but the division also  offers solutions for transportation and water production, later developed positively also in 2011, also supported by  new products launched to the market.  Waste water activity, and that's why you have the arrow going down, was a bit slower in 2011 compared to 2010,  and this is mainly driven by two circumstances. First of all, there was a certain weakness in the Spanish market, a  very strong market for Cardo Flow Solutions, due to the economic situation in Spain. And the other impact came  from China where we also had a sort of weakening in the waste water market due to the new five-year plan, which  was under development, and which now includes quite substantial investments into the waste water market in  that country.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: External growth, as you know, was always a key driver and a key strategic goal for Sulzer. And in the year 2011, we  could demonstrate that we are delivering and we are also able to close big acquisitions. The acquisition of Cardo  Flow Solutions at the end of 2011 – July 2011, made us a strong player in the attractive water market and also very  competitive position and good prospects for us.  We had two other add-ons in the service business in Sulzer Chemtech, which now allow us to use their local base  for other services from Sulzer Chemtech in those areas. And at the beginning of 2012, we closed another  acquisition in Spain for a pump factory, which now gives us access to the North African market and strengthens  our position in the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's have a look at Sulzer Pumps. Sulzer Pumps is a market leader in pump technology. They have a clear leading  position in oil and gas upstream and they have a top three position in water and in energy or power. The 2011  performance of Sulzer Pumps was very strong. We have a year-over-year growth in sales of 15%. We have a return  on sales of 11.9%, and we have a return on capital employed of 42.2% on adjusted basis. The number of  employees, of course, through the acquisition has also increased by quite substantially, by 1,800 and Sulzer  Pumps now employs more than 8,200 people worldwide.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The share of the water market, of course, increased through the acquisition from 10% to 16%. But the sales volume  in the other regions remained more or less unchanged and well balanced. The operating income, of course, was  impacted by the acquisition effect. Operating income was impacted by CHF30 million of non-recurring effect and  by CHF9 million, as you can see here, by [ph] I mean (21:21) five month of amortization.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The Pumps business, ex those special impact, generated 12% return on sales – sorry, 11.9% return on sales, which  is comparable to the previous year, 21% was the normal operational performance, Cardo. Just a quick reminder of  what Cardo actually stands for. Cardo, as you know, is a leading player in the water market. It supplies pumps and  other equipment for the water and the waste water treatment. And its customers are mainly municipalities,  private and public operators of plants, and also other customers in the water industry.  The integration process was carefully designed and is well on track. The group generated, in those five months,  sales of CHF180 million and it secured a strong operating result of 14% of EBITDA to sales. A new factory in  Shanghai is currently under construction, and will be up and running in third quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, what are the achievements and the next steps for Sulzer Pumps? Sulzer Pumps wants to develop its market  position, of course, in the attractive water market by also benefiting from the synergies with the newly acquired  business, the existing business, and it also wants to develop its presence in the beyond BRIC countries. It has also  put a strong focus on improving its operational excellence further. The outlook for 2012 expects a further increase  in volume, as well as in operating income.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's have a look at Sulzer Metco. Sulzer Metco is a market leader in surface solutions. It covers a wide range of  technologies and materials, and it holds a leading position in the thermal spray market. Also, Sulzer Metco's  performance in 2011 was strong, both orders and sales increased by a double digit figure on adjusted basis. Return  on capital employed also went up and is now – amounts now to over 18%, clearly value-generating level.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The highlights in 2011 are clearly the strong synergies, which could be realized now from the combination of the  electromechanical business. The key focus for 2012, the strengthening of the new business area of long-term  service agreements for the power industry. Sulzer Turbo Services expects another increase in business volume and  profitability in 2012 on a moderate basis.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: This slide now gives you an overview of how we expect our main markets to develop in 2012. Most of the markets  are expected to show a stable development or further stabilization, like in power generation. Let's start with oil  and gas. Oil and gas should develop stable on already high activity levels. For HPI, we expect also stable  development at current activity levels. This is mainly driven still by low activities in North America and in Europe.  This view is clearly supported by the [ph] Boxcore (42:28) Project Statistics, which reflects the activity level of the  HPI segment on a global scale.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: After decline in 2010 and 2011, we see a stabilization in the power generation in 2012 with some growth potential.  Major OEMs like Siemens, ABB also Alstom for power plants have reported some important orders already in  2011 for four [ph] power (42:55) plants mainly in Asia. And this should have positive impact on our business with  some time delay. Also the nuclear market shows a slow recovery after the Fukushima incident. Bear in mind, for  example, that even in the U.S., a license for a new nuclear power plant was not grant by the government.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: For water, we generally expect growth, a good development based on infrastructure needs mainly in emerging  countries. In the additional markets, we expect an ongoing solid activity from maintenance.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What do we expect from 2012? Based on the current assessment of our environment, we expect healthy and  moderate growth.

This was partially driven with the development on the shale, oil and gas  side as well as certain tar sand activities in North America. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

But, nevertheless, we saw a very good growth from our side in the  water segment there. Transportation we may have to look at it from two different market segments. texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Breakdown here, still oil and gas. Important, energy is still the biggest one and general industry. There was a little  bit of a flip in terms of oil and gas growing a little bit more than energy. But also in this case for Turbo Services,  the energy part is one of the most important market segments. Sales by geography also well balanced, nicely split.  No major difference this year compared to previous year.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Sulzer Metco showed a somewhat slower growth rate albeit in a very high level already in 2011. Our Sulzer  Chemtech division was able to keep the order volume at the level of 2011. And you have to bear in mind that in  Sulzer Chemtech, we were able to book some very large orders in 2011 in the oil and gas business.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Europe and North America were clearly the growth drivers of our business in 2012. North America increased by  22.5%. The U.S. was also driven by the gas boom where we benefit mainly from the surrounding classes like for  instance, the pipeline project. Europe's growth of 14.2%, of course, was supported by the first full year inclusion of  the Cardo business, but also by Russia which developed quite well in 2012. We had a very positive order intake  growth there in the oil and gas business but also in the power business.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The sales level reached with a little bit more than CHF4 billion, also record high for the last 10 years. All of our  four divisions contributed to this picture on a nominal, but also on an adjusted growth. Sulzer Pumps and Sulzer  Turbo Services also here reached a very high level. And you can say that both divisions actually reached a record  level in sales in 2012. Also, the service business grew by 12% and stabilized to just over 40%. And we believe this is  a good achievement because the new wastewater pump business came with a lower service share to the Pumps  division.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The sales by region looked pretty similar to order intake. Strong double-digit growth in North America, but also in  Europe. We had a decrease in South America which is of course also related to Brazil. And Asia was growing  continuously. The share of our emerging and developing markets decreased slightly to 39%, which is also because  of the lower share of our acquired wastewater business.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Thank you. Last but not least, what is our outlook and what is the conclusion from our side? I think as I  mentioned before, there were different drivers in the different market segments. And looking forward, what is our  assessment for 2013? And here again, I think we see on the oil and gas side, specifically in North America on the  pipeline business but also on oil and gas side with the FPSOs with projects in South America, a certain pocket

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Power side, it's a little bit of mixed situation how we see it here. Here we forecast to continue more or less at the  similar levels. We have seen some more investments on the renewable side. But we are here a little bit more  careful in terms of the development. Water side, clearly further growth expected in Asia but also in other areas.  That's where we see the biggest growth potential from our side. Transportation again forecasted to continue at the  similar levels. And this applies for both the aviation as well the automotive side. So all in all, we see certain key  opportunities in the market segments in which we are placed.

file: SUN - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: I would now like to explain the new disclosure structure due to the discontinuation of Sulzer Metco in the next  slide.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: I will now show you the key figures of our divisions. In Sulzer Pumps, we were faced with a very weak start into  the year. In particular, the wastewater market in Europe but also in the U.S. and in China did not show the  expected demand. The clear reduction in volumes have the effect that some major wastewater facilities were  suffering from underutilization, which drove down our operating income and our profitability.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let me now give you an update on the development of our key markets. Our largest market, oil and gas first. In the  last quarter of 2013, we have seen a generally stable picture, selected parts such as the U.S. upstream, midstream,  as well as the upstream market in Brazil continued at high levels but provided less large project.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Power is a different story. As expected, we have not seen any improvements in the last quarter of the year. The  market remained at the relatively low level, and for the full year we recorded a decrease in power driven by less  new projects in this industry.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: For water, we could not match previous year's level. This development was driven by a very weak start in  particular in municipal wastewater. The U.S., Europe and China started very slow in 2013. In the last quarter of  the year, we had some recovery in wastewater partially driven by seasonal effects, since the last quarter of the year  is usually the strongest in this industry.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: For the full year, we recorded a decrease in water driven by the weak demands in municipal wastewater and a  weak demand in Europe. The general industry was stable in Q4 compared with the previous quarters. Overall, it  was negative year-over-year.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We are convinced that the three key markets: oil and gas, power, and water are highly attractive markets  underlined by the so-called megatrends, offering opportunities for this time another growth going forward.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let's start with Sulzer Pumps. Here, we have two areas which contributed to this decrease in EBIT. First of all, our  configured pumps business which is mainly the wastewater business where we had a situation of underutilization  of capacities. And secondly, also in the engineered business and here specifically in Europe, we had less favorable  product mix. On the positive side, in the engineered business, we had quite nice increase and developments  in  Americas and Asia Pacific.

texts.speaker: Jürgen Brandt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, since the water business is the main contributor to this gap, let me give you a little bit more explanation on  the reasons for that. First of all, the volume year-over-year dropped by about 10% in sales. Then the EBIT gap,  which of course was a consequence of that cost by this business, amounted to more than CHF 20 million. The  return on sales was negative in the first half of the year. We were able to improve that as expected in the second  half, and especially due to the strong quarter. We had a positive return on sales for the configured solutions  business.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We want to become a leading supplier for performance, critical applications and provide world class services for  owned as well as third party equipment. We focus, as we mentioned, on those three key markets: oil and gas,  power, and water. And we will also remain active in some selected other industries where we have already a strong  position. On the equipment side, we focus on flow management, processing, and treatment.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: One example for our M&A strategy going forward is the very recent acquisition of the majority of Saudi Pump  Factory in Riyadh. They will be the first complete manufacturing facility in Saudi Arabia for a global pump  manufacturer of pumps according to technical standards of the American Petroleum Institute, serving one of the  largest oil and gas markets worldwide to achieve further profitable growth. It is our clear goal to leverage the  existing potential for sustainable profitable growth.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The new Sulzer is composed by three divisions supported by central group function. Our Pumps Equipment  division serves its customers with world-class equipment and spares in our three key markets. It will be a CHF 1.8  billion sales division with about 7,100 employees. The first step to establish a new water business segment was  initiated in 2013 and is now operational since January 2014. The next important steps with in the Pumps  Equipment division will be the formation of oil and gas, as well as power market orientated business unit. These  are on our agenda for 2014 and are expected to become operational beginning of 2015.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The third division is Chemtech, which will continue to serve its customers with solutions for static equipment,  such as separation technology and process technology as well as tower field services. Chemtech's annual sales  amount to CHF 7 50 million with some 4,200 employees around the globe. So the main changes are the formation  of a new, integrated service division where we combined the highly skilled service crews from pumps and turbo  services in order to leverage the potential in the service area around the globe; the formation of a water business  segment; and the creation of central group functions to support this new organizational structure.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In the year 2014, we will form now the oil and gas and power market-orientated business units within the Pumps  Equipment division. The profile of the new organization is as follows. By division, more than 50% of our sales will  be generated by our Pumps Equipment division. By region, EMEA accounts for roughly 4 3% of our sales. By  markets, oil and gas is our biggest market with roughly 51%. And by split, the sales split based on the 2013  numbers is some 56% for equipment and 44% for services.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What are now the next steps which we are planning in 2014 to further support this strategy? Our agenda for 2014  shows the next important steps to become one market-orientated company. First, we are expecting the closing of  the Sulzer Metco deal in Q3 2014. We are and we will put high emphasis on the execution of the water st rategy in  order to sustainably improve the operational performance here in the coming years. We will continue to form  business units which are market-segment-orientated in our Pumps Equipment division. And we will continue to  scan the market for targeted acquisitions in order to further strengthen Sulzer.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What is our key market assessment for 2014? Based on our present knowledge and excluding any major changes  in the general economic conditions, good activities for parts of the oil and gas markets are expected. Sulzer is well- positioned in upstream, mid and downstream oil and gas and has very good relationships to a broad customer  base.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Water is expected to show some improvement in selected regions such as the U.S. and China. The general industry  is for us a little bit of a mixed bag and, therefore, rather difficult to predict. For pulp and paper, slight increase for  small and mid-sized projects is expected for 2014. So, overall, we remain cautiously optimistic for 2014, but at the  same time continue the investment or let's continue to monitor the environment very thoroughly.

file: SUN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In a challenging market environment, especially after significant oil price drop, we achieved our financial  guidance. We were able to stabilize our profitability and the effects of the restructuring changes initiated showed  adverse results. With the implemented measures, we laid the foundation to further improve the profitability in the  coming years.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As you recall, we decided to build Sulzer's core business for equipment and services around three key markets: oil  and gas, power, water; and to maintain niche positions in selected general industry. In this market, we offer  customer-focused solutions for performance critical application. We also decided to become one focused, market- orientated, globally operating company. Let me now explain to you what we exactly mean with this.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also want to ensure we maintain the capability to continuously adapt to changes in our environment and can  deliver value to our shareholders through optimal capital allocation. You will hear more about this program in this  afternoon, but let me briefly touch on the core elements of our Sulzer Full Potential Program.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This year, the business unit water goodwill impaired by CHF 340 million relating to the wastewater business line.  With this, we are aligning book value with future growth rates and profitability assumptions. Thomas will talk in  his presentation in more detail about the impairment.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our focus markets are supported by macro trends, such as population growth, urbanization, sustainability and  energy efficiency. We therefore believe all these markets remain attractive in the long term. In 2014, we have  experienced different development in our markets. In oil and gas, demand improved despite the capital discipline  of major oil companies after the significant oil price drop. With a share of 54% in the oil and gas market, our  exposure in this market has increased. The oil price volatility limits our top line visibility in 2015, but the absolute  level of investment is still expected to remain high.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the power market, the demand decreased driven by fewer new projects. The demand in the water market was  also lower than 2013, driven especially by the engineered water business. Here, challenging conditions in South  Africa, Spain and Brazil were the main drivers. Demand in the general industry was also lower.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last year, as mentioned, we stabilized our margins and laid now the foundation to improve our profitability in the  future, especially the performance of our division Pumps Equipment is not satisfactory. The division achieved an  EBITR of CHF 141 million. The wastewater business has a significant influence in the margin deterioration over  time, but also the decentralized procurement approach and regional managed manufacturing network are  opportunities and levers to improve the profitability in the future.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me outline the key points I'm going to make during my presentation. As you heard already, sales and  profitability guidance was achieved. With stabilized margin, we took the impairment on the goodwill relating to  the business line, wastewater, and we're increasing shareholder return through increasing the ordinary dividend  by 9% to CHF 3.50. And we are updating the dividend payout range from one-third previously to 40% to 70% of  net income going forward. These reflect also our conviction that we will realize Sulzer's full potential going  forward.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: With that, let me move on to the impairment in relation to the wastewater business line. The impairment was  necessary, and it relates to the wastewater business line which, as you see on this slide here, is within the business  unit Water, and that business unit is inside Pumps Equipment.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And first, let's look at the proportions, and some of them are noted on the right side of the slide. Sulzer overall  carries about CHF 1 billion of acquired goodwill on the balance sheet, of which CHF 620 million are allocated to  the business unit Water. And almost all of that CHF 620 million resulted from the acquisition of Cardo Flow  Solutions, which is the wastewater business line today.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We understand the wastewater business line and our business unit management have solid plans in place going  forward. Therefore, to reflect this, the goodwill impairment of CHF 340 million resulted from the change of  estimated future growth rates and profitability assumptions in order to bring them in line with past performance  that we have seen and expected market development. And with that impairment as you also will note, we are  reducing the goodwill within the Water business unit by over 50%.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The markets, as you know, are becoming increasingly volatile because of the current developments in the oil  prices, some regional conflicts, and also some geopolitical development. The low oil price could influence Sulzer's  performance which accounts for 54% that you have seen of our business negatively. However, our business mix is  balanced through our 45% service share, as well as through our exposure to other markets, regions and customer  segment.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The outlook for the oil and gas market overall for us is negative, and we expect a slight decline in this market  driven by Pumps Equipment and Chemtech. In the Rotating Equipment division, we expect a stable order intake  in this market.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Activity in the power market overall again is forecasted to remain stable at a low level, although driven by the  demand in Pumps Equipment. Rotating Equipment Services expects in this market a slight increase.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Demand in the water market is expected to grow slightly driven here by Pumps Equipment.

texts.speaker: Klaus Stahlmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As shown, oil and gas, power and water are long-term attractive markets, and we know how to win in those  markets. With our products and services, we serve performance-critical applications where quality, reliability and  technology leadership are key. We have this truly global footprint with established manufacturing and service  centers. This helps us, as already mentioned by Thomas, with the current appreciation of the Swiss franc as we are  generally naturally hedged.

file: SUN - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 25February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: 2016 will be another challenging year. What we will see in a minute is that the savings from the Full Potential plan  allowed us to partially mitigate the market impact in 2015 and we aim to partially mitigate again the market  impact in 2016 knowing that there are significant headwinds, and there is uncertainty. Really, the question will be  what the overall reaction of our customers in oil and gas will be in this market environment. But we are pushing  forward what we can control, which is our Full Potential plan and we once again should be able to mitigate the  market impact in 2016.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Page 4 is a snapshot of our exposure to the market. Sulzer is a company that is 50% exposed to oil and gas, but  Sulzer is also a company that is 50% aftermarket, which is a factor of resilience. By the way, in oil and gas itself,  we are also 50% aftermarket. And Sulzer is also a company that has a pretty good geographical balance. What y ou  see from here though is that Asia-Pacific has gone in a year from 22% to 18%, and that is mainly related to China.  With that, our exposure to emerging markets has gone from 45% to 42%. Developed economies have resisted  better in this environment than the developing markets.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to the next page, page 5, we'll talk about the main market we're exposed to, Oil and Gas. We'll talk about the  other markets afterwards.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil and Gas, the high oil price volatility has led to a degree of uncertainty with our customers that has resulted in  project cancellations and postponements, therefore, fewer projects and lower investment levels. It should be no  surprise that that has had a spillover effect, which means that we've had higher competition in some of the other  segments. Not only has – CapEx were used significantly but OpEx is also under pressure because preventive  services are being pushed out by our customers.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So if you look at our overall order intake level in Oil and Gas, it has gone down by 13%. As I said, in Oil and Gas,  half of our business is aftermarket, which has been less affected. Actually when you look at oil and gas aftermarket  as a whole, we've actually grown slightly thanks to two large orders in Tower Field Services in Chemtech. So t hat's  once again is flat to slight growth in aftermarket oil and gas, Sulzer as a whole.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So that's a snapshot of how we performed in Oil and Gas in 2015. If I were to add how we view the market going  forward – these are not our numbers, these are Bloomberg numbers. But what you see is that when you look at  market expectations for Oil and Gas CapEx a year ago, and you compare them to market expectations for Oil and  Gas CapEx now, you see that there's been a significant downward swing. A year ago, people were expectin g –  observers were expecting 6% erosion for over three years and now we are talking 35% erosion versus 2014 level.  This is a dramatic change and will have significant impact on the oil and gas-related business in terms of volume,  but also in terms of pricing.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I look at 2015 and I look at the comparison between 2015 and 2014 in terms of Oil and Gas CapEx – I'm on page  7  now. If I look at Oil and Gas CapEx versus how Sulzer performed, what you see is that you see an upstream  CapEx which has gone down by almost 40% for the market. And you see a refining CapEx which has gone down by  something like 20%.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look at Sulzer's numbers, Sulzer in new equipments in Oil and Gas has gone down by about 20%. And  Sulzer, in terms of sales, has been a lot more resilient in the aftermarket. I said that our orders were flat to slightly  up and in terms of sales, we're slightly down. But, once again, 3% down, if you want the absolute number, versus  19% down for the equipment side of things. So what that shows you is that the aftermarket business is more  resilient, but it also shows you that Sulzer has been more resilient, part of that being due to our relatively high  exposure to downstream versus upstream.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to page 8 – we talk about Oil and Gas, but our business is only 50% Oil and Gas. And the other 50% has  done well. The other 50%, as you know, is the Power markets, the Water markets, and the General Industry  market. In the Power market, which represents about 16% of our orders, our order intake in 2015 is actually up. I  should actually give you a number, because it's a good number, it's up 22%. So in 2015, in a challenging year, we're  up 22% in Power.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Water, we also had a good year. It's been driven mostly by good orders in Engineered Water in the first half of  the year. Second half of the year was slower, but the first half of the year was very good in Water.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I now move to page 9, this is a snapshot of where we see the market going in the non-oil-and-gas-related  markets that we cover. So these are CapEx for publicly-listed Power Utilities predictions, and what we see is a  slight growth. And if you look at the same thing for Water Utilities, the listed ones, you also see slight growth. And  once again, these are market numbers, not our numbers, but they support what our assumptions are for next year,  which is flat-to-limited growth in new markets.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, if on a CHF 3 billion company if you say 4% to 6%, that's CHF 120 million to CHF 180 million. Now we are  saying CHF 200 million. So we've raised the bar. We haven't stepped back from our commitment. On the  contrary, we stepped up. And we also are communicating as an absolute because you have to keep in mind that  there are market headwinds, and some of that will go into mitigating those headwinds. But the cost cutting could  be blunt. The cost cutting at Sulzer, the target is CHF 200 million by 2018. Hopefully, that's clear for everybody.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to the next page, page 14, this is an overview of the Sulzer Full Potential plan cost savings, phased. So the  three years, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018 – actually that's four years – three years going forward. And what you see is  that we delivered CHF 36 million of savings in 2015. The number we'd given you as a target for 2015 was CHF 18  million, so we delivered twice what we had anticipated. I think that shows that we're running hard to make it  happen, and people are mobilized. And what we see is that we'll get to CHF 100 million to CHF 120 million in  2016. So we will have an additional CHF 60 million to CHF 80 million of profit – of P&L impact, positive P&L  impact by these actions in 2016. Full run rate by 2018 is CHF 200 million as I said, versus the CHF 120 million to  CHF 180 million that had been given before.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And if you look at what that means in terms of cost, what you have at the bottom is the cost impact. It's 1 times to  1.2 times the savings, so I think it's in line with probably most of your benchmarks. It's a reasonable number. And  as always, it's more frontloaded because when you announce, for example, a factory closure or yo u take the  provision upfront, and therefore you get the impact upfront.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will use – I will actually quote the CEO of Schlumberger. I don't know if in these meetings I'm allowed to quote  CEOs of other companies. But he made a really good point on his conference call a few weeks ago; asked about the  cost savings and the eroding profitability and when that turns around. And the message he gave and I think the  message that fully applies to Sulzer is that these actions were structural and that yes we are fighting headwinds  that lead to volume erosion and we're not fully countering that volume erosion at this point. But I think the  expression he used was, a tightly compressed coiled spring and I think it's a good image. We're compressing that  cost structure. And when the market starts picking up again, and it will, we  will be in a great position to actually  reap the benefits of everything that we are doing now. So we're mitigating current headwinds, but we are also  building the future.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will now go to the next page, and the next page is Sulzer Full Potential again. I 'm on page 15 and it gives you the  contribution to the main actions of Sulzer Full Potential to the cost savings and how far advanced we are in those.  So the light blue is what is the quantum we're expecting from all of these actions, how the CHF 200 million breaks  down essentially. And the dark blue is what we've achieved as a P&L impact to -date. Once again, this is – there's a  P&L impact as you can imagine, because this program is a year old. If you have a CHF 36 million P&L impact in  year one that probably means that you have close to twice that potential in terms of run rate, right? Because you  get some of the benefit from the actions that happened right at the beginning of the year and the actions that  happened at the end of the year don't really materialize as a P&L impact in the first year. So once again, think  about the P&L impact, which is CHF 36 million in year one, 2015, but also what the run rate is and how that will  contribute going forward.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, what we've achieved is what you see here. Y ou'll see that some of these bars have changed; the CHF 200  million has gone up versus the CHF 120 million to CHF 180 million that we had before. But the attentive  observers – and I'm sure there's a lot of them in this room and over the phone, will note that procurement is less  than it was before and our Chemtech Operational Excellence for example is more. Operational Excellence is  footprint and capacity reduction – not only that, but it's mostly that.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But if you look at 2015, you'll see that our margin on orders is slightly up versus 2014. I think it's 33.8% versus  33.5%. So we are slightly up. And we're slightly up because we are giving a large part of these procurement savings  at this point to customers, especially in Oil and Gas in order to preserve our position and  continue to build our  business.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Saving targets, they're worth what they're worth, because what matters is what you find at the end of the day in the  bottom line, but we think that we can cut indirect by something like 9%; direc t spend by something like 5%.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: While we have seen sizeable suspension of previously received orders from our oil and gas customers, we have to - date seen only very few and minor order cancellations. Sales were down 3.2% on a currency adjusted basis, mainly  due to the suspensions and headwinds in oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me walk you through the market headwinds. They come in three forms really. The first one is the volume  effect, the first bar on the left, if you see there, of CHF 38 million due to the suspended orders in oil and gas in  Pumps Equipment and the lower volumes in Chemtech's China business.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the right side, in green, you see the effects of our self-help program Sulzer Full Potential which we accelerated  as Grég already referred to, that's CHF 36 million P&L impact at a run rate level, obviously, you could say twice  that, and it's twice the level we have guided for at the mid-year point. As we already mentioned, we announced  two foundry and one factory closures last year, and we'll do more structural streamlining across the company in  2016 as required.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to the outlook section now, on page – do you have the right page number? On page 32. So what is our view  of the market going forward in 2016? Our market assessment for 2016 is in line with many of our industry peers.  We have a balanced business mix with half our sales outside of the oil and gas markets and in aftermarket  business that accounts also for half our sales.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But the company expects oil prices to remain low and to have high volatility in that market in 2016 and beyond  resulting in subdued demand and price pressure from oil and gas customers. So oil and gas 2016 will increasingly  be a difficult market.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The rest of the market, we expect to be flat for the year, so power, water and general industry. We see continued  growth, by the way, in the water segment. So water should be moving a little bit better than that.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will now summarize what we've covered today, before I hand it over to Christoph for questions. I'm now on page  35. So we've had increasing market headwinds in 2015 and we expect these headwinds to continue in 2016.  Against these headwinds, we've accelerated the Sulzer Full Potential program and we've also increased the cost  saving target from the previous CHF 120 million to CHF 180 million to now around CHF 200 million saving by  the end of 2018.

file: SUN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 1March2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Slide 4, slide 4 is a snapshot of our positioning in the market. So, the caption is the rebalancing continues. If you  look at the slide, you see that oil and gas is 45% of Sulzer and the aftermarket is 53%. Now, oil and gas is 45%.  Within the 45%, you've got the CPI market, the chemical processing market, which we're accounting as oil and  gas. If you didn't count the CPI market as oil and gas, would be at 39%, not 45%.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, a little bit of perspective, 45% or 39%, depending how you look at it is Sulzer in oil and gas today. The  rebalancing happened in two ways, really. It happened through gravity, because the oil and gas market is down  and, therefore, that's working that number down. It also happened through the acquisitions that we made,  because the acquisitions were not geared towards oil and gas and, therefore, that led to this rebalancing.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The other thing that you see on there is the numbers have changed a little bit versus last year. You see that 12%  is the part of our order intake, which is water-related. Now, I think the number we showed last year was 13%, and  we said we've been growing in water. Actually, we did a little bit of reallocation. Companies have this tendency to  kind of redo their allocations from time to time to say, well, this business is more like this and not like that. So, the  reality is that the comparable number for last year was 11%. This year is 12%. So, water is going up in terms of  the part of Sulzer that it represents.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: I would maybe add one thing, which is that order intake 53% aftermarket. Last year's number was 53% also. So,  your question could be, well, your new equipment business in oil and gas is eroding. Why isn't the aftermarket  going up? Reason for that is that our Tower Field Services in Chemtech counts significantly in the aftermarket  number. And Tower Field Services is an aftermarket business, but it's an aftermarket business which is unusual.  It's very lumpy, so it's outages, customers don't want to do an outage or turnaround. And it's a business with costs  that are mostly variable. So, our business kind of goes up and down, depending on whether customers are doing  outages or not.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Let me go to the next page. Next page is an overview of the markets. So, for those of you following online, this is  page 5, and it's our non-oil-and-gas markets. So, the 55% of Sulzer, if you include CPI, that's not oil and gas. So,  power, water and general industry. What you see on this is, I guess, a lot of green. All three of these markets  were up in 2016.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In power, we saw a good level of activity that was driven by China and India. Europe, Middle East and Africa is  still slow, but we've seen investments in gas in the U.S. The challenge that we're facing in the power market is  simple. The market is healthy, but because from a pump perspective, these are similar pumps or at least made in  the same factories as the oil and gas pumps.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Most companies that are involved in pumps for oil and gas are also involved in pumps for the power industry.  Because these companies were not getting the volume they need to load their factories from oil and gas, what  they do is they have a tendency to be very aggressive commercially on the power side of the market. So, power is  a bit contradictory, because it's a healthy market that is under a lot of price pressure because of the oil and gas  downturn.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In water, we've seen a solid municipal waste water markets in the U.S. and in China, and continuously active  desalination segments in the Middle East and in Southeast Asia.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If I take general industry for pumps, we were up despite the fact that the pulp and paper market was a little bit  down. And the final point is we have an electromechanical service business, where we – which counts in general  industry and it suffered a little bit in the UK last year. It has a big presence in the UK and we're suffering the  impacts of the changes in the British industrial landscape, to put that in an elegant way. So, that's the non-oil-and- gas markets in 2016. As I said, positive, growing, and we had some good successes in those.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If I go to the next page, page 6, that's the oil and gas picture. Now, the oil and gas picture is less rosy, as you  guys would expect. Our order intake in 2016 was down 11% versus 2015. 11% is in many ways a reasonable  number. You'll see on the next slide that the market itself – CapEx market itself was down something like 24%.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Why were we down only 11%? Because oil and gas is spilt in upstream, midstream, and downstream, and the  part that is really hurting today is the upstream markets. The upstream market was down in 2016. It will be down  again in 2017, by the way. Our customers invested less in this area. Fewer projects means higher competition,  and therefore, a lot of price pressure. That is significant, because you have to keep in mind that our orders in oil  and gas in 2016 become more sales in oil and gas in 2017. So, therefore, we are subject to that price pressure.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: That is changing. You guys saw that the oil prices went up in year 2016. What that means is that refining spreads  have gone down, and therefore, we have customers that were not stopping for anything in 2016 that are telling us  that in 2017 they will arbitrate in favor of some of these outages that need to happen. So that will be good for our  aftermarket business and downstream.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, overall, 2016 was another tough year in oil and gas. 2017 is not going to be much better. The downstream  market will continue to pick up somewhat, but the upstream market, in our view, will continue to drop in 2017  towards a trough that will happen sometime during that year. We expect to rebound in 2018, but we don't expect  big news in upstream in 2017. So, rebound in 2018, another tough year in 2017. But the light is there at the end of  the tunnel. Supply and demand will rebalance in the second half of the year, and that should mean good  commercial opportunities for Sulzer. Once again, not in 2017, but in 2018.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: That's what you see in the slide 7, which is – it's Bloomberg data. It's not Sulzer data. It's the CapEx disclosed by  the top 300 publicly traded oil and gas related companies worldwide. What you see is – I think there's a lot of  information that's interesting on this slide. What you see is that the market dropped from 2014 to 2015 CapEx by  24%. From 2015 to 2016 it dropped by 26%. Now, our oil and gas order intake was down only 11%. This counts  everything. This is CapEx. We were down 11%. Now, what we've tried to do is to break it down for you a little bit.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If you look at the box at the top, you see the Sulzer oil and gas order intake. If you take pumps new equipment,  we were down 32% from 2014 to 2015, when the market overall was down 24%, we were down 24% from 2015 to  2016, roughly in line with the market. Now, the market numbers, they include everything. They include – it's all the  CapEx. So, it's not only new equipment, obviously.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: But just to give you a feel of how our new equipment behaves, how the business behaves when the market is  down. Once again, down 32% two years ago, down 24% this year. That's the pain that we're experiencing in  terms of factory load for these oil and gas pumps. Now, if you look at the aftermarket for pumps, which if you were  to look for the numbers in Sulzer, you find most of that in RES next year. But in 2016, you had some of it in RES,  you had some of it in Pumps Equipment, because our parts business was still in Pumps Equipment.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: And then if you look at Chemtech, now Chemtech, we took the Separation Technology business. We didn't add  the TFS business, because the TFS business, as I said, it's an aftermarket business that's lumpy. If I look at the  ST business, the Separation Technology, that's a business that has a combination of new equipments and  aftermarket. We didn't separate them. We just gave you the numbers as they are.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: All right. So, let's go into an update now on the Sulzer Full Potential plan. I'm on page 9 now. Page 9 is the –  there's a chart, which the top of it is the savings and the bottom of it is the costs. So, the short version of this slide  is we're ahead of schedule and ahead of targets on SFP. We're delivering as much or more than what we were  expecting, and we're doing that quicker than we expected.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So let's go to page 10. That's the breakdown of the SFP savings, indirect procurement, SG&A, and then the three  divisions that we have in 2016. What you see on here is that we're at CHF 124 million of P&L savings since  inception. That is ahead of the plan, and it's more than halfway towards our CHF 200 million number.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What you also see on there is that we've made a lot of progress in Rotating Equipment Services and Chemtech,  where we've delivered most of the plan. Still have a little bit of work on the Pumps Equipment side, because we're  still – we've announced a lot of things. Some of these measures are under social consultation currently; and  therefore, we have to give that due process, but we'll make up for that in 2017.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: The reason why we have not included that in the SFP number is that usually what happens is if you take any  comparable plan – you look at other companies, most of them actually do include the direct procurements within  their saving plans when they have to do something like this. And usually direct procurement is about a third of the  number. I benchmarked that in my previous job, because we were trying to see whether we're aggressive enough.  It's about a third usually, 30% to 40% roughly.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: These companies are direct comparables. They're not all a perfect fit for Sulzer, because some companies don't  have the same portfolio we have. Some companies are not present in the same markets. If you take a pump  company that is mostly water, they'll behave differently from a pump company that's mostly a sort of mining and  fracking, to give an example. But still, as a population, there's enough of them on this page to give you some feel  for where we are.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Looking at the quarterly order intake development here on slide number 14, you really see a two-part story. The  first part is 2015, where we saw a clear downward trend in orders as a result of weak oil and gas demand, and  you see it here on the slide on the left-hand side. The second part is 2016, where we have bottomed out  commercially at an average order level of around CHF 700 million per quarter, including acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: And in Q4, we saw a nice rebound. Q4 orders came in 19% higher than Q4 2015, and the driver of the order  increase in Q4 compared to a year ago was oil and gas, which was flat in Pumps Equipment and up in Rotating  Equipment Services and in Chemtech. Q4 also was 14% up sequentially driven by oil and gas, which was up 18%  for Sulzer overall and driven by Geka.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Notable achievement for our Rotating Equipment Services division, which was able to limit its profitability erosion  to 30 basis points versus the prior year in a tough oil and gas market setting. Chemtech, it's here the bright spot at  an 11.4% opEBITA margin compared to 10.1% last year, helped by increased profitability at Sulzer Mixpac  Systems and underlying profitability improvement in all other Chemtech business units due to the Sulzer Full  Potential initiatives that Torsten and his team have carried out. On top of that, Chemtech profitability clearly  benefited from the consolidation of Geka in here.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Now, let me comment on the headwinds, which come in three forms. First, as a volume effect of about CHF 18  million due to the lower order intake in oil and gas from the year before. Second, in the margin column, here right  in the middle, you have a CHF 52 million price effect, as pricing has been under pressure across the board in oil  and gas and in power, mainly in the new equipment space, but also in the service and aftermarket space. And the  third effect of this challenging down-market is underabsorption in our factories, shown here as other costs of CHF  56 million.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: And then lastly, on the right-hand side of the chart in green, you see the effect of our Sulzer Full Potential self- help program. We have accelerated our SFP program for an CHF 88 million favorable P&L impact in 2016, and  that's nicely ahead of the CHF 60 million to CHF 80 million savings range we had initially guided for. We are able  to accelerate SFP savings mainly in the indirect procurement and selling and admin categories, as Grég  mentioned before, as well as in Chemtech, Pumps Equipment, and headquarter group functions.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If I go to another change that we made for the beginning of 2017, we announced to you last year that we were  taking our parts business for pumps that was still in the Pumps Equipment division and putting it in the service  division in RES. Now, why did we do that? We explained it last year, we had already moved the field service and  the workshops to the RES division, and it was kind of strange from a customer perspective to essentially have a  customer that wanted parts and service to be talking to one Sulzer division for the service and one Sulzer division  for parts. It wasn't very efficient.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Another acquisition that we're excited about, but we haven't closed yet, Rotec, Rotec gas turbine service, haven't  closed yet because we're still tying up loose ends. It's more of a regulatory aspect, but it's planned for the end of  Q1. Hopefully, we can keep that to that timing. There's no particular difficulty. It's just we're closing a deal in  Russia and takes a bit of time.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Rotec gas turbine, it's the gas turbine service part of Rotec. There's a larger Rotec business that does other  things, like EPC and software that has nothing to do with us. They also do steam turbines, nothing to do with us.  We're buying the business that does gas turbine service. It's CHF 35 million of sales. As you see from there, it's  20% EBITDA. It's a very similar business to our turbo service business that's in RES.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What it does for us is that it increases significantly our presence in one of the exciting markets for gas turbine  service. And the gas turbine service is really competitive these days. It's competitive mostly because the market is  down a bit, because utilities were not running their gas turbines as much because of the beneficial aspects of  renewables. That has led into a bit of a price war that's driven by the big OEMs, so the GE and Siemens  essentially, to name them.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: But we have a good position in this space as a large independent. Our customers value the fact that we're  independent. They also want us to be local and to have a footprint. And by buying this business, we get full  localization in Russia with the business that's based in Moscow, but the workshop – that blade workshop in  Ekaterinburg. So, our business in Russia for gas turbine service goes from being CHF 5 million to being CHF 40  million, which is significant, and we think we can grow from there.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Last acquisition that we announced right at the end of the year, actually we closed already because it was a  simpler one to close, is this Vessel Internal Electrostatic Coalescer, VIEC. It kind of rolls off the tongue, as you  can see. We're marketing geniuses. It's a complicated name, but it's a good business. It's – really we're buying a  product range that was developed by Wärtsilä. It's a product range to separate oil and water in the upstream  markets. It's inline separation. It allows us to do that very effectively with a smaller footprint. It has lot of upstream  applications for the oil and gas sector, where you're trying to get these equipments fitting into a smaller space to  save space on rigs or vessels or these types of installations.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We expect that the oil and gas market will rebalance, rebalancing between supply and demand sometime in the  second half of 2017. I know some observers were saying earlier, our read is second half. But if we keep could  predict the oil and gas market in a really accurate way, Thomas and I would be rich. So, take it as an indication,  it's a conservative indication versus what some other people are saying.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: In power, we see that the gas market should develop positively. But there's, as I said, a lot of competition on the  service side driven by the OEMs. Coal is still substantial, but it's decreasing with the exception of Asia. And we  expect that price pressure that's carrying over from oil and gas to continue in power in 2017.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Water, we see active markets in municipal and desalination. And general industry, general industry at Sulzer is a  sum of different things. If I take APS, we believe everything will grow in 2017, dental, beauty, industrial adhesives.  If we take our general industry market for pumps, for example, we think that pulp and paper will be healthy. We  think that metals and mining will remain challenging, but that the commodity cycle is turning and that business will  start to improve slowly. And that's our view of the market for 2017.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, we had a very successful Q4 in a difficult market. I think Q1 is going to be softer from a market perspective  and softer from a Sulzer perspective. We expect the Q1 in terms of orders to be somewhere around the 2016  level. It doesn't change anything to our guidance for the full year, 5% to 8% up, but we're just wanting to manage  you guys' expectation so that you don't think that the storm is over and everything is linear from now on. The oil  and gas market strongly is not linear currently, and Q1 will be soft for everybody, I think, in oil and gas for the  reasons that I've mentioned, certainly for Sulzer. But still, order intake 5% to 8% up on the year for 2017.

texts.speaker: Grégoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: I'm moving now to our last slide on page 33. It's a summary slide, so I'll repeat things that I've already said. Oil  and gas headwinds will continue in 2017. That market will continue to be really challenging. Upstream will be  down. We think downstream will be up a little bit. We think the price pressure will continue to be significant. We do  expect a rebound for Sulzer in oil and gas in 2018.

file: SUN - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 28February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What you see on here is that order intake in 2017 is back to growth in Pumps Equipment even organically as oil  and gas starts to recover from its lows. Downstream continue to improve and upstream is also up from very  depressed levels. On the other hand, the power markets, the power segments for us suffer from fewer projects for  new power plants especially in China. If we take oil and gas and power together, if you want to call that energy,  the order intake was essentially flat is plus 0.6%.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: If I look at the other segments over Pumps Equipment activity, the municipal water segment for us was growing  steadily by around 3%. And in pulp and paper we also had a very successful year. Usually, we report general  industry and pulp and papers within general industry. We broke it out because actually pulp and paper is half of  general industry. So, I think it's valuable information.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: We also announced in December the acquisition of a business called JWC in the U.S. It's grinders and shredders  for wastewater. It's a significant acquisition in the sense that it's $250 million of enterprise value. But it's a  significant acquisition mostly because it's the first acquisition we make in our water business in what I would  describe as post turnaround.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: As you remember, we bought Cardo Flow a few years ago. We had a few hiccups with that integration right after  [ph] the effect (00:10:32), an impairment down the road. But as I explained over the last two years, our water  business has been improving steadily, and we're quite satisfied with how it's performing today. So, we've opened  up the checkbook again for that activity. And the JWC acquisition is a good illustration of that.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: It will allow us to grow in the key U.S. municipal wastewater market, in which JWC has very good distribution  channels. And the Sulzer platform will allow JWC, which is quite a U.S.-centric business at this point, to grow  internationally. So, it's a really good fit from a product perspective, and it's also a really good fit from a growth  perspective in terms of commercial access, both for JWC and for the existing Sulzer businesses.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Order intake in RES, I'll split it in the various segments. I'll start with the turbo service segment, which as you guys  know is mostly service for gas turbines and compressors and various other rotating equipments, but a lot of it is  gas turbine service, a market on which a lot of things have been written in the last few months given  [indiscernible] (00:13:06) reporting.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Despite lower organic sales and price pressure from the OEMs, the operational profitability, operational EBITA  margin increased in 2017 in RES on cost savings and on the positive contribution of Rotec gas turbines. The  acquisition of Rotec, which I mentioned a minute ago June 29, 2017, it allows us to build a really strong platform  in Russia. We're certainly the strongest independent in Russia for gas turbine service.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: And in terms of footprint, we have local capabilities that I think even outweigh some of the OEMs. So that is a lot  of gas turbines in Russia and this business was very successful for us in 2017. Rotec, the integration was  smooth, and commercially, we had lots of successes. The business made significant contribution to RES in order  intake in sales and in operational profitability in 2017. So, good acquisition, good timing for us, and we continue to  see good market prospect for that business in Russia.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Some companies will have valves and we don't have valves, some of them will have seals and we don't have  seals, some of them won't have oil and gas exposure and we have oil and gas exposure, some of them are pure  water-pump companies and – it's a very different market. It's really hard to have a long-term comparison. But  that's the indicator we chose, so we continue to try to walk you through it. What we said three years ago is that we  were middle-of-the-pack in about 730 basis points below the market leaders. What we are showing on the right is  that we're getting closer to the leaders and our gap is now 350 basis points. Same gap as last year roughly.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Why am I not a fan of the slide? I'm not a fan because of something that we've added on here to help you guys.  We don't give company names because it's always awkward to comment the performance of your competitors  and the objective is to talk about Sulzer. But we've added color coding. What you see in blue here are the  companies with oil and gas exposure, sorry. So, these ones, and what you see here is that maybe three years  ago, when we started using this indicator, it was interesting because it showed Sulzer was middle-of-the-pack  whether we compared ourselves with companies that have oil and gas exposure or not.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: What you see on the right is that we've improved our operations, we've taken cost out and we're a better  performing company. But what you also see is that out of the four companies that perform better from a  profitability perspective, performed better than Sulzer, three of them don't have any oil and gas exposure. So, now  that we've improved the business, now that we've become more cost effective, now that we've become more  competitive, the slide essentially becomes a proxy for oil and gas exposure, which I'm not sure is a very useful  tool at this point. But, you know, it is what it is.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: For a full disclosure, the only company that performed better on an adjusted profitability perspective than Sulzer in  2017 and does have oil and gas exposure is – it starts with a W, and ends with an R, and the letters in between  are E and I; I think Weir. These guys are cyclicality on cyclicality, right, mining and fracking. So, a very different  play from Sulzer. It's – I don't think you shareholders for the same reasons, but that's our comparison.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, hopefully, that explains to you that we have improved, we're doing well, we can't make the fact that we've got  45% oil and gas exposure go away. By the way, we're not trying to make that go away because we think that in  the next few years, that's going to be very virtuous for Sulzer, as the market recovers. But that's the way our peer  group pans out at this point of our development.

texts.speaker: Thomas J. W. Dittrich
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Moving on to slide number 16, I'll walk you through the operational profitability bridge from 2016 to 2017. You  know that slide we have been showing it to you every six months. And as you can see savings from our SFP  program of 2.2 percentage points in green more than offset the market headwinds of about 1.7 percentage points.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Okay. So, the first slide is the market outlook. You see the split of Sulzer according to end markets: we're 30%  general industry; we're 11% water; we're 16% power, and 43% oil and gas. What you see on here is that we  expect growth everywhere except in power. Power is going to be challenging for 2018. We expect the market in  power to decline because of the, what we mentioned about the gas turbines. The gas turbine market and gas  turbine service market with volume and price pressure. And also on the pump side, we see fewer power plant  projects especially in coal and that has an impact on our – on our Pumps Equipment business.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: So, power will be depressed. Nuclear actually will be – will show some interesting opportunities but nuclear is very  lumpy. Big projects in some specific countries like Russia, China and therefore is a lot harder to predict. But  power overall is going to be a drag for us and everything else is going to be, is going to be positive. Oil and gas,  we expect the downstream market to continue on its 2017 trend. And in upstream, we're seeing a notable  increase in inquiries. It doesn't mean that they'll translate into orders in 2018 but clearly the level of inquiries is up  significantly and our customers were back at evaluating projects and trying to decide where they're going to invest  their money and those are good signs.

texts.speaker: Gregoire Poux-Guillaume
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sulzer AG
texts.text: Our working assumption at Sulzer is just that that upstream recovery will not lead to significant order upswing in  2018 but will lead to good things in 2019 but as I've said, downstream already rebounded in 2017 and will  continue to rebound in 2018.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, as you can see, the environment has become increasingly challenging, and Tony will come back through the  operations in more detail. texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let me turn now to outlook for the rest of the year, in Severn Trent Water, we expect OpEx to be higher year-on- year in the full-year due to increased in investments of our networks, higher input costs and higher quasi taxes  and these will be offset to some degree by efficiency savings. However, our expectation is that OpEx for the full  year will be below the level of the final determination.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: Severn Trent Water and Services and then a few comments on sector development since we last met, including  Ofwat's recent consultations.
