texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: So starting with Severn Trent Water, we have already started to deliver in those areas that we targeted for  improvement at the start of the year, specifically our unplanned interruptions, our leakage, our supply availability  and serviceability from our networks. Incidentally, those were the areas highlighted in Ofwat's annual  performance report. And following the severity of the last three winters, we have increased our network  replacements activity, and our infrastructure renewals have increased period-on-period. As you can see on the  chart, unplanned interruptions has benefited from that investment, showing a reduction in rates, compared to the  start of the year. On leakage, we are on target year to date, and indeed, as the winter approaches, we have already  put in place additional resources to deal with the challenges that the cold weather can represent, so prudent  approach to maintaining investment in our network to maintain serviceability.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: I should also add on the supply availability that we have no anticipation of any winter drought orders in our area.  We continue to build on our leading position on renewables, increasing our generation now to 23.8% of our total  requirement, that's an increase of about 440 gigawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: On our key performance indicators, we've now completed our annual update of the KPI benchmarks, and I'm  pleased to report that we have improved in three areas. Critical ones for our customers, being first-time call  resolution for billing, achievements of our sewage treatment consent, and our employee motivation score. In two  areas, customer written complaints and sewer flooding, our performance has moved back to medium  performance, but we now only have two areas in the lower quartile performance, supply availability and  unplanned interruptions, both of which, as I've indicated, we're already seeing improvements on.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: Now just in case anybody forgets what our business is about, we are about water and waste treatment and right at  the heart of everything we do is our continued focus on process and technology improvement. So just a couple of  we're using new for the UK and new for Severn Trent. We developed this, a new Anammox treatment process,  ANaerobic AMMonium OXidation. Essentially, it's a more efficient biological treatment process that should allow  us to reduce the amounts of energy in chemicals that we're using in treatment, compared to our traditional  methods.

In our U.S. operating services in the first six months, we experienced lower bid activity and slower customer  project work, as municipality funding came under squeeze.

texts.text: Looking ahead, now, on sector developments, there have been a few significant regulatory developments. Overall,  we are very pleased that many of the ideas that we've promoted through our change in cost engagement strategy  have now been incorporated within these. In August, Ofwat published their views on increased customer  engagement. There is that builds on the successful customer engagement work we did at our last price review, so  Trent Water Forum that will be a customer-oriented panel that will be a fundamental part of our PR14 price  preparation.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: In October, Ofwat published their views on regulatory compliance, again, suggesting things that we've been  talking about, a move towards more risk-based regulation. And then just this week, on Wednesday morning, we  saw Ofwat's opening consultation on future price limits for PR14. In there, we see their desire for simpler  regulation, reiteration of greater customer involvement, confirmation that we are looking at five-year wholesale  and retail price limits. Incidentally, that confirmed that there would be – allocation of the RCV will be entirely to  the wholesale component, a greater focus on outcomes, and a shift of incentives to total expenditure, and of  course, some support for water trading. Now we're working through the detail of all of those proposals to prepare  our responses, but we remain confident that Severn Trent is well-placed to address any of those regulatory  changes.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: Finally, we're expecting the Defra white paper, we believe that will be published sometime in December. They are all things that we're extremely familiar with and have been at the core of our changing course  preparation.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thank you, Mike. Well, as I said earlier, I'm going to cover two areas. First of all, our operational performance in
texts.text: So in summary, we have our plans in place and we are delivering operational improvements. So far, PDaS, private  drains and sewers, is going well. In Severn Trent Services, whilst the long-term drivers  remain positive, we have to stay focused on the current economic climate. The recent consultations that we've  seen that is shaping, certainly, PR14 in the future of the sector, we're reasonably comfortable with their echoing  the direction that we've been setting in changing course. And of course, we remain committed to delivering our  sustainable shareholder value and our dividend promise.

file: SVTL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 27November2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I'm pleased to say that we're performing in line with expectations. We've made good progress in making the  additional investment we announced back in May, and we're delivering the resultant improvement in many of our  operational areas. Striving for continuous improvement, so far this year we're seeing that in a number of areas  such as supply interruptions, security of supply. We're on track to deliver improvement in our serviceability on  our water distribution networks. On our non-regulated side, we're making both operational improvements and  exiting the Metering Installation business and our Severn Trent Laboratories business.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Group PBIT, pre-exceptional charges, was down modestly at 2.6%, and that's a result of the higher infrastructure  expenditure that we announced earlier this year and depreciation at Severn Trent Water. And in addition, we have  some costs of course this time around additional costs related to private drains and sewers. Severn Trent Water  turnover and PBIT we'll talk about in a little moment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The third driver was the impact of measured consumption. And this period has been down 2.8% due essentially to  the wet summer with commercial consumption, and in particular, agricultural consumption much lower than we  expected. And this resulted in an £11.4 million decrease in turnover compared to the previous period.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Hired and contracted costs were lower in the period falling by £3.4 million, and this was due to the scaling back of  work following the big focus we had in the second half of last year on leakage reduction, which was largely  successful. Tony will come back on the leakage question later.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Power costs have increased by £3.7 million in the period due to higher consumption, mainly caused by the wet  weather, and we've got some of that today and higher strike prices on our energy cost hedging compared to the  previous year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Even though the operating environment we would still classify as difficult, we have seen some improvements in  the current period, in contrast to the weaker performance we saw a year ago. Like-for-like turnover increased by  9.5% while PBIT increased just under 2%. And this has been led by significant growth in disinfection products  within water purification, particularly gas feed and electrochlorination, and as well as the launch of our BALPURE  product, which contributed £2.5 million of sales, and we have about £3 million in orders. Early days but  nonetheless we have £3 million of orders for BALPURE on our books.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So Group outlook for the rest of the year 2012 and 2013, as Tony highlighted, we believe we are on track to deliver  our expectations. Within Severn Trent Water, OpEx is expected to be higher year-on-year due to the increased  investments on networks, higher input costs and higher taxes, partially offset by some efficiency savings that we  continue to deliver.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning to some of the key operational functions now, we are delivering improvement in critical areas. Looking at  which looks at interruptions greater than 12 hours, and it's a key component of the serviceability assessment at the  end of the year. That's benefited from our increased infrastructure investment and something like a 50%  reduction so far there.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Compared to our performance in September – sorry, comparing our performance to September this year to the  position at March, we've also improved high water quality, enhancing our water treatment processes, something  I'll touch on in a little more detail. And on leakage, we've now achieved a further 4% reduction since March and  we're on plan to meet our Ofwat year-end target of 468 megaliters.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So overall, an improving picture but with those three deteriorations and just very quickly, the first one of those is  higher greenhouse gas emissions. Very straightforwardly, we have used more energy this year with our less than  average weather causing us to spend more energy in pushing water and waste through the networks. And the  other two areas are internal floodings and pollution incidents. What we're seeing there is the additional numbers  coming through that we're experiencing with the advent of the private drains and sewers adoption. But in both of  those areas, we are such – from the higher base, we are showing an improving trend.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Moving on to our investment program, in May, we announced that we would be investing an additional £150  million over the rest of the AMP period to improve some of our network performance metrics and critically to  deliver stable serviceability in our water distribution network.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As you've seen from our performance on interruptions, that is working. For example, we've invested an additional  £6 million addressing trunk mains renewals. We've been resurveying the whole of our 5,500-kilometer network of  mains to see where there is additional remedial action that we could take.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've trained over 150 people – of our people in improved incident management techniques and we've made  more tankers and pumps available to be on standby for deployment not only when a mains burst but you've seen  some of the flooding going on around the UK at the moment, but in deployment of our field activities to handle  that.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've also been enhancing our water treatment works installing more ultraviolet disinfection. For instance, at  three boreholes, we've three more to do. That's a much more sustainable solution for improving water quality.  With UV, there are no chemicals involved and the whole life treatment cost is actually lower. We've accelerated  our refurbishments on some of the filters of our larger surface water treatment works and we're re-engineering  our disinfection processes at one of our largest treatment works in Birmingham.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: All of these investments are helping us to deliver water to our customers which, as they tell us, they wanted always

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning to the non-regulated activities, during the first six months of the year, we had a number of changes and  some positive operational trends. We formed our new company, Severn Trent Costain, with Costain Group PLC to  provide water and waste treatment services to high volume commercial and industrial users as that new retail  market now starts to develop in the UK, and I'm pleased to say that we were able to land the first national  customer switch in the UK.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In operating services, overall, we saw a solid performance. In the U.S., we've increased our contract base, and in  the UK, our MOD contract delivered good performance. In products, revenue and PBIT were both up period-on- period led by significant growth in the disinfection products, particularly gas feed electrochlorination as people  are starting to build again, and as Mike has already mentioned, orders now for our Ballast Water Treatment  product BALPURE.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: First, to limit the degree of flexibility that Ofwat is seeking, and we've suggested that that could be done by  limiting that flexibility to removing retail sludge processing and water resource management from wholesale  controls. Alternatively, we suggested that could also be limited by reducing the limit on the revenues from  wholesale to be exposed to competition to 20% rather than 40% in the proposal.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In line with Ofwat's proposals, what will set out there will be a series of outcomes that we could deliver and that  will then be an opportunity for our stakeholders to seek to influence how we balance those outcomes. You may  also have seen recently our published joint report with National Grid changing course through sustainable  financing options to encourage equity financing in the water and the energy sectors. And we have copies of this  outside. If you don't have one, please do take one, and watch out for a forthcoming publication that we have  commissioned from KPMG and titled Financing Infrastructure in the Water Sector Beyond 2015.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, a new and the key part of the PR14 process is something called the Customer Challenge Group that Ofwat  Buckland, who is also the National Chair of the Consumer Council for Water. And the members of the panel are  drawn widely from our statutory regulators of the DWI, Environment Agency, Natural England from CCWater,  Citizens Advice Bureaus, interest groups like the NFU and the CBI, and local authority representation from across  the East and West Midlands.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So in summary, we have delivered again on our commitment. We're delivering the investment program, and we're  seeing the consequent operational improvements in the areas that we've targeted. We're making good progress  developing our processes and plans for the next price review, PR14. And we remain supportive of the principles of  reform of the water industry and we believe we're well positioned to benefit from those opportunities.

file: SVTL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 26November2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Group PBIT pre-exceptional charges was up 0.4%, despite rising power costs and higher depreciation in Severn  Trent Water, and of course, lower PBIT from non-regulated businesses. With the net interest charge rising almost  £10 million period-on-period, underlying profit before tax excluding gains on financial instruments and  exceptional items was 5.8% lower.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The third driver was the impact of measured consumption. Now this was slightly higher period-on-period due to  the dry summer we saw in 2013, compared to the unusually wet period last year. And this resulted in a small  increase in turnover of around about £3 million.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Hired and contracted costs rose by a small amount to £2.4 million. Materials were lower period -on-period by £1.7  million, and this again is mainly due to some lower spend in wastewater treatment areas. With costs in other areas  increasing by £1.1 million, overall directly managed costs grew by 2% in the period and that was below the level of  inflation.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So moving on to indirectly managed costs, those that we have less control over, we have, however, been able to  keep our bad debt chart stable at 2.2% of turnover and this results in a slight increase of £400,000 period -on- period. Power costs, however, have increased by £4.4 million in the period due to higher strike prices on our  energy costs compared to last year. And rates and services charges, including the CRC levy this period was  basically flat.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now moving on to tax. There was a total current tax credit in the period of £12.8 million. Now, this included an  exceptional current tax credit in the period of £44 million and this reflects the anticipated refund of overpayment  of corporation tax in prior periods. This has arisen from the resolution of a longstanding industry discussion with  HMRC over the tax treatment of certain capital expenditure within our water and wastewater treatment works.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, turning to outlook for the full year. Looking first to the regulated business, we expect consumption to be  slightly higher year-on-year given the trend that we've seen in the first half. OpEx costs for the year are expected  to be in line with the final determination on the like-for-like basis. OpEx will be higher year-on-year due to  inflation, and of course, power costs. And this we partly offset by our continuing efficiencies which we will see  during the year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We have the lowest average combined water and waste bills in England and Wales. We've absorbed cost increases  such as private drains and sewers. And we've maintained our focus on bad debt. We have one of the lowest bad –  levels of bad debt in the industry. And we do this by helping our customers with a very wide range of social tariffs  and solutions, from payment plans to water efficiency advice, to working directly with the Departments of Work  and Pensions, to innovative work with Citizens Advice Bureau.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, what does that look like on the ground? How has our operational perfo rmance been? Well, let me start with  customer – sorry, let me start with operational improvements. And again, we're delivering improvement in the  critical areas. Our sewer flooding, particular area of focus for this year, has seen a further 31% reduction i n  incidents on a rolling 12-month basis. That's compared to March 2013. Our water supply interruptions, that  interruption is greater than three hours for our customers, that's benefited from some of that increased  infrastructure investment, and we're showing a 41% reduction compared to March.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And on our environmental performance, pollution incidents, a reduction of a third compared to the position at  March. Now, that's manifesting itself as well in our customer service performance as assessed by the SIM or   Service Incentive Mechanism. Y eah, last year, our SIM score improved by 12% year -on-year, and that put us in  fifth place overall out of the water and sewage companies. These charts show you outperformance for the first six  months over the last three years and you can see that we've made good sustained progress on both qualitative and  quantitative measures.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now one continuous improvement, you all know by now, we do not believe in de minimis levels of performance.  We're always striving for something else, and innovation is at the heart of that. So an example – another example  of innovation here, as you know, we are the industry leader for producing energy through anaerobic digestion in  our sewage treatment process. But we're now also starting to invest in technology that can extract another  byproduct, very specifically phosphorous, in that waste process.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Unchecked phosphorous actually causes huge problems. It's a pollutant in rivers, but it also clogs up our pipes and  assets, so extra on cost for operation and maintenance. So Stoke Bardolph in Nottingham, large sewage treatment  work, treats most of the sewage waste coming from the City of Nottingham, we've been building a new plant that  allows us to extract the phosphorous from our digestion plant and process by biological means.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, having extracted that, that is then a super agriculture fertilizer that we can sell on to farmers.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now not only has that saved significant capital and operational costs over conventional solutions, but it also  extends our ability to deploy wholly biological solutions rather than chemical solutions. And of course, that's great  for our environmental performance. So we have the first installed in the UK, but we have the opportunity and the  potential to roll that technology into our rather large waste site refurbishments.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Where is it going? Well, we're continuing to invest in our water treatment works, ensuring our water is always  good to drink, improved disinfection specifically that our borehole works, and improved filtration are some of the  schemes.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We're continuing our program of trunk main replacement and leakage reduction, 38,000 repairs so far this year.  And you can see the benefit of that in our reduction in supply interruptions. We're also improving the network  flexibility so we can move water around our network more easily to improve the resilience of the network and  protect customers from loss of supplies.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On waste water, it's investment in treatment works and ensuring that we have a good environmental compliance  there and we are delivering our best ever performance on that. The other target for investment on the waste  network is on the sewerage network and particularly our proactive work reducing blockages. A nd this is investing  more in CCTV surveys, particularly targeted at those areas where we have the propensity for networks to block.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, just before I turn to our Q&As, one final update on our continuing Changing Course p ublications. Just  recently, we published the document around the implementation of the Water Framework Directive. It's there on  our website if you've not seen it at all.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The key message there, and there's a bit of a crossover here with what our customers have told us in PR14, is that  Water Framework Directive is a good thing. Improving the ecological status of rivers is a good thing. Customers  want that. However, customers don't want to see huge price rises to pay for it. So, what we set out in Changing  Course is our proposed solution to a measured implementation of the Water Framework Directive.

file: SVTL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 25November2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our capital investment program is on track to deliver the AMP5 spend of £2.6 billion, and we've brought forward  £15 million of AMP6 spend to make sure we hit the ground running on the April 1st next year. We're stable. We're  improving on 13 of the 14 Ofwat Key Performance Indicators in the first six months of the year, with some really  good improvements in areas that customers truly value most, such as, for example, sewer flooding.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As a company, we probably haven't told our customers about their lowest bills as much as maybe we should, but  this is something we plan to do much more in the future. And in line with the promise we made in our AMP6  business plan, we're looking forward to launching a new social tariff in April next year in conjunction with the  Citizens Advice Bureau.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Internal sewer flooding incidents, pollution incidents and leakage, are all improved; and we're in a good position  on leakage going into the winter as the target we agreed with Ofwat of 453 mega liters per day for this year. And as  you'll see on the chart, we're ahead of that, up 427 mega liters.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And whilst our sewer blockages performance has improved on interruptions greater than 12 hours, a single major  incident has negatively impacted this metric in the first six months. At our water treatment works, we've got a  program to improve performance which, as we said all along, will take time to  implement fully although we are  pleased to see initial progress. So more to do, we are progressing well with our plan.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And the last of my slide before I hand over to Mike is to talk about what are we doing to get ourselves ready to  deliver in AMP6. I've been working closely with my team to ensure that the business is in the right shape and  ready to deliver right from the very start of AMP6. We've welcomed two new members to the team since we last  spoke in May, Helen Myers, our new Group Commercial Director has joined us; and Sarah Bentley, our new Chief  Customer Officer, starts work on Monday. Plus we've made some further organizational change such as merging  previous Water and Waste teams into a single wholesale operations team, which will make us more effective  across the organization.

texts.speaker: Michael James Edward McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Our long run planning assumption is that measured consumption will fall mainly due to lower commercial usage.  This indeed was what we saw but this was offset by higher than expected household usage over the period. We also  had a small positive impact from consumption in the prior period due to the very dry summer in 2013.

texts.speaker: Michael James Edward McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: A proportion of this cost was also related to investment to improve our service. There was a £1.5 million increase  in own work capitalized. Hired and contracted costs also rose by £1.5 million. With materials higher period-on- period due to a higher spend in waste, cost in other areas are also increasing. We've been able to keep the bad debt  charge at 2.2% of turnover, with a small increase of £0.4 million. Power costs have actually reduced in the period  by £700,000 due to the higher levels of renewable generation we brought on stream this period and a small  supply of credit that we received in the period. And this saw an increase – and quasi taxes also saw an increase of  £2 million.

file: SVTL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 26November2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And recently, we ran a competition whereby we asked all of our people around the various water treatment works.  We asked them to bottle and to brand their water. And effectively, that gave us the various variety that you see  there. We, then, as an employee of the Severn Trent, all got the chance to taste and to vote for our favorite of the  types of water. And this is the winner, Severn's Finest.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So let's start. So if you might recall back in March, we had our Capital Markets Day. And at the Capital Markets  Day, we laid out our vision where we wanted to go between now and 2020. And it was based on the premise of the  fact that we wanted to make sure that bills are fantastically affordable, that we were environmental leaders, and  we value fantastic customer service. And that combined together would create the most trusted water company by  2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Simultaneously, as a senior team, we need to work out on making sure that we're sector leaders in efficiency. So  we're absolutely keeping the march going on our renewable agenda, and again, collectively together, we believe  that would help us to be successful in new competitive markets. So these are the areas that we think will create a  winning formula.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: On ODIs, for example, this is a very tricky year to get to any form of green payout on ODIs. If you look at the step  change you have to deliver, it's double-digit percentage improvements across a wide range of measures against  which they're measured, and that total just add up to an overall number. We're really pleased that the hard work  of our colleagues has meant that at the half-year position, we're now comfortable enough to be guiding you toward  the £10 million upside for this year, when previously we've guided towards flat for the first year. Now, these are  the measures that our customers said they really cared about, so really, this is us fulfilling our promise to our  customers to provide them with improving and great customer service.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The fourth lever is around energy cost. And quite simply, energy is the second most expensive thing in a water  company. And that means our ability to self-generate energy has to be good news both in the short and the long  term. And since we last spoke, there's an improvement of 4% in terms of our self-generation performance. That  takes from 28% to 32% self-generation. It puts us well on track for the 50% self-generation that we plan to do  between now and 2020.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And I think we can also see under this new regulatory framework that when we deliver better outcomes for our  customers, for our communities, and for our environment, that also delivers increasing value for our shareholders  as we can benefit from ODIs and our growing RCV. And we are investing in schemes that will ensure great water  and wastewater services in our region for generations to come.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In May, I explained that we're aligning the group into two divisions, Regulated Water and Waste Water and  Business Services. Regulated Water and Waste Water is the heart of our business, comprising wholesale waste and  water operations on our regulated household retail business. I've shown here the turnover for Regulated Water  and Waste Water from both a like-for-like and a new reporting basis. Like-for-like, our turnover is down £12  million or 1.5% due to the £25 million impact of lower prices, offset by some modest benefits from new growth,  meter optants, tariff mix, and other changes.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: To get to the new reported basis of turnover of £754.4 million, we stripped out the £12 million of regulated  renewable energy revenue that we're now reporting in our Business Services division, and just under £15 million  of revenue from non-household retail. This is a net number as £200 million of external non-household revenue is  now reported in Business Services, and this is offset by the £185 million of our Regulated Water and Waste Water  division charges for the related wholesale services.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the new reporting basis, PBIT for our Regulated Water and Waste Water business was £270.2 million. On a  like-for-like basis, PBIT was up 2.9% to £283 million as good cost control across our wholesale operating activities  more than offset the lower turnover. Just focusing on the highlights, our net labor costs were down by £1.2  million. To give some additional color, our core employee costs were down £8.2 following our Space to Lead  reorganization and the closure of our defined benefit scheme. These savings were partially offset by the costs of  our new group-wide bonus program, which aligns all employees' remuneration to our targets for health and safety,  ODIs, outperformance, and profit. Marginally higher than contracted costs as we've accelerated certain capital and  ODI programs and lower levels of capitalized labor due to the phasing and mix of projects within our capital  program also reduce the overall impact of these core employee cost savings.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our infrastructure maintenance program is benefiting from better commercial contracts and more efficient works  programming, resulting in costs £12.6 million lower year-on-year. And other costs were also down £6.9 million  largely due to a one-time £4.4 million rebate from the environment agency and £3.4 million of gains on property  sales.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Adjustments for the new segment reporting transfer to Business Services £6.5 million of PBIT for regulated  renewables and £6.3 million for non-household retail, resulting in a reported PBIT of £272.2 million for the first  half.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So let's turn now to our Business Services division. So this division now comprises our operating services in the  UK and overseas, our renewable energy business both regulated and non-regulated which is now managed as one  operation, and in preparation for deregulation in 2017, on non-household retail operations. And of course, our  water purification business is not included in these continuing numbers following its sale on July the 2nd.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turnover in operating services was up 8.3% and PBIT was up 8.9% driven by growth on existing business and the  new Coal Authority contract. Our renewables business contributed £6 million on turnover of £24 million, and  we're now generating the equivalent of 32% of our energy needs. As I mentioned earlier, our non-household retail  business billed our business customers £200 million and generated PBIT of just over £6 million, and that brings  that total PBIT for that division to £17.3 million.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Due to strong positive cash flows from operations and the receipt of £47 million net from the sale of our water  purification business, our net debt to RCV was just under 60% at the half-year point. However, as we work  through our capital investment program during this sem, we will be moving our gearing levels to around 62.5%  notional gearing level assumed by Ofwat as planned. As a result of our rebalancing strategy, the proportion of our  debt that was fixed at September 30 was 67%, and that's compared to 75% on the same date last year. And we  expect this to fall further in the next 12 months to about 56% when we replace the fixed year bond maturing next  spring with a new USPP debt. Taken together, these actions means we've made good progress on delivering a  better debt structure for AMP6 and beyond.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And finally, turning to technical guidance for the full year, I'll leave you to read through the detail at your leisure  but the key highlights are, for Regulated Water and Waste Water, we're guiding to turnover on the new basis of  between £1.49 billion and £1.51 billion for the full year.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, these measures here happen to be four of the most important measures to our customers, measures that  when we ask their opinion as part of the charge control process, they said if you focus on something, it's these that  I really care about. Internal/external sewer flooding, supply interruptions, and our obligations to the environment  in the form of pollutants.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, all of this is against the backdrop of decreasing bills. The average household bill in our patch has gone down  by £4 this year, and we're very proud of the fact that we have the lowest bills in Britain and the fact that'll be true  between now and 2020. So, being able to demonstrate great operational performance as well as low bills are key  planks towards making sure that we get to that strategy of being the most trusted water company by 2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, before I jump on to, I guess, the ODIs, and I have got the Swingometers charts that I promised you in May.  Before I jump on to that, I just want to touch on the type of serviceability measures that weren't in good enough  shape last year. And one in particular is worth just talking about for a second or two, and that's water quality. So,  we were disappointed of our end-of-AMP performance on the capital measures in the water quality space. And we  wanted to make sure that you're aware of the efforts that we've put into that to really cue that right at the center of  our organization.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So we talked about the fact in May, we were a matter of months into what we believed would be a three-year  journey of investment and refocusing our people towards making this an absolute priority. We're now 11 months  into that program, and we're seeing some green shoots come through. So we have seen a year-on-year  improvement of 64% drop in coliform detections in sites. Nonetheless, we know there's much more to be done. So  we're not declaring victory on any of our measures today. We can see areas of improvement on every single one of  them, but I think that the focus that the team have invested in this is beginning to pay back.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We've got four work streams that we look at. And to bring one to life, let me shed an idea as to what does it mean  when we say we focus on assets. There's a number of things under that category. You've got some of the team  members today from asset creation. We're looking at accelerating and bringing forward schemes that we believe  will make a difference in terms of the water quality of our assets.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: If you're at one of our sites, we believe you see a step change in terms of the standards. We've done independent  audits; self-audit ourselves across all of our sites to look at any issues that might exist and raise the bar. We've also  looked at some of the policies and actually invested more in some of the policies. So for example, we used to clean  tanks and district service reservoirs on average every 10 years. We've changed the policy and brought that down to  5 years as being a new plan for ourselves. These are the types of things we mean when we said we've invested in  water quality over the last while.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: On the others, you'll see we've got some where we've got very pleasing green performances. We've got a couple  that there's absolutely still more work to be done. Water quality complaints is a good example. So water quality  complaints, our actually year-on-year performance is a 6% improvement year-on-year. However, it's not yet at the  stretching targets that were set by Ofwat. We're not yet to that rate of improvement and it will take us a period of  time so we can turn that measure back into green. It's part of our three-year journey across water quality is that  particular measure.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: If you look at SIM, to pull out another one that isn't green currently, we continue to make good progress against  SIM. We exited last year at sixth and we believe that we're probably broadly seventh this year cumulatively so far.  We've seen some volatilities, some highs, and some lows. But we're very, very clear on what it is underneath that  that our customers are saying isn't as good. We've got a very solid plan to get ourselves into upper quartile. And  we remain confident that that's feasible and achievable, but we're just going to make sure we execute all elements  to that plan.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So, an example on the left. This is the northwest of our patch, and we have a community here of 50,000 people,  broadly half of which didn't have another supply. And we could see that we'd had a few outages on this particular  pipe, and we could see we're going to have to upgrade.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And when we look to the plan, the initial plan recommended by operations was to do a full replacement of the  main. When we looked at it again, it became apparent that actually, if we took a risks-based view at it, there were  actually three or four points along the main where we need to do the works. But rather than cause huge disruption  to that community, we have the same outcome by upgrading part of the main rather than the entire duration of  the pipe. That's an example of totex mindset thinking.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: On the right, this is around asset management. On this, we had a very old asset, one that we've begun to have a  couple of problems on water quality in terms of discoloration complaints. At the same time, there's a couple of  outages. And we looked at this and said, okay, it's out of its time window, it evidently needs replacing.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And again, the chief engineering team were able to look at it again with a fresh mindset and say, just before we do  that, can we just check how important this actually is to the local grid? Do we even need this particular part of  capacity on our strategic grid? And it became apparent from that modeling that it was adding marginal amounts  to it. We were best actually to make this an abandoned asset, to physically separate it, to cut it off so it could no  longer interact with our assets, and that will be the right thing to do, and it would be better to reallocate the spend  we could've spent from this on something else. These are examples of things that we're doing to embed the totex  thinking across the organization.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: They've been educating local communities because at some stage in the future, there will be days when the water  changes quality as we feed new supplies in. And they've been going through the journey of educating people to get  comfortable with that long before the time. And they've also been sorting out the pre-application process in terms  of the instruction with the EA, which is due to get formal agreement either side of Christmas, either just before or  just after. So the summary is the budget and the time for the level of work behind the scenes, as you can imagine,  is hard yards to deliver something which is this important to our future.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We've then gone through and looked to all of the contract, all of the partnerships, and everything that we need or  we buy within our company to verify are we buying it in the right manner, is there more that we can do? And they  broadly divide that into two types of savings, effectively either the capital program efficiencies where we work for  their partners to work on different ways. Some of that's been tendering, some of that's been looking again at what  we were buying, some of that's been looking at how we add waste in calls cost in the process and looking at  ourselves differently in terms of our partnership. And then there's been supplier efficiencies. Looking at  consumables or particular things that we buy or contents that we have, and saying how could we do that in a  different manner? Maybe begin to go for a smaller number of suppliers as we've talked about previously on our  sewerage commercial model or also in our chemicals model.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, the reason that we're comfortable we will outperform, and I would say passionate about it, is because in the  last [indiscernible] (31:21), what the regulators said to us is that you are a very efficient company for waste. They  said you are the sector leader for waste. But they also said you are inefficient versus your peers for water. And one  of the things that we set out for ourselves as part of the vision at the start is we want to go into the next regulatory  period as a sector leader across waste and water. We want to be the frontier company for waste and upper quartile  for water. And to do that there's a whole heap of areas that we need to still improve, and it's those areas that we're  going after, which is why believe we can outperform the [indiscernible] (31:52), which is on the basis of us moving  towards upper quartile efficiency in water.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So second to the last slide for me before we open up for questions, and it's renewables. We're proud to the fact that  we're the leading industry player on the renewable story. We're proud of the fact that this year, we've increased  our self-generation by 4% already, moving ourselves to 32% of our energy needs self-generated. It's good business  for us on the basis that we have effectively the right sites co-located, we have a need in the form of ourselves, the  need for the energy. We're confident we can deliver double-digit IRRs, and we're seeing that continuing to be the  case across all of the investment cases that come through James and I. We're confident that £190 million  continues to be the budget that we'll need to get to the 50% by 2020. In terms of early progress, we're confident  that we'll have about 40 solar array sites live by March, locking in the higher tariffs. That will then put us where  we want to be on solar for the moment.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We've then begun to find some continued exciting activities and expands new opportunities in our anaerobic  digestion area whether that's in food waste or if that's also in the sewage areas. And it's those areas which continue  to increase, continue to deliver more excitement for us that will drive us towards that 50%.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We're pleased to get to the first moment that says, that's the first way we target efficiencies banked in terms of  locked-in savings of £372 million. And now, we get the chance to embark on an exciting journey towards  becoming absolutely the sector leader in terms of efficiencies for water and for waste.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We think the totex mindset is embedded in our culture. And that's important because it means that we will spend  every pound of capital and OpEx wisely. But also it helps drive out inefficiencies and costs. We're proud to actually  to be the leader right now of the renewables in our sector. We want to go further. We want to actually set the  standard, and we look forward to doing that between now and 2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We've got people seconded into the DWI and into open water. We're playing our part in actively shaping the non- household retail market, whether it's codes or whether it's systems. We're making sure that we engage with the  Welsh government on the Silk Commission, and we've been contributing actively to the open place from ideas that  Ofwat's set up in terms of guiding towards Water 2020. So we've always wanted to be a company that's at the  heart of reform, and we continue to do so.

file: SVTL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 24November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, our strategy is to be the most trusted water company by 2020, and we're going to achieve that through  delivering an outstanding customer service, best value service, and also environmental leadership. Since the start  of the regulatory period, we've been working really hard to adapt our culture to become more customer-focused,  improve our operational performance by making our processes simpler and slicker, and also embracing  progressive technologies, and contributing more to the environment through investing in assets and also our  renewable agenda.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our Regulated business. Regulated Water and Waste Water is at the heart of our group,  comprising our wholesale water and waste water operations and our regulated household retail business. Our  turnover is up by £10.8 million or 1.4% due to the £11.6 million impact of the annual RPI price increase, slightly  higher consumption and growth in customer numbers, offset by changes in the charging base and other small  variances.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Power costs were down £1.7 million. Higher power consumption from increased water into production was more  than offset by favorable wholesale electricity prices, which we've secured through our active hedging program.  The bad debt charge for the period was £10.3 million, that's £2.5 million lower than the prior period.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: From June 1, credit risk for non-household customers transfers to the retailer, initially Water Plus, and our  Regulated Water and Waste Water business will retain the credit risk for sales to the retailers and of course  household customers. As a percentage of household revenue, our bad debt performance has improved year-on- year to 1.8%, down from 2.2% from the prior period, as we make good progress on supporting our vulnerable  customers and focus on improving cash collection performance from our other customers.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As planned, we've significantly stepped up investment in our infrastructure renewals program, an increase of £14  million compared to the first six months of last year, including £5.3 million spent on a new 1.8-kilometer tunnel  adjacent to the existing aqueduct at Bleddfa in Wales, one of three tunnels being built as part of the Birmingham  Resilience Program. Depreciation was up only marginally due to the continued growth in our asset base, and we  held other costs broadly flat despite last year benefiting from the £4.4 million refund from the Environment  Agency.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning to Business Services, we're pleased with the division's performance, showing good top and bottom line  growth this half year. And just as a reminder, these numbers and comparatives do not include any non-household  retail activity. Total turnover was up £16.9 million, of which around £9 million was due to favorable U.S. dollar and  euro FX movements, and the balance was due to good like-for-like growth in Operating Services and increased  generation in our Renewable Energy business.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Total PBIT was up £4.9 million due to the increased turnover and improving margins in Operating Services and  the increase in renewables activity. And I will go into our renewables program in more detail later on. Taken  together, Business Services delivered 44% growth in PBIT to £16.1 million for this half.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to cash flow, we've been focused on improving our cash flow this year, and I'm pleased to report our  cash from operations was up 7.4% to £532 million due to the growth in PBIT, strong cash collection and the  benefit to the group's operating cash from the trading terms of Water Plus.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've invested £235 million this half, up from £190 million last year as we ramp up our capital spend on projects  including the Birmingham Resilience Program and the new sludge thermal hydrolysis plant at Minworth. Outflows  for interest, tax and dividends totaled £193.3 million, and we've invested £15 million in the creation of the Water  Plus JV including £10 million of new equity. In addition to this, we and UU have both equally advanced cash to  fund the working capital requirements of the new venture of around £45 million. Together with other movements,  the value of net debt reduced by £82.1 million over the period.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Moving on now to give you an update on energy, we're now generating an equivalent of 35% of our Regulated  business' energy needs, up from 33% at the end of last year. This equates to an increase of 16 gigawatt hours,  enough to supply 4,000 homes per year, driven by a combination of increased production from our solar arrays  and increased efficiency from our combined heat and power systems, which are used to generate energy from  sludge.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We remain on track to be generating an equivalent of 50% of our energy needs by 2020. And our investment  program is progressing well. We've now spent around £70 million of the £190 million planned for AMP6, with  roughly half spent on sludge anaerobic digestion and half on non-regulated assets, primarily solar last year, and  food waste AD this year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Overall, our Energy business generated EBITDA for the first half of this year of £10.6 million and PBIT of £7.4  million. Our focus on energy isn't just about generating more, but also on using less. As an example, at Melbourne  and Derbyshire, we've recently installed live data monitors on our pumps that will enable us to optimize pump  configuration and save around £400,000 a year. And we're looking to roll out this technology to other sites as  soon as possible.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We know RCV growth is a key cornerstone of our investment proposition. And as a reminder, based on the final  determinations, we're expecting to have the third fastest growing RCV of the water and sewerage companies  across AMP6, and the fastest of our listed peers.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, finally, turning to technical guidance for the full year, I'll leave you to read through the detail at your leisure;  however, there are a few small changes for this half year. First, as we are six months into the year and have  better visibility, we're narrowing our expectation of turnover in the Regulated Water and Waste Water business to  between £1.5 billion and £1.52 billion.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Thank you, James. So I'd like to start by talking about our winning formula. As I said before, we believe our sector  works best when we think about the needs of all of our stakeholders and they're met or exceeded, so that means  our customers, our colleagues, our investors and the community. And our winning formula does that. It puts  customers at the very heart of our business and by meeting or exceeding their expectations, it will help us on the  journey towards our strategy to be the most trusted water company.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As James mentioned just a second ago, energy is a high cost base for any water company. And as such, our  renewable plan, [ph] it gives us a sense as well as being something that we're proud (15:34) that we can self- generate 50% of our energy needs by 2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And all of this is wrapped up in a [ph] climate for our (15:42) sector where competition is increasing and the ability  for companies like ourselves to be adaptive, to be nimble, to respond well to regulatory change is essential for  future success.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So in September the Consumer Council for Water, they shared an annual report, which examines the  performance on complaints of all companies in our sector. And we are pleased to see that we had the highest  reduction year-on-year, a 28% drop, but also we're now the second-best performer amongst all of the WASCs.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's jump on now and look at our performance for the first six months. And by now, you'll all be very familiar with  the ODI swingometers, and these are the top eight measures, the ones that have the most value and also the  ones that customers said they care about most. And we're pleased we've had a decent start. Now, there's a  couple of things to mention. The first thing is whilst there were a good number of greens, there is also one red  there, which is worth talking about, and it's water quality complaints.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So how are we actually performing on our overall asset creation on our capital [ph] bill (20:35) programs? We saw  that since RCV and a growing RCV is [ph] coursed to the (20:38) proposition, what I thought I'd do now is walk  you through the progress we've made on our capital schemes. So there's some images here. The one on the left  is our largest capital program in this AMP, the Birmingham Resilience scheme. In order for us to deliver a growing  RCV, we have to deliver all of our schemes to time, to budget, to quality [ph] of any shortfall (20:58) in the future,  but also avoiding ODI penalties against the larger schemes.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Well, prior to [ph] the fact (21:04) in the last few months, we've landed a few of the really key aspect of the  Birmingham Resilience deal. We've now let all the contracts and we've secured all the planning permissions. That  means the teams were [ph] beavering away and actually the stand outside, where you can meet one of my  colleagues, Paul, (21:14) who'd love to share with you the latest.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, you can see a photo here for tunnel boring machine [indiscernible] (21:22) actually to breakthrough on the  completion of the first of the tunnels sometime in the next few weeks, which is absolutely fantastic. In terms of the  other things we said we do in the totex mindset, as we've said we look at things constantly through the angle of  totex rather than capital. And a good example of that is recent decisions we've made around Draycote. Draycote  is one of our reservoirs. We've got population growth in that area. And coming into the AMP with increased  demand, we would have thought we would have probably looked to enlarging that reservoir. And, actually, we've  been able to look at it through a totex mindset and through the UK's largest water trade obstruction, meaning that  we can meet our demand through another way, a better way for the community, a better way for us.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: But, also, 58 DWI obligations, which are critical obligations we must deliver during the regulatory period. We're  doing well against those. They're right at the heart of our plans to invest and do more water quality, and we're on  track to deliver all of those during the regulatory period.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, in order to for us to continue to outperform, we need to be innovative. And I thought I'd give you a couple of  examples around the innovation culture that we're embedding. So on the left hand side is one of our wastewater  examples. On the right hand side is a clean water example.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So in the sewage process, [indiscernible] (22:43) phosphorus is a chemical, which is naturally created. It's  expensive for us to treat, and it has to be treated before it goes back out into the environment. And we've  traditionally spent a lot of money on this as a sector. And at the start of this regulatory period, we asked the R&D  team to try innovative ways of what else could we do with the long-standing problem.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And what they've come up with using a range of different things is some [ph] clever blended technologies, which  we're now running across our states because (23:04) it gives us the opportunity to not only save money in the  process, but actually to be able to make sure that we take the phosphate and be able to actually use that for  farmers in fertilizer going forward, [ph] as expected of the whole community, but much (23:17) better for our cost  base as well.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On the right hand side, you've got an example around pressure. [ph] We surge (23:35) pressure in our pipes. And  because they're underground, we just can't see it. And, previously, we've had our telemetry [indiscernible] (23:32)  every 15 minutes, giving us an indicator of the pressure surges coming through. With our new [ph] SMART  networks program (23:36) we're now able to see 128 times a second what pressure is happening and that gives  us an opportunity to better invest in our assets and to understand our [ph] state in much more detail, ideally  bringing down first to (23:45) the future, allowing us to do a better management of our overall [ph] state (23:52)  from a network perspective.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've mentioned about 14 months ago, we announced our two [ph] CSR kind of key tenants (24:29), the areas  we wanted to focus on in our corporate responsibility agenda. So one was around healthier rivers in our region  and the second was around water efficiency in our region. And we continue to make good progress against it.  Again, there are some examples of things that we're doing in the [ph] stands next door, particularly bringing one  thing to light. The TWI (24:45) recently recognized us for the amazing work we're doing on catchment  management as an example of real focus and step change flowing through to healthier rivers.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've seen the regulator continue to reaffirm their support for risk/reward scheme. Clearly, we believe  passionately in that as a winner in the world of incentivization. And we've also seen additional snippets on some  of the areas of the new competitive world, whether that's by resources or whether that's water resources.

file: SVTL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 23November2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our vision remains unchanged, to be the most trusted water company by 2020. And we believe by doing the right  thing, we will deliver really strong benefits for our colleagues, our customers, our communities, and our  shareholders. We're halfway through the five-year regulatory period. We feel that we've made good progress in  the first two-and-a-half years. We're in good shape for this time and also to move seamlessly into the next time to  come.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On our excellent performance on Waste means that we're now expecting to reach the cap on Waste ODIs for this  AMP. Underlying basic EPS is up 7.7% due to the growth in underlying PBIT and a lower effective tax rate, which  more than offset the increase in financing costs. In May, we uplifted our ordinary dividend policy to growth of at  least RPI plus 4%, which means our interim dividend increased by 6.2% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our Regulated Water and Waste Water business, for this year, we'll be showing Dee Valley  separately to allow like-for-like comparison with the prior year. In Severn Trent Water, revenue has increased by  £16.9 million for the RPI and K-factor allowance, and £12.9 million from the ODI net outperformance payments  earned in the first year of the AMP. These were offset by £12.1 million of WRFIM adjustments for billing in excess  of the Final Determination in that same year. Other movements of around £5.5 million included the impact of new  connections, meter optants and the management of voids. So, after including the additional £12.5 million of  revenue from Dee Valley, our turnover for the year is up 3.2%.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning to our underlying PBIT for Regulated Water and Waste Water, we've delivered an increase of £9.5 million  or 3.5% for the half year. In Severn Trent Water, we've maintained good control over operating costs, which have  increased by just 1.2% year-on-year. Our net labor costs increased by £2.6 million following the annual pay award  and an increase in head count as we in-source more activity. This in-sourcing has helped to lower net hired and  contracted costs, which are down £3.7 million with the comparison also benefiting from £1.8 million of setup costs  for non-household retail separation last year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As I guided in May, we've seen the impact of a sector-wide increase in electricity pass-through costs, which we've  offset through reducing usage by around 1%, despite a 2% increase in water into supply. Also, we believe we  have the lowest imported unit electricity costs in the sector, even so our gross power costs were up £4.4 million or  11% year-on-year. And as a group, we're able to hedge some of this increase through self-generation, which is  reported in our Business Services segment.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now turning to Business Services, and as you can see here, we're delivering top and bottom line growth as  promised. In June, we sold our U.S. operations and together with our Italian business sold late last year, we've  reported this as a discontinued operation. Our Operating Services division now generates 95% of its revenues  from the UK and is up £2.9 million in turnover and £1.4 million in PBIT, driven by higher commission income and  additional work awarded on the MoD and Coal Authority contracts. Our Renewable Energy business increased  turnover by £3.1 million and PBIT by £1.6 million. And we're now producing the equivalent of 38% of our energy  needs and are on track to hit our target of 50% by 2020.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In 2015, we committed to investing £190 million in our Renewable Energy business over the course of this AMP.  We've now invested £116 million of this, with 60% in our non-regulated assets, including a newly operational  Roundhill food waste plant and a third plant in Derby which is under construction.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Finally, let's turn to our technical guidance for the full year. I'll leave you to read through the details, but there are  a few changes I want to highlight. Firstly, with our strong start on customer ODIs this year, we're confident that  we'll beat our performance last year and earn at least £50 million in net outperformance payments. Most of our  ODI outperformance to date has come from our exceptional Waste performance. The total AMP capped for Waste  ODIs is about £190 million gross of tax. So, the £75 million we earned in the first two years leaves £115 million  available for the remaining three years. Based on our performance trajectory on key Waste commitments, we now  believe it will hit this cap.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We believe right now is the right time for the societal impact of this strategy. We've got the backdrop of a housing  shortage in our region. We've got customers with affordability challenges, wanting lower bills, and we've got  population growth. We think this strategy delivers against all three of those areas and helps all of those  stakeholders. And we think it's another example of what it is that we're doing creatively as a senior team to look  for innovative ways to keep bills low for the future, whether it's cost efficiencies, whether it's the bill smoothing of  the ODI impact, or whether it's the property strategy, all of them add up towards really understanding that keeping  bills in good shape is important for our future.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's talk about our performance operationally. You'll recall the swingometers, we traditionally use these, and  we're proud of the first six months of our operational performance. On the most of the customers care about most,  which is internal and external sewer flooding, the hard work of my colleagues has delivered a 48% year-on-year  improvement, which is fantastic. If we look at the two of the other big, I guess, rate-making items, it will be  leakage, which you can see has gone down by 4 million leaks a day, and it'll be category 3 pollutions; again, both  of those are ahead of our regulatory targets.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On supply interruptions, we also have had really strong underlying performance. We have had a couple of recent  events, which have moved us into our deadband territory on that particular matter. Over the last couple of years,  we've talked a lot about water quality complaints. It's been our challenging measure, and I'm really pleased that  the business improvement activities, the investment, the focus from us across the piece has really begun to move  that needle. And you'll see that we're 12% better year-on-year and we're confident of that continuing through the  remainder of the AMP.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: If I were to draw out just two, I think they've got some really fantastic methods in their water quality arena. So,  their mains cleaning techniques have been great for us to learn from. It helps them deliver the sector-leading  mean zonal compliance performance, and that's helped us improve this year. It's also been super-helpful for us  on our water quality complaints performance.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: If I were to call something else out, it will be their SIM performance. They are properly upper quartile on SIM.  They're first place on billing. They're fourth place on water. That's helped us as we continue our ambitions to  move and continue to improve against SIM. If you look at all the benefits that we've been able to help with, they're  a heap. There's technology. There's innovation. There's R&D. There's the opportunity for us to help shape their  vulnerable programs, which they've not really got in shape. And, of course, there's the whole cost savings arena.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And if you take one example, which I guess would be electricity contracts, by moving them onto the way that we  purchase electricity and onto our contracts, we've been able to make double-digit percentage improvements on  the price that goes into electricity price for the Dee Valley customers.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, efficiency is a passion for us. We're proud of the fact that we've worked hard over the course of the last  period of time to make ourselves one of the most efficient companies in our sector. We've locked in a further £50  million for the totex efficiency savings.
