That takes us to £660 million locked in so far against the total forecast  commitment of £770 million of totex efficiencies for this AMP. That's 86% locked in at the midway point.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And the reason we're so passionate about this is partly to keep customers' bills low for the future and partly  because when the regulator looks at us and considers the effects of PR19, there will be a strong cross- comparative sector efficiency debate. And when we look at ourselves as to how we stand, we believe the  following. So, on Waste, we entered an upper quartile. We think we've made continued very strong progress on  our Waste business and we're firmly in upper quartile as it stands today.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On Water, we entered mid-table as you might remember. We believe the efficiencies we've landed have moved  us a couple of places up, but still more to be done and we're confident we've got the plans in place to continue to  land those savings between now and the end of the AMP.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: To set ourselves in good shape, we've got a challenge group, a customer challenge group called the Water  Forum who are fantastic experts and are really going to test our plan. We've made sure that we've taken more  insights and more customer data than ever before. We've actually [indiscernible] (23:50) over 7 million  conversations in social media to give us some of that rich level. And that's just one of the mediums that we've  used to gather the customer data.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: At the same time, we're not resting on our laurels. We're doing two big concrete things to get ourselves in great  shape. The first is investment. We're investing in THP, in thermal hydrolysis plants, and making sure we've got  the best possible technology to really move ourselves into being a leader in the bioresources area.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And the second thing we're doing is making sure that we've got the right operating structure. We recently trialed in  Staffordshire a new operating model. We wanted to understand and to learn from that, was that the right thing to  do across our company. And the answer is a resounding yes. And what came out of the trial was enhanced asset  management, the opportunity to make sure that we deliver more commercial savings, the chance to get our  sludge data which for us is a key measure, and to make sure there's an organization we were primed to be more  commercially aware and to drive towards success in what is a new and competitive market for us. And Andy's  here, I'm sure he'd love to take some questions later. And we've also got one of our [ph] fans (25:50), if someone  wants to get really into it after the presentation.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And to give you just a couple of examples of how we think this is in our DNA, it's inbred within us, I would say look  at the partnerships that we do across the piece. We've just launched quite a creative partnership with house- builders. If they're prepared to build water-efficient homes, then we're prepared to actually waive the charge for  the entire connection fee to really try and go for water efficiency to help the environment.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And if you look at the spirit within Severn Trent, then over 40% of our colleagues have either done their  volunteering or about to do it by the end of the year to try and clear up 40 kilometers of the worst rivers in our  patch. That sense of desire, the 40% of the organization to get involved in making the patch better is something  truly unique to Severn Trent. Of course, we're also proud to be named in FTSE4Good to once again be  recognized in terms of the Carbon Trust accreditation. But I think it's the atmosphere about how we run the  business that I think is probably slightly different for us.

file: SVTL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 22November2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've landed Agrivert, an acquisition which will continue to bolster our green Energy business. And we're proud  to have been announced and acknowledged as a Pathfinder Company by the Purposeful Company, and I'll talk a  little bit about that in a bit more detail.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As we've announced at the full-year results in May, we're now managing and reporting our Bioresources and  Property Development activity within Business Services. To help you navigate through this transition year, I'll be  showing comparatives from the old segmental basis with a bridge to the new basis of reporting.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, let's turn to Regulated Water and Waste Water. Turnover for this, our largest segment, grew by 4% overall,  mainly driven by the RPI-linked tariff increases in Severn Trent and Hafren Dyfrdwy of £28 million. Customer  ODIs of £8 million that we earned for outperformance in 2016/2017 have been partially offset by the same year's  WRFIM adjustment that trues up billing over the five-year final determination. And other small differences  including the impact of new connections and meter optants brought the total increase for the year to £33 million.  As I mentioned, we've included on the slide a bridge to our new basis of reporting that shows the movements of  revenue out of Regulated Water and Waste Water for those activities now managed in our Business Services  segment.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's now turn to PBIT. We held underlying PBIT for our Regulated Water and Waste Water business broadly flat  as the higher turnover I mentioned previously was offset by an increase in net operating expenses. Now, in May, I  guided you to expect an increase in power costs and Environment Agency fees, but I didn't forecast the glorious  weather we saw over the summer months. And while not exceptional, the hot, dry/wet spell did significantly  increase our customers' demand for water. And as you can see from the slide, most of the £10 million of extra  costs to meet this were in hired and contracted services and power.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In the second half, we'll be absorbing a similar amount of additional costs for operational recovery, which we'll  touch on later. Going through some of the larger movements, net labor and hired and contracted costs combined  were up £10.5 million. Absent a hot weather, combined costs were up around 2% as the annual pay award and  higher head count were partially offset by a higher split of our work allocated to capital programs this year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Power costs increased by £5.3 million year-on-year due to higher pass-through rates, as previously guided, and  the cost of pumping more water during the summer. Our bad debt charge increased by £2.5 million, and we're  currently providing a 2.1% of household turnover, slightly better than the 2.2% for last year. And finally,  depreciation was 5% higher as we wrote down the value of retiring assets being replaced this year, and also see  the proportion of investment in innovative shorter life technology assets increase.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We're turning now to our Business Services segment. It's been an exciting year for our non-regulated business.  The sale of land in Nottingham at the start of this year generated a profit of £18 million and will enable our 830  new homes to be built by the developer. We're nearing completion of our acquisition of Agrivert, which will add  five food waste anaerobic digestion plants to our portfolio, generating the equivalent of 106 gigawatt hours per  annum. Agrivert brings with it significant management expertise, secure long-term contracts, and 20-year  Renewable Energy subsidies, all of which make it a great fit to our existing food waste business.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, turning now to cash flow and net debt. We generated cash from operations of £490 million. And we reinvested  much of this in capital projects, with CapEx spend up £70 million this half year to £340 million as planned. Work  on projects such as the Birmingham Resilience Programme, upgrades to our waste assets as part of the Water  Framework Directive, and improved sludge processing in our new THP site mean that 2018/2019 will be Severn  Trent's biggest year of capital investment in the last decade. After accounting for tax, interest, dividends and other  items, net debt increased by £62 million over the period.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So finally, let's turn to our technical guidance for the full-year. I'll leave you to read through the detail, but there are  a couple of points I want to highlight. The forecast in the higher energy pass-through costs and EA license fees to  continue through the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, the activity to meet customer demand during the hot weather cost us around £10 million in  July and August, which has been fully reflected in our first-half results. We're forecasting a similar amount of  spend on operational recovery after the events in the second half, and we expect to absorb – which we expect to  absorb through ongoing efficiencies to leave our guidance across operating costs and IRE unchanged.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We continue to expect a neutral position on customer ODIs for year four based on the current incentive cap on  waste ODIs. Now, as you know earlier this year, we applied to Ofwat to lift the cap on waste ODIs. On the 1st of  November, Ofwat published the consultation documents relating to the application. We're assessing the proposal  they've outlined, and we'll respond this week. So we'll update the market and, if necessary, our guidance following  the consultation phase. The rest of our guidance remains unchanged.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So then, we set out in 2015 that we absolutely wanted to make sure that our vision was to be the most trusted  company in our sector. And we knew that in order to do that, we asked our customers, what would that look like?  And they said there would need to be fantastic value for money, environmental leadership, and great service.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, trust, you have to earn it, you have to maintain it. It does feel as though, as we head forth, that that sense of  trust and societal purpose is something which we are really believing is a key part of the future. And the way we  view this is to view the facts that to be the very best Severn Trent we can be is built on a culture of trust with all of  those various stakeholders. We also think it's good for those stakeholders. We believe that sense of trust at the  heart is good for customers. It's good for colleagues. It's good for the environment. And we actually believe for  investors, it creates value as well for the long-term. So that's why we've made two changes to our presentations  as of today. You would have noticed on your seats, not only do you have the beautifully crafted slides from the IR  team, which will take you through the results, but you also have a lovely document for you to have a little preview  of that later. And in that document, you'll see a whole heap of concrete examples that try to bring to life the efforts  and the outputs which have led to us being acknowledged as a Pathfinder Company in this Purposeful space, the  only utility to be acknowledged as a Pathfinder.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: You'd have also seen, hopefully, on the way in that we've actually also begun to evidence how we're performing  against 11 of the 17 UN sustainable goals. And what you're going to see in a second or two as I slip on to my  slides is you're going to see little icons, and those icons reference where we're making efforts and delivering  things against the sustainable UN goals. It's a real passion for us, and we think it's something we can talk about  more to help maybe bring out that sense in our business to make it more visible to yourself.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, with that, let's go on talk about PR19. We couldn't possibly have a presentation and not have one slide on it.  You would definitely have missed it. So, we submitted our plan. We feel our plan is robust. It's balanced. It's  ambitious. We think that it matches the needs of our customers and also our regulators. And to remind you of  what [ph] the focus our (00:13:28) plan is, it's based first of all on a 5% bill reduction which is [audio gap]  (00:13:32) and continues to make us the lowest bills in the land through to 2025 both in England and in Wales.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: It's also predicated, the Severn Trent plan, on a 13% reduction in costs. And that actually, we believe, depending  on the model Ofwat chooses, could well see us up a quartile in Waste Water and Retail. It's got the largest RCV  growth of any of the listed. It's based on the fact that it's got a strong financing sustainable backbone through it,  whether that's the credit rating, the dividend policy, or the gearing. And crucially, it has the largest of the RoRE  ranges on ODIs, and that's because we absolutely embrace incentivization we have in this five-year period. We  absolutely want to do the same in the next five-year period.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, let's start by talking about Water. So, it's continued to make a good progress over the course of the last well,  and we're getting ourselves ready to be in the right shape as we enter AMP7. On water quality complaints, I think  we've talked about it in the last couple of years, we've made a further progress. We're confident this year of  improving by 6%, which is based on last year's 12% reduction again on water quality complaints. And we still  believe that we'll be in good shape to be [ph] in the award territory (00:16:23) by the end of next year for exiting  the AMP in strong shape on water quality complaints.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've got a laser-like focus on leakage, whether it's find and fix activity, whether it's new innovations that we're  scouring the world to bring in, we know we've got a really ambitious 15% target next AMP, and our minds are so  much focused on getting ourselves into the right position for that bigger AMP7 challenge.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: I wonder if we haven't talked about it as much, but it's the kind of perfect timing is we [audio gap] (00:16:49) in the  environmental arena. And actually, we've got some of the team here today that you can have a chat to afterwards.  And it's the opportunity for us to really change behaviors of farmers. We've had this scheme we've been working  with farmers called Farm to Tap. And we've been educating and working with change in behaviors of 800 farmers  over the last few years. [ph] According to what it means (00:17:06) is that we work with them on how to make the  quality of the river better. We have to make sure that we actually spend less money on treatment processes,  we're actually supporting them in their farming methods. So, the great news is that's gone really well. And  actually, there's now an opportunity this year for us to earn up to an £11 million ODI reward at the end of AMP4  for our performance in that catchment area.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As James mentioned earlier, we have seen some absolutely glorious weather and, of course, that brings with it  some challenges for us to manage during the course of the summer. And we're really pleased with how we  managed that position. We had the reservoirs at 98% capacity went into it in a strong position, to be able to  manage the 22% increase in demand that our customers drove at peak moments. We're on track to still improve  on our supply interruption's year-on-year performance. We've said we'd halve back this year, and we're on track  to that performance which again is a good improvement.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And I think when James mentioned earlier, it will cost you money. If you have a situation like that where there is  just a step change in customer demand and more activity to be done across the business, then of course, it would  have cost us. And we've followed the £10 million cost for the first half of the year. For the second half of the year,  we [ph] now know we can rebalance (00:18:12) water around the network, make sure we're in exactly the perfect  place to enter into another summer. And that's why there will be a further cost allocation to the second half again  which will follow in normal operating costs.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, moving to Waste. We believe that we truly excel in this part of the sector. And if you, of course, compare our  factual performance for this AMP, whether it's ODIs, whether it's our cost base, whether it's in frontier, whether it's  our environmental performance we have achieved the last three years, reaching four-star status in that coveted  EA rating, we think we've demonstrated that we're real leaders in the Waste part of our business.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And we don't talk enough, I think, about how we delivered that. [ph] It's always based in (00:18:49) the catchment  work. So, quite simply, we have some of the best asset models in the sector, and that allows us the data to  understand where we're going to put our efforts. It means that by using the culture, our performance culture that  we've embedded through the climate of ODIs with the telemetry that we have across our network, combined  together, we intercept, we then prevent, and we really make sure that we've got this really good virtuous circle of  activity that limits customer pain and creates a much stronger environmental performance. And it's that sense that  we think it's right at the heart of why we do well in Waste Water.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, we recently asked our customers what they'd like for the future, and they came back strongly with a real  push on the fact they really care passionately about this part of our organization. And that's why we've continued  to make sure that our AMP7 plan factors that in strongly. We've got the largest ODI range on waste measures.  We've also made sure that on the two measures that you can supersize, we've supersized both of those. And  we've also listened to our customers quite carefully and included some bespoke that ODIs we've not done before,  but our customer said they're really passionate about seeing progress in that space. We've got a strong  momentum and strong progress in AMP6 on this area, and we feel good for the challenges in AMP7.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, let me just touch now on our people. So, it's the culture of Severn Trent that we think makes us a special  organization. And it's been a jam-packed people agenda over the last period of time. And our people were  generally proud of that that once again we were named in the social mobility index. It's a real passion for us. 30%  of the nation's cold spots – places where if you're born, you've got less chance of getting on with your career – are  in the Severn Trent patch. And we have a huge opportunity here to really influence the lives of people in our  region for the better. And we are praised as part of that for the work that we're doing specifically on recruitment in  those cold spots.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: With that, let me summarize. And what I'm going to do by summarizing is just to contextualize, before we get to  Q&A, the whole last three-and-a-half years. We're three-and-a-half years in to what is a five-year journey. And we  started the AMPs, really passionate about saying, how to make sure that our bills are the lowest for the future?  What can we do on efficiencies to drive that long-term ambition for our customers? [ph] And our men have (22:06)  identified £870 million worth of efficiency savings, which we're proud of.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We also went live with a new financing strategy, which has paid off well and got us in a strong place UQ for the  next period. We then also said to ourselves, we want to make sure we achieve really good things that our  customers and our communities are passionate about. And that's why we're so proud to have landed strongly for  all three years of the last three, we've been the outperformer on ODIs, and that's a measure that customers care  about most. We've also made some good progress on some of the customer topics and made sure that we've got  that environmental four-star status two of the last three years.

file: SVTL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 28May2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: months to March 31, 2010. As these results cover my last year as Chairman of Severn Trent, I’m  pleased to report today on our third successive year of continuous improvement. We faced the  challenges of the coldest winter for 30 years and an economic environment, which remains  uncertainty – uncertain.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Yet, Tony and his team have delivered substantially increased underlying PBIT. We continued to  deliver on our plans to raise standards and control costs. Indeed, operating costs in Severn Trent  Water were down year-on-year, while delivering our required outputs. And I’m particularly pleased  that we still managed to deliver on our leakage targets.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Mike will outline the key numbers in a moment, and then Tony will update you on our performance  improvements and give you a wider view on AMP5. But first, I’d like to take this opportunity to thank  our employees in Severn Trent Water, who contributed to further improvements in customer service  and helped us maintain our high standards across our key environmental obligations. This includes  generating now 20% of our electricity from renewable sources. We closed AMP5 successfully, and  as a result of our lead-in investments are well positioned for AMP5.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: In Severn Trent Services, the fundamental drivers of the business remained strong. Our Operating  Services business performed well. And during the year, we took the opportunity to restructure our  Water Purification and Analysis businesses to position them for growth in 2010, ‘11 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Finally, a word on the future of the water industry in England and Wales. Last month, we published  our document, Changing Course, outlining our view of a sustainable future for the industry. There  are copies outside, if you’d like one. There’s an opportunity now to review the regulatory framework  ahead of the next cycle. And while the 2 decades since privatization have been a success, bringing  higher customer and environmental standards and more efficient companies, the sectors reached a  pivotal point with very high industry debt, rising carbon emissions and customer bills rising faster  than inflation.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: To deliver the investment required over the next 20 years, we believe that long-term and innovative  approaches need to be taken to resolve these issues and suggest changes to the policy on  regulatory framework to do this. We’d encourage you to read the report and would welcome a  dialog with you. At a professional and personal level, it’s particularly pleasing to have presided over  5 years during which Severn Trent has undergone significant change to become a company  recognized as delivering operational excellence with good quality outputs, continuous improvement  on the lowest average water and storage bills in England and Wales.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: So let me look principally at the activities related to Severn Trent Water. In previous guidance, we  said that exceptional costs would be around about 20 million to deliver an additional 5 million to  OpEx savings in the year and keep operating costs flat year-on-year. As you can see, operating  costs have gone down slightly. So we’ve done slightly better than the performance that we said  we’d achieve during the course of the year.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Now, moving to tax, there were a number of features within the 2010 current tax charge, which  have applied downward pressure this year on the effective rate. And the principal points are as  follows. We had accelerated allowances on plants and machinery because the Finance Act 2009  doubled the rate of deduction on the first year allowance. There was also enhanced capital  allowances for expenditures on designated energy saving and water conservation and plants and  machinery and with specified research and development costs, these were also clarified during the  year and therefore, we were able to file lower costs associated with those. There was also the fact  that infrastructure income was much lower than in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Tony Wray, Chief Executive  Thanks, Mike. Good morning, everybody. Let me start with Severn Trent Water and in 2009/10, we  set ourselves tougher targets in line with our established culture in Severn Trent of continuous  improvement. We updated our benchmarks to maintain our push to always aim for upper-quartile  performance across all of our activities. And indeed, we made excellent progress on a wide range  of fronts, in particular as Sir John has already told you, beating our leakage target despite the  coldest winter for 30 years and very pleased at attaining our milestone of producing 20% of our  total energy requirements from our own renewable sources.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Of course, there is always more to do against those tougher benchmarks. And as you can see from  the chart, we now have 2 areas of operations that are in lower quartile, that of course we target for  further improvement this year. Just to give you the specifics, those 2 areas are interruptions to  water supply for our customers and meeting some of our site-specific consent targets for a small  number of our sewage treatment works.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Let me highlight for you a number of our performance areas where we have made significant  progress since the last time that we met. First, on sewer flooding, we delivered sustained  improvements from our increased and targeted preventative maintenance programs, that’s  delivering sewer flooding – fewer sewer flooding events for our customers. Secondly, on water  quality, we continue to enhance the already high performance that we have in the sector.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: And on energy, we’ve already over and above achieving our 20% self supply and you’ll recall our  target to achieve 30% by 2014/15. Over and above that, we’ve already hedged our wholesale  requirements for the first 3 years of AMP5 and that’s already demonstrating a saving of some £20  million versus the Final Determination allowance. Of course, we’ll continue to build on our  contribution from renewables.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Turning to Severn Trent Services, Severn Trent Services made good progress managing, as Mike  said, the challenging economic conditions during the year. The fundamentals of our business here  remain strong. The demand for expertise in water and wastewater treatment, the management of  those activities continue to be driven by scarcity, demand, climate change and regulatory  requirements.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Looking at the 3 components of our business here, Operating Services performed well. It built on its  presence in the U.S., the UK, the Middle East and Asia Pacific. We had a strong pipeline of  contract bids. In fact, we saw a much higher level of enquiries, particularly in the U.S., from  potential customers, local governments and municipalities looking to outsource their water and  waste activities to achieve their budgetary constraints.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: But in water purification, our products business, many projects were delayed. Importantly, we did  not have projects cancelled such that by the end of the year, we were able to achieve our largest  ever order book of some $100 million, giving us a strong start into 2010/11. We did also take the  opportunity to restructure. We moved to a lower cost base manufacturing, particularly moving our  manufacturing to lower-cost locations.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Looking a little further out across AMP5, this chart gives you an insight into the breakdown of our  OpEx cost base and how we see that changing over the course of AMP5. In 09/10 prices, you can  see we’re aiming to keep our OpEx broadly flat through to 2014/15. But the profile between  controllable and non-controllable cost is quite different. Quasi taxes, such as rates, abstraction  rights, Ofwat fees, we expect them to rise along with power cost. But we expect that to be offset by  some reduction in bad debt as the economy we hope improves. But all in all, non-controllable cost  will rise by about 7.4%. Offsetting that will be the impact of our ongoing efficiency programs,  reducing controllable cost, predominantly personnel costs, hiring contracted services and  consumables.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: So for AMP5 in Severn Trent Water, we are confident that we can meet our objectives. Profile for  CapEx and, within that, infrastructure renewals should be broadly flat over the 5 years, small  variations year-on-year due to project timings.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: Further efficiencies will come from the benefits of our SAP release 2 program, the continued  consolidation of our real estate, and as we see the gains coming through from our contracting  strategy and the innovation on our capital programs. We do have certainty on energy costs,  certainly for the first 3 years. And as I’ve already mentioned, that will help provide savings in the  order of £20 million versus the Final Determination.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: In Water Purification, with our more capital-light model and rationalizing and moving our  manufacturing to lower-cost regions, we’ll continue to grow into our Middle and Far East markets. In  Analytical Services, with our lower cost base, we will ensure our new long-term contracts are up  and running and profitable.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: So John mentioned our document that we published just a few weeks ago, Changing Course, a  document we issued setting out our view of a more sustainable future for the water industry. Now,  the last 20 years since privatization have indeed been very successful, raising £85 billion worth of  investment, raising standards for customers, raising water and waste standards in the UK. But they       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: 8 have come at significant cost, the rising industry debts, rising cost to customers and a significantly  greater carbon footprint. We believe there is a more sustainable future and it’s characterized by the  6 recommendations that you can see on the chart here.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: We could see industry carbon commissioning some 13% lower than they would otherwise be. And  all of that would flow through to average household bills being some 11% lower than they would  otherwise be. So please do take a copy of that with you today, if you’ve not seen it before, and  please do feel free to engage with us on those topics. Now is a really important time over the next 2  years to engage on shaping the regulatory framework for the future.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: So to summarize, we have made further progress this year on our performance and we still have  plans to do more. We delivered our AMP4 capital program at the targeted efficiency of 6% and we  delivered efficiency savings on our OpEx for 2009 and ‘10. Because of our early-start strategy and  successful execution of our efficiency programs, we’re very well placed to deliver on our  commitment for AMP5. And with Severn Trent Services, we’re well placed to continue our organic  growth.

texts.speaker: Sir John Egan, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome to our Preliminary Results Presentation for the 12
texts.text: So with that, let me move on to take your questions as well as myself, Sir John and Mike, I’m joined  today with 3 of my executive colleagues, Martin Kane, our Director of Customer Relations; Tony  Ballance, our Regulation Director; and Andy Smith, our Water Director.

file: SVTL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 27May2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: this morning with the fire alarm going on. Let’s get proceedings underway. Good to see you all here  today for the Severn Trent 2010/’11 Results Presentation.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Expenditure on maintaining our infrastructure network did fall by £7.6 million in the year. Weather  did impact on our capital programs through the period. And our expense on infrastructure in ‘10/’11  was at the low-end of the revised range of £97 million, and it was down on previous year as we  said. I’ll come onto the outlook in a second.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: The main component this last year related to the Waste Water Transformation program and some  of you who were at our Investor Day in December will understand a little bit more about that. And if  you’d like to know that the slides are still available on our website. You can see more details about  that.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: And we had two items – two other items. One was a charge of £3.8 million in Severn Trent Services  arising from the group’s response to an audit by the Drinking Water Inspectorate, plus some of the  services provided by Severn Trent Laboratories in the Bridgend facility in Wales. And there was a  further charge of £3.9 million in the corporate segment arising from the group’s response to a  request from Ofwat to provide information under the Competition Act powers that they have in  relation to the last contract with Severn Trent Water and indeed other water companies. These last  two items, at this stage, it’s not possible to identify whether there’s any or indeed – will be any at all  further liability that may arise on these matters. But we do record the costs that we’ve incurred to  date.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: The group’s net debt to RCV, that’s at group level and not the water company, group net debt to  RCV was 56.8%, and that compares to 57.9% in the prior year. You will see more details as before  in the back of the pack that you have in front of you on debt and cash.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: First of all on Energy, we’ve increased, again, our renewable energy power generation now  achieving 22% of our total requirement from our own need. This year that included the start-up of  our energy crop plant at Stoke Bardolph. We have also decreased the amount of energy that we  use in our treatment and distribution processes overall. That’s important in the context of the new  carbon tax.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: We’ve again reduced the incidents of sewer flooding through our increased and targeted preventive  maintenance programs. Good news for our customers. Customer service levels improved in the  areas of first-time call and first-time job resolution and further 10% reduction in billing-related  complaints.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: We also improved water supply by reducing the number of properties at risk of low pressure on our  network, moving from median performance now throughout the quartile. However, we did have the  extreme December, the coldest in our region for 100 years, and the third year in a row of unusually  low temperatures. That had a major impact on our leakage and our interruptions to supply.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: But with an exceptional performance by our teams and the deployment of considerable additional  resource, we were able to maintain our leakage at last year’s record low of 497 megaliters a day.  Now that was short of our target of 483. But since then, we’ve continued to reduce leakage, and  we’re back on track with getting our leakage down to where it needs to be. But let me stress, we  held our leakage flat right across.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Finally, we did deliver to our customers the lowest combined water and waste sewage bill in  England and Wales for 2010-’11 with a nominal reduction year-on-year for our customers.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: On energy, as I mentioned, we’ve increased our renewable and we plan to continue to add to that  portfolio. Our plans are on track, and indeed, we’ve now been granted our first planning permission  for a significant wind turbine at Wanlip in Leicestershire at one of our largest sewage treatment  works. In addition, as we previously reported, we have hedged the vast majority of our wholesale  energy requirements for the remainder of the AMP delivering around £20 million saving versus the  final determination over the AMP.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: A couple of examples here, just to give you a flavor of the type of things that are coming out of that  supply chain working to drive the efficiency. At our Derwent Valley aqueduct scheme and that’s  increasing capacity on our main spine network for transportation of water north to south. The  improved modeling that we’ve applied has identified solutions that avoid us having to lay about 26  kilometers of new main; have smart reuse of some assets that we’ve got and that’s saving us  around £4 million on the planned £31 million spend for that part of that scheme, around a 13%  saving. And that’s the kind of thinking that we’ve got driving on through our schemes.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Another example on the water treatment works at Tack Lane where we’re introducing a new  technology for Severn Trent, but tried and tested in the broader world for treatment of pesticides  and it’s a technique known as air stripping, rather than the technique that we would usually use of  using granular activated carbon. Again, that’s given us a capital saving on the project but actually  we’re finding it’s also a lower cost operation and on that particular site alone will save us about  £10,000 a year in operating costs.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Looking forward then for Severn Trent Water in 2011-’12, our goal clearly is to continue to deliver  on those performance improvements and the efficiencies that are now planned. On our CapEx,  we’re guiding to a range of £450 million to £470 million net and within that, £120 million to £130  million of infrastructure renewals, higher than last year as we catch up from some of the weather  impacts on our program just last year. Our operational expenditure will show an increase year-on- year in ‘11-’12 driven by inflation, rising import cost, quasi taxes, including the carbon tax offset by  our ongoing efficiency programs.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Just a few words on our approach of the adoption of private drains and sewage. We have already  leveraged the expertise of our supply chain partners, and we already have in place the resourcing  model and the processes to keep our fixed cost to a minimum. We expect the transfer of assets  now to take place on the 1st of October. And in our release this morning and in the appendices to  this presentation, we’ve included our initial estimates of the potential impact in the current year ‘11-  ‘12.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: In water purification, though, it was a tale of two halves, growth in the first six months and then a  falloff in the second half of the year, principally on sales of our high margin electrochlorination  products as well as the impact, I think as Mike said, is the Gulf coast drilling moratorium and the  political and the social unrest in the Middle East, which was delaying funding and shipments.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Looking forward for services with the fundamental market drivers remaining strong, we remain  confident in our opportunity for sustained future growth in Severn Trent Services. Our base  business in operating services and water purification is expected to deliver continued growth,  particularly in the second half of the year. At the PBIT level, we expect those base businesses to  deliver a continued growth, but offset by the investment we’re making in the new opportunities such  as building our market and technology, for example, resources to support the launch of our ballast  water and ultraviolet disinfection product lines BALPURE and MicroDynamics. So those  investments which we plan to be around £5 million will support the growth over the next five years.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: 8 Just a few comments on regulatory developments. Since our publication of our changing cost report  back in April, we’ve been very pleased with the response on the engagement that it’s generated  across many stakeholder groups. Clearly, there are a number of ongoing reviews in the sector, the  Gray Review, the White Paper, and what we’re seeing in there, we’re very encouraged, we’re  seeing our ideas and views on sustainability, financeability and better optimization of water  resources being incorporated into those debate. In particular, we look forward to the planned  Government White Paper later this year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: Most recently, we were encouraged by, of course, publication of the preliminary model highlighting  a number of things, in particular, protection of existing investments, driving the right behavior for  each part of the value chain by putting in place appropriate incentives and the potential to place a  value on water and introduce upstream competition. Our strategy of continuous improvement and  focus on high standards, lowest charges for our customers, great people in Severn Trent puts us in  a strong position to take advantage of those opportunities should they arise.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Okay. Good morning, everybody, and thank you for bearing with us with slight logistical interruption
texts.text: And just a very quick plug for a new publication from Severn Trent which we will be putting out in  June. In Changing Course, we raised the prospects of water trading and our publication coming  forward, Changing Course through water trading, sets out our ideas on how we believe we could  integrate water trading into the existing process for the development of 25-year water resource  management plans. So, please do look out for that one in the coming weeks.

file: SVTL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 30May2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The next driver was the impact of consumption. Measured consumption was down 1.6% year-on-year, which  resulted in a reduction of £10.5 million in turnover.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: However, hired and contracted increased by £36 million due to higher requirements for gangs to fix leaks  following a series of particularly cold winters, particularly the winter of 2011 – of 2010/2011 over the last three  years and the cost of PDaS, which themselves were £3 million. We do not anticipate a similar level of hired and  contracted spend this coming year.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Quasi-taxes, including service charges, environment taxes, et cetera, including the CRC levy at £6 million,  increased by 13.5%. So the CRC – the new introduction of CRC levy was half of that increase – almost half of that  increase.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Severn Trent Services. In this chart, I've set out PBIT before exceptional items over the last four  half-year periods. And I've shown this because of the sequential six-month period as the business started to see  market slowdown and the second half of 2010-2011, the prior year, having seen growth in the first half of this year.  And as you can see, the environment became increasingly challenging over the first half of this last year,  2011/2012. But as we expected in the second half of 2011/2012, we saw an improvement, and this is mainly in the  delivery of the water purification products and mainly in the second half.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: For the full year, reported turnover fell by 1.1% year-on-year and PBIT was down 30%. And, again, this was mainly  due to the lower sales of higher-margin filtration products over the year, but particularly in the first half-year  where they were particularly affected. PBIT was also impacted by our decision to invest through the downturn in  the market. And as such, we invested £2 million overall in business development in both operating services and in  our new ballast water treatment product, BALPURE.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our average debt maturity now is around 16 years. And it's also, in the current climate, worth noting that we  manage our cash very carefully and we invest in deposits with highly rated banks and liquidity funds and we look  regularly at the list of counterparties and, if necessary, we change them.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We, therefore, now feel it's appropriate to share some of the benefits of this outperformance with our  stakeholders. Now, Tony will talk to you in more detail about the additional capital investment, but we aim to  maintain our progress on network improvements and deliver further improvements in customer service levels.  This will also deliver importantly further capability to move water around our network and facilitate water trading  in the future, which I think you will understand is a somewhat topical subject.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So turning to outlook for this current year 2012 and 2013, in Severn Trent Water, we expect OpEx to be higher  year-on-year due to increased investments in our networks including the £150 million that we mentioned  progressively, higher input costs and higher quasi taxes, and we'll offset some of these in relation to some of the  efficiency savings that we will obtain. Our expectation is OpEx in the full year will still be in line with the level of  the final determination.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: CapEx should be between £570 million and £590 million. Within that, we expect the infrastructure renewals to be  somewhat like £140 million to £150 million. And importantly, these numbers now include the cost of PDaS, the  additional investment program we announced today.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: since we launched them back in 2007, some detail on the additional capital investment that we've announced  today, and how our plans are progressing for our next price review, PR14. But first, let me just bring you up-to- date with the very topical subject of drought and water resources.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: We have successfully managed our network through some testing conditions to ensure that our customers have  not had any usage restrictions. We've achieved this by reducing our leakage by another 33 megaliters per day year- on-year improvement, and now that's our lowest ever level of leakage, beating our Ofwat target. We've also been  able to, through our network investment, move our water around our network to preserve supplies where they're  scarce. So this has been our 15th consecutive year with no hosepipe bans – significant, given that prior to April, we  had the driest 18 months on record for the Midlands, which included two very dry winters when we would  normally expect our aquifers and reservoirs to refill.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Now, over and above managing the drought for our own customers, the additional resilience in connectivity in our  networks also helps us to facilitate trading and the development of thoughts on water trading. As many of you will  know, we've been developing those ideas on water trading since we published our paper last summer and we  continue to see opportunities for that going forward.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: You may have heard us talk already externally about one particular example. We've been in discussion with  Anglian Water about how to use some of the available ground water that we have below Birmingham, but we could  use the river network for to transport that surplus through the Rivers Tame and the Trent, across to Anglian to  allow them to abstract at Gainsborough and we will continue to look for opportunities of that type as we continue  to invest in the resilience and the connectivity of our network.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Most critically, we're pleased to see the strong encouragement from Ofwat for water trading, building on the policy  direction set out in the Water White Paper, soon to be the Draft Water White Paper.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Our performance in the drought has been helped by our ability to ensure that our supplies are available for use,  making sure our treatment plants are maintained and available when we need them and that increased our supply  availability for our customers. On leakages, I mentioned, outperformed the Ofwat target and achieved the lowest- ever leakage for Severn Trent.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: On the second component, SIM qualitative, or how a customer feels about their interaction with Severn Trent, our  improvement program that I talked about last year has now started to show improvements in all of the areas that  we targeted, so resolving customer issues and getting things right first time, making it easier for our customers to  contact us and making commitments and keeping them. And over the course of the year, we have seen a  significant improvement in our qualitative scores. We expect that performance improvement to continue.  Just taking a slightly broader look over the last five years, we introduced KPIs back in 2007, first water company  to do that and we've focused on continuous improvement since then. So, for example, customer-written  complaints are down and down now over 70% compared to when we started; sewer flooding incidents, reduced by  10%; first-time job resolution for our customers increased by 10%; and our internal health and safety performance  improved by 50%. Now, our KPIs are not only there to align people to improve service, they're aligned right across  our organization, helping us deliver high standards of service and environmental standards.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Turning to operational expenditure now, and that improvement in operational performance translates into good  performance on cost control, this chart compares the makeup of Severn Trent Water OpEx from 2007 and 2008  compared 2011/2012. And although the operating cost base has grown by some 15% over that time, the makeup  has changed.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: On our non-controllable costs – that's bad debt, rents and rates, service charges such as our abstraction costs –  they've grown by 22%, and now they represent about a third of our total OpEx costs. Now, what we can do – can  and do take action to mitigate some of those, such as our power hedging, renewable strategy, we have less control  over those. But the message here is operational improvement has kept costs that we have direct control over below  inflation.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Of course, being more efficient and delivering greater productivity is also a part of that continuous improvement.  And here's an example of how that also helps us to drive through better customer service. In leakage, we're  delivering more repairs per team per day, as well as significantly reducing the average time to repair the leak. And  this is on the back of our previous investments of things like our SAP, computer systems, our improved leakage  management systems, alongside our people working on driving operational excellence and continuous process  improvement. Finding and fixing leaks quicker is good for customers. It's good for our water resource position,  and, of course, it's good for cost control.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Where we need to improve further is our water below ground assets. So that's the pipes in the ground. Now,  within this, our measures of performance and the key determinants are reducing mains bursts – we're on track  and we're doing well on that – reducing instances of poor pressure – we're on track and we're doing well on that –  and the thing that I've already highlighted that we need to continue to improve is our unplanned interruptions  performance. And that remains our focus in that area for this year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Now, as Mike mentioned, we've announced today that we are investing an additional £150 million of investment  delivering even fewer unplanned interruptions for our customers, more reliable performance of treatment from  our waterworks and our waste treatment works, and even fewer pollution incidents.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: Now, with an eye to the future and continuing to build further resilience and flexibility in our water network as a  component of our future water trading, one example of where that additional investment will be made is in the  renewal of some of our biggest pipes, our trunk mains, to give us greater security and some new valving to give us  greater options for switching our network.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: In Water Purification for products, our market conditions were very mixed. The US saw limited investment by,  again, local municipalities, but we did see activity picking up in the Gulf of Mexico. In our emerging markets, Asia- Pacific, Middle East, North America, they also grew. And in the UK, with the second year of the regulatory cycle  for the water companies kicking in and the capital investment plans really starting to pick up, we saw a pick-up  there. And as Mike mentioned, our BALPURE project is already finding customers ahead of our expectation.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, there was encouragement for water trading such as abstraction incentive mechanism,  reducing abstractions where it's environmentally damaging, deregulating bulk water trading, stronger obligations  on companies to consider imports and exports when planning water resources.  Where we are focusing our attention for all of those things that we like, on those things that are not clear yet, it's  in areas such as the balance between rewards and penalties on incentives and how Ofwat's proposed totex  approach might work.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Thanks, Mike. So this morning, I'm going to focus on a few things: our operational performance across our KPIs
texts.text: So, in summary, we've delivered again on our commitments to our stakeholders. We've beaten our leakage target.  We've reduced supply interruptions. We continue to forecast no water restrictions in our region for this year. And  we've maintained the lowest average charges to our customers. Our strong balance sheet and delivery of capital  efficiencies enables us to increase our investment program to improve further service for our customers. It also  allows us to provide an additional return to our shareholders.

file: SVTL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 30May2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Severn Trent Water PBIT grew year-on-year before cost related to PDaS, which is the first full year that we've had  those cost and while at Severn Trent Services we saw a top line growth and some growth in PBIT before the  investment that we carried out in growth areas and we'll come back to some more of those in detail later.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The third driver was the impact of consumption. Now this was down 1.4% year-on-year due in principal to the  2012 calendar year being the second wettest year on record, which, impacted in particular commercial and  particular agricultural business consumption during the course of that year and this resulted overall in the £19.3  million decrease in turnover. Fourthly, the impact of new properties and meter optants increased turnover by a  modest £1.1 million and with other net movements contributing a negative £4.5 million. This leaves turnover for  Severn Trent Water for the year at £1.511 billion, an increase of £53.5 million or 3.7%, as I said.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As I said before, this is the first full year that we've seen the costs associated with private drains and sewers. And  we saw an increase of £5.7 million year-on-year to an annual cost this last year of just over £10 million.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And moving on to those costs where we believe we have less control, we've been able to keep the bad debt charge  stable at 2.2% of turnover. Power costs for the year have increased, however, by £6.1 million due essentially to  higher consumption as we have had wet weather and we had to pump more of that – particularly on the waste  side, more of it around our networks. There's also been a higher strike price on our energy costs when compared  to the previous year.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Quasi taxes increased by 4.9% (sic) [£4.9 million] and that includes the carbon reduction commitment and  following the announcement last year of additional capital expenditure of £150 million, expenditure on  maintaining our network and infrastructure network increased by £18.8 million in the year. Finally, depreciation  increased by £14.4 million year-on-year due to the higher level of previous additions. So overall, that brings us to a  PBIT of just over £500 million, which as I said is broadly flat year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Michael J. E. McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Like-for-like turnover increased by 5.3%, driven primarily by the strong performance in water purification  products, which saw its revenue grow by 13.4%. This improvement was driven by strong demand for disinfection  and filtration products, principally in China and the Far East, while we also saw growth in demand in Brazil and  Malaysia for electro-chlorination products due to the increased oil and gas exploration in those markets.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: On leakage, we've delivered a further 5% reduction this year. That follows on from a 7% reduction last year. So we  beat our Ofwat year-end target, and as one of the few companies that put a leakage reduction target in throughout  our AMP5 plan, we're on track to deliver our AMP5 target.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And then finally turning to asset serviceability, our key focus for the year was improving serviceability in our water  distribution network. And, as you can see with our targeted mains renewal program, reduction in supply  interruptions, reduction in leakage, we've achieved that, so we now have all four asset classes rated as stable.  That's important in the context of PR14 as it's this year that Ofwat makes its assessments on the state of all  companies' networks.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Ofwat and their KPIs, this chart shows how our performance has progressed since last year. We  have 10 KPIs that have improved since the last year, three that are stable, and one that has deteriorated. So  overall, a very strong improving picture, but with the heavy rainfall last year, as Mike mentioned, and the flash  flooding we saw widely across the region, we did see internal sewer floodings rise. Now despite that, we were still  able to make the network improvements to protect the further 228 properties from the risk of sewer flooding, and  we now have the lowest ever number of properties on our homes at risk of flooding register.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Moving on to our capital investment, and RCV growth, as I said earlier we're on track with our additional £150  million investment announced last year. Over this year, we have invested £54 million and here's some of the  examples of where we've directed it to improve services to our customers. So for instance, we've invested an extra  £17 million finding and fixing leaks, delivering our lowest ever leakage in 20 years.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've invested an additional £8 million replacing trunk main networks, and improving our incident management.  That's been a significant contribution to our interruptions of supply performance improvement. On the waste side  of our business, we spent £12 million on critical assets at our treatment works, and our environmental compliance  is at our best ever level in 15 years and we've invested an additional £4 million, reducing the number of sewer  blockages in the 49 most worst performing drainage areas in our territory.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now as part of our commitment to continuous improvement, we are always encouraging our teams and our supply  chain partners to innovate. And that's alive and well in Severn Trent, and here's just one example I'd like to share  with you of the sort of things that our people invent. This thing is a thing called a Lontra Blower and you won't  know what these are, but let me tell you there are 280 blowers installed across the Severn Trent network. And  what these things do, they provide aeration in a critical part of the sewage treatment process. Now the important  thing to notice, these blowers last year consumed over 182,000 megawatt hours of electricity. That equates to an  electricity bill of about £9 million per annum.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our teams working with Lontra – they're a clean-tech start-up and they develop energy saving compressors for  engines in the UK. We've developed a blower that improves efficiency by 20%. Now rolling that out across our  entire fleet will obviously help reduce our operating costs by reducing our electricity use and cost, but also help  reduce our carbon emissions by about 19,000 tons of CO2. That's about 3% of our total emissions, so innovation is  alive and well in Severn Trent.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In products, revenue and PBIT grew year-on-year led by significant growth in Asia and Brazil in particular, as well  as the first contribution from sales from our BALPURE ballast water treatment projects. We're also seeing growth  in our disinfection and electro-chlorination lines.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Looking at other opportunities for value creation, our plans are on track to install this year our first four wind  turbines. That will move us further towards our target of 30% of our gross energy needs produced from our own  renewable sources. And we're about to start our first food waste anaerobic digester program, which will push us  on beyond that limit. We also continue to have property development opportunities, in particular, developing  some of our surplus land for industrial and commercial use.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We expect final methodology for PR14 from Ofwat in July now, and our business plan will then be submitted in  December along with the independent report from our customer challenge panel, the Severn Trent Water Forum.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our AMP6 capital program, we expect to reflect the ongoing requirement for certainly maintaining the services  and the standards from our networks that our customers already enjoy. We will have to deal with the new quality  standards, such as the Water Framework Directive, and in addition, address customer's requirements now for  security of supply certainly of water resources and protection from the effects of flooding.

texts.speaker: Anthony Paul Wray
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Severn Trent, as Mike covered, has a strong, flexible, sustainable balance sheet, the structure of which you know  we keep under constant review. We maintain our clear focus strategy focused on water. That means continuing to  drive operating performance, improving customer service levels in Severn Trent water, and being ready to exploit  the opportunities that regulatory reform and non-reg provides us. Finally, we are committed to our dividend  policy of growth of RPI+3% until March 2015.

file: SVTL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 29May2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Y ou'll see, for example, we have a 20% improvement in internal sewer flooding, [ph] previous (02:40) customers  are really important measure for us in the company. We've also improved our environmental performance by 41%,  in terms of a 41% reduction in serious pollution incidents. We're one of only of a couple of companies who have  made [ph] I mean any improvement who made a significant (03:00) improvement of that nature. And we've been  commended by the EA [Environment Agency] for the great work in that space.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: If we jump on to talk about the Water part of the business, you'll see that there are 11 indicators in Water, 9 of  which had a good year. In fact, you'll see that a couple of the ones we shared with you last time, still quite proud of  the progress we've made on a couple of these. You'll see that water supply interruptions over 3 h ours have been  reduced by 45%, a very strong performance, as you can imagine, year-on-year. We also see that on leakages, we've  done some good investments in this space. One of only two companies that committed to really making a big  difference on leakages in this AMP [Asset Management Plan]. A matter of fact, we've achieved over 9%  improvements during the course of the AMP so far.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
