texts.text: So, there are two areas, two indicators that didn't go as well as we would've liked. One is around performance of  our water treatment works. And the second, we shared in the slide, is around interruptions over 12 hours. Now, a  good chunk of our mix in this particular target was related to one incident that was lin ked to past years.  Nonetheless, it's a disappointment for us for the year, and there's more for us to be done in the future to make  sure that we deliver again for this particular matter.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So far, we've invested £120 million of that £150 million. And to find evidence as to how that's been invested  wisely, I thought there were two stories that came to mind. The first is around leakages. We've invested £44  million in leakages. As I've said, we're ahead of our amplified targets with more plans to go [ph] and fix (06:38).  And the interesting stat is, that's a 20-year high for us in terms of leakage performance, which is great.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Another area that we've invested, which, again, we can see great results coming through, is around the £16 million  in sewage treatment works. That has led to a best-ever compliance performance of 99.29%. And as I've said, we  see that historically linked to our overall environmental improvement. So, just to share with you, we're on track  with the investments we've committed to, but also probably even more importantly, we're on track with those  investments yielding the benefits that we want those to actually achieve.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Group PBIT pre-exceptional charges was up 4.3%, despite rising power costs and high depreciation in Severn  Trent Water, and lower PBIT from our non-regulated business. Now, there are some exceptional charges of £44  million, and these are made up of three main elements. There was a poor performance, I'll come on to in the  Products business, which led to a total of £3.4 million of restructuring costs this year, and that also led in turn to a  non-cash goodwill impairment of £24.7  million.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The third driver was the impact of measured consumption. Now, this was slightly higher year -on-year due to the  dry summer last year compared to an unusually wet period the year before that, and this resulted in a net increase  in turn of around about £7  million.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, employee costs have risen by £12 million. And that's predominantly as we've invested in focused service  improvement and other investment areas. As a result to the large portion of this has been capitalized, with £5.5  million increase year-on-year in own work capitalized. And hired and contracted costs also rose by £ 6.6 million  during the period. With materials lower year-on-year due to lower spend in wastewater, and costs in other areas  also decreasing, overall directly managed costs grew by 3% year-on-year, and this was in line with inflation.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Moving to indirectly managed costs, we've been able to keep the bad debt charge, yet, again, stable at 2.2%, and  the small decrease of £0.5 million year-on-year. Power costs have increased by £4.7  million in the period due to  higher strike prices on the energy costs compared to the previous period.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Rates and service charges, this includes the carbon reduction, credit levy, also saw an increase of £2.2 million. So,  overall, indirectly managed costs grew by 3.2%, again, slightly above inflation. And this is a trend, unfortunatel y,  we see continuing. So, overall, we're able to keep total company operating costs to an increase of 3.1%.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In contrast, the Operating Services continue to perform well, with growth in revenues and profits year -on-year.  And these were driven by new contract wins in the United States, such as the 10 -year contract with the city of  Bridgeport. Business also acquired 14 contracts in California from the U.S.-based SouthWest Water. In the UK,  our relationship with First Milk group progressed, and we have a 10-year design, build and operate contract to  provide new effluent treatment for the plants we're building in South Wales.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As we stated before, this relates to the tax treatment of certain capital expenditures within our treatment works,  both water and waste. We re-examined that expenditure back to now and including 2001, and now believe that the  current tax credit for the prior-period overpayment to be something like £59 million, and that's up from the £44  million that we announced at the half y ear.

texts.speaker: Michael McKeon
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, let me just cover off the outlook for 2014-2015, which I'll remind you is the final year of AMP5. Prices at  Severn Trent Water rose by 1.5% in April 2014, which was the k-factor of minus 1.1%, and November RPI of 2.6%.  We expect lower measured consumption, and this is in line with the long-term trend after we have unusually  strong consumption in 2013-2014.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Mike. So, two things to cover, the first is PR14. So, we're in a constructive dialogue with Ofwat right now.  We're well on track for our submission, which is June 27 . As you know there's three areas that they've asked  further evidence, and we're in the process of collating that evidence [ph] quickly (21:03). The first of those areas is  ODI. The second is around legacy adjustments at the end of the AMP period. And the third is around the  Birmingham resilience scheme. So, we'll have to take Q&A on tho se [ph] which we'll get to one moment (21:10).

file: SVTL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 22May2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And the last thing we've done in terms of the highlights from last year, is refocused our Business Services division.  As you would have seen, we did a turnaround of subsequent sale of water purification and that now get the  Business Services team focused on our core competencies which is water, waste, retail and renewables.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, you'll see that seven of these are green and that means good strong year-on-year performance  improvements. And there's a couple of those that we think are ac tually quite big ones. They're the ones which are  quite large on the ODI's number going forward. So particularly proud of it. And I'll [ph] turn (02:50) your  attention, for example, to internal sewer flooding. And the reason we think this is actually critical, if we just ask  our customers – and as you know, we did as part of getting ourselves ready for this next period of time – what the  things they most care about, our customers shared the thing they most care about is internal sewer flooding. It's  one of the largest ODIs for that reason and we're proud of our year-on-year performance improvement of 20%.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Another area that's had a significant uplift in the year is around overall provisions. And these are categorized by  the EA. And this particular measure is around category one, two or three pollutions. Y ou might recall that a year  ago, I shared with you that in 2013/2014 we've been the only four-star rated company by the EA, so it's an area  that we are quite strong at. So, if you see a further 18% performance improvement year-on-year; again, it's a really  strong performance. That said, we have a couple of red ones here as well and let's talk about those next.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So actually on serious pollutions, whilst our overall performance on pollutions is much better year-on-year, we did  have two individual more serious pollutions in the last year than we had in the year before. [indiscernible] (03:50)  for us, and we'll be striving to get ourselves back to our best ever performance rates and get ourselves back to the  top of the leader board across all of those pollutions categories.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The second area you see on here as a threat is around the particular basket of measures, and it's only one measure,  as you'll recall, is the same measure we talked about last year. And you remember that we had a discussion last  year regarding coliform reductions. Now, we've made a 33% performance improvement year-on-year on this  particular measure. Nonetheless, it still manages to make that basket red because it's just at outside the Ofwat  reference point. So, even though it's a significant improvement, nonetheless, it's not enough to get us inside the  Ofwat reference point. We did flag that last year that we thought it takes two years to get ourselves back on the  [indiscernible] (04:29) Water Purification and in terms of this particular water quality measure, just wanted to  share that with you up front. There's the two [indiscernible] (04:35) on the high standards we set for  [indiscernible] (04:37). We're pleased with the progress we've made and we're looking forward to the new climate  that is ODIs.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Liv, and good morning everyone. I'm delighted to be presenting these, my first set of results. It's a  great time to be part of the Severn Trent team. I knew the company well by reputation and as a thought leader in  the sector before I took the role. What has really struck me since joining is how aligned and  focused the whole  company is on its customers, on community and environment and on delivering the cost efficiencies and other  challenges of AMP6.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There are lots of valuable commercial opportunities to go after, and I've been pleased to see the high energy and  determination focused on a wide variety of projects, whether it's efficiency improvements through digital  technology in our core wholesale business, maximizing the value of our property portfolio, or in renewables,  where we'll be increasing our self-generation levels to over 50% and achieving some solid low-risk, double-digit  returns on the £190 million investment we communicated in March.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The company has spent the time ahead of AMP6 valuably by getting the business in the best possible shape and, as   you'll hear shortly from Liv, we're already well up the curve on securing the planned efficiencies and have  outperformance very much in our sights. This forward thinking hasn't stopped with the beginning of AMP6. We're  planning for the next industry challenges such as sludge and water trading and more near term, how the non- household retail market will pan out from 2017 and how we can be ahead of the pack. It's exciting time to join.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We also decided to increase contractor spend in the second half of the year by just under £7 million on projects  that get us in the best place to start AMP6. During the year, we've continued to focus on o ptimizing and refining  debt recovery initiatives such as customer risk segmentation and Water Direct payment plans, which have helped  to improve our credit management performance by £3 million in the year and resulted in a bad debt charge of 2%  of revenue, that's down from 2.2% last year. Power costs also fell due to increased renewables generation and our  continuing drive to reduce energy consumption.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to our non-regulated business, the focus hasn't just been on AMP6 this year. We committed to you  last year that we would turn around the Water Purification business, and we've done this. And our decisive actions  drove the business from a loss position last year to an operating profit of £4.9 million this year. And as you would  have seen in our announcement on May 13, the deal with the DeNora valued the whole business at $99 million,  which represents an EBITDA multiple of around 8 times.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to the continuing operations in the Severn Trent Services, which exclude the Water Purification  business. We grew revenue year-on-year by just under 5% by contract wins in the U.S. and new business in the  UK. Profit for the year was impacted by investment in our business development capabilities in the U.S. and year- on-year performance was also affected by some one-off favorable items that benefited our 2013/2014  comparatives.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And last of all, we remain excited about the renewables opportunity. We've been leader of the pack for a while in  terms of self-generation of energy. But nonetheless, we believe there is more. That's why we have chosen to spend  £190 million. And getting to the point where we generate over half of our needs in terms of equivalent energy  generation, it will be a great addition and that's what we'll do between now and 2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The second thing we've been working on is around the Birmingham Resilience scheme. We've been working on  lots of our capital programs, but the one I thought I'd give you the update on is the largest of the capital schemes  certainly for us, but also for the sector, which is the Birmingham Resilience scheme. And it's a number of smallish  activities which add up to progress in this space.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So for example, we've been purchasing the key land points, the particular pumping station point is now bought  near Southport. That's done. We've also been looking at the pipeline land for making sure that we get focused in  terms of planning permissions and also making sure we get the extraction permissions we need. That's in addition  to securing the correct contracts right at the start of phase 1. So we believe that overall, we're in good shape, which  is the largest of our capital programs.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The second thing I want to say on ODI is that quite rightly, the regulators set very high target before you get into  the reward zone. And I want to bring that to light so you can see that year one on most of the ODIs, is the big step  change here. And what you can see here is for water quality complaints that in the first year to get into a reward  territory, you've got to do about a 17% improvement. In years two or three, it becomes a more manageable 8% or  9%, and then, as you can see, it's flat thereafter. So the key thing is – I know lots of you asked me questions about  what do I put in the model in terms of ODIs, and I guess the only guidance I can give you is it's a slow burn, right?  It's not an instantaneous moment, one, because there is this big first off year where quite a few of measures, you  have to do a big improvement.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So to bring Coalport to life, and I guess I will probably give you an example, every one of these results say going  forward, but to bring Coalport to life, we're talking about sludge treatment works. And what we would naturally  have done and within the FD plan, is that we would straight replace our digesters which had come to the end of  their natural life cycle in terms of 30 years old, and are ready for replacement.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: What we did as part of our chief engineer creative testing solutions is looked again at options, and the solutions  we're now going with is actually to build a dewatering plant and actually it's a tanker to a nearby site using  efficiency more at nearby site and not spending on the asset financially. When you look at the configuration of our  network, we have another option available to us. That actually saves us 30% of the plant's totex spend which is a  fantastic achievement, and that's an example of totex thinking. So, you can see that saved us £4.9 million, which is  just great.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And in terms of where that's come from, as you can see down on the slide, 60% of that £100 million, £60 million  come from new supplier contracts and broadly it's based around two. So one of which is a chemicals contract,  which Helen actually alluded to at Capital Markets Day, and the second of which is a new contract we've got with  Amey, which is our partner – we had two partners in our wastewater business. We've now moved to a single  supply contract with Amey and renegotiated a really contract with them which is in line with some of the activities  that are linked to ODI payments but likewise as equally helps us in terms of savings.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We're also actively involved in making sure that as Open Water gets set up, that would contribute towards the  creation of that competition model in industry. We believe it's important to have people from Severn Trent  seconded on some of these key industry programs, but currently, we've got people seconded into the DWI and also  seconded into Open Water. We're actively working with Welsh as part of the Silk Commission reforms and  contributing to that discussion. We'll make we're listening and also adding value in that.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, there's one area that we're less enthusiastic about, and that is the proposed changes from Ofwat in terms of  the CIS reconciliation and in terms of midnight adjustments in 2020. We don't agree with that at all. We've made  that clear. We've submitted our points to Ofwat. I guess we now await their decision, but it's worth being clear  that's one area that we are less keen on. And with that, maybe we'll talk something we are more keen on, which is  renewable.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So, renewables. So, we mentioned to you guys – let's just jump next slide to renewables, if that's okay. Well, we  mentioned to you guys at the Capital Markets Day that we saw an opportunity for us to continue to spe nd in the  space. We currently have 28% of our energy this year equivalent [indiscernible] (31:26) self-generated. And we  want to switch that to around 50% by 2020.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: We shared with you before, there were a number of technologies, and it's a portfolio plan. So it's a mixture of AD  spend in sludge, also in crop and also in food waste, and then in solar. And that's what we've been doing over the  course of the last while and we shared that with you in March, just getting ourselves ready to begin to make this  happen. And we've seen some good early successes. So we've seen actually the last self-generation entirely from  our current assets improved slightly towards the tail-end of the year, and we exited at about 30% per month self- generation.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The second bit of good news is having decided that we're going to do solar. And we've now got ourselves ready for  the first solar array, we'll actually go live in July. So quite a short time window. It's actually six weeks when you've  got the site ready and everything is commissioned – and everything is bought, but actually commissioning is a  very tight time window. So six weeks, so the first of those will go live in July.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And we continue to make progress in our AD agenda, with the second of our food waste plants now clear in our  minds as to where it can be located and beginning the progress towards securing the contract for that and  beginning to build. So, good solid progress. As you know, we believe this is a good economic case for us. It's good  for our customers, we believe it's good for as a company. It's always something we are going to need is energy, and  we think this gives us a good opportunity to get ourselves over 50%, and as such is a natural hedge for us going  forward, and more volatile pricing.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: And it includes educating our people to become conversant and almost second nature talking about totex and  ODIs. It means making sure that our Business Service division best sorted for the future and that meant the sale of  WP and we are refocused and ready to focus on our core skills, which is water, waste, retail and renewables. A nd  it's also about putting customers right at the heart of our strategy because we believe fantastic customer  experience helps create long-term shareholder value. And that, of course, is the great discussion of the day.

file: SVTL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24May2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And the couple of things that we're most proud of, I think, is the fact that we've achieved £23.2 million worth of  ODI rewards in the first year. And also, that we've identified £670 million worth of totex efficiency savings to be  delivered over the five years. Now, in terms of just [indiscernible] (01:55), a year ago, I talked about this winning  formula. And I've said and I believe the sector works best when we have balance. And by balance, I mean that  there is success for all three main parts of our stakeholders. And that means that customers need to win. And we  think they win when they have good value build and also, fantastic customer service. We didn't get regulator wins  and we begin to push the benchmarks on cost and also performance metrics driving better performance for  customers for the future.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We're proud of the fact that we've been the frontier company in waste, but we know there's more to be done to  step change ourselves on water.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: With energy as the second highest cost, we believe that a key part of strategy is making sure that we are standard  setters in renewable energy, and we're delighted that we've seen a 17% improvement in the amount of energy that  we self-generate in the last 12 months.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, turning now to our regulated business. Regulated Water and Waste Water remains the heart of our group,  comprising our wholesale water and waste water operations and our regulated household retail business. We've  shown here the turnover for Regulated Water and Waste Water on a like-for-like basis one last time to enable  comparison to the old Severn Trent water segmental results and also on the new reporting basis, following the  change to our segment reporting at the start of this year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Like-for-like, our turnover is down £31 million or 2%, primarily due to the £30 million of net price impact with  higher consumption year-on-year and growth in our customer base being offset by other minor changes and tariff  mix. To get to the new reported basis of turnover of £1.506 billion, we strip out the £17.5 million of regulated  renewable energy revenue that we're now reporting in Business Services and just under £27 million of revenue for  non-household retail. And this is a net number between the £391.3 million of external non-household revenue  now reported in Business Services, offset by the £364.7 million of Regulated Water and Waste Water division  charges for the related wholesale services.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to our PBIT for this division. On a new reporting basis, PBIT for our Regulated Water and Waste  Water business was £492 million. On a like-for-like basis, PBIT was down 3.5% or £18.7 million to £520.3 million.  And as shown in the waterfall, the decrease in regulated revenue of £31 million is the primary driver of this year - on-year movement. This aside, we delivered some good savings across our cost base with operating costs lower  year-on-year as guided by around £15 million.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Hired and contracted spend was £8.5 million higher than last year and this increase included ne w spend in  preparation for market opening, increased waste water distribution cost over the winter months, and incentive  payments to our contractors to help us deliver our ODI rewards. Our power costs were lower by £2.1 million this  year. We saw a good increase in our regulated renewables output, including £4 million of additional gas to group  sales, which was partially offset by slightly higher energy consumption particularly on the water side as we put  more water into supply and pumped more diverted water to enable asset upgrades. With net energy cost of around  £62 million for the group as a whole, we're absolutely focused on using less, generating more, and paying the  lowest energy prices.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: With the creation of the Water Plus JV, which from 2016/2017 will not be part of our consolidated financial  statements. Our bad debt charge will be on the remaining household customers and will therefore be closer to 2%  as a percentage of revenue.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to our infrastructure renewals. You'll recall that we had a low charge in the first half of the year. We've  increased activity significantly in the second half. However, year-on-year spend remained £8.8 million as we  benefited from better commercial contracts and more efficient work to programming. Depreciation charges are  £11.3 million higher in the year, with the increase due equally to the higher underlying asset base and accelerated  write-offs on some older assets, which we decommissioned as part of our cleanest water and renewables upgrade  programs.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Material and other costs were £2.6 million lower year-on-year. Higher costs, in particular, on business rates and  abortive capital write-offs were more than offset by the £4.4 million refund from the Environment Agency in the  first half, and property disposal proceeds, which in the second half were in line with those reported for the first  half. And we see the disposal of our surplus property assets as an ongoing opportunity that will benefit all of our  stakeholders. Adjustments for the new segmental reporting transferred to Business Services £17.6 million of PBIT  for regulated renewables and £10.6 million for non-household retail, resulting in a reported PBIT of £492 million  for the full year. So, let's turn now to our Business Services division.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As a reminder, for 2015/2016, this division included our Operating Services business, the regulated and non - regulated renewable energy business and non-household retail operations, which will shortly be transferred to the  new JV. Water purification is of course excluded, following its sale in July 2015. Turnover in Operating Services  was up 7 .8% on a like-for-like basis driven by growth on our existing business in the UK and overseas. And PBIT  was up 10.3% on both revenue growth and lower overhead costs. Our renewables business contributed £16.9  million on turnover of £50.1 million, and we're now generating the equivalent of 33% of our energy needs, and  that's up from 28% at the end of last year. Our non-household retail business billed customers £391.3 million and  generated PBIT of £10.6 million.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning back now to focus on our regulated business. Let's look at how we performed on a Return on Regulatory  Equity or RoRE basis. To start, the base allowed return on equity, as set in our Final Determination, was, of  course, just under 5.7%. Our strong ODI performance of £23 million before tax translates into 0.7 percentage  points of outperformance. Our staff and our supplier partners have worked hard for these results, but we also  acknowledge that the relatively benign weather in our region this year has certainly helped. And as such, we're not  forecasting to see a repeat of this performance every year, particularly as the ODI targets continue to get tougher.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, turning to technical guidance for the full year ahead. I'll leave you to look over the detail but I'd like to  highlight the key points. First, in our Regulated Water and Waste Water business, we expect to see lower OpEx  again this year as we continue driving cost efficiencies. Second, we expect to step up both our infrastructure  renewals expenditure and our wholesale CapEx, meaning that wholesale totex will be between £1.11 billion and  £1.13 billion for the full year. 42.1% of this wholesale totex will be added to the RCV. And third, we're forecasting  £15 million of net ODI rewards. Lower than 2015/2016 as the targets are reset for each year of the AMP and  become more challenging in year two.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Fourthly, I guess you can see here, is energy. We genuinely believe that as a high cost line for us, the opportunity  for us to self-generate is a strategic tenet of our strategy going forward, and we're really pleased to have mov ed  from 28% self-generation last year to 33% self-generation this year. And lastly, as James mentioned, we're pleased  with our strategy to move towards more floating rather than safe debt has proved to be effective and to deliver the  results that we [ph] thought (23:07) within the year with a 90 base points improvement. Now, it's the combination  of financing, ODIs and totex that adds up to the RoRE calculation, which gives us the 8.4% for the first year.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And it's tricky to begin all those examples, there are four under them, as well as the two here. But these are just a  couple to try and bring it to life. On the left, you got Waterpedia, and Waterpedia is a standard management  system and it basically brings together all of the standards you have on an organization like ours, which we want  people to be referring to. It allows us to be data-driven to make better prioritization decisions and to use the data  of the point we need to make the right call. And we've got 1,200 colleagues who've got access to Waterpedia on the  handheld devices, using this on a daily basis.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Now, there's still more to be done. Water quality complaints, as an example, is a measure that we're disappointed  in our performance this year. Y ou can see it's red on here, and whilst we have a concrete plan and strategy in place  as to how we're going to improve, we've not managed to make that progress at the pace and momentum we  would've liked in the first year of the AMP.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Now to try and bring out to exactly what you need to do to have a strong view on ODIs, what I'd want to do now is  shine a spotlight on one particular metric. It's one of the ones that our customers said they were absolutely  passionate about. There's nothing worth that has happened to your home is to end up whether you're affected by  internal or external sewer flooding. And we've seen our performance improved 28% from external sewer flooding  and it's not by chance that's sort of a huge amount of hard work and we have 13 different work streams running to  deliver improvement in this space. And I just want to touch on four of those work streams now.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The first is around data analytics. And here, we took 10 years worth of data, and we're talking seasonal data,  meteorological data, repeat performance in a particular location, we mashed up together to und erstand. If we  were then actually to change our preemptive investments to actually go out and visit that work in a different  manner, to invest our money in a slightly different manner, will that yield positive results, which it did.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The second thing we did is we looked even more in detail of a correlation between blockages and floodings, and we  then worked with various institutions whether it was universities or fast food chains to understand how we could  be, I guess, more savvy in terms of our sewers. What would a healthier sewer look like, and we did a series of  education plans with tightened institutions like that.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: What we've then done, as we've said in November, that we were confident of locking in a further £50 million by  today by the announcements of our May results. A natural fact, we're ahead of that. We've locked in £80 million.  The next number then is identified but isn't yet locked in at £180 million worth of efficiency savings. So, we're  giving you guidance that we're confident to delivering over the course of the next few years. In total, that takes us  to £67 0 million.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: What we've then done is we believe, as I said earlier, this tend to works best when the balance of all needs and  desires of all of our various stakeholders are managed. And as such, we're electing – of the £260 million  outperformance, we're electing to spend back £120 million on areas that we believe are important to our  customers. And the areas that we believe are most important is water quality, enhanced security and also making  sure that we cancel that step change we talked about on vulnerable customers. And that is a totex spend that will  play out in the same way to spend, other total spend and we're going to see RCV in exactly the same equation as  you would expect.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We're proud of the fact that we've made progress. This is absolutely just in line though with our previously  announced strategy. We've got a strong track record of being the sector frontier company on waste, though there is  more to be done for us in terms of our water efficiency and this is around moving us towards the upper quartile on  water and that's been why we've been working so hard to get these locked in and identified as early as possible in  the AMP.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And to give you an example of what a type of saving here would look like, if you were to think about our rapid  gravity filters, so quite simply, I guess, the way in which we – the process we use to filter water, so it's good to  drink. We've obviously been buying this for a few AMPs . But the opportunity to make sure that we buy this AMP  are effectively [indiscernible] (35:11) to be delivered and also cheaper is one that we've ceased. And through  collaborative planning, to understanding how to make sure the entire process is done quicker, we've been able to  procure this 30% faster to build at 20% reduction in price.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And it became apparent to run the tender process, the money was being lost by the fact t hat it wasn't an attractive  scheduling approach and by a high number of water visits. We've worked on that collectively, and that means that  we've got a better price, but actually the supplier is equally pleased. And by putting incentivization instead of  contracts as well, it gives both of us a joined ambition to deliver as much as we can.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So jumping now to talk about energy. Now energy, as James mentioned, we want to make sure that as our costs  that we have spent quite a lot of money during the course of the year, we want to self-generate more. We want to  make sure that we actually use less, and we want to make sure that certainly when we do buy, we buy it cheaply as  possible. And this is just sound economic good sense for us. We're signing off business cases to have double-digit  IRR returns, so it will give for us in terms of [indiscernible] (37:16) to see the impact for the year, but they're also  good for the future. So, it's good financial sense for us. It all factors to be good for the environment and a  good  opportunity going forward for our business. We're pleased with our progress this year. The key fact would be 44  gigawatt hours of extra energy generated, a 17% increase in energy generated from 28% last year to 32% this year  and absolutely firmly on track for a 50% ambition by 2020 within the £190 million cost that we've previously  talked about.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We have three regulators that we work closely with. Starting with the drinking water inspectors. And we've been  clear, we're one year into a three-year plan to really drive up our cleanest water program which is our internal plan  for all the activities in our water ambitions.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've also been openly supportive of the vast majority of proposals that are in the Water 2020 documentation as  you can see by our published consultation responses. This one area, I guess, where we're not quite in agreement  and that's around the migration to CPI. But we believe [indiscernible] (39:02) a little bit of uncertainty as we look  forward to seeing what comes up tomorrow.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And the third regulatory relationship is the Environment Agency. We've worked extremely hard over the last 12  months to live up to the high expectations that our customers have from us in environmental credentials. We  think this is critical as part of our longer-term ambition to be the most trusted company in our sector. We're  actually delighted to have received for the last couple of days a letter from the EA shar ing that we've been  provisionally awarded the four-star status. Now, the four-star status, for those of you who don't know, is the  leading accolade that effectively says you are the best company in your text. That's what four -star status is. And it's  the second time in three years that we will have been awarded that which is actually fantastic, and we're super  proud of all the hard work of our colleagues in achieving that.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: To give you a sense of what you've got to do to be able to deliver I guess achieveme nts like that, we've seen our cat  3 pollutions dropped by 21% year-on-year and our serious pollutions dropped by 8% year-on-year, bearing in  mind we're already a leading company in this particular measures.

file: SVTL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 23May2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, our vision is to be the most trusted water company by 2020. And we believe that if we do the right thing and  we continue to deliver the very best returns for customers, for colleagues, the communities and also investors that  that we'll achieve that trust. And so I'd like to talk about, before highlighting today's results, then hand to James to  talk to the financials in detail.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our Regulated Water and Waste Water business, which comprises our wholesale water and waste  water operations and our regulated household retail business. Turnover is up 1.5%, mainly due to the annual RPI  increase and higher consumption with some partial offset from an increase in meter optants and other small  movements. Dee Valley contributed £2 million of turnover in the regulated business from just over a month in our  ownership.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: This year, our Regulated Water and Waste Water business has delivered growth in PBIT of 2.5%. Turnover  contributed £22.7 million of that growth. Our net labor costs were down £3.9 million year-on-year due to  continuing efficiency improvements in our operations. Our net hired and contracted costs were also low year-on- year, reflecting tighter supplier contract management and some insourcing of activities that we can do more  efficiently in-house.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The full year reported cost of £146 million also includes approximately £7 million to prepare our wholesale  business for the new non-household retail market. We saved over £2 million on power costs, lowering our overall  energy usage despite increasing water into supply to make consumer demand and we've also actively managed  our wholesale prices which reduced year-on-year. Our household bad debt charge has remained steady at 1.8%  of household revenue as we continue to make good progress on supporting our vulnerable customers and  improving cash collection across our customer base.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As planned, we significantly stepped up investment in our infrastructure renewals program up by £10 million  compared to last year. With our asset base growing by 4%, our annual depreciation charge has also increased as  expected. Material and other costs have remained broadly flat despite a refund from the Environment Agency of  £4 million flattering prior-year comparatives. This reflects a number of efficiency programs across the business,  including ambitious regional store strategy, which has helped reduce material cost by over £2 million.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Moving onto our Business Services division. This year, we have, as promised, continued to grow the top and  bottom line in both Operating Services and Renewable Energy. Turnover increased by £33 million with around  £23 million coming from favorable movements in the U.S. dollar and euro and £10 million from underlying growth.  PBIT increased by £8.8 million or 31%.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: In Operating Services, we have some good contract wins, maintained high customer retention and effectively  managed some of our lower margin contracts. In February, we sold our small Italian business, which this year  contributed around £21 million in turnover and around €0.5 million in profit. In the renewables business, turnover  increased by 8% to £54 million and PBIT increased by £2.5 million, driven by higher electricity generation from  sludge and crops. I look forward to sharing more with you on our renewables business shortly.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: During the year, we invested cash of £24 million to set up Water Plus, £78 million to bring Dee Valley into the  group, and received net cash of £5 million on the disposal of our Italian business.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Turning to energy. We're building a diversified and sector-leading renewables business that's delivering double- digit IRRs on all new investments and a rapidly growing EBITDA up 16% to £26 million this year. We're on track  for our 2020 target of generating the equivalent of at least 50% of our energy needs, and we've now built or  commenced construction on the majority of all the assets needed to hit this target. And in the next 12 months,  we're looking forward to further contributions from three schemes in food waste, THP, and crop digestion.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Through team effort and some healthy inter-site competition, we've reduced power usage across the business by  10-gigawatt hours this year, further securing our 50% target. And we have a full program of energy efficiency  activities for 2017/2018. However, we are expecting power cost to rise next year as we're hit, along with others in  the sector, with higher pass-through costs, which for us will be up around £6.5 million.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: A key component of the investment case in Severn Trent is our strong RCV growth. Based on company final  determinations, we started AMP6 with the fastest-growing RCV of the listed water and sewerage companies, and  our latest estimate for our 2020 RCV is around £9.5 billion, an increase of around 23% in nominal price terms.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Finally, to our technical guidance for 2017/2018, and I'd like to pull out a few highlights. In our Regulated Water  and Waste Water business, turnover will be higher year-on-year due to agreed price increases and a full year of  Dee Valley. We're guiding to a range of £1.57 billion to £1.6 billion. Operating costs are expected to increase due  to addition of Dee Valley's operations and the impact of sector-wide changes in business rates and the energy  pass-through costs I mentioned earlier. We lost other inflationary pressures with further efficiencies.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And for customer ODIs, we'll strive to continue our exceptional operating performance through next year. But with  tougher regulatory targets and a lower number of debt bans and factoring in a 10-year average weather profile  after two very mild winters, we expect our year three net rewards to be around £23 million.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And the single most important measure that jumped off the page was around sewer flooding, and our customer  said that was the one again switched at the highest fashion. And as such, that measure, which has the highest  associated [indiscernible] (17:48) linked to it. And we're really pleased to have delivered a 40% improvement over  two years and to have beaten the regulatory target by 21% on combined performance with our best-ever  performance on that measure set this year.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Quite rightly when customers are still on the taps, they expect that water to be readily available. And as such,  we're pleased to have beaten the regulatory targets by 17% on supply interruptions.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We're passionate about being environmental leaders and the most visible measure that is defined in the  environment space is Cat 3 pollutions, and we've beaten the regulatory target by a whopping 25% in that space.  So, we are proud of the fact we've had an exceptional year across almost all of our ODI measures.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Of course, there remains more to be done. And if there's one that I guess we've got a little bit disappointment  around, it will clearly be around our water quality complaints performance. And we're going to double up our  efforts. We're going to invest more in mains cleaning and flushing. We're going to take the benefits of Dee Valley,  which had a fantastic improvement over the last while and make sure that our customers can count on us to keep  making progress.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, a year ago, we talked about the fact that we were choosing to reinvest £120 million of our outperformance in  areas that customers cared about most and that was water quality, security and vulnerable customers. We're  pleased with the progress we're making in that space, and we've now contracted £50 million of that £120 million,  and we're on track to identify and contract the remainder during the course of the next 70 months.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, let's move on now and talk about the evolution of our sector. We believe you want to be on the front foot. It is  an evolving situation which is exciting for the sector and we want to make sure that we're part of shaping that  agenda. You might recently have read our latest publication in the Charting a Sustainable Course series and this  was around the fact that we believe there's a real opportunity for regulators to use the incentive regime to create  real benefits for customers as well as real desire for companies to outperform.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We passionately said that we want to make sure that we're shaping that agenda in terms of the sector and we're  pleased with the fact that we decided to take a different approach when we looked at non-household competition.  Now whilst it's early days, it's going to be live in a matter of weeks. We are encouraged by the early signs of the  positive situation with our joint venture with United Utilities entitled Water Plus.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: For a long period of time, we've said that we welcome and support competition in the marketplace. And with that  in mind, we're happily looking forward to the opening of two new markets as we head towards 2020, both  bioresources and water resources. And we love the fact that we work in a sector, we have strong transparent  overview on what's going to come between now and 2025.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've been able to make sure that we continue our investments in technology to make our colleagues' life easier  and we've also been able to continue our journey towards the fact that great businesses are businesses which  have really strong corporate social responsibility credentials and also that atmosphere and feel throughout the  company. And an example of that, I guess, will be that recently, we announced a new volunteering program. And  literally in a matter of the first few weeks, we saw 1,000 colleagues sign up to that [indiscernible] (23:17) helping  to clean up rivers and canals, which we know is something customers care about most within our past  reorganization.

file: SVTL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 23May2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So, given the lively debate that exists right now across our sector, [indiscernible] (00:14), strategy to be the most  trusted water company felt more relevant. And we're going to achieve that through a balanced performance for all  of our stakeholders, whether it's customers, communities, colleagues and our investors.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And as previously announced, our full year dividend will be £0.8655 which is an increase of 6.2% on 2016/2017  reflecting our dividend policy of RPI plus 4% growth. In our Regulated Water and Waste Water business, turnover  grew by 3% overall mainly driven by the RPI-linked tariff increases in Severn Trent Water of £34 million and a full  year of Dee Valley ownership which added an additional £26 million of revenue this year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Underlying PBIT for regulated water and waste water grew by 4.1% or £20 million. This was driven by the higher  turnover I mentioned previously, a full year's contribution from Dee Valley and good control of our underlying cost  base despite the challenges of power and business rate increases and a harsher winter.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As I guided, power costs – power pass-through costs were higher this year accounting for over £5 million of the  £6.9 million increase in power cost year-on-year. Our bad debt charge increased by £4.7 million in the year. We're  successfully collecting more current debt from our customers but have seen a decline in the amount of older debt  being paid in both accounts collected by us and by other water companies on our behalf. The prudent  provisioning we applied to this older debt increased by both charge for the year and the level of bad debt as a  percentage of household revenue 2.2%. We're applying new, innovative credit management strategies to tackle  this change in collection profile.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's turn now to our Business Services segment which following the sale of our U.S. and Italian businesses now  comprises Operating Services in the UK and Ireland and Renewable Energy. And once again, we've seen top and  bottom line growth in both Operating Services and Renewable Energy. Operating Services had a strong year  benefiting from a new contract with plumbing and drainage insurers that contributed significantly to both revenue  and PBIT, up £3.9 million and £3.1 million respectively year-on-year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our Renewable energy business is also growing well with revenues up 11.9% to just over £60 million. PBIT also  grew but at a lower rate as startup cost on our new Roundhill gas-to-grid, food waste plants impacted overall  margins. We generated the equivalents of 38% of our energy needs this year, and the new capacity coming on  stream in 2018/2019 from our third food waste plant in Derby and the expansion of our crop digester at Stoke  Bardolph will help towards our 50% end of AMP target, hedging the group against rising wholesale power cost.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: As part of our preparation for AMP7, from this year, we'll be managing and reporting all of our bioresources  activity in Business Services, which I'll discuss further in a moment and provide more details on in our July trading  update.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's turn now to RoRE, which representing in line with our first methodology to allow clearer comparison with  others in the sector. We're pleased to report our best year yet for RoRE, outturning at 11.5% for the year. As you  can see, this performance has been broadly based from outstanding service delivery on waste customer ODIs,  continued totex efficiencies across the business, and a good trajectory on financing based on a balanced debt  strategy, and of course, aided in 2017/2018 by higher RPI.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Our performance this year takes us to a cumulative RoRE for the first three years of the AMP of 9.3%. For the last  two years of the AMP, we expect RoRE to be impacted by the waste ODI cap as we've now owned broadly all the  available rewards on waste, our reinvestment of the £220 million of totex savings we've announced, and lower  financing performance based on current RPI forecast.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We're looking forward to the competitive bioresources market and have made a number of early changes to get  ready. We've created six regional treatment hubs, and we made our first trade from one of these earlier this  month.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: We've rationalized our tanker bases to reduce miles travelled. We're using advanced treatment techniques to give  economies of scale and greater gas generation, and we've identified and closed our least efficient sites. As a  result of these actions, we've incurred £17 million of accelerated depreciation and £4 million of other restructuring  costs, which have been recorded as an exceptional charge in the year.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's turn now to our technical guidance for 2018/2019, and I'd like to put out a few highlights. In our Regulated  Water and Waste Water business, turnover will be high year on year of between £1.62 billion and £1.65 billion,  reflecting RPI-based price increases and £17 million of gross ODI outperformance payments from 2016/2017 with  the largest share being carried over to future years.

texts.speaker: James Bowling
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Operating costs are expected to increase as the continued pressure of high energy pass-through costs and an  increase in EA license fees offsets our delivery of further efficiency. On customer ODIs, taking into account of  Waste cap, we expect to be in a neutral position for year four.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And broadly, they divide into these eight categories. And as you can see on the slide, we've got six that are green,  one that's amber, and one that is red. And that's because of a disappointing performance on two measures that  traditionally were stronger, but this year we've not been as good at. I'm confident that as we continue to deliver  our plans, we'll keep improving. I'm confident that across this wider basket, this feels like a fair reflection of our  current performance. We have got some absolutely fantastic performance areas. Nonetheless, there are some  areas we can and will continue to improve.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: So let's move on and talk about our water performance. It's been a mixed year. So on the one hand, we've had a  couple of measures, which we've been really disappointed in. On leakage, we've had seven years of fixing our  leakage targets and yet and having been on track actually for almost all of this year right to the last few weeks.  Nonetheless, we ended up where in March, we lost the ability to hit that because we just couldn't recover quick  enough, having been affected by some of the harsh winter weather.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now, quite rightly, we've taken significant penalties against our performance on those two metrics. As you'd recall,  at the start of the regulatory period, we took a different [indiscernible] (16:27) which were quite bold call on ODIs.  We said we put big risk and big reward against those metrics. And we're proud of the fact that our waste business  has had such strong performance, but actually it lessens the blow, leaving us with an £80 million net ODI reward  for the year.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Across the wider water business, there were actually many reasons to be cheerful. Since the start of the AMP,  we've improved water quality complaints by fantastic 12%, improved low pressure by 11%, and we've also  improved coliform detections by one-third. And when you look at water quality complaints, a measure we've talked  about a few times, the fact that we've had a good structure program, we've invested wisely, we've learned from  Dee Valley, we've worked well with partners, that has led to that turnaround, and we're now confident of being  back on track for the FD by the end of the AMP on water quality complaints.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Let's move on and talk about our waste business. Now, our waste business has had an outstanding year, and not  just on the ODIs, which have been stellar, but actually across all the waste metrics, and we believe that it's the  underlying performance culture that's truly ingrained. It's the relationships we've got with our partners and  suppliers in the space which really works. It's the fact also though that we invested wisely. You'd recall, we  invested at the end of AMP5 and again early in AMP6 to have that fast start, and that's paid back for us. And we  feel that we're in really great shape across the piece going into the next AMP. We're actually excited to see how  far can we push our waste water performance in the tail end of this AMP and leading into the next.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: Now part of waste, of course, is environmental performance, and we're proud of our environmental track record  this year. Just two metrics that I'll call your attention to. The first is that we're expecting to receive the coveted  four-star status from the Environment Agency again. That will be for the second time in three years. And only a  couple companies traditionally get that, two or three companies receive that each year, and it means strong  performance across a whole basket of environmental measures. We're also proud of the fact that we've once  again been reaccredited by the Carbon Trust. We've been member since 2009. We're proud of that. We're  pleased again to have gone through the renewal process and to have been chosen for that accreditation again.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: The second is on anything that we consume, whether it's energy, whether it's our own water to our network, or  anything we consume, how do we make sure that we're as efficient as possible in our manner around that? And  that means there is more opportunity for us on energy costs for the future. There's more opportunity for us to  manage our network more efficiently for the future as well, and that's the second big area is in that consumption of  basic supplies.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And the last area then is obviously investments. It's one of the plans, one of the preparations. And we've just  recently submitted the big schemes that we believe we've got some logic to them, and we're just looking forward  to discuss with them over the course of the next one. As you can imagine, it's focused on environment, it's  focused on supply demands for the future. And that are opportunities that we believe while still keeping bills to be  decreasing in the future, nonetheless, there is a real opportunity now for the sector to lower bills to customers and  to invest for the long term, and we look forward to that being part of our plan that we submit in September.

texts.speaker: Olivia Garfield
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Severn Trent Plc
texts.text: And we can actually make a real difference to people's lives. If you look at the social deprivation in the patch that  we serve, actually about 30% of it is socially mobile cold spots, and that's the real opportunity for us as we recruit  and make sure that we're looking to give jobs in those areas that maybe traditionally wouldn't have such a great  role. And we're really proud of our ongoing recruitments in some of the social mobile cold spots and the  opportunity to join us and to succeed and do well.

And in the current context, this is a major asset for a Group  such as ours.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Executive Committee
