texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: I would like to mention three of those awards. For the 10th year running, we have been recognized by the Dow  Jones Sustainability Index as a world leader in sustainable development in our own line of business. I think it's  something to be proud of.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: In 2006, we started by providing foodservices to them, so that started building trust with them . And it really gave  us the position of an observer within the walls of the hospital. We were able to identify very closely the needs of  this particular customer. And this is what happened. We identify a major necessity that is to better control their  energy consumption. So that resulted in an audit assignment which itself resulted in a new contract for energy  management. And now we are helping this hospital to renew and keep its accreditation and to reduce its energy  consumption and energy expenditures, and this resulted in a 30% decrease in the cost of energy consumption for  them.

texts.speaker: Siân Herbert-Jones
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And finally, in the Rest of the World, growth stands at only 0.2%, but as we've been explaining to you over the past  three quarters, we have to look very clearly at each customer segment to understand this better. There's been quite  a significant falloff in the Remote Site segment, down 7%, because projects have come to an end. And basically,  overall, our mining customers have been reducing their projects, the scope of their projects and their operating  costs. However, we've got very high levels of energy within our commercial teams in Sodexo in the energy sector.  And I think that in the Off-site, the Remote Sites, next year will be going back into growth. If we exclude the  Remote Sites, the revenue for the Rest of the World is closed to 7%.

file: SW - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 19November2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Lastly, let me mention some of our actions which show our commitment through our mission and our promise to  our clients, which is to improve the quality of life and be involved in the development, the economic and social  and environmental development in the countries and communities that we serve. One of the fields which for us is  extremely significant is fighting against waste. As you probably know, 30% of the food which is produced around  the globe is never consumed.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And today, in the world, there are 800 million people who are starving and suffering from malnutrition. In order  to fight against this scourge and aberration of such waste, we've taken the initiative of creating a coalition which  we called Food Waste Coalition with a few global partners such as PepsiCo, Unilever, McCain, Ardo, SCA, WWF,  in order to work with them, because we are all part of the value chain of food. We move from the field to the plate  after all.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And in this initiative, I believe we bear a significant responsibility in order to combat waste and muster the  energies of companies, of the general public, but also of governments. Therefore, we've created this coalition, this  platform, which works on this significant issue. We are convinced that, as a company, we have to work towards  creating a better world and a more humane economy.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: To continue on our societal commitments now, once again, let me mention the following. The Dow Jones  Sustainability Index has given us – once again for the 11th consecutive year has given us the recognition of being  the global leader in our business area in terms of sustainable development. This is actually the outcome of all  those years of significant efforts of our teams around the globe in the fields of the environment, of the societal  effort and in terms of governments. And I express my thanks to them for all their efforts which make us a  responsible company.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: All of this is related, of course, to the price of raw materials and commodities. Now, the oil sectors and the gas  sectors are suffering very clearly. And the mining sector for us as well is suffering. It is a significant area especially  in Australia and in South America. And also, the pick-up in Europe will remain quite sluggish.

file: SW - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 17November2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Other findings from the survey are that 80% of our employees consider Sodexo to be a socially and  environmentally responsible company, and 86% prefer working for Sodexo than for a competitor. As well, 21 of  our group's entities achieved Best Employee Certification from Aon Hewitt benchmark. These are critical KPIs for  Sodexo, as you know. We are people business again, and our people's engagement and development is  essential for our successful delivery of quality of life services.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Now, I want to comment on our corporate responsibility commitment. I won't take you through all of these  recognition in details. I just want to highlight that Sodexo continues to be recognized for its commitment to  corporate responsibility. We were confirmed as Industry Leader by the Dow Jones Sustainability Index for the  12th year running.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Among all of these partnership and commitment, I want to focus on what Sodexo is doing to fight food waste,  which is a very important ethical, economic and environmental issue in the world we live today. You may know  that one-third of the food which is produced in the world is wasted. And if I take European example, in Europe,  around 88 million tons of food is wasted every year. And the associated cost of this are estimated at over €143  billion. So, just one quarter of the food wasted globally in the world would feed 870 million people, who currently  go hungry around the world.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: So, to tackle this issue, Sodexo last year joined forces and initiate a coalition between Ardo, McCain, PepsiCo,  SCA, Unilever Food and the WWF to launch an International Food Waste Coalition in order to combat food waste  throughout the foodservice value chain. So, we're very proud of that. In addition, Sodexo and the WWF have  worked together to design and deploy the best practice to lessen the environmental impact of the group services  at its client sites, including through a program to reduce food waste and the adoption of technologies that will cut  energy used by 12% to 45%.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: The Rest of the World region, as we have already mentioned, has had a tough year. Our clients in the oil and gas  and mining sectors had to cut back capacity radically both in exploration but also in production. Added to this in  Chile, the economic situation was combined with a particularly difficult social environment, which meant that many  of our client decided to spread their risk, and we've had to close down some significant contracts.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: In Education, the stagnation is due to the exit of a contract in Africa. I will [ph] add that (42:49) in terms of activity  outside of Remote Sites, we've seen some improvement in Latin America and in Brazil in particular in the last  quarters. However, we are seeing the opposite in Africa and the Middle East as the oil price crisis prolongs, really  affecting spending power and therefore, development in oil-related economies.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: We are now organized by client segment, Corporate Services, Health Care, Energy and Resource, et cetera. This  is now where the P&L responsibility lies. Then, we have the services operation and transversal functions which  are also global to ensure that all the segments are optimizing processes and spreading best practice across all  regions.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: On top of it, digital innovation, in which we're investing, will pave the way also for new opportunities. Of course, in  the very short term, we have Q1 hurdle, which Marc elaborated on. But the ramp-up of the Adaptation and  Simplification program savings and continued tight control of SG&A, as well as ongoing Operation Efficiency  programs and lower financing costs, are all going in the same direction. And I can assure you that the  management teams throughout the world is taking – is totally focused on accelerating growth and increasing  margins.

file: SW - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 16November2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Second reason, Energy & Resources is continuing to improve as we explained at the end of last year with a  strong Q4, up 5%. And this is the ramp up of several contracts that we have signed, namely Collahuasi in Chile,  but also Rio Tinto.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Now, in terms of profitability, on slide 6, we have achieved strong growth in operating profit, i.e. 8.4%, and this is  before Adaptation and Simplification program and also the currency effect. This is in line with our objectives, and  this represent 40-basis-point improvement in the margins . Again, the Adaptation and Simplification program is on  track, and has delivered €150 million of cost savings this year against only €32 million last year.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: For the 10th consecutive year, we received the highest score in our sector, in RobecoSAM's Sustainable  Yearbook (sic) [Sustainability Yearbook] (11:15), and we were named the top-rated company in our sector on the  Dow Jones Sustainable Index (sic) [Dow Jones Sustainability Index] (11:21) for the 13th year in a row.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: On slide 12, you can see that our commitments, in that Corporate responsibility are built into our future strategy in  a tangible way. We have chartered our roadmap, Better Tomorrow 2025, in alignment with the UN's sustainable  development goals to produce actionable change in the following key areas: in the area of hunger or gender and  waste.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: We are contributing our expertise to fight against hunger, both through our own operation and through the  voluntary work of our teams. Last year's Stop Hunger distributed more than 5.7 million meals to people in needs.  Sodexo's Partner Inclusion Program drives diversity in all countries where Sodexo operates. We actively support  women and minority-owned businesses and work to help create sustainable economic opportunities for those  communities around the world. And we are a founding member of the International Food Waste Coalition, which is  a collaborative farm-to-plate approach against food waste to allow the food service value chain.

texts.speaker: Michel Landel
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sodexo SA
texts.text: So, we continue to invest in this space. And, for example, we work to reduce food waste through the creation of  WasteWatch using LeanPath technology, and we are committed to waste measurements at all our sites of  Sodexo.

texts.speaker: Marc Rolland
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Moving to slide 21, the Adaptation and Simplification program has been successful and is perfectly on track.  There were hundreds of projects of very different sizes with approximately one-third of the overall program  affecting gross profit and two-thirds SG&A. The projects came from all around the group, both in terms of mix of  businesses and regions.

texts.speaker: Marc Rolland
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: At the end of fiscal 2017, two years into the plan, we are even very slightly ahead in terms of savings with a total  amount of €150 million achieved this year, representing a step-up of nearly €120 million versus last year. We are  confident that we should be able to deliver the expected €220 million of sustainable annual cost savings in fiscal  2018.

texts.speaker: Marc Rolland
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: After taking into account the €137 million of exceptional costs linked to the Adaptation and Simplification program  versus €108 million in the preceding year, the operating profit was €1.189 billion, up more than 8% relative to the  previous year.

texts.speaker: Marc Rolland
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Now, let us move on to the review of operation. Firstly, the On-site business. Starting with Business &  Administrations on slide 29, you will note that all the figures in green boxes are excluding the Rugby World Cup  and the 53rd week impact.

texts.speaker: Denis Machuel
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Typically, the smart kitchen, the Evolution offer on smart kitchen. This is a very innovative oven technology that  has been initially developed by our Peruvian teams, and this speeds up food preparation. This reduces kitchen  space as well as electricity and water consumption, and it also enhances security for our people. This offer is  currently, as we speak, being rolled out in South America. And our teams are also working on the global  deployment of the offers, I think in India, Eastern Europe, with the creation of specific recipes that are adapted  through these new ovens.

texts.speaker: Denis Machuel
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: At the same time, in terms of processes and back offices, we are building our digital food and FM platforms in  data infrastructure that will enable, in turn, more efficient services and prepare for the future. These platforms will  provide nutritional informations on recipes, implement path management of air, heating, lights reservations in FM  and they're very promising.

texts.text: In Africa, Asia, Australia, Latin America, and Middle East, organic revenue growth remained strong at 11.2%,  reflecting strong new business and same-site sales in Corporate Services in all regions and a better environment  in Energy & Resources, particularly in mining.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sodexo SA
texts.text: Now, on the anchoring corporate responsibility pillar, on the bottom-right corner, I'd like to highlight the recent  launch of 200 new plant-based menus across hundreds of University, Health Care, and Corporate Services  accounts in the U.S. with – I have to highlight that – delicious and trendy dishes like typically carrots, osso buco,  tiramisu made with cashew nuts, cream, et cetera and the likes are very well received. These offers they respond  both to consumer trends and environmental concerns. You may know that food production accounts for a quarter  of all greenhouse gas emissions. And so, helping people increase their share of plant-based foods and reduced  meat in their diet is a critical step in reducing those emissions.

texts.speaker: Michael Wolf
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Swedbank AB
texts.text: Let's turn over to the environment we operate in. The economy in our four home markets are still relatively strong  and performance mainly impact on the strong domestic demand. But the global economy is affecting our export  industry, and credit demand remains low. But where there is growth, we participate. Our strong balance sheet and  low risk level continues to support us in terms of lower funding cost and is a signal to our clients that we are there  to support them.

file: SWED.A - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 28April2015 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Wolf
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look at the environment that we are operating in, it's still very much in transformation. The Central Bank is  printing money. We lack political reforms especially in Sweden. I would like to highlight the need to increase  housing starts and invest in infrastructure to create sustainable growth and productivity.

texts.speaker: Göran Bronner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the other hand, we have seen lower commission income in Norway as a result of a weaker pipeline or more  uncertainty as a result of the weaker oil prices. The business activity in general has stalled there for the  time being.

file: SWED.A - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 26April2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Birgitte Bonnesen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Good cost control was manifested in all areas. And as you know, this is a priority for Swedbank. Our asset quality  remains strong, and this was confirmed by very [ph] low (6:21) loan losses. We continue to stay very close to the  few customers that we have in the oil sector. And since the last quarter, we have successfully completed a few  restructurings. But as I said, we'll come back to this.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: We have guided that higher loan losses in the oil-related sectors should be expected given the persistent low oil  prices, but even more important, decreased investments by oil companies globally. We have also said that many of  our clients have a quite robust cash flow, thanks to long contracts and strong backlogs. The continued subdued  market is, however, increasingly affecting clients as contracts and funding mature. Consequently, loan losses are  quite low in the first part of the year, but challenges will arise with time if market circumstances are not  improving.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: We acknowledge that the Brent oil price stabilized somewhat during the quarter and closed around $40 per  barrel. This is on the margin positive for the market, but what really matters for recovery is that oil majors are  increasing their investments. Swedbank research estimates that oil companies globally decreased investments last  year with 23% and that investments will decrease with another 25% in 2016. Only 2017 is certain an increase of  investments can be expected.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: We note that oil-related clients and marketplace in general are doing many things to cope with the situation, and  Swedbank has, too, in the quarter, actively participated in a number of restructuring negotiations. The increased  risk has not yet materialized in individual impairments. However, we have since last year seen increases in a  number of exposures in our internal early warning indicators such as watch list, negative rate in migrations and  increased forborne exposures.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: So, summing up, we remain with the expectation that loan-loss provisions will increase, particularly in the second  part of 2016 and possibly into 2017, in line with the continued bleak outlook on the oil-related markets. Thank  you.

texts.speaker: Michael Wolf
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we look at the environment and changes in the environment, which we have had extra focus on during 2014,  then I would like to mention two areas. Of course, Russia and Ukraine increased its effects on the Baltic  economies. And then the oil price fall and its effects on shipping and offshore. texts.speaker: Göran Bronner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And then lastly, I just want to point to the fact that the falling oil prices are changing the environment around us.  Of course, it will increase the risk in the portfolio. Anders will come more into that. But it will also mean a  changed client needs. Clients have a higher degree of restoring, repairing balance sheets in their corporate sector  and take on less leverage and restructure the part of the balance sheet. So it will be more equity-related  transactions going forward. And I think we are in a very good position in our Norwegian business to capitalize on  that from a business perspective. And then, Anders will come further into the risk part.

texts.speaker: Göran Bronner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Lastly, just explaining for you a little bit more in detail the capital. I think the capital has been affected by REA  [risk exposure amount]  increasing with the volumes, and that has been partly mitigated by a higher degree of  collateralization in our lending volumes that reduces the LGD effect. And also, we have a model change in the  Baltics where we have moved to internal model that has released some REA as well that mitigates the REA  increase that comes from the volumes.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: Then turning into some of the focus areas, and let me start off with shipping & offshore and the falling oil prices.  The portfolio is largely denominated in U.S. dollar. It has been stable around $3.5 billion to $4 billion since 2010.  So the increase you see in Q4 is related to FX effects. The falling in oil prices impacts this broad sector a bit  differently. 40% of the portfolio is impacted positively or neutrally, 60% which is mainly oil and offshore business  is negatively impacted. However, when we look at the portfolio, we have lent money to companies with strong  financials. We have focused on good collateral and conservative loan-to-values. And they are strong owners that  we know well and most of them are listed companies, i.e. they have access to the capital markets.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: We have run a number of stress tests on the portfolio. Two of them has been under the assumption of an oil price  of $60 and $40 respectively over a longer period of time, i.e. it's not a V -shaped assumption, it's a flat curve for a  fairly long time.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: We are working closely with the customers. We see that the markets believe in a gradual increase in oil prices, but  we work under the assumptions that it will stay on a low level for a fairly long time. Then moving to another area,  which is Baltic Banking and the impact from Russia, Ukraine and the weaker Russian economy, as both Göran  and Michael said, we have seen so far limited impact on our portfolio. If we dig a bit down into the portfolio, we  can see that our estimate is that around SEK 2.5 billion of exposure to customers that have a direct relationship to  Russia.

file: SWED.A - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2February2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Wolf
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The front book market share is hovering around 14%, 15% compared to the normal 20%. And that is very much  due to that not every bank in Sweden is adopting the new amortization rules as we speak. Overall, credit quality  remains strong; however, the lower oil price will, if it continues to trade at this level, cause credit quality  challenges in the sector.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: Due to the uncertain oil price development, I would like to spend some time on our oil-price-sensitive portfolio in  Norway. As you might remember, in conjunction with Q4 2014 report, we communicated an outcome of the stress  test that we performed on oil prices being at $40 per barrel for two consecutive years. We then said that at that  price level, we would see a negative impact on credit quality starting in 2015. That credit losses in this sector will  be the most likely not materialize until 2016 or 2017.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: Due to a continued supply surplus and uncertainty regarding the future demand from oil, the price has been under  pressure throughout the year. We have consequently been in close contact with our customers throughout the  year. And in line with expectations, they have, so far, succeeded in handling the situation well.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: As a result, the bank was not affected by any credit losses in this sector during 2015 and we mana ged to reduce our  exposures in the oil-sensitive offshore portfolio by almost 10% to $2.2 billion equivalent to roughly SEK 18 billion.  The derivatives exposure amount to $300 million.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: With a further decline at the end of the year in the oil price, the uncertainty has obviously increased. And we  conclude that disposals, stacking, and the negotiated contracts of new builds will be necessary to regulate the  supply in the market.

texts.speaker: Anders Karlsson
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer
texts.text: Having said this, I would like to remind you that the oil price density of offshore portfolio constitutes only 1.3%  our total lending. And I still expect that Swedbank's asset quality will continue to perform strongly. However,  given the uncertainties in the external environment and the low visibility in the oil price development, it is not  reasonable to expect credit losses on recent years' very, very low levels. And hence, we expect somewhat higher  credit losses for 2016.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And finally Industrial Controls, and you can see the Spanish website there a little bit clearer in that picture. Like - for-like sales up 4%, so a good second quarter here and really some good project wins there, some defense wins in  the U.S., good activity also on the healthcare and OEM market where we sell products from a number of our  businesses into those markets. I would say the U.S. still a little bit of a drag here, and y ou saw the performance of  U.S. in the quarter was not fantastic. I think we're still seeing some short-term trading weakness there. Whether  or not that's sequestration-related or not is very difficult for us to say, just given the short cycle and small order  size here in this business, but you certainly get the feeling that there's some recovery potential in North America.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: On the right hand side, another first for us, again, from our Servomex business is a product we're calling  OxyDetect, which is the first gas detector that we've ever made, and those of you know something about gas kn ow  that there's sort of two sides of it; one is detecting gases which shouldn't be there, so gas detection, and that's  more of a safety and emergency application; as well as gas analysis, which is our core capability. Gas analysis, you  want to measure how much is there; gas detection, you just want to know if there is gas or not gas. The problem  with gas detection is that the standard technology in the industry today is a consumable.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: So the customer needs to replace the electrochemical cell, which drives t he gas detectors, which is a bit of a  problem, because if the detector – if the cell goes out like a battery goes out, your detector doesn't work anymore.  So the customers have to replace those things on a preventive basis, ahead of them maybe wearing down .  OxyDetect is different. It doesn't need a replacement cell. So there's no consumable in it. And we've been able to  bring that at a price point, which actually makes it attractive. It's more expensive than a standard detector, but it  does away with the need to replace the electrochemical cells. So we think that could be a big deal. At the moment,  we have just brought out a product, which is looking at oxygen, but again very important in explosive areas to  know whether or not you have oxygen in the atmosphere.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Test and Measurement had a pretty robust first half, and indeed all of their end markets are really quite  supportive. Automotive doing very well globally, particularly Asia, where we saw a number of important p roduct  and project wins, and indeed some good long-term drivers there in automotive. We're getting quite active in  electric drive trains. We're getting quite active in alternative material development and testing. Same is true for  aerospace, we see good strength there still and we've seen a couple of important project wins around smaller  business jets in the U.S. and a couple of big project wins in Asia that we talk about in the statement too, so good  demand there, also a lot that around new material testing, carbon fiber, and lighter material testing which is  obviously driving a lot of the new product development in that sector.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And then the other segment here in test and measurement had a reasonably good first half and that is our  environmental monitoring, environmental sound monitoring, which is a two -pronged business. One is a pure  service business and we talk in the statement about a number of significant project wins there, mainly around  airports in Europe, here in the UK, in the U.S. and in Australia, some very, very encouraging wins.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In-line Instrumentation, I would say reasonably good demand here. Energy and utilities has been quite strong and  some very good project wins in the first half. Most of them in emerging markets, so we've seen, for example, in  China particular interest in emissions control, emissions monitoring, and we've had a number of – like quite a  number of project wins there associated with exhaust gas cleaning from industrial output from power generation  and large industrial plant, just been very good and couple of big project wins including one in India with the  Reliance Group.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And Clive talked a little bit about the bottom line effects here. Really the volume gains weren't enough to offset  some of the adverse product mix that we had, which was largely around the pulp and paper segment, but also to  do with some of those larger projects on the energy and utilities side as well.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: What the Zetasizer Helix does is it brings an additional measurement capability into the Zetasizer, which allows  for chemical speciation of – in this case probably biopharmaceutical products, protein-based products, which  allows the customer to get a very rapid measurement with a fairly small sample size of chemical composition and  dynamic stability of a product, which in that particular sector is vitally important.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And next to that you see with a Malvern sign on it, the MicroCal product from the GE acquisition. This is a  calorimeter, which is used particularly again in biopharmaceutical applications for heat measurement in reaction  situations. And again it's used for drug development, drug discovery, as well as drug quality and efficacy  measurement.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: To the right-hand side you see two products out of our test and measurement business. The first one there,  QuantumX is a new module on our well-established QuantumX family now, some of you will have seen that when  we visited Darmstadt a couple of years ago. This is their high voltage module, and when we talk about electric cars  and electric car drivetrain, you need to be able to measure voltages and acquire data from high voltage signals.  And this one will go up to 1,000 volts, which is probably the order of magnitude – not probably it is the order of  magnitude that electric cars, electric vehicles run on in the sort of 200 volt to 300 volt level. So this is able to  measure voltages in the drivetrain, combine that with mechanical signals or mechanical structure analysis and  give the customer test data for drivetrains.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: This would typically be used in remote infrastructure measurement and control. There is a couple of examples in  the statement of recent project wins there. One, in the U.S. in oil and gas. So, in that case it was tankers and  remote tank monitoring and volume measurement. The other example was in China, and it was in water  treatment, city water treatment where we've sold similar types of products in about 15 cities now across China. So  it's all about remote data, Internet and Ethernet based networking and either cellular or Wi-Fi applications,  wireless or wired.

file: SXSL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 30July2015 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: And the cost actions are under way. Some of them we haven't fully announced and they range in nature from  resizing due to the decline in oil and gas price, in the case of our ESG business, to back-office sales functions  consolidation, some consolidation of sites. So it's really looking at the complexity of our asset footprint and  consolidating wherever possible and taking cost out that way. And we'll be able to update you in full in terms of  how this is progressing as we progress towards the year end.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But hot on the heels of that there will be an Ammonia application version as well as a Combustion Gas application  version, both of which are very interesting for emissions control applications. And you may know that we've been  doing very well in that area, particularly in China, over the last couple of years. So that should give our business  there in China with Servomex some added boost, but also on a global level. We think we have a world-class  platform there.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: North America continues to be weak. It's improved somewhat since the end of Q1, but still down 2% for the half  year. And that remains really a market that we see ultimately driven by huge cutbacks in the oil and gas sector,  which of course filter through to a number of industrial markets. And a lot of our business in North America is in  the industrial controls area, so very general discrete automation. And so that knock-on effect of weak spending in  oil and gas to us, at least, seems to be having an impact on more sort of broader industrial spend.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then our software and environmental noise service business also had a good first half to the year. We also had  an acquisition in that area with the software business of ReliaSoft, which came in at the beginning of the year and  also made a nice contribution in the first half.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on, our In-line Instrumentation business a little bit weak overall, down 1% like-for-like – a little bit less  than 1%, it was 0.6%, and reported down 2%. The highlights here, very much in the energy utility side of the  business. The downstream petrochemical market was good. Our wind business had a very good first half, which  was on the back of some good OEM business, but more importantly and strategically of interest a couple of very  interesting wins with wind farm operators. And these are interesting because it shows that we've got a good  solution and that when the wind turbines come off warranty, which takes three years to five years depending on  the OE, that there is a need for the kind of monitoring services that we're able to offer.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then finally, industrial controls. And this really has been the weakest performer of the group, down 1% on a  like-for-like basis, up 6% on a reported basis, which, of course in itself tells you this is a U.S. business. So good  reported growth on a currency basis. As I said in the intro, this is an oil and gas story, most of all in the U.S. and  the knock-on effects of that reduction in oil and gas spending on U.S. industrial demand.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've gone live with an ERP system in OMEGA in the first half in Asia and the U.S. We'll roll that out completely  in Europe in the second half. But, again, that was a big investment and I think a big investment of time on the part  of the OMEGA business. They didn't have an ERP system at the time of acquisition. The HMI business products a  little bit weak, a lot of that was going into the oil and gas market last year.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We talked in quite a bit of detail on the day of our focus on some key strategic markets, markets where we see  good long-term growth and markets in which we wish to invest. The pharmaceutical, life science market we talked  about, some of the software businesses around our Test & Measurement, automotive and aerospace. We talked  about the investments in the industrial Ethernet business in our Industrial Controls area and also our interest in  some of the energy businesses in In-line Instrumentation, as well as our ESG business in Test & Measurement.  Those businesses are all global and so our drive to expand globally continues.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A couple of examples just to highlight those initiatives. On the top left, I talked about our Zetium X-ray  spectrometer as being a very exciting new product. One of the interesting aspects of that new product is that it's  being launched in five specific industry versions which come with software, with applications which are tailor- made for the customer's industry. So there's a cement version, a metals version, a minerals version, a petro  version for the oil and petroleum testing, and a polymers testing for the downstream petrochemical market. So  very specific solutions which go beyond the product and actually deliver to the customer some software and some  applications which are tailor-made for their industry.

file: SXSL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 28July2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: Acquisition spend, the £27.3 million relates to the acquisitions – the three acquisitions of Clean Air Services,  Capstone, and [IPS] and a small amount of consideration deferred from earlier years. Dividend, tax, and interest  £38 million, £15 million, and £2 million, respectively, all self explanatory and currencies. So we closed the year  half with net debt of a £104 million or 0.5 times EBITDA.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A lot of our M&A activity over the last two years has been focused on this area. The first half of the year is no  different. Now, we made the acquisition early on in the year of a company called Clean Air Services, which does  just that for the pharmaceutical industry. It's a Swiss-based company.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Just to talk about the segments in turn, Materials Analysis was our best performing sector and here is very much  the life science, pharmaceutical, academic research areas, electronics, semiconductor all quite good. Offset by  continued weakness in the metals and mining industry where we have stabilized, at least we are seeing good  support from the service side of that business, but obviously not much by way of new projects and expansion.  Clean Air Services that I talked about comes in here and adds to our capabilities in pharmaceutical and then very  good bottom line result, as Clive mentioned, the cost reduction measures mostly benefiting Materials Analysis  group.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then we come to the two more difficult segments Clive highlighted, In-Line Instrumentation, which aside from  pulp and paper, which we've seen good performance in now for a couple of years as we successfully divert away  from the traditional coated graphic paper markets into packaging into tissue and into pulp, but obviously in the  downstream energy part, we've heard a lot about program postponements, project cancellation, et cetera, in a  number of those industries also affecting Asia.

file: SXSL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 25July2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: As John said, we made good progress in advancing the projects under the Project Uplift umbrella. As you'd  expect, net Uplift cost for the year are front-end loaded, and benefits are back-end loaded. So, we try to strip out  the effect of Uplift in the first half, we'll continue to do that for the year, but we'll provide both before and after  Uplift figures. A little confusing, a little more complex than normal, but we'll try to make it as simple as possible in  keeping with the spirit of Uplift, which is all about driving simplicity.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In all cases, we continue to invest in R&D, Malvern PANalytical being no exception. And one of the new products  that you see there that PANalytical – actually, the PANalytical side of the business traditionally has recently  launched. It's called the Xflow, which is quite a new technology for PANalytical, and that it is the first true online  liquid x-ray spectrometer. So, it's used particularly in liquid applications, oil and gas being one of the key ones  where you're looking for elemental analysis, trace elemental analysis in fuels and oils. So, that's an interesting  development.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And then Rest of the World, not a large part of the business and certainly has declined in recent years given the  issues that we faced in Russia and given the issues around natural resources, oil and gas, mining and also the  decline in Brazil and the economic situation there. So, you see that also have actually, although it's flat for the half  year actually have at least stabilized at those low levels.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Moving on to slide 18, end-user industries and sales there. And really a very positive picture, really across all of  the key end markets, most notably automotive, semicon, electronics you see up double digit. Energy and Utilities  has made a big turnaround, not surprisingly given some of the macro trends there on oil prices and also what's  happening in the North American unconventional space, so minus 17% moving to plus 10%. And a similar story  around metals and mining, particularly mining where we're also starting to see some budgets returning there and  capital investment on the part of the mining companies and everything else you see in pretty good health until you  get down to academic research which has been a bit of a disappointment, certainly in terms of sales. The order  side of things and the prospect side of things not quite – so bad, so we would expect to see that recover a little bit  as we go through the year.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: On Test and Measurement, you see a big yellow truck there coming out of Millbrook's new climatic chamber. This  is used, obviously for high temperature/low temperature testing. And it's a recent – part of the recent capital  investment spend at Millbrook. They will continue to do that. We have an expansion underway also in their Test  World facility in Finland. And with the acquisition of the CSA business in Leyland, there will also be opportunity to  add to that capacity as well.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: So, automotive here clearly highlight Germany and China. As I mentioned, some of the key recipients of the  machine manufacturing business and the oil and gas in North America really helping our ESG Solutions  business.  So, pretty good growth here, 5% on a like-for-like business after actually a good run in automotive and aerospace  now for the last couple years.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: We also expect though to see the investment in some of those markets continue. Some of the packaging markets,  tissue, for example in our Pulp And Paper business doing very well. Energy and Utilities, also quite a bit of  momentum there and quite some order intake and order backlog around our Vibro business particularly as the  slide mentions in the wind power area, but also in some of the downstream refining and oil and gas markets.

file: SXSL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 24July2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: From Servomex, you see one of their new products which is their multi-gas system used, here the example of  being highlighted around a flue gas monitoring which is obviously key for a number of industrial products,  industrial processes, as well as combustion efficiency.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: The main reason for Germany's low growth rate is last year's tough comp, underlying trading conditions are good,  and when Germany grew by 11% last year. The UK benefited from strong double-digit growth in its largest end- market, which is automotive. But they also saw growth in environmental noise monitoring, energy and utilities and  in academic.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In terms of end markets, pulp and paper continues to be a challenging area but still some good growth there as  we diversify into tissue and packaging in pulp. And also as we saw on the first slide, growth in the energy market  even though we had some tough competitor here in the wind business, we had some very big orders and sales in  the first half of 2017, but despite that growth in energy.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And then we have within our In-line Instrumentation business, a couple of segments or a couple of operating  companies who have particular capability around data analytics, as well as the joint venture which we've just  established with Macquarie Capital, which will focus on environmental applications, bringing from Macquarie  Capital their know-how, as well as their very large installed base of assets and the capability and the cloud-based  solution that the EMS business has established over the years.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: So very – a very exciting opportunity there we think on the services and on the front-end of the IIOT opportunity.  And as Clive mentioned, we have also invested in the half year to launch Spectris Advance as a brand for our  digital solutions and we have been investing in R&D there to develop some and refine some of our capability and  some of our solutions particularly in the wind business, but we intend to pursue several other verticals as well in  due course.
