file: SXSL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 17February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Just to start off with a couple of color pictures there on our first slide, as usual we'd like to show off some of our  new developments from the past year. From left to right – on the left there, Malvern Instruments, new  Mastersizer, the 3000, the predecessor product for 2000 is the industry standard for particle sizing and Malvern  have brought out a better, smaller, faster product which we expect will also become the industry standard in due  course.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The next picture over isn't one of our products, but I guess is a reference to our Energy businesses, which did very  well last year. Our Energy business was up 44% across the group with traditional businesses such as Servomex,  Vibro doing very well. Our Test and Measurement did very well in Energy, but also reference to our new  acquisition, Sixnet, which is a very interesting add-on to the N-TRON business of – we acquired in 2010. Very  much in the remote monitoring, remote control, remote data logging applications; very typically you find those in  oil and gas applications, as depicted here on the chart. We're very excited about the potential that, that market  offers.  On the – staying on the wireless subject, moving over to the Omega products, picture there in the third over, this  is their Wi-Fi sensors which were launched last year and again a new range of products for Omega, which are used  very typically in wireless sensing applications around a manufacturing location. We expect those products to be  very successful. And finally, on the right-hand side, HBM's new handheld, as you can see from its size, handheld  data acquisition product; again very to use, a common theme of many of our products these days. And this one  plugs straight into a PC through the USB interface there that you can see. Used for data acquisition applications in  R&D, aerospace, automotive, anywhere where an engineer needs to go out and quickly collect data.

texts.speaker: Clive G. Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Now also good performance in some of the other areas there; we have a nice services business there around noise  monitoring we've talked a bit about in the past, and also other industries, consumer electronics and also power, as  I mentioned at the beginning. Some of the acquisition there in the HBM group gives us very good position in  power testing, which has helped our exposure there in the energy sector.

texts.speaker: Clive G. Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In-line Instrumentation; again a pretty solid performance here; energy and utilities doing pretty well,  petrochemical, hydro, wind. In fact the picture there on the bottom left is a hydro plant. It's the second largest  hydro-generating station in China, which are Brüel & Kjær Vibro businesses kitted out with their condition  monitoring equipment; 4.2 gigawatts of power that produces.

texts.speaker: Clive G. Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In Test and Measurement, that picture there is not a picture, that's a simulation, a computer simulation, which is  indicative of some of the trends in the Test and Measurement market that customers more and more are using  simulation as a tool to test. And here we've taken our solution outside of the car, which typically is what we've  been monitoring and simulating, to simulating the exterior noise of typically alternative-fuel vehicles, electric  vehicles which is very important.

texts.speaker: Clive G. Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: On the bottom left, not very clear picture, but this is one of the IRM gauges and IRM was one – was the other  significant acquisition that we made during the year in the In-line Instrumentation segment. Their core  technology is really gauging for metals applications, which complements very well the technology we have which is  used for packaging, used for plastics. So, this gives the NDC business really an entrée into the metals processing  industries around the world, global industry but particularly in emerging markets that looks very promising, and  quite a bit of synergy there in terms of the technology and the application know-how.

file: SXSL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 20February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: ASD on the other hand has, firstly, different technology. It's infrared-based and here you see somebody using an  infrared radio spectrometer. And it is portable, so this is stuff that goes out into the field. So quite a different  channel to market, quite a different user, but nevertheless it is the mining companies, it is the mineral companies.  These are used for geological surveys, soil surveys and used extensively in the mining and mineral sector.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Acquisition-related spend, £16 million. About two-thirds of that was in relation to the 2012 acquisitions, the other  £5 million odd paid in relation to earlier acquisitions. That was mainly in relation to Lochard, so we – it's an earn  out, our environmental noise monitoring business included in the Test and Measurement segment. We like paying  earn outs, because it means that they're performing pretty well.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Our – let me see. What else? Our Energy and Utilities has continued to grow over the past couple of years through  a number of things. But in In-line Instrumentation, both our Servomex and Vibro business continue to do very  well, but also we're picking up opportunities in Test and Measurement, particularly for the Energy business as  well. So that's grown and continues to grow.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Another example of a – one of ASD's products that I talked about earlier, that's a – that is a mineral analyzer that  again is used for field work in the mining and metals area.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: I talked about the Vibroport earlier. Our Servomex business has done very well growing their – they have a  separate OEM business line. Servomex's core business is gas analyzers. A number of you visited that facility in  Crowborough a couple of years back. Their core business is selling to the oil and gas refining, petrochemical world.

file: SXSL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 27February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And our airport noise monitoring business, our environmental services business here in Test and Measurement  also had put in a very good performance. A couple of very significant wins in that business and one of the reasons  why we've seen a good growth in the aftermarket service contribution from Test and Measurement.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: But, overall, this segment benefits from the high portion of aftermarket service consumables and services here.  And, as you know, that's over 40% and we saw an increase here from 40% to 43% in the year. The energy sector  continues to look reasonably good even if we didn't see many of the large projects materialize last year as we  thought they would – thought they might do. But, nevertheless, the level of customer activity and certainly the  investment plans in that sector look quite good.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: On the left, in Malvern, the Nano-ID, interestingly, is a new product that PMS launched which gets them down to  measuring 10 nanometer particles in air. But based on the technology from a very small start-up company that we  started working with here in the UK several years ago and we finalized that acquisition last year.

file: SXSL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 27February2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: And at that time, we said the adverse mix was really concentrated in In-Line Instrumentation where lower margin  products made up a higher proportion of sales in our pulp and paper consumables business in particular.  And we  had heavy systems content in our industrial gas and online process measurement and control businesses. And at  that time, we thought some, if not all of that, would come back in the second half. We did see a pickup. Industrial  gas business did reverse all of it. The online process measurement and control business saw an improvement.  Where we didn't see the pickup was in In-line Instrumentation and the sales came down a little bit – the margin  came down a little bit there.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then finally here, a little picture of a truck. This is our new platform acquisition, ESG Solutions, which  completed in the second half last year. A very interesting business with great technology, a real leader in t he  exploration technology for oil & gas and also mining, and really a productivity enabling solution for mining and oil  & gas operators, enabling them to maximize ROI from their investment.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on to sales by end-user market, I think nothing much to say there, really. As you would expect, metals,  minerals and mining down a couple of percent. And the gains coming in energy and utilities for our In-line  Instrumentation, energy business did extremely well, and also, Machine Building was up and the U.S., the  strength of the U.S. economy was a key contributing factor there.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Electronics was very good and then, of course, we had the platform acquisition here at ESG, which again as I  mentioned earlier, we can bring some great technology, great market position with good opportunities despite  some of the challenges undoubtedly that the unconventional oil and gas market will face. But certainly looking  through what we think are short-term issues there, we see plenty of opportunities in conventional oil and gas, as  well as in the mining sector for that business. And we think it's really a platform that we can grow over the next  couple of years.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And just a quick word about some of the acquisitions that we may not have mentioned already. It was a busy year,  and I think slide 19 helps to just position everything that we did and where it fits. So ESG, I think I've talked about  as new strategic platform in Test and Measurement. In the Life Science area, two acquisitions, the GE MicroCal  acquisition and a small technology business called Affinity Biosensors, which both completed in July.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So anywhere where you don't want an electric current you can use optical fiber to pass a signal so oil and gas  applications, explosion proof environments, deep-sea environment, moisture, high moisture content  environment. So very interesting technology, it's a business in Portugal and we are again, very excited about that  as a new sensor platform for our HBM business. Very high value business.

file: SXSL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 16February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: We also had favorable sales mix in Particle Measuring business. And the same is true in Test and Measurement,  although you can't see it here, the aftermarket sales, 20% and 20%, that includes ESG. And for the time being,  we're showing ESG mainly as not after sales. There's quite a bit of chunk of after sales in there. If you just looked  at the two old companies, S&V and HBM, we actually see a slight improvement in [inaudible] (17:25).

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Materials Analysis segment, which did quite well last year. This is where we've seen good progress on our life  science initiative. The picture you see there on the bottom left is the Viscosizer product which has been selling very  well indeed into the life science area. It's used for viscosity measurement of ultra-small sample sizes, which is  fairly typical of the kind of research and quality control environment in large molecule development and  production.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And on the right-hand side are In-Line Instrumentation, also had a mixed year in terms of some strengths, but  also some segments holding us back. Our service business around Vibro has been doing very well and that's the  picture there. It's a hydroelectric power plant. I think it's in South America, if I'm not mistaken. But their  breakthrough into renewable energy, in particular hydro, but also wind has made very good progress in the course  of 2015.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Operating margins were really impacted by the head count increases that we had. And then we had one -off effects  in 2014, R&D grant income which didn't repeat in the course of 2015. And one of our top -selling products there on  the bottom right of that chart was the UDI-20 from Particle Measuring Systems. It's not quite a black box. It's a  silver box. May not look much, but actually is an industry beating product which can measure contaminants in  liquids used for semi-conductor manufacture down to 20 nanometers, which is about the limit of technology  today. And as the semi-conductor companies are gearing up for larger wafer sizes, they are getting down and  actually now moving down below 20 nanometers as the dimensions that they're trying to measure.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Test and Measurement business had a reasonably good year, up 1 % on a like -for-like basis, a further 6  percentage points on a constant exchange rate. Big contribution here from the ReliaSoft acquisition, which took  place in the year as well as the contribution from ESG, which occurred late in 2014. And our ReliaSoft acquisition  is very interesting, and we also followed that on with two further bolt-on acquisitions. One for ESG and one in our  Sound and Vibration business. I'll talk a little bit about those later.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our In-Line Instrumentation business declined to moderately down 1% on a like-for-like basis, and no inorganic  contribution here. So at constant exchange rates, also down 1%. As I said at the outset, quite a mixed perfo rmance  here. Some sector is up, our wind energy sector did very well. Some very nice wins there into the independent  wind farm operators. And also, our pulp and paper business did quite well. Again, we're seeing continued good  performance in the tissue side of that business and also in the pulp production side, offset obviously by continued  weakness in coated paper and the traditional paper segments; and also some weakness appearing in the  petrochemical energy sector as they also start to delay and postpone projects towards the back-end of the year.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As you're well aware, moving on to the red segment there, we have been investing quite heavily in a couple of what  we perceive to be high-opportunity, long-term growth segments, things like the life sciences area. The energy  sector long-term, we believe, is very interesting transport. Some of the areas as well around nano materials, basic  material development and research, and also, in our Industrial Controls business, the networking of equipment  and the communications technology revolution, which is happening on the factory floor. And again, areas that we  continue to believe hold out very good potential for long-term growth.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Couple of examples from across the portfolio in the course of 2015. In terms of customer solutions, I mentioned  our Vibro business doing very well in large third-party monitoring of wind farms. A very big opportunity here.  Some big breakthrough in North America, where we're seeing a lot of the turbines come off warranty, where we're  seeing customers having a broad mix of different turbines and looking for single providers to help them manage,  monitor and service those wind farms.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We also made an acquisition, Spectraseis, around our ESG platform, which was acquired in 2014. And this is  really a product line, which gives ESG capability to measure seismic information from the ground surface. The  core technology of ESG is hardware and software, which is used to monitor data captured underground. And this  adds the capability of over-ground measurement, which is very important in exploration, very important  depending on the geography where you have a lot of horizontal drilling and maybe no downhaul possibility. It  gives you the opportunity to capture that data from the surface.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then finally on that slide, you see Sound Answers, which is very much a play into the consultative solution  selling that I mentioned earlier. Sound Answers is a business based in the U.S., which provides consultative  services to the car industry mainly, around helping them to solve, identify and measure and test design issues  related to sound and vibration, noise harshness, which is exactly the market that our Brüel & Kjær business plays  in. So this, if you will, is the frontend capability for them to get much deeper into our customer in terms of helping  them to solve problems rather than just selling them hardware and/or software.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, with that, I'll just summarize by saying we had a challenging 2015 I think it's fair to say. Had some quite mixed  trading conditions across the world. Growth in Europe and Asia offset by certainly a tough North American  market and rest of the world climate. Very good strategic progress made through the year and we are very excited  about some of the new products, and some of the new initiatives that we have underway.

file: SXSL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 14February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Millbrook was the largest acquisition that we made in the year on slide number 6. Millbrook provides a very  interesting front-end service capability, service platform to the automotive industry with a combination of on-track  testing, in-house or engine cell testing, dynamometer testing, indoor testing as well as Nordic cold weather  outdoor testing. And they have a full suite of testing capabilities for the automotive industry from engines,  drivetrains, powertrains, emissions, safety, crash, fatigue, lifetime testing. You name it, they can carry out on  behalf of the automotive customers pretty much every test required to bring a car to the market. Largely, a UK- based business with the exception of the Nordic testing facility in Finland but very much a platform that we see as  a vehicle for us to grow. This business can grow within the UK but more importantly, can grow beyond the UK, in  Europe, in Asia, and in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: As foreshadowed at the last trading update, we have impaired the goodwill of both Omega and ESG; this is on  slide 14, in aggregate by £114 million with a further £1 million reflecting the write-off of other intangibles in ESG.  The impairment charge for Omega represents around 45% of the goodwill balance. For ESG, the carrying value  of goodwill has been impaired in full. Omega, obviously the biggest demand here, £94 million. A number of factors  contributing to the write-off. And what we saw was operational performance really deteriorated in 2016.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: In the case of ESG, the impairment really resulted from a revised strategic [ph] outflow (20:15) cut based on  updated market indicators for the upstream oil and gas market with recovery in the oil and gas prices now  forecast to be in 2019. So, later than we've anticipated when we acquired ESG at the tail end of 2014. All of this is  non-cash and hits the reported earnings and the reported operating profit and EPS which is spelled out on the  front cover of the prelims.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: The other £94 million, self-explanatory. For the sharp-eyed of you, you'll see that the cash tax is quite a bit lower  than the P&L taxes. And the reason for that is we were able to use some tax losses arising from the Spectris  acquisition by ESG in Switzerland, and the other part of that is the phasing of the profits which were back end- loaded, which meant that some of the payments in 2016 shifted to 2017. So, closed the year with net debt of £151  million, 0.7 times EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Oil and gas, ESG sits here, and that continues to remain challenging and price dependent, impacting demand. In- line Instrumentation, and you can see here down 4% in sales at £11 million, and down 4% in operating profit,  down £2 million. So, very well controlled cost base across the board and margins held flat, notwithstanding a 4%  sales decline.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Sales growth in tissue electronics, telecoms, web and converting, they declined in pulp and paper hydrocarbon  processing and oil and gas, capital intensive. And regionally, they were the only ones, as I said, who posted  growth in North America with sales decline in Europe and Asia. Good, strong pipeline in relation to Capstone, the  acquisition, and the end markets, positives would be tissue but still weakness in coated paper and demand from  wind energy sector looks pretty reasonable.

file: SXSL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 19February2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Over on the right-hand side, one of our BTG instruments; it's a charge particle measurement device for pulp  applications. BTG has had a very successful run over the last four or five years, with their latest instruments for  the pulp and paper industry. I'll come back to a couple of more of those later in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Acquisitions and disposals, Concept Life, which we acquired last month, and the 2017 acquisitions should  generate sales somewhere in the region of £60 million to £70 million and adjusted operating profit of £7 million to  £8 million. The nine months' worth of Microscan contribution is here, £33 million in sales and £4.5 million of  operating profit, which will need to be stripped out for the comparison purposes. And we have combined with  Macquarie Capital to set up a joint venture for our environmental noise monitoring business. And that will result in  sales being stripped out for the top line.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Project Uplift Phase 1 costs of £11 million and net benefits of £3 million. So, £14 million gross benefits, costs of  £11 million. And then Phase 2 costs for the shared service center will add an extra £3 million to £4 million. So,  broadly, net-net zero for 2018 if you combine those two, and that compared to, in the case of Phase 1, a £12  million net benefit we were expecting in 2018.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Just maybe spending a couple of minutes on each one of the segments and the highlights. This picture is maybe  not a very clear example, but actually, a very interesting product and the orange helmet is maybe a giveaway that  it came from PANalytical, is their online Xflow system, their Epsilon Xflow system, which is their first ever really  commercialized online XRF measurement which is used for continuous analysis of liquids, particularly in refining  and petrochemical applications, looking for elemental trace levels in fuels, typically. And that has been launched  last year and is a big switch for them. Those of you who know and follow PANalytical know that their traditional  space is in the lab. It's offline. So being able to move their measurement into an online application really expands  their opportunities.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: We also made an acquisition in the United States of a company called Omnicon, which is in the software world  and does a lot of software implementation and software services around reliability and durability, which is, of  course, one of the key application areas of our HBM business. And so that business really expands their existing  software footprint, which we call Prenscia, and so adds to their overall offering. And I'll also come back later and  talk a little bit more about the joint venture with Macquarie, which is with the environmental monitoring service  business, as Clive mentioned, in the Brüel & Kjær business here.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And also, in our Vibro business here, a highlight being the 18,000 turbine monitoring systems that we now have  sold into the wind industry, and so the growth in the wind industry, particularly offshore wind industry, has been a  big boost for that business and one which we continue to focus on and invest around the remote monitoring  capability of our solution. And we have some interesting developments coming to market actually in this calendar  year as well.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: We closed the acquisition of Concept Life Sciences, a very analogous acquisition, I would say, to the Millbrook  acquisition for Test and Measurement. Concept Life Sciences will be part of our Materials Analysis business, has  very interesting and a very relevant customer overlap with our Malvern Panalytical, in that it services the  pharmaceutical, the chemical, agricultural, and environmental markets.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Concept Life Sciences, just in brief, a couple of key messages there, a market leader here in the UK in whole  area of contract research, so, customers go to Concept Life Sciences and give them parts of their research to be  done. So, Concept Life Sciences owns and operates, and runs a network of laboratories across the country, 11 in  total, 700 employees, of which 500 or more are scientist-level and above. So, very highly trained, very highly  skilled, very highly experienced organization working on research contracts with their customers. As you all know  that market is growing very substantially, the whole R&D area into biotech is growing, but also regulation around  things like agrochemical and the environmental sectors we've seen growing. And the sheer complexity of the  entire R&D spectrum end to end is one which is leading companies to outsource more and more portions or parts  of their R&D program.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And secondly, another, I think, very exciting development, which we announced at the end of last year which is  that we've reached an agreement with Macquarie Capital for them to buy into 50% of our environmental  monitoring services business. This is a business that we have developed over the years as part of our Brüel &  Kjær business. We also made an acquisition in 2009, a company called Lochard, which you may recall.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And that business is headquartered in Melbourne, Australia and has been doing very well over those last 10  years, combined with Brüel & Kjær of developing its environmental monitoring service from a core in airport and  aircraft noise, and tracking, moving out into broader transportation applications, city noise monitoring, city  transport and roads monitoring, and also into industry and industrial environmental impact management around  mining and construction are two of the key end industries.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Macquarie, as you may know, are the world's largest asset owner and manager of assets. They have a huge  portfolio of infrastructure utility, energy assets, and they were also looking for a way to get into the business of  monitoring and optimizing the performance of their assets. And the – so, the EMS business, given its remote  monitoring capability and very highly developed service offering, was a very good fit for them. And obviously, the  benefit of the joint venture will be that the business will now grow along with Macquarie into their substantial  installed base of assets around the world. And we will also be looking with Macquarie to invest and grow that  business over the coming years.

texts.speaker: John E. O'Higgins
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: So, in total, the Phase 1 benefits we're now announcing will be £25 million on an annualized basis, again, in the  same time period which is the end of 2019. And the total cost to achieve is down £10 million from £45 million to  £35 million. And then the net benefit of Phase 1 in this year will be £3 million, but we will obviously start to ramp  up the cost of Phase 2, particularly as we move into implementation on the shared service. Those costs are  currently estimated at between £3 million and £4 million for the year.

file: SXSL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 19February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: Our disposals, that's just to eliminate from the like-for-like comp, and that's down to the environmental noise  monitoring services business and Microscan, which we talked about on the sales context. £1.5 million translation  gain in the second half almost completely offset the £1.6 million loss in the first half to leave the full year at a small  loss.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: The disposal proceeds of £44 million represent the net proceeds from the sale of environmental monitoring  services since the joint venture with Macquarie, as well as some deferred consideration on the sale of Microscan.  Share buyback £100 million plus the stamp duty of £500,000, we bought back 3.8 million shares at an average  price of around just over £26 pounds. Other outflow of £115 million self-explanatory dividend, tax and cash  interest paid. So closing the year with net debt of £297 million after small adverse currency just over 1 times  EBITDA, which is the first time we've been above 1 time since 2013, so nice place to be.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: The gross margin decline was partly down to weak growth in volume in Brüel & Kjær, our sound and vibration  business due to some internal sales force issues, which have now been resolved and partly due to an operating  company mix effect. 40% of the sales growth came from our two smallest businesses in this segment, ESG, the  fracking business environment, and Millbrook which together make up 15% of the segment, but contributed 40%  of the sales growth and they carry lower gross margins than HBM and Brüel & Kjær.

texts.speaker: Clive Graeme Watson
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And as you know from January 2019 so from last month, the merger of S&V Brüel & Kjær and HBM is underway,  merging their activities into a new company called HBK, leveraging their respective strengths and complementary  domain expertise. The outlook for this segment is positive. Demand in the automotive sector is expected to  continue to grow benefiting from the rapid growth we've seen electrical and hybrid vehicles, stricter emissions  testing, battery development in particular which we're invested in, and the growth in connected and autonomous  vehicles is all positive.

texts.speaker: Andrew Heath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Spectris Plc
texts.text: And then finally on Omega, Omega is a specialist distributor of temperature, pressure, flow, and level sensors and  the associated instrumentation that goes with all of that. It's a highly differentiated business model providing its  domain knowledge and application to customers both online and over the phone enabling our customers, the  engineers to easily configure their product selections. Omega is the leader in North America with international  presence and growth opportunities particularly in Asia. The served market is almost £2 billion, growing above  GDP, driven by increasing demand for process optimization, preventative maintenance, and increasingly  industrial IoT applications.

file: SY1 - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 4May2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Finally, we have expanded our Asian activities with the opening of a new plant for liquid flavors in  Singapore. Liquid flavors are used for adding flavors to beverages, ice cream, and dairy products,  among others. The new plant uses cutting-edge technology and is also a trendsetter in terms of  waste reduction and energy savings.

file: SY1 - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 11May2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We believe that this is a good result especially in light of two challenges. First, the strong euro, and  second, the high raw material prices. As the conflict in Africa and the Middle East increased and  Japan was hit by the worst natural catastrophe in its history, the oil price rose significantly in quarter  one. As a result, raw material prices became even more volatile and inflationary.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Scent & Care, for example, introduced three new plant-based bioactive ingredient ranges:  Actipone, Extrapone and SymFinity. These are innovative ingredients which will find their use in  cosmetic applications such as body lotions and many other personal care products thanks to their  anti-oxidative and anti-aging properties.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In order to be prepared for further price increases in raw materials, and that serves also as a risk  buffer for us to counterbalance potential increases – further increases in raw material prices.  Nevertheless, my expectation or the expectation of the Board is that going forward this inventory  level will be reduced especially as we’re seeing now more short-term volatility in raw material  prices, so I have to observe that very carefully.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: Chart seven highlights our earnings development in Q1. On the Group level we increased our EBITDA by 2% to  €87 million. texts.text: Thank you, Bernd. Ladies and gentlemen, before I will come to the outlook for the remaining weeks, let me give  you more information on our latest acquisition, Pinova. texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and President-Flavor & Nutrition
texts.text: Please turn to chart 17 which explains a strategic rationale. The acquisition of Pinova supports various strategic  priorities. We expand our backward integration of important raw materials and specialties. We strengthened our  portfolio of using fragrance ingredients and we extend our forward integration of menthol. As the graphic on the  left demonstrates, we received access to two new and sustainable material streams, wood and paper, as well as  orange oil. These high volume raw material platforms ideally complement our current portfolio which is mainly  petro basis.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and President-Flavor & Nutrition
texts.text: At this point, I would also like to stress that palm oil, another important raw material platform which is under  criticism due to sustainability aspect does not play a role in Symrise's business. We expect clear synergies as we  integrate Pinova. Our green chemistry platform in combination with Pinova's expertise, the wood based materials  will create a range of unique starting materials boosting our competitiveness in the creation of fragrance  composition.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and President-Flavor & Nutrition
texts.text: As illustrated on the right, Pinova will also further extend our forward integration. Pinova produces, for example,  cooling substances used in combination with menthol based products for enhancing cooling effects. Pinova's  product find application in oral care products, such as toothpaste, mouth wash, or chewing gum. With the access  to complementary cooling agents, such as carvone and anethole, Pinova's sensory ingredients business perfectly  adds to our current menthol activity. And most importantly, it underlines Symrise's global leadership in menthol  and oral care.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and President-Flavor & Nutrition
texts.text: On chart 18, we provide an overview on the effects for Pinova. Their supply chain will significantly benefit from  our knowhow and process management. Within the framework of our R&D expertise, infrastructure and green  chemistry process technology, raw materials will be processed much faster and more eco friendly than before.

texts.text: A growing global population will need more clean water and food. Again just a few numbers, by 2030 nearly $4  billion people will live in regions with water shortages. texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Symrise AG

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: As outlined before, consumers' worldwide demand for healthier food which tastes good. The  new strategic partnership with Indevex Biotech from Sweden will play a key role in developing functional  solutions containing 100% natural compounds with full scientific documentation.

This is the conclusion after having  assessed 350 companies in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: Furthermore, in our industry, we are the only player who reports within the so-called Standard A category of the  Global Reporting Initiative, GRI, because of our high and comprehensive reporting standards. However, the biggest impact came from purchases of natural menthols, in order to compensate for the  shortfall caused by the ramp up of the new menthol factories.

texts.speaker: Bernd Hirsch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: Moving on to raw materials, we had some improvements over last year. In this respect, please keep in mind the  one-time cost from ramping up our menthol capacity last year. texts.speaker: Bernd Hirsch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: Naturals net-net were slightly up versus the year before. 2013 was clearly a year that offered benefits to those  buying mainly in the spot markets. In other words, with a one-year perspective, we had a slight cost disadvantage  from long-term relationship with suppliers of major natural raw materials, but we are still convinced that our  strategy of backward integration in the long run offers substantial benefits, in terms of high predictability, when  calculating our prices and in terms of traceability of our products.

texts.speaker: Bernd Hirsch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: Manufacturing costs grew by more than €20 million, driven by the rise in energy cost for major production sites in  Germany. The highest increase percentage wise about 12%, we had in research  and development. This reflects our strong commitment towards innovation and indicates that we have a strong  pipeline of new projects as the majority of R&D is development work based on existing customer base.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Symrise AG
texts.text: In our operations, we will continue to grow our business within all customers segments and in all regions. A  particular focus will be on the emerging markets where we want to generate two-thirds of our group sales by  2020. And we are committed to sustainability. We want to generate 40% of our strategic raw materials through  our backward integration. In addition, we will work on constantly reducing our environmental footprint.

The  normalized EBITDA of the segment increased to around €242 million. The EBITDA margin grew to a very good  21.2%. Sustainability is a word often heard these days, maybe in the context of environmental aspects or earnings.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

texts.speaker: Bernd Hirsch
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition, the picture in natural raw material is much more diverse; and in total, this was slightly up versus the  year before. However, we are convinced that our strategy of backward integration offers substantial benefits in  terms of predictability, quality and traceability of our products.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The key to our long-term success is to address major global trends. Sustainability, urbanization and economic  progress, naturalness and well-being are underlying growth drivers for our business. They influence consumer  preferences and thus requirements for new solutions.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our comprehensive R&D, which not only relies on traditional disciplines, but also capitalizes on green and white  chemistries, delivers tailored solutions. We constantly expand our portfolio on applications through organic  measures as well as strategic goals on acquisitions. In addition, we constantly drive efficiency, be it our raw  material supply or our operations. Our 2014 financials demonstrate this strategy has paid off and has delivered  sustainable results. We, therefore, consequently continue on our strategy going forward.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Furthermore, we will begin the extension of our regional hub in Singapore, which will become the innovation  center for the region. As part of our efficiency efforts, we will also invest in a new energy plant and a state-of-the- art logistics center in Holzminden. Our capital expenditure guideline remains fully in place. We invest about 5% of  our annual sales into new projects.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the cost side, some foreign exchange rates and raw material prices will remain volatile. Although the oil price  has significantly decreased, a number of agricultural commodities such as citrus have increased. Symrise,  however, is well positioned for profitable growth and will, therefore, fully capitalize on its global market presence  and portfolio.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President-Flavor & Nutrition, Symrise AG
texts.text: We have highly sophisticated processes to audit our suppliers to trace the origin and the use of 10,000 of raw  materials. Each bag in the supermarket, we can exactly trace down to the origin. We can also tell when and  where they were processed.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President-Flavor & Nutrition, Symrise AG
texts.text: Another differentiating factor for Symrise is our strong R&D expertise. We not only follow traditional disciplines,  but also use new one such as green and white chemistry. We have entered into cooperation with science experts  and attract talents and strengthen our R&D teams. R&D is a keyword, which brings us to innovations.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President-Flavor & Nutrition, Symrise AG
texts.text: With this, please turn to chart 26. Innovation is at the heart of our business. It determines purchasing decisions by  our customers and the end consumer. The more innovative a consumer brand product is, be it in terms of a  specific flavor, ingredient or function, the more successful it is in the market. We spend more than 6% of our  annual sales for R&D. But money is just one side of the coin. It also needs an effective use of know-how. In all of  our R&D centers, we systematically foster the transfer of know-how between business units. An active ingredient  like SymUrban is a perfect example. We combined expertise in skin care with latest insight on environment  pollution, cross-linking expertise has strongly contributed to our innovation power.

texts.speaker: Heinz-Jürgen Bertram
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President-Flavor & Nutrition, Symrise AG
texts.text: Our unique setup, our global presence and our portfolio with an increasing focus on natural resources are strong  levers. We are, therefore, confident for this year. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President-Flavor & Nutrition, Symrise AG

texts.text: Just as I told you, I thought it was very interesting to remind to all of you what Symrise Nutrition about. And  Symrise Nutrition is about three main IDs. texts.speaker: Jean-Yves Parisot
texts.profession: President-Nutrition (Diana), Symrise AG
texts.text: Now what is Diana about? And I think by explaining to you the business model, you will be very well  understanding why we are focusing on the ADF/IDF acquisition. We are really mastering key  strategic stream in meat, for example, the chicken stream; in vegetal for some vegetables like onion, red beet,  fruits like acerola or strawberry; and last but not the least, some marine raw materials. So this is what we  guarantee to our customers that we are really guaranteeing food safety possibility of these raw materials.

texts.profession: President-Nutrition (Diana), Symrise AG
texts.text: The second competency is the technological competence. We are applying on these raw materials a set of  technologies; and the value of Diana, which is a process-based entity, is really to put together different  technologies to create functionalities. We furthermore raised our ambitions in terms of profitability, long-term Symrise aims to achieve an  EBITDA margin within the target corridor of 20% to 23%.
