texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: So turning back to that working capital inflow of £8 million, our cash tied up in inventories reduced by £10  million since March. Corn inventories are usually much lower at this time of year depending on the timing of  harvest. So a £10 million reduction is unusually low. Because of the severe drought, the U.S. corn harvest was  early and the price of corn higher, so we held a bit more corn at higher prices and this is the main reason for a  higher than expected inventory value. These factors also influenced both receivables and payables: receivables  because of the higher price of corn and payables because we had not yet paid for much of the corn we'd taken into  inventory.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We continue to develop the market for our zero-calorie fruit-based sweetener PUREFRUIT with a number of new  sweeteners. This included the incorporation of PUREFRUIT as an ingredient in new products launched into the  U.S. tabletop market.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In September, we launched TASTEVA, our new superior-tasting Stevia-based natural high-intensity sweetener,  thereby enhancing the product portfolio and further strengthening our global leadership position in speciality  sweeteners, and I will talk more about that later.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Sales of industrial starches, acidulants, and ethanol fell by 2%, with volumes down 7% as we continued our  strategy of gradually switching corn grind in both Europe and the U.S. to produce food starches. In industrial  starches in the U.S., where contract lends tend to be longer than in Europe, lower volumes were offset by firmer  pricing and improved margins resulting in a better performance for the period.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In U.S. ethanol, which is a small part of our business and we have used production to the lowest practical –  negative territory. As a result, operating losses were higher in the period. And with no obvious signs of excess  capacity coming out of the market, we expect the environment to remain very difficult in the second half.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Let me now spend a couple of minutes talking about corn market dynamics during the first half. In the U.S. the  worst drought in 56 years has had a significant impact on this year's corn crop, with the USDA reducing its  forecasted supply by almost 25% between June and October. As a result, towards the end of the first quarter, corn  prices rose sharply, reaching a record high in the U.S. of $8.31 per bushel on August 21 and have remained  elevated since.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The extremely dry and hot conditions have also impacted corn quality with the presence of aflatoxin, particularly  in areas hardest hit by the drought. Although aflatoxin does not impact our end products such as sweeteners and  starches, it does concentrate in co-products, specifically corn gluten feed and corn gluten meal and its presence  above certain thresholds can restrict the end markets to which these co-products are sold.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Continued dry and hot conditions in Central Europe also drove up European corn prices, and with sugar prices  expected to remain relatively stable, this is reduce isoglucose margins during the second half.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We also announced today the launch of a new eight-year £30 million venture fund, which will broaden our global  innovation program by providing a vehicle to access and invest in early-stage speciality food ingredient  companies, complementing our existing innovation capabilities within ICD.  Before I conclude with the outlook for the full year, let me take a couple of minutes to talk about some of our  recent new product launches. As I've already mentioned, in September we launched TASTEVA, our new zero  calorie stevia-based sweetener that will expand the choices available to our customers and complement our other  high-intensity sweeteners, Sucralose and PUREFRUIT.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Our sensory research and global customer feedback showed that TASTEVA delivers a clear taste advantage over  high-purity stevia alternatives, across a wide range of food and beverage applications. We believe the introduction  of TASTEVA to our portfolio will enable our food and beverage customers, seeking sweeteners from a natural  source, to develop solutions without the bitter, liquorish aftertaste often associated with other stevia-based  sweeteners and further reinforce our position as the leading global provider of sweetener solutions.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: At October, we announced the global launch of our new salt reduction ingredient SODA-LO, which has been  created using a technology that turns standard salt crystals into free-flowing crystalline microspheres. These  smaller, lower-density crystals, efficiently deliver salty taste by maximizing surface area relative to volume,  making it possible to enjoy the same taste, while reducing added salt content in certain food applications such as  bread and savory snacks by up to 50%.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Faced with significant price rises and supply constraints in the egg market, many food manufacturers are seeking  to control recipe costs by reducing the egg content of their products. In response within our food systems  business, we have developed new HAMULSION stabilizer systems enabling egg replacement in bakery products of  up to 100%. This builds on other initiatives within our food-systems business to help reduce input costs, including  the launch last year of CARCAO, a carob powder ingredient that can be used as a partial cocoa replacement.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In bulk ingredients, we expect the firm demand for liquid sweeteners in the U.S. to continue and demand in our  other food markets to remain stable. In Europe, higher corn prices are expected to reduce isoglucose margins in  the second half. Market conditions in U.S. ethanol are expected to remain challenging.

file: TATEL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 7November2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Corn prices in both the U.S. and Europe have reduced significantly since July 2013, as expectations grew that this  will be a bumper harvest. While we expect a continuation of volume growth in starch-based specialties, the  significant fall in corn prices is likely to limit sales growth during the fourth quarter of this financial year and into  the next financial year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In the last couple of years, we've passed through higher corn prices to customers, and that's a big part of the  reason why sales growth has outstripped volume growth. But looking forward, I expect a reversal of that trend.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In industrial starches, acidulants and ethanol, sales increased by 5%. Overall profits were lower than the  comparative period, as a result of softer pricing in the European industrial starch market, which more than offset  slightly better conditions within U.S. ethanol.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: As in previous years, we managed our inventories down to make way for the new harvest. We took them especially  low this year to manage the exceptionally big reduction in the corn price between old and new harvests.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We continue to see good long-term growth potential for no-calorie high-intensity sweeteners, driven by the focus  on healthier lifestyles and calorie reduction. We are very well-placed to benefit from this global trend, having  broadened our sweetener portfolio over the last two years.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We delivered strong volume growth in our natural high-intensity sweeteners PUREFRUIT and TASTEVA. While  we are encouraged by this performance, their contribution to-date to the overall high-intensity sweetener category  remains relatively small.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving onto Bulk Ingredients. Adjusted operating profit was 11% percent lower at £92 million, primarily the  result of lower bulk sweetener volumes. In North America, we saw a 5% reduction in bulk sweetener volumes,  including lower volumes of HFCS where demand is strongly correlated to the consumption of carbonated soft  drinks, where consumption declined in the U.S. by 4.5% in the six-month period to the start of October.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We have started a program to position this business for long-term growth, initially by investing $6 million to triple  capacity at our plant in Sweden. We continue to work closely with an increasing number of customers to qualify  our novel salt-reduction ingredient, SODA-LO. Like other, new-to-the-world ingredients, the time required to  seed the ingredients to the market is longer than that for a basic line extension. But we continue to see strong  customer interest in traction. Looking ahead, our focus will increasingly turn toward converting customer projects  into sales and broadening the range of applications in which SODA-LO can be used.

file: TATEL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 6November2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: To ensure we could service our customers' requirements, we incurred incremental costs in areas such as air  freight, buying in additional product from the market, and having to make some sub-optimal production runs. We  also lost sales due to product unavailability. The cost related to the operational and supply chain disruption in the  first half was £31 million and as stated in September, we anticipate further supply chain-related cost of around  £10 million in the second half.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Through proprietary processes we developed in-house, we have created a product with a cleaner color and a  cleaner taste which works particularly well in creamy, delicately-flavored products like yogurts, and in light sauces  such as mayonnaise and dressings. The launch of CLARIA has gone well, and we are already making early  shipments to some customers.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In industrial starch, overall volumes in the U.S. were broadly in line with the comparative period with slightly  higher unit margins. In Europe, a more competitive market put pressure on margins and reduced profits.  Conditions in the U.S. ethanol market improved, delivering year-on-year margin growth. Acidulants performed  broadly in line with the comparative period, while profit from the Bio-PDO joint venture was slightly ahead,  benefiting from lower corn costs.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: Now, let me walk you through the detail of the key numbers. Starting with the income statements, sales at £1.4  billion was £357 million lower than the comparative period. Around half of this decrease relates to pass-through  of lower corn costs following a reduction in corn prices of around 30% as compared to the first half of last year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our recently-launched CLARIA line of starches is one example of the label-friendly products we have been  developing in ICD over the last four years. Other ingredients we have brought to market with a clean-label  positioning includes SODA-LO, TASTEVA, PUREFRUIT, PROMITOR and PromOat Beta Glucan. These products  are all growing strongly and generating strong customer interest and engagement, reflecting the health and  wellness benefits they bring to consumers.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: While we do not invest growth capital in Bulk Ingredients, we continue to deploy capital to reduce costs and  increase efficiency, including investment in energy reduction and yield improvement projects. We continue to look  for ways to dampen volatility, including initiatives to diversify grind, increase our corn storage capacity, and to  reduce our exposure to regulated markets.

file: TATEL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 5November2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: Turning to the headline results for the half year. Sales were 6% lower mainly due to the pass-through of lower corn  costs and lower commodity prices in the U.S. for ethanol and co-products. Operating profit for the first half  increased by £19 million or 12% as we benefited from a solid operating performance and improved supply chain  execution. Of this increase, foreign exchange translation accounted for £8 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: In Bulk Ingredients, volumes were flat while sales decreased by 11% to £729 million, reflecting the pass-through of  lower corn costs and lower commodity prices in the U.S. for ethanol and co-products. Operating profit was 15%  lower at £42 million.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: North American bulk corn sweetener volumes grew by 2%. Following a normal summer's weather, the U.S.  demand for carbonated soft drinks was relatively resilient, and this together with strong sweetener demand in  Mexico saw shipments increase in total.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: North American industrial starches saw volume 5% lower as primary capacity allocated to this business was  reduced in favor of Speciality Food Ingredients. Profits in the core business excluding commodities was slightly  higher than the comparative period. In commodities, high ethanol inventories and low gasoline prices in the U.S.  drove a continuation of the low ethanol prices first experienced in the second half of the 2015 fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: Operating profits from commodities was £11 million lower at a loss of £2 million. The fundamentals of the U.S.  ethanol industry show no near-term signs of improving, and we expect returns from U.S. ethanol to remain weak  in the second half.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: Finally, the annual bulk sweetener pricing round has progressed more quickly than in previous years. We have  now agreed pricing for the large majority of the volume that was available for contracting for the 2016 calendar  year, achieving modest margin gains.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: Capital expenditure of £81 million reflect the continued progress in implementing the extension to capacity for  Speciality Food Ingredients. A major cost saving initiative to construct to combine heat and power plant at our  Loudon facility in Tennessee has also commenced. The project involves installing new natural gas-powered  turbines, heat recovery boilers and the laying of a new gas pipeline and will result in more efficient,  environmentally friendly and lower cost energy to power the site.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: In Bulk Ingredients, the fourth quarter offers some moderate margin benefits on the sweetener volume we have  recontracted. However, the fundamentals of the U.S. ethanol market show no near-term signs of improving, and  we expect returns from U.S. ethanol to remain weak in the second half.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The commodities group manages corn procurement and also the network of storage facilities we use to manage  the cost effectiveness and security of our corn supply. It also manages the sales of co-products, such as corn oil,  corn gluten feed and corn gluten meal, and of ethanol, which is produced at one of our U.S. mills.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And finally, we are working continuously to improve productivity in our plants. The most recent material example  of this is the combined heat and power plant under construction at our facility in Tennessee, that Nick referred to  earlier, which we expect to be a key driver of manufacturing cost reduction as of fiscal 2018. These four factors,  together with the dampening of commodities volatility, underpin the division's medium-term ambition of  generating steady earnings and cash.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our portfolio of products lends itself extremely well to healthy snacking, in that our products help to reduce fat,  sugar and salt, and add fiber. For example, PromOat Oat Beta Glucan is used in smoothies to add fiber, texture  and support healthy cholesterol levels. And this subcategory is growing at around 6%, nearly three times the  overall beverage category. Similarly, our line of CLARIA Functional Clean-Label Starches work very well in  drinking yogurt and other subcategory growing well above the overall category.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Staying with new products. As shown on the previous slide, one product that has been a key contributor to new  product sales is PROMITOR Soluble Corn Fibre. A dietary fiber, PROMITOR can be used in a wide range of  applications and is label-friendly.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Expansion capital is expected to be around 45% of the total, up from 25% in the last four years, and cost reduction  projects will account for around 20%, up from 13% in the last four years. Increased investment in expansion and  cost reduction projects will drive increased returns. We will retain a disciplined approach to capital expenditure  approval and target hurdle rates.

file: TATEL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 3November2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: North American industrial starch volumes remained robust and were 2% higher. Overall demand for paper and  board remains steady, with reduced demand for printing and writing paper being offset by higher packaging and  tissue demand. Demand for starches for building materials also remained strong during the half. Commodities  remain challenging with a loss of £3 million, representing stable year-on-year performance. High U.S. ethanol  inventory levels continued to pressure ethanol margins.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We have also continued to see a benign input cost environment. Corn supply continues to be healthy with the  2016 U.S. crop expected to reach record levels. We have seen relatively stable and low corn prices over the last  two years which have benefited the competitive position of corn derived products.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Firstly, the fundamentals of the end markets we operate in have been relatively stable, with the U.S. corn wet  milling industry well balanced, and U.S. corn prices currently low. The commodities environment is still  challenging, albeit relatively stable, with U.S. ethanol margins continuing to be under significant pressure and  showing no near-term signs of improvement.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We continue to focus on improvements in operational efficiency and cost control. For example, in addition to  existing efficiency programs, we have also established dedicated continuous improvement Six Sigma teams to  lead productivity and efficiency projects across our manufacturing and the broader supply chain network. These  teams are already beginning to have a positive impact.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving to innovation. Sales of New Products from our innovation pipeline continued to achieve good traction with  volume growth across all our three platforms of sweeteners, texturants and health and wellness. We extended our  line of CLARIA functional clean label starches with the addition of CLARIA Delight. This tapioca-based clean label  starch delivers a clean color, flavor and texture, and can be used in a variety of applications including soups,  sauces, yogurts and dairy desserts.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We also extended our sweetener portfolio with MULTIVANTAGE Syrup, a low-sugar syrup which can be used to  reduce sugar content while maintaining calorie levels, which is very important for customers in certain applications  such as breakfast foods.

file: TATEL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 2November2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: North American bulk sweeteners volume grew by 2%, driven by strong export volume to Mexico where demand  for carbonated soft drinks remains firm, as well as modest growth in volume in U.S. bulk sweetener customers,  reflecting good contract compliance and supply chain execution.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: High fructose corn syrup demand remained relatively stable, with consumption of regular carbonated soft drinks in  North America decreasing slightly in the six months to September. North American Industrial Starches volume  was in line with the prior period, as overall demand for paper and board remained steady.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Core Bulk Ingredients continues to perform well, driven by combination of strong product line focus, good  commercial and supply chain execution, solid demand and moderate margin gains secured in the 2017 calendar  year contracting round. Commodities contributed profit of £10 million, an increase of £13 million, reflecting gains  from the sourcing of corn and in co-products mainly from corn oil. Ethanol cash margins remained relatively flat.  We manage commodities for cash generation and look to dampen volatility through de-risking strategies. In the  second half, the contribution from commodities will be subject to market dynamics.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The second objective is to broaden our customer base by penetrating faster-growing customer channels, such as  private label and food service. The third is to focus on those higher growth subcategories, which play well into our  expertise in sugar and calorie reduction and fiber enrichment, such as health and nutrition, dairy and bakery  categories.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The performance of Bulk Ingredients is largely driven by two factors. The first being market and industry  dynamics, and the second, the way we manage the business. Looking first at market dynamics. The U.S. corn  wet milling industry remains well balanced. The fundamentals of the key end markets we serve, such as regular  carbonated soft drinks and paper and board, are relatively stable. And consecutive years of good harvests have  contributed to a period of largely stable and lower U.S. corn prices. The current U.S. corn harvest is forecast to be  at the higher end of historic levels, with inventories remaining high. The commodities environment is also  relatively stable, albeit, U.S. ethanol margins are at the low end of the historical range.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We have made significant improvements to our demand-and-supply planning processes, and also, increased our  focus on improving operational efficiency and reducing costs. Dedicated Six Sigma teams are leading productivity  and efficiency projects across our manufacturing and supply chain network in diverse areas, such as reducing  railcar turnaround times, reducing waste in our citric acid production process, and debottlenecking industrial  starch lines.

file: TATEL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 8November2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In Food & Beverage Solutions, we are continuing to focus on sugar replacement and calorie reduction in our  selected global categories. On the slide, there are some examples of customer wins in the beverages and the  soups, sauces and dressings categories. Whether it is providing sugar reduction, fiber enrichment or a clean  sweet taste, the combination of our technical skills and local capabilities enabled us to provide the right solution  for our customers in each case.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In Primary Products, we manage our portfolio to maximize margins by optimizing product and customer mix. We  continue to diversify capacity towards new and growing markets where we can provide customers with a high- quality product and a differentiated service, whether that be supply chain flexibility or on-site technical expertise.  Examples include sweetness for growing craft beer and fermented alcohol market and industrial starches for the  cardboard and packaging market where growth is being driven by an increase in online shopping. In addition,  through our joint venture with DuPont, we are providing customers with renewable sourced ingredients used in a  wide range of growing end markets, including clothing and cosmetics.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving to two examples illustrating sustainable productivity. In the first half, we installed a new gas boiler at our  plant in Decatur, Illinois. This new boiler will help improve plant reliability and will also produce steam to generate  electricity. This project is expected to generate benefits of around $1.5 million annually. In our global supply chain,  we are working to reduce storage and handling costs by increasing the amount of product we ship direct from our  plants to customers instead of channeling them through our warehouse network. Overall, we have a growing  pipeline of simplification projects, many of which are already under way.

texts.speaker: Imran Nawaz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Primary Products. As Nick already referred before, industry fundamentals remain solid, with the U.S. corn wet  milling industry. It's well-balanced and demand is firm. Our volumes were in line with the prior year, and that  reflects the firm industry demand but also good operational performance and our good customer contract  compliance. Our Sweetener volume was in line with the prior period as we managed mix, balance in both  customer, products and also in fact category demand. North American Industrial Starch volume, you see here,  was down 3%. However, that's a result of actively managing our corn wet milling assets and driving it to the  higher-margin businesses.

file: TATEL - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 27May2010 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Primary industrial losses of £8 million compared to profits of £3 million in the prior year. Ethanol  cash margins were modest throughout the year, and have weakened in recent months and I will  come back to this in a moment.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Also, within primary industrial, the corn gluten feed co-product sold to the animal feed market has  also remained under pressure, reflecting lower demand combined with increasing supply of an  alternative feed co-product from dry-mill ethanol production.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Turning to focus on the key trends in U.S corn and energy markets in a little more detail, corn  prices plotted in yellow on this graph have remained in the $3.50 to $4 per bushel range since  January and the early indications are that the 2010 crop will be a decent one.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Looking at the green and blue lines on this graph, you can see the relationship between the prices  of ethanol and gasoline during the year. The resulting margins for the blenders over the last nine  months have favored the blending of discretionary ethanol above the mandated demand level set  out in the Renewable Fuel Standard.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: You can see the close correlation of corn and ethanol prices in recent months. And here there has  been only a small cash margin for ethanol producers. However, this margin has been enough to  bring considerable additional supply onto the market, which has kept margins tight and only in the  spot market.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: As Javed has already said, the continuing weak and uncertain outlook for ethanol and challenging  conditions in industrial starch markets, do not provide any basis to complete our plant in Fort Dodge  for the foreseeable future, leading to the impairment, Javed discussed earlier.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: We have also shown the raw sugar reference price, in green. As I’ve said before, this is not  necessarily the price we pay, as we can pay premium for example, for better quality, but it does  demonstrate how the margins between the raw price and the actual refined selling price in Europe  have opened up.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Actual total cane imports are lagging significantly behind the EU Commission’s own 2005  projections. In light of this, we continue to talk to the regulators to ensure that the mechanisms  available to them, including duty-free imports, are employed to maintain a balanced market.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: The division as a whole achieved operating profits of £30 million in the year, up from £12 million in  the comparative period. As well as benefiting from the improved EU refining margins in the second  half, performance for the year benefited from lower energy costs compared to the comparative  period, and a continued reduction in logistics costs. It also benefited from the last full year of  transitional aid, and we will book the final £8.5 million of this in the first half of the current financial  year. Molasses delivered £13 million of operating profit, a good result driven by solid margins,  although below the exceptional result achieved in the comparative period.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: We are pleased that SPLENDA Sucralose has continued to increase its share of the global High  Intensity Sweetener market by value, from 25% to 26% during the year, and believe that long-term  customer agreements will continue to drive volume growth going forward.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Turning briefly to cover energy costs. Total costs of £193 million were 11% below the prior year.  We benefited from lower prices, particularly from natural gas, and achieved efficiency  improvements totaling £11 million, or over 5%. We have contracts and hedges in place that cover  approximately 65% of our estimated energy use for the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: We anticipate that industrial starch margins in both the U.S. and Europe will remain at lower levels,  despite some improvement in demand, and we see little near-term improvement in U.S. ethanol  markets. Although unit refining margins are expected to be stable, profitability at Sugars in the 2011  financial year will be constrained by short-term supply challenges.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: The second leg of that is by driving bulk ingredients in our sugars businesses for sustained cash  generation to fuel this growth. What I mean by bulk ingredients, let me just define that for a second,  I mean the large corn-based commodity businesses like HFCS, like industrial starch, like biofuels.  That is what constitutes bulk ingredients in this nomenclature. These are large businesses,  relatively very large businesses for us. They are very cost efficient businesses. We’ve got some  very strong customer relationships in those businesses, and as you’ve seen they are inherently  cash generative.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Right. Good morning. Welcome to the presentation of Tate & Lyle’s Results for the year ended 31st
texts.text: Asset utilization, we’re going to be moving to a measure of return on capital employed. A lot of  these things are still work in process, being finalized, and we’ll report back to you when I come  back and report the 2010 base starting KPIs, which we will do once we’ve kind of redone the  accounts. The balance sheet will be net debt, EBITDA, interest cover, no change, just to ensure  that we are measuring the strength of the balance sheet. And in corporate responsibility, we clearly  have a safety index, it continues to be a priority and we will continue to report on that. In addition to  that we will also in the next few months look to have a sustainability index, but again that’s one of  the things that’s work in process at the moment, so that will be likely added to the corporate  responsibility KPI.

file: TATEL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 27May2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: We have no higher priority than safety. Whilst our safety performance continues to compare  favorably against the industry, the Group’s overall safety performance deteriorated during 2010,  and we take any reduction in performance very seriously. A detailed plan has been put in place to  drive an improvement in performance, which our global safety teams, employees and contractors  are working hard to embed across the Group. We are establishing KPIs for environmental  sustainability, which we will report on from next year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: Within starch-based specialty ingredients, we experienced increasing demand for modified food  starches across all regions, driven by the gradual economic recovery and the demand for more  convenience foods in the developing markets. Speciality corn sweeteners benefited from the  continuing trend of sugar substitution where customers are increasingly turning to us to provide  alternative lower-cost sweetener solutions in an environment of high and volatile sugar prices. The  success of PROMITOR Soluble Corn Fiber 85 has driven strong growth in our Fibres offering.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: 3 Ethanol sales increased based on higher volumes and prices. Whilst cash margins improved in the  U.S., ethanol continues to generate a loss at the operating level. The disposal of our ethanol facility  at Fort Dodge reduces our exposure to what remains a highly volatile and commoditized industry.  Whilst sales increased within our citric acid business, profits were lower than the prior year as a  result of higher input costs.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: You can see the significant increase in corn prices in both the U.S. and Europe from these graphs.  While we can hedge the gross cost of corn in the U.S., we cannot cover co-products, which broadly  follow soft commodity prices. Thus, rising corn prices during the year give us a benefit through  firmer co-product income. The large movements year-on-year added £16 million to profit. And the  majority of this benefit is realized in Bulk Ingredients.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: In U.S. sweeteners, high domestic cane sugar prices in Mexico helped accelerate the substitution  with corn sugar. And fine weather last summer offset the impact of the long-term trend of declining  domestic demand. However, the contracting round for calendar year 2010 was conducted against  the backdrop of lower capacity utilization, and lower prices offset the benefit of the higher volumes.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: Ethanol continued to make a loss at the operating level, but this was reduced compared with the  very difficult market in the prior year. Citric acid sales increased, although profits are lower because  of higher input costs.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: A quick word on energy. Lower gas prices helped reduce our total cost by 7%. And, as usual, I’ve  included a chart on energy cost for the whole business in the supporting information. As a Group,  we’ve got contracts and futures in place that hedge around 70% of our energy costs for the 2012  financial year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed, Chief Executive officer & Executive Director
texts.profession: Good morning, and welcome to the presentation for Tate & Lyle’s results for the year ended 31st of
texts.text: The initial focus of this group is really around three specific categories. And that is sweetness, it’s  around texturance, and it’s around health and wellness categories. In our case today, that means  specialty fibres mostly. And it probably doesn’t kind of surprise you to hear that we are seeing a big  increase in demand for customers, for either new products or reformulations, which either reduce  calories, reduce fat, reduce sugar or do all of the above. And our products, and our current  products lend themselves very well to these trends, and I think are quite well-positioned to benefit  from them.

file: TATEL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 31May2012 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Group Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Industrial starch volumes were 5% lower as we again moved grind to speciality starches and sweeteners. Profits  were higher as European margins benefited from lower availability of alternative starches. Ethanol again made a  small loss and citric acid profits were in line with the prior year. And in April 2012, we announced the sale of our  Colombian joint venture, which contributed £2 million of profit in the year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Group Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: I'm going to look at corn prices on this next slide. And I've extended the chart which I showed you at the interim  results. The corn price has an impact on co-product selling prices. The corn price in the first half of the year, which  is the first green line, was much higher than the average when we agreed contracts for the 2011 calendar year, and  that's the red line on the left.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Group Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Tight supply combined with a drought in Texas, which increased demand for co-products going into feed, and our  fixing of long-term contracts at favorable pricing generated £19 million of additional income. With over 80% of  the grind, the majority of the benefit is reported in Bulk Ingredients. You can see a much narrower profile in the  second half, indicating more normal returns, albeit co-products still generated a small amount of additional  income in that period.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Group Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Turning to the exceptional items. In the year, we reversed impairments and provisions of £76 million as we  restarted our sucralose facility in McIntosh. We also reversed a smaller impairments of £7 million as we have  started to reuse a fermentation pilot plant for our bio-based material collaborations. We've separated out the costs  of our business transformation project and report them as an exceptional cost of £15 million, with £5 million  associated with the global Commercial, Food and innovation center in Chicago and £9 million on Global Shared  Services and the new IS/IT platform.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: During the year, we also made good progress in helping customers work with our zero-calorie, fruit-based  sweetener, PUREFRUIT, and continue to build the project pipeline. With customer product development cycles  typically lasting around 18 months for this kind of ingredient, the focus over the coming year will be to convert  these opportunities into sales and to support customers on new product launches. The facilities and new  capabilities at our recently opened innovation center in Chicago, which I will discuss later, will help to accelerate  customer projects through the pipeline.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving on to the Bulk Ingredients division where sales increased by 18% with volumes down 2% overall,  reflecting our strategy to gradually divert corn grind to Specialty Food ingredients. Adjusted operating profit  increased by 13% to £172 million.  Now moving to talk about the main categories. In the U.S. sales of bulk corn sweeteners increased by 16% as a  result of higher corn prices and lower volumes from the switch of grind. As in the previous year, we experienced  firm U.S. domestic demand on the back of a more stable U.S. carbonated soft drink market and continued to see  robust demand from Mexico.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Same with bio-based material, we made good progress on the two initiatives we announced last year with Amyris  and Genomatica both at our pilot plant facilities in Decatur, Illinois. While the contribution made by these  initiatives remains small, they provide a good opportunity to diversify our corn grind to reduce volatility in the  longer term. Net, we are pleased with the performance of both our Speciality Food Ingredients and the Bulk  Ingredients divisions during the year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In Bulk Ingredients, we anticipate improved bulk sweetener margins in both Europe and the U.S. to broadly offset  our expectation of more normal co-product returns and the impact of softer market conditions in industrial  starches in Europe and ethanol in the U.S.

file: TATEL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 30May2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In our starch-based specialties, absolute margins per tonne were slightly higher, but the impact to passing through  higher input cost into sales – into the sales values reduces the percentage. Following the 2013 pricing round,  which again concluded against the background of rising corn costs, this is something I expect to repeat in the  current year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: North American bulk sweetener sales increased by 7% as we again were able to pass through higher corn cost to  customers. As discussed at the time of the 2012 contracting round, we achieved a modest HFCS unit margin  increase after recovering higher corn and processed ingredient costs and profits were higher than the prior year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The U.S. ethanol market was challenging and there was an increase in operating losses even after the £4.5 million  benefit from settling the dispute with Whitefox Technologies. Citric acid profit was slightly ahead of the prior year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The drought in the Midwest last year affected corn quality and, because of the high incidence of aflatoxin, reduced  profits by £8 million, affecting all segments, but mainly through lower prices on some co-products. This  suppressed co-product improvements in the year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Coming back to the working capital outflows of £107 million. The drought in the U.S. last year reduced the size of  the U.S. corn crop, brought high levels of aflatoxin infestation and drove prices up as supply-demand ratio has  tightened significantly. We're, therefore, again holding a high level of corn inventories until closer to harvest and  we had more working capital tied up at 31 of March because of the higher corn price.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving on to high-intensity sweeteners, after a very good performance in the 2012 financial year, SPLENDA  Sucralose volume was slightly lower as a result of a soft first quarter and lower demand from the table top  segment where competition from natural alternatives has increased. While we saw a return to more normal  growth patterns from the second quarter onwards, this was not enough to match the tough prior-year comparable.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We expect the longer-term demand for SPLENDA Sucralose to continue to be underpinned not only by its product  attributes, specifically the superior taste profile and heat stability, but also its use in health-related and cost- optimization projects.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: With our two large-scale continuous production facilities now operational, we continue to be in a position to  provide our customers with the highest standards of quality, sustainability and reliability in the industry. The  inclusion of our zero calorie natural fruit-based sweetener, PUREFRUIT, in table top products has created a  greater awareness of this ingredient and driven a number of other new product launches and incremental sales.  The initial customer response to our stevia-based natural no-calorie sweetener, TASTEVA, has also been  encouraging having already been incorporated in new customer product launches.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In Europe, despite isoglucose margins being squeezed in the second half due to higher corn prices, high and stable  sugar prices in the EU meant that the overall performance for the full year was ahead of the prior year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In U.S. ethanol, which as you know represents a small part of the business, market conditions remained  challenging with excess capacity and high levels of inventory resulting in negative industry margins for much of  the period. As a result, full-year operating losses from ethanol is somewhat higher than the prior year. Despite  higher raw material costs, our citric acid business delivered an improved performance for the year as did our Bio- PDO joint venture which delivered a small operating profit having made a loss during the prior year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Staying with bio-based materials, in December 2012 with our partner, Genomatica, we successfully completed the  first commercial scale production of Bio-BDO using a bio-based manufacturing process at our plant in Loudon,  Tennessee.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Now, let me take a moment to talk about what has been a volatile year in the corn market. In the U.S. Midwest, the  worst drought for over 50 years had a significant effect on last year's harvest against the backdrop of what was  already a tight corn market. As a result, we saw a big increase in corn prices during this summer as the USDA  revised down their estimates for stocks-to-use ratio from an estimate of nearly 14% in May 2012 to just under 6%  in August 2012. Unsurprisingly, the corn price remained high and volatile for the remainder of the financial year,  although we did see the price ease toward the end of March based on assumptions of record planting intentions  for this year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving on to innovation, where again we have made steady progress. We launched six new products from our  innovation pipeline during the year including a new texturant called NUHESIVE, an adhesive starch used in  snacks and cereals; our stevia-based, no-calorie sweetener, TASTEVA; and our new salt-reduction product,  SODA-LO.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In the last six months our Open Innovation team completed two development agreements with university spin- offs. The first was with Nandi Proteins to develop an early-stage protein ingredient technology, and the second  was a further agreement with Eminate to develop its hollow microsphere technology to reduce sodium  bicarbonate in baked goods.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We recently added to our existing range of speciality corn-based fibres through the acquisition of Biovelop, a small  beta-glucan business operating out of Sweden. Beta-glucan is a premium ingredient with approved health claims  including from EFSA. This clean label ingredient represents an excellent addition to our speciality fibres and  health and wellness portfolios. We intend to invest in this business over the coming years to build on the  foundation already in place and to help realize its full commercial potential globally.

file: TATEL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 29May2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: While we expect good volume growth and a modest increase in unit margins in the 2014 calendar year, the  reduction in corn prices is expected to hold back sales value growth in this product category and the division as a  whole.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Industrial starch volumes were 2% higher, with an improvement in the U.S. offset by a more competitive market  in Europe. Conditions in the U.S. ethanol market improved during the year and losses were reduced. Acidulants  profits were lower.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving to co-products and corn prices, the good U.S. harvest in 2013 eased the tight corn supply and prices fell  sharply in July last year to around $4 per bushel, around half of what they were the year before. However, the  forecast stocks-to-use ratio has tightened again in the last few months on the back of firm demand for ethanol and  exports, and prices have moved up towards $5 a bushel. Co-product returns were lower than our expectations at  the start of the year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Corn oil prices fell as a result of increased supply, not only from the new harvest, but also because dry mill ethanol  producers are now able to extract oil. We took the decision to sell forward some corn gluten feed, although this  worked against us when prices rose as the severe winter restricted supply. This was partially offset by imp roved  returns from corn gluten mill which we have also sold forward. Overall, returns generated by co -products was £7   million lower than our expectations, compared with a small amount of net additional income generated in the  prior year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: We, therefore, also had less working capital tied up at the 31st of March because of the lower corn prices. The  lower price also drove receivable and payable values, which broadly offset despite a difference in the timing of  corn payments without which the working capital improvement would have been higher. Thi s reduction in  working capital helped improve our average cash conversion cycle by three days.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In high-intensity sweeteners, we see good volume growth opportunities, underpinned by a strong long-term global  drive for calorie reduction, a trend that we are well placed to address through our product portfolio and leading  applications expertise. During the year, high-intensity sweetener volumes grew by 5%.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Bulk Ingredients, where the modest increase in unit margins achieved in the 2013 calendar year was  more than offset by a number of challenges, including unusually cold weather in the U.S. and another volatile year  in the corn market. In North American sweeteners, volumes were 2% lower, reflecting the impact of the cold  spring which resulted in a marked reduction in consumption of carbonated soft drinks, the key end market for  HFCS in our first quarter. Despite the lower volumes, profits were ahead of the prior year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In U.S. ethanol, where, as you know, we are a relatively small player, o verall, market conditions improved during  the year due to lower corn prices and increased demand. As a result, we delivered a better performance from this  category with a reduction in operating losses in the year.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: The performance of our acidulants business was lower than the prior year, as a result of increased competition,  which reduced volumes and more than offset the benefit of lower raw material costs. Our Bio -PDO business  generated a small profit driven by lower corn prices.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: So now, let me come back to the three areas I said I would focus on. Starting with sucralose, when  notwithstanding the competitive environment and pricing headwinds, we continue to see lo ng-term volume  growth opportunities, driven by a number of factors that I will come on to shortly. As you can see from the chart,  superior taste profile and heat stability of sucralose means that it remains the high-intensity sweetener of choice  in a wide range of food and beverage applications.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: In 2013, over 6,300 new products were launched incorporating sucralose, a 54% increase over the prior year, well  above that for other high-intensity sweeteners. As a result, sucralose's value share of the global high-intensity  sweetener market continues to increase standing at 35% in 2013 compared with 28% in 2009.

texts.speaker: Tim Lodge
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Let me spend a couple of minutes talking about the progress we are seeing on a couple of the products we have  launched since ICD was formed. Starting with TASTEVA, one of our natural-source, no calorie sweeteners. This  product has now been launched in 25 countries with customer product launches already on shelves in all regions  across a range of end categories including carbonated soft drinks, snacks, te as, energy drinks, and dairy. As well as  gaining traction with customers, TASTEVA has gained recognition in the industry, based on its superior taste  characteristics, having won two global innovation awards in 2013. The pipeline for TASTEVA is healthy, wit h  approximately 150 projects across all four regions, as we seek to convert this growing number of global  opportunities into sales.

file: TATEL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 28May2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director
texts.text: However, there are some parts of the business, mainly in ethanol and co -product pricing, where our ability to  dampen volatility is limited and no viable hedging options exist. While we expect conditions in the commodity  markets will vary from year-to-year, for these commodities, our approach is to plan for a normal year and we'll  provide guidance as the year progresses on the expected impact of these commodities on the performance of Bulk  Ingredients.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our main operating assets in North America feature four very large corn wet mills with significant economies of  scale. These four plants also produce Speciality Food Ingredients, and therefore, provide an efficient base to  support Speciality growth through grind reallocation over time. The North American corn futures market is an  additional vehicle with which we can reduce risk and dampen volatility as unlike in Europe, we can hedge our corn  purchases against customer commitments.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Consumer trends, such as the increasing demand for convenience food, natural ingredients and for healthier food  in general are driven by well-known factors such as modern day 24/7 lifestyle, the greater sensitivity around food  processing and provenance, the rise of obesity and diabetes globally and so on. What is clear, however, is that  these trends are creating strong demand for those categories and ingredients which directly address them. We see  this clearly in the new product development priorities of our customers. And our portfolio of products lends itself  extremely well to addressing these, in that they help to reduce calories, sugar, fat and salt, add fiber and provide a  cleaner label.

file: TATEL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 26May2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We made good progress strengthening our business in support of our 2020 Ambition. Javed will talk in more  detail later about the major change initiatives we have delivered, so our focus on processes, capabilities and the  balance sheets.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Sales decreased by 6% reflecting the pass-through of lower corn costs and lower prices in the U.S. for ethanol and  co-products. Operating profit was 3% lower at £84 million with significant margin gains in the core business,  offset by Commodities weakness. The core business performed strongly with volume growth in North American  Sweeteners 1% higher, supported by improved demand in Mexico and better supply chain performance. The  margins improved reflecting tighter demand across the industry, lower energy prices and supply chain efficiency.  Multi-year toll contracts reduced the volume of business that is recontracted in any single year. Contracts renewed  in the 2016 calendar year pricing round were renewed at moderately high unit margins, and this benefited the  fourth quarter of the fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Commodities reported a loss of £9 million, a reduction of £29 million from the prior year. Low crude oil prices  and high U.S. ethanol inventory levels continue to pressure ethanol prices, resulting in losses in our ethanol  business.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We expect capital expenditure for the 2017 financial year to be around £150 million as previously guided. This will  include our co-generation project at Loudon, Tennessee where we are spending around £40 million to make the  plant significantly more energy efficient.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Commodities, however, the environment has been very challenging. In particular, high ethanol inventories and  low gasoline prices in the U.S. continued to put significant pressure on industry margins throughout the year. The  fundamentals of the U.S. ethanol industry do not show any near-term signs of improving. And therefore, we  expect returns from U.S. ethanol to remain weak in the 2017 financial year. The U.S. corn wet milling industry  remains relatively stable and well balanced. U.S. carbonated soft drink sales volume, the main demand driver for  our bulk sweeteners, declined by around 0.5% in the 2016 financial year, somewhat less negative than the longer- term market trend.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the corn market, three consecutive strong harvests have led to a period of relative stability in U.S. corn prices,  and the latest forecast is for another good harvest this year. Strong cost control and operational efficiency are  critical to the success of this business, and we continue to invest in our plants for efficiency gains  and cost  reduction, such as the co-generation project at Loudon, Nick talked about earlier.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Clean-Label is also a growing trend in China. Since 2012, there has been a 51% increase in new product launches  with a Clean-Label claim, and this is one of the reasons why our line of CLARIA Functional Clean-Label Starches,  which work particularly well in yogurts, are getting good traction in China.

file: TATEL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 25May2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: As a result, the core business delivered operating profit growth of £28 million with higher North American  sweetener sales despite consumption of regulated carbonating soft drinks declining by 0.7%. Contracts renewed  for the 2017 calendar year delivered modestly high unit margins and benefited the fourth quarter of the 2017  financial year.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: During the year, we expanded our texturants portfolio through the launch of a number of non-GMO starches and  also CLARIA Bliss, a tapioca-based extension to a line of CLARIA functional clean label starches. We also  extended our sweetener portfolio with MULTIVANTAGE Syrup, a low sugar syrup, and launched a new crystalline  version of DOLCIA PRIMA Allulose opening up new categories and applications.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Bulk Ingredients. In short, the division had an excellent year. Looking at market dynamics, the  U.S. corn wet milling industry remains well-balanced. The fundamentals of the key end markets we serve such as  regular carbonated soft drinks, and paper and board have been relatively stable. And three consecutive good  harvests have contributed to a period of largely stable and lower U.S. corn prices. The commodities environment  is also steady, albeit U.S. ethanol margins are at the low end of the historical range. This overall balance looks set  to continue as we move into the 2018 financial year, although market and political factors could obviously  influence this situation.

texts.speaker: Javed Ahmed
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: A good example of this is the $60 million investment in a new combined heat and power facility at our plant in  Loudon, Tennessee. This highly complex engineering project was brought into use as planned in the third quarter  of the financial year. Not only does it decrease energy used at the facility by approximately 15%, but also  significantly reduces our carbon footprint at the site. So in summary, over the last year, Bulk Ingredients made  good progress on margin management, continuing to drive operational efficiencies and maintaining tight cost  control. These will remain key areas of focus in the coming year.

file: TATEL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 24May2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Mark McLeish
texts.profession: Group Vice President, Finance & Control, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: New products continue to show good momentum with 15% increase in sales to $121 million. Higher sales in  texturants were driven primarily by our clean label starches and Non-GMO solutions. In sweeteners, PUREFRUIT  performed well and sugar replacement in beverages drove growth in our stevia portfolio.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: To show you the way I wanted to work with our customers in the future, in Primary Products, we recently provided  an innovative supply chain solution for large U.S. private label customer. And this flexible approach enabled us to  win new sweetener volume across multiple categories.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: For Food & Beverage Solutions, I'd like to share one example in more detail. I'm really proud of what the team  has done with Nestlé in helping them take sugar out of their famous range of Nesquik Powder drinks. Nestlé  wanted to significantly reduce the amount of sugar they use in Nesquik without compromising taste. Working  closely with them at both the global and the local level, using our PROMITOR fiber, we were able to provide the  right solutions to reduce sugar by up to 40% in Nesquik products across numerous countries from the UK to  Spain, from Hungary to Chile.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Thirdly, I wanted to take a more active approach to M&A, particularly in the context of strengthening our existing  product platforms and expanding our geographic presence. With that in mind, this morning we announced that we  have extended our relationship with Sweet Green Fields, our stevia partner, by taking a 15% shareholding with a  one-way option to buy the business outright.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Stevia is a key component of our sweetener portfolio and this investment will strengthen our partnership, enhance  our stevia offering, and support Sweet Green Fields' continued expansion and lease development program. This  transaction is the first example of what I intend to be increased M&A activity.

texts.speaker: Anthony Nicholas Seymour Hampton
texts.profession: Chief Executive, Tate & Lyle Plc
texts.text: Actions to deliver this will include simplifying the business, zero-based budgeting, and increasing efficiency in our  end-to-end supply chain. Melissa Law, our new President of Global Operations, who joined us from the oil and  gas industry, is bringing a new and different level of focus to this area. We will use the $100 million of productivity  benefits to reinvest in growing the business sustainably, particularly to serve our customers better and also to  support margin progression.

texts.text: In terms of costs, we benefited from cost reduction actions. I think we can see some benefit from  that in the first half.

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tullett Prebon Plc
texts.text: So the cost reduction actions that we've taken have enabled us to cope with that increased costs that we are  inevitably incurring during this period.

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith
