file: TCAPL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 29July2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tullett Prebon Plc
texts.text: PVM. During the period we announced the proposed acquisition of PVM. It's the leading independent broker of oil  and oil instruments. We're proposing to pay $160 million, of which $112 million will be initial, $48 million over  three years, dependent upon revenue targets. We've tried to keep the earn out targets as simple as we possibly can.

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tullett Prebon Plc
texts.text: Why are we doing it? Increase in scale in energy. Energy is a business that we like for a variety of reasons. We've  shown capability to invest in that area through acquisition in the past, which has worked well. You may recall we  bought the Primex business a while back, which has actually proved to be a pretty good acquisition, and our  management was capable of integrating it. It diversifies our customer base. Clearly, one of the problems that we  face at the moment is the impact of market conditions and regulatory change upon our traditional bank customer  base. The vast majority of clients in the PVM business are not from that area and don't overlap with our existing  customer base.

texts.speaker: Terry C. Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tullett Prebon Plc
texts.text: And it will give us a very significant presence in crude oil and petroleum, which we haven't currently got in our  energy business. It also leads to one other spinoff, we hope, and expect, which is it will enable us just to expand  our data sales business. Unsurprisingly, the areas where we're good at data sales are the places where we're very  strong in products. And clearly at the moment, we're not in crude oil and petroleum and we expect to be so after  this. So we think it will give us a side benefit from that, but a significant one. Completion is basically subject to  FCA change of control approval and other regulatory including competition approvals which we require to  complete it. So we are now purely awaiting them.

file: TCAPL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 28July2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As I said, our revenues were up in every geographic region. PVM, the oil brokerage firm we bought last November,  had a fantastic first half, higher oil trading volumes meant its revenues grew by 35%. And with PVM on board our  Global Energy revenues more than doubled, actually making it our largest product group at the moment.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, we continue to innovate launching TP-AIME, which we announced not long ago, it's a screen-based  matching engine for the alternative secondary market, Knowledge Zone, an online OTC market education tool,  which you can access through TPI, and in the U.S., we established emissions trading capability. And more  traditionally, we expanded our commodities presence in Europe by commencing brokerage of iron ore.

texts.speaker: Paul Richard Mainwaring
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: If you look by product group, as Phiz has said, it shows our revenue from Energy and Commodity products has  more than doubled and that reflects the inclusion of PVM and the high level of the activity in oil markets generally  and to development of our activities in this sector in all three regions.

texts.speaker: Paul Richard Mainwaring
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: The increase in associates and investments reflects the receivable due from the purchases of Unified Energy  Services that will paid to us in installments. And it also reflects our share of our net profits from our joint venture  in China, we will receive a dividend from that business of £1.3 million in the second half.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Firstly, more on today's announcement on the acquisition of MOAB. MOAB specializes in the brokerage of  physical and financial instruments in the energy markets. It has a broad range of products like gasoline, gasoline  blending components, oil product swaps, ethanol and ethanol derivatives, natural gas financial derivatives, crude  oil, distillates, weather and power. Product-wise and geographically, it's a great fit with our existing energy  business PVM and the Tullett Prebon Energy business. And I'm going to get my papers in the right order here.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: MOAB was established in 2003, has a total of 30 staff and is located in Norwalk, Connecticut, which I visited a  couple of times. It has long-standing relationships with major oil companies, gasoline blenders and the oil trading  divisions of investment banks. So it's another all-to-all market, which we like. We calculate that this investment  will generate a return on capital employed equal to roughly twice our cost of capital. We have lock-ins on senior  management and the details of the upfront and the transaction consideration are contained in both press releases.

file: TCAPL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 2August2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Baddeley
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our revenue from Energy and Commodities products has continued to grow, reflecting the inclusion of MOAB,  high levels of activities in the oil markets generally and the development of our activities in this sector in all three  of our main regions. Energy remains the biggest product group by revenue for the Tullett Prebon business.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The global divisions are: Global Brokerage, which comprises the Rates, Credit, FX and Treasury businesses;  Global Energy and Commodities; Information Sales; a new division called Institutional Services; and a new Global  Corporate Services division to efficiently support these separate functions. These divisions will have separate  business plans and leadership and the Tullett Prebon and ICAP brands will continue to directly compete.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Institutional Services incorporates non-bank revenues and was identified in the 10 Arrows strategy we conducted  with McKinsey in 2015 as a key opportunity for the firm. This is a brownfield initiative, which is starting relatively  modestly but one for which we are very ambitious. Now we already deal with corporates and selective institutions.  For example, our Energy and Commodities division operates in a true all-to-all market of the buy-side, sell-side,  producers and consumers.

file: TCAPL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 8August2017 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: In Energy & Commodities in APAC, Tullett Prebon is strong in oil products and precious metals, whereas ICAP is  strong in iron ore and in the Australian energy markets. Australia is now an important center for us. Our Tullett  Prebon-branded Chinese joint venture continued to grow revenue, head count, and profits.

texts.speaker: Andrew Baddeley
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director TP ICAP plc Board, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: However, the investments we've made in oil brokerage market through PVM and MOAB saw oil brokerage, our  largest product in the segment, grow by 10%, which meant that the overall revenue were only £4 million down on  2016, a result that was significantly ahead of the market's experience. Institutional Services benefited from the  inclusion of revenue from Coex under the authorized representative arrangement and accounted for £11 million of  the growth.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: In our Energy & Commodities division, we've built a new product area for the Americas with a new Natural Gas  Liquids desk, which links in with our global Liquefied Petroleum Gas desk in EMEA. We've also expanded our  LNG desk in EMEA. We have a program of marketing and attracting a new customer base by successfully  pitching the funds in a market that has long been all-to-all in nature. A number of commodities asset classes we  cover, such as coal and iron ore, are now mature and large enough to be of interest to them.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: In Energy & Commodities, the two biggest macro factors are the apparent abundant supply of natural gas and oil  from shale rock as an alternative energy source and, as ever, the outlook for the economy of China. Commodities  traders have had a very tough second quarter. Large amounts of liquidity await direction from the outcome of  these variables and we are very well-positioned to efficiently facilitate their movement.

file: TCAPL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 7August2018 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Energy & Commodities is our second largest business. Revenue for the first half were slightly down by 3% to  £167 million. Energy & Communities include oil, power and gas, coal, iron ore, base and precious metal, soft  commodities and renewables. It operates in every major energy center in the world and serves clients including  banks, trading companies, government organizations, corporates and hedge funds.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: We are adding expertise in our Energy & Commodities to deepen and broaden our offering. We are also taking  advantage of our global footprint to improve client coverage. For example, we just started to link our crude oil  desks in Singapore and London, so at the end of the Singapore day, London could take over and they can work  and order for another five hours or so. We therefore improve the likelihood of getting the right outcome for the  clients.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Market conditions in the Energy & Commodities sector are heavily influenced by factors which are unpredictable  and outside our control such as weather, global shipping patterns, economic growth or geopolitical events. The  solid performance of this business is testament to our diversification both by product and geography.

texts.speaker: Robin Stewart
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Energy & Commodities revenue was down 3% to £167 million. Growth in oil, European power and gas and metals  was more than offset by weaker U.S. energy markets and a reduction in coal and iron ore. Institutional Services  grew 6% to £17 million, driven by the strong performance of Coex business and in particular the U.S. desks.

file: TCAPL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 3March2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Executive Committee & Director
texts.text: Okay, Paul. All right. Thanks very much, Paul. So without doubt, the PVM acquisition is the standout operational  results for 2014 and its important on many levels. We closed the deal in November. It brings with it 33 new  product desks, a 130 new specialist brokers and 350 clients. It's a great fit with our existing energy platform and  we were delighted to close the deal in competition with other suitors. It means that 22% of our pro forma revenues  going forward now come from energy and energy-related products and this is an exciting development for Tullett  Prebon.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Executive Committee & Director
texts.text: PVM's main activities are in crude oil and petroleum. Crude oil is one of the world's most actively traded  commodities, if not the number one traded commodity. It has an average daily turnover of more than a 150  million barrels of OTC oil derivatives. It also participates in the biomass and biofuels sector. It has started the  physical and financial broking of coal and the physical options broking of EU carb on. It adds Singapore distillates,  euros and energy-related shipping to the Tullett Prebon Group.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Executive Committee & Director
texts.text: And we're also able to combine Tullett Prebon and PVM Energy datasets to expand the product line in data. And  overtime, there will be further synergies. Put simply, the energy markets are global, and it's [ph] a multiple (25:37)  market, so it's a diversification from our traditional financial sector client base.

file: TCAPL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At the product level, however, it was a year of winners and losers which we've showed in this way here. Energy  bolstered significantly by the acquisition of PVM in November 2014, was clearly our best performing business.  Boosted by unprecedented movements and volatility in the price of oil, Energy & Commodities revenues posted up  102%, reflecting the inclusion of PVM for full year, the benefits of the acquisition MOAB in the U.S., which I'll  touch on in a minute, which we acquired in July and the ongoing development or our Energy businesses across all  three regions.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving onto the operating highlights. There's been a lot of changes in 2015 and the management team and our  employees have responded tremendously. We delivered business as usual to our clients. In July, as I mentioned,  we bought MOAB, a leading independent broker of physical and financial instruments in the energy markets in  the U.S.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: MOAB has expertise in physical gasoline, gasoline blending components, oil product swaps, ethanol, ethanol  derivatives, natural gas financial derivatives, and distillates. MOAB is an excellent fit with our existing crude oil  and energy broking activities. And it's consistent with the strategic aim to build our global energy franchise to be  number one in the world.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Building on PVM's highly regarded energy data assets, Tullett Prebon Information, TPI, deepened its global crude,  refined and middle distillates coverage. TPI also signed exclusive agreements with Numerco to distribute nuclear  fuel data and separately added biofuel, ethanol and palm oil products to its data coverage.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And we've also announced the launch of tpsynrex, a joint venture between Tullett Prebon and Synrex Limited to  develop a new institutional all-to-all real estate trading portal for the issuance and secondary trading of indirect  real estate risk. Finally, we added capabilities in ETFs, iron ore, renewables and environmental energy.

texts.speaker: Paul Richard Mainwaring
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: If we look at the analysis of revenue by product group, it shows the impact that PVM has had on our Energy &  Commodities business, where the revenue has doubled to £204 million. As you will see, the revenue in the  traditional interdealer product groups of Interest Rate Derivatives, Fixed Income and Treasury Products have all  fallen in the year, which reflects the lower level of activity in those markets, which results in the continued  structural pressure on the banks, who are our major customers in those areas and the cyclical pressures from the  further flattening and lowering of yield curves of major currencies.

file: TCAPL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 14March2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Phiz will talk about the macro environment later, but I just want to take this opportunity to give an update on  current trading.

texts.speaker: Andrew Baddeley
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director TP ICAP plc Board, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Energy and Commodities, the acquisition of PVM in 2014 continues to be a big success. The  acquisition of ICAP's Energy business means we filled in some more of the gaps we had in areas like freight,  North American oil, Australian power and iron ore, and strengthened our presence in precious metals, ethanol,  soft commodities and Asia Pacific coal.

texts.speaker: Andrew Baddeley
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director TP ICAP plc Board, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: As I said earlier, Energy and Commodities are now close to 600 employees operating in 33 offices around the  world. Importantly, 87% of revenues, last measured, come from non-banking clients, with corporations and trading  companies being the lion's share. We're the biggest independent energy broker in the world. It's also an area of  technology promise and we're pursuing some interesting innovations for the future. So, we will watch that space.

file: TCAPL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 13March2018 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Now it's worth remembering how different this business is today than when we started this journey in 2015. It is  fundamentally different, and there are a number of reasons for this. Obviously, we dramatically increased our  scale. Not only is TP ICAP now the world's biggest interdealer broker, but it's also the world's largest Energy &  Commodities broker, and the single largest source of independent OTC pricing data creating greater operating  leverage for the group.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: On the real estate front here in the UK, we're finalizing our move to one location in Victoria for our Energy &  Commodities business which we expect to open in the summer. And also this summer, our new U.S.  headquarters in Manhattan. Our new combined UK headquarters will be announced shortly, but most importantly  to our brokers and our customers at the same time, we've continued to provide a leading product while supporting  our separate and competing brands.

texts.speaker: Robin Stewart
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Overall, the business benefited from being well-diversified across both product lines and geographies. Global  Broking was stable year-on-year with a more positive environment for the rates business in the U.S. offset by  challenging conditions in credit markets. I'll take you through a breakdown of the asset classes on the next slide.  As we've told you at our Capital Markets Day in November, Energy & Commodities have a difficult year. Our oil  business delivered an excellent performance, which was more than offset by Power & Commodities. As a result,  overall revenues fell 4%.

texts.speaker: Robin Stewart
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Revenue from Institutional Services doubled, albeit from a small base due to the inclusion of COEX from January.  The acquisition of COEX was completed on the 30th of November.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Our Energy & Commodities division is the world's largest with 20 offices around the world and a coverage of  comprehensive Energy & Commodities products across the three brands we operate, Tullett Prebon, ICAP and  PVM. It actually also has our most diverse customer base with nearly 90% of its revenue coming from non- banking clients. These are commodity producers and consumers, refiners, energy companies, utilities, hedge  funds, asset managers and trading companies. Also interestingly average revenue per broker at TP ICAP is the  highest in this division.

texts.speaker: John P. Phizackerley
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: In 2017 the Coalition Survey of major bank revenue noted that commodities revenues have reached their lowest  levels since 2006, because of ongoing weakness in energy products, low volatility, reduced client activity, and  trading underperformance.

file: TCAPL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 19March2019 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Robin Stewart
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Energy & Commodities was down 1% to £331 million. Oil market revenues were flat, while growth in gas  commodities, renewables, European power and metals was more than offset by the impacts of weaker U.S.  energy markets and challenging market conditions for coal and iron ore.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: Moving now to Energy & Commodities, our second largest business with revenues of £331 million in 2018.  Energy & Commodities include oil, power and gas, coal, iron ore, base and precious metals, as well as soft  commodities. It operates in every major energy center in the world and serves clients including banks, trading  companies, government organizations, corporates and hedge funds.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: During 2018, we have added to bolt-on acquisitions. In January, we acquired SCS, an Energy & Commodities  broker-based in New Jersey. And in November, we acquired Axiom. Axiom specializes in oil, ethanol and physical  grains. Axiom reinforces our presence in Houston where it's headquartered. We now have a core competency of  adding acquisitions to our existing infrastructure. And as the energy broking business is a very fragmented one  particularly in the U.S., we believe we can continue this trend and become the acquirer of choice.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Breteau
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TP ICAP Plc
texts.text: We have also diversified our offer organically in 2018. I think whether derivatives broking and extending the  activities of PVM from oil into gas and power in the U.S. We told you last August that we are investing an  additional £6 million across our three broking businesses in 2019. One initiative that we have prioritized is a  machine learning application that equips brokers with data to improve how they sell to clients.

texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: As communicated in our guidance for 2013 in March this year, we fully expected it a challenging market  environment, and have included in our planning assumptions, potential impacts from the financial uncertainty  associated with sequestration of budgets in the U.S., and continued austerity economics in much of Europe, a s  well as a certain amount of headwind from the ramping down of a couple of Partner business accounts. These  assumptions, both in terms of headwind and opportunities for growth, have been largely confirmed so far.

texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: For 2013, these challenges and drivers, as we've previously communicated, combine in such a way th at growth will  be skewed entirely to the second half of the year. We saw in 2012 a similar effect. However, the skew in 2013 is  expected to be even more pronounced with the first half of the year, and especially Q1, suffering from the  uncertainty of sequestration and the generally slow release of budgets.

texts.profession: Acting Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: As a summary, we face some challenges, but these challenges are related to specific development programs and  are therefore well defined. texts.text: 2013; we'll also be continuing to exploit the commercialization of products that we launched recently into the  market. The first that I would mention is our air displacement liquid handling, which we applied to our EVO  Freedom systems in the second half of last year. We've seen a very good reception to that technology from the  marketplace. And I think now we uniquely positioned that we're the only liquid-handling automation company  that's able to both – offer both liquid displacement and air displacement, which, each offer advantages for  particular applications in the marketplace. texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: We also have a number of other minor product launches during the second half of 2012, particularly some  modules for our detection platforms. It controls the  carbon dioxide and the oxygen; essentially a mini incubator for a particular detection system. And of course, we  will be rolling out a certain number of new products during 2013; relatively small products, but we will wait for  those individual announcements during the course of the year.

texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: So just to recap, the way we think about our organic elements of our strategy for the business; for the Life Science  Business, clear priority, as you saw from one of the 2013 priorities, is to improve significantly our innovation  processes, and make sure we're operating much more efficiency from the R&D spend, and also bringing products

texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: Over the medium-term, beyond 2013, my ambitions for the company are to evolve the business more towards  what I would describe as a total solutions business. At the moment, we're very much focused more on the  instrumentation and a range of, principally, plastic consumables, and what I'd like to see is addressing a broader  range of application, and offering more of the solution to our customers. So clearly, that includes more  consumables and it could well include certain selected reagents. And that would be done on an inorganic basis;  clearly, of course, both of those opportunities offering greater recurring revenues from our business.

texts.speaker: David Roy Martyr
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tecan Group AG
texts.text: The first of our top priorities for 2014 is driving growth in our Life Sciences Business. In Europe and North  America, like others, we already saw the first signs of market recovery in the second half of 2013 with modest  improvements in order rates and customer pipeline activity. Certainly, as we enter 2014, there is much less  funding uncertainty for our customers compared to one year ago when many were dealing with sequestration and  reductions of budgets.

texts.speaker: Martin Thiel

texts.text: So we think capital recycling is an important thing at the moment. And capital recycling is not only a matter of  selling and buying assets. It's also a matter of using equity and debt in different periods and environment. You  remember, in 2013, we bought back convertibles with a high dilution effect. In 2014, we bought back own shares  below NAV at €9.30. And now, we are flexible because our own shares, we can use them for further acquisitions  opportunity. So, for us, it's not only a matter of selling assets. It's also a matter of using equity and debt but we're  talking about capital recycling.

texts.speaker: Martin Thiel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TAG Immobilien AG
texts.text: And on the right side, we've given you some points what we've done there and what was the reason for the  successful asset management. We have strict receivable management to point out. We did a lot for the service quality. But in this case what we have done, we  nearly spend no CapEx. Of course, we did investments and the maintenance. But there were no major CapEx  measures required to get to the successful sale we had in 2014.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Yeah. Thank you, Meera, and good morning to all of you. December, cold temperature outside. India, warm  temperature, both physically and in the marketplace as we could see from the entry movie here. Thank you for  joining in on our presentation after we – for the Indian project after we carry through the auction process just  some weeks ago. It's been quite an eventful year. And today, we want to give you the platform and to present our  ambitions in the Indian market going forward from here.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: Good morning to [audio gap] (14:55 – 15:14) Okay. Let me try. Good morning to all of you. I will try to go through
texts.text: We have also now established a principle that everything in the future which has to do with spectrum would also  be based on auctions. We have also established a principle that in these auctions, you are actually buying  technology-neutral spectrum, which you can use to whatever you want. And it's interesting to see that one of the  smaller players that won five circles in this auction, Videocon are saying that they are not going to use their 1,800  megahertz spectrum for voice. They are going to use it for 4G. I wish them good luck with that but that's  interesting to see how that technology neutrality is actually now enabling you to do more than just additional  voice.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: Good morning to [audio gap] (14:55 – 15:14) Okay. Let me try. Good morning to all of you. I will try to go through
texts.text: It's also interesting to see that the government is trying to level the playing field. They have made it clear that a  900 megahertz refarming auction is now coming up, that's going to happen in the beginning of next year. And  they have taken their opportunity with the situation that the Supreme Court ruling gave to try to clean up all the  regulatory issues that has been floating around for some while.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: Good morning to [audio gap] (14:55 – 15:14) Okay. Let me try. Good morning to all of you. I will try to go through
texts.text: So, this is an example from one of our states, where you see that the green means that this cluster is already now  profitable. And then you see that there are some reds. And what we then do is that we either strengthen the  distribution or we move out some of the base stations because we have the ability to take some of the radio  equipment knowing that we don't own the towers and replace it into areas where we see that we can generate  revenues and better business.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: Good morning to [audio gap] (14:55 – 15:14) Okay. Let me try. Good morning to all of you. I will try to go through
texts.text: And then we do that cluster by cluster until it's green. And when it's green, it's when they have that 20% market  share, then we move into new clusters. And that's the way we have operated and that's the way that machine is  built.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: Good morning to [audio gap] (14:55 – 15:14) Okay. Let me try. Good morning to all of you. I will try to go through
texts.text: For example, that gray half 50% there, that's network rental and it's power basically. So, if you see a cell site is not  yielding any traffic or yielding any result, we are moving that cell site into another area or we shut it down during  night time to save power. So that's the way we can scale the cost according to how the business is going.

texts.text: This kind of decline of the revenues in the fixed-line, of course, put efficiency measures and efficiency  requirements on our [indiscernible] (10:52) organization, and Berit and her team need to address this with the  aim of reducing the cost and implement new ways of completing the work processes. file: TEL - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 30April2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: As we communicated last quarter, we are modernizing our infrastructure with decommissioning of the copper  network. This is to build a future-proof fast-speed [indiscernible] (00:09:22) network for our customers. I'm quite  proud that in the Norwegian management team took the challenge to sunset the copper network much faster than  originally planned. And as we talked about in the last quarter, our aim is then to sunset this within the coming four  years and then to have migrated customers over to mobile and fiber solutions. And currently, the management is  if I can use that word, speed-dating with local authorities to plan for how this is going to work and to make sure  that the timing of decommissioning and introduction of replacement products are coming at the same time.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: In addition, we are now in the progress of improving the operational model for tower infrastructure in Norway, and  we evaluate right now to combine three infrastructure operations here, aiming to improve efficiency related to how  we operate these towers. This is obviously also related to all the work we do on our total tower portfolio globally.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: We see that we're able to reduce several elements. We are reducing continuously now salary and personnel  costs. Operation and maintenance cost is influenced and also other OpEx which are those regulatory cost savings  Thailand. Then these improvements in the quarter is partly offset by higher energy cost for two reason. One is the  larger network in both Thailand and Bangladesh and the second is the devaluation of currency in Pakistan and  Myanmar, which has led to increased fuel prices in local currency. So we know that the OpEx development will  vary from quarter-to-quarter. We continue this strong effort in order to reach 1% to 3% reduction towards 2020  and we still believe there is significant efficiency potential left in the group.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: We started the year with an ambition of breaking the OpEx trend. And I think what we communicated in the  Capital Markets Day was that the OpEx should flatten out this year. So, this is a good start, and we are quite confident then that we now have concrete plans and targets on  how to deliver on this revised guiding.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Christian A. Rostrup
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: In addition, cost reductions were seen in almost all business units this quarter. That is of course also quite  comforting for us with this program. texts.speaker: Jørgen Christian A. Rostrup
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Our cost initiatives are starting to pay off. And we are ahead of the plan for the first phase of our cost cutting. In the first half, Telenor reduced reported OpEx with close to NOK 1 billion,  but this was helped with what we regard as positive currency effects of approximately NOK 0.4 billion. So then in  order to deliver on our new ambition for 2017, the underlying cost reduction have to continue into the second half  of the year.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Christian A. Rostrup
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: And then as Sigve was saying, our midterm ambition to reduce net OpEx from 1% to 3% per year in 2018 to  2020, is maintained.

texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the presentation of Telenor’s Results for the
texts.text: So we see that coming from an EBITDA of 8.2 billion, going down to around 7.9 and India taking  out approximately 1 billion, we were able to compensate approximately 700 million from other  operations, and it’s really Asia that is the strong contributor to that improvement. And of those 800,  it’s DTAC, it contributes about 400 and DiGi about 250 and then Pakistan about 100, which is quite  amazing given the flooding that has occurred in Pakistan.

texts.speaker: Scott Engebrigtsen, Communication Manager
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the presentation of Telenor’s Results for the
texts.text: Then this translates then into the cash flow, which we measure then as EBITDA less CapEx and  we have 23% cash flow margin this quarter compared to 17% in third quarter 2009, and correcting  – looking at the underlying, excluding our greenfield in India, would have been at 29% this quarter.

file: TEL - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 26October2011 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jon Fredrik Baksaas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everyone. And I'm of course very happy to stand here today with this third  quarter results. They come forward very strong; they are solid. They build upon what we have achieved over the  last couple of quarters, I have to say. And once again, I think under quite difficult circumstances in many areas of  the world, the economic area for the time being, we are coming through with some strong results. And we can be  proud that our systems, our people and our companies basically have found their way through this quarter where  competition is tough and where there are growth in some areas of the world and where the growth is being  searched for in other areas of the world. At the same time, we have to think of those countries that have their  practical problems for the time being, primarily thinking of Thailand in this respect, where the water problem, the  flooding is so severe. And it's assumed that it will take weeks before the effects of this has come to its full visibility  and that the society starts to work again.

texts.speaker: Jon Fredrik Baksaas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Financial services is still an important growth element and contributes to 2.5 percentage points of the growth this  quarter. The EBITDA margin improvement of 2 percentage points year-on-year is partly supported by savings  from the energy initiatives implemented by Telenor Pakistan which comes both from better battery backups and  the swap activities that we are now through in towards the end of this year.

file: TEL - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 29October2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard Olav Aa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: OpEx is increasing NOK 146 million. That's mainly related to new sites in India, the 3,000 sites Fredrik talked  about. Those comes in with rent costs and energy costs before we can fill them up with revenues. CapEx side  excluding, Globul & Myanmar is actually a small reduction of NOK 152 million. I  mentioned CapEx was slightly  up, but that's due to CapEx now in Globul on the network swap. And Myanmar, we invested approximately NOK  250 million in Myanmar this quarter on OpEx and CapEx in line with the plans.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also see an improvement on EBITDA. In addition to the revenue growth, we see that from lower energy costs.  And as you know, energy cost is certainly very important part of our operation on – or network cost in Pakistan.  We took a position of giving away free Facebook initially in Pakistan. That we have now [ph] brought (13:52) back  on. So now we are charging their Facebook users. And to our pleasure, we see that the people that used to come in  on the free offer are now willing and able to pay. So again, there are some positive signs on the ability in the mass  market, and willingness to actually pay for the data usage.

file: TEL - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 26October2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jørgen Christian A. Rostrup
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: CapEx was NOK 3.8 billion for the quarter, and the CapEx-to-sales ratio is 12%. The investment activity in the  quarter were lower than we planned for and anticipated. This is primarily due to the heavy flooding in Bangladesh.  I have personally only see some films and picture from that, but it's quite clear to us that we could not carry out  the CapEx program while that flooding and rain situation continued. We also had some rollover to Q4, especially  in Pakistan, for other reasons.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Christian A. Rostrup
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Year-to-date, CapEx is 16% lower than the same period last year. Then bear in mind that we start communicating  on this already at Capital Markets Day. The reason for this being lower, except that we have then some rollover  from third to fourth quarter, is that we had significant investments in mobile networks last year and naturally, are  supposed to come down this quarter. In particular, the greenfield rollout in Myanmar, the intensive 3G investment  program in Bangladesh, and also heavy lifting the major part of network densification in Thailand, which has been  so important for us. So, we expect CapEx to pick up somewhat in fourth quarter, and we maintain our guidance  on the CapEx/sales of 15% to 16% for the full year.

file: TEL - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Efficiency improvements, high on our priority list. We have managed to reduce the cost base year-to-date to NOK  1.3 billion, or 4%. And if I may, this in spite of meeting the tougher – much tougher comparables that we saw  since we had significant reduction from second quarter 2017 onwards. So, we are building on top of the effort that  we did last year.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: And then, on the other side, site rental and also network expansion or site rental and energy related to network  expansion, 50% each on those two elements related to the Asian business and network expansion there.

texts.text: If we then move on to the Central and Eastern Europe region for Telenor, this region also produces  a significant very good margins, but this is done in a very challenging and much more challenging  economic climate than that in the Nordic areas. texts.text: We have also given some mention to 2010. There is, as far as we can see it, signs of market  recovery in Asia. texts.speaker: Scott Engebrigtsen, Communication Manager
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the presentation of Telenor’s Results for the Fourth
texts.text: During second half of 2010, we’ve seen some increase in energy and food prices. However, we do  not believe this to have material impact on our business so far. But, of course, we will cautiously  monitor this situation going forward.

texts.speaker: Scott Engebrigtsen, Communication Manager
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the presentation of Telenor’s Results for the Fourth
texts.text: If we then break down the growth into the various region, it’s very easy to see that Asia, the four  established operation in Asia, is the big contributor to the growth. And, in particular, Thailand and  Malaysia, which has a very good macroeconomic climate these days. But you also see now that  India is starting to contribute significantly to our growth, 1.7 percentage points in the fourth quarter.

file: TEL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 8February2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jon Fredrik Baksaas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Looking forward and reflecting upon Asia's position in the global economy, this is where the optimism continues.  Many factors are feeding into this, of course, both on the positive side and on the negative side, and we have to  watch out for energy prices, potential consequences into food prices and inflation in general. And these are the  parameters that normally impact our operations the most. We solemnly believe, though, that the Asian economies  will basically be the driver of the global economy also for 2012. I think that is a pretty strong conclusion. If there  are conclusions from that was, that's at least one of them.

texts.speaker: Jon Fredrik Baksaas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Then for the top topic that I really mentioned when we started. 14 days ago, when we knew little about what may  come out of Supreme Court, we would have shown this panel with pride. There is a phenomenal operating  performance in Uninor in fourth quarter, and as you can see, we are taking both revenues and we are reducing the  EBITDA loss significantly. I have, though, to say, that there is a one-timer on the EBITDA side of roughly NOK50  million, which has to do with reconciliation of fuel and energy prices in the operation, but still, the operation as it  moves forward with a low-cost focus, with a competitive mindset at street level, being best on basic services, really  has given us figures, facts and figures to talk about when it comes to fourth quarter. Then it is, of course, in the  extreme unfortunate fact that the Supreme Court came out with the ruling only some few days ago. I have to add  that if we take the market share of Uninor in the geography that we have launched, we had in our market share in  that geography of 5.5%, so – and this is according to the trial statistics.

texts.speaker: Richard Olav Aa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Then dtac, it's down NOK178 million, but the underlying performance in dtac is actually NOK80 million better  than last year because we have reduction in currency of NOK80 million, and the revenue share is about NOK170  million reduction on the EBITDA. And also remember, we had a network outage in dtac in December. So I would  say that October and November were very strong months from dtac. I know it will be very, very interesting to see  how we cope with dtac in the first quarter after the network outages and the flooding in Thailand.

file: TEL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 13February2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jon Fredrik Baksaas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Through several severe fires in – incidents in Norway recently, Telenor has again demonstrated its robust network  and strong commitment to local communities in Norway where communication stands out as a very important  infrastructure. In this sense, the 800 megahertz spectrum that we acquired in the auction in December will enable  us to further roll out high-quality nation-wide 4G network over the coming years.

texts.speaker: Richard Olav Aa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Telenor ASA
texts.text: That will have a CapEx effect of around NOK300 million, and also an OpEx effect around NOK300 million,  because we rent towers, and we have to energize the sites. And before we can fill them with customers, they will  have a quick payback time. We will have a negative effect on both EBITDA and CapEx in India.

file: TEL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 11February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard Olav Aa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Before I go into the details on the revenues and EBITDA, some remarks on the currency. The Norwegian kroner  weakened considerably to many of the Asian currencies. And as you know, approximately half of the revenues in  Telenor comes from Asia, which you see on this slide. A sharp drop in the oil price appreciated the value of  currencies in Pakistan, Bangladesh, India, which all are oil-importing countries, and the Norwegian kroner came  under pressure. And this, of course, has a very positive effect on revenues and EBITDA for the group since half of  the group now is positioned in Asia.

texts.speaker: Richard Olav Aa
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: So given the high CapEx, even though we have a solid improvement in EBITDA, the cash flow for the quarter is  down to NOK 3.6 million (sic) [NOK 3.5 billion] (31:35). But I would like to point your attention to the chart  to the  right hand-side there, which is the reconciliation of the cash flow development from 2013 to 2014 for the year as a  whole. And the green box is really important there.

file: TEL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 10February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-16.pdf
TEL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 31January2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: If you look at the – looking at OpEx reduction per business units in 2017, it's good for us to see that we have  achieved that in almost all of our markets. This was one of the ambitions we also had, everybody to participate  and to build up a collective large effort in this area. Telenor Norway continues its cost cutting efforts and deliver a  3% OpEx reductions. Initiative has been implemented both in the fixed part of Telenor Norway's business, as well  in the mobile. And we see several positive effects also from moving to digital channels for sales and for customer  care. Going forward, we will do more within the technology area in Norway.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Then on the efficiency side, as Jørgen also said, historically, we have had an increased OpEx base year-over- year. It has increased around 2% to 3%. When 2017 started, we said that we need to set a stop to that increase  and the plan, when the year started, was to level out the OpEx spending and then start reduction from 2018 and  onwards. Fortunately, we were able to do better than that. The reason for that, I will say, is that we started the  year with aligning the troops, so to speak, aligning the organization around the efficiency agenda, getting their  mindset right, getting their commitment, align the KPIs and the targets, so that we as a group could do something  with this together.

file: TEL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 30January2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: On the OpEx side, the target was to stabilize OpEx in 2017 before we started to take it down and the ambition  was to reduce OpEx in the range of 1% to 3% year-over-year. Looking back, it's encouraging to see that we have  overachieved the target and we have actually delivered more than 3% OpEx reduction in 2017 and 2018. On  CapEx, we have delivered on what we communicated. In total, I'm pleased to see that we actually have done  what we said to do. However, the program we started in 2017 it's – we are just halfway and there is more to be  done.

texts.speaker: Sigve Brekke
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: On costs, both COGs and OpEx, they increased year-on-year with THB 1.7 billion. That explained why the fee  that we paid to TOT on leasing the 2,300 megahertz frequency is explained by increased network costs with that  massive rollout that I explained. And in the quarter, we also had cost related to transition from concession into  license, and those costs you will not see in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Efficiency improvements continues to be a top priority, and we managed to reduce our cost base with NOK 1.2  billion or 3% in 2018. This quarter we see OpEx remaining stable despite having temporarily increased costs  related to transition from concession to license. If you're isolating the OpEx increase in Thailand, we see an OpEx  reduction in the quarter of 1.5%.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: Looking at the full year's reduction, we see a balanced set of numbers across all categories reflecting again our  efforts to work both on simplification and also targeting the more structural OpEx reductions. We communicated  on February 2017 that we expected OpEx reduction in the range of 1% to 3% from 2018 onwards. In both 2017  and 2018, we have been successful in executing on the program. We still believe there is significant potential left.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: In the first two years of our efficiency program, we have managed to reduce OpEx with some NOK 2.6 billion or  more than 3% per year. I believe we can say we are ahead of our plan. Nevertheless, we maintain our ambition, it  remains firm. We aim to continue to deliver 1% to 3% OpEx reduction per year also for 2019 and for 2020. And  we have also started to plan for efficiency improvement also beyond 2020.

texts.speaker: Jørgen C. Arentz Rostrup
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telenor ASA
texts.text: In addition to these structural modernization initiatives, we are also in the process of reviewing our tower  infrastructure assets. This is a project we started mid-2018. We are in an exploratory phase and we will give you  an update as we go. We have around 50,000 owned towers in the Group which of two-thirds are situated in Asia.

texts.speaker: Mats Granryd
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tele2 AB
texts.text: Moving on to regulatory update in Russia, as maybe you are aware, we have had quite a lot of progress on the tech  neutrality, technology neutrality, which is – when we say technology neutrality, we mean that you can use  spectrum to – on any type of technology. You can do 2G, 3G or 4G on any given spectrum. And, of course, for us  this is important to be able to offer 4G service on our 2G 1,800 megahertz spectrum.

texts.speaker: Mats Granryd
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tele2 AB
texts.text: We are expecting a decision, a positive decision, before the end of 2012. And most likely this will coincide then  with the LTE tender or LTE license tender. And that we also think it will happen sometime during 2012. We don't  think it's going to be a decision on tech neutrality before there will be a decision on the tender, LTE tender. But, all  in all, I think that's an encouraging progress on the tech neutrality, it's something that is very important for us.

texts.speaker: Lars Nyberg
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: This is, of course, the environment we are active in. We've talked about the need to change our business model  many times. We are going from minute-based  charging to tier pricing, from voice to data. That's basically the environment we operate in.

file: TELIA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 19April2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Per-Arne Blomquist
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: We continue, of course, to work at our efficiencies, which we have to do, given the pressure on the top line. And  last but not least, we have to continue to work with the sustainability issues that has been under discussion for  quite a while. And I will come back to that later on, and also comment upon this.

texts.speaker: Christian Luiga
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Corporate Control, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: Broadband finally, on the surface, it looks quite bad and we have challenges in broadband revenues. In the first  quarter, it's much lower than it has been in the previous quarters. The biggest impact comes from international  carrier, low margin voice business and also interconnect. We also have an impact of the very cold weather.  Actually, the soil has been very frozen in Sweden for the first quarter, extreme, I would say. And that has impacted  the revenues side and the build-out.

texts.speaker: Christian Luiga
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Corporate Control, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: As I said, EPS is flat. SEK 0.05 comes from the currency effects, and we remain at SEK 0.95. CapEx-to-sale is  10.7%. That is lower than our full year forecast. We still believe we will reach to 14% at this point. One effect is in  broadband in the first quarter, the same as I said before. The extreme cold weather has put a pressure on the build  out of fiber.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: We are continuing to strengthen our corporate governance and our sustainability agenda. file: TELIA - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 21April2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Apr-15.pdf

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had an AGM recently where we published our combined annual and sustainability report, an important step  towards a full integrated report one day and this has been well received. That was very well-received, and we appreciate all the feedback we have gotten. And this gives us  great encouragements to continue the hard work that we're doing in many of these markets to stand up for, for  instance, freedom of expression, but also to improve our governance and compliance across the footprint. And we  issued our second transparency report, which is also part of our freedom of expression ambition to show the  dilemmas that we're facing and talk about it openly.

texts.speaker: Johan Eric Dennelind
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So all in all, we're pleased with the progress. But as always when I talk about our sustainability work, it is a long  journey.

texts.speaker: Christian Carl Peter Luiga
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Corporate Control
texts.text: So the main reason for the EBITDA decrease is the gross margin. On the gross margin, 1 percentage point comes  from equipment. We have some storm costs in Sweden. It's not the big part, but it's SEK 40 million, and we also  have some changes in the fixed side. With the fixed side, it's going down, and that impacts the gross margin. So  those are the three elements to remember on this.

texts.speaker: Christian Carl Peter Luiga
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Corporate Control
texts.text: The fiber rollout is going very well. We had good weather conditions. We have less problem with the supply on the  sub-supplies that we have in this part. We have a 48% for sales on penetration on our sales in the first set and last  year, we had 42%. So we have increased the number of hit rate when we have our sales in fiber this year. So that's  good. We are today having two-thirds of the orders closed on the 5 villas per hour that we are going to deliver this  year. So it feels good. I think, this is all as expected and maybe even a little bit better. And it feels good that we will  deliver on our targets for this year on the fiber.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telia Co. AB
texts.text: Another thing I want to mention in this context is our Younite initiative that we launched during the quarter. Our board stands firmly behind that, and  that we have gained and received a lot of positive feedback on that position. So, hopefully, we can get all  investors to be sustainability investors.

texts.speaker: Johan Eric Dennelind
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Acting Head of Telia Sweden, Telia Co. AB
texts.text: And these are examples of some of the things we do. We have, I must say, a very transparent good annual  report, which is a combined Annual and Sustainability Report. Please read it.

texts.speaker: Christian Carl Peter Luiga
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telia Co. AB
texts.text: The biggest part of the cost program will come from resource cost and COGS. COGS, we see both the cross- border synergies we work on the vendor side and we also work with the network and IT cost. On the resource  cost side, it's the new way of working and it is also how we are becoming more efficient in our operations.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Telia Co. AB
texts.text: And we're not dropping the ball on our strategy. We are integrating the sustainability into our business. texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telia Co. AB

texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Telia Co. AB

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: I'm going to now shift gear a bit and get into a bit of my observations and a bit of wrap -up. I'm going to start with  our sustainability and governance agenda. Needless to say, this is, as I mentioned, part of my initial priorities.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: Thirdly and lastly on this slide is to establish measurable KPIs, well, all KPIs should be measurable, and report  them in this kind of forums and to the key stakeholders that we have. texts.speaker: Johan Eric Dennelind
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: I think we spoke about the sustainability side. We are embedding such sustainability into the way we're working.  And the journey ahead looks very promising and very exciting. But we need to make sure that we strengthen our  competitiveness, where we operate and where we compete, otherwise we will not create long-term sustainable  profits.

texts.speaker: Per-Arne Blomquist
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: If you look at the nine months, I would say that it's a okay result, given the environment that we are living in and  also given sort of the situation that the company has been in for a while. And we're even increasing our EBITDA in local organic terms.

texts.speaker: Per-Arne Blomquist
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: Eurasia, have a good cost control, have initiated quite a lot of initiatives. And it's actually an achievement as such  to have declining costs when they're living in the kind of environment that they do with  the high inflation.

texts.speaker: Per-Arne Blomquist
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, TeliaSonera AB
texts.text: We continue to invest. We have been a bit behind during the first, we'll say, six months. We are now speeding up.  Reason for being a bit behind has been, first, we claim that the weather was a bit too cold and that was partly a  reason. But we have also been much more thorough in the, we'll say, investigation on what we should invest in.  And we have created some kind of delays ourselves, which I think is very sound, not just to have the autopilot  investing in things that we do not need.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telia Co. AB

file: TELIA - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 19October2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Eric Dennelind
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Telia Co. AB
texts.text: A few words then on the fiber. We're speaking a lot about fiber because it is part of our core business going  forward. We're digitalizing Sweden. We're the leading fiber operator. We have not revised our ambitions to  fiberize 1.9 million households. And we are taking our fair share of the market. But the market is affected by two  things. One is a huge demand, still. We're not delivering to the demand out there. Two, it is getting harder and  harder to access the last millions of household – or 100,000 households and we're getting into permit issues. texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: On top of that we also introduced our most premium no frame touch bike carrier for the roof mounting. We have therefore developed a model called Thule UpRide, where you actually grip around the wheels only and  lock the bike securely in position that way and that new model was also introduced at the Eurobike.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB

Maybe if we could move ahead. Yes. Thank you.  And we also introduced the Thule Vital, a series of bike hydration packs with some patented solutions on how you  can make sure that the drinking hose isn't in the way when you're biking fast, easily accessible but at the same  time attaching to the bag. So a lot of nice positive feedback and press around some of our new hiking packs.

file: THULE - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 26October2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: So, when you're best in class, to decide to replace what is already the best in the market is a quite aggressive  decision, but a few years ago, we felt that we could take roof racks to the next level. Roof racks is not a product  which we will launch a new model or a concept every two, three years, which we do in bike carriers and in other  categories. It's a platform technology, which is quite costly developed, and I'm going to get back to that, but it's  also something where the user doesn't get excited by default or in just looking at it. It just needs to work in an  excellent way.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: As I said, we already had the best, yet we have been running the most expensive developing project ever and  that project will, by the way, continue because this is such a large and complex category of roof racks due to the  number and models and types of roofs that there are on the cars around the world, that in actual term, our next- generation roof rack will be launched in three phases. The first phase was in quarter three, when we introduced it  at the fairs, the whole concept, and in next quarter, then this quarter we're now in, Q4, the first two models of the  new generation are started to be sold in stores. Then there are further models for different types of car roofs  hitting in 2019. And then, finally, all the models will have been updated by 2020.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: And for the consumer, what we're offering is a much faster and easier installation of the roof rack on your car roof,  a much easier installation and attachment of various equipment to your roof rack, an increased load capacity and  also a nicer look and feel. So, it is truly setting a completely new standard what roof racks does.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: So, a slight little pipeline depletion and that will be something that will continue without then pipeline fill for some  models and pipeline depletion for some models during 2019, therefore, this is more a launch setting the standard  for why we will be growing with the roof racks in the coming 10 years.

file: THULE - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: And unfortunately as I'm sure at least all the Europeans that are listening in are aware of, we have had a very mild  and late winter. In fact, snowfalls really only started to come here in the last few weeks of January and not in Q4.  And that has resulted in a negative effect of our snow chain sales.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: Then we have Specialty, which is, by far, our smallest segment, but which normally has the big quarter in quarter  four. Already during the road shows in November, we announced the concerns we had about the season coming  from a very low year in 2013-2014 winter. Now going in then to the 2014-2015 winter, unfortunately, as I'm sure  everybody watching any type of skiing sports or wanting to do any type of winter activities in Europe [ph] has  noted (9:10), it was a very mild winter and a very late winter. That meant that it was the weakest year ever, also in  terms of selling season for our snow chain business. And as you can see, we had a significant 36% in constant  currency drop in sales in snow chains.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Thule Group AB
texts.text: I'm happy to say that there finally is some snow in Europe so that in general, we actually started selling a little bit  more snow chains than normally. But it is still a small period now. It is the Q4, which is the crucial one for the  snow chain business.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, if we turn to the next page, we look at operating working capital and operational cash flow. texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look at actual performance then in 2015, it's green across the board, which is always nice to be able to say.  We had a 5.1% constant currency organic growth. And although  it is an ambitious target, there are not that many companies around the world that has a 17% underlying EBIT, it  is, of course, something that – combined with the 5% organic growth, something we are aiming to achieve over the  coming years.

texts.speaker: Jan Magnus Welander
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So let’s go through the next page and that illustrates the situation a little bit more, that’s page 15. texts.text: So we will see nevertheless it’s still a fragile picture for that business. texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Overall, adjusted for seasonality, stabilization across all major product groups that’s what we are  seeing which is not too bad. texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the next page, slide 23, you see what really was achieved in that business area. texts.text: And also the mining equipment is doing well, and especially a success story is the mobile crushing  plants that we’re having. texts.text: The higher losses have primarily one root cause and this is the delay in completion of our coking  plant and also some technical and quality issues. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But what does this mean as batteries or battery A is only running? It means that we have to buy  significantly more coking coal than the original plan, and coking plant is also delivering into our  integrated energy circle and that means there is B and C not running, right now we are not able to  really benefit from the energy – integrated energy circle, it actually mean that we have to buy power  and natural gas.

texts.text: With that let’s go to Steel America. And the customers and       corrected transcript

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that said, go to the next page. And I think that is just underlining and underpinning what  Heinrich has said in case of the coking plant. Because when you look at our guidance that we have  deteriorated for Steel Americas is very clear it is majorly driven by the coking plant on one hand the  repairs that we have and on the other hand slower ramp up that we’re seeing at the moment with a  high consumption of imported coke, which is at the moment on high price levels, as well as a higher  consumption of natural gas.

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Our Plant Technology business was down by €593 million. Here, we are not very much concerned. This is a very  normal behavior in our Plant business. The overall market is good. texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: For the second half of the year, on the Materials side, as you all probably also hear from the market, we have some  encouraging signs on price and volume side. For Steel Americas, we expect a further decline in losses, especially  after we can really add the third [indiscernible] (11:51) battery C of our coking plant, which we believe can have  first contributions from May onwards.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: CapEx management going forward, as we already stated in December, the continued tight CapEx management  will be reflected in the targets for this year.
