We have the peak of the CapEx program for Steel Americas behind us.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Steel Americas. The temporary setback in our sequentially improving underlying performance reflects the  technical difficulties and the overall weak market environment we saw in our fiscal Q1. With cost effects from the  technical difficulties include repair cost for the coking plant especially related to refractory damages in the hot gas  pipes. Only a small impact on the production levels but repair work was very well time consuming, therefore led to  non-production times.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: We had a three-week downtime of blast furnace number one, and outage of the gas turbine which was back in  March. Additionally, we come up with an environment with a negative effect on Q1 results. The revenues per ton  only troughed in December and improved since then, especially in January.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The focus on the coming months for us will be ramping up coke battery C. We expect to first push in April,  finishing all repair works and completing the technical ramp up through to fiscal Q4 bringing down fuel costs  especially working on the fuel rate replacing external by internal coke and increase further the PCI rates and to  successfully manage the certification process.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Components business, ongoing strong demand from our automotive customers and from the engineering  industry, especially construction and equipment. Wind energy, we had a slowdown in China for windmills due to  the empty inflationary measures by the government. The increase in order intake was 4% or €1.8 billion at a stable  sales level of €1.8 billion, so book-to-bill was 1%.  Adjusted EBIT margin went slightly down to 5.9%, mainly by higher development cost in new products, the weak  demand for wind energy in China and the ramp up cost for our new plants in India and China, the special effect  was €66 million, the disposal gain on ASP in Brazil and the healthcare savings in Waupaca were offsetting these  effects on a reported level.

file: TKA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 12February2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The BiC reloaded program at Steel Europe will contribute €500 million to the group's overall €2 billion impact  target until 2015 and is a forceful step reflecting and even better substantiating the new performance ambition  within our strategic way forward. We have delivered on the profit and cash targets in Q1. EBIT adjustment from  continued operation came out at €229 million, which is at the upper end of the announced around €200 million  and all businesses did contribute positively.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Plant Technology started excellently in the new business year with a large petrochemical order for a fertilizer plant  in U.S. exceeding €1 billion. This business is really benefiting from the dynamic development in the U.S.  petrochemical industry and they are further promising at sizable fertilizer projects in the pipeline for the current  fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On the other hand, this program is also reflecting the challenges in the European steel markets where we have a  high and volatile raw material price situation and going forward, I'm not sure how the market in Europe will  develop. Overall, the program had two elements, to identify all opportunities on the market side, but in addition,  as the market most likely remains flat, take all opportunities which we can tackle internally.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: To reflect our much stronger focus on efficient use of capital, we show you on the next picture how our capital  employed will change after the full execution of our portfolio measures. After the sale of Stainless and Steel  Americas, first of all, our capital employed will be reduced to half. And even within this much lower value, the  steel production will be reduced from 60% to only 40%. This is a significant reduction of our balance sheet and  will allow us going forward to show a much better capital efficiency at a much higher likelihood that we turn our  company into a company which is able to generate free cash flow.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: At Components Technology, we have to consider the impact of the divestments, the limited visibility, the lower  utilization rates and all the ramp-up costs for some plants presently built in China and India and also the  increasing competition in our bearing business for wind energy applications. Furthermore, we have a limited  visibility and do expect continued intense competition in our material businesses.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The stable demand overall for replacement equipment, new installations for NF metals compensate the slight  decrease in coal and iron ore growth project. The outlook for cement markets in stable despite the continued  challenging project financing environment.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: With that, I would like to come to our impact program. The performance in Q1 was backed by first efficiency gain  from our impact 2015 program and we announced €2 billion is what we want to achieve over three years, €500  million this year, €750 million in the two other years at 2013-2014 and 2014-2015. Within the first quarter, we've  already realized €80 million out of the savings we announced this year. That means we expect to further ramp up  and a higher run rate for the coming quarters.

file: TKA - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 14February2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-14.pdf

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG

And this is really driven by some first signs of  recovery in the European auto industry and we also see some recovery o n the Chinese wind energy component.

file: TKA - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 13February2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: However, important parameters affecting our business environment have experienced major changes over the  past six months, and since the beginning of our reporting year. The oil price has halved and exchange rates have  significantly shifted. The euro has depreciated sharply against the U.S. dollar.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: From a today's standpoint, the sustainability of these developments and the timing and intensity cannot be fully  calculated. But clearly, from an overall statement, lower energy prices and a declining interest in a fixed rate, in  themselves, should be beneficial for the private consumption, for investments, and for our competitiveness out of  Europe.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So especially, the export-oriented business from Germany in the automotive industry should benefit from the  lower oil price. It should be positive that we have the weak euro, as more than 50% of all cars in Germany are  exported. And above all, 70% of those markets are financed, which again will be driven positively by low interest  rates. So if we add overall, we expect, net, a positive impact on ThyssenKrupp.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Truck markets remain difficult, with the exception of the U.S. The business environment for wind turbines,  especially in China, improved, while construction equipment market remains weak.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the technical side, the interests for fertilizer and polymer plants, especially from U.S., continues. Customers  ask us for plantations, because the gas price is still attractive. Clearly, we do expect that decision-making might be  postponed a little bit, but the funnel is still very active.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In other areas, we could win two bigger orders for electrolysis plants in mid two-digit million range in France and  Cuba. The development in cement is very favorable. We see sustained high demand for cement plants, driven by  infrastructure growth in emerging markets; as well as in North America, driven by low energy prices.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Here we could win a sizeable order to build the most technological advanced and environmental-friendly cement  plant of its kind for McInnis Cement in Canada. On the mining side, it's obvious. We have the ongoing lower  demand for new installations, but the high order backlog and the growing [ph] parts (11:03) of service and repair  business, which should entirely compensate the reduction in new installations.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Here we could win a sizeable order for open-pit handling equipment for coal and limestone in India. The auto  plant business has very good conditions in U.S., Europe and China, as well as a number of project opportunities in  the aerospace industry.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: With the discount rates, especially for pensions in Germany, having gone down quarter-on-quarter by 50 basis  points, the actuarial losses came out at gross €538 million or €374 million after taxes. And we expect them, for the  next quarter, if the environment continues the way it is, to build out even a bit further. But this is a timing issue on  the free cash flow and a non-cash issue on our equity. And therefore, the negative Q1 free cash flow was the full  year expectation but help us to gain back traction on the gearing figures.

Also orders at our automotive production equipment unit increased to new high. Important, looking forward,  there are further big projects in advanced negotiation stage at Industrial Solutions.

texts.text: Y eah. Thank you. The sound development in our capital goods business is compared to weaker materials  performance in the significantly weaker materials environment. Business wise, improvements in cars and wind energy component outweigh  downturn in Components for trucks and construction machinery and market weakness in Brazil.

file: TKA - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 14February2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, demand from the wind sector, in particular in Brazil and India, remains challenging. Orders at  Elevator Technology were up year-on-year with a book-to-bill ratio above 1. And the order backlog at a high level  of €4.9 billion. Overall, growth is driven by new installations and modernization in the U.S. and Canada and  supported by some major projects, in particular in South Korea.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Now, let me jump over to the EBIT. EBIT adjusted is significantly up year-on-year, marking the best start to fiscal  year since the beginning of our strategic way forward. EBIT adjusted of the components business has further  increased year-on-year, reflecting growth, especially in construction equipment components. Despite lower  volumes in wind energy components and adverse FX effects, however, margin is slightly down year-on-year as  ramp-up cost of the new plant, as well as product mix effects diluted margin expansion.

file: TKA - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 12February2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, thyssenkrupp AG
texts.text: Orders at Components Technology were up year-on-year mainly due to growth at industrial components,  benefiting from a big order from the wind energy sector and continued strong demand for construction equipment  components, whereas the market for heavy truck components especially in the U.S. and Europe still growing  although with dwindling growth dynamics.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, thyssenkrupp AG
texts.text: Demand for automotive components is slackening particularly demand slowed down in China and Western  Europe, the later one influenced in part by new test procedures for fuel and electricity consumptions and vehicle  emissions, WLTP, and Brexit uncertainties noticeable with customers, overcompensated growth in the steering  with the start of production at new plant. Despite a lack of big ticket orders at Industrial Solutions, the project  funnel especially for the chemical plant and mining continues to be strong.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, thyssenkrupp AG
texts.text: Market dynamics for chemical plant engineering are improving with promising orders from MENA and the U.S. the  past quarter. Orders included, among others, medium-sized ammonia plant in Saudi Arabia from Ma'aden, and  orders for services in Asia, Africa and Europe, as well as medium-large order for stockyard equipment in Australia  for BHP South Flank with an order value of approximately €150 million.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, thyssenkrupp AG
texts.text: Our discontinued steel operations, including mainly Steel Europe and thyssenkrupp MillServices from the  Materials Services business area came in significantly lower year-over-year. Positive price effects year-over-year  were overshadowed by effects from lost volumes, reflecting logistics constrains on account of low water levels on  the Rhine; shift in demand due to new emission standards, WLTP, in the auto industry. Moreover, the low water  levels resulted in significantly higher cost due to changed transportation logistics.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, thyssenkrupp AG
texts.text: In light of this nervous environment, it's more important to promptly deliver on our performance and efficiency  programs based on our financial year 2021 targets. Specifically at Components Technology, the focus lies on  managing plant ramp-ups, not only to achieve fixed cost dilution especially at our plants in Asia, Mexico, and  Eastern Europe, but also increase the delivery of our new electric powered steering systems. At the same time,  we will fix the operating inefficiencies for all critical steps along the entire value chain with the dedicated internal  teams. On top of that, we've hired an external experienced COO at Springs and Stabilizers.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Both demography and urbanization naturally drive Infrastructure and buildings and just to name a  few of our businesses, this definitely drives positive demand in our Elevator business but also in our  bearing business and undercarriage business, just a few example. And all these trends together,  naturally we see it every day, demand much more resources and energy which again drives  positively of all elements of our plant business and in chemical plants, in raw material exploitation in  minerals, but also once again in our bearing business for mining equipment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now I think to fulfill growing demand, I think this is possible for quite a number of companies. But  what is the specific core competence of ThyssenKrupp? And I have really personally experienced  this when I went through our company in recent months. Where we are extremely strong and strong  for many, many year is really our very specific and outstanding knowledge of engineering in the  fields of material, of mechanical engineering and plant engineering. And with these outstanding and  specific competences, I think we are one of the companies which is able to solve the issues of  more demand in a much better way. Because this is what our society and our political decision  makers want to see not only the more, but the more in a better way and they really drive us by law  and policy making, reduction of CO2 emission is a clear demand on us and also an efficient use of  infrastructure. And, for example, if I just jump on the reduction of CO2 emissions then this through  the way we produce our material. If we compare the CO2 emission per ton of raw material of steel,  then the average exhaust CO2 of our blast furnace is significantly below global average and also  below European average.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: But not only in all our own procedures we can provide measures to produce in a very, very efficient  way but also to our customers and one area, for example, is the cement production. We have a  solution for alternative fuels with reduced CO2 but also NOx and SO2.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And if you look on the efficient use of resources, we can also take an example for white cement.  Here we have a new cooling method which reduce the consumption of water by 40%. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nevertheless, challenge going forward will be that we have to face the massive increase of iron ore  and especially coking coal prices as of April 1st. Therefore, we cannot exclude that it might come to  a temporary margin softness in fiscal Q3.

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Current trading conditions, we continue our ramp-up and stabilize. The start of the coke plant,  battery B, now running at 30% will help to higher self sufficiency in coke supply which was driving  down Q1 and Q2 figures as we had to buy coke at pretty high prices. Therefore, we’re pretty confident that we can make our figures as we’ve planned here. texts.text: And naturally, having €1 billion loss in Steel Americas last year and accumulated loss of more than €500 million  in the first six months, it was obvious that we had to reiterate the strategic rationale which made us decide to  invest in the plant in Brazil and in Alabama. texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: In addition, the change of the iron ore price model and especially the increase from roughly $60 per ton to now a  level of $150 per ton give us some disadvantage to partly integrate steel manufacturers in U.S. On the market side,  we see the reaction of our customers, especially those in automotive arena, extremely positive. They are really  very, very satisfied with the quality, and as I mentioned, of the steel we can produce. So, we have very good  chances that we can achieve some price premium in those end customer segments. But we also have to accept the  fact that now in the ramp-up, the maturity of our volume is sold via service center. And also in qualities where we  are in head-to-head competition with others, those will give a significant pressure on the pricing side.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Starting with Steel Europe, what we see is that quarter-on-quarter, we reduced our inventory by 1.3 million tons, 1  million tons less ore, coal and coke as raw material and 300,000 tons less than finished goods. This did not  completely turn into cash, as some of the – especially, the goods were just sold, but we did not collect the cash, so  we had an increased receivable against it and on the other side, due to the lower volume of inventories, both  payables went down.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Overall, flat carbon steel market is characterized by quite fragile supply-demand balance, surplus capacities are  searching for new and sweet spots. Price development remains unsatisfactory in spite of some spot price  improvement we saw since the trough – end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Steel Americas, overall comment, the improvement in the underlying performance reflects particularly in lower  cost. Technical difficulties in Q1 have been reduced. Now, we have the first push of Coke battery C and we see that  half of Coke battery C is already working at 80% currently. So the ramp-up and the quality and the volumes we see  coming out of battery C is better than we have seen when we ramped up A&B. So we are well on track here.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Having said that, the fuel rate in Q2 was improving, but nevertheless, it's still above 500 kilos per ton and PCI is  still a bit below 100 kilos per ton. So further improvements possible, but we are on track, we are improving  sequentially.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: EBIT expectation for the second half, we expect high pressure still on the prices, as we have to sell to service  centers and there, with the [ph] CRU minus (30:22) logic, so it will be challenging due to the market entry again,  but we will have improvements from a more stable ramp-up overall and Coke battery C will help that the energy  circle and the coke supply and the fuel rate will further improve.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Materials Services, quarter-on-quarter, I think given the environment, we have seen better volume, but better  margin as well. So the result compared to Q1 more than doubled to €90 million EBIT adjusted in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On the bearings business, we have a split picture. Good demand from yellow goods and wind energy. However, in  China, we still see that the temporary slowdown we have seen so far will continue for wind energy a bit longer.  Overall, therefore, quarter-on-quarter adjusted EBIT was up by more than 20% and for the rest of the year, we  expect that we can keep it somehow on these levels. Waupaca has been fine and the divestment, therefore, will  change the picture. After the closing, we will report without Waupaca.

file: TKA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 15May2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: With the start of our Strategic Way Forward, 25% of sales and 50% of capital employed have been already divested  or marked for sale. And the result is that the exposure to the steel production is significantly reduced to less than  40% today and will be below 30% after the sale of Americas.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: We have another opportunity to grow in our Industrial Solutions business, just consider the big ticket order of €1  billion for a fertilizers plant in Q1 or the €350 million cement plants from orders in Indonesia or Thailand booked  in Q2. Cement orders, but definitely even more important, is the contribution of our Capital Goods business on  the earnings side. The contribution from Capital Goods represent 85% of the adjusted EBIT.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The performance overall in Q2 and H1 was backed by our first efficiency gains from our Impact 2015 Program. In  Q2, we have been – we have realized €190 million, bringing the realized efficiency gains in H1 to €270 million, we  more than doubled the Q1 effect in the second quarter. So, we're well in line with our target of €500 million for  this year. Today announced efficiency potential from our ACT Program, €250 million will further substantiate our  overall €2 billion Impact 2015 target.

file: TKA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 13May2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Yeah. Welcome from my side as well. Taking a look at the group orders, in an overall still challenging environment  with very intense price competition, in particular our materials businesses, our cap goods activity is the key  drivers for the underlying growth of group orders and sales in the first half. Overall, orders in the first half  increased to €20.9 billion, up 4% year-on-year as reported and up 6% on a comparable basis, it is adjusted for  M&A and ForEx. Our cap goods activities were growing by a decent 7% on a comparable basis. Highest growth  came from Components Technology, underlying up 15%, reflecting further signs of recovery in European auto and  the Chinese wind energy components.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Fertilizer plant projects are overall taking a breather, but project pipeline for petrochemical plants includes  diverse promising opportunities related to further value-added processing steps, as well as to plan infrastructure  and utilities upgrades. Production systems for the automotive and aerospace industry saw slightly weaker demand  in the first half, but we expect good opportunities in the second. Marine Systems, after the big ticket for two  submarines for Singapore in Q1, sees generally promising demand with a good project pipeline.

file: TKA - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 12May2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the Industrial sides, orders increased, especially for wind turbine components in China. Elevator could lift  orders in a seasonally softer quarter to new record level of €1.9 billion, despite China slowing down to flat unit  growth, with some price pressure driven by stronger competition. Overall, orders increased year-on-year by as  much as 20% benefiting from positive FX effects and strong demand for new installations, especially in the U.S.,  in the Middle East and South Korea.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Clearly, mid-term low oil price and gas prices are providing tailwinds for our petrochemical businesses. Short  term uncertainty and volatility led to late investment decision, notwithstanding high continuing demand and  promising negotiations on planned projects.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The attractive gas prices clearly drives good prospects for fertilizer and polymer plants especially in U.S. In Q2 we  could also win a bigger order, a follow up order for a fertilizer plant in the mid-two digit million range in Hungary.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the cement side, we do see sustained high demand for cement plants driven by infrastructure growth in  emerging markets, as well as low U.S. energy prices. Remember after sizable order to build the most  technologically advanced and environmentally sound cement plant of its kind in Canada in first half year, we  continue to see good prospects for cement plants in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Mining is a slightly different story. Ongoing lower new installations and greenfield demand will not entirely be  [ph] cautioned (7:44) by good level of replacement and service orders, but high order backlog and demand for  more efficient products and solutions, secure a solid performance.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lower energy prices and the declining interest and fixed rate do have a stabilizing effect on private consumption  and are beneficial for the competitiveness of important customers industry in the eurozone. The high order  backlog with good earnings quality at Elev ator and Industrial Solutions already secures our targeted profitable  sales growth well or little close for the full year.

file: TKA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 10May2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Nevertheless, the sharp deterioration of the materials environment clearly left its marks. Our first fiscal half year  clearly captured all of the negative headwinds that had contributed to pushing both steel prices and inventory  levels to a trough. And on the other side, import levels took unsustainable peaks.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Demand for wind energy components is currently normalizing in China. 2015 has been exceptionally strong in  anticipation of expiring incentives. Nevertheless, growth is still available in the offshore and high megawatt  segment. The midterm company specific growth outlook remains highly encouraging, as in particular, the market  feedback on our recently introduced electric power-assisted steering systems continues to be very strong.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: At Industrial Solutions, order's up in the first half benefiting from the strong first quarter, which included entirely  the large cement plant order from Yamama. Q2 lacked big ticket orders and was weaker therefore year-on-year,  but higher order volumes for fertilizers and cement plants in the U.S. and we now are in an advance status.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Components technology. Improvements in car and wind energy components outweigh the downturn components  to trucks and construction machinery and the market weakness in Brazil. In Elevator Technology, we're well on  track with sales growth of 5% in Q2 and 50 basis margin improvements despite the continued difficult market  situation in individual European countries like, for example, France.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Industrial Solutions' strong second quarter with high margin projects and billing phase and the margin at 9.5% in  the reporting quarter, temporarily above the 6% to 7% target range. In contrast to this, all materials BA's down  year-on-year reflecting a highly adverse price environment. Nevertheless, all materials businesses could improve  quarter-on-quarter. Material Services could slightly improve quarter-on-quarter despite even higher windfall  losses which increased from around €30 million in Q1 to around €50 million in Q2.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: At Elevator Technology, we expect to see continued top line growth and margin improvement in line with our full  year targets. At all our materials BA's in Q3, we still expect to be down year-on-year, but up quarter-on-quarter. At  Materials Services, we expect a significant sequential increase as windfall losses fall away. Please keep in mind H1  came in with €80 million of losses of windfall losses.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Steel Europe should benefit from high efficiency gains and volumes closer to prior year levels, with given the lag  effect quarter-on-quarter flattish revenues per ton. Steel Americas should already benefit from – albeit given some  lag effects – only slightly higher revenues per ton. This is slightly diluted by high iron ore cost; and, of course,  ultimately, earnings are still subject to uncertainties regarding the potential ForEx effect on the sales tax asset.

file: TKA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 12May2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The future growth will be fueled by our advanced driving solution, which also will further improve our margin  profile. To highlight very specifically steering, within the next 6 to 8 years, we will generate additionally sales of €8  billion from electric power steering products, the full stream revenue is expected from 2019 onwards. Just to  describe that again in a nutshell, we will see $1 billion of incremental profitable growth in annual sales by 2019  just from electric power steering.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Another major drive will come from our green energy solutions. This includes our RedOx Flow batteries which  offer already state-of-the-art outputs of 20 megawatts and a capacity of 200 megawatt hours.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board and Chief Financial Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: With that, let me start on the outlook for this fiscal year 2016-2017. Following adjustments to our full year forecast  therefore mainly reflect good operating performance, the sale of CSA with Steel Americas not classified as  discontinued operations as well as the recent renewed severe dislocation on the raw material markets especially  for coking coal with temporary effects on the expected costs and net working capital.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board and Chief Financial Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: To clearly say again, when we gave out our guidance and were talking about non-lasting dislocations in the  market, we could not foresee that through Q2 this would maintain the way we currently saw it, iron ore being up in  the high 90s, and the coking coal was coming back. The lag as you can see throughout our P&L and our cash  flow takes quite some time given our contract structure and the logistics being transported over the oc eans and  then produced.

file: TKA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 15May2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, demand from the wind energy sector for bearings, in particular in Germany, Brazil, and India,  remained challenging. Orders at Elevator Technology were down year-on-year. Not only this FX have negative  effects, but we also have to acknowledge that the prior-year quarter marked a new record high due to the large  number of big tickets. For example, we had two [indiscernible] (05:24) in last year.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: EBIT adjusted at the Components business decreased year-on-year, despite growth especially in current  construction equipment components as well as heavy vehicles. Adverse forex effects, raw material cost pressure,  lower volumes in wind energy component, besides customer-induced slower ramp-up in new plants in China,  dragging on earnings.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Corporate costs, as indicated, came further down this quarter, mainly due to lower expenditures for the group  transformation initiatives and the G&A cost reduction that we outlined and clearly communicated last year. We're  ahead of our schedule here. Besides this, it is important contribution for sustainable cost reduction going forward.

file: TKA - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 14May2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Orders at Components Tech are also significantly up year-on-year mainly due to growth at Industrial Components  on the back of continued strong demand from the wind energy sector, as well as for construction equipment and  heavy components. Growth in the steering and camshafts business with a new plant and ramp up was  overcompensated by weak underlying order demand, particularly demand slowdown in China and Western  Europe, the latter one influenced in part by new test procedure for fuel and electricity consumption, and vehicle  emissions WLTP, and Brexit uncertainty noticeable with customers.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Corporate continued its positive trend from the previous quarters further improving its EBIT adjusted year-on-year,  next to the continued focus on G&A cost reductions in that quarter as well as in the region. Results benefited from  positive effect from real estate sales in the low single digit million number. Our key operations including mainly  Steel Europe and thyssenkrupp MillService from Material Service business area came in significantly lower year- on-year on the back of impact from loss volumes reflecting a shift in demand by OEMs amongst others due to  new emission standards in the auto industry.

file: TKA - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 13August2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that, let’s go to page 3. And well, obviously Germany does well. And we have a stronger than  expected recovery of the German economy. And I think that’s very clear and that is mirrored in the  performance of ThyssenKrupp. And you see it here, the German business climate index has  definitely increased. It’s the largest increase since the German reunification. The business situation  has clearly improved and the utilization in Germany now is only slightly below the long-term  average.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that, let’s go to page 4 and page 4 shows the management focus. And I think, well, when you  look at efficiency and you know these are the three pillars we’re working on. Efficiency, projects and  portfolio. And with projects, we talk about the Americas projects. And when you look at efficiency,  well, we have realized quite some cost savings. So we are really on track with all our targets in  case of cost savings. And we have booked last quarter, so in Q3, additional charges to reduce  structural overcapacities at Components Technology, get to that back overall, it’s a charge of minus  €47 million. And cash and cost control is in, let’s say, definitely in our focus whether we have been  so successful, I will explain later on. As I said, there was good and bad.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Projects. The Americas projects saw the commissioning of the blast furnace and the meltshop. The  blast furnace number 1 is running since July 12. The first coil in Alabama has produced since July  31. So well, I think we’re on track. And now, we’re working on the market heavily and that should  pay off. And last but not least, we think we should ramp-up the second blast furnace earlier, now  expected to come into operation at the end of 2010 instead of the end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And when you go on the next page, you see the point efficiency, and the efficiency improvement is  definitely, as I said, developing. After nine months of the fiscal year 2009 and ‘10, we think that  savings, the sustainable savings, have grown to €1.4 billion. So that’s well above our expectations  and I think we are well on track to get to the target of sustainable cost savings of 1.5 to 2 billion in –  fully effective in the full-year 2010-2011. We have increased the sustainable number for these cost  savings by 600 million since the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that, I would like to go to the business area performance on page 16. And on page 16, you  see Steel Europe. And well, as I said with Steel Europe, efficiency gains, higher volumes, higher  average revenues per ton compensate the increasing raw material costs. So we were able to  balance the development, which is definitely better than we expected. So that’s fine.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And well, we have successfully passed on the raw material cost increase. The raw material cost, as  you know, continue to rise due to the lag effect of the new quarterly coal and iron ore contracts. So  it is very clear there is still the risk of limited temporary margin compression, which might occur in  Q4. So we will see what that means to us in case of results. That’s something we have to deal with.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Okay. With that, we’ll go to Stainless Global and Stainless Global certainly is a field of challenges,  of huge challenges. And you see a positive 64 million, which is fine. As I said, the nickel hedging  effect in Q3 was a positive one. You know that we have reported to you that in Q2 the hedging  effect was negative, it was roughly 80. In Q3, it’s a positive one of roughly 50. So I think that’s how  things have changed. Nevertheless, I think we see a significant swing in earnings, which is good.  And we see higher transactions prices here and we see also a partial reversal of the negative nickel  hedging effect.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 6 The current trading conditions, you see that the order intake went a little bit down and that was  certainly due to the nickel price correction that we have seen, that the nickel price went down. And  we have also seen a decrease in alloy surcharges for July and August, the deliveries have been  quite weak here. So let’s see.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that, let’s go to a more substantiated view on page 22. And there you see that the output is still  on a relatively high level. Shipments came down a little bit and I think that underlines once again  that our order backlog was good. So deliveries were on a relatively high level. You see that the  average transaction price per ton went up quite significantly. It was roughly 30 percentage points,  and this was certainly driven by higher alloy surcharges and the base price certainly. So that looks  good. We will see what that wait-and-see of our customers, what that really leads to, but as I have  said, with the rising nickel price, the activity has already started again.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that, I would like to go to page 23, Materials Services. As I’ve said, Materials Services was a  great result in Q3. Significant improvements of volumes and prices due to the continuing economic  recovery and certainly also Q2 is not our most fantastic quarter due to seasonally and weather- affected issues. So, we are seeing definitely the point that it’s a recovery trend in Germany and also  our business at Materials Services is benefiting from this.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We expect seasonally slightly weaker volumes, slightly weaker volumes in Q4, a robust demand  from auto and mechanical engineering customers to continue and we see certainly quarter-on- quarter high – higher flat carbon steel prices. So let’s see what that means for Q4.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The order intake remains solid, as you can see, with 800 million. We see for chemical plants larger  orders to continue from the more stable fertilizer market. And I think overall, a great business is  mining equipment. The order volume exceeds  €300 million and the commissioning of the plant will be in 2012. I think that underpins that also in  Plant Technology we have a great portfolio and that portfolio works fantastically, and we’re  benefiting a lot at the moment from the mining equipment business.

file: TKA - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 12August2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On the execution side of our strategic plans, we are in full execution. I'll give you later some details. On a target  side with our operating performance at first nine months, we are on track to achieve our official target. Naturally,  our environment is not totally favorable given the pricing softness in U.S. [ph] for the market (00:02:42) for steel,  and the development in the capital market. We believe that we clearly have to say to you that we need to consider  a more pronounced wait and see attitude amongst some of our buyers leading some pressure on the spot business  and prices.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Current trading conditions, we are continuing to work on the ramp up and stabilize the coke plant battery and the  integrated energy circle. Battery A is currently running at around 80%, battery B, which started on April 1 – April  22, the first push is currently running at 70%. Battery C will have the first push in spring next year. Steel USA, we  are continuously increasing our production levels and we have progressed start of the [ph] coding (00:23:41) lines  to gradually move into higher value products and customer segment. Galvanizing line number one start at the end  of March, continues annealing line April, the third galvanizing line at the first call on July 15, the fourth line  expected to come on line end of this or early next year.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Moving on to Plant Technology. Order intake here is the highest since Q1 '09 and '10 and could compensate for  the slightly weaker Q2 we had. We have strong order intakes, especially in greenfield projects in Indonesia for  Holcim, capacity increase for our customer Cementos Procenal in Mexico and further cement orders in the  pipeline, mainly in MENA expected to come into force shortly.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: We saw further increasing project activity also from the minerals industry. We saw POLYCOM grinding mill and  material handing plants for copper ore in Peru and a POLYCOM grinding plant in a pellet production line in  Brazil. The smaller orders that are typical for the business overall were on a high level as well. And for our oil sand  mining, we have also a contribution pro rata order intake.

file: TKA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 10August2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Again, we saw a very strong demand from mineral and mining and from the automotive industry. But we saw  some project delays for our chemical plants. But we do believe there are new chances coming up with some new  investments in U.S. We got a request for quotations for new fertilizer plants driven by the extremely low gas prices  from the automotive industry especially in the U.S. This strong demand could compensate some weaker demand  for industrial components business, more specifically for our large bearings business mainly in China.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Excluding these effects, our earnings would have improved despite the fact that our plant furnaces are still not  running with optimum fuel rate and still has a too low PCI share. We clearly, going forward, expect improvement  in Q4 and the quarter coming from the completion of the technical ramp up from the subsequent optimization  phase and also due to the fact that customers like our products and we see clear progress in the certification  progress.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: However, we also have to admit that most of these improvements short and mid-term will be taking off or eaten  up by the challenging market environment which we see right now, because due to the fact that we saw failing  scrap prices, all the steel prices went down significantly in North America. And on the other hand, so far, our  portfolio is not really favorable for us because our share to OEMs and hot premium quality product is still very  low. So the maturity of our volume today goes via service tenders where we see fierce competition.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The other point is that the market demand right now does not allow us that we really ramp up Alabama to the  level that we would really see significant digression effects. So the utilization in Brazil going forward remains flat  at best. We might even take it back a little bit if the market environment overall remains so challenging. So what  you probably will miss going forward is the volume-driven efficiency impact and digression effects.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Plant Technology should remain broadly stable at high level. On CT, I think for your models, it's important to  understand that CT will miss the earnings of Waupaca in Q4 as well as some lower earnings from our bearings  operations in wind energy, as I said, from China. But also in Q4, the tax credit in America will come to an end. So  we do believe that also here we will lose some momentum in the bearings business. Marine Systems overall should  develop roughly at a normalized level. And all this together made us very solid and confident that we could  confirm our overall guidance.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: One is Berco in Components Technology. Berco is a supplier of undercarriages on a just in time business to  earthmoving OEMs. This business has the volume of €500 million with around about 3,000 employees. And the  other thing is our Construction Elements Group at Steel Europe. This is one of Europe's biggest suppliers of  lightweight steel construction elements for roof, floor, wall, and some facade applications with a total sales of  €300 million and around about 800 employees.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Coming to the inventory levels of Steel Europe and Americas in the Materials Services business. As we already  have shown in Q2, we made another progress in Q3. Inventories at Steel Europe are down by 400,000 tonnes;  200,000 are ore, coal and coke, and 200,000 slabs and finished products. After €1.3 million reduction in Q2,  another progress in reducing our inventories and to align with the weaker environment.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Then I want to come to a short outline to what have we reached in our impact program, realizing efficiency  potentials across the group. As we have announced throughout the year, we want to achieve €300 million cost  savings in this program. Out of that, 80% of the targets have already been realized by end of June and we're well  progressing ahead. And what is even more important, we see progress across all business areas. And it's not just  one single project making up for the money, but it's really a huge number of numerous matters we see everywhere  which reflects that we really got the organization and got a mobilizing effect and a high level of acceptance.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: What did we do so far? If you take a look at Steel Europe, Steel Americas, besides the reduction of the working  capital, which we do throughout the Materials businesses, we have short-term work for 2,220 employees starting  in August. We will reduce leased labor. The idling of blast furnace number nine will be there. We will decide  somewhat next year whether it's needed to bring it back in. Cost cutting programs will continue.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On Elevator Technology, we have around 500 employees in Southern Europe, UK and Russia that we reviewed.  Production process optimization like the German factory in Neuhausen and some other cost cutting programs  throughout the group. On Plant, some head count reduction in Thailand, Mexico, Australia. And we have a plant  at Marine Systems more employee flexibilization to cope with that.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Nevertheless, while targeting the benchmark position, we cannot decouple from market with prices remaining  unsatisfied. However, global price levels seemed to have stabilized recently with first successful price increases in  the U.S. The European flat steel market is still influenced by uncertainties despite supply adjustment, but price  pressure is easing in Northern and Southern Europe a bit. General direction of the market and pricing should  become clearer just in September after the holiday time has ended in Europe.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: In the current market portion and environment lacking confidence, we will not restart the re-line blast furnace #9  this year and have introduced short time work at several downstream operations as of August. Overall,  performance in Q4 should be roughly flat versus Q3 of lower volumes and higher average revenues per ton.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Quarter-on-quarter, EBIT was reflecting the strict cost management and that will not just depending on metal  services. So, we could cushion a bit by our well diversified product and customer mix. But we are not depending  on specific material grade or specific industry segment. And our complementing trading and logistics and  processing business was helping here as well. Raw materials trading was affected by lower utilization of  customers. Especially in the steel industry, customers are very careful and price conscious. For Q4, we expect a  rather stable development.

file: TKA - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 13August2013 1230 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Most importantly in a weak market environment, we lift up our performance where we are targeting a cost saving  of €2 billion until 2015 and one important contribution comes from a higher efficiency in our G&A function. We  have recently announced of the so called ACT program, Achieve Change @ ThyssenKrupp. As a consequence of  the reduction is our G&A function, we reduced our work force from around 15,000 to 12,000, but most important  it's not only activity that really shows impac t which is the name of the program. So, we can really measure a  consistent ramp up on the savings with positive corrections, both on the EBIT and free cash flow side.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On our Process Technologies side, we are seeing ongoing demand for fertilizer plants and other petrochemical  technologies in the U.S., driven by the shale gas boom. Resource Technology's side of the picture is a little bit mix.  On the cement side, we continue to profit from the infrastructure growth in Southeast Asia and also some  additional opportunity in the U.S., where all the plants are required to be modernized to follow more strict CO2  emission standard.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: We prepare for the future in those businesses. Therefore, we do also intensify our R&D activities. One example for  this, we recently opened Europe's first multi-purpose fermentation plant to explore new growth prospectives in  the area of bio-chemicals, which are based on renewable raw materials.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On CSA, blast furnace #2 has gone back into operation and is currently in the ramp -up phase with temporarily  increased fuel rate and specific coke consumption. So, we are currently – production level is already up to 5,000  tons a day but still we have to further work on the ramp-up to stabilize it and get the PCI rate down.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Steel USA, it's a continued challenging environment above all in the service center businesses. However, we think  pricing has troughed and auto exposure is increasing. The performance in Q3 and in the first nine months was  backed by our efficiency gains from our Impact Program 2015. The nine months we have already realized €410  million savings, €140 million out of that alone in Q3. So, we're well in line with our full-year target of around  €500 million.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: If we take a bit more look into what we really did at our inventory management, with the examples of our  Materials businesses, we see in Steel Europe, the inventories and the days of inventories on – as well the steel  product as well as the raw materials have gone down in days of that we really need. Quarter -on-quarter  inventories are now close to historical low levels of Q4, 2012 and they are year -on-year down 1.1 million tons.

file: TKA - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 14August2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: In Q3, we achieved additional impact savings of €260 million, giving thus now achievement of €750 million after  three quarters. And therefore, we are confident that we will exceed our impact target for the current fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: If you look on the individual business areas, Components Technology has recorded strong year-on-year gains in  all three quarters and overall, we can see a 30% increase in the first nine months. The demand recovery for  automotive components in Europe continued and the market environment for components for wind turbines  further improved, especially in China. Order intake at Elevator is up 7% year-on-year on a comparable basis,  mainly driven by ongoing strong new installation demand in China, the U.S. and South Korea.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The current order trend at mining is still affected by a very tight customer budgets for new installations, but  largely cautioned by our oil sand business where we do see equipment orders and our growing components and  service business.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The project pipelines for our petrochemical plants includes, promising opportunities still related to fertilizer  plants, but also associated with offside utilities, as well as further value-added processing steps, which we do see  coming forward, for example for polymer plants.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The order intake at our material businesses were really influenced by M&A, specifically the sale of our Tailored  Blanks and up 7% in Q3 versus the prior year quarter, but virtually unchanged on a comparable basis. If you look  at Material Services, we need to consider that the numbers do now include the contributions for VDM and AST  and hence, are up 25% on year-on-year and up 8% on a quarter-on-quarter basis on a reported level. Excluding  VDM and AST however, orders and sales were only on the prior year level, which really reflects changes in our  product mix as well as very, very low prices for old steel and most of the raw material segments.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: At Steel Europe, orders were down by 6% on a year-on-year basis due to the disposal of Tailored Blanks and partly  to the continued [indiscernible] (12:10) steel prices, which we still do see on the European market. On a  comparable basis, orders were up by 1%, as lower prices were broadly compensated by higher volumes.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Steel Europe. Quarter-on-quarter higher EBIT adjusted as weaker shipments from production and logistic  constraints, we had some severe weather impacts not on our assets, but on the railway logistics in Germany, were  more than compensated by a slightly higher average revenue per ton and lower raw material costs, expect quarter- on-quarter significantly lower EBIT adjusted in Q4, not reflecting operational changes but reflecting the normal  seasonality due to the blast furnace number 2 relining, lower production volumes and other maintenance and  repair costs we will have along with the relining of the blast furnace number 2 and less fixed cost dilution and we  have some storm-related lag effects on shipments still as the logistics especially for trains have not been  completely intact, and we will not catch-up all of it, all of the losses in Q4.

file: TKA - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 13August2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We've achieved already €800 million EBIT impact or more than 90% of our full year saving targets after the first  nine months. And this was driving our EBIT adjusted significantly up again on a year-on-year basis for the third  year in a row to well above €500 million, and thus to the highest level in 15 quarters.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Four out of six BAs improved their performance. Apart from IS, which has margins in the target range, but lower  earnings as a result of the mix of completed project milestone, and apart from Americas, they are fighting against  sharp increased price and margin pressure, and the operational performance was slightly distorted by bottlenecks  due to the water shortage in Brazil. All other BAs improved quarter-on-quarter, as well as year-on-year to the  highest level in recent years.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Overall, we clearly watch China very carefully. The intended transition in China to a more consumption driven  economy does not come without frictions. The indirect effect cannot be easily assessed yet, but as CT, SE and MX  export oriented customer groups might be affected. But we believe that the effect today is highly overestimated,  because we should keep in mind that only 4% of the German car production is exported to China.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Now, let me give you an update on the outlook. Sales are expected to grow by a mid single-digit percentage rate.  Organic growth at Elevator and Components, as well as positive EBIT effects will outweigh the price pressure in  the material businesses resulting from lower material price at MX and lower raw material prices in our steel  business. We do believe that the impact out of lower material price and raw material prices is in the range of 2% to  3% on our sales figures.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Therefore, our statement that on a comparable basis, group sales will be roughly level with the prior years, should  include that consideration. This reflects the level shift as I said in raw materials up to 2% to 3% impact.  Notwithstanding, based on the progress in our operating performance and in executing our efficiency measures,  we reiterate all our targets for our key performance indicators, expect significant improvement of EBIT adjusted,  the net income and the free cash flow before divestment and clearly also for ThyssenKrupp value-add, despite the  fact that we had strike cost at AST in Q1, that we have extra hit with some price pressure at our material  businesses, that we too have negative FX effects on our sales tax asset in Brazil, and some bottlenecks at CSA from  the shortage of water, and clearly, despite the fact that we have continued reluctance by customers to decide on  big tickets at IS.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We have figured this year's EBIT targets for IS and AM a bit more cautious reflected the aforementioned big  orders weighing on sales as I said, as well as the sales tax effects and production bottlenecks from the water  shortage in Brazil at CSA, weighing clearly on the underlying operational performance at day end.

texts.text: So Andreas and his team they will not, let's say, wait at all after the success of BiC-reloaded, they are already  working on the next program. So the materials environment after that very adverse pricing in H1 has now turned  more favorable and what is also beneficial that we have reduced in recent years the overall share of our material  exposure.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Industrial components benefit from positive developments for wind power components with improving dynamics in  China, while demand from the Construction and Mining Equipment segment remains weak. The midterm  company's specific growth outlook remains highly encouraging due to the strong customer commitments for our  electric power assisted steering systems.

file: TKA - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 10August2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Based on the comprehensive benchmarking exercise, we identified a corresponding cost reduction target of €400  million over the next three years for these G&A costs. Furthermore, Peter Feldhaus, the new CEO for Industrial  Solution, and his leadership team are accelerating the execution of the transformation program at Industrial  Solutions.

file: TKA - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 9August2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer & Executive Board Member, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Orders in Industrial Solutions were significantly higher year-on-year, exceeding the €1 billion threshold, mainly  driven by an order for a car body manufacturing plant from a German OEM. While on the one hand, we see that  demand in mining is clearly picking up again, while the other hand and as an overall observation, we see that the  number of major projects has recently decreased considerably within certain parts of the portfolio, partly due to  the continued uncertainty regarding investments, for example, in the fertilizer sector and partly due to  overcapacity buildup in the cement market in recent years.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer & Executive Board Member, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: EBIT adjusted for the group was significantly down year-on-year, mainly due to the recognition of around €200  million of additional expenses at IS identified through a comprehensive project analysis and a review of the  budgeted figure in its plant construction and shipbuilding segment. The main negative factors being higher  expected total costs, particularly for a marine project in Turkey, cement plant in Saudi Arabia and a biofuel power  plant in Australia. At the same time, lower sales, a less favorable sales mix and partial underutilization dragged on  earnings at Industrial Solutions.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer & Executive Board Member, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Specifically, for Components Technology, we now expect sales up in the mid-single-digit range and EBIT adjusted  slightly below prior year level due to adverse exchange rate effects, increased material costs and an  underperformance at springs and stabilizers. Nevertheless, like-for-like EBIT adjusted will be above prior year.  For the current quarter, we do not expect any impact from the [ph] WLTP (00:09:35). Nevertheless, we continue  to monitor the environment and stay in close contact with our customers.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer & Executive Board Member, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Specifically, as major projects are awarded less frequently, we need to adjust our EPC resources and set up for  optimal execution of small and medium size project. The aim is to reduce cost and complexity to improve  efficiency, flexibility and quality in order processing and also to shape and industrialize the technology portfolio.  For example, PET recycling, Carbon2Chem, while driving digitalization potential especially in service.

texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On Steel Americas, we have uncertainties on the spot market and as I said, we are the next two years are very  sensitive to spot market, because we still are – only there's a very small portion certified by OAM. But, what's again worth highlighting, that ThyssenKrupp is much more than a steel or materials group.
