file: TKA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 11December2012 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Dec-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: This compares to our Capital Goods business which now represents 75% of the adjusted EBIT, and here we could  only or also here we saw the strong resilience, meaning EBIT went down by only 7%. So despite the fact that we  saw a strong impact in our material related business, we nevertheless did extremely well in comparison to  competitors both for our steel production, but also for our Material Services business.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: I think the explanation or the impact on our capital employed can be seen better on the next slide. When we  started our strategically – the portfolio measures, 60% of our capital employed was actually allocated to steel  production, in Steel Europe, Steel Americas and Inoxum, and only 40% to Capital Goods and Material Services  business. And with our executed actions, first of all, we have nearly halved our capital employed and we have  improved the structure because steel production on a much, much lower basis represents only 40% of the capital  employed.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Very often we talk to you that we will move the reputation of our company, ThyssenKrupp from a steel-making  company to an engineering company. We need to support these by higher expenses, higher spendings in R&D and  you can see that despite the challenging environment, we have increased our R&D spending by 60%, and also for  the running business we are planning to increasing further, not only spending, we clearly want to allocate it to  growth opportunities and differentiation potentials. And we also tackle new areas. As you can see here, for  example, the TechCenter for carbon composites, which we have established very new, we do not believe that, one,  either steel or carbon composite will win. We do believe that going forward we will have intelligent combinations  of both materials. And in order to secure what we are investing, we have also established new processes for our IP  management.  Naturally, it's a little bit challenge that we have to do this fundamental transformation of our company  ThyssenKrupp in an environment which is not giving any tailwind. On the contrary, if you look on the  development of GDP for both years 2012 and 2013, all the information we can take show a downward correction  for nearly all the regions. Clearly, the most severe situation we face in the euro zone and we are very happy that  China and India despite some discussions are continuing to provide growth opportunities on a very, very high- level. But we do not believe that this will change significantly before the unsolved debt crisis in the eurozone is  handled in a convincing manner by our political decision-making.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Head-Internal Auditing, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: At our Components Technology business, we need to consider that we will not anymore have Waupaca. This is  [ph] selled (20:07) and we do face a lower utilization rate for our automotive Component business. Furthermore,  as we are building five factories in China, we will see some ramp out cost and clearly and this was already  comment we gave you in the last three quarters, see an increasing competition in the bearing business for wind  energy applications.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Nonetheless, the order intake remains strong at virtually all our cap goods businesses. Elevator Technologies  continues close to record levels with a high growth rate at new installations in China, up 59% and within the full  financial year complemented by good modernization demand in the Americas and Europe.  Plant Technology could generate its highest quarterly order intake in the last fiscal. Driven by larger orders in  chemical and cement plants, Q4 orders included a cement plant in Mexico, one of the largest orders in several  years was an greenfield turnkey delivery valued around €160 million, bringing overall the order book back to or  close to the record level of 6.6. Book-to-bill in Q4 was 1.2.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: And the new fiscal year started particularly strong as the petrochemical businesses, which was the mega order for  fertilizer plants in the U.S., exceeding €1 billion. We benefit from the dynamic development in the U.S.  petrochemical industry as we are a market leader in the construction of plants for the processing of natural gas,  the central growth driver for the U.S. petrochemical industry. The decline in Components mainly reflect the sale of  Waupaca which was not there for the full fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Different from last year, networking capital released in Q4 2011-2012 was mainly driven by a reduction of  inventories and we expect neither reversal of receivables and payables in Q1 nor the build-up of inventories as we  continue managing inventory very cautiously, especially across all materials related activities. If we take a look at  Steel Europe inventories, we see that in Q4, quarter-on-quarter we were down by 1.3 million tons – 1.1 million  tons ore, coal and coke, so the raw materials, 0.2 million tons on finished goods, year-on-year volumes  significantly reduced by almost 30%.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Controlling & Accounting, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The other 50% of the targeted efficiency gains are distributed to 20% by increase of operational productivity,  around 15% by increase of personnel productivity, for example, increased service business at Elevator with  existing workflows and by 10% by energy saving measures where we have a new energy management system in  place and 5% will come out of the corporate life.

file: TKA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 30November2013 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Dec-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Furthermore, we made progress in group de-risking. We have consequently managed and reduced our legacy risk.  As announced, yesterday we signed the sale of Steel USA to the consortium of ArcelorMittal and Nippon Steel &  Sumitomo for $1.55 billion, in addition with a long-term slab supply contract which delivers a sustainable  perceptive for CSA.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Hence, we do now focus on the operations, performance improvement on the plants, which we also did while we  had the sale process. Our coat plant is now stabilized, the output predictable, all that the [indiscernible] (05:50)  which we have agreed with the authorities is virtually completed. Our blast furnace #2 and gas turbine #11, which  caused some problems during the years have been ramped up and are now running on normal utilization level.  The cash burn is fading. The business cash flow was improved from minus €2.8 billion in 2010 -2011 to minus  €533 million in 2012-2013.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On the impact side, our achievement in fiscal year 2012-2013 goes definitely in the right directions. We committed  for cost savings of €500 million, we have exceeded the target by 20% and this really shows that our leadership  team and our employees are strongly committed and we have a very stringent cash and costs control. For 2013 - 2014, we even target higher impact contributions of around €850 million. So, the total annual saving targets of  2014-2015, which was so far €2 billion was lifted up to €2.3 billion to consider the continuation of our plant in  Brazil.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: On our Resource Technology side, we see some opportunities in Southeast Asia in some infrastructure projects ,  primarily in the cement plant area. And we also see, at least part-wise that we can benefit from an increasing share  in our Service and Repair business which might be a kind of a cushion to the mining business where we do see a  weaker demand due to lower CapEx spending of our customers.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: One of the most promising area is our process technology where we do expect new petrochemical project in the  U.S. driven by the shale gas industry. And we also intensify our R&D activities. We have just opened Europe's first  multipurpose fermentation plant to explore new growth prospectives in the new area of biochemicals. Our top line  development this fiscal year was impacted by portfolio effects primarily on Components Technology and weaker  markets for our Material businesses, however, again cushioned by sales growth at our project and service  businesses within ET and IS.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The overall improvement is driven by continued sequential improvements at Elevator Technology, up by 15%, to  record EBIT adjustment level of €67 5 million, and significantly reduced losses at our Steel Americas operation  with losses roughly halved to €495 million and definitely reflecting the four aforementioned efficiency measures.

file: TKA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 20November2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Group order backlog further increased from a high level to now €24 billion, of which orders in hand at Elevator  and Industrial Solutions totaled to €18 billion, which really forms a very strong base for the targeted profitable  sales growth in these businesses. Moreover, we once again achieved or exceeded the efficiency earnings and debt  reduction targets formulated at the beginning of the last fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Going forward, we clearly see that we need to expect a very mixed picture in the region and sectors, and with the  lowering of forecast over recent weeks, as we do illustrate on the slide, there is a moderate or higher global  economic growth at best overall. So the rising uncertainty over the economic climate and the fact that we do have  only limited visibility especially in our material activities demand that we take a [ph] more (06:00) cautious view  of development in the fiscal year 2014 – 2015.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Light vehicles showed an ongoing positive development in China and in the U.S.; and further recovery from low  levels in Western Europe. Truck market remained weak except for the U.S. Industrial components benefited from  an improved environment for wind turbines especially in China. Construction equipment markets, however,  remained challenging.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Plant have received interest for fertilizers and polymer plants and associated [ph] lot size (11:52), Resource  Technologies sees a stable order development with good cement demand cushioning declining orders at mining.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board
texts.text: Mining. Declining order development since reliable orders for conveyor belts, handling systems and growing  service, maintenance, and components business cannot compensate for declining installation demand and lower  oil sands orders.

file: TKA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 19November2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In addition, customers were reluctant to place orders in view of a volatile and falling oil and raw material prices.  Nevertheless, we won numerous orders in the falling period. Process Technology for [ph] example (08:58)  profited from strong demand for electrolysis plant. Besides larger cement plant contracts, Resource Technology  booked several orders for crusher/belt system.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: System Engineering recorded keen demand for production systems for the auto industry. And Marine Systems  won contracts for two submarines and corvettes. We see further opportunities for follow-up orders for fertilizer  plant in the U.S. We see good, continuous demand for electrolysis plant driven by a channel growth in the  chemical industry and by environmental-driven replacement of old [ph] mercury-first (09:37) plants. And we see  a promising cement pipeline in Middle East.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look on our light vehicle business, we saw ongoing robust demand in U.S. and Western Europe. In China,  the growth, we saw a slowdown in H2, in the second half of the year, in Q4. Brazil showed a weak demand, but we  really have to state that until today, we do not see any negative effects on volumes, on prices, from the Volkswagen  emission crisis. On the – let's say, trucks, the growth in U.S. was overcompensated by weak environment  especially in China and Brazil. On the industrial components side, we saw a strong demand for wind turbines  across China, Brazil and India, but the construction equipment was still weak all over the world.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look on 2015-2016, going forward we expect that further progress on our Strategic Way Forward will again  be reflected overall in our key performance indicators. However, the economic climate has deteriorated and  uncertainties have increased. Our Materials business in particular are exposed to considerable foreign trade risk  because China's growing production surplus is being diverted massively into exports, resulting in regional supply  overhangs and sharply falling prices worldwide. The import pressure on the materials market, especially from  Asia, is a particular concern for us. In view of volatile energy and raw material prices, our customers in plant  engineering continue to be reluctant to award major projects.

file: TKA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24November2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: We do see a clear cycle silver lining but to be clear, we should not confuse cyclic improvements with structural  weaknesses of an industry. The pressure from imports, from raw materials, especially in coking coal, from excess  capacities and from [indiscernible] (03:55) and especially [ph] threatening (3:57) cost increase related to the  European trading scheme remains high. And despite the strong position versus most peers, and great efforts and  achievements from leadership team and our employees, Steel Europe did not earn its cost of capital in the last  fiscal year. That is the reason why we have launched the one steel program and the measures developed will be  implemented step by step.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: The corresponding innovation and sustainability [ph] driven (7:25) growth of our [ph] value (7:25) pipeline  becomes increasingly visible across all our key development areas. Just to give you a few examples. This  includes, for example, technologies for the energy transition. Our redox flow batteries that are based on our years  of experience and strong technology position in chlor-alkali electrolysis.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: They can provide a key to stabilize the electricity grid, which becomes increasingly important as the share of  renewable energies rises constantly. And sustainable mobility, this includes, for example, our new electric   powered steering systems with supplier nominations from all international OEMs worth more than €7 billion over  the product lifecycle. [ph] This (8:13) also include intelligent service offerings. Two examples here, the big data  application MAX, a concept already in successful use to provide predictive maintenance for elevators by  systematically analyzing operating data. Another example from our cross-sector innovation. We have launched  together with most [ph] capable (08:35) industry and research partner the Carbon2Chem project.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: [ph] They are intended (8:42) to convert industrial emissions into valuable chemicals using renewable energies. It  has positive results and gets recognition. This year, we were ranked a world leader in climate protection by CDP  and we're added to the Global Climate A List. This does reflect our consistently high level of performance and  transparency in terms of climate protections.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: This stuff also include a significant improvement in energy efficiencies as well as a comprehensive data model  covering our total carbon footprint from Scope 1 to Scope 3 emission. So, it does mean it includes our suppliers  and also the use base of our products with our customers.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Let me come to the outlook. Going forward, we expect further progress on our strategic way forward will be  reflected overall in our key performance indicators. Our efficiency program, impact, will again be a key driver,  where we target once again €850 million. Furthermore, we assume that the economic effects of the future [ph] call  of (9:58) the USA, the potential weakening of growth in China and the impacts of the Brexit referendum will  remain manageable. In addition, as a general principle, we intend to pass on price increases for raw materials just  like recently seen in the coking coal sector total market. Overall, group EBITDA adjusted will increase to around  €1.7 billion.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Another positive element is our long-term slab supply contract, the queuing of base load, linked to the solid U.S.  steel market environment.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: At Steel Europe, a much better underlying performance is temporarily diluted by the reline of blast furnace B at  our joint venture, HKM, as well as by spillover effects from the production issues we had at the [indiscernible]  (17:04) facility, slowing down the increase of realized prices while we see first effects from higher raw material  costs already reflected in Q1.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: And we have continued to feed our value pipeline by consequent execution of our impact program, by continue  structural growth at components and elevators, by comprehensive transformation programs at Industrial Solutions  and Steel Europe by successfully turning around AST and proactive adjustments and material services, by a  much improved performance and opportunity profile at Steel Americas, by consistently increasing investments  into R&D, digitization and into our climate protection strategy, by consequently executing on our zero-tolerance  compliance policy, and most important, by improving the performance ambition across the entire organization.

file: TKA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 23November2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Within the next six to eight years, we will generate sales of €8 billion from electric power steering products.  Production and customer deliveries are currently ramping up, and will finally lead to about €1 billion in profitable  sales when customers take off their agreed commitments.

texts.speaker: Heinrich Hiesinger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: With MULTI, which we'll see on the Capital Market Day, we developed and presented the world's first rope-less  horizontal vertical elevator, achieving up to 50% higher transport capacity and reducing peak power demand by  as much as 60%, ultimately bringing new possibilities to buildings and city planning.

texts.speaker: Guido Kerkhoff
texts.profession: Member of Executive Board and Chief Financial Officer, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: At Materials Services, we forecast a slight decline in adjusted EBIT given foreseeable low windfall gains; progress  at Steel Europe is dependent on the development of the materials market assuming a continuation of the currently  favorable trading condition could even result in a year-on-year increase in adjusted EBIT.

file: TKA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21November2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Despite this progress, we did not live up to our performance expectations in the past year even though order  intake matched the high prior-year level. Adjusted EBIT was significantly down year-on-year due to significant  headwinds from FX and material costs as well as one-time of more than €350 million on the back of additional  project expenses and industrial solution, risk provisions due to quality issues and components, and production  restrictions in Steel Europe due to low water levels of Rhine and the introduction of WLTP in the automotive  industry.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Generally, robust growth and demand for car components in Western Europe offset declining demand in the U.S.,  while the climate in China became softer towards the end of the fiscal year. Market environment for heavy truck  components are forged crankshafts; and for construction machinery, remained positive. Thanks mainly to the  good situation in the U.S. However, demand for industrial components in the wind energy sector remained weak.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Chemical plant engineering orders were high year-on-year due to a major contract for a chemical complex in  Hungary and a medium-size refinery contract in Germany. However, situation for major projects remains difficult.  Nevertheless, we see a big opportunity for a fertilizer plant from a U.S. customer, who is about to get the financing  for the deal. System Engineering order intake reached a new high, reflecting continuing high demand for  production systems for the automotive industry. Order intake at our materials businesses was high year-on-year,  mainly due to continuing, stable, and high prices on material markets.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Next to the aforementioned risk provisions, lower demand and strong price competition for wind turbine  components, weaker productivity in springs and stabilizers and a flatter start-up curve for the new plants due to  factors on the customer side direct on earnings. In addition, significant currency effects and raw material cost  pressure together amounting to well above €100 million direct on the results not only at Components Technology  but also at Elevator.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: EBIT adjusted in Materials Services came in ahead to the already strong prior-year figure supported by positive  price and volume trend and continued earnings securing measures and a high contribution from ASP. Earnings at  Steel was significantly above strong prior year, however production restrictions also due to the low water levels on  the Rhine and reduced shipments following the introduction of the new emissions standard WLTP in the order  industry, together amounting to about a bit less than €100 million weighted on earnings in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Claus Ehrenbeck
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ThyssenKrupp AG
texts.text: Moreover, the current business units; fertilizers, cement, electrolysis and polymers, and industrial specialties will  be merged into chemical technologies, while the general matrix organization will be simplified by reintegrating the  network of excellence into the business area and business units and rightsizing of regional organizations.

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: The combined ratio of the group has improved by two percentage points, despite the major losses that we have  experienced from the flood and other major events, but as I said earlier, it's being co mpensated by the good  performance of the underlying business, particularly of improved accident year loss ratios. And these apply to the  German motor business, on the personal lines business, as well as on the commercial lines business, because of  premium increases.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: The major loss that we suffered in the second quarter are the European floods, which have hit the group with  €232 million. And as you may recall, we have given you a First Estimate that it will be below €250 million; so we  stay within the guidance. The second major event was a landslide in a copper mine in the United States, which has  cost us €37 .8 million.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: As already mentioned by Mr. Haas, yes, we have suffered from large losses, natural catastrophes in particular, the  first half-year, but this has been partly offset – partly offset, I should say, by a favorable development of the  underlying business, both in terms of sort of new claims that have – that we've – we've seen fewer new claims and  then – and positive run-off results.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: Y eah. As far as the – there is something I should mention; the underlying combined ratio in the non-life business,  of course, has been also affected by the natural catastrophes in the first half-year, but not as much as one probably  would expect. And these [ph] are areas of revenue (21:01) that were not  as affected by the hail and by the floods as other parts of the country.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: Retail International is delivering what it should be delivering, if not more. And this is why we are still very happy  with the acquisition in Poland. texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: As in the rest of the Reinsurance industry, we've seen an expensive second quarter in terms of natural  catastrophes. Mr. Haas already mentioned the figures. This of course, is also sort of an event for Hannover Re as a  – and as a re-insurer. On the other hand, there was an offset, because the underlying normal business developed  nicer than we'd really planned.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: However, I still have to mention and make you aware that this expects that we stay within our capital budget –  large loss budget. And the large loss budget for the rest of 2013 would be slightly below €400 million. I don't want  to hide; and that will be certainly one of your questions that the hail event three weeks ago has already eaten  somewhat in this large loss budget for the second half-year 2013.

file: TLX - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 14August2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: Claims wise, we have to report two noteworthy events. And the one is the Storm Ela that hit parts of France,  Belgium, and particularly Germany, and here, the northern part of the Ruhr valley was affected. That has cost  quite a lot; and an above average development of Industrial Lines losses that mainly occurred in June. Again, I'll  come back to this when I discuss in detail the figures of the Industrial segment.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: On a half-year basis, the combined ratio seen a slight increase of 0.3% up to 96.4%. This is the result of Ela, the  storm. It is the result of the above-average losses in Industrial Lines in June. It is not the result of the below- average losses of the natural catastrophe in the Reinsurance business because this is mainly not reflected in the  figures, and it is also a result of an IAS 8 restatement that I will discuss when I talk to you through the Industrial  Lines.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: Let me spend some seconds on the large loss development. And you see the distribution of what happened in the  first six months 2014. The total large losses, and that would include natural catastrophes as well as manmade  losses, large manmade losses, would amount or amounted to €250 million. If you translate this into an impact on  the combined ratio, we're talking about 4.1% on an average group level. If you look at a segmental level and  divide the Talanx Group into Reinsurance and Primary Insurance, you see that the impact on the Primary  Insurance business has been more significant. Here, we're talking 5.2% and only 3.1% as far as the Reinsurance  business is concerned. Ela, in the aggregate, has cost us some €73 million in the group.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: The gross written premium trend, and you see on page 7 the quarterly distribution of the GWP development. It's  quite interesting if you analyze the figures on a quarterly basis because on a quarterly basis, you will find out that  the business has picked up momentum in the second quarter. The first quarter was somewhat lackluster putting it  mildly. But in Q2, top line momentum has picked up. And that is not only true for the Industrial Lines business. It is  also true for our German Domestic Retail business. I think as far as the non-life business is concerned, I'll come  back to the figures. Otherwise, the seasonal pattern as such is relatively stable.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: Yeah. Let me briefly now talk you through the next slide. And that's 12 and the purpose of this slide is to explain to  you why the Ela biz so to speak has been higher than our market share in the German market. If you look at the –  on the left-hand map of Germany, you find – we've taken this from the Met Office the severity of the storm that hit  Belgium, France and the northern part of Germany and pink and violet that area were the worst areas and red is  pretty bad. The worst hit area was actually northern parts of – the northern part of North Rhine Westphalian  including the Ruhr valley. Now, if you compare this map and look at the sums insured that we've got in our  property business in Retail Germany, you'll find that there are two areas in Germany where we are heavily  exposed and that's the [indiscernible] (00:24:14) region, and that is the northern part of North Rhine Westphalian.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: And if you further then compare our exposure to what the market exposure is and derive a kind of market share of  the exposure, you'll find that the market share in this area is much, much higher, and that's true both in North  Rhine Westphalian as well as for the [indiscernible] (00:24:35) region. Now, why is this? The answer is pretty  simple. I think as far as the non-motor business is concerned, the portfolio of the Retail Non-Life book that we've  got within Retail Germany is very much inherited from the [ph] oil drilling (00:24:53) business.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: And as a rule of thumb, you could say that the best part of the [ph] oil drilling retail (00:25:02) business was done  with, in a radius of 100 kilometers around the Cologne Cathedral. Now, this unfortunately is the area where Ela hit  the country worst. And this is why we've got an above average exposure to Ela. So this is – just putting some  color on the figures.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: Let me now come to a closer look at our investment portfolio. It hasn't structurally changed; you see this on page  17. We continue to be a fixed income investor. Although we've now added a bit more infrastructure, if you look at  the half-year financial report, you'll see that we acquired a wind farm in the second quarter. And if you look at the  events after the end of the reporting period, you would find that we have in the meantime closed another  transaction for another wind park and another area of Germany. So they would probably see a higher exposure to  infrastructure and renewables and stuff like that. This would also be part of the discussion that we will have in  October as part of our investment workshop. So I wouldn't want to discuss all the details here and now.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: And of course, we know that in certain areas, the natural catastrophes have been higher than anticipated. But  bottom line, on a group-wide level, we are still sitting on an allowance of €650 million large loss that are factored  into this calculation. It is true to say that that, of course, it depends where it would hit us in a low tax or a high tax  environment, would be primary or reinsurance business. I think as far as the primary insurance business is  concerned, I personally would say we've had our fair share.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: So – but in the aggregate, we are still very, very sort of confident as far as the – our ability is concerned to digest  large losses, be it natural catastrophes or manmade losses.

file: TLX - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 12August2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-15.pdf
TLX - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 12August2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Now let's move on to the large losses on page six. The summary here shows you that the large losses for the first  six months have increased significantly, particularly the NatCat losses. Whilst last year, we had NatCat losses of  about €92 million, we are now accounting for a charge of €302 million, so €211 million up versus first half year  2015. Largest loss were the wild fires in Alberta, Canada with around €132 million for the group as a whole.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Significantly down, particularly in Industrial Lines, and this is a very pleasing development. The man-made losses,  €78 million less than that we have recorded in 2015. But overall, due to the higher NatCat burden, large losses up  by €132 million to €495 million, which is still in line with the provided NatCat budget of €505 million. But it's not - the difference is not as wide as we have recalled in the first half year 2015. Industrial Lines is pleasing that here  the overall budget has not been exhausted. We are about €12 million below the budget for the year 2016.

texts.speaker: Dr. Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: The combined ratio is not as low as it should be. There are two reasons behind this development explaining the  best part of it, the one is a 1.3 percentage point combined percentage point combined percentage points above  average contribution of NatCat developments, while in the aggregate that's both true for the primary business as  well as the Reinsurance business. We have stayed within the NatCat or the large loss budget. This is not  true for  the German Retail business because, particularly in June, we saw a series of bad weather events that were more  costly than our plan so to speak. So that is the 1.3% excess contribution of NatCat.

texts.speaker: Dr. Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: In terms of our own steering, this is the figure that will also take into account minorities and would also take into  account a more sarcastic modeling of the operational risks. We are talking about 245% as opposed to 253%. Just  in passing, I'd like to mention that none of these figures would include any transitional measures.

file: TLX - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 14August2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Now, you know, the first six months do not necessarily allow to give you a read-through for the whole year, and  you also know that the major part of the U.S. hurricane season is still to come. You know, the predictions are that  the hurricane season will be quite heavy. But on the other hand, the business momentum in the first half-year is  better than we have expected.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Last but not least, you see the green globe on the right part of the page. We have been included now in the  FTSE. Index here is the environmental, and social government's performance medals to us, and we know it also  medals to you, and therefore we are quite happy that we have entered now this important index.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Page 5, an overview of the large losses. As I said, total was very light in the first half year. The overall amount of  large losses that we have suffered is €195 million versus €495 million for the same period last year, i.e. €300  million less. Then, in the previous period, single largest event was the Cyclone Debbie that has hit the Industrial  Lines business as well as Reinsurance with €54 million. The most relevant NatCat in the second half year was the  heavy rains powered by the storm occurring in Germany, man-made losses well within the budget.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: If you turn to page 6, you have here a reflection of the overall large loss budgets and what has been used so far in  the first half year. To give you an indication, if we had not carried forward the unused large loss budget for the  remainder of the year, if we would have let fall that into the bottom line, our bottom line result would have been  about €100 million higher than what we have shown and the total unused large loss budget for the remaining four  and a half months for the year stands now at €900 million. This is certainly a good buffer and should help us to  cater even a more forceful hurricane season than last year.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Brazil is improving and it has to improve in order to make – in order to achieve the objectives for the entire year.  Chile has developed quite nicely both top line and [indiscernible] (24:29) if you allow for the wildfires that we saw  in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Torsten Leue
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, Talanx AG
texts.text: So, coming to our large losses, which is always an important figure in our industry here, especially in our portfolio,  well, we have always this NatCat and the man-made. NatCat was, the first half year, not to be [indiscernible]  (04:16). We have some storm we call Friederike, but this was basically all over – all NatCat claims were just one- third of the large losses, two-thirds came from the man-made. And, here, you see the €100.5 million, which was  the biggest losses we had then in that area, basically accounting for 40% of the total loss we have. And this is  basically driven by a business [indiscernible] (04:38) business by the Fire portfolio we have, and especially in  Germany, where basically, it's a sector [ph] we use burning in America (04:47), all the consequential claims are  hitting other industries like suppliers, especially automotive industry.

texts.speaker: Torsten Leue
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman, Talanx AG
texts.text: So, we have checked the runoff and as well the positive reserve quality proven by Thomas Watson. Now, we  have done it. We have the feedback, everything is normalized here, and we can tell you more about it. But  basically, there's no issue regarding this run-off and the reserve quality.

file: TLX - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 14November2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: On the other hand, however, the first nine months were also characterized by a very significant burden from large  losses, which is to a large extent driven by the very unusual accumulation of natural catastrophes in our home  market, Germany.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: Page 5 shows you the very material loss burden that we have suffered in the nine months and you see that the  increase is significantly, we have here suffered for the group as a whole, €667 million in large losses. Of course,  the flooding in Europe was the most significant event and then followed by the hailstorm Andreas in Germany  which did cost us €119 million and therefore the overall large loss burden impacted the combined ratio with 7.2  percentage points. And you see on the bottom line of the page that last year at the end of the first nine months,  we had just €243 million in large losses.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: And you can particularly see that the primary business was significantly hit by the flooding as well as by the hails  and therefore the large loss budget is far above what we have targeted for 2012. To illustrate the impact of the  natural catastrophes in Germany, let me turn to page 6 which shows you the impact on residential property. This  is market data which we have available and we have it only available on residential property and the statistics go  till August 2013 and you see if we take the average losses for 2002 till 2012 on a normalized level, which it would  equal then 100% then you can see that in the first eight months for 2013, we have already reached a level of  202% and I'm quite certain that Christian will further increase this burden and will make 2013 the most costly  NatCat year in Germany since the beginning of this century.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: So why is it that in Q3, there is more than 20% above what it should be? It is an accumulation of natural  catastrophes, particularly, Germany but not exclusively. And it is a series of more than medium-sized claims,  particularly, in the marine and transport line of business. While the Industrial Lines pursue an internationalization  strategy, I'll come back to this in a second, it is true that we are still very much the German industrial lines  [indiscernible] (00:15:35) and therefore it should not come as a surprise that the unusually high natural  catastrophe burden that we've seen in 2009 and particularly in the third quarter is also associated with an above  average claims burden for the Industrial Lines business.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: On the other hand, it is necessary because within [indiscernible] (00:19:20) premiums there would be a pretty dire  prospect here. On the other hand, we continue to invest in better and more efficient IT and this is the other 50%  balance of this €20 million IT supercharge, we will call it like this. If you deduct the 3% loss ratio, combined ratio  deterioration that is associated with the above average, natural catastrophe that we've seen in Germany, not just  in Industrial Lines but also of course in the retail lines. If you go up to 3%, that means that on a normalized level,  we would manage to keep the below 100% combined ratio target, that is we are writing black figures structurally  in retail non-life business. We have also mentioned here these that these are forecasts that are our events  [indiscernible] (00:20:27) reinforcement of interest driven research.

file: TLX - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 13November2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Supervisory Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: As far as the Industrial Lines business is concerned, you can also take from that chart that the bulk of the large  losses are not coming from natural catastrophes, they are fire and property losses. So they are man-made losses  in the first nine months.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner Celle
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Talanx AG
texts.text: Non-Life Reinsurance, I'm going to make it very briefly. See the main headlines in page 13. On the nine months  basis, the premium is marginally up. This is because Hannover Re continues to pursue very disciplined  underwriting strategies and not so hard market for the [indiscernible] (00:23:59). The large loss budget has not  been exhausted, so they're just sitting on a nice reserve of unused – underutilized natural catastrophe budgets.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Supervisory Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: So [indiscernible] (00:32:58) for the outlook 2014, as always, the [indiscernible] (00:33:04) claim, capital markets,  cats and currencies. For the year – remaining weeks of this year, we have still quite comfortable buffer in respect  to the large loss budget. This is mainly attributable to the Reinsurance segment but also for the primary insurance  we have budgeted for another €40 million in large losses. And this has to be taken into account when it comes to  the group net income of at least €700 million. Of course, until year-end, we will also have to carefully evaluate  what are the consequences of prolonged low interest rate of the environment, what are the consequences that we  see from the German Life Reform Act and all that will have to be taken into account. Nevertheless, as I said, we  are confident that we achieved that target of at least €700 million for 2015.

file: TLX - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 12November2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-15.pdf
TLX - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 15November2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: However, we have to bear in mind that in the fourth quarter we have the burdens from Hurricane Matthew, which  should amount to roughly €100 million. We have the BASF fire loss, which will also make it to the large loss list.  We don't know yet what the burdens will be from the New Zealand earthquake. And, as I said, the buffer is quite  pleasing, therefore, also our confidence in the €750 million that we will want to achieve for 2016.

file: TLX - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 13November2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Nov-17.pdf
TLX - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 12November2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-18.pdf
TLX - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 21March2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: Page 9, gives you a brief summary of the natural catastrophes that hit the group both in primary business and the  reinsurance business during the course of 2012. And as you see, the main event has been Sandy. Sandy  occurred in the fourth quarter and it certainly did not help to improve the combined ratio in this particular quarter. I  think it wouldn't surprise anyone to see that NatCat is still very much dominated by the reinsurance business, yet  given the growth of the industrial business that is one of our strategic ambitions would automatically lead to  growing relative importance of the primary business also when it comes to NatCat exposures.

file: TLX - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 24March2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Supervisory Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: Coming to page 6, you see the overview of the large losses that have affected our group in 2013. The largest loss  as you can see was the flood in Europe in May and June with €175.6 million, followed then by the hailstorm  Andreas in July with a total of €156 million. However, what you should also consider is that the man-made losses  for 2013 have been also quite unusually high particularly on the property side with a total burden of €183.3 million.  Just to give you a flavor of the two most substantial losses here was a landslide in a copper mine in Utah, which  cost us €43.5 million. And the second largest was a fire in a Chinese semiconductor factory in September, which  cost us €29 million.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Supervisory Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: Now, coming to page 8, there we would give you a better insight in how we arrived at the €185 million large loss  budget for 2014. The large loss budget on the primary business is mainly derived out of our internal capital model,  the Talanx Enterprise Risk Model. And here we have made significant progress to model the catastrophes much  better and to evaluate these risks on various confidence levels. You can see that our key natural catastrophe risks  in primary insurance are European risks, and the figures show on a net loss but before tax what the 200-year  event would cost us by the individual events. As I said, the main single risk is European earthquake, and here  particularly, earthquake in Germany in the Rhine Valley.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: Where have we seen the growth? We have seen the growth in hardening German rates, no wonder given what  we have seen in the German insurance market; and we've made additional inroads in France and Italy. If you look  at the combined ratio, the full year has seen 101%. And if you deduct from the 101% the roughly 5% which has  been the bill of natural catastrophes particularly in Germany of slightly more than 5%, it would have taken us right  to what we saw last year.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: I think there is another indicator that is of some importance, and this is the self-retention level. Self-retention level  from an optical point of view has declined, although this is not the full picture. The reason for the optical or  accounting decline is that we had to buy more restatement premiums as a result of the natural catastrophes plus  we've changed the accounting – when it – the reinsurance accountings in the book premium definition.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: As we come on the next page, and that's page 14, to an area that Haas already touched upon, this is the  discussion around reserve levels and run-off results. What you see on this chart is, A, bars that depict the relation  of the run-off results to the profit and premiums plus a ratio of the net reserve level to net premiums level. And  what you can draw from this is that 2013 has not seen an above-average release of the reserves, and as I said, it  has seen an increase of the net reserve level in proportion of the net premium level. So, assuming that we've  made hay despite of the natural catastrophes in Germany by looking at the reserves is just wrong.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Talanx AG
texts.text: Page 21 gives you the details of our GIIPS exposures – exposure, although it may be fair to perhaps drop the one  I, at least for Ireland. We've seen a modest increase as we flagged at the end of our third quarter. Given that the  euro environment had become more benign in our eyes, we have slightly increased our exposure to selected  GIIPS, on each and every one, but with a selection. We have continued to do so in the first quarter of this year but  moderately, very cautiously, with a slight preference for German – for instruments issued under German law and  subject to German jurisdiction because we have seen that if the worse comes to the worst as in the case of  Greece, that provides you with some better protection.

file: TLX - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 23March2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: Turning to page eight, you'll find the large losses that we have experienced in 2014. The largest loss was the storm  Ela that hit in June, Germany, Belgium and some surrounding countries with €105.5 million.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: If you move to page 17, we've again tried to drill down the special effect, the PVFP write -down. Just to give you a  flavor of what we've done. We've actually deconstructed the PVFP calculating units into smaller ones; and this has  enabled us to apply in a net effect, a more rigid PVFP calculation.

texts.speaker: Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Now, the PVFP reduction is not money that we would take away from the shareholder in any way, because here  we're talking about a balance sheet item that would have to be written off any way over the years to come in a  structured fashion. What we've done this year is, we have accelerated the depreciation in order to stabilize future  years profit wise, and that I think is very reasonable way of managing volatility over time.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: So the Group net investment income is now also defined as a floating rate 750 basis points above risk free r ate.  And overall, considering that the environment in the Industrial Lines business, and of course also in the  Reinsurance P&C business has become quite more challenging. We are now forecasting for the next five years,  overall, mid-single digit percentage growth rate per year in our Group net income, and this is based on the  relatively strong 2014 year result.

And that is through both for the primary as well as the reinsurance sector.  The total loss of the Tianjin last stood at €154 million at group level and that was certainly one of the most  significant claims in last fiscal year

texts.speaker: Dr. Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: I think the rest of the entities that you see in this page that is pretty self-explanatory. The fourth quarter has been  fairly benign. That is true for the ordinary course of the business as well as the natural catastrophes. So that  certainly contributed to a pleasing year 2015.

file: TLX - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 20March2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: The largest loss was the – have been the wildfires in Canada, followed then by the Hurricane Matthew in October  2016. And this again, underlines how difficult it is to guide you on the earnings for the respective year. Until the  end of the year, we have to assume that the large loss budget that we have provided for is being used. If,  however, in the last three months of the year, this budget is only used to some extent, this, of course, has a  positive impact on the earnings. Therefore, it's always difficult to give you a more or less precise guidance on the  earnings, we always have to presume that we are using our larger loss budget.

texts.speaker: Dr. Immo Querner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board, Talanx AG
texts.text: Thank you. Welcome also from my side. That's my charge to take you through all the nitty-gritty details. At times, I  perhaps shall allude to some conservative P&L management, so you should be surprised. And I'm particularly  happy to start this year with the Industrial Lines segment given today's weather, which is rainy, I think it's  appropriate to start with the rain-making segment.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Retail Germany, the improvements we have made in our direct distribution capabilities are paying off with a much  better renewal particularly in Auto business than we had last year. What is extremely pleasing is the good start in  our Bancassurance business with still a major improvement in the sales of Biometric and accident products. Also  here, the loss development is unspectacular. We didn't have any major winter storms nor did we have any heavy  winter weather.

texts.speaker: Herbert K. Haas
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Talanx AG
texts.text: Retail International, very good start. The payment growth in these market, particularly in Poland and in Turkey,  they where the markets have turned very hard, is double-digit growth. This is extremely pleasing.
