file: TOM - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 26April2012 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If you look at our logo, it says TOMRA transforms. With transforms we mean that we can contribute and  transform to a better world, that we can transform a world that is getting increasingly scarcer resources, a world  that needs to focus more on environmental and resources productivity. But also transform in an internal context  that we are taking new ways and operate them in new frames.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let's take a step into Collection Solutions. It was a unique, warm quarter, especially North America. On the  bottom of this page, you can see some maps of the North American or United States overview. The colors indicate  that the redder they are, the warmer it is compared to normal temperatures. So you can see January had warmer,  but no so exceptional. February had a little bit more warmer on the East Coast, and March was exceptionally  warm with this big red area.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And our business is affected by this because warmer weather means that people drink more beverages. Beverages  are then returned in high volumes to our machines and through our operations, and that drives both our revenues  and profitability. And that is also one of the explanations for the good results we had especially in North America.  But overall, measured on local currencies, we had a slight growth, 2%. So we can say it was a stable quarter.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Europe, it was somewhat slower, but it was fully then compensated through the higher activities in United  States, which were partly driven by the warm weather I talked about, but also partly by higher activities in terms  of high machine placements.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Particularly strong momentum we can see in the recycling sector and in the food sector. The mining goes a bit up  and down. It is a small start-up business for us and it's effective with whether we get bigger projects or not in a  quarter and it can change the landscape. It's something we are not worried about. It is the character of a start-up  business.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The challenge today in the mining sector and sorting applications is that the mining environment, they process  huge volumes. A copper mine or an iron ore mine process tens of thousands of tonnes per hour. Our sorters, what  we have today, they are ranging up maybe 100 to 300 tonnes per hour. And you can imagine that is not in the  scale what you need for operate in such an environment. We have thousands of tonnes per hour. So the objective  with this project, which Rio Tinto has asked us to work with them on is to develop a sorter that can take 1,000  tonnes per hour.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And just if you imagine that in the current scenario where we have sorters that take between 100 and 300 tonnes  per hour, we can identify with our sensors and our processing equipment up to 40,000 objects every second.  Identify them and then take a decision in a very short period of time, whether this should be sorted in or sorted  out. Now, we are talking the scaling of that in a factor 4, 5. And of course, that is a huge opportunity for us but also  huge challenge.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Europe, you have quite strong regulations when it comes to packaging waste initiative. So the recycling targets.  And you can always argue with it, is it the market drive or is it regulatory drive. In the U.S., you have less of this.  It's the pure commercial drive behind that. The market's interest in getting hold of commodities both in metals,  but also in various waste types.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Of course, we always need to be reminded. We have certain effects of seasonality as I mentioned before. I think  nothing to worry about there. But we also are aware of that sensitivity of this sector to the cyclicality of the  industry. Would there be sharp changes in commodity prices? Would there be a sharp change in the environment  or the economical climate? We would certainly see that. But as we can, at this point in time, look at the situation,  we believe there would be a continuous good momentum in the business.

file: TOM - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 23April2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: We are, however, navigating in a more complex and macroeconomic climate. So I will elaborate a little bit more on  that. But I'm pleased to announce that we are on track with what we had anticipated.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: We have a high content of service in the business. About 50% of the revenue is stemming from service. We have a  cost reduction program running where we have stated that we want to reduce our cost of goods sold for new  products by 40% in five years. We are mid-term in that and we are performing on that. So I would say the business  is very much following on track.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: And when we reported last year about the first quarter, we showed you curves about how exceptionally warm the  weather had been in North America in that period. This winter was not as warm. We had the storm Sandy  affecting North America. And people tend to drink less when it's colder and they tend to drink more when it's  warmer and it affects the volume.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: We see, overall, a slight reduction in the consumption of soft drinks and beverages in United States. So long-term,  there has been a decrease. But we have seen that TOMRA has been able to stay fairly robust in that landscape. So  it's more of a seasonality. I would say weather-driven swings we experienced here. So, fairly stable situation in  that regard.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Let me then turn page and talk about TOMRA Sorting Solutions. On the macro picture, this is a fantastic business.  We have some, more than 10,000 sorters now out in the world, performing a strong duty for our customers and  for the environment.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Every year, we deliver more than 1,000 new sorters and they serve our customers in the food, in the recycling and  in the mining segment. Since the acquisition of BEST last year, we have now carved out a leadership position in  the food sorting as well, so the combination is that we're leader in recycling, in mining and in food.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling is traditionally very important for us and remains a very important part, especially since recycling has  higher gross margin and higher earnings levels. Recycling has been a little bit less visible in the quarter. We have  experienced a bit slower pace here, especially in the metal side. We had a strong Q4 out revenue performance in  recycling. So in the [ph] context (13:08) of Q4 – in Q1 now, a little bit less recycling.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling is an area where we still are a little bit cautious about outlook. We remain cautious about outlook. We  mentioned that in the last report that we had a cautiousness about it and we cannot say that this has rebounded.  So we still remain a little bit cautious when it comes to recycling, especially metals recycling, which is the smallest  part of the recycling business, but here we haven't seen a turnaround on that side.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: We did also divest a very small part of the portfolio, which is the freezing and chilling business. It is a business  that we got with the acquisition of Odenberg and it has an annual revenue of about €7 million and it was divested  as a management buyout, has no other effect on profit and loss. It was more engineering type of business, did not  fit into the TOMRA portfolio. So we're pleased with that development.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: A very positive recent development is in the, what we call process analytics. This is an own development in  TOMRA, which we started in 2005, in the TOMRA Sorting Solutions area, with the know-how on optical sensors.  We started looking into, could we analyze the content of seafood? Could we see with a sensor what is the water  content or the fat content or the specific colors of a salmon? Could we see how much does a crab contain of meat?  And the answer was yes. So we found applications for the seafood industry where we can actually do exactly what I  pointed out here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: We have sold some 30 to 35 machines in the meat industry alone. And what we do here is to help the meat  processors produce a specific grade of, for instance, minced meat. So assume you would like to have a fat content  of X percent, we can help them doing that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: When it comes to Sorting Solutions, a more complex landscape. Here we are active in more markets. We are in  about 85 markets. We're acting in different sectors: recycling, mining and food, with a different seasonality and  dynamics in itself and we are affected by different drivers in industry. So, let us go sector by sector.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling is a little bit more tricky to give a prediction on. And we already stated that in the last quarter outlook.  We do have metals recycling, which is very low right now. And we don't see any change here. So that is very much  driven by commodity prices there, not dramatically low, but the industry is uncertain about that, and the  willingness to invest in metals recycling has been seen as more slow here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: Waste recycling is a more stable business. We are working on some less macro-driven infrastructure project, let's  say, MSW, municipal solid waste, which is more politically-driven, where countries invest in their infrastructure  to treat waste. Here we have a strong position, that is performing better.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: But then you have the other scale on the waste recycling, which might be small plastics pellets-producing, sorting  plastic pellets or aluminum flakes, for that matter, and here they might be swinging more. So we have a more  mixed picture.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, TOMRA Systems ASA
texts.text: It's difficult for me to tell you in honest exactly where it will go. We would probably expect that the business would  perform fairly stable, even though there is a lot of potential out there. We see a lot of requests for quotations and  we do have a positive belief in the pipeline of projects. But I would very much like to see the release of the energy  here before we start talking about really a rebound. So that's very much macro-driven.

file: TOM - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 24April2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Looking into the quarter, we had a good activity level in the Nordic region, also a stable activity in North America.  However, we had strong weather conditions or strong bad weather conditions with freezing temperatures, which  normally brings the volumes of beverage consumption down, which we also experienced this year.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Blizzard is a leading technology with pulse LED for timing of instant quick freeze and vegetables. The Falcon  is dedicated for lettuce. The Nimbus BSI is, in a way, a revolutionary technology because here you really go down  and look at the chemical composition of the products, enabling us to do a world-class sorting in IQF fruit,  vegetables, nuts and dried fruit. Modus is specifically designed for carrots and potatoes. And the Sentinel is for  whole fruits and vegetables.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We should, however, in this context, not forget the important recycling business and the mining business. And  here you can also see the new Finder solution for metals, where TOMRA traditionally has been a clear market  leader and we, of course, intend to maintain this leadership position.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Recycling has complete different characteristics. It's a project-based business. We are serving customers in areas  such as metals recycling, plastics recycling, and recycling of household waste products.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The two first areas I mentioned, metals recycling and plastics recycling, are strongly exposed to the commodity  pricing situation. We have experienced for actually a longer period already now that the metals recycling market  has been somewhat weaker, and we have not seen any change in that. That continues to be our view on that  marketplace.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With the recent strong changes in oil price, you know that for plastic, the alternative of recycled plastic would be  to have virgin plastic, and that is mostly based on an oil petroleum product. And with this drastic drop we have  seen from something like $115 just some six months, seven months ago down to estimated $60, $65 now, we  asked ourselves what is the impact on that on our business landscape.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We do assess that the PET recycling sector is rather exposed here, and some other plastics might be more resilient  to these exposures. But that is an area where we are a bit cautious, especially now looking forward here, what will  be the impact on the drastic changes in oil price on the plastic recycling, so there is an area of caution.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But also looking into the household waste sector, which is important here and most fast-growing area, we  continue to see good amounts, and here TOMRA is absolutely favorably positioned. When you think of household  waste, you have a broad array of products to be sorted, everything from organic material into plastics, could be  metals, paper, a very broad spectrum. And our broad technology actually makes us unique in this situation.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the light of fast-growing large cities where you have high concentration of people in few places, you can imagine  that there is a significant waste generation in these places, and that also then drives the needs for waste treatment  plants close to these major cities. And here, of course, going more and more into taking care of the resources being  disposed off and, hence, the need for automated sorting.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And here we offer a very strong alternative for them because our sorters enables the mining companies to go into a  dry and less energy-intense kind of separation. And we are, by using different sensors, enabling the miners to  extract the valuable minerals from the waste minerals and doing that in a smart way.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Recycling, a bit more mixed when I look into the market situation. I repeat metals and certain parts of the plastics  recycling are affected by the commodity prices. Why? We see that the household waste is still strong and very  important sector, both today and in the future. And mining, despite the gloomy picture of the mining sector, there  is a need for solutions that offer a lower cost preposition and that's exactly what we can do, helping the mining  companies, reducing the energy demand, energy consumption, the water consumption, and increasing both the  productivity and profitability by reducing the cost. So again, I think it is working well. The combination of what –  where we are and this mixture actually of our activity levels, both in food recycling and mining makes us stronger  than we were in the past, because we now also have a better strength in the cyclical times.

file: TOM - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 26April2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we look into these megatrends, they will drive some important changes to the world. And some of them include  that we will need to produce so much more food than today. Some people guess that, by 2050, we will need some  50% to 7 0% more food resources than we do today to feed the hunger of the world. We will also need a lot of steel,  concrete, aluminum and other minerals to satisfy the need to build urban living spaces. We think that TOMRA is  well positioned to support these megatrends. And in the long run, we are continuing to invest in our sensor  technologies that will support resource productivity.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I recently met a big customer of ours who is producing almonds. And what I was told is that when they get the raw  material, meaning the almonds, into their facility, they might have some 4 to 6 defects per kilogram of – or two  counts of material. And our task then would be to remove these foreign materials. This could be stems, leaves,  small stones, and other kind of foreign material.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And the result they have, steadily now, they're measuring that, of course, very care fully, is that they are having at  the end of the line after a number of sorting steps, they're having one defect in 4,000 tons. And if you were to  calculate that in PPMs, you will come to very, very low levels because you would have to see how many almonds   are there in 1 ton, and then see the number of one defect in all the almonds you would find in 4,000 tons.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The food makes out about 60% of the Sorting Solutions. If I go to the second business, which is recycling, here we  have a more mixed picture. We have a business that many of our customers are competing with recycled material s  against virgin material. If you take plastic, for instance, the alternative of a recycled PET would be to produce the  PET out of oil [indiscernible] (23:53). And as the oil price has gone down so dramatically in a rather short period  of time, and as we see this volatility which we experienced here, it causes uncertainties in the marketplace.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The same you can say for the metal – recycled metal processor will face the same challenges. So, getting  aluminum, if the aluminum market price or commodity price are low, they would be very challenged. They are  really competing against in a commodity index like in LME. And they do not have the same flexibility to change  their cost situation as we can experience that the commodity prices are changing.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, these parts of the sector, of the recycling sector, are under pressure. However, there are also here parts of the  recycling business that is more robust. And here we talk about markets that are regulated where, for instance, a  geographic area like the European Union might put up recycling requirements for their member states. And to  meet this, they need to invest in modern equipment and in order to create clear fractions that are ultimately able  to be recycled, they will need the sorters.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And in those markets, we see good development. We further see as a result of the megatrends, and here thinking  about rapid development of new cities, we also see in those sectors good development of sorting municipal and  solid waste.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, in summary, robust technologies, very meaningful applications driving food quality, enabling reduce of  recyclable materials and finding, in this case, very – valuable gemstones is what we are doing. And we have a good  mixture of the business now especially thanks to the food element which we have build up since 2012. So, the  portfolio mix is helping also here.

file: TOM - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 28April2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And if I look into these businesses, we've had – as we, in last year, had a bit slower order intake in recycling, we  see a margin dilution effect here. We have less revenues from recycling, more from food. Recycling, traditionally  has higher margin structures, and by that, you get to dilution. So, we have a margin dilution by the mix effect and  we also have about 1% margin dilution as a result of Compac, which we will need to get used to, because  Compac has a lower margin and we'll, so to say, be institutionalized in our lower margins going forward until we  can lift the margins in Compac on a more steady basis, but that would take some time.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Almonds are [ph] water – they are (14:27) depending on water for the growth. California has had a almost five- year period of drought, and in this winter, they had strong, good rainfalls, and again, that is bringing the whole  sector alive. So, on the food side, both on the processing side, which I talk about the traditional Tomra Sorting  Solutions, what we also label as bulk sorting, but also on the fresh fruit, which we are now entering with the lane  sorting and Compac, we have [audio gap] (15:04) momentum in the marketplace. Both units performing well in  terms of order intake.

file: TOM - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 25April2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: It's nice to see that TOMRA is in a good marketplace. We are seeing growth aspects in many dimensions. We see  improved or increased focus on environmental methods. We see need in the industry to increase productivity, to  increase quality and to enable high consistency. And these are actions and these are needs, which we can meet  with our sensor-based solutions.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: New South Wales, we started go live December 1 in 2017, so it's only some four months away. Till to-date we  have collected more than 250 million objects. Remember the authorities in New South Wales introduced a system  in order to reduce littering. And they are very concerned of course about marine littering and sensitive ecosystems  around the Australia coast and globally.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, they put up a target to reduce littering by 40%. And with that, collecting volumes through our automated and  manual Collection Solutions is our answer to that. So, 250 million – more than 250 million objects, bottles and  cans have been collected until today. And we are pleased with that development. In fact, it is slightly better than  we had anticipated when we launched the system. So, compared with our internal forecast and where we are  today that's a positive.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, for me that's a proof that the model works. The system we have put in place with the automation, with the  manual collection points, with the data system, with the organization – remember we've gone from zero people  about a year back until 100 people now operating here, all doing green jobs and saving environment. That all is  functioning well. So, well done there to that team. And we are still however, in a ramp up phase, so this will  continue for a while more for us. We will continue to invest more sites, install more machines and that will go until  probably third quarter this year, then we should be complete. So, as a result, we're also carrying a burden of  ramp-up costs in installation or investment costs on our result and balance sheet for a continued period of time.  But this is all calculated and all as we have expected it to be.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: News for us is that the Environmental Minister of UK has gone out publicly and announced that they will now  launch a process to look into deploying a deposit system in England. And the main purpose of this similar to what  we have seen in Australia is to reduce plastic pollution or littering. It's quite a sizeable market, and there's a lot of  containers being consumed every day. So, it's something we warmly appreciate and salute that they take this  initiative in sake of a better environment and cleaner society.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If we look into recycling that is maybe the highlight now. I should maybe have started with that. I just started with  food because it's bigger. But recycling is really in a very dynamic phase. I think the biggest driver here is the  China regulation what they call National Sword where China has gone up publicly and said we don't want to be  the world's waste dump, which is right. Why should we send waste from different parts of the world just to be  handed in China, why don't we take care of our own waste that is the rhetoric here. And this is something I think  from a macro perspective which makes full sense.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: But as a result of this, a lot of waste was in the past recycled in China, handled in China. And that opportunity has  just gone, and many markets, many countries are facing challenges because they were not prepared with their  capacity, with the technology and processing to handle all the waste. Therefore a lot of emergency actions are  taking place right now and we are, with our, technologies in a good position to support both our clients and the  national systems to improve that. So as a result of this, Sorting Solutions is in recycling has experienced a  moment of very strong market momentum. This will not last forever, but as we see it right now historically and for  the near future, we see continuous good momentum here. So as result, very strong development in order intake  in recycling.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Also further developments like requirements for lithium, for car batteries are increasing in demand. And with that,  our focus on industrial minerals. So that sector is exciting also going forward and we continue to support it.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In New South Wales, of course, activity will increase. And we had close to NOK 50 million of revenues in this  quarter, NOK 10 million, maybe NOK 20 million more in the next quarter. We still will continue to lose money  because of the ramp-up effect. We're also going into the winter, so the volumes is slightly lower as the  temperature is falling in Australia. But the loss will be less in second quarter than in first quarter. Third quarter,  probably close to breakeven and then in fourth quarter, we will make money.

file: TOM - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 7May2019 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If I look into the markets in which we are active, TOMRA is well positioned in both areas of the recycling sector,  both with Collection and Sorting, what we label under circular economy. We see that this is taking off strongly also  driven by regulations like in China National Sword, but also driven by other needs. We also see that our  automation solutions for the food industry are sought after. Our customers they need to improve their quality.  They need to improve their resource productivity, and our solutions are meeting many of these needs. In this  quarter, however, we saw a somewhat slower order intake in Food on back on a strong quarter in end of last year.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: It comes from the fact that many of the traditional markets in the Western hemisphere have actually  underinvested over years in this sector and have relied very much on exporting their waste to markets like China.  As China suddenly imposed this ban on imports, they were facing challenges in processing their waste volumes.  Some have sought shelter, if I say so in trying to export to other markets like Malaysia, like Vietnam, like  Indonesia. These markets are challenged by this situation. They are trying to ban it because it's not a  environmental friendly and sustainable solution for them. And in parallel to that, many of the existing markets are  investing more. So we will continue as we can see to see a demand driven by this in the aftermath of this National  Sword for some period going forward.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In addition to that, we are seeing more and more demand for the use of recycled material, as consumer goods  companies, the bottle industry, are transforming more and more towards using recycled content in their products.  We also have countries or regions like European Union which with a Single-use Plastics Directive are driving for  more recycled content and collection. They announced in February in the Parliament that the Single-use Plastic  Directive will be implemented telling that by 2027 75% of all bottles in European Union need to be collected, PET  bottles, and 25% being recycled content; and by 2029, 90% of all the plastic bottles being sold in the region need  to be collected, and 30% of all new bottles need to contain recycled content or the content of new bottles need to  be minimum 30%.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: That drives the circular economy sector as such. So Collection and Sorting are being interlinked, and we are  actually seeing the demand increasing by legislation driven, by consumer goods companies, and the fact that they  need to reuse or use recycled content drives what we call circular economy. And that's exactly where TOMRA is  aiming to work now and in the future. I refer to our Capital Markets Day of last year where we talked about the  future of TOMRA and one part of it being circular economy. Food had a strong order intake in the fourth quarter  last year. It was slightly lower in this quarter here in the first quarter. We saw specifically in United States some  delays in orders, and our customer tells us that it is temporary delay and there's certain uncertainty in the market  predominantly due to the trade situation or the trade dispute between U.S.A. and China. We see that in our  activity and pipeline that it's picking up, and we look forward to an improved situation in the year.

file: TOM - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 16July2010 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen – being present here in Oslo, in Akershus and outside.
texts.text: This graph indicates to you how the water bottle that was introduced in Q4 2009 is developing. So  as you can see on this graph here, that in October 2004 there were no water bottles being  redeemed in the machines. These are Tomra machines, recorded Tomra receptions. And we are  now at a level of about 45 million containers a month. That’s from my point of view quite an  impressive development in a short time and as I mentioned before, in order to cope with these  requirements and these higher volumes, we have worked on replacing the portfolio in United  States.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen – being present here in Oslo, in Akershus and outside.
texts.text: IPT is very depending on external drivers. We saw that in 2008, where we had a very weak order  intake, and I use the word “very” here because there’s been big changes. And this picture is to  illustrate for you that when we came into the fourth quarter of 2008 in essence the material price  paid for recycled material was down at level of zero. This then leads to that industry as such, the  material recovery facilities, those industries do not see any opportunity to invest. And we could also  as you recall, report then that we have in this particular situation very low order inflow for the Tomra  Group.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen – being present here in Oslo, in Akershus and outside.
texts.text: On the Material Handling on the East Coast we will continue to see the positive impact of the water  bottle volumes. And on the West Coast we will see the gain from higher aluminum prices, the  reinstated handling fees and efficiency gains. That will be carried forward with us.

file: TOM - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 15July2011 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, we see a positive momentum in this business. We have a strong order intake, especially in waste recycling. And  here we have been also pleased with the development in new markets like Eastern Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Overall, we had 11% growth. And if you take organic growth adjusted for the acquisition we made in the company  called RSI last year, we have a 6% growth. The gross margins were slightly down, and this is a cost-driven effect of  – due to the fuel prices.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The volume is mainly driven here – the reduction in volume is mainly driven by the weather. And we have here for  your information introduced a graph where you can see the rain conditions in California which have been above  normal in this year. So it's been more wet, more rainy, less good weather, which leads to less drinking  consumption.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So if you look at the blue line here in that green area, the blue line represents the average of rainfall in the period,  whilst the green area then indicates this year's performance – or this year's weather condition. So that has led to  that there is a decrease between 5%, 6% in beverage consumption in California in the period, which also went  straight into our results here.  Despite that I can say that we are holding up result-wise. Totally – and these numbers are now all in million U.S.  dollars, US$45.8 million of revenues. And you can see that East Coast is now a little bit larger than the West  Coast. Before they were more or less equal, but this is now a result of the acquisition we made. So East Coast is  growing here and it delivered US$26.1 million in revenues, whilst the West Coast delivered just short of US$20  million.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the Materials Handling, on the East Coast no drastic changes; the operation is running well. And here we see  opportunities to grow when we now have RSI on top of what we had before. So that is the main growth driver right  now on that side. And on the West Coast operations with Material Handling, we are expecting to continue  benefiting from the higher aluminum prices or commodity prices. And in balance of that, we had some volume  drops, but that could also be temporarily if the weather improves. So we see that we are also here performing  pretty in line with expectations, but no major moves. We had not anticipated that to be any growing business, but  rather stable.

file: TOM - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 18July2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We have been talking about a project called cost of goods sold reduction, where we aim to reduce the cost of goods  sold by about 40% over five years. Here is an example for how it looks. In the execution, we have a complete  turnaround of the supply chain. When we started this project, you should know that we purchased about 80% of  our components, which we need for manufacturing, in high-cost countries, predominantly in Scandinavia and  Germany. We then set a target to revise that from 80% to 30% in five years. So by 2015, you will see that we will  source about 70% of our components from low-cost countries. We are today at about 50%. So we have done a  dramatic change here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So let us go into TOMRA Sorting Solutions. I brought more mixed picture here. For sure, we have, as you know,  three activity areas. The biggest being food, then recycling and mining. This business is much more exposed to  cyclicality than the Collection Solutions. We saw that Collection Solutions is stable in rocky waters. Collections –  Sorting Solutions have much more exposure.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If we start with recycling, here we can clearly see the link to commodity prices, investment sentiment and a  general anticipation of the future of industry. Do people dare to invest or not? Do they get access to financing or  not? And in food, we see that it's more robust against cyclicality but also here definitely we see that is – there's an  exposure. And mining, being so small, we don't comment so much on it, but for sure we have a high link to the  mining sentiment there.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And you can see down this bottom – the graph here – that we can see the commodity for different aluminum,  copper, nickel and zinc. And you can see how that is actually deteriorating over time, and how we see that that  affects especially in metals recycling in the recycling business.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So the recycling segment definitely has seen a more challenging environment. And thanks to that, and thanks to  the fact that food has been growing, it has changed the mix in the Sorting business.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We don't see in the short term here any new markets opening up in Collection Solutions, so we operate within the  same boundaries as we have done for a number of years, more or less no major changes. If we exclude the  introduction of water bottles in New York, in Connecticut, we have had no major changes since 2005, 2006 when  Germany found out their laws for recycling.

file: TOM - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 18July2014 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And you see this product was developed from the original [ph] ID (28:16) to a ready-made product in significantly  less than a year. So, we go from years to months here in terms of R&D. We can suddenly pool together the  expertise we need and bring them to a taskforce. We can take platforms out of our library of technologies and  bring them in. And in fact, in this case, we're also taking from the recycling library technology into food and  creating a transformative factor there. So, it is important what we do here and it's going on in the right direction as  I demonstrate by these examples.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, let's then look at the future. If we look long term, I think we can see so many signs for increased focus on  food, health and safety, resource shortages, environmental matters. TOMRA is positioned to help the world to  solve problems in these sectors. We are favorable positioned. We are a leader and we are really in the right white  spot here for today and for the long term.

file: TOM - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 17July2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As for instance, low oil prices, which have effect in our customers in the plastic recycling sector. Commodity prices  in metals are not yet as strong as they have been historically remaining unstable, they also post a problem for  many of our customers in the area of metals recycling.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also experienced a positive development in North America. As we have reported before, the North American  market has been challenged especially by the volume decline of beverage containers and that comes from the  effect that people drink less beverage containers, that both is a trend and also follows the economical cycles. And  it's also depending on weather, of course. And it comes from the fact that there are changes in how the consumers  operate and use RVMs or alternative channels to return the bottles.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I then move onto recycling. We have experienced a very good period in recycling. This despite actually, this is a bit  of a surprise given the macroeconomic situation with the low oil prices, with Russia that is not dynamic market  and also metals commodity uncertainties. We have experienced, as I said, a robust and actually very good period,  driven by big waste treatment plants, what we call MSW or Municipal Solid Waste, also driven by good activity in  high quality plastics and metals has been better than we anticipated. So, all in all, positive development in our  view. Looking forward, we see no signs of slowdown here. So, we anticipate this sector to remain robust as far as  we can see today.

file: TOM - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 19July2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Yes. As you hopefully know, we have three different activities in Sorting Solutions. We are sorting food products  for better quality of food and for better productivity for our customers in the food processing industry. We are  sorting recyclable materials in both in municipal solid waste to treatment plants, and also in more industrial offsets  like packaging industries and e-waste. And we're also sorting in the mining industry being the smallest part.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When it comes to the recycling, we have now experienced for some period of time low oil prices and fluctuating,  and also low commodity prices for metals and plastics, and that affects our customers. And we start to see that in  the second quarter last year, and we see that continuously. So, the momentum is weaker here, although I would  not like to say it's a very difficult or very elaborate situation. We just see that we don't have the growth as we have  seen in the past.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Having said – talked about mining and recycling, food shows another picture. Here we see good momentum both  when it comes to order intake and revenue progression. We have also invested quite a lot in the last years in  setting this business up for up-scaling, for more customer-focused support, meaning we have invested in  technologies. We have invested in marketing and sales. We have created a common sorting platform on the  technology side, and we have invested in a common production unit, so that we are effective and can support  market with high quality, short lead times and competitive products. And we see the results of that. So, it's very  pleasant to see that food helps us in a situation where we have this macroeconomic headwinds affecting recycling  and mining. And it's actually food that is the star for this very period.

file: TOM - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 19July2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We have decided to create a corporation with a company called Cleanaway, the leading waste management  company of Australia, and is a very good symbiosis between how we can operate, where we can stand for the  collection technologies, the automation part, and where they have all the infrastructure processing and trade of  commodities.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: That's all I can actually say to that. We do salute though the initiative from the authorities in New South Wales.  They are taking this initiative in order to reduce littering and waste. They want to reduce that by 40% up to 2020  and that's a very important step to take. If we look into the overall situation globally, actually, except for some  markets which are really taking good steps to reduce waste. But in most markets in the world, actually this is a  major issue and it has vast implications.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Looking at [ph] Plastic Oceans (12:13) as an example, we today have so much plastic in ocean that it's start to  become a real environmental concern. Predictions are that by 2050 there will be equal amount of plastic in the  oceans as there are fish by weight. And if we just think of that scenario, what that means for the environmental  situation in the oceans, for the marine life and also for the sources of food from the oceans, this is something we  think is a real challenge for the planet and we see that Collection Solutions are a really good solution to reduce  that problem, because most of the waste you find in the oceans is actually coming from land by people throwing it  away into the nature, wind, water, rain, will make the work to bring it out to the oceans and then it stays there for a  very, very long time.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So this is a real problem. And the plastics, as you know, will break up into small, small particles and will go into  the food chain, which is really devastating. So we think that with this initiative, it's really bold step from the  Australian authorities that they do this and we would be very keen to participate.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Just to give you a few numbers. Out of the all packaging waste that is generated every year, only 2% are  managed in a closed-loop recycling. You can say that is the area where we, as TOMRA, are contributing. That's  only 2% of the global waste stream in packaging waste.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Only 20% of the total plastic is being recycled. Closed-loop is when you can really keep it at the same level from  food to food. And if you talk of [indiscernible] (14:08) recycling, it might reduce the material, but it will then be  down cycle. So 2% being closed-loop, 20% being at all recycled. The rest is being wasted either on landfills,  being burned in incinerator for heat where we destroy meaningful resources in the nature. So that's the scenario,  and therefore, we really salute the initiative of the authorities in New South Wales, and we hope we can be a  partner of that process going forward.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, now we have a good split, 50/50 or slightly more in Sorting than in Collection. And it's been part of our  strategy to build two legs and position TOMRA in areas where we see that there's long-term megatrends of  demand, where we can also with our technologies contribute meaningfully to improve business by improved  productivity, by improved quality and consistency, but also contributing to a improved sustainability for the world  as a total.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In the recycling, I touched on that before. With our solutions, we're able to separate out waste streams that comes  in mixed into clear fractions, so that these materials can actually become a second life, a new life again. Meaning  that we are making an extended life of meaningful resources, which is so important for us to learn how to do that,  and spread the knowledge and the technologies to do this. So, we can do that so successfully is really something  that is generating great values, not only to the business, but also to a more sustainable world.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Also on the food side, a very important, we see so dramatic changes in food. We see that we will have to produce  70% more food by 2050 than we do today and we can simply not increase the farmland by 70%. It's all about  improving the yield, improving the efficiency, reducing waste, and at the same time, we have to satisfy ever- increasing needs around the world. When I was a kid, I remember, I could eat these wonderful blueberries during  a couple of weeks and month tops in the summer. Today, my kids, they expect to see blueberries in the retail  store every day the year around. So, this is an example for the shift we are seeing. And behind that, of course, it's  a complex value chain, it's a complex – or very advanced farming and processing, and the whole distribution, and  that is the area where we actually contribute nicely into.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, all in all, very exciting, we are leader. We have a clear leadership both in food which is, by the way, the  biggest market or industry in the world, and we are a clear leader in recycling, too. If you look back  here a little bit,  especially in recycling, last couple of years has been somewhat slower. We experienced reduced activity level  last year in recycling and that was much driven by the commodity situation. Oil price, you might recall, went down  from around – above $100 at least per barrel down to something around $40 per barrel and $50 per barrel. And  our customers, those who process plastic to sell that as a new resource are, of course, competing there with  virgin material, and if the virgin material comes down so drastically under such short time that creates a big  problem for the industry.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Oil prices, to stay on that, commodity have not increased dramatically, but probably, the industry have found a  new normal here and we see that is a good momentum in the industry. So, in fact, if we look at the activity, we  have revenues in Sorting Solutions were up 8% in local and organic. If we then include acquisition, we actually  increased revenue in the quarter by 44%. And we have a slight down on gross margin – I think Espen talked  about that, that's all linked to Compac, the acquisition. And the order backlog is now strong at NOK 873 million.  Sorry, I made a mistake there. I should come back to this.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So with that, I think I can hand over. I'm very pleased with the acquisition that we got the opportunity. It fits very  well to our portfolio. It strengthens our position in this important big and growing market. And we can contribute,  again, both to better business, as I mentioned during the example, but also to reduce food waste and making sure  that the consumers around the world get the type of product they expect to get.

file: TOM - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 19July2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Looking a little bit at the bigger picture, we do have quite a lot of drivers right now around both Collection and  Sorting in recycling. And if you want to label it under one umbrella, it is actually the circular economy. And the  main drivers in here are for sure the plastic oceans. The plastic oceans are affecting our lives and it's very  emotional. And the population drives a debate here, which of course ends up on the table of the politicians. United  Nations in December 2017 appealed to all countries in the world to introduce a deposit system to reduce litter and  the plastic ocean.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In May 2018, the European Union regulation or regulatory framework are working on a proposal for reducing  single use of plastic and to collect used beverage containers to a degree of 90% by 2025. And the European  Water Bottle Association have gone out with a commitment that by 2025, they are targeting to collect 90% of all  the bottles sold in Europe. And on top of that, they aim for having minimum of 25% of recycled materials in every  new bottle being produced. These are big steps not seen before, which gives us good encouragement when it  comes to the future market development.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: The European Water Bottle Association are thinking about how to collect bottles, how to use the collected  material. They want to innovate new material types and they also want to engage the consumers. So this is all in  all, we think, a very positive statement, a good way to do it. It will drive collaboration in the industry. And if it's lived  up to, I think it will be cleaning up Europe quite a bit. And with that also, a good possibility for us to contribute to a  better and more sustainable society.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In addition to that, we have one more big player which is China, which until now actually have imported significant  volumes of waste from all over the world. So many countries have actually neglected their should I call that  requirement or their duty to install waste treatment facilities in their own countries, handling their own waste. It  was simply put on ships and gone to China and they were being handled. China said, no, this is not the way  forward. We do not want to be the waste dump of the world. They have launched an initiative sometimes back  called National Sword. That was in mid last year, pretty much one year ago. And we see clear effects of that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We see that countries are clearly struggling with handling their waste. The waste dumps are or landfills are getting  full. The mountains of PET bottles are piling up. And the only real way forward for them is to build a local  infrastructure to handle the waste. And that's not bad. It creates a more sustainable society and it creates green  jobs. So it's just to do it. But we see this happening and these are two really main drivers which we are observing  and we are seeing driving our business as we speak and we think for the foreseeable future as well.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Today, we have about 1,000 round number of reverse vending machines installed and they are then in about 250  automated sites and we will continue to install a little bit more as we go forward, but we should be completed with  a total installation and building up by the third quarter. And if we look from December 1, until today, we have  collected about 500 million beverage containers, it's supported by the public, it is more and more seen as a  positive contributor. And these 500 million, many of these bottles would otherwise have ended up in the nature  and in the ocean.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So I think we are in a good way to meet targets set out by New South Wales government which was to reduce  littering by 40%. And I think that's something really meaningful in today's world as we – especially if we think of  what I talked about before with the ocean littering.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And then we have England, where did UK ministerial environment went out and also started the process in March  and they are currently in the face of collecting inputs in the consultation process, probably it will end by the end of  the year. And so this is a little further down the road and hard to guess, but if one estimate is that they will start  January 1, 2021 if this process goes on and concludes in the way of course we hope it will do.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: This is something we haven't had in the past, it was actually not possible. So if we think of that with, we see that  the demand, the opportunities for food products not only by, but that population is growing and we have more and  more rich people on this planet or less poverty if I may say that way that all drives the consumption.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling is really participating on the effects of the National Sword and on the overall more environmental  awareness. We also see a lot of large corporations now taking a much more active role in going for more  sustainable businesses, meaning that they try to work out programs whereby they can use recycled materials  when they produce new goods. And we, of course, as a leading player here having the vast experience both from  household waste sorting into packaging waste sorting into e-waste and to end-of-life vehicles, we have the  broadest offering in the industry and can really work with these companies.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And we are demanded for in that regard also to help them drive their processes to what's more – a more  sustainable business. That sustainable call comes from, I think, more and more, yeah, the leadership of the  companies start looking more differently into it, it's not only about the dollars, it's also about developing a more  sound business and also of course the political pressure with social media and so on. People are more and more  aware that they have to work on the reputation.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, we see this is not a trend that is short term. This is something that's actually accelerating. We can talk about  the National Sword being an event that will last for a while. We think that will last for quite some time because  there's so much catch-up work to be done here in the markets to build up the local infrastructure for recycling, but  the corporate social responsibility that's rather accelerating from a rather low level, but I see that is going  favorably into the future.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And consequently, we again ended the quarter with a new all-time high backlog; we're all almost NOK 1.6 billion.  The conversion rate still is estimated to 70%, depending revenues in next water is assumed to end up around  70% of the current order backlog. And as I already said, this is not guiding, just an indication for you that want to  model TOMRA on a quarterly basis.

texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: I will now explain to you a little bit more about how it works with our sorting applications. So, basically, you come with an ore from the  mine, which goes into the process, goes through primary crushing, and then, with the help of our  sorters, we’re then able to separate out those materials, which contains a certain percentage of the  mineral you’re looking for and separating out the waste.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: By doing this, we can help the mining companies to make better use of their existing deposits. In  other words, you can turn old dumps into a valuable resource. We can process material with a  lower grade level so that you can make more precise decisions on which material you process.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: It generates economical benefits for the mining companies. They can increase their capacity  because you don’t need to process the waste in your crushing and sorting applications or in the  crushing and water treatment applications. By that you can also reduce energy significantly, and  you have also less wear and tear and chemical materials being used.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: And that also then leads to a better environmental footprint. You have lower carbon dioxide  because the mining industry consumes a lot of energy. You can reduce acids which are used to  separate out the minerals from the waste in a traditional process and, by that, also less pollutants,  less water usage and, all in all, a healthy environmental contribution.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: The typical products we are talking about here are, on the left side, you see a series we call run of  mine. This is a fixed installation, and it’s a very rugged belt construction with sensors like radiometric,  photometric, electromagnetic and X-ray.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: Here is a picture illustrating how such an application looks in the field. This is then for de-stoning of  coal. So, typically, in the ore that comes out from a mine in the coal sector, you have between 10%  and 30% stone content. You want to eliminate those stones. They should not be transported from  the mine into the power plant. They should not go into the burning chamber because they will not  be burned, they will only transform to a slag in the ash in the power plant. So being able to take  them out generates good benefits for the power plant downstream.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: With this picture, we illustrate to you a movie, just to see how it actually looks in real life. You will  not be able to see much of the technologies here. It’s then transported over the  processing belts here, spread out for sorting capability. We can process about 120 tonnes per hour,  metric tonnes per hour in this particular application and you then have optical sensor equipment  that will help you to remove the stone from the coal. And ultimately, in the end, you find then a pure  product, which you want to process further into your power plant and some slag products as well.  And what you see here is then the smaller, the fines we call them.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer

texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: Well, this is then a schematic showing you how such a plant looks. You can see you have an in- feed coming from the left-hand side here where you first have a mesh or a gator where you  separate out material by size. The very small particles are taken out, so basically 50%. If you think  this is a plant with 1,000 tonnes per hour, about 50% of the material is sorted out through the metal  gator. Then you go into the right-hand side where you can see the four red boxes in there. And  these are then sorters, Tomra sorters or TITECH sorters. And together, they will be able now to  process 500 tonnes per hour in this particular configuration.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: And, as a result, the end product will be either a product which you want to produce further, in this  case coal, or the waste product, which is then primarily stone. So in an application like this, we can  see then four sorters. And application can vary so it is not one standard here, but the core elements  are standard. So we process with optical or electromagnetic sorters, we provide the conveyor belts  and so on.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: This is then an illustration of tailing dumps. So, again, here you take care of an existing dump from  a mine. And these were considered waste in the past, these dumps, and there are huge dumps  existing today, where we now, with these sorters, are able to reprocess them and make use of the  existing valuable resources in there.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: So, again, this is something where we help the mining sector generate valuable resources out of  what was previously considered waste. And it is very easy to do it because the dumps, they are  over ground, so they are just laying there waiting to be processed.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: With our applications, we can save substantial amounts of energy and water, and these are big  cost drivers in the mining sector. We can make use of a lower head grade so material that was not  good enough in the past can be used now, and you can also come out with a more homogenous  product when it comes to the quality.

texts.speaker: Stefan Ranstrand, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Abrupt Start] the Tomra Group. I will today present to you the third quarter results of 2010. With me
texts.text: We experience from day to day, tougher environmental regulations. We see disasters in various  forms and shapes in the mining sector, and ways to help prevent using of water, help prevent  generating of big dams or dumps of hazardous material are welcomed. And we can help there. And  the sector is also facing increased pressure on costs, and we can help them in that regard.

In  order to take – handle the bigger water volumes on the East Coast, we have also needed to add  some costs, so the operating expenses increased by $0.7 million in this context to serve the  business.
