texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have delivered about 40 RVMs to Middle East to a international waste handling and logistics company called  Averda. This is a good development for a new region and they have further plans to expand the operations in the

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We see gross margin going down a bit, but we see a very good cost control on the operation. The gross margins are  affected by diesel prices and that we have lower fees in California on the processing and handling fees.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Material Handling, we expect a decline as we go into Q4, it has to do with colder weather, colder temperatures  which affects the drinking consumption and the volumes are important for the business, so the higher the volumes  are the better are the revenue and earnings, but this is fully inline with what we have seen historically, we have no  other changes here, but for the seasonality.

file: TOM - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 17October2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Then we have also reported to you earlier that our cost of goods sold improvement project is progressing as  planned, but we are now in a phase where we have, so to say, reaped many of the low hanging fruits when it comes  to sourcing. We are now in a transition phase going more towards where the technology changes will give us the  future benefits. And hence, we have not big operational contributions at this very stage.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Here too, we have also made revolutionary design changes in the technology so that it's very easy to maintain, to  operate and to clean. So it's faster, it's cleaner and it's able to take all type of beverage containers.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Sorting Solutions. Good growth, 12% organically. When you look at the data later, you will see that last year, you  cannot calculate the 12% because that is, we had chilling and freezing business, which we have divested. But fully  organic, with the same portfolio, it's a 12% growth. And this has primarily been driven by food recycling, as you  might recall, had a slower start in the year when it came to the order intake. And therefore food, which has had  good activity level, has outgrown in this period.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So in fact now, if you look back one year, we had a split in the portfolio, about 60% was food and 40% was mining  and recycling. At this quarter, we are at the level of 75% food and 25% being the rest. So we can see that food has  generated good revenues growth.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: When it come to the order situation, here is a bit mixed picture. So we had a good start in food in the first months,  and very weak start in recycling. So recycling was a concern for us, but over the last months, say, four to five  months now, we have seen a steady improvement in recycling and it looks promising. I don't say guaranteed good,  because it's very much depending on the macroeconomic climate. But we see good development and it's  promising.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We have one very exciting technology on the TOMRA Sorting Solutions, which is QVision. This is a real revolution  for the meat industry, and we have now seen good sales results of this product. Traditionally, when you process  meat, you produce a batch, and then you take samples or you make either during the process or at the end of the  process, you take samples of what you have produced. And you go to a testing equipment and see whether you  have produced according to the specification.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So let's assume you produced mincemeat, and you need to meet a certain specification of fat content or water  content et cetera. You can only see that when you have processed a whole batch. A batch is typically one metric  ton, so it's quite a sizable volume. You can only see that afterwards. And if it's not according to the specification,  you have a lot of work to reprocess this batch, and very often it's a challenge.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We can measure, we can offer a solution to the industry to measure in-line. So instantly, you see what you're  producing here, and that is a revolution. You don't produce any waste, you produce a right product from start.  And it's very easy to install, it do not take a lot. You can basically just roll it in over an existing meat line.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: I have myself visited plants where they produce mincemeat for the burger industry. And we are talking about  quantities, 10 tons to 15 tons of meat an hour. And here, of course, having an equipment being able to deliver  precisely to the specification is very important.

file: TOM - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 17October2014 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But in U.S.A. in addition to this retail reverse vending operations, it has dev eloped over years, a small redemption  centers or depot. They are either people professional focusing on only taking back bottles, collecting them and in  passing them on to the recycling companies, because they can live on the handling fee. So that is a via ble business  model for them. Or alternatively there are cash and carry stores who are bottles – wholesalers or bottle – focusing  on bottle sales only and by that they get bigger volumes also with their customers coming back.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So that's an area where we also need to look into, and we are here putting more resources into a digital  engagement that we try to use modern channels to get the population to realize the opportunities here. Here, I  would say, we are little bit more far away, so that is more long-term path. But it is in our interest, and it's in the  interest of the society that we try to recover every single bottle that is being consumed so that we can rescue the  material value in that to be able to work for a better resource balance on the planet.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In addition to that, there is non-deposit on water bottles in Massachusetts. And that is exactly the initiative I  talked about before, and that could be enough change here if that would be legalized through the ballot. There  would be, for us, in practical terms, just a volume increase. The installed base infrastructure is there, so it is not a  matter of selling more robust vending machines, so when you're installing more mac hines, it's a matter of  handling bigger volumes, which are out in the system. So the whole infrastructure is at hand.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We can compare that with the event we have in – I think it was in 2011 or 2010 in the Bottle Bill expansion in  Massachusetts and New Y ork where, actually, the water was also included in the deposit scheme, and we could  participate on the volume growth there.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Croatia is another market, has been, as I said, a deposit for years. But now, they want to make  it efficient, want to  make it a real viable opportunity to help them fulfill the requirement for recycling and resource management. And  will introduce a barcode requirement and will introduce Compaction, which is almost a must to make it a viable  system, because if it's not compacted, you end up shipping a lot of air and the whole effectiveness of the recycling  system very quickly falls apart. But – so they have taken the right things here. The market here is similar size to  that of Lithuania, our best estimate, about 1,000 machines.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In 2005, TOMRA was a different company than it is today. We had a vision to help the world recycle. That was a  very fine vision but it was also contained. It had problems in ex panding the scope of TOMRA. But in – within that  scope, the management decided to acquire a unit called Compaction, consisting of two operations, Orwak and  Presona. It was balers, which is a product or a solution that compacts material so that it is more e fficient in  logistical chain, both at site, to make it easier there, and also to reduce cost for the material that is being transport  from the consumer being in the industrial use or retail into the recycling facilities.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And we need to enable to be a leader in the sensor-based solutions for optimal resource productivity. We need to  focus all our resources into doing that. We see a big opportunity. We see a fast development. Y ou can see in  TOMRA Sorting Solutions, where we are now active in recycling, mining and food. There's a lot of requirements  coming up here in the future, not only when it comes to applications but also the geographical opportunity,  expanding it to new markets and we have, therefore, decided we need to put all our management attention into  precisely that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In consequence, we have decided that we will divest the unit of Compaction. It is a unit that stands on a very  strong basis. We have renewed the technology base. For this industry, I would say it's the most innovative  technology we have today – which is in the market today I mean, sorry. It is a smart construction. We are about  25% to 30% lighter in our material construction than that of the competition. Meaning that's an efficient design. It  is space-saving because we have reversed the whole way of compacting by building in the cylinders into the  machines than having them on top which is traditional. It's a safe unit we have. The safest product in the market  and we have a totally top, modern production facility.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the past, we were too small because the mining volumes are so big. But with that, we are coming into epicenter.  And we have also focused the team, both when it comes to sales and technical support, on the core markets. The  products we are seeing here includes nine sorters of our new high-volume XRT sorter for phosphate. The  phosphate in this case is embedded in flintstone, and it's about separating that. By doing that we can help the  customer reduce substantial energy cost and reduce substantial water consumption.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: This application will be in the inland in Saudi Arabia. So it is dry, water is a constraint. We have shipping  distances to ports. So all these matters are being more concentrated in ore and removing the waste rocks, in this  case the flintstone is critical.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We were here up against the competition and the fact that we have this high efficient sorters mean that we could  make the footprint half. So the alternative with our old technology would have been to have double amount of  sorters. But in this case, we were so efficient that we could have half amount of what the alternative would have  been.

file: TOM - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 21October2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, with that, we are moving over to Sorting Solutions. As you know, we have three areas of activity in Sorting,  where the biggest activity is in the Food sector, then we have activity in Recycling and in Mining. And the whole  concept here is to create a common modular technology platform. So where we develop base technologies one  time, which we can then use in the different sectors. It's also based on that we have consolidated the whole supply  chain. So, the suppliers and the production is operated as one unit covering the three streams.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Beyond that, we have to have expertise serving the different markets for Food, Recycling and Mining. So, that  means that we have salespeople, application engineering, and service people, which are experts, and focusing on  their customer base and their application needs only. This business is quite different to that of Collection  Solutions. We are active in about 80 markets, so it's a truly global business, and we have many applications.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And we are doing good actually. If I look into the overall picture, I'm confident that we are gaining market shares  in terms of orders now in Food. I'm confident we're gaining market shares in Recycling, whilst in Mining I am  unsure, it's a start up business for us, it's very small, so we don't have that exact insight into it.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When it comes to Recycling, we have seen good momentum. So that's really progressing well. When it comes to  Mining, we see a clear delay in decisions. And it's very difficult for us to navigate in this landscape to see – say  anything about the future. You'll recognize that the Mining is a smaller part of our activity, so it doesn't make a big  difference, but nevertheless, these are the main characteristics.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When it comes to the Recycling, we should be very satisfied with the results, to tell you the truth, because this is a  tricky market right now. Those of our customers who are operating with metals Recycling, I'm thinking about  scrap yards also including e-waste and those who are working with upgrading of recyclable plastics, they have a  difficult situation, because the commodity prices have come down dramatically. That really changes their business  model.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: They have a complete different return on investment. They have a complete different revenue stream, much lower  revenues, of course, if you don't get the same output. And their supply side is not necessarily responding to the  demand side. Meaning that if the oil price goes down, which affect the PET prices. Let's say, the oil price goes from  $115 to $50, which is a dramatic reduction, the cost for them to source the recyclable plastic will not go down in  the same amount because it's a lot of manual activities involved in collecting material. So it is a tricky situation.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I hope that gives you a reasonable understanding of what's happening in a marketplace and how are we operating.  I'm pleased with the strategic work that has been done. And I think we are in a good way, and especially that we  are here in Food and Recycling doing well.

file: TOM - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 21October2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, if I take, for instance, for recycling, if you have low prices of plastic, our customers who might be or are then  recyclist of plastic material will compete with virgin material coming from oil. So, if the oil price goes down  dramatically, that competitive alternative being plastics out of virgin oil will be at the lower price level. Hence, our  customers are fighting in a business environment that is shifting very much.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Exactly the same happens in a metal sector. Metal prices, commodity prices for iron, copper have been week for  a period of time now, and that has a big impact. And of course, that also affects the investment sentiment in our  business. The payback period becomes longer, the uncertainty is higher in the business, and that is exactly what  our customers are experiencing and makes them considering more longer times before they make investments.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We do, however, also in recycling, have businesses which are less sensitive to commodity prices. And here, for  instance, it's worth mentioning, municipal solid waste or household waste treatment. They are more driven by the  megatrends of the urbanization, new cities where you need to handle the fast-growing volumes of waste. So, that  is happening and that is a long-term trend. And also, in that sector, which is actually the most difficult area to sort,  because you have so many fractions.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Yeah. Just want to make a small remark. You saw quite in-depth inspection of every object, in this case, green  beans I think. So very high precision works done. That's what we have to do. Only now imagine that that happens  about 40,000 times every second. That is with a speed we're operating. So what you see on illustration here is  slow, but in reality it's going extremely fast. There is no alternative to this. You cannot do that manually. You can  never come to that precision level and that hygiene level with manual work. This is a brilliant sector of technology.  A lot of knowhows going into that process and cross-breeding our technology and knowledge in the TOMRA  Group from where we have in our taking knowledge from recycling into food and all the experiences we have in  the companies both ODENBERG and BEST over time to build this unique TOMRA platform. So this is an  important product and it is something we are really very excited about.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling, I talked about that before. Low commodity prices. We are stable in this business. It helps of course that  we have such a strong technology especially in the municipal solid waste. We have also seen a good recovery in  the U.S. business here. And in particular, I would like to point out also Asia and here again China as a highlight  and the mining business don't need to say too much. The diamond is really helping us out in that area.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Here, you are taking a commodity, here thinking about apples, oranges, kiwis, avocados. The problem is not  foreign matter. The problem is to grade these products here, or the task is to grade these products into different  qualities. So, it can be graded. If you have a shipment of oranges coming in, say a truckload, that can then be  graded into 20 different product categories. So, it's taking a commodity and making a product out of that. And  here, grading means looking at different sizes, a big object, small object, you can grade it. So, you have a  common sizing. And other thing is to look at the surface quality. Are there any damages or any spots on the  surface? You can provide your customers with a homogenous visual quality.

file: TOM - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 23October2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Shortly, if I look at the broader picture where TOMRA is operating, we do have a very focused portfolio around  Collection Solutions and around Sorting Solutions. We are based on sensor technologies and we are active, you  could say, in two main segments. One is what we traditional call recycling, with the solutions we have both in  Collection and Sorting, and more modern word which you will probably hear more from us is circular economy. It's  really about how can we bring bottles and cans into new life. And with the discussions, with the developments I  see in the market, I see that we are very well positioned in the fact that we do have both Collections and Sorting.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: How is that you might ask. Well, a lot of consumer goods companies now start looking into really taking care of  the sustainability agenda, trying to build a model where they can produce new products out of recycled material.  They need that both to secure material at a lower cost, but also in order to show that they take responsibility. The  biggest challenge in this model, or one of the biggest challenges, are actually to get hold of the material. So by  having Collection Solutions that can collect in a high-quality way with continuous volumes is an enabler.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: The processes to do recycling of new products out of recycled material requires a lot of knowhow. And I dare to  say to a large extent, we are a good partner for that. We have a lot of knowhow to help these consumer goods  companies to do that. It's still at an early stage, but I see that's a big driver going forward and it's good that we can  work on these concepts early to build smart circular economy solutions with the use of the platform of TOMRA  capabilities.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We also have a joint venture here with a leading waste management company called Cleanaway, and we have  signed a partnership with one of the leading retail chains in Australia, Woolworths. It's interesting. Strategically it's  a high importance. It's a new market. That's good, because we know that traditionally Collection Solutions need  these kind of new events to continue to grow.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Now when we move on to a market like Australia here, we are, in order to make the system function, in need to  work with someone else, a partnership but collaboration for logistics and for handling of the plastic processing.  That is now, in this case, Cleanaway. It's great for us to learn to work that way. The machines are actually more  like we call them kiosks. They are standing not in-store, they are standing somewhere close to retail or in some  locations, so again partly a hybrid. They are also designed in a partly different way that can take different type of  fractions and so on.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Stefan. Just briefly on New South Wales since – and also I'm eager to put some figures into spread  sheets. The setup in New South Wales is that we have established a joint venture with Cleanaway, and we have  been awarded the contract for [ph] running (00:18:39) the network of return points in New South Wales.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: But beside that, our responsibility has been outsourced either through Cleanaway, which will pick up the bottles,  process and sell the material, and TOMRA, which will build the collection infrastructure via kiosks, the RVMs, and  operate this infrastructure. And consequently, TOMRA will do an investment, which will hit our books. And how  big? It's a little early to say how this will be, but to use very round figures, you can assume that the fixed assets  plus the working capital could, as a guess, today be around AUD 50 million. Particularly, the working capital part  is uncertain because it's how the cash flow will work within the system here but just to give an idea of what this  might be.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: On the recycling arena, we have to remember that China is a very important market. And China has come out  with a new event, they call it National Sword, which means that they will not allow import of waste, which  happened in the past. They are banning that. Meaning that now that waste that was previously exported to China  needs to be handed somewhere else. And we see a lot of initiatives now to actually invest in the domestic  markets.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, let's assume that waste is generated in America. Instead of shipping that waste to China, they will need to  treat that in America and make valuables out of that. So, again, that's a good driver actually in the industry. So,  such an initiative like the Chinese have launched the so-called National Sword is actually not negative for our  industry. And hopefully people see the opportunity to generate good recyclable raw materials in the local market,  and by that also creating green jobs. So, recycling, I see that we have seen a recovery in the market, and we see  that we are in a positive momentum.

file: TOM - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 23October2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Okay. Let's get started. Thank you to everyone [indiscernible] (00:00:07) for joining us here live in [indiscernible]  (00:00:09) – in Oslo actually or joining in listening at the webcast. This is the third quarter presentation for  TOMRA. My name is Espen Gundersen. I'm the CFO. Together with me, I have Elisabet Sandnes, Head of  Strategy, and [indiscernible] (00:00:29) which is our Investor Officer. Stefan Ranstrand is unfortunately traveling,  joining the Circular Economy Seminar Summit in Japan and consequently not joining in on this presentation.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: The other event so to say this quarter has been Queensland. Queensland is the state that's North of New South  Wales where they also are about to introduce deposit. They had choose a slightly different approach to this than  New South Wales. In New South Wales, there the EPA, Environmental Protection Agency, had a rather thorough  process, very involved in the setup, establishing targets, focusing upon convenience. And in Queensland it has  been a process where much more responsibility has been placed upon the industry.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, Cleanaway will also be present in Queensland, but they have separate contracts on logistics and processing  with CoEx and we are not in a joint venture with them in that respect. The system will be live from 1st of  November. Very round figures. We will invest NOK 50 million in this state. And revenues, very round figures. We'll  assume to be around NOK 50 million per year when fully operational.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: It's also very important to remember the EU initiative, the single-use plastic directive. Draft was launched  previously this year, and there seems to be a clear commitment among most of the countries in EU to implement  this directive. There is some resistance and discussions from some of the Eastern European countries when it  comes to ambition level. But, in general, there seems to be a high support for the main target which is to introduce  90% target on beverage containers made of plastic by 2025.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Previously, it was 90%, now it's 99.5%. Meaning, it's only allowed 0.5 percentage point of contamination in the  waste being imported for China. And as a consequence of this, import of waste to China has almost disappeared.  Each of the previous exporters has to deal with their own waste. Waste is piling up. And there is a demand for  recycling coming out of this.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In addition or in combination with this, we also see the marine littering and the concerns about all the waste in the  seas, and the new plastic directive we talked about in EU is a direct consequence of this. And you see also  [indiscernible] (00:21:08) around the world coming out of this problem. And governments all around the world  want to find solutions to deal with this challenge. And there's no one – no quick fix. But what it can do is going for  deposit on beverage containers and it can also ban plastic bags and you can focus upon plastic littering trying to  be more sustainable model. So, we're using the plastic we have out there. And for this reason, we also see  initiatives that benefits TOMRA Recycling and TOMRA Sorting.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And also I think it's worth mentioning the focus upon larger corporations' initiatives when it comes to corporate  social responsibility. A lot of what happened 10, 15 years ago was more green-washing where really – the focus  was really not to increase recycling rates but just [indiscernible] (00:22:07) did something. Today, I think that  initiative is – there are more of them and the willingness to really [indiscernible] (00:22:16) this is much higher. So  I think a lot will also come as a consequence of these bigger companies' initiatives for creating circular solutions,  reusing the plastic in a different way now than historically. So, good development in Recycling.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: One more slide, we had our Capital Markets Day in 15th of September. We think it was a success in respect that  we managed to convey what we wanted to convey, partly focusing upon the environment TOMRA is operating on  and how TOMRA will benefit from those drivers and monetize based upon the opportunities that's out there, how  TOMRA has the right to participate and win in these markets and it was little more than 100 participants physically  in Asker and little more than 400 looking in on the webcast. We also as part of this communicated new financial  targets and I would just want to very short repeat this making sure that everyone has received them. Top line  growth for the next five-year period, we assume should be at least 10% on average for the period knowing, of  course, that at least in Collection, we are depending on political processes. But still adding up the opportunities  we have in pipeline, we think this is a fair commitment to make.

file: TOM - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 15February2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And there will be many reasons for the results and we will explain them to you, I hope, in the session here. But  some highlights includes that we do continue to perform and deliver on the cost reduction program we launched  in 2010 in Collection Solutions.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We all know that resources are getting scarce. We all know that the planet is under enormous pressure when it  comes to global warming, when it comes to carbon dioxide, but also when it comes to supply of critical resources  for the fast-growing global population. And we do have answers for that not to solve the problem but we can  contribute to the better. And by being united, we are stronger here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We, according to the numbers we get, there is an annual decrease on the consumption of soft drinks in the U.S. of  some few percentage points. And since we're operating in a market with materials recovery and throughput, this  affects also us. But the operation is well-managed and we managed to hold our position very well. So, thanks to  that, we have a strong and stable business.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: I do feel that we are well prepared for this important business. We have on the one hand, the cost reduction  program, which is now you can say midway. We stated that for all new products, we will reduce the cost of goods  sold by 40% in the period 2010 to 2015. So, we are pretty much in the middle here now. And we have been able to  deliver as planned.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: With that, I leave Collection Solutions and I go into Sorting Solutions. We operate Sorting Solutions in three  different areas. Also illustrating with these hands here; we are in – with the stones here or rocks, we are in mining.  With these potatoes, we indicate that we are sorting food. And with this shredded plastic, we indicate that we are  also in recycling. So, these are the three activity areas we do have in TOMRA Sorting Solutions.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We can, for instance, identify certain toxins. There is one toxin called aflatoxin, which is cancer causing. That is  common in some nuts, for instance, peanuts, coming due to temperature, humidity can grow on the surface. You  cannot see it by the human eye, but our machines can detect that. So, that's an example for food quality, food  safety, how we can contribute to improving that. We know right now there is lot of talks about food safety, food  quality, this will only increase, and this is an area which is very important for us, one of the drivers actually going  forward for that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: But we do believe it's a short-term flattish, stable, medium-term slight upwards trend; but long-term, we see that  we are positioned in the market that has needs and we'll only increase. People talk more and more about recycling,  the need for that, to reduce dependency on virgin materials, improve the environment, improve the health and  safety. People – the public opinion, they want to do this. They think recycling makes sense and we have the best  systems in the world for that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So long-term, we are confident and the drivers are very much the cost. We can reduce the cost and we can improve  the quality. You can have many different recycling systems, but with our system, you can maintain the quality of  the goods, so that you can maintain it on food-to-food level, not by down cycling, but recycling.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, recycling, what you traditionally know as TITECH. We have here two sectors. One is waste, which is the  biggest sector. Actually here we do have – we had good momentum last year. We had good orders momentum also  in Q4. But we do feel that we see an uncertainty and that is very much linked to the overall business climate. This  is cyclical. So, if you have low activity in – lower commodity prices, lower investment climate, and more difficult  access to financing, this is affected.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling, mixed also here. We have waste recycling, which is actually performing well. Short-term, it's on a high  level, so short-term, stable. Medium term, we would have to see how – if it is a rebounce , and long term,  definitely we feel confident. Metals recycling, which is fairly small, is still – we feel still an uncertainty there, a low  momentum. And in mining we feel a fairly stable development.

file: TOM - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 19February2014 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: The launch of the T-9 is a big moment for us. We are very proud of it. And it really is a machine that is much  faster, easy to clean and it takes all. We with this technology can actually also receive objects that are not around  which is new for the industry that has been a limitation for the development of recycling of other packaging  materials.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, Sorting Solutions, yeah, much more diverse picture. We are in markets that are really roller coasting. Take  mining, for instance, which has been as black as this can get. I think if you look in mining industry as a whole,  where many of the mining companies are really challenged, when we have a part of recycling that has been also  very heat because the metals recycling is very similar to mining so that what you see happening in mining, you  also see happening in metals recycling.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: You're basically producing a raw material being ferrous iron or copper or something like that which can be other  recycled material or virgin material. They are basically competing as a commodity, and hence, the two sectors are  very linked to each other. Whilst in the waste recycling, where we think about municipal solid waste, we think  about industrial commercial waste, we think about PET recycling, we see a better momentum, so really, a spread  here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Recycling has a bit stronger – it's a leaner product with less surrounding or auxiliary equipment, so you have a  more robust gross margin there. In the food business, you have more auxiliary equipment, so the gross margin  can vary more, actually. If you have a big plant with a lot of peeling equipment, you have more mechanical  equipment and you have lower gross margin. If you have a [ph] pure sorter (23:11) for maybe fruit or peanut or  something like that, you have less auxiliary equipment and you have a higher gross margin.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Sorting Solutions, we have three business streams. Mining is probably most difficult to predict right now. We have  to look at the mining industry as such, to say where that's going to take. But that is also the smallest business. So  it is not really a very important when we talk about the outlook. Recycling, we have two legs in there. We have the  waste recycling which is the biggest which looks robust. And then we have the methods recycling which is  weaker, but also the smaller part.

file: TOM - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 18February2015 100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And in that context, when you are recycling with what we were with TITECH at that time, what is today TOMRA  Sorting Solutions Recycling, and one could see that Compaction is a good complement to that. So that was the  original idea, which was right at that time.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Meaning, we will have to build homes, cities, infrastructure, workplaces for 1.5 million people every week during  the 35 years. That's a gigantic impact. When you see these things happening and recognizing that the world is  already challenged when it comes to environmental concerns, when it comes to resources, you see there's a need  for certain solutions. And here TOMRA has carved out a unique offering that really generate benefits for a  developing and growing planet. And one of them, of course, is to take [ph] good care (19:54) of resources so they  can be reused, and that we're doing recycling and Collection Solutions is a strong contributor for that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Sorting Solutions then. Let's remember, we have three areas; food, which is the biggest, around 60% to 63% of the   total sales. We have recycling and we have mining. Let me start with the smallest, the mining, where we have  actually invested quite a number of years in making this growth unit.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And looking into the benefits for customers in Mining, I think it's very important to understand how they're  operating. Very often the mines are far away from where the material will be used, that means a lot of  transportation is involved. I have met customers where transportation cost makes up to 25 % of the value of the  ore that is transported. Being able to sort them already at the mine enables you to remove those rocks that do not  contain the mineral you are looking for. So, you'll transport a high value material instead of a mixed material. By  that you can reduce the transportation cost dramatically and giving the mining company high paybacks.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Recycling has a little bit mixed picture right now. We are recycling both on materials like plastic, paper, household  waste and metals. Metals have been pressed for quite some time due to uncertainty or fluctua tions in commodity  prices that gives our customers big uncertainty into their financial planning. Recently, we have now experienced  the oil price reduction, of course, that also impacts our Recycling customers.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Those who recycle plastic are suddenly competing with complete new prices on virgin material, because they are  actually competing with recycled plastic and virgin plastic. And as the oil price goes down, of course, you can  produce virgin plastics at a lower cost. So, that creates an uncertainty. To date, I can say that we have not seen  effects of that, but we monitor that very carefully. So, until today, we have actually had a good momentum, a very  good momentum, I dare to say, in the Recycling. But again, that's an area of uncertainty.

file: TOM - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 18February2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look into the market situation in the quarter for Sorting Solutions, we see that Food remains solid, recycling  was a little bit slower in that particular quarter. We see that as a temporary, we don't see a major shift in recycling.  Actually, we are positive about situation we're experiencing recycling, in particular, given that the commodity  prices are so low. And if you imagine that you would be a company working with recycled plastics or recycled  metals, you will compete with virgin material. And when the commodity prices are low, your market conditions  changes abruptly.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But there are segments here, for instance, municipal solid waste, where we talk about household waste being  treated. They are more infrastructure driven. As the world is getting more and more urbanized, they need to build  the facilities to handle big waste streams out of cities. They are less driven by commodity prices. So, when we look  into recycling, we actually have to look into the mix year.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SEVP & Deputy CEO
texts.text: So, we are already on a high level when it comes to replacement cycle, then it will last for some additional years,  no doubt about that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And – we – on a full-year basis, we had growth in all businesses and Mining still generated good growth in  revenues, based on the fact that we had a big order in 2014, the Ma'aden project. That was not repea ted, so the  order backlog is affected by that negatively, but in terms of revenues, we executed fully on that project last year  and everything went well. That was also a good sign because that was a project into a region, Saudi Arabia, where  during the summer months you will face 50 degrees, 55 degrees of temperatures. Y ou have new conditions and it  was a large order for a small organization, so certainly we had to watch that we wouldn't face any major quality  concerns and so, which is quite common when you have larger projects expected, that was executed impeccable I  must say. I'm very pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With our equipment, Lucara Diamonds are able to identify these diamonds, the rocks containing these diamonds  before they go into their crushers. So, in fact they can look at fairly big rocks and sort them out, so that if there is a  big diamond there, you don't go through a very standard crushing, you will treat that piece of rock in a different  way and by that you can also uncover this beautiful gemstone. And so, we saw an opportunity, we dev eloped the  technology and we find a partner in the industry who saw that this is an opportunity for them and that was the  success. And I tell you this because this is very often the way we grow in the Sorting business. We have an  excellent and very broad technology platform. I dare to say that we have the broadest and strongest technology  platform in the whole industry. And one of the reason of course is that we have merging the technologies from  different sectors. We have laser, which we have from Food, which we can also use in Mining and in Recycling. We  have infrared which traditionally comes from Recycling, which we now use extensively in Food, and we have X- ray, which we actually use across. There are differences in the X-ray because of course you have much higher X- ray energy levels here than you would look into food objects. But we still work with the same kind of technology  and cross – can crossbreed the learnings we make here.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SEVP & Deputy CEO
texts.text: Looking at Sorting, as Stefan said, it's good momentum in Food. Tobacco is low, which is kind of part of Food, but  it's slow, but there's Food Sorting, has been a good momentum, which is important, it's a big segment. Recycling  has also – they've developed okay in a challenging market, but we have to take this little month by month, because  of course the commodity situation we experienced is not good for the segment, we could do significantly better if  you had a different environment around those. But so far we have managed to see new opportunities in new  regions and so on. But of course we have to be cautious when we look forward on Recycling, what it will manage to  do in those environments. And Mining is Mining. It's a small part but of course very influenced by the commodity  prices, say for the small niche, which is diamonds.

file: TOM - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23February2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Thank you, Espen. Collection Solutions, a fine business. The heritage of TOMRA when we were found in 1972,  the brothers Planke innovated this technology solution, which has today become a multi-national business, where  we have a global market share in terms of number of machines amounting to around 75%. These machines  contribute tremendously to a better environment reducing littering and providing the consumers and users a very  convenient way to contribute to the society and the environment. We collect some 35 billion drinking containers,  being bottles and cans through our some – we have around 70,000 machines in some 30 markets every year.  With that we help to reduce littering, marine littering, think about the plastic oceans which are getting so – such a  topic today and enabling recycling of these bottles. So, we give the bottles, the second, third, fourth life, so they  would be reused. And all in the context of optimizing the resource productivity to make better use of it.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So today, we have about 900 machines in the Lithuanian market and collected some 400 million objects in the  year, a result which is beyond our expectation. It's been a very successful introduction. And I learnt today that it  was viewed by the public in Lithuania as the third most important improvement of the year in Lithuania. So that  also shows that the public really embraces this kind of solution where they can, with a very little, very limited effort  contribute to better environment.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And of course, many people view upon the very good results. If you take Germany for instance, I think their return  rate is – meaning, the recycling degree is up to 99% in the country and that is something to look upon and say  why don't you do that and make our country clean and become a sustainable, become part as the group of the  people who want to contribute to a better environment and a sustainable society. So I think that's really positive.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If we look at the performance, it was a good year. If I look into the full year, we had an increase in orders of 8%. If  I here look at the mix between the three areas, food was growing strongly, mining was growing strongly, recycling  was slightly down. And it's not – and if I maybe then dive in a little bit more to recycling, I'm convinced that we  have not lost any market share, so we have maintained or might even be that we have grown market shares. But  let's just keep it at not lost any market share and it's just been a slow momentum in the industry. And that is most  likely to be caused by the commodity prices.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: You know that, a big part of our recycling is in plastic recycling. And, of course, here if the commodity prices show  big fluctuations, thinking about oil which is a raw material for plastic, then you have effects. Because our  customers are selling recycled plastic to the industry, and then the comparison will be virgin material. And if the  virgin material prices go down, you would have the spillover effect on the recycled plastics.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In fact, we see that recycled plastics in many areas have a higher price than virgin material, so it's more valued  which is, in a way, strange. But that I think we can explain by the focus of sustainability. Many companies today  are trying to build a more sustainable profile, meaning that they try to – as raw material use recycled material in  order to show the public that they take responsibility and prepare for potential regulations that might come in the  future or fees for oil and such commodity.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: But if I look at the order intake, again, full-year basis 8% up, last quarter 20% up. So, we see a good momentum  in the industry when it comes to the order intake. And food was and is much more stable. What we do in the food  industry through our two legs is that we help the food processing industry or packaging industry to automate the  processing. I will come back a little bit to that when I have the graph where we also show the acquisition, why we  did that one. But here – and we see a continuous growth in the food processing. You can say something like 2%  to 3% is the food growth every year. You'll remember we have to produce about 70% more food than we do today  by 2050. So, there is an underlying demand here, which is then not so cyclical like the recycling industry.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So that when you, for instance, go into a packaging of potatoes, you are sure that there are only potatoes going  into this plastic bag, or when you do French fries you make sure there are no stones, no other product in the  process than the potatoes which you are processing. So, that's really what we do. And here we are number one in  the world. We can take it up to extreme levels.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If I go into the nuts industry, we've done some mathematical examples there. You can – we talk about ppm, parts  per million. So, when you start typically in the process, you would have about 400 ppm. So on 1 million pieces,  you would have 400 defect objects. When you go down after sorting through our machines and we here – mind  you, we have number of machines in a row, you will have come to purity of maybe 0.2 to 0.25 parts per million.  So, extremely few foreign matters or defect products. That you could not do manually, it's impossible to do  manually because you cannot have people hand-pick into this level of quality.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, imagine that you take kiwis from New Zealand, which is actually a good example, because Compac is in New  Zealand and kiwi is a very common product, it will be packed in New Zealand for shipment. So, they make a first  grading of it. In fact, it's to the degree that you can see, what maturity is the product having. So, what is the shelf  time of it, so that you can minimize waste by that. And then when you come to, say, England, which is a big – take  London, it will then be packed in for retail, for Tesco, for the other retail chains and then it will be re-packed again.  So, you have kind of two points here, where you typically work in these applications.

file: TOM - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 21February2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And the whole waste sector, we talk about circular economy, the ability to reuse material in a economical way,  where we see increased environmental concern surround the globe, especially maybe presently driven by the  marine littering or plastic oceans, that is really a concern, where we are talking about that it might come to a  situation, where we have equal amount of plastic as we have fish in the oceans, that drives for how can you  reduce littering, and obviously our core technologies are very efficient in that regard.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We also see increased regulations driving demand for our solutions, and we also see growth in packaging waste,  very much driven by digital economy, especially e-commerce, which is then a beneficial or a factor when we look  into how the business develops.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Apart from that, we're performing well in all markets. Northern Europe, we had the replacement, as you know, in  Sweden that has ended. But other markets have actually been able to compensate for the downfall here. So  Northern Europe is performing well. We see slight growth in North America, 4%. Nothing substantial but still it's a  growth there. And we have added in Asia Pacific the New South Wales, which came alive on December 1, 2017.  We got the award – on the tender award around mid-July, and then we had to prepare for this ramp up. And we're  still in a ramp up phase, Espen will talk a little bit more about it, but I just learnt yesterday that we have until now  from December 1 until today – until yesterday, collected 100 million objects, which is the objective of this  introduction of container deposit system was to reduce littering and the 100 million objects is I think a clear sign  that the system is working. We get positive feedback from the consumers and the users. Their system is  functioning well but we get complaints that it is not everywhere. And, of course, this is a result of a ramp up. It's a  quite vast geographical area, the State of New South Wales, and we still have to do job there to complete the  installation. Espen will talk more about that.

texts.speaker: Espen Gundersen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Yes. Most of you probably remember this history. There was a tender process in New South Wales. And in July  2017, TOMRA together with Cleanaway was awarded the contract for operating the system in New South Wales.  Cleanaway is the biggest waste management company in Australia and we have together formed the joint  venture, which is rather slim in respect that you have outsourced most of the activities. TOMRA is operating the  infrastructure of automated collection points. And Cleanaway is doing the pickup the processing and the  marketing of the material meaning the bottles and can going through the system.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We see good momentum across all businesses. We contribute to securing quality, we contribute to improving  productivity, and in many cases, even enabling business at all. They are, for instance, in recycling area, plastics,  you could not sort manually. You cannot see the difference, but our sensors will be able to see the difference. So  it's high tech in that regard.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: The recycling has also experienced strong growth for the time-being. It's driven by regulations. So for instance,  packaging waste initiative of European Union, we have National Sword in China where China has decided to  import – have a ban on import of waste. Meaning that, now countries who did export their waste to China before  have to treat it at home, and with that, we see an increase in demand, but in general also the growing waste  volumes is critical here. And in this area, we are a clear number one. We have a market share north of 50% in the  recycling sector. And also from a technology, from a thought leadership, from a market reach, there is no one  really to match us in today's world. It's an exciting sector.

file: TOM - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21February2019 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Very nice to be – seen you all. Thank you for coming and thank you for attending. Espen Gundersen; Bing; and  myself, Stefan Ranstrand, would like to present TOMRA's Fourth Quarter and 2018 Results. 2018 was an exciting  year for us. We had good momentum in recycling. You might recall that in the beginning of the year, China said,  we will no longer be the waste dump of the world. They put up a regulation which they called National Sword. And  that led to that countries that until now had been exporting their plastic or they waste into China, no longer could  do so, and you see the mountains growing of waste because they could no longer export it. And we're also in  result of that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, we have a very strong demand for Sorting equipment, which is not a short-term story that will actually  continue, but we just saw that increase in 2018. And we see that some other markets are coming in where they  are actually exporting instead of to China, into Malaysia, into some other – like Indonesia and so on. And these  countries themselves are trying to put up a ban on this because it is not right to export waste. It's an opportunity  actually to make local use of it and create green jobs. But that's not part of the story here. I just want to say that  we had a good momentum in recycling, and we probably expect to be continuing, experiencing good business in  that environment.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We also saw a lot of discussions, fairly new for us when it comes to new deposit markets. Actually Espen talked  about the tsunami. I rather talk about the surf wave here because tsunami is a little bit to have negative effects.  So, surf wave can be quite sunny and nice. We think that that is something really exciting. We'll talk shortly about  the most – present ones shortly.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And we had a full year for the first time of Queensland. So, Queensland – sorry, New South Wales. New South  Wales, we commenced 1st of December in 2017, so 2018 was a full year. Within the first 12 months, we collected  more than 1 billion objects. So, quite an achievement. Many of these objects would otherwise have ended up in  the oceans, in the land. But now people see this as a good option, and we had throughout very positive feedback.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Looking at 2018 further, some big topics affecting TOMRA, plastic oceans. We are swimming in plastic more and  more. And one way, our way, to contribute to solving that problem is to reduce the inflow of plastic. We do not  intend to clean up the ocean; we don't have the technology to do that. But by collecting plastic material, we can  prevent it from entering into the ocean, and that is our approach to it. And that's how we also see our business  contributing to a major mega problem. We also had a lot of discussions on ban on single-use plastic on political  level, on European Union level, and we see effects of that. I will talk shortly about that.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Circular economy is a topic which we see more and more every day [indiscernible] (00:06:37) linear where you  consume through a way where you say consume and reuse – or reduce, reuse, recycle and that's spot-on where  we want to go. And European Union came out with a very clear indication of what they understand as single-use  plastic directive. I'll talk about that shortly, but it largely affects TOMRA.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: We also had a Capital Markets Day where we clearly staked out our future. TOMRA is zooming in on two main  areas. One is circular economy, the other one is future food. That's not in any way a disconnect to the past  because the solutions we have from the past will be the only future – present and future and they support this  megatrend. So, I hope you felt that that was a logical extension to where we're going to go, but that's likely where  we say this is what TOMRA looks like in 2030.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Looking into the European Union, single-use plastic directive. This is important. So, European Union actually has  the most prominent political body here in the world, I would say. It's going out and saying about 2025, 25% of all  PET bottles will be built on recycled content. So, they will use recycled content when they make new bottles, 25%  out of them.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: And by 2030, 30% of all plastic bottles should contain recycled content. That's very, very important. It's not only  telling that we need to collect the material, we also need to reuse it. That will enforce the industry to really look  into how they design the products, and we need to build up the systems for enabling this. And for TOMRA that  means good opportunities. I cannot guarantee anything but we see good opportunities both in terms of collecting  because by collecting, number one, you get hold of the material which is very important in order to recycle it.  Number two, you get hold of the material in a good quality way. And number three, you actually have visibility  onto what you get hold, so that the downstream know what's coming in here.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: If you think of a traditional waste management, a lot of waste is coming in but it's very unstructured. You don't  know the quality, you don't know the quantity, et cetera. But such a system is very precise and we know that by  experience, because our machines to 65%, 70% are actually connected. So, we know exactly what's happening  on the instant. So that's very important.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Secondly, they're talking collection targets 77% by 2025, that is what should be collected of all the plastic bottles  and 90% by 2029. In our world, we don't think that this is possible unless you have a deposit system, but we  would see what comes as proposed but we think this is a very positive indication for the industry.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: Further to that, talking about extended producer responsibility. It's a very important element. It cost money to take  back waste and the extended producer responsibility should help that. And they also talk about cross- collaboration which I've touched on before which is a very important element to really make this shift from a linear  to a circular economy. The whole industry much must work together.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: What's working good today is the front end, the collection and the recycling, but also these consumer goods  producing companies or bottle-producing companies need to adapt their process and say until now they use virgin  material predominantly, now they need to design the processes in a way that they can take recycled material.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, in addition to that, there will be some [indiscernible] (00:12:18) which is very logical, like, think of it, the plastic  is fantastic material. It's designed for several hundred years of usage. And then you have a plastic straw, which  you might use for 10 seconds for a drink or a minute for a drink, depending on how eager you are or thirsty you  are, or [ph] tops, the ear tops (00:12:38) with the plastic bar in the middle there. It's not needed. You can actually  find a replacement for things like that, and they are addressing that, which is totally right. That is not so relevant  for our business case, but it's a good initiative in the totality.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: So, since we know that Collection is a business that is more tied to deposit markets, there's no such limitation on  Sorting. So, we have installations in about 80 countries. We have more than 10,000 sorters. We are active in  recycling, in mining, and in food. We have experienced very strong momentum in recycling. We have experienced  very strong momentum in mining. We have experienced good momentum in food. As I said before, food is less  event-driven, mining is more cyclical, and recycling is really capitalizing on this plastic ocean, National Sword  events, which I mentioned about it before.

texts.speaker: Hans Stefan Ranstrand
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Tomra Systems ASA
texts.text: In the extension, that will also transform into a new sector demand for recycling because when the consumer  goods companies say, we will use recycled material like we saw in the European Union directive, well then we will  have more need for sorters again. Because then it's really about making a very fine product. Plastic being a  commodity or a resource that is in unstructured form not really useable, but to be able to deliver a very defined  specification over time, that is the job, and there that you cannot do without the sorters because you cannot even  see with the human eye the difference between certain different plastics. They might look the same to you. But  our sorters will see the chemical differences between them. And in order to build that circular economy that is  needed, absolutely needed function, so there will be an extension, a replacement from this National Sword-driven  market which we experience right now. There will be a new market demand growing up here progressively over  time.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Trelleborg AB

file: TREL.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 13February2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, the highlights, if we look back and comment a little bit on the quarter, we say we have kind of a mixed picture  in terms of market segments. I mean we have some segments doing very good like aerospace; automotive doing  good. We have also some industrial segments which is also having – we see some signs of improvement in the  construction segments. So, there is, let's say, overall more good movements in some segments. And then we, of  course, we have some other segments which is more dramatically down. If you say then agri or farming  equipment. OE is dramatically down in the quarter, continuous going forward. We have also of course oil and gas  even though we don't see that in sales, but, of course, the sentiment in the oil-and-gas-related activity has changed  dramatically in the quarter, and we also have some niches in Europe, especially in Europe, and general industry  niches in Europe were also – has been quite depressed for us in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And in the quarter, delivering as you see a strong improvement in profits even though the overall volumes is  relatively flattish or even negative in terms of volume and then assisted by some currency. Of course, we deliver  good sales and that also have, let's say, a drop, too, in the results. And on top of that, we continue to benefit from a  good market position. We see that. As you know, is lower oil – lower oil price is also driving down some of our raw  materials, and we've been kind of putting a priority on the margins here in front of volumes in some segments,  and been able to do that due to Trelleborg market positions.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: TrelleborgVibracoustic delivering EBIT margin, 7.6%, which is slightly down compared to a year ago. Explain  then, we have some start-up costs here related to some of the restructurings we've been doing within  TrelleborgVibracoustic, moving from Hungary to Turkey, moving some production around in Europe, which has  happened. On top of that, also start-up costs. We have a new factory in China coming up in this quarter. We also  have a new factory in the early phases in Thailand.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then, as I finish off, of course, I mean, we have seen in the quarter dramatically different drop in oil price – sharp  drop in oil price which is creating challenges and uncertainties. But, of course, also on the flip side of this coin is  also some benefits that we have, let's say, benefiting hopefully the global economy that we have lower oil prices  and also some benefit in lower raw materials, also if we believe to capture. But nevertheless, for the segment as  such, oil and gas, which is roughly, to give you a flavor, it's not a major part of Trelleborg. It's roughly some 10% of  Trelleborg. There of course, we have a dramatically different business environment today compared to only a few  months ago.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But then also I would like to remind you that the majority of our oil and gas exposure is fairly late, cyclical in oil  and gas, so a lot of this is production related, offshore-drilling related, which is not the part of the offshore which  is the first impact. So, we are not dramatically concerned about the order book, even though the competition for  new products here is increasing since a lot of our competitor, including ourselves, has some exposure also in a  more early cyclical part of the oil and gas sectors. So, this is creating some uncertainty, and we need to be ready  that there will be some turbulence. But, once again, this is not really a dramatic impact as of now, but we expect it  to happen going forward.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Same applies basically in agriculture OE segments where we also just say on that sector, we have some 10% group  exposure. But then, of course, a lot of this is also off-the-market related and some is OE related. So, we say roughly  slightly less than 50% of this is really OE related where you know there's been dramatic drop and that will also  have an impact going forward even though we still believe in the long-term good fundamentals, both in oil and gas  and agriculture OE, even though we have some short-term challenges here.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also to note here, we have some for you, our product deliveries within this area. We usually don't talk about but  industrial house, sometimes have a big product deliveries and it's also tough comparison compared to a year ago,  which is impacting this. So this is also kind of a one-off, even though it's a small part of industrial solutions but it's  notable in this quarter especially. That is why we're mentioning that. That is mainly also oil and gas related. It's  being able to call oil offloading hoses and these kinds of products, sometimes big invoicing and sometimes a bit  less. I know it's a little bit less, a tough comparison compared to a year ago.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also in construction, organic sales is up in this, which is somewhat surprising. Maybe I talked to you before about  the oil and gas, but we need to say, this is also something that we deferred. There's an invoicing from the quarter  before which we then committed off the debt.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: While looking now, and as I say, highlighted here at the final bullet, oil price. But we have to know that we have a  very good order book in this.
