But we say also, the  competition in the order book has been increasing and we have decided really to go for this and make sure that we  have good loading in the factory.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also, in the quarter, especially, we have also a specific EBIT impact. We're introducing a new technology for  subsea buoyancy and part of that has not gone exactly as planned so we have an EBIT impact in the negative EBIT  impact in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But also here, we have to be aware, as I already spoke about, the sharp oil price is creating uncertainty. We don't  see it in the order book at the moment but of course, we are not naïve. We know that there will be an impact.  There will be some price pressure. There will maybe be some cancellations. We have not seen anything yet, but we  want to really highlight that there is a risk going forward on this.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But looking at this in total, we as I said oil development this year, and looking at the full year for Offshore &  Construction, we are actually running at the same margin for full year, even though we have had the extra kind of  turbulence. So, overall, good development even though of course we were aiming for something more, and we  definitely aim for some higher profitability in this area going forward. But short term, there will be some  challenge.

texts.speaker: Peter Lennart Nilsson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: TrelleborgVibracoustic, most of you knew it. But simply to remind you, this is a stand-alone company. Fully stand-alone financing and a stable, solid  performance actually compared to what we had before. We are continuously improving in this area.

texts.speaker: Ulf Lennart Berghult
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Then, we come to the TrelleborgVibracoustic associated in the bridge. You can see then, as Peter mentioned, we  came from – we believe it's a good operation performance. One is then that we wrote-off some deferred tax assets, which we also [indiscernible] (29:31) with  a positive impact of that. texts.speaker: Ulf Lennart Berghult
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: TrelleborgVibracoustic, slightly down compared to a year ago, but we are, let's say – we know there why it's like  that, and we have still good volume growth and a good drop-through in the kind of the pure operational side on  TrelleborgVibracoustic. So, no concerns really there.

texts.speaker: Ulf Lennart Berghult
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Then we have two, let's say, two areas where we have to monitor closely, and that is a sharp fall in oil price is  creating uncertainty in oil and gas-related activities; some 10% of the group. Even though once again, I will  remind you the majority of our exposure in that segment is really late cyclical within oil and gas, even though this  is going to impact us here as well because most of our competitors, including ourselves, is exposed to all areas of  the supply chain. So, the competition even in this solid demand segment is increasing due to the fact really that  the dropping away in the more land based and the seismic parts of the oil and gas industry.

texts.speaker: Ulf Lennart Berghult
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: But overall, we are of course quite happy with this result. And even though we are highlighting this oil-and-gas  exposure, agri exposure, we'd like to remind you that the biggest profit providers in Trelleborg Sealing Solutions  and Industrial Solutions doing very well. And they – if we know will get a catch back in the European economy of  course. That is also where we get the majority of the benefit. So you see, it's a balanced picture, but even though  we will have challenges in these two segments that we are highlighting.

texts.speaker: Ulf Lennart Berghult
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Demand, I mean all in this next picture have been pushing this oil and gas and agri down. But overall in  Trelleborg, I mean, it is still a minor part of Trelleborg. So overall, we believe that this will balance out. And, of  course, we note there's also some signs of improvement in construction where we have some mixed belief in  Europe. But you know that as well as I do, what will happen in Europe, but nevertheless, we don't believe it'll  deteriorate further. And if there's anything, it will be better, which will then be balancing off the smaller segments  within Trelleborg.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: I guess, one should have expected perhaps slightly higher impact of weather-related claims, but I guess there is  more an element of luck in that respect. If you look at the run-off levels there, it's at a flattish level.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: And I guess to summarize, as you may recall, we've said that we want to target from the third quarter 2013 and  onwards combined ratio at or below 90%. We want to target a cost ratio below 15% in 2015. We want to target  DKK 1 billion worth of efficiency measures to achieve an ROE post-tax of more than 20%.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: And I guess if you look at the first quarter which is traditionally one of the worst quarters of the seasonal pattern,  to be at 90% for the combined ratio and above an ROE of 20% in the first quarter is slightly better than expected,  showing that our efficiency measures are slightly ahead of plan, but as Tor said also, that weather claims and large  claims are lower than we expected. At the same time, the run on equities is hardly predictable.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: But if you look at the efficiency measures, we've only achieved DKK 240 million so far out of a program of DKK 1  billion, so clearly the majority of the program is still ahead of us. And given that we want to further improve our  results also given the continued low interest rates, it is very important that we continue to produce and improve  our efficiency measures. But for us, at least, the first quarter marks the first time that the majority of the earnings  improvements can be derived from our own efficiency measures' program, which is truly important also for the  future periods.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the negative side, we see a reduction in the insurance technical result of DKK 94 million, impacted largely by  DKK 120 million higher weather claims, mainly due to the storms that have hit across the Nordics and a larger  number of house fires as a consequence of winter in the Norwegian market.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Commercial, we see an increase in combined ratio of 2.7% with a negative impact of some 2.4% from weather  and some 10.8% from large claims, one particularly large claim, but also on the positive side, some 9.3% on run- off gains, 0.3% lower on the cost ratio and an underlying improvement in the claims of 1.8%.

texts.text: And we see an underlying improvement in the claims ratio in all three major business areas, private lines,  commercial lines and corporate lines and now also a positive result in all those three segments. texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: Now, of course, we don't expect many points for the investment gain. And I guess we all know that investments  will move all over the place also in the coming quarters and years. But the most important is the improvement of  almost 4 percentage points in the combined ratio which had some tailwinds from having fewer weather claims,  which helps the result. On the other hand, has some headwind from having more large claims and lower interest  rates which increases the combined ratio. And as we'll see, this is driven from an improvement in almost all areas,  although not in corporate where we've seen the large claims of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: At the same time, we write down intangible assets, which is mainly IT assets, of roughly DKK 100 million. We also  have a few transaction transition costs which means that the total P&L impact will be slightly negative. But more  importantly, we released DKK 250 million of capital supporting the Finnish operation. And even more  importantly, we can move our management focus to Denmark, Norway and Sweden and create a lot more investor  value from that.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: Corporate, you can see, is the only area where the combined ratio has actually increased compared to the year  before. If you look within the numbers, the cost for large claims and weather claims increased from 9% last year to  have high large claims, still to have a combined ratio of 92.6% shows that our corporate business is on the right  track as well.

texts.speaker: Tor Magne Lønnum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: In terms of weather claims, it's fair to say that we have had a relatively low impact this quarter.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: While improving the results, we have also done a number of things with the customers in this quarter. We've  worked very hard to avoid claims. We have visited a large number of private customers, giving them what we call a  Tryg Full Check which is offering them a free-of-charge walkthrough of their house, advising them of how to  secure their house and avoid future weather and water claims. We have visited a very large number of agricultural  customers, going through all of their electricity because we see that is where the short circuits that creates fires  and  large claims, to avoid that.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: We have restructured now completely the product, so that we take onboard that responsibility. But we then ask  the customers what are the single items worth more than DKK 50,000 in your house, per item, because people  know that. And they were taking into account what is the burglary risk, what is water-flooding risk and a number  of the other increasing risks. We take that much, much more clearly into account. And we increase the number of  parameters used to set the price significantly, so the pricing will be a lot more precise while at the same time being  more customer-friendly.

file: TRYG - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 10October2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: Now, clearly, you should bear in mind that roughly 1 percentage point of the improved combined ratio is due to  lower weather claims and large claims than last year. And although we would like to take the honor for that, of  course, that's probably not the right solution. And also, you can see that, clearly, the business areas, Private lines  and Swedish lines, is the areas where the improvement is the strongest.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: I think what is also important is that while the beginning of the journey from the 99% combined ratio downwards  was largely driven by price increases, in the last period, we've seen clearly that our efficiency program targeting  DKK1 billion in efficiency gains by 2015 has been the main driver of the improved results. And it's very comforting  to see that that program is moving according to plan both on claims procurement and on costs.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: And clearly, as I said, a main driver – the main driver of the results improvement is the efficiency program. Y ou  may have seen that now until now, so far, we've delivered DKK445 million in the total efficiency program of both  claims procurement and cost reductions, which means that we still have another DKK550 million to go, which  would clearly support our earnings in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Tor Magne Lønnum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: If we move to the next slide, if you look at what happened here in terms of large claims, weather-related claims  and run-off, we had a drop in terms of large claims of 1.8 percentage points for this quarter compared to last year,  so some tailwind from large claims. We see that the weather-related claims dropped by 1.1 percentage points, so  also, some tailwinds from weather-related claims.

texts.speaker: Tor Magne Lønnum
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: Y ou can ask why we have negative weather-related claims in the quarter, but this is a technical adjustment from  last quarter only. And then you've seen that we also have a slightly higher run-off gains this quarter than last year.  And that is really the main drivers in terms of adjustments for the underlying.

texts.speaker: Morten Hübbe
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Tryg A/S
texts.text: Y eah. Before we take your questions, just a short summary. I guess we are very pleased to deliver upon our three- year combined ratio target when we set out the below 90% target and we were, in fact, close to 100% that seems a  rather steep ambition. I think we're proud to deliver that with some margin. And I think it's very important that,  in the last year or so, the main driver has been our own efficiency program, because, really, that is what drives  bottom line efficiency, and also, competitive position in the longer run.

file: TSCOL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 5October2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive, Tesco Plc
texts.text: For our industry, high petrol costs remain a stress point. The striking difference between our own petrol-inclusive  like-for-like growth and our ex-petrol growth of almost 4% in the second quarter reveals just how much  customers' spending has had to be diverted into filling up the car. Our petrol sales grew by over 20% in the first  half, which means three-quarters of £1 billion more spent on petrol in Tesco than in the same period last year,  much of this at the expense of customers' regular shopping.

file: TSCOL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 3October2012 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: When I first laid out the plans to you in April, I described them in terms of six key areas. And I'll use that to give  you a brief progress update this morning. Before I do that, though, what's really happening here is that Tesco is  changing. It's running less hot, it's loving the stores we have, it's reducing new store growth, it's competing harder  online. It's a very different Tesco than it was two years ago. It'll be a very different Tesco in two years' time.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On new space, we're on track for around a 40% reduction year-on-year, with a much bigger proportion of what we  opened going into Express. In fact last week, the Café Matthiae in Richmond became the 1,500th Express store in  Richmond.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have the systems. We have the processes. We have the supply chain to do it. We're now using them in a way  that we weren't using them before. Tailored ranges to different catchments have been launched in grocery  categories such as bottled water, herbs and spices.

file: TSCOL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 2October2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: I'll tell you more about how we're driving this change shortly. But first, I want to hand over to Laurie. Laurie.

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: As an example, all of our fresh chicken that's sold in the UK now comes from the UK. All of our beef, whether  frozen, fresh or in our ready meals, is either British or Irish. We've strengthened our relationships with the  farmers through the extension of our producer network to all dairy farmers. And we've hired a new agricultural  director from the National Farmers' Union. Our partnership with producers, which I first announced at the NFU  Conference early this year, is real and it is relevant. It's the key to the transparency in our food supply chain.

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: Of course, in addition to the uplifts that I've described, a key and a growing benefit of our refresh program is the  potential to improve our gross margin mix of the stores, whether by tailoring the range to the local catchment or  by deploying our latest thinking on space allocation.

texts.speaker: David Lewis

texts.text: Really interesting thing, she knows a lot about Tesco. And she's really very, very, very precise. She had no idea.  When I told her about Farm to Fork, when I talked to her about food waste, when I talked to her about the  education program and the free meals, and the things that we're doing around our store, she had no idea. No idea.

file: TSCOL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 7October2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've made some changes in general merchandising around making that a more sustainable and by that, I mean a  more profitable model and not just nakedly in the pursuit of growth, but still growing nicely given the changes  we've made. And actually clothing has been quite a strong performance both in-store and online. But in online,  we're talking about a growth of 14%.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: But importantly, one of the things I thought I would put in here – because I'm conscious that we talked about  reducing range, a lot of people then go to, does that means there's going to be no range? But actually, you got to  remember we have a very much larger range than anybody else. So, the reduction is not – when we take it out, we  still have, by far, in a way, the best range and best choice of any offering in the UK. And the other thing that we  have done but I haven't talked to you enough of is that we've used the range resets to introduce an awful lot of  innovation. Yeah, so nearly 700 innovations have come in. So, new things have come in.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This is a Komodo Dragon chili. Who likes chilies? Okay. Who likes Scotch Bonnet chilies? Yeah, at the back, my  chairman puts his hand up. So, John, apparently, chilies are marked in their heat intensity by Scovilles, okay? The  Scotch Bonnet chili, apparently, on the Richter scale has 350,000 on that Scoville measure, okay?

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've also done an awful lot of work in terms of the health agenda. Over the last three years, the changes we've  made, soft drinks and others, 4.5 billion calories; same consumption, 4.5 billion calories fewer. A little help makes  a big difference.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Treats for all is one of my favorites. This is – I don't know how familiar you are. Is there anybody in the room is  sort of gluten-intolerant or food allergy-intolerant? We're the – Tesco is the largest Free From retailer in the  country by a long way. And what's really interesting is over here. And I put this one on because I've personally  been really impacted by some of the letters I get. I think we're the only – I'm pretty sure that we're the only people  that have a Free From ice cream range suitable for children. And I get mails. I have mails from parents who talk  about watching their eight-year-old child, their 13-year-old child eat an ice cream for the first time.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've, for the last seven, eight years, paid a fair price in milk on the sustainable dairy group, but the thinking  around sustainable dairy is now in sustainable lamb or in sustainable potatoes. The idea for us is to have a  sustainable agricultural group for Tesco. We will relaunch the sustainable dairy group in order to make it a much  more productivity-based and improvement-based deal. But that's the level of negotiation engagement with the  farming community that carries on.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And finally, around our values, something I'm particularly passionate about being pushing very hard with Rebecca  and a few other people is, the area of food waste, all right. So, we do in Ireland, we have in Ireland a relationship  with a business called FoodCloud. And that is direct store to local charities, avoiding putting any food that can be  safely consumed by you or I, nothing to waste, but into the community in a safe way.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We brought them together with FareShare because of the size of it. FareShare, our partner here in the UK. And the  three of us are now working on the commitment to eradicate any food waste from our operation that can be safely  consumed. We think we can eradicate that to zero inside two years. 12 stores in the UK, working on it. This is the  application that makes it happen. Was with them last week, making really, really good progress.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Farm to Fork. I mentioned before the curriculum. We're approaching – I don't know if you've ever been in a store  when you've seen this happen. It's really quite phenomenal. We're approaching 1 million children, yeah, 1 million  children who have walked the supply chain from Farm to Fork as part of the Tesco initiative, educating them  about food and where their food comes from. It's absolutely remarkable, all right?

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: But it's just again reengaging children with their food, educating them about the food chain. And just – I think it's  970,000, so very close to a million children doing that. And just playing actively our role in the communities in  which we're in and it's important to mention, our approach to the plastic bag levy is to take the £0.05 and to  reinvest it in local community projects against the environmental agenda selected by our customers, that's how  we're going to use that money.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In the UK, it's exactly the same. It's exactly the same. This has particular meaning for the UK because those of you  who are familiar, we put a turnaround bonus into our stores, all right? So, for non-managers in our team, which  were generated by this, so they're particularly interested in this traffic lighting system, and they got that today.

file: TSCOL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 5October2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: What it means at the group level – last time I presented, it was all six green. Actually we got two reds now, right,  at the group level. So let me say two things on that because – not because the number is particularly important as  you'll see, but it gives you hopefully a little bit of an insight into how it is we as the Tesco leadership team are  behaving.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: We do have across – I can't say it's all produce, reducing the surplus production, key and important element of  reducing waste, but also maximizing the return from a crop. We had our – John [Allan] is in the room, but we had  the board recently standing in a lettuce field in Peterborough as we walked them through the supply chain to show  how it is we're working and sharing demand forecasting literally down to when it is we decide to harvest that field  versus that field versus that field in order that we do not drive waste into the supply chain system. And that's  what's lowering the system waste that you see here and ultimately improving the quality.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: And an example, a couple of examples that I love. I don't know how familiar you are with crop flushes. We did it  once in the first year. We've done it six times or so, in fact, just slightly more. And what this is, for those of you  who are familiar and all new to me over the last two years is hitting a demand forecast as a farmer is difficult. It's  really difficult. You don't know when the sun is going to shine. You don't know when it's ripe and what the crop will  be. So we have a demand forecast. And everybody doesn't want to short that, so they always produce a bit more.  If you only take what the demand was, then you've got some waste.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: So what we do is we work with our partners to say, and these are examples of when just after that period, in fact,  actually it was that period that the board were there, there was a huge amount of iceberg lettuce coming out of the  fields early. We worked with them very short order. These things happen in days. This might be a Monday  conversation or a Tuesday conversation. We open upon it. We buy all of the crop. There's a marginal cost to the  crop. The farmer gets to sell everything, no waste. We manage to keep a small amount of margin as we go  through. The customer gets a hell of a bargain, but nothing's wasted. So these are six examples of crop flushes  that we have managed by working with our partners together in a completely different way.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: Bottom right hand corner, avocados, anybody who have been in South Africa will know there's been a drought. A  lot of avocados come from South Africa. There's a size specification that everybody would want for an avocado.  Because of the drought, avocados are smaller this year. All of them will be outside of the quality spec.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: As I looked at what's happened both in the supplier base and indeed our own retail operation, actually there's a  waste of space and we need to deal with the waste of space. And that's what will drive some of the improvement  that you'll see in there.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: So how do we think about that as we look at how it is we configure ourselves and what we sell where. We call it  maxing the mix. And this is the illustration of principles. So if you take – let's take this is a UK example. Large  store or small stores in online, which is how we run the business now inside and we have four sort of our key  categories. The absolute margin for our business is the bottom green. You'd not be at all surprised that I haven't  put specific numbers on for each of those boxes, I hope. Not surprised by that, are you? Good.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: And the final one from us is innovation, right? There's a whole stream on innovation and this is the one that you  like the most because I'll talk to you about Brand Guarantee, talk to you about farm brands. I haven't talked to you  there about food waste. Definitely market-leading in terms of food waste and what it is we're doing there,  something we're extremely passionate about. We are committed that no food that's safe for human consumption  would be wasted in Tesco's retail operation by the end of next year. And we've done a phenomenal amount on  that. All large stores by the end of this year, brilliant achievement, and what you've seen in terms of technology.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: The next, for us was around how it is we maximize value from property, and we've made announcements and  clear declarations of this as we've gone through the turnaround. And what you see on the left-hand side is a  cumulative impact of the £1.2 billion of value that we generated from the property portfolio. And in the first half of  this year, that's carried on. There's been about £175 million of value released. We talked again back to October,  we talked about this concept of air rights, and in this half year, you saw the Hackney transaction, which is the first  of those air right deals.

texts.speaker: Alan J. H. Stewart
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: These waterfalls often mask offsetting movements beneath the data. And in this case, positive fresh food volumes  have been partially offset by declines in, for example, general merchandise, where we continue to be far more  selective in the volume we drive. I would also highlight the significant progress we've made towards reducing  costs towards our £1.5 billion group cost reduction target, as Dave's already mentioned.

texts.speaker: David Lewis
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: But you also see that we continue to change. We've done some category resets, we've done some supplier  resets, this consolidation. I've given you two examples here. We now have one supplier for onions. So  Stourgarden are now our 100% supplier for onions. It's allowed us and them to invest. It will make onions be a  more British onions, a better price for customers, the investment will reduce packaging by 20% given our – so  actually a very strategic partnership in one category, which is a good illustration of what we've been doing.

texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order

texts.speaker: David Reid, Non-Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order

texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order
texts.text: Our stock reduction program’s a great example. It’s better for customers because it’s driven a big  improvement in availability for both food and non-food. It’s simpler for staff because it’s easier to  locate stock to fill the shelves, and stock errors can be identified more easily.

texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order

texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order
texts.text: But inevitably, it takes time to build awareness and understanding of a completely new concept. And as you can see, we’ve linked this to our green philosophy by explaining how saving  energy can help us offer low prices. So, there is very good word of mouth now kicking in.

texts.speaker: David Reid, Non-Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order
texts.text: In the same way that we stuck to our strategy in other parts of the business, other parts of the  steering wheel, we’ve also remained focused on our work on community and on the environment.  In October, we committed ourselves to these three challenging long-term targets to become a zero  carbon business by 2050, to reduce the carbon impact of the products in our supply chain by 30%  by 2020, and to help our customers have their own footprints by 2020.

texts.speaker: David Reid, Non-Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order
texts.text: As David mentioned, we’re making good progress, meeting our emissions targets this year. We’re  actively supporting local communities, including through Community Champions in the UK and  internationally.

texts.speaker: David Reid, Non-Executive Chairman
texts.profession: Welcome everybody. Thank you for joining us again today. We will follow the usual running order

texts.speaker: Alan Philip Clarke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: Our business in Thailand has had an extraordinary year by any standards. The flooding catastrophe which  engulfed the country didn't do lasting damage to Tesco Lotus. Instead, it came out stronger. At the worst, about  over 150 of our stores, mostly express, closed and all four depots underwater. I don't know how you feel about it  but I love this picture. I've never seen anything like it in my years in the business. Despite challenges like this, we  kept our like-for-likes and our profits growing although the latter was helped thankfully by having adequate  insurance cover.

texts.speaker: Alan Philip Clarke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: The second element is stores and formats. There's a lot to talk about here, but in essence of it – the essence of it is  we're going to love the stores we've got and the overall pace of new developments will moderate. The pace of  refreshing stores has already stepped up and we're aiming to complete all the large stores by the end of 2013. We'll  do 430 stores this year to improve the look and the feel, using warmer colors and materials, better lighting,  improved site lines across the store and, as you see here, less functional signage.

texts.speaker: Alan Philip Clarke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Tesco Plc
texts.text: Some of you know I like to get into the detail and having examined every aspect of what we have in terms of space  and what's right for the future, we're taking a fundamentally different approach. Putting down a lot of new space  has produced great results for Tesco in the past, but I don't think the current race for space across the industry is  the key to a sustainable future. So on development, there will be less new space overall; 1.5 million square feet this  year, nearly 40% less net new space than last year. Our new space will also reflect the growing importance of our  online business in general merchandise and our desire to focus on the most productive use of new capital.

It's a good store. It's coming down to 70,000 square  feet, a 15% reduction. Oldon, currently 101,000 square feet coming down to 90,000 square feet, an 11% reduction  and the addition of more complementary retail. Glasgow [ph] Silverburn (51:41) Extra currently 101,000 square  feet coming down to 90,000 square feet, an 11% reduction again.

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Tesco Plc
texts.text: In the UK, expect 2014 to be a year where like-for-like is held back by the changes we're making, general  merchandise in half one, electrical space reduction all year, the deflationary pressures that are coming in food, the  refresh disruption, and the year-on-year reduction of above-the-line vouchering that we've be making since  January.

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Tesco Plc
texts.text: We will, however, be making progress each and every day for customers, creating more value for them in their  store, creating more value for them online, driving more loyalty. And just look at the additional steps we've  already taken, with Clubcard Fuel Save. Already, 3 million customers have saved £0.06 off each liter of fuel. And  we've signed up 22% more Clubcard customers than we did in the equivalent period last year.

texts.speaker: Philip A. Clarke
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Tesco Plc
texts.text: If the Welsh trial is repeated, we'll see an 8% increase in our fuel sales. It's a program that's unique to Tesco. It's  made possible by our 484 petrol stations on our large store car parks. And price is about loyalty, too. Prices have  come down for our most loyal customers. Prices are down on the products which matter most to customers. And  there's more to come very soon. We're also going to make the cost of home shopping lower and make Click &  Collect much more convenient and affordable for more of our customers.

texts.speaker: David Lewis

texts.speaker: David Lewis

And you will have seen our Bags of Help local community scheme, where all of the money that  comes from the bag levy is put back into local community projects voted for and chosen by customers in that  particular store.

file: TTE - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 30April2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Patrick de la Chevardière, Chief Financial Officer  Thank you.  Hello, everyone and thank you for calling on a Friday afternoon.  First, I will comment  on the results and then we will go to the Q&A. I will not take too much time on the first quarter  environment.  Globally, oil was trading around $75 per barrel but the price of gas remained low and  the refining environment was still difficult, even if margins recovered.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Looking at the first quarter results compared to the fourth quarter of ‘09, production was 2.43 million  barrels of oil equivalent a day, an increase of 2.1%. Adjusted net income was $3.2 billion, an  increase of 3% compared to the fourth quarter and I would remind you that TOTAL was among the  most resilient companies in 2009 in term of results. Annualized royalty for the business segments  was 15%, which compares favorably versus our peers. The net cash flows were $3.6 billion  compared to a negative $1 billion in the fourth quarter and our gearing at the end of the first quarter  was 21.5%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So now I will comment on each of the segments. In the Upstream, the five major projects that we  started in 2009 are performing well and in line with our expectations. The second train at Yemen  LNG started up in March in advance of our summer target date. First quarter production was 2.43  million barrel of oil equivalent a day, an increase of 4.5% compared to the same quarter last year  and more than 2% compared to the previous quarter. Part of the increase is coming from our  energy volumes, which grew by 38% year-over-year. Also, another point to make here is that the  improvement in Nigeria and the reduction related to OPEC’s restriction was positive compared to a  year ago and that’s roughly in line with the fourth quarter. We confirm that we expect production to  grow by 2% on average over the 2010 to 2014 period and we confirm the 2010 growth will be  above the 2% average at current oil prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In term of commodity prices, the average for Brent in the first quarter was $76 per barrel, up slightly  compared to the fourth quarter. Our average realized liquid price was up by about 5% compared to  the fourth quarter. Our average realized natural gas price in the first quarter was about $5 per  million Btu, down slightly from the level of the fourth quarter. The price does not include sales of  LNG from our equity affiliates, notably the new production from Qatar and Yemen.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Europe, our average gas price for spot and contract sales was modestly higher, although our  long-term contract prices in Asia and South America were flat. But there have been some change in  the portfolios that reduced our average realized gas price including mainly the addition of the  Barnett Shale and of the Tabiyeh contract in Syria.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Adjusted net income from the Upstream segment was $2.7 billion, a decrease of 5% compared to  fourth quarter. Given the higher average price realization and higher production volumes, the  explanation for this is mainly an adjustment in Upstream taxes. In the first quarter, the Upstream tax  rate was 60% versus 58 in the fourth quarter. The fourth quarter tax rate was below the 2009  average and the first quarter includes some adjustment from last year. The annualized first quarter  Upstream royalty continues to be very competitive at 20%. We are continuing to actively manage  the Upstream portfolio.  In the first quarter, we acquired a 20% share in the Barnett Shale. We  sanctioned the development of Surmont Phase 2 in Canada and the Laggan-Tormore project in the  UK North Sea.  The Gulf project, deep-offshore Angola, has been sanctioned internally and we  expect our partner to report it very soon. These three projects should start producing in the 2014,  2015 period and contribute close to 200,000 barrel of oil equivalent a day net to our long-term  growth.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Managing cost will continue to be a priority. We were one of the very few in 2009 to succeed in  keeping our technical costs per barrel flat and we had the lowest technical costs among the major  ones. Going forward, our challenge will be to control the world pressure on costs related to raw  material and energy costs. Overall, our role is to position the company for future growth and to  maintain capital discipline so that we can fully benefit from the increase in commodity prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the long term we are confident that the Downstream environment will improve, as the global  economy continues to recover. But it is clear that there is too much capacity in the global system  today. Total’s response to this situation has been to manage cost and reduce refining capacity.  We  have decided to close one distillation unit at the Normandy refinery.  We are in the process of  shutting down the Dunkirk refinery and selling another refinery outside of France.  So we can  confirm the target of reducing by 20%, our refining capacity between 2007 and 2011. Note that we  also announced in the first quarter, the merger of our refining and marketing activities in Italy with  ERG, which will further improve our competitive position there.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Switching to Chemical segment, compared to the fourth quarter, adjusted net operating income  more than doubled $2.2 billion in the first quarter. We are in an environment that has shown  positive movement in response to the economic recovery, particularly in the Specialty Chemicals  but we are still in a recovery mode. For the Base Chemicals in March, we started up the new 1.3  million ton per year ethane cracker at Ras Laffan in Qatar, which will contribute very positively to  the petrochemical bottom line. This is in line with our strategy to develop this activity in the Middle  East based on cheap ethylene feedstock and in Asia.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Looking ahead to the second quarter, we remain very positive about production growth.  Oil price  remains strong and our gas price realization should benefit from a positive lag effect. So, we are  confident that Upstream will be in a good shape. Downstream and Chemicals are more difficult to  predict. We expect refining margin and petrochemical margin to continue to be volatile. For both the  Downstream and the Chemical segments, we must continue to concentrate on restructuring in  major countries, expanding in growth areas and controlling cost.

file: TTE - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 29April2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Patrick de la Chevardière, Chief Financial Officer  Hello and thank you for calling. I will make some comments on our first quarter results and then go  to the Q&A. Before commenting on the results, let me say a few words about the proposed  acquisition of the solar energy company SunPower that we announced yesterday. I’m sure that you  have seen the terms so I will be brief.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: By acquiring the majority interest, Total will have the scale and international footprint we need to  establish a significant presence in what we believe is one of the fastest growing segments of the  energy industry. We have an excellent fit with our existing Solar business and certain on the  activities, plus we’ll bring our financial strength to a growing business. We have a great deal of  respect for this company, its workforce, its management and its technological leadership. This adds  a new dimension to Total and we look forward to working with SunPower.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 For CEPSA; effective at the beginning of March 2011, CEPSA has been moved from equity  affiliates to assets held for sale. Under the IFRS rules, we no longer include the financial results for  CEPSA. For comparison, CEPSA generated about $25 million per month on average in 2010. The  first quarter results include charge of $244 million to increase the deferred tax provision due to the  change in the U.K. tax rate. This item is not included in the adjusted results. You will also find a  new item for the mark-to-market impact related to the valuation of the gas and power inventory, but  this is not included in the adjusted results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving on, a lot you know about the environment, so we’ll not spend too much time on it. Oil and  gas prices moved higher and faster than expected. European refining margins were squeezed by  the increase in oil prices, so margins fell back to low levels. Chemicals performed well despite  higher [indiscernible] (00:04:01) costs. Product demand was strong enough to allow us to pass on  the higher costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As for price realization, liquids averaged 94% of Brent, slightly lower than 2010, due to wider price  spreads. Gas was $6.19 per million btu reflecting vast improvement in U.K. spot prices and the  oiling long-term contract in the portfolio with a lag effect.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Just to remind you again, Total has very little exposure to WTI or Henry Hub and about 40% of our  gas is sold as LNG. Extreme profitability improves significantly in the first quarter. Compared to the  fourth quarter, net income per BOE increased by 28%, to more than $18 per BOE, versus a 16%  increase in our average hydrocarbon price. First quarter ROACE on an annualized basis was very  strong at 26%. This is at the level of the best in the majors.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Overall, we are pleased with the way that the Upstream is performing, and we are in the process of  making the portfolios stronger for the future. We have recently closed three major deals: Novatek in  Russia, the Synenco Strategic Alliance in Canada, and Santos in Australia. We signed the deal with  Tullow to enter Uganda and should close the Yamal LNG deal sometime this summer.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Sulige Thai gas project has been approved by CNPC, and is now ready to get the green light  from the Chinese authorities. Production should start in 2012, in advance of the previous forecast.  In addition, we are moving closer to final investment decisions on Shtokman in Russia and Ichthys  in Australia. These are giant projects that add visibility and a lot of trends to our production profile.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the LNG business, where Total is one of the top player in the world, demand continues to be  strong in Asia and Europe. Total prices are currently around $12 per million btu in the Far East and  close to $10 million btu in Continental Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We are currently in discussion for long-term sales and purchase contract, mainly with Far East  buyers, and we see no signs that the link to crude prices is at risk. More broadly, the fundamental  for gas are growing, outside of the U.S. of course, as a result of the event in Japan.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the Downstream segment, refining was squeezed by the increasing oil prices and weak product  demand in Europe, but supply optimization and marketing outside of Europe balanced it.

file: TTE - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 27April2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Hello, this is Patrick de la Chevardière speaking. Thank you for taking the time to join this conference call. Before  commenting on our first quarter results, we will start with an update on Elgin. Events like this remind us that  safety must be our top priority. And so I have asked Manoelle Lepoutre, Senior VP of Sustainable Development  and Environment, and Michel Hourcard, Senior VP of Development, to be here today in case you have any  technical questions.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The latest update on Elgin. We believe this situation is now under control from an operational standpoint. The  leak has diminished substantially from its initial flow rate and we have put in place a diverter to channel the gas  away from the platform. This is a key step in improving the safety of the installation and we are preparing to start  the well intervention next week. We remain confident that this will stop the gas leak. As a precaution, we will  continue with drilling the relief wells. The first one was started last week and the second one should start in the  next week or two.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: From a financial standpoint, I can confirm the estimates we share with you during our April 2 conference call. The  response and remediation effort is costing about $1.5 million per day, net to Total before taxes and insurance. The  estimated impact on production is about 50,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and the financial impact of the  shutdown on net operating income, net to Total is about $1.5 million per day or around $50 million so far. We are  working in close coordination with all the relevant authorities and we will maintain close contact on all matters  pertaining to this incident and its remediation.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For long-term production growth target of 2.5% on average for 2010 to 2015, we have started up or have under  construction 95% of the volume we forecasted for new projects. So far this year, we have launched three major  projects. Ofon 2 in Nigeria is one of the last projects we needed to launch that is expected to contribute to the 2015  target. We also launched two other projects for longer term growth. Ichthys in Australia and Hild in Norway. In  addition, we acquired an interest in wet gas windows of the Utica shale and finalized our entry in Uganda as an  E&P operator there.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Let's recall that in 4Q 2011 we had a positive one-off item for $139 million related to changing the way we report  over and under lifting. So taking this into account, the increase would have been 7%. The first quarter upstream  results were also affected by higher taxes. Upstream production was nearly unchanged at 2.47 million barrel of oil  equivalent per day in the first quarter versus 4Q 2011.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As you know, we have implemented the reorganization of the downstream businesses so the group's results are  now presented based on new segments: Refining and Chemical, our downstream industry oil activities on one  end; and Supply and Marketing, our downstream commercial activities on the other.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Refining and Chemical reported a small profit and showed some improvement from 4Q 2011. But the main  message here is that the environment for European refining and petrochemicals remains very challenging.  Margins were squeezed by high feedstock costs [indiscernible] (8:09) and lower demand. European refining  margins, however, are trending upwards. Supply and Marketing again delivered consistent results and this  segment continues to perform well.

file: TTE - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 26April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In exploration, we have very good result in the Vaca Muerta, our shale play in Argentina with four rigs running.  For Total, this is a very significant and conventional play and on the same scale as our Utica shale play.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On our Ivory Coast prospect, we discover oil-bearing zones that demonstrate the existence of a hydrocarbon  system and we are completing additional studies to design an appreciation program and to further explore the  block. Wells are in progress on our prospects in pre-salt Gabon, Australia, Kurdistan, and in the Gulf of Mexico.  We are optimistic about the wells to come in the pre-salt Brazil and Angola. Keep in mind, more than 80% of our  exploration potential for this year is yet to be drilled.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In development, operations will remain focused on delivering our portfolio of more than 20 high-quality projects  on time and in budget. We are looking forward to the start-up of Angola LNG and Kashagan. We are on track with  Ekofisk, CLOV and Laggan/Tormore. With the FID of Moho Nord in Congo, we further increased visibility on  production through 2017. And the FID for Elgin should come very soon because the project has been approved by  NNPC and by us as operator. Note that we have been actively managing our future investment profile in a  disciplined manner.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In Canada, with the sale of Voyageur, we have rationalized our position there and are now concentrating on a  redesign of Fort Hills project. In Russia, we are focused on Yamal and we expect this is to be one of the lowest cost  LNG project in the industry. In Uganda, we are making progress with the authorities and are now speaking in  term of a much smaller refinery project.

file: TTE - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 30April2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Looking at the first quarter environment compared to the previous quarter, Brent has remained fairly stable at  well above $100 per barrel, and our average liquids price realization was essentially unchanged at $102 per barrel.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Our average natural gas price realization were slightly weaker, and in the downstream, European refining margins  fell by 35% to less than $7  per ton in the first quarter. In this environment, our first quarter results were very  solid. Adjusted net income was $3.3 billion, and adjusted earning per share was $1.46 per share. Our overall  performance was roughly in line with the fourth quarter, and on a relative basis, we should continue to be very  competitive with our peers. Also, as you know, effective this quarter, we are reporting in dollars, and by now, you  should have the restated historical figures in dollars for comparison.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On Elk and Antelope discoveries in Papua New Guinea, the next step will be some exploration and delineation  drilling to confirm the extent of the reserve base. We expect to move up several tcf of onshore gas that will ship off  the construction of at least one new LNG train in the coming year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And to finish the upstream story, we have several exciting prospects in exploration. We just announced a very  encouraging oil discovery in Ivory Coast, and we plan to follow that up with more drilling in adjacent block this  year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In the pre-salt basin, we are drilling Xerelete, plus we will drill two wells on [indiscernible] (5:37 ) later this year.  In one of the most anticipated drilling campaigns in recent years, we are about to spud two Kwanza pre -salt wells  in Angola, and there should be a third by year end. We are also preparing to drill high potential frontier well in  Deep Offshore South Africa. So, the hunt for elephant-sized discoveries is continuing in several areas.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Operationally, the upstream segment is performing well, and with the exception of our ongoing fr ustration with  Kashagan and some disappointment with the startup of Angola LNG, we are confident about our future  production growth and the increase in free cash flow that it will generate.

file: TTE - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 28April2015 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The first quarter environment was marked by much lower oil prices, but there were some mitigating effects,  mainly the Downstream environment was very positive with strong European re fining margins and better  conditions for marketing. Also, we were helped by the first positive result of our cost reduction program, higher  production, as well as the stronger dollar.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the Upstream, we had significant production growth in first quarter 2015, 7% more than fourth quarter 2014  and 10% more than first quarter 2014. The most important contribution to the higher production was the new  ADCO contract which took effect on January 1. This adds 160,000 barrels per day of oil that we plan to grow an d  profit from over the next 40 years.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Taking all of this into account, adjusted net operating income for Upstream segment was $1.4 billion in the first  quarter of 2015, compared to $1.6 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014. This represents a decrease of 15%, which is  significantly lower than the 30% drop in Brent. The price impact was mitigated by the positive effect on our cost  reduction program, production growth, the lag effect on gas prices, and smaller differentials between Brent and  our realized liquid prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We do not usually comment on the quarter OpEx number, but they can vary depending on a number of factors,  but the trend is clear and our first quarter OpEx is running well below the 2014 average. Most of this cost  reduction is linked to our self-help program, which targets saving of $800 million for the year in the Upstream.  And assuming that oil prices remain at this level, we would expect to see more cost deflation as we move through  the year. In countries, where we have cost in local currency, the stronger dollar has a positive e ffect on our result.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition, Refining & Chemicals is executing its cost reduction program with a target of $600 million of savings  by 2017. With these plans, we will achieve our 2017 objective to reduce the European capacity by 20%, and we will  reduce the breakeven of each of our European refineries to less than $20 per ton.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The Refining & Chemicals contribution will fluctuate with market conditions and margin, but we are better able to  capture value because these restructuring efforts have made us stronger and more responsive to the environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We have fully impaired our onshore field in Libya, which is most of the charge, as well as our producing blocks in  Y emen. As you know, we are very focused on managing costs and cash, particularly given the current oil price  environment. We are not betting on a quick rebound but we believe that fundamentals will eventually push prices  higher, although we cannot say when. Using certain initiatives like the scrip dividend and hybrid financing, we  estimate that we can manage our gearing around 30% this year. By 2017, we will more than cover the dividend  with free cash flow.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the near-term, our strategy is to concentrate on delivering the new startups, eight of them this year including  the three that are already producing. At the same time, we are reducing our CapEx and OpEx to lower our  breakeven in all segments and increase our free cash flow. The first quarter result shows that Total is resilient in a  tough environment and we are positioning the company to be the strongest player by 2017, regardless of oil prices.

file: TTE - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 27April2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Brent has rebounded since February, but I remind you that the first quarter was very tough particularly at the  start. There were 11 days in January when Brent closed below $30 per barrel. The intraday low was $27 per barrel,  something we have not seen since 2003. Brent averaged $34 per barrel in the first quarter, a decrease of more  than 20% quarter-to-quarter and almost 40% year-on-year. The U.K. gas pipe fell to $4.3 per million btu, a drop  of more than 25% compared to the previous quarter and more than 40% compared to a year ago.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The net result for Marketing & Services decreased compared to the previous quarter. I remind you that the fourth  quarter include a positive contribution of about $300 million in new energies from SunPower related to the  Quinto solar plant. And there were also the impact of asset sales, mainly the Totalgaz business compared to last  year result. Again, the important point is that Downstream generated $1.7 billion of cash in line with the $7  billion  objective for the year.

file: TTE - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We maintained the pressure on costs and compared to our 2014 base. Our objective is to reduce OpEx by $3.5  billion in 2017 and $4 billion in 2018. The contrast this quarter is in line with our expectations. Quarter for quarter,  E&P technical costs are down by 7%. E&P OpEx is at $5.6 per BOE, so we are on track to achieve our cost  reduction target of $5.5 per BOE for this year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As usual, I will review the numbers by segment and then go to the Q&A. We have now four reporting segments. In  the Upstream, we have E&P, plus the new segment, Gas, Renewables & Power. In the Downstream, we have  Refining & Chemicals, plus Marketing & Services. You have the pro forma splits from past periods, and I will be  referring to these numbers for all of the segments.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Starting with E&P. First quarter 2017 adjusted net operating income for E&P was $1.4 billion compared to $0.4  billion a year ago and $1 billion in the previous quarter. Brent has recovered from a year ago, and our average  hydrocarbon price realization was $38 per BOE in the first quarter, an increase of 44% year-to-year and 6%  quarter-to-quarter. Production increased by 4% on the year-to-year and, on a quarter-to-quarter basis, to 2.57  million barrels per day. We are targeting production growth of more than 4% this year. About 2/3 of the increase in  2017 is coming from ramp-ups on projects that started last year, the largest being Kashagan.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The moment the new 2017 started, the main contributor is Moho Nord, which started as planned in March and will  add about 30,000 barrels per day, net, in 2017. The Barnett acquisition made a positive contribution to production  growth in the first quarter. The Al Shaheen field in Qatar will begin adding production from the third quarter. While  there may be some impact on the full implementation of the OPEC cuts, the main message is that we have  effectively de-risked the production growth story for 2017.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As we increase production, all else equal, cash flow from E&P will continue to increase. Adjusted cash flow from  operations in this quarter was $3 billion, an increase of 63% from last year and 5% from the previous quarter,  basically in line with our published 2017 sensitivities. Operationally, we announced today that E&P sanctioned the  first of its 10 major projects, Phase 1 on the Aguada Pichana Este development of the giant Vaca Muerta shale  play in Argentina.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Total is the second largest acreage holder in the Vaca Muerta with more than 300,000 net acres and will be the  operator of Aguada Pichana Este with 41%. The project benefits from the low-cost environment, existing capacity  in the Aguada Pichana gas processing facilities and an attractive gas price set by the Argentina authorities. So,  we are very pleased to be moving forward in the next wave of Upstream development.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving onto our new Upstream segment. Gas, Renewables & Power contributed $61 million of adjusted net  operating income in the first quarter compared to $73 million a year ago and $132 million in the previous quarter.  The bulk of the GRP results are coming from our well-established Downstream gas business, including LNG  trading. These businesses are growing steadily and delivering results.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The results also include our new battery business from the Saft acquisition last year, and we are pleased with the  way it is performing. We cannot comment on some forward results, but I think most of you know this is a difficult  time for upstream solar cell producers. Looking forward, I remind you that we are expanding our gas business,  including new opportunities with LNG FSRUs in Ivory Coast, Pakistan and Brazil, as well as a new partnership in  Singapore for LNG bunker fuel.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Operationally, over the past two months, we sanctioned two major petrochemical projects. In the U.S., we formed  a joint venture to expand our petrochemical on the Texas Gulf Coast. Total will have 50% of the venture with  strong industrial partners, Nova and Borealis. The main thrust of the JV is to build a 1 million ton a year ethane  steam cracker for $1.7 billion at our Port Arthur site, allowing us to capture significant synergies. The deal is  consistent with our long-term view that gas will be plentiful in the U.S. and provide us with advantaged ethane  feedstock and low-cost energy.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We also announced a $450 million expansion project at our site in Daesan, South Korea. It will take advantage of  low-cost propane to produce ethylene for the Chinese market and capture significant brownfield synergies. These  new projects are examples of our strategy to take advantage of existing world-class platforms to capture profitable  growth opportunities linked to advantaged feedstocks and to benefit from the low-cost environment to sanction  cost-competitive projects.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The group's effective tax rate was 31% compared to 23% last year and 31% in the previous quarter. The rate for  the E&P is sensitive to change in oil price, and it has moved from a negative minus 48% a year ago to 42% in the  first quarter. The Downstream tax rate is relatively stable around 25%, 30%. With Brent in the $56 per barrel  range, we would expect the effective tax rate for the group to be around 30%, 35%.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We announced the sale of major E&P assets in Gabon for $350 million in the first quarter. We are discussing the  sale of our TotalErg retail business in Italy and some E&P assets in the North. Asset sales proceeds increase our  ability to take advantage of the current environment and add resources to the portfolio, as we have done with  recent deals in Brazil, Uganda and the U.S.

file: TTE - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 26April2018 815 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And on the top of it, we also announced that we will implement a buyback plan to buy up to $5 billion in – with the  idea which was the idea to share part of the oil price upside with our shareholders, and this plan has begun. We  bought back an additional 5 million shares for $300 million in the last two months, between February and March.  And to be clear, more than $70 per barrel.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Of course, we are very pleased with recent share price evolution – increase, I would say. But we'll continue to buy  back shares as it was announced in order to continue to share this oil prices upside with all shareholders. So after  I make these remarks, which are obviously very important and because we put into action our commitments to our  shareholders, I leave the floor to Patrick, our CFO, to review the first quarter results.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Looking at the segment, first quarter 2018 adjusted net operating income for E&P was $2.2 billion, up 58%  compared a year ago, and 21% versus the previous quarter. Compared to first quarter last year, Brent increased  by 24%, and our average realized hydrocarbon price increased by 25%. Production grew to 2.7 million boe per  day in the first quarter, an increase of 5% from a year ago and 3% from the previous quarter, despite the end of  the Mahakam license in Indonesia.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: There is a record level of quarterly production. The previous high was 2.66 million barrel per day in 2003. We  benefited from major ramp-ups including Moho Nord, Kashagan, Yamal LNG where the first of three trains is  producing 6.4 million ton a year, well above the nameplate capacity of 5.5 million ton a year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Before turning to cash flow, we note that the differential between Brent and our average realized liquid price  increased to $6.5 per barrel in the first quarter of 2018 from $4.5 a barrel a year ago and $3.7 a barrel in the  previous quarter. This is mainly the impact of growing Canadian volumes at a time when exports are pipeline- bound and netbacks are very weak. This is an exceptional situation not linked to higher oil prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: May I remind you that in terms of our oil price sensitivities, the calculation are made using constant differential, so,  in fact, it should be used with the realized liquid prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the Gas, Renewables & Power segment, adjusted net operating income in the first quarter was $115 million  compared to $61 million a year ago and $232 million in the previous quarter, thanks to better result from the solar  business.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Finally, looking at the corporate numbers, the group's effective tax rate increased to 40% from 31% a year ago  and 32% in the previous quarter. The rate for E&P increased to 48% in the first quarter as a result of higher oil  and gas prices, and the share of E&P within the group results was much larger as well. The Downstream tax rate  is relatively stable at around 25%, 30%.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: To summarize, we have a good start to the year. We are performing in line with our plans. The balance sheet is  strong and the environment is favorable. Brent has been above $60 per barrel since early November or nearly six  consecutive months. And we have been above $70 per barrel for most of April.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Although product demand is strong, European refining margin has been volatile in an environment of rapidly rising  oil prices. Petrochem margin have remained fairly stable at high level for more than a year supported by strong  underlying demand growth. At the current oil price level, obviously, we have more cash flow than anticipated and  we can execute comfortably our return to shareholder policy and that's what we are doing.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: According to what we said there, again, we told you that we wanted to take advantage of favorable [ph] CapEx  (14:43) to invest [ph] consistently (14:41) and acquire some assets to create value. So what we have executed  during this last quarter was, in fact, deals which were prepared in the previous year, I mean, where the price of  the barrel was lower. And we told you that we will focus on where we are good, which is to play to our strengths,  in particular in some [indiscernible] (15:07) Middle East, the North Sea, Africa, deep offshore, LNG and in  Downstream to focus on petrochemicals, retail and lubricants and that if there's a future, we will expand and we  are expanding along the integrated gas and power value chain.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The first one is that it's a concession where there's a potential oil increase from 320,000 barrel per day to 450,000  barrel per day at 100% share. And more important than that, there is a very large gas gap, 5 Tcf of gap to be  developed. And there is a change of policy in Abu Dhabi, a country we know very well, where Abu Dhabi has  decided to really monetize its domestic gas resource.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And so part of the focus on Umm Shaif because there there is a big upside and the fiscal terms on gas are very –  it is a necessitation, be designed to be an incentive to produce this domestic gas. So there is an upside on Umm  Shaif on gas, and this is why we focused to share there. We have taken a smaller share on Lower Zakum  concession, 5%, because it's a more traditional oil concession, I would say, but part of our loyalty to Abu Dhabi  was we were offered to be on both concessions, so 5% on one side and 20% on Umm Shaif.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: It would be a world-class 1.5 million ton cracker based on advantage feedstock, first refinery of gas because there  is a strong integration there, but also access to some ethane and LPGs. So it's a start of a new adventure with our  friends of Saudi Aramco and it's fitting very well with the idea that we focus on CapEx in refining and chemicals on  the integrated platforms where we spend a lot of money to put all the logistics in place with the refinery and now  we want to capitalize on that together.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And then on the top of it, we have announced last week another move in the field of integration gas to power,  which is the acquisition of the company called Direct Energie, which is a company, which is in the field of gas and  power retail marketing but also a power producer. This company – so it's an opportunistic move which should not  surprise you. We announced you, but we want to build a business in the low carbon business going downstream  the chain of gas, gas to power.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
