texts.text: But we announced in October that we want to establish ourselves as in a position in the French gas and power  retail market with a brand called Total Spring. In fact, the things have accelerated because these enhancements  created another opportunity, the acquisition of Direct Energie. After we announced our entry in the French gas  and power retail markets in October, we've seen that the share of Direct Energie has decreased and the main  shareholders have decided that there was maybe right time for them to sell. So we have somewhere shaken the  market when we entered and we are gathering the fruit much quicker than expected.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: This level, which will become a quite interesting business, but Direct Energie gives us again access to midsize  and will accelerate our development. In the portfolio of Direct Energie, there were all the interesting assets, in  particular they are some gas-fired power plants that they acquired at quite a low cost in 2015, 2016. So we will  have 1.2 gigawatts of power generation there, which will come at the top by the way of the power generation gas- fired power plants we have in the Total portfolio.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: This is interesting because it's part of the integration between when you make a retail business you don't go only  on trading to acquire power, but it's also good to have some physical assets that you produce yourself with a good  cost of access, which would be the case with these assets and they have also renewable business, 500  megawatts which could grow to 2 gigawatts so this fitting well as well with our strategy, power strategy.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So at the end, what we want to build in line with what we explained you and I think for some of you will follow us  very precisely, remember, two years ago, there was a puzzle to explain the strategy so I think the pieces of the  puzzles are put in place now, one after one so we'll show you a bit scheme and next September the strategy  meeting, you will see how the puzzle is going together and this is quite logical. Now we are expanding a lot on the  gas business. We have become number two in the LNG trade. There is a logic to sell this gas to customers, or  gas to power integration and this go downstream to retail marketing including having in our portfolio some  capacity of power production like gas or renewables.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We'll be clear. We don't have any ambition to become a utility. We just want – we follow the value chain to get out  of this gas value chains maximum value like we have done in the oil business with some success during years  and years. This is what we target and obviously, we're not at the full capacity to produce the power we distribute  because we'll buy and trade like we are doing already by the way some of the power that we will distribute to our  customers.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So this is the idea, I think by doing these moves again what we want to do is enlarge the spectrum of activity of  Total and to develop integration the gas evaluation and gas to power and to have access at the end of the day, to  some areas, which are growing as a grow their potential growth in this market. And I think that for shareholders,  it's a way also to give them access beyond traditional oil and gas to businesses, which offer higher growth for the  future.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: If you remember, I told you that $2 billion an acquisition could be $3 billion minus $1 billion, $5 billion minus $3  billion, $7 billion minus $5 billion. But we'll be active, of course, on the sale of assets. And I would make one  comment that, clearly, in this type of environment, $70, it's easier and could be even good to sell some upstream  assets today. We are not so active in the last two years because we didn't want to lose value, but at this level of  price, there are – we can be again countercyclical in the other way, which is to sell when the price are better.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Last one, don't believe all the rumors of bankers and Total is not interested by acquiring neither Santos nor Oil  Search. We have enough interest in PNG with 38% oil and gas, solar energy with 27.5%. So I know people think  – some people are giving rumors, but don't believe all of them. We are in line and we will stay in line with the  strategy we have described to you, to focus on our core areas.

file: TTE - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 26April2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Total has been moving at a very rapid pace in the recent year, continuing to deliver production growth, cost  reduction, portfolio management and capital discipline. One of the highlight marking our progress has been the  creation of the new integrated Gas, Renewables & Power, or iGRP segment. Effective this year, the LNG  business, including the Upstream and Midstream operation, is being reported as part of the iGRP segment. So,  we have provided the restated past results, and the current results reflect this new format. Also this year, we have  revised some of our indicator, and we have, of course, implemented IFRS 16.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Operationally, Upstream is on target and performing very well. And our main priority is to FID new major project,  like Mero 2 in Brazil and Arctic LNG 2 in Russia, to lock in low development costs and ensure profitable growth  well into the next decade.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I would also like to point out that exploration has delivered some good news recently in our core North Sea area  we made the Glengorm gas CNOOC discovery, the largest in the area since 2008 on a blog that was part of the  Maersk acquisition. And in deep offshore South Africa, we made a significant play opening discovery with the  Brulpadda well.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the redefined E&P segment, first quarter adjusted net operating income was $1.7 billion, compared to $1.8  billion a year ago and $2.0 billion in the previous quarter. Brent averaged $63 per barrel in the first quarter,  compared to $69 per barrel in the fourth quarter. Our average liquid price realization was stable quarter-to-quarter  at $59 per barrel, reflecting mainly the rebound in Canadian differentials. Natural gas, however, was down about  10% from previous quarter to $4.5 per million btu, mainly due to mild weather in the first quarter. And I should  point out that exploration expenses increased by about $100 million in the first quarter compared to the previous  quarter and the same quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving to iGRP, this new segment spearheads our ambitions in fast-growing integrated gas LNG and low-carbon  electricity businesses. Overall, LNG sales were 7.7 million tonne in the first quarter, double compared to 3.8  million tonne in the first quarter last year, and stable compared to 7.9 million tonne in the previous quarter. iGRP  adjusted net operating income was $0.6 billion in the first quarter of 2019, an increase of 23% year-on-year. iGRP  generated $0.6 billion of cash flow before working capital changes in the first quarter, a 50% increase compared  to the first quarter last year, reflecting mainly the 50% increase in our equity LNG production. Quarter-on-quarter,  iGRP cash flow before working capital changes was stable despite the sharp drop in NBP and LNG spot prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Total's portfolio of LNG project is unmatched in the industry. Yamal LNG and Ichthys LNG are ramping up, and  Cameron LNG Train 1 is set to start in May. We signed a definitive agreement for our entry into Arctic LNG 2, as  well as the gas agreement with the state of Papua New Guinea to clear the way for Papua LNG. In North  America, we are working with our partners to add two additional trains at Cameron, as well progressing the ECA  project in Baja, Mexico, and we further committed to invest in Tellurian's Driftwood LNG project.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In addition, we are actively pursuing the expansion of Nigeria LNG, with an FID target by the end of this year. By  2020, we expect our LNG business to grow to 40 million tonne a year or 10% of the global market. And the new  iGRP segment provides us with a platform to effectively optimize profitability along the entire LNG value chain.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The iGRP segment is active in many growing market. In the first quarter, we announced a 10-year LNG supply  agreement with Guanghui Energy in China that calls for 0.7 million tonne a year that will source from our global  portfolio. On the marketing side, we have merged Total Spring into Direct Energie, and the combined entity is now  trading as Total Direct Energie. We also announced that our Saft battery unit is creating a joint venture with the  Chinese group Tianneng to develop and manufacture advanced lithium-ion cell for EV, e-bike and energy storage  solutions or ESS. China is the largest and fastest-growing market for EV and lithium-ion batteries.

file: TTE - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 30July2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Patrick de la Chevardière, Chief Financial Officer  Thank you. Hello, everyone and thank you for calling on a Friday afternoon. First, I will comment on  the results and then we will go to the Q&A. I will not take too much time on the first quarter  environment. Globally, oil was trading around $75 per barrel, but the price of gas remained low and  the refining environment was still difficult, even if margins recovered.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Looking at the first quarter results compared to the fourth quarter ‘09, production was 2.43 million  barrels of oil equivalent a day, an increase of 2.1%. Adjusted net income was $3.2 billion, an  increase of 3% compared to the fourth quarter, and I would remind you that TOTAL was among the  most resilient companies in 2009 in term of results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, now I will comment on each of the segments. In the Upstream, the five major projects that we  started in 2009 are performing well and in line with our expectations. The second train at Yemen  LNG started up in March in advance of our summer target date.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: First quarter production was 2.43 million barrel of oil equivalent a day, an increase of 4.5%  compared to the same quarter last year and more than 2% compared to the previous quarter. Part  of the increase is coming from our LNG volumes, which grew by 38% year-over-year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Patrick de la Chevardière, Chief Financial Officer  Hello and thank you for calling. As usual, I will comment on the results and then we’ll go to the  Q&A. The second quarter environment was not so different from the first quarter. Our realized  liquids price was up slightly to about $75 per barrel, natural gas realizations were down by about  5% to just below $5 per million Btu.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So now I will comment on each of the segments. In the Upstream, in terms of commodity prices the  average Brent price increased by 2.4% compared to the first quarter. And our liquid price realization  increased by close to 1% to about $75 per barrel. The larger differential between our liquid price  realization and Brent was mainly due to the mix effect including the impact of turnaround in the  North Sea. The average natural gas price realization in the second quarter decreased to $4.82 per  million Btu, down 5% from the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This reflects weakness in the spot market in both the U.S. and the U.K. This price does not include  sales of LNG from our equity affiliates, notably the new production from Qatar and Yemen.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Operationally the segment is performing very well. As I said in my opening remarks, second quarter  production was 2.36 million barrel of oil equivalent per day. The major projects that we started up  last year, plus a second train at Yemen LNG that started up in April are ramping up as expected.  We also benefited from higher production in Nigeria although the situation is not yet back to normal  position levels there.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Production volumes and average idle time prices were slightly lower, but we had a positive mix  effect the stronger contribution from gas trading and the lower effective tax rate. The effective tax  rate for Upstream decreased to 58% in the second quarter from 60% in the first quarter. As we said  in May, the first quarter was a bit higher than normal due to some adjustments. And the 58 to 59%  rate is more reasonable in for this environment. The annualized second quarter Upstream ROACE  continues to be very competitive at 21%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Regarding the drilling program in general, we recently created [inaudible] E&P segment to ensure  that there were safety and environmental procedures are of the highest standard. These task forces  deal respectively with drilling safety, subsea capture and containment and environmental  protection.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the record, we operate about 40 rigs simultaneously and a little more than 350 wells per year.  We have completed a review of our drilling operation and BOPs and they are in line with our  procedures.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We are very confident of our drilling procedures. They are well structured and technically  exhaustive and we expect them to be certified ISO 9001 later this year. So we believe [inaudible] is  in good shape and we look forward to presenting you with more detail during the strategic update in  September.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, some comments on the Downstream and Chemicals. Our European refining margin indicator  averaged $31.2 per ton in the second quarter. This reflects continued improvement compared to  last year but the environment for refining remains difficult.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In general we have a plan to reduce our footprint in Europe and achieve a 20% reduction in global  refining capacity between 2007 and 2011. We have completed the major process to form total debt  in Italy and this will allow us to improve our situation there. We will start up a new de-filterization  unit next month at our Port Arthur refinery on the Texas Gulf Coast that is part of the modernization  program there. And we have secured the financing for Dubai. This is a major step towards the  rebalancing our refining system to the East.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Just a word on the status of the Dunkirk refinery, we are appealing the recent court order to restart  the refinery. We have started the declassification process for the plant and this is a compulsory first  step for either shutting the refinery down completely or restarting it but our original project remain  unchanged.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second quarter results represent the best operating profit we have seen from this sector since  the third quarter of 2007. Our operation in Korea and Qatar are making strong contribution to the  sector. In the second quarter, we started up the world’s largest oil cartel at Ras Laffan in Qatar and  this should add significantly to the bottom-line for years to come. This is in line with our strategy to  develop base chemicals in the Middle East, based on cheap ethylene feedstock and in Asia.

file: TTE - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 29July2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Hello and thank you for calling. As usual, I will make some brief comments and then we will go to the Q&A. We  reported our second quarter results. Compared to last year, the adjusted earnings per share increased by 6% to  $1.80 per share, reflecting the higher oil and gas price environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: First, effective April 1st our 12% share of Novatek is included in the income from equity affiliates and we are  reporting our shale operation, which was 115,000 barrel per day net to Total in the second quarter. Under the  IFRS rules, we have to amortize a large portion of the difference between the purchase price of $4 billion and the  income from Novatek was reduced by about $35 million of amortization. So our results include a net of $15  million. We expect this contribution to increase over time as Novatek's position grows and domestic gas prices in  Russia increase.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The environment, as you know, remains favorable for the upstream, challenging for the downstream, particularly  in Europe, and stable for the chemicals. The Brent price has been well above $100 per barrel. European refining  margins have been squeezed by high oil prices on one side and weak product demand on the other. Chemicals  perform well and even without strong growth in the global economy, there has been good demand for our  chemical products. The euro/dollar exchange rate has been volatile, leaving the dollar weaker against the euro. We  are a dollar company, but this affected our results in euro. Macro concern over sovereign debt issues have affected  euro index equity markets and we believe this has continued to have an impact on our share price.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Operationally, we are continuing to move at a very active pace. This is illustrated by our second quarter highlights  that include launching the Ekofisk South and Eldfisk II developments in the Norwegian North Sea, the start of the  Angostura Phase II production in Trinidad and Tobago, the third discovery on Block 17/06 in Angola, plus a gas  and condensate discovery in Bolivia, the acquisition of a 49% stake in the shale gas play in Poland, and the  acquisition of an additional 25% interest in the Tempa Rossa project that raised our share to 75%.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the downstream and chemicals, we are making major changes in the portfolio. The sale of CEPSA has been  completed and we should receive the funds today or Monday. This is €3.7 billion or about $5.3 billion. This marks  our exit from the downstream business in Spain, meaning also that we have already exceeded our target to reduce  worldwide refining capacity by 20%.

file: TTE - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 27July2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Hello, this is Patrick de la Chevardière speaking. Before commenting on the second quarter results, I will start  with a brief update on Elgin. The gas leak was stopped on May 15, and the situation is under control. We are  preparing the cement that will permanently plug and abandon the G4 well and we expect to complete this by mid- September.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We are continuing to add new production. So far this year we have started up four new fields: Usan, Islay, Bongkot  South and Halfaya and these were delivered on time. Between now and the end of the year Angola LNG, Sulige  and Kashagan should start up as well. This week we launched the Tempa Rossa Oil Project in Italy. Total is the  operator with a 75% share, and we can confirm that the project economics are very good using our $80 per barrel  Brent scenario.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Tempa Rossa is planned to start up in early 2016. I would also add that we were successful in increasing our share  of Ichthys LNG from 24% to 30%, and as you know this is an excellent project in a core future growth area for  Total. So, we remain very confident about the progress we're making with portfolio of major projects.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: From a volume perspective, Upstream production was 2.26 million barrel of oil equivalent per day, a 5% decrease  compared to the first quarter. The new start-ups had a positive impact of about 40,000 barrels per day compared  to first quarter 2012, but this was offset by seasonal maintenance and normal declines, so again we can attribute  this decrease essentially to the one-off incidents.

file: TTE - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 26July2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In development operations, we remain focused on delivering our portfolio of high-quality project on time and in  budget. We are entering an unprecedented period of start-up over the next four years. We are on schedule with  our major start-ups for 2014, namely Ekofisk, CLOV, Laggan/Tormore, and Ofon II. We launched Moho Nord in  March and Egina in June, and I remind you that these are both giant deep-offshore oil project operated by Total.  So we continue to increase the visibility on our production growth.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Refining & Chemicals continue to advance an ambitious restructuring program with major projects on our main  integrated platforms. At Normandy, we have nearly completed the modernization project. At Antwerp, we  announced a new modernization project. This includes closing a cracker, maximizing synergies, and reducing  dependence on external conversion feedstock. And at Port Arthur, the steam cracker was modified to optimize its  ability to use ethane as a feedstock.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We recognize the importance of the dividend to our shareholders and our commitment to provide them with  sustainable and competitive returns. Our outlook for the environment remains favorable, and our confidence in  delivering growth increases as we continue to execute.

file: TTE - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 30July2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Hello. Patrick de La Chevardière, here. As usual I will make some short comment about the quarter and then go  straight to the Q&A. Looking at the second quarter environment, Brent was close to $110 per barrel. Natural gas  prices were weaker affecting the lower NBP price and in the Downstream, European refining margins were really  depressed at $11 per ton.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Like you, we will have to rely on the operators for revised guidance for Kashagan and Angola LNG and except  those two fields I can tell you that the portfolio of major projects is progressing essentially as planned. And most  of these projects like CLOV are operated by Total.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And finally on the financial results, adjusted cash flow from operations for the  second quarter was $6.2 billion  stable to the previous quarter despite the lower upstream volumes. Organic CapEx was $7.2 billion, in line with  our budget. Since the start of the second quarter we have announced more than $2.5 billion of asset sales,  including our interest in the Shah Deniz project in Azerbaijan, $1.5 billion; our Total gas LPG business, $0.5  billion; and our coal mining affiliate in South Africa, $0.5 billion also; and our CCP Composites affiliate.

file: TTE - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to the business segments; we start with the Upstream. In the second quarter despite the situation in  Y emen and the start of the seasonal maintenance, production decreased by only 4% compared to the first quarter,  and it was up by 12% compared to a year ago. The seasonal maintenance impact is temporary. In the coming  months, we will start three additional major projects, Surmont Phase 2, Laggan, and GLNG, making seven  major  start-ups for 2015, including the four that are already producing. Vega Pleyade will start-up around the turn of the  year. So even without the restart of Y emen LNG, we are confident that we will achieve our target of more than 8%  production growth for 2015.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Adjusted net operating income for Upstream was $1.6 billion, an increase of 15% compared to the first quarter.  Brent was up by 15% quarter-over-quarter to more than $60 per barrel. Gas prices were weaker affected by lower  oil-linked LNG prices as well as lower prices for NBP in Europe, but on balance higher liquid prices more than  offset lower gas prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: OpEx fell significantly and our cost-cutting program is on track to exceed the $800 million of Upstream savings  targeted for this year. Exploration expenses were down by more than $200 million quarter to quarter, and this is  another sustainable benefit related to the action plan we launched at the beginning of the year to mitigate the fall  in oil prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Last point on the Upstream. We recently started up Dalia Phase 1A. This is an infill drilling project on deep  offshore Angola Block 17. It produce 30,000 barrels per day at 100% and helps to maintain the 9-year old Dalia  FPSO at production plateau of around 200,000 barrels per day. This is a good example of a deep offshore  brownfield project that has strong economics even in this lower price environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, moving to the Downstream. The European Refining Margin Indicator or ERMI averaged $54 per ton for the  quarter, a level we haven't seen since 2008. The ERMI was strong reaching high well above $60 per ton in the  second quarter. The average for July is above $50 per ton. We can see that we undere stimated the positive impact  that lower prices would have on demand and it is the same story for petrochemicals and marketing margin.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Going forward, we have the strongest production growth among our peers. Our company -wide cost reduction plan  is gaining momentum and we are reducing CapEx. Our second quarter result demonstrate our integrated model is  working very well. We are continuing to execute and deliver on our growth project as well as continuing to reduce  the breakeven in both the Upstream and the Downstream.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We generated $10 billion of adjusted cash flow from operations in the first half of the year despite the drop in the  price of oil. And our strategy is to continue to improve the underlying profitability of Total even in a relatively  weak price environment. Please keep in mind that we will make our strategic outlook presentation in London on  September 23. So there are certain questions that may have to wait.

file: TTE - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 28July2016 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The environment has been volatile including, for example, the Brexit vote. Oil prices recovered in the second  quarter from very low levels in the first quarter, and our otherwise realized hydrocarbon price increased by 25% to  $33 per boe.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: At the start of the third quarter, volatility remains the dominant theme in the market and oil prices are again under  pressure. Our response to this volatility is to continue contemplating on achieving our goal of being competitive in  any environment by reducing our cash breakeven, executing on our project and delivering results.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the second quarter, we announced a reorganization of the Group with two main objectives. First; to improve  efficiency by putting in place global services for all of our businesses; and second, to promote the development of  a new business segment for gas, renewable and power along the gas and electricity value chain. We are  continuing to reshape our portfolio by reducing specialty chemicals with a coming sale of Atotech on one side;  and on the other side, by investing in oil and add Downstream businesses and new energy. We are adding the  GAPCO marketing asset in East Africa; the battery company Saft, and Lampiris; a gas and power distribution  company in Belgium. Thanks to Atotech sale, we confirm that our net asset sales for the year should be in line  with our $2 billion target.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking at the business segment results, we start with Upstream. In line with our previously announced targets,  second quarter production increased by more than 5% year-over-year and by more than 4% for the first half  compared to a year ago, mainly due to a number of recent start-ups and ramp ups including Laggan, Vega  Pleyade, GLNG and Angola LNG. Compared to the first quarter, production was down slightly by 2%, mainly due  to scheduled maintenance and the PSC effect linked to the increase in oil prices.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the second half, we are looking forward to the start-up of Incahuasi in Bolivia and Kashagan. We confirm the  4% growth objective for the full year. Adjusted net operating income for the Upstream was $1.1 billion in the  second quarter or more than double the level of the first quarter. In addition to 25% increase in the average  hydrocarbon realization, we are continuing to cut costs and we are led off our target to reduce OpEx to $6.5 per  BOE this year from $7.4 per BOE last year. I confirm that our global OpEx saving will go beyond our target of $2.4  billion for the year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we reduce cost and increase volumes, we are becoming more sensitive to changes in the Brent price,  particularly to the upside as we move well above the breakeven point. Despite the 35% increase in Brent, gas  prices were still low, decreasing slightly in the second quarter compared to the first quarter, mainly due to a lag  effect on oil-linked contracts in Thailand and Indonesia.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking at cash which is our primary metric, the Upstream captured the higher oil price and generated $2.3 billion  of operating cash flow, before working capital changes in the second quarter, an increase of 25% from the first  quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving to resource renewal; the giant Al-Shaheen concession had the advantage of a very low breakeven and  will represent a net increase to our production of around 90,000 barrel per day for 25 years starting mid-2017. So  we are very pleased to have this to our portfolio. In addition, we can see strong production growth for the end of  the decade. We have several pre-FID projects that we are working on now in Angola, Brazil, Uganda, Argentina  and Papua New Guinea, to name just a few. So we are comfortable with the long-term growth potential in the  Upstream portfolio.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: A short comment about the contribution of equity affiliates to net operating income. The contribution in the second  quarter was very strong at 60% to $797 million. Affiliates in the Upstream generated $452 million mainly due to an  increase from Novatek Termokarstovoye and an increase in GLNG affiliates. Affiliates in the Downstream  generated $345 million, notably thanks to our world-class sites in Korea, Qatar and Saudi Arabia and mainly by  taking advantage of the good petrochemical environment. It was a good quarter for the affiliates and they are an  important part of the Group.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The evolution of our pre-dividend cash flow breakeven is very positive. For the first half, operating cash flow  before working capital changes was $7.7 billion and this cover our net investment of $7.7 billion. So we are  balanced with Brent averaging $40 per barrel in the first half of the year. The effective tax rate for the group was  22% in the second quarter. So we continue to have this mitigating effect related to the low oil and gas prices in  the Upstream. The take-up of the second quarter scrip dividend was 62%. So the cash portion of the dividend was  about $625 million.

file: TTE - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 27July2017 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Oil price volatility has dominated the environment. After finally breaking through $50 per barrel in the first quarter,  market sentiment is of course sending the average Brent price down by $4 per barrel or 8% to $49.6 per barrel in  the second quarter. European refining margins, however, have done well in the second quarter averaging $41 per  tonne, and petrochemical margins have continued to be good as well.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Regardless of the environment, we remain relentless in our pursuit of cost reduction. At mid-year, we are close to  our OpEx target of $5.5 per boe for 2017. Year-to-date organic CapEx was $6.9 billion for the group, and we are  capturing efficiencies there as well. We will continue to cut cost and these efforts continue to make us more  resilient in any environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Our average hydrocarbon price realization was $35.5 per BOE down from $37.9 per BOE in the first quarter.  Production was 2.5 million barrels per day, representing 3% growth compared to a year ago, but a decrease of  3% compared to the first quarter impact due to seasonal maintenance as was the case a year ago.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We are confident that production growth for 2017 will be more than 4%, so no change in thinking here. Mainly, on  the strength of adding the Al-Shaheen field in the second half plus Kashagan, Moho, and the other ongoing  project, which far offset the natural decline and the OPEC quota impact.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The new start-ups are making a strong contribution to the average operating cash flow per barrel, so we have a  positive mix effect that will be ongoing as we continue to start up more projects. Also, cash dividends from equity  affiliates increased by about $200 million compared to the first quarter, which is partly a timing effect and it  includes the semiannual dividend from Novatek as well as other affiliates like Nigeria LNG.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: It is important to note with Brent around $50 per barrel, the E&P segment operating cash flow covered its organic  CapEx for the second quarter and first half of this year. CapEx efficiency is improving and we are able to fund  growth with a lower level of investment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As the last point on E&P, the effective tax rate was 36% in the second quarter compared to 42% in the first  quarter. This reflects a mix effect and sensitivity to hydrocarbon prices. As a result, the effective tax rate for the  group was 28% compared to 31% in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving on to Gas, Renewables & Power segment, GRP contributed $95 million of adjusted net operating income  in the second quarter compared to $61 million in the first quarter thanks to better result from gas and power.

file: TTE - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Looking at this in more detail, Maersk is fully onboard now and we have Kashagan, Fort Hills, and Yamal LNG  continuing to ramp up. The start-ups of Ichthys, Kaombo, Tempa Rossa and Egina will show growth in the second  half and these are good cash accretive new barrels.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In addition to the Zinia 2, we have recently restarted infill drilling programs on major fields in our core areas and  we took FIDs on the Arcadia gas field at GLNG and a new phase of drilling for Al-Shaheen. The Gas,  Renewables, Power segment generated about $200 million of adjusted net operating income in the second  quarter, reflecting better results from the gas trading and new energy.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Earlier this month, we closed Engie LNG acquisition and this positions Total as the second largest player in the  fast growing LNG business. Also in LNG, we announced in May that we are taking a direct 10% stake in Arctic 2  in Russia, further expanding the LNG portfolio.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In July, we closed the acquisition of 73% of Direct Energie. We have Total representative on the board and the  offer period to acquire the remaining share has been launched. We are committed to growing along the gas- electricity chain and this acquisition is a big step toward achieving critical mass in our two largest markets for  electricity distribution, France and Belgium.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Turning to the Downstream. Refining & Chemicals contributed $821 million of adjusted net operating income in  the second quarter, an increase of 14% compared to the previous quarter. The European Refining Margin  Indicator recovered from a seasonally weak first quarter and averaged $35 per ton in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Petchem prices remain strong, but rising naphtha feedstock costs affected margins in Europe. We completed  some maintenance programs in the second quarter, the most important being Antwerp and Normandy petchem.  So we can expect better margin capture going forward.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the future growth in R&C, we are concentrating the investment on petrochemicals and targeting opportunities  to take advantage of low-cost feedstock. We have two ongoing expansion project in the U.S. and Korea. We also  launched two studies recently. That project in Saudi Arabia, with Saudi Aramco, to strengthen the integrated  SATORP platform and capture synergies, plus another project in Algeria with Sonatrach. And in France, we are  converting La Mède to a biorefinery and we'll be producing renewable biodiesel later this year.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And for the first half, the group generated a robust debt adjusted cash flow of $12.5 billion. Although oil price are  above $70 per barrel, we are relentless in our demand for discipline on investment and OpEx, including the rapid  capture of synergies from new assets. For the group, we have increased our cost reduction target for 2018 from  $4 billion to $4.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: With this strong growth in cash flows and discipline on spend, net cash flow was $3.9 billion for the quarter and  $5.1 billion for the first half. Profitability is also continuing to improve. Return on equity increased to 10.9% for the  12 months ended June 30, 2018. And ROACE of the group is now back above 10% for the first time since the oil  price crash. We are committed to maintain the strong balance sheet. And at the end of the second quarter, our  net debt to capital ratio was 16.5%. This is a small increase from the third quarter. Due to the timing of the AGM,  we made two dividend payments in the second quarter. So we made three dividend payment in the first half and  the cash out impacted our net debt.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We bought back 19 million shares in the second quarter bringing the total to 28 million shares for first half. The 28  million shares include 18 million shares to eliminate dilution from the scrip. We bought back an additional 10  million share for about $600 million as part of the $5 billion buyback announced in February. So in addition to  increasing the interim dividend by 3.2%, we are delivering on our commitment to share the oil price upside with  our shareholders with a buyback.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: This result demonstrated that we are taking advantage of the favorable environment. Production growth is  providing strong momentum for cash flow going forward. Our countercyclical strategy acquiring Maersk Oil and  Petrobras assets clearly rewarded us in the environment.

file: TTE - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 29October2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We reported another good quarter. Compared to the second quarter we are down slightly because  of lower refining margins and the reclassifications of Sanofi from equity affiliates to other  investments. Year-over-year our adjusted third quarter results in dollars are up by 20% and if we  exclude Sanofi we are up by 33%. Looking at the environment, the dollar has weakened against the  euro. Oil prices have been strong and this is in line with our macro view.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For natural gas, the third quarter reflects stronger prices, mainly in Europe and Asia, and refining  margins in Northwest Europe were significantly weaker in the third quarter than in the second  quarter. Our Upstream production of 2.3 million barrel of oil equivalent per day reflects a strong  4.3% growth versus the same quarter last year. This is among the best of the majors. And it  confirms that 2010 should be our best year in terms of production growth over the past 5 to 6 years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Upstream profitability is good. The annualized royalty for the third quarter is 20%. Even though  volumes were a little lower and the contribution from gas marketing and trading was not as high as  in the second quarter. Globally the Upstream is performing well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And to illustrate this point, notice that our year-to-date average oil equivalent price increased by  24% in dollar compared to the same period last year. Our year-to-date net income per barrel  increased by 29% and our Upstream net operating income increased by 39%. So, our Upstream  profitability has increased by more than the oil and gas price. And this shows that we are adding  new high-quality production that is delivering higher returns.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Downstream segment is sensitive to the environment but, as we said in our strategy  presentation, we have taken steps to strengthen the underlying profitability here.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you know, we have become more active in using acquisition and investment to upgrade the  portfolio. So far this year, we have announced about $6 billion of acquisitions, including mainly a  deal in Uganda that is pending, the GLNG deal in Australia, the UTS acquisition in Canada that  closed last month and the Barnett Shale joint venture at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Second, we have launched four major projects so far this year, Surmont in Canada and Laggan  Tormor in the U.K. we are launching in the first-half. CLOV in Angola was sanctioned in August.  And the development plan for Alfaia has been approved, so it is launched as well. In addition, the  operator of GLNG in Australia has received government approval. So, we should be able to launch  it by year end.

file: TTE - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 28October2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We reported a clean set of third quarter results that are in line with the second quarter. Adjusted earnings per  share was stable despite the weaker environment. Upstream result decreased mainly due to lower hydrocarbon  prices and higher upstream tax rates. The Downstream posted a strong increase despite the decrease in European  refining margins. Not included in these numbers is $1.5 billion of gains on asset sales and $7 billion in cash flow  that we collected in the third quarter. It is important to point out that our strategy to unlock value by redeploying  capital from major assets to gross assets is working very well.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the environment, the Brent price has remained well above $100 per barrel. European refining margins have  been volatile but on average, weak for the quarter due to high oil prices on one side and weak product demand on  the other. Chemicals have also been affected by softer demand during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In the Downstream and Chemicals, we announced a very broad reorganization project that will lead to creation of  two new segments, an industrial one and a commercial one. Upstream production was 2.3 million barrel of oil  equivalent per day in line with the previous quarter. The ramp up of Pazflor and Trinidad had a positive but small  impact on the third quarter production. Normal seasonal maintenance was slightly lower than in the second  quarter. Asset sales, mainly CEPSA and normal declines partly offset these positives.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We are very confident about our outlook for 2012 production growth above 3%. In 2012, we will benefit from the  ramp up on Pazflor, Trinidad and Islay. Novatek will continue to grow. Libya is being restored and we will have  new startups like Usan and Angola LNG.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Average net operating income per barrel in the third quarter decreased compared to the second quarter. Two  obvious factors that are driving part of the decrease are the lower hydrocarbon price and the higher Upstream tax  rates.

file: TTE - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 31October2012 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The adjusted results do not include certain special items. We impaired the Barnett Shale gas field, and there was a  one-off tax in France on crude and refined product inventories. Now I will make some brief comments on the  business segments.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Adjusted net operating income for Upstream increased by 10%, to $3.6 billion. This increase was mainly due to  strong contributions from project startups, equity affiliates, and downstream gas activities. Upstream production  increased slightly in the third quarter. This was due to the ramp-up of Pazflor, Usan, Halfaya, and Bongkot South.  This growth was partially offset by seasonal maintenance and normal decline.  The contribution from equity affiliates increased, and our LNG business is performing well. We increased the  number of cargo redirected this quarter to 14, for a total of 33 so far this year, despite incidents at Yemen LNG and  maintenance at Snohvit. Over the first nine months of the year, LNG represented 18% of production and 24% of  Upstream results. Together with LNG, offshore development remains a core area of our business.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In terms of production, the fourth quarter will be impacted by the recent heavy flooding in Nigeria and high levels  of planned maintenance in offshore Nigeria, the UK, North Sea, and Qatar. Production for the fourth quarter  should benefit from the startup of South Mahakam in Indonesia, ahead of schedule, the expected startup of  Angola LNG, and the ramp-up of Usan, Halfaya, and Atla.  We are still working towards our goal of a gradual restart of Elgin-Franklin by year-end or in early 2013.  Assuming that fourth quarter production is relatively stable compared to the third quarter, full-year production  could be down slightly compared to 2011.

file: TTE - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 31October2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In the Upstream, adjusted net operating income for the segment was $3.1 billion in the third quarter, in line with  the second quarter. Stronger oil and gas price were offset mainly by higher exploration charges, higher taxes, and  a negative production mix effect. The mix effect included a decrease in better than average barrels, for example in  Libya, and also a lower contribution from equity affiliates, mainly Nigeria LNG.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the development projects, we provide an update last month at out Investor Day, showing that we are on the  track with the major project scheduled to start up through 2017. For project sanctions, we are moving forward as  planned with the recent final investment decisions for Vega Pleyade in Argentina and Fort Hills in Canada. Vega  Pleyade is a high return conventional offshore gas and condensate field that we will develop using horizontal  drilling, and we expect first production in the second half of 2015. Fort Hills is a giant oil sand mining project in  Canada with estimated CapEx of CAD13.5 billion to develop more than 3 billion barrel of resources. We expect  first production by end of 2017 and then a plateau of 180,000 barrels per day that will remain stable for decades.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We also announced that Total is part of the consortium that was awarded the Libra pre-sold field in Brazil. We are  pleased to add these giant resources to our portfolio, especially at less than $1 per barrel. Total's share in the  bonus is $1.4 billion, which should be paid in November. There is also a minimum work obligation of about $50  million net to Total for 3D seismic, two wells, and an extended well test that must be completed by 2017.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The bulk of the investment and production will come after 2020, when we expect the Libra field to become an  important part of sustaining our future production growth. Just to give you an order of magnitude, Libra should  represent about 8 billion to 12 billion barrels of oil equivalent and has the potential to reach about 1.4 million  barrels per day of production fulfilled at 100%. The estimated profitability of Libra is comfortably above our order  rate. Fort Hills and Libra are giant long plateau projects that add strength and stability to the portfolio and  provide us with better visibility on our post-2017 production.

file: TTE - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 29October2014 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Under such circumstances, we thought it will be better to use this conference call to  give Patrick Pouyanné an  opportunity to present himself. He will comment on the strategy and the environment, and I will present the  results. The two of us will share the Q&A and the third challenge for us to overcome today will be to know which  Patrick you are talking to. But don't worry, we will make it.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: [indiscernible] (4:30) has raised questions, so let me address that now. First, despite the drop in oil prices, we see  no reason to change our long-term outlook. Ultimately, oil prices must settle in the range but intensify as the  development of the 50 million barrel per day of new production needed to meet the future demand by 2015. And  we believe [indiscernible] (5:02) range is too low to promote the development of sufficient resources. We also  believe that eventually OPEC will support the oil price as they have done consistently in the past and I remind you  about our production growth come from a portfolio of projects but are resilient at $80 per barrel.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So to share the situation today, it is clearly not business as usual. And in the event that oil prices remain  lower for  longer, we'll have to adapt. Where we have flexibility we come to using it, mainly in terms of dividend or different  activity. We'll also use this opportunity to negotiate better terms for suppliers and service companies and all  [indiscernible] (6:43) projects will be carefully reexamined. We are in the early days of a dynamic situation, so we  watch very closely the environment and the evolution of a productive cash flow allocation.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The success of CLOV demonstrates our ability to execute and deliver on major projects. Looking at the startup  schedule for the coming years Ofon 2 is nearing [ph] trading out (10:00), Laggan-Tormore is back on track and  scheduled to start up in first quarter of 2015. Ekofisk 2 is on schedule to start up this winter getting us started on  the pipeline fitting GLNG, the Surmont team in phase is expected in mid-2015 and Termokarstovoye and  [indiscernible] (10:29) are on schedule. We will be at around 2.2 million barrels per day by the end of this year  and our target for 2015 is 2.3 million barrel per day with no contribution from Kashagan, ADCO and Angola LNG.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition to the strong performance from refining, petrochemicals are continuing to do well and marketing has  been stable at a good level. Just as a reminder, one of the benefits of the integrated model is that the Downstream  can capture significant value when oil prices are volatile and this is one of the strengths that make us resilient.

file: TTE - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 29October2015 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our objective is to lower the cash breakeven for the group which will allow us to perform more competitively in  any environment, and we can accomplish this by starting up the new projects, reducing CapEx and cutting costs.  Compared to last year we are in a different environment. Brent averaged more than $60 per barrel in the second  quarter, but fell during the third quarter hitting a low of less than $45 per barrel and averaging only $50 per  barrel for the second quarter. European refining margins have been strong for the past year and they remain high  in the third quarter, averaging $55 per ton. Cost has continued to come down but we think there is room for more.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Against this backdrop we report a fairly robust third quarter with adjusted net income of $2.8 billion. Compared  to the second quarter this is a decrease of 11%, reflecting mainly the impact of lower oil prices on the Upstream,  partially offset by stronger Downstream results.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Adjusted net operating income for the Upstream decreased by 29% compared to the second quarter, essentially  due to the 24% decrease in our realized liquid price as well as weaker gas prices. Our LNG business continued to  be resilient. Its third quarter contribution fell by less than the 18% decrease in the Brent price and represented  about 30% of the Upstream adjusted net operating income for only 15% of the volumes.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Downstream adjusted net operating income was $1.9 billion in the third quarter, a 5% increase compared to the  previous quarter and a very impressive 57% increase compared to the same quarter last year. The European  Refining Margin Indicator in dollars per ton has decreased to the low-$40s for October. We have no way to know  if these trends will continue or revert, but we know that this time of the year can be seasonally weaker because we  are between the summer driving season and the winter heating oil season. In any case it shows importance of our  strategy in the Downstream to reduce the breakeven to less than $20 per ton at each site, and our successful cost  reduction program is an important part of this.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Finally, the corporate section. Third quarter adjusted cash flow from operations was $5.1 billion, a 5% decrease  from the second quarter, demonstrating that we are resilient in terms of cash which is our priority in a weaker  environment. The results include the benefit of our ongoing OpEx reduction program. Year-to-date at the group  level we are on track to exceed our cost reduction target of $1.2 billion. This is coming mainly from Upstream. So  we are really starting to see some strong results from the program we have launched nearly two years ago.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We have generated $15 billion of adjusted cash flow from operations of the first nine months of the year despite a  drop in the oil price. And our strategy is to continue to improve the underlying profitability of Total even in a  relatively weak price environment.

file: TTE - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 28October2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We are delivering Upstream production growth of more than 4% this year and continuing to cut costs, and this  positions Total for superior cash flow growth. We expect the environment to remain volatile, but based on our  2015 and first half 2016 performance, Total has been the best-performing major whether the oil price is rising or  falling.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The third quarter 2016 environment remained challenging. Brent was $46 per barrel, stable compared to the  second quarter, but our average realized hydrocarbon price fell by 2%. And European refining margins were $25  per ton, a decrease of $10 per ton compared to the second quarter, but they are back above $40 per ton since the  beginning of October.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As usual, we will cover the number by segment starting with Upstream. We are continuing to deliver Upstream  growth well ahead of our peers. Hydrocarbon production increased by 1% quarter-over-quarter and by 4.3% year- to-date. We have started up all five major projects planned for this year, including Kashagan in October, on top of  nine start-ups in 2015. We are on track for new project to add 350,000 barrel per day in 2017, and at $60 Brent,  this represent close to $3 billion of incremental cash flow.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Just a few words about our LNG businesses. LNG volumes have grown by 5% year-over-year for the nine  months, and represent more than 30% of the Upstream net results. And this is part of the reason why we have  outperformed our peers.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving to the Downstream. Adjusted net operating income for the Downstream was $1.5 billion in the third  quarter, a 5% increase compared to the previous quarter. The strong contribution from Downstream has been the  backbone of Total resilience. European refining margin were lower but throughput volumes were higher. We are  on track to reduce the break-even to less than $20 per ton, and this will further strengthen our ability to resist  volatility in the environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de La Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Marketing is performing well, generating a return on capital employ of about 19%. New Energies contributed $100  million in the third quarter, reflecting the completion and sale of the Henrietta solar farm by SunPower.

file: TTE - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 27October2017 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: More recently, we announced the $7.5 billion acquisition of Maersk Oil, and this will increase our production by  160,000 boe per day, mainly in the North Sea, when we close the deal in the first quarter 2018, and then grow to  more than 20,000 boe per day for 2020. This acquisition is accretive in 2018 at $50 per barrel for cash flow and  earning per share.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For E&P, third quarter 2017 adjusted net operating income was $1.4 billion, an increase of 84% compared to the  same quarter last year, while Brent increased by only 14%. Production grew by 6%, to 2.6 million barrel per day.  E&P operating cash flow before working capital changes was $3.2 billion, an increase of 15% from last year.  Operationally, we are continuing to perform well. We are in line with our target to grow production by 5% in 2017,  mainly thanks to the start-up of our operation in Qatar on the giant Al-Shaheen field in mid-July, plus the ramp up  on Kashagan and Moho. We anticipate an on-time and on-budget start-up of Yamal LNG by year end. In all, we  have 16 projects starting over the period 2017 to 2019 that represents more than 700,000 boe per day of  production. And more than 10 project to sanction by the end of the next year, representing more than 350,000  boe per day all with high returns at $50 per barrel.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In addition to growing the production, cost control continues to be a high priority. In the third quarter, OpEx was  $5.1 per boe and year-to-date we are around $5.4 per boe. We are on track to achieve our OpEx reduction target  to less than $5.5 per boe in 2017 and then $5 per boe in 2018 from nearly $10 per boe in 2014.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving on the Gas, Renewables & Power segment. GRP contributed $97 million of adjusted net operating  income in the third quarter, in line with $95 million in the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: From our perspective, the oil market remain volatile. On the one hand, we have stronger than expected demand,  and on the other hand, inventories are decreasing but still remain high. There is a balance today mainly thanks to  the 1.8 million barrel per day OPEC, non-OPEC cuts, which are part of the complicated geopolitical environment  that always carry the risk of uncertainty. So, we are not committed to any particular oil price scenario. Instead, we  are committed to reducing the breakeven.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As we said in London last month and during the meeting we have had over the past few weeks, we have  established timetable for executing and delivering on our strategy. We have moved faster than our peers to adjust  to the new oil price environment, and we are moving now to lay the foundation for competitive performance in the  future.

file: TTE - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 26October2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We are consistently delivering excellent results, thanks to production growth, cost reduction, capital discipline.  The quarterly results confirm this consistency. We are increasing production faster than our peers through organic  investment and countercyclical acquisitions. So we are well positioned to fully capture the benefit of higher  commodity prices. The quarterly results confirms that with 8.6% growth and we are on the forefront developing a  profitable low carbon electricity business fueled by natural gas and renewables to strengthen and diversify the  company for the long-term. And the quarterly results reflect this with the acquisitions of Direct Energie and two  gas-fired power plants.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving onto the Gas, Renewables & Power segment. GRP contributed $272 million of adjusted net operating  income in the third quarter, an increase of 41% over the second quarter, reflecting in large part excellent activity in  LNG trading as well as gas and power trading.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We closed the Engie LNG acquisition in the third quarter, positioning Total as a second largest publicly traded  player in the global LNG business. In addition, we completed the Direct Energie acquisition in the third quarter,  which is an important part of our strategy to develop a profitable business to certify the fast growing demand for  low carbon electricity. Our objective is to integrate the low carbon electricity business with the activities we are  developing along the LNG and gas value chain. Starting next year, we will report on the integrated Gas,  Renewables & Power segment, so it will include the entire value chain from the wellhead to the customer.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Refining margin in Europe averaged $40 per ton in the third quarter compared to $35 per ton in the second  quarter and $48 per ton in third quarter 2017. Margin has been volatile, rising to more than $50 per ton in August  and falling to $25 per ton in September when oil prices ramped up and gasoline inventories were high.  Petrochemicals has been less volatile and margins have remained at fairly strong level. Seasonal weakness is not  unusual late in the year, so keeping this in mind we believe it's mainly volatility in feedstock prices that is moving  the margins.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Last week, we announced a 50/50 JV with Adani, a private group in India, to develop a variety of energy offers in  the rapidly developing Indian market. First, we plan to develop LNG regas terminals. So this JV will benefit our  GRP segment. In addition, we will get the license for the JV to build a retail network of 1,500 stations over 10  years. So this is consistent with our M&S strategy to focus on large, fast-growing markets. The future investment  needs for this JV are within the CapEx guidance that we have provided.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We will continue, however, to manage a company with a conservative, full-cycle perspective on commodity prices  and downstream margins. We have the portfolio that is rich with short-cycle opportunities and we have positioned  the company to take advantage of the low development cost to lock-in high return production growth for the  future.

We see  subsea equipment down by 15%, the FPSO cost down also by 15% and some risers and flexible  asset CapEx down by 20%.

All those projects in aggregate will contribute by 2014  at about 800,000 barrel per day.

We have signed a new JV in Italy with Erg, and this will be also for us to match this  objective.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: As far as the North America is concerned, we’ve made significant additions to our portfolio there.  We’re not only talking about a maturity of our shale-based oil, we are also determined to participate  in the unconventional gas market, particularly shale gas.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: In downstream, and the best way of gaining market share in downstream, it’s necessary both to  adapt our production base for refining and for petrochemicals to the environment, that’s nothing  new, even if there is quite a lot of criticism of that. And it’s structural, and it’s not just linked to the  financial and economic crisis.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: And we also wish to integrate into our business development model, not only economic issues, not  only our core business, but also sustainable development in the widest sense of sustainable  development starting with energy efficiency, the fight against global warming, everything which  makes an oil major an acceptable partner, even though people sometimes have difficulty in  understanding why it’s necessary to close down a refinery and at the same time ask us to reduce  our greenhouse gases. But that’s the contradiction we have to live with.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: On the slide, you have everything we’ve done this year, and all the projects that are developing  very nicely. There are three major acquisitions at the end of the year, which we’ve now signed:  Ahnet in Algeria, Chesapeake in shale gas in Texas. And also – this is going back a little bit further,  Cobalt in Deep Offshore in the Gulf of Mexico, and the final project almost is our participation in one  of the giant fields that has been put up for development for Iraq. This is about 2 billion barrels of  long-term oil equivalent. So that shows our determination to contribute proven reserves to our       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Our view of the economy has not fundamentally changed even if the – even if there has been a big  impact of the crisis on the price of gas and refining margins. Brent according to the method used  has either fallen a lot or risen a lot. What is important for us is the average in 2009 compared to the  average of 2008. And it’s down from 100 to about 60.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Although, from the 1st of January to the end of December, it moved up from 32 to 80, so you can  do what you like with figures, but the fundamentals are that prices are down. The same is true, of  course, even more so for the price of gas, where we have seen a complete decoupling between the  price of oil and the price of gas. We’ll come back to that later on.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: We think that could continue. There is of course two possible ways we could think about this, either  that the price of gas will get closer to the price of oil and we don’t think that’s very likely at the  moment, or the price of oil will fall towards the price of gas and for other reasons we don’t believe  that’s very likely either given the market expectations and OPEC policy and geopolitical reasons.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Why do we believe that our strategy, which is based on a gradual rise in energy prices is the right  strategy, quite apart from the effects of the current crisis? Well very clearly, as we have seen with  the recovery of consumption in emerging economies, particularly China, demand is recovering in  those countries and it’s recovering more strongly than we thought. Will that last? We don’t know,  but it’s clearly a strong recovery at the moment. In Europe and the United States, consumption is  down, but in the 2009 to 2020 period, available capacity will be gradually dwindling.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: 3 So, I think it’s a bit optimistic to say that we can increase to 95,000 barrels per day, not because we  don’t have the technical capacity to do that, but because there are factors beyond our control,  which may prevent us from doing that.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: But the reserves are there and what’s important for us is to get our hands on those reserves when  the capacity will be there or may not be there, so there is I think structural support for the price of  crude oil. We’ve seen prices range from 60 to $80 per barrel, more recently between 70 and 80.  Will the $70 support hold? I don’t know.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: But I think recently, the fall in oil prices has been more to do with the fall in stock exchange equity  markets and less to do with the underlying demand for oil. Gas, it’s a similar situation, but the  results are different and there is an excess of supply over demand at the moment, but the market is  much more of a physical market. It’s much less of a forward-looking market, like the oil market for  reasons of organization, for reasons of what the partners in the gas market want.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Even though in shale gas for the time being, the players in that market are looking at intelligent  solutions to sell at the right price, but there is very clearly a bubble at the moment which is  preventing prices from rising. Now Total is lucky enough to have a lot contracts which are linked to  the oil price rather to the spot price. So we have managed to get fairly high prices compared to  what demand would dictate.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
