texts.text: But we believe that the capacity will remain over-capacity for some time now. And we shall  accommodate that. There is a debate about the size of the gas reserves in the U.S. I think we’ll  come back to this, as well. The figures that we’ve heard cover a very large range from very low  figures to very high figures for the time being.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: The new LNG production that we have is done at very competitive prices and therefore this has led  to gas prices remaining at a fairly low level, but that’s doesn’t prevent in the medium term us  anticipating a very strong rise in the demand for gas by 2020. And we shall see what the LNG  provides and we may have to delay the bringing online of some projects, particularly in Africa, and  there may well be a strong recovery in prices at some point in the future. That being said, when we  launch the project today and you can see this is the case for Shtokman, we are talking about  production in 2016 and 2017, not today.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: The gas we are extract – we are selling today comes from reserves we found many years ago. So  don’t think – look at things backwards and say that we should delay our new project simply  because the prices today are low. Patrick?

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Patrick de La Chevardière, Chief Financial Officer  As regards the results, let me remind how volatile the environment was in 2009. The average liquid  price was down 36%, but Q4 to Q4 was actually up 44% which is good indication of how volatile  prices were. Gas prices were also down 30% over the full year and interestingly, the refining margin  indicator was down 65% at an average of $17 H per ton on the fourth quarter average of 11.7%  which explains the net operating income in refining that I’ll be commenting in just a few minutes.  You’ll also see that the euro and dollar pair has been roughly stable from 1.37 to 1.49 over the year  as the total [inaudible]. At 7.8 billion, income was down 44% as you’ve heard, adjusted net income  in dollars, that was down 47%.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: In the downstream, the first quarter was quite positive. Downstream was net income of 1 billion for  the full year and of course chemicals suffered of course with the general environment and only  generated €400 million adjusted net income, particularly in chemical specialties.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: What we can say, if you look at the right hand side of the slide, what we can say is that Total has  resisted very well by comparison with the other oil majors with the possible exception of BP. In fact,  our upstream resisted much better than Exxon or Shell for instance. The same type of thinking can  be said about the downstream; our downstream fared well relatively speaking by comparison with  our main rivals.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Moving on to the next slide, our balance sheet has a gain of 26% exactly at year-end. As out of  which we can continue to invest and uphold our dividend with a certain degree of serenity. If you  look at the figures for 2009, gross CapEx, that’s the green bar on the right, that’s gross CapEx of  18.6 billion, dividend of $7.6 billion – all in dollars by the way – funded through cash flow from  operations to the tune of 17.2 billion.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Now we will continue to take a considered and measured approach to cost reduction. We know that  there is a general tendency for costs to increase. There is a lot of demand for high-tech projects in  oil and indeed in petrochemicals as well. So, more than ever before, we must take a disciplined  approach to cost control and show we have operational excellence while continuing to invest. The  stop-and-go policy, as we have seen in the past, is a policy that doesn’t work.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: And the five major projects started up, you know them by heart, you know them all well. The good  news is that they’re almost in all full production. I don’t know that’s fully the case in Akpo. Louis?  Correct? Has the ramp-up been completed yet? Yes? Tahiti is working well in the Gulf of Mexico.  Tombua Landana in Angola, as well, and our two LNG projects on the right hand side which have  made us a leader in the LNG market. These are projects that were launched at a time when costs  were much lower than they are today, giving us a very obvious competitive edge. We’re particularly  proud of the Yemen LNG project because this was, well, quite an adventure, over and beyond the  figures that you see here.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Now, as was the case when we compared income with production, these are projects that are not  just sensitive to oil prices between 60 and $80 a barrel, these are projects that increase that are  very much energy price sensitive.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Now for the same reasons, we said part of this concerns gas and the other part concerns oil, isn’t  that correct? These are the two price scenarios, aren’t they? Yes. Production was approximately  240 million barrels per day, all five projects combined.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Just a few words about positioning in geographical location and of course the technology used as  well. Since 2004, we have found that the geographical breakdown has changed. Middle East has  increased, the Americas are also on the up, Europe quite naturally has seen its reserves decline  and of course Africa is very stable. As for the technologies applied, the Deep Offshore hasn’t  changed an awful lot in terms of reserves, heavy oil is up, LNG is up as well.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Unconventional gas, well, you need a magnifying glass to see the actual contribution but the  advantage is this is something new in 2009, so a big increase by comparison with the previous  level of zero. Gas largely unchanged for similar reasons to the ones I mentioned earlier on and  hydrocarbon liquids down quite sharply. As for the breakdown by country, OECD or non-OECD,  very little change by comparison with the previous years.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: What about the five major projects we’ll be launching this year in 2010? Well, they will be  production and you are familiar with them all of course as well but this year we have decided to  launch them. Of course we have the Surmont Phase 2 with Conoco Philips in Alaska and the  CLOV, or CLOV project, which is the fourth hub of Angola’s Block 17, We’ve got Tormore in the  West of Shetlands. I might say that we and it’s worth mentioning obtained special tax benefits from  the British Government, thanks to which we were able to launch this project with a greater peace of  mind than would have been the case otherwise and this is a gas project.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Now, the resource space, this is a building up to FIDs. As you know we’ve made a number of  efforts to bring in a number of exploration permits. There’s also the need to bolster our appraisal  work on existing wells. And there are a number of acquisitions of the third type, as they are known,  EXCO, the Abu Dhabi extension, which is particularly interesting as it’s a premiere, I would say, a  first. It’s not so much the Gasco number as the processing of associated gas with the production of  oil onshore.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: As for medium-term projects, this is between the final investment decision and the arrival of new  resources, particularly with a view to preparing the period for 2011 to 2014. Our start-ups mainly  involve projects that have, by definition, been launched, or are being acquired. Barnett Shale is in  Chesapeake Bay. We will be beginning production with the $30,000 – 30,000 barrels a day. As for  the third hub before CLOV and Block 17 in Angola. These are projects that we will be starting up  before 2014.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: 7 from one year to the following year, anyway a pity because it’s a very, very attractive project. Now  we have a number of partnerships, Chesapeake, of course, which drew our minds, or who to our  minds are the experts in the development of shale oil and gas in the U.S. This could be the starting  point of a very interesting adventure.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: In North America, we have a number of positions we are developing. First of all, in heavy oils, now  those are taking longer than initially anticipated. We are looking at 17 with ConocoPhillips,  obviously we are working on Joslyn which is an oil field for which we expect the FID in 2011. I’m not  going to review them all in detail. But we are still very eager to continue to expand our presence in  the U.S. be it unconventional hydrocarbons or tight gas. And when necessary with the support of  partners and allies who certainly have greater expertise than we have in certain areas whence the  somewhat unusual joint venture that we have entered into with Cobalt with a view to exploring the  Gulf of Mexico, especially in the deep offshore sector.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Heavy oil, you are familiar with. This is not a gas project of course, but that’s really for the long term  and of course we will be resuming with unconventional gas with the Barnett Shale in the U.S., also  in Algeria. LNG, I will develop for a few seconds, not just a number of new projects, but a number of  future projects as well, I talked to you about.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Most importantly, our production prospects for the period between 2009 and 2014 we’ve promised  that our average production of the period will increase by an annual 2%, despite the decline – that’s  a similar decline to last year, approximately 5% per annum on average. Factor that in with the price  of crude oil, and you see that a number of projects that are near the end production and that we will  have to make a number of acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Let me move on to LNG, which is something I can go through fairly quickly because this confirms  the strategy that we have initiated and which is working well. We have now become, I’ve been told,  number two in LNG in 2010. But that’s fine, but it’s not necessarily where we are in the rankings, it’s  what we can produce in terms profits and cash for the company.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Two major projects here: Yemen LNG which awaits the second train for 2010, but with a very low  breakeven point, which makes it possible to trade gas in London. And to get the best possible  outlets for our gas sales to optimize our sales and you can see that sales of LNG are expected to       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: 8 develop very strongly and purchases, too, clearly, so that we can maintain our positions on this  market, which is an important market, which even though it seems to be a bit bubbly at the  moment, should enable us to improve our return on investment and recover cents and dollars for  millions of BTUs, so as to make these projects as profitable as they were proposed last year. These  are results of LNG, as you can see they are very creditable, which is basically what’s on this slide.  So I shan’t repeat it for the projects that we have; they’ve made a contribution of $3 billion to the net  operating income of the Total Group in 2009. Yemen LNG and Qatargas, Train 5, it’s Train 2 of  Qatargas, 2, but it’s ours.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: And we are looking at new projects over and beyond Angola LNG, which is currently being  developed. And Ichthys and Shtokman, we are finalizing studies on and we have new projects for  the future, like in Africa, even though we know of course that security is not something that we can  chose to ignore. And it doesn’t make our life any easier.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Developing complementary energies, we started this drive last year. It’s the result of our vision on  supply and demand in the long term, in spite of the fact that, because in view of the fall in demand,  but a fall in production capacity, we feel that there will be not enough fossil energy to meet global  demand, and we want therefore to look at how we can be involved in developing new  complementary energies, which make it possible for us to meet our commitments in terms of  reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: In solar, here you have precise examples of what we are doing, so it’s not just words, it’s action.  We have started a number of partnerships, more in research and development – than development.  But as technology is developing very quickly, we take time to decide on the larger projects.  Biomass is an important issue for an oil major like Total, and we also are involved in a number of  private projects there.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: And the nuclear venture of course, which has of course had a small setback with Abu Dhabi. But  that doesn’t prevent us from thinking about equivalent developments in an area which is not really  our core business, but which is for us a new energy. And we have basically the same view for  2030, 70% of fossil energy is to meet global demand in 2030.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: We must adapt our production base to the current structural environment and that’s what we intend  to do with a reduction from 2007 to 2011 of 500 barrels per day of capacity, that’s about 20% of our  global capacity, with nevertheless capital spending which is down, but nevertheless significant for  the continuing part of our operations.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: We do not intend to truck with either security or the environment. So from 2009 to 2015 you will see  that it’s about $2 billion per year that we shall be investing in order to maintain our production base  in the proper condition. And then there is nevertheless growth and further profitability.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: Sustainable development integrated to our projects, as I said initially, it’s very clear that we have  decided in a very determined way to include sustainable development within our business model  and to do that for the Analysts’ presentation, as well as for the other presentations. Sustainable  development governance will be involved in all of our projects. We shall be looking very closely at  energy efficiency, we’ll be looking at reducing greenhouse gas submission, will be looking at our  attitude towards local populations and the local authorities. We shall basically be trying to be more  acceptable to all the stakeholders while continuing to grow our business. It’s not always easy to do  that. And so it’s not easy for people to realize that we are changing.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: In Yemen, for instance, we are particularly keen on environment and training. In Angola, we are  involved in Angolisation, and clearly we need to find new methods for trapping – capturing CO2 and  we need as we are doing to look at clean energies like Solar in Abu Dhabi for instance, not only to  reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, but also when we’re talking about new energies to develop  those new energies in line with our sustainable development philosophy.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: What about coal, some people say. Well, without – the lack – capturing product, there is no point in  getting involved in coal and so we shall have to until we see what that project will contribute. The  continuing investment program, as Patrick was saying earlier on, is the underlying basis of our  policy, 18 billion in 2009, 18 billion CapEx in 2010, perhaps it’s not quite comparable because in  2010, we won’t have the acquisitions that we had in 2009.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is Annual Meeting on the 2009 Results, the Fourth
texts.text: To conclude, our key strengths. People often ask us, what’s the difference between our company  and the other majors? Well, I think, a lot of things, basically. Particularly in terms of the position in  the oil market, I think our sustainable development philosophy is something that is now very much  in the heart of our business and must be taken seriously by everyone.

file: TTE - Q4 2010 Earnings Call London 11February2011 1130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: But again, we are pleased to present to you, not only our 2010 results, but also our forecast and  our understanding on the way the company is going to run in the mid and long-term. And the way  we consider it is the best to get access to the additional profits coming from oil and gas prices – to  start with oil, and then gas in the longer-term – in our profits and return to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Capital growth means also accelerating asset sales. And what we mean by this is not just selling for  selling. We have a good balance sheet. We have a strong discipline on investment. But it’s true that  at the time you can sell assets at a high price and you can also have access to new reserves at a  very cheap price, it’s probably better to find a solution where you don’t sell, because you don’t  believe in oil prices.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: But for doing this, it’s true that it’s the right way, and thanks for the message, yes, we can sell some  of our assets, still keeping our strong understanding that we believe in higher price of energy, so we  have no reason to sell just for selling.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: And at the end, because it’s not any more what some people call greenwashing. We more and  more consider that we need to go involved in the real sense in new energies projects, not as just a  simple player, just trying to fight and compete with the Chinese or Indians, which is impossible and  certainly not profitable. But to find ways to participate to something which is important, bring new  energies, which are needed to just fill the gap between potential offer and potential demand.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: We continue and we see more and more, some kind of a common understanding on there will be  not enough precise energies to cover the demand. There will be a lot of reserves available, but not  easy to develop soon.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: At the same time, we need to be part of those, trying to make it also doable to develop solar,  biomass, biofuels, and if possible, too, one day, nuclear when it becomes profitable and  acceptable.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: The adjusted net income increased by 26% to $13.6 billion, mostly driven by upstream. It’s  interesting to note that our net operating income from this segment increased by 33%, which show  that we have been able to capture the increase of the oil price. And the net operating income goes  up to $14 billion in 2010.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: The return on average capital employed also benefit from the environment. The average ROACE is  17% and 21% for the upstream. You can see also a very strong rebound on the ROACE for  chemical, thanks to the environment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: We – still pending, we have Uganda, which is still pending on authorization to be given by the  authorities. We sell assets on the other side. We sell Jarden’s Mapa Spontex, and we are in the  process of selling the Lindsey Refinery. It’s a long process, I do acknowledge that. But it will be  done. And we entered also in the GLNG project in Australia. We sold Valhall. We sold Block 31 in  Angola, all in aggregate, making for $4.7 billion of cash, which was used to fund the acquisitions we  did.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Upstream performance was obviously very good. This is a recovery for Total that we post a 4.3%  production growth. The production for this year was 2.33 million barrel a day, driven mostly by LNG  plus 40%,  also gas plus 6%, and liquids, which were down by 3%.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: You see on the right hand side of the slide that both projects are extremely sensitive to the oil  prices. That those six major projects will generate more net operating income than the average of  our portfolio. Just to give you figures, using $80 per barrel scenario, the average of our portfolio in  2010 was generating $13 per barrel of net operating income. Those six projects would generate  $21 per barrel in the same environment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: We had a strong contribution from LNG project. Some time I heard some of you telling me that LNG  is not profitable. This is wrong. With 20% of our production coming from LNG, this represent 25% of  our adjusted net operating income.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: We increased our exposure definitely in this year and last year from LNG coming from Yemen, from  Qatar, and also from the recovery in Nigeria LNG, where the production was very low in 2009 and  recovered in 2010.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Please trust us when we tell you that LNG is a profitable business. And you see the figure of 20%  of the production represent 25% of the adjusted net operating income.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: In the Petrochemical, we started the Ras Laffan steam-cracker in Qatar. And we entered into a joint  venture for coal-to-olefin project in China.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: The European refining is facing difficult time as we commit to reduce our capacity and to reduce our  exposure to this European refining business. We basically did it. The last event to happen is the  sale of Lindsey oil refinery. If you compare – on the left side of the slide, if you compare the  capacity we had in 2006 and the capacity we’ll have end of this year, this would be a strong  reduction from 2.3 million barrel per day down to 1.8 million barrel per day.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: I can tell you I believe you when you say LNG is a good business for Total. I strongly believe you.  But I mean, remember sometimes you’ve told me, don’t be so rude with our friends. I would have  never said they are wrong. I would have said they might not be totally right. Be careful.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Outlook. Well, let’s go to the basics. I mean environment. Favorable medium to long-term  environment. You have on that slide the oil, natural gas and refining margin.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: On oil, you know our old story, which by the way, has not been changing too much, even if the old  peak oil – and I’m not suppose to use it any more – but the day where we might be a little bit short  of capacities is coming. And when you look at this graph and the 2010, ‘20 figures. You see that we  are at $93 million barrels per day of production of liquids, which is not too far of the 95, which we  consider as probably in 2020, ‘23. It’s difficult to say. Probably the day where we’ll be at 95, which  is the way we see it today, probably the maximum level of production available.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: If you add to this the H2L GTL what we call the gain on processing, and the biofuels, you achieve  the 100 million, 101 million barrels per day. Which is, by the way, becoming more and more, the  view of most of the energy players. I hope, as I was saying this morning, that now that most people  agree on this, it’s not going to be wrong. Because at the time, we were the only one to say it. And  still we see it that way.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Now it’s very important to understand why the understanding of the market being always long and  using all reasons to go long is because of this. It’s not only because of Egypt. It’s not only because  of – I don’t know what, or cold weather or whatever. It’s just because the fundamentals out there.  And if you look at this in details, you will see that definitely the possibility to make it higher are  becoming more and more difficult.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: On the gas, you might tell me that why are you just talking about Europe and Asia. Well, maybe,  because I mean, Total is much more, I would say, linked to it. We are in Europe. We are in Asia.  We are very little exposed in the United States, even if we believe in Shale gas, as you know. But I  mean, if you look at just Europe, we see the end of the bubble, thanks to demand, by somewhere  around 2014, 2015.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Why? Because demand is growing. And if you look at the way first to that, especially gas coming  from Russia, gas coming from – even LNG. It starts to be a concern if you don’t find new ways to  develop new LNG businesses.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Don’t forget also the cost of logistics, flexibility is also a concern. You cannot just bring ships from  one place to another in two minutes time. And in our slides, you see what has been the work done  by the trading division of Total on the LNG business, is trying to move more and more ships from  one place to another to get access to the best markets.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: And the end, not the last, refining margin, even if on that slide, you see in 2015 that we have been  only able to reduce – if I can tell this – the additional capacities from around 6 million barrels to 2  million, it’s 6 million to 2 million, but coming from different places.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: And to consider it’s not our role, to consider is – it will be just followed, that’s not the case. So let’s  be not only prepared for it, let’s be working on making this acceptable in bringing something else  in  exchange, which is most probably more concerned about environment, more concerned about the  way our clients leave and the way they can definitely, at the end accept a higher price, which  definitely will be at the end to be paid and suffered by them.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: 12 major projects. 2011, 2012. Those are FIDs. So it’s not new production. You have the dates of  production. I will not go on them one by one. But I mean it’s a good mix of portfolio, conventional,  deep offshore, heavy oil, unconventional gas and LNG. All of those projects are today well moving.  Definitely on time.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: And the question mark on Shtokman will have to be lift before the end of March, when we’ll decide  on the FID. And as you remember, we have decided to split the FID, one part being gas pipe, one  part being LNG. The LNG part being decided by the end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Exploration budget increased to 2.1 billion. So it’s not only to go to more aggressive place, but also  increasing the investment base. So between 2010 and 2011, it’s moving from 1.8 to 2.1. If you go a  little bit backward, which is not so long ago, five years ago, 2006, it was 1.5 million.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: But all the others are part of what we will be drilling in 2011, which means a large numbers of wells,  and I hope a large number of discoveries, including – to please my British colleagues here –       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Is it challenging? I don’t know. But 2% increase in production when we see the average increase of  oil demand by 1% in the years to come. It’s a good number. And definitely it’s part of our wish to get  additional production and operating income.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: Downstream Chemicals, well, Patrick has been almost covering the subject before, i.e. in the way  we have to achieve this target. The target is just is very easy to move from 9% rate of return,  ROACE, in 2010 to 13% in 2015. So an additional 4% and doubling of cash flow. That’s not only  doable, it’s a strong commitment. Of course, it’s linked with the environment. And for this we are  using the 2010 environment, which is almost equivalent to a mid-cycle environment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: But I mean with all which has been done and is underway, to be more careful on safety, to be able  to reduce our capacity and improve the break-even levels. To definitely improve the  competitiveness of our Petrochemical activities and being more present in the Middle East and be  more present in Asia, and still keeping our tools, our units in Europe, in a good fit and competitive,  we strongly believe that this goal is our goal. And 13% in coal business, which is not – and  definitely not in alignment with the environment of the Upstream – is strongly considered by the  company, by the management, as a way not only to diversify our risk, but also to make good profit  for our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: As you see, 2010, 22, we moved it for being between 25 and 30 in 2011. Definitely, it will depend  on the environment. It’s what we’ll be seeing at $80. It’s probable that at more than 80, we will have  gearing less than this. And maybe, we could think of having a higher dividend if our profits are  getting higher. But you have all the ways with this to calculate the sensitivity of our results on higher  price of brands, additional production, refining margin and of course, at the end, the remaining  sales of Sanofi-Aventis.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: I don’t know if I should say good evening or good afternoon or good morning for those in the States.
texts.text: And just to make it a little ping, you remember why we decided not to be too arrogant in our policy  in Iraq, that’s just because of this. You cannot ask us to bring more value to the shareholders, to be  more than $13 per barrel in profits per barrel, and go to projects with margin which are below $2.  Whatever the return could be, it’s very important to us just to be sure that we keep our industry in  what it is – companies to be able to deliver growth in a sustainable way, taking more care of the  environment, taking more care of the climate change, taking more care of our clients, and just being  able to move in an environment which will have, sometimes, to suffer in increasing energy prices,  and make it still acceptable and profitable to all of our stakeholders.

file: TTE - Q4 2010 Earnings Call Paris 11February2011 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So I think 2010 was a good year of transition in the positive sense of the term in so far as we have  a good income, good cash flow. We have the ability to fund our future, and we have a relatively low  gearing, certainly below the range we have set ourselves of 25% to 30%. So, in – given that  situation, we feel in a strong position to move forward with a very good overview of the energy  sector, which as you know, we’re not over optimistic or surrealistic about this. We are very, very  realistic about the future for all sorts of reasons, given the fact that the current energy prices are  what they are, and prices we feel that are unlikely to drop.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: 2 But just as importantly, this wasn’t just due to the better environment but also as a result of our  better operational performance and of course the level of business, which enabled us to be more  competitive and not just in exploration and production.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: We have projects in oil, of course, but in other forms of energy, because we haven’t just got the  duty, we have the will to seek out new forms of energy, which of course requires research,  something we are doing by acquiring stakes – by acquiring stakes in companies, but also by  making commitments to work along these companies, these partners with a view to the long-term.  Again more about that a little bit later on.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Again, this isn’t just [inaudible]. These are firm commitments that we have made. There are a  number of operational managers in E&P that will confirm that for you. We are continuing to  contribute to the development of local economies. This is now built into our business plan, it’s not  just something we communicate about. Indeed in all the projects that we roll out at all sectors of our  business, we include a society issues and responsibilities, commitments that we make not just to  local authorities, in terms of global warming, but indeed to the countries in which we operate.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Now in 2010, I think you know the environment by heart, there’s little need to comment that.  Certainly it was an improvement on 2009, not as good as 2008. However, there were sharp  fluctuations. We started at a very low level, went to a very high level and finished at an annual high.  The important thing is the average, the $79.50, that’s the average price of the Brent – Brent price in  dollars. This is the average we have used in determining the quality and feasibility of our project. So  that’s an annual average of $80 a barrel in 2010. Henry Hub and the National Balancing Point, we  talk about that later on.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Now our asset portfolio is really growth driven and of course very much focused on optimization. It’s  often been contended that we don’t work our portfolios efficiently, particularly in the upstream. I can  assure you that when you’re long in dollars per barrel, when you believe in an increase in oil prices,  well then it’s difficult to envisage disposing of assets.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Upstream performance of course, has been driven by production growth, production which grew  4.3%, and that’s good news. LNG has contributed substantially to that growth, all the better and  you’ll see a little bit later on that LNG is not just a one of the drivers behind growth, but also a driver  behind profits and profits that are higher than the upstream average. The distribution of liquid and  gas is of lesser importance, I think, especially in view of the fact that we generate greater value with  gas than with petrol, particularly with regard to spot prices and Henry Hub prices. So, in dollars per  barrel in the upstream, prices rose 23%, that’s 13.1%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: 5 And even though the projects are not easy, the oil shale in Canada is a very difficult project, even if  it’s in an OECD country. So, it’s not necessarily the case that it’s easy in the OECD, and not  outside the OECD. You have the breakdown between liquids, other gas and LNG, and in the six  projects it’s basically 50-50.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Renewing exploration acreage, this is of course a priority and we’re trying to gain further permits on  our traditional areas, like the United Kingdom, for instance or Angola, but also looking for new oil in  other areas. It’s a frontier exploration, more or less, with greater risks, with greater budgets, $1.8  billion up to $2.1 billion. But all this, of course, is something that means that we must renew our  potential for future development.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: We’ve made a commitment of 1.4 billion barrels extra per year, basically 50-50 between exploration  and what we call unconventional projects. Sometimes there are more traditional projects and  sometimes there are more unconventional projects. But all this is necessary and must remain in  balance so that the portfolio continues to develop for the company.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Proven reserves, 124% replacement rate in 2010. This is the explanation of how we get from one to  the other and there is a price effect there, which is negative. Clearly this figure includes our  acquisitions, and that I think is quite natural. Good breakdown by country, as you can see, a good  breakdown by category of hydrocarbons with a fairly large share for LNG and liquid oil.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Deep offshore, I think it’s a good thing to be in deep offshore basically, because that’s where we  find not only our new barrels of oil, but also profitable barrels of oil. There has been all this debate  which is after Macondo, whether it was – whether that was too risky, there’s been a big debate  about that. But I think as far as we’re concerned, [inaudible] I think that’s represents about 12% of  our production, little more in our reserves, about 15% in our reserves, deepwater oil, and that, I  think, is a good balance. It’s a good risk management and if we have to take more precautions, of  course for deep offshore developments, it – there is no question that we shouldn’t continue in this  sector with greater technology and more experience. 12 years of proven reserves, that’s a little  more than 12 and more than 20 years on probable reserves.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Strong contribution from LNG. This is a specificity of this company, particularly this year there has  been a big increase in upstream production from Yemen with the two trains, which are now fully  ramped up and the ramp-up of Qatargas 2 and the contribution of the marketing and trading  department of LNG, which makes it possible at the present time when there are major distortions  between the three major markets, to use the trading department to redirect LNG into areas where  it’s likely to benefit from greater market opportunities, Europe and above all, whole Asia.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: The best way of finding the optimization of the best feedstocks for petrochemicals, we need to look  at how we can produce polymers from ethanol, for instance, and even more upstream from coal  and specialty chemicals, which has had record results in 2010. And that proves once again that we  can make money in specialty chemicals and we are making money in specialty chemicals, even  though the market environment is not yet absolutely fantastic, but that’s thanks to the tremendously  good work of our people in specialty chemicals who have done a great deal to make our units  competitive in 28, 29 and we’re drawing the benefits from that today. Just to dispel a rumor, apart  from the disposal of Arkema there are no further projects for disposal in the pipeline in terms of  specialty chemicals.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: New energies, now. We are now moving on to what we said, to actually doing it in the three areas  that we are focusing on as a matter of priority – biomass, solar, and perhaps one day clean coal,  when we shall find a way of dealing with the CO2 issue, and perhaps one day as well, nuclear. But  for the time being, we are looking at areas where research is the priority. Our aim is to find  solutions to produce new energies, which can be profitable, no subsidies. We don’t believe in  products which can be subsidized over their lifetime, especially when you are a company like Total.  What we’re interested in is finding products today that will remain competitive tomorrow in the major  countries.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: And in solar powers, we have a lot of work to do. We are looking at thin film. We are looking at bio- fuels. We have a project which has been developed in Abu Dhabi, as you can see here, a large  solar farm which when it’s commissioned, will be the largest solar farm in the world. And again, this  is an illustration of our partnership strategy. It’s hardly a coincidence if it’s in Abu Dhabi. Of course  there is a lot more sun in Abu Dhabi than there is in France, but there is also oil in Abu Dhabi. And  we are a long-term partnership of the Abu Dhabi authorities. So clearly, technology is a priority in  these areas.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: What about the outlook? The medium term environment, I don’t think I need to spend too much  time on that because I think everyone knows how we feel about the medium term. We make  distinction here between oil, gas and refining. In oil, first of all, we believe that oil demand will  continue to increase 1% a year. Again, there can be arguments about this. Is it demand that drives  the supply or supply that drives demand – drive supply the other way around.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: We believe that it’s both in a way, and that the output is likely to be 95 million barrels a day, but  can’t go much further than that. And if you add bio-mass, bio-fuels, [inaudible] and processing  gains, we arrive at a figure which is – which you are very familiar with, 100 million to 101 million of  barrels per day. That’s basically our figure and most of the energy majors find that figure is  acceptable.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So, what some people thought was unacceptably prudent as far as TOTAL is concerned, now you  see that it’s basically the consensus among the energy majors. And I hope we will be right about  that.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: As far as gas is concerned, we’ve talked about Europe and Asia. What about the other market?  Well, we’re not really present in that market. So, it is less of an interest to us, but we do have a  view-point on American gas, particularly on HH.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: We see a major increase in demand, oil demand has been flat for the past few years. Now, it’s very  difficult to say when it will actually take off again, given the uncertainties about the development of  non-conventional gases.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Start up of new projects in 2011-12, this is why in 2011, as you have seen and as you can see on  this slide, 2010 and 2011 are at the same level. This is no scoop, I think. But don’t forget the 4.3%  increase in upstream production in 2010 and that will continue in 2011.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So that’s pretty stable, but good enough and then a big increase from 2012 onwards. And here you  have all the projects on the right-hand side of the slide in a number of countries, which explain how  we arrive at 270 million barrels more in 2011-2012.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: 8 conventional or deep offshore, heavy oils, unconventional gas and finally, LNG. All of these projects  are well underway and the launches are well underway.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Exploration budget up to $2.1 billion, up from $1.8 billion the previous year, and from $1.5 billion in  2006, so sharp increases. You see where we have various challenges, quite a few border line pits,  quite a number of challenges ahead of us, be it in Guyana, Angola or elsewhere. For those of you  who are interested, we’ve divided up the type of the pits by type of challenge, by type of geology.  But importantly, we are involved in virtually all the various types of challenges known to the oil  sector at present, which makes this a very challenging portfolio and makes 2011 a very important  year for exploration.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So more barrels in 2020, 70 million that’s our share, with a better divide between Joslyn and Fort  Hills and very importantly, a much faster ramp-up to the plateau.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: On the right hand side of the slide, you’ll see that between 2014 and 2018, Total will become the  biggest oil producer of the majors in the North Sea. Just as importantly, we’re not decreasing our  production. It’s going to be a good intrinsically rather than better than the others.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Now downstream-chemicals, we made a commitment last year regarding downstream-chemicals,  which I’ll repeat – that was to increase our profitability, the environment being unchanged by 4%  over the period 2010-2015. We’re now in the middle of the cycle. In fact, the middle of the cycle is  actually the 2010.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Chemicals, innovative chemicals, we are not just a green company but this is to tell you that we are  also capable of being more efficient and also capable of being much more responsible in terms of  global warming. Our goal is to produce from biomass, products of quality that is just as good as the  products we get from naphtha or ethane, but products that will be intrinsically profitable. Now there  are two ways of being profitable, either people accept to pay more for a cleaner product, or we  reduce our costs sufficiently to make them competitive. Now, which costs [inaudible], our  impression is that it will be a combination of those two factors.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: In all events, we can’t have the same thing without paying that price. Now, we are gradually  withdrawing from naphtha, as we have done with the ethane, but also methanol to olefin, or through  bio-polymers.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: 10 in chemicals, $3 billion in downstream. And as I told you earlier on, the bulk of our CapEx will be in  the upstream sector, which accounts for 80% of our total CapEx. Though we will not cease to invest  in other sectors of the business, other deserving sectors, particularly in Normandy where between  2012 and the years to come, we will be investing to bring this Normandy refinery up to market  specifications.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So we have increased financial flexibility. I’ll stress this point. I simply want to stress that at $80 a  barrel, we are as we were last year, at an average of $79.5. At $80 a barrel, the group is faring well.  Obviously at $100 a barrel, we would fare better. Now, that may seem somewhat self-evident, but  it’s important to be able to show you that new products will be more profitable when the price of oil  is $100. If it’s just a matter of increasing prices at the pump, that would not make us more  acceptable, nor would it improve our profits.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: Just a brief reminder to conclude regarding safety, the priority or importance that can be placed on  safety and reliability and social responsibility, profound change in each segment, especially after  Macondo or Deepwater Horizon. We will continue to re-shuffle our portfolio, not to shrink, but to  grow, but to grow better, should I say.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: I’d just like to make an announcement regarding safety and security here before beginning with the
texts.text: So it’s important to be able to benefit from a good oil price in order to prepare our future, without in  any way jeopardizing our demands in terms of financial policy.

file: TTE - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The important element, the reserve replacement rate, which has been the challenge for our company for many  years, close to 200%, that is the figure net of the price effect. That's great, but it's also linked with the policy we  have had for now a certain numbers of years. And with the new acquisition we've made recently, proved that it will  be for continuity and not just one short rate. The adjusted income plus 17%, $16 billion, it's what it is. It's not a  bad result, but we will see that when we compared to certain of our competitors, it's true that we still are a little bit  behind. When the price of oil climbs, we still are a little bit behind our competitors. And that's part of the strategy  we've had that we've explained to most of you when we presented the Upstream last year. We want to have more  and more asset in our portfolio which are more, we say, linked with the price of oil, the same way we are doing it  with the price of gas. It's important. It's not yet totally done, but it's on the way.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Operational excellence, we are a heavy industry company with a lot of responsibilities, but also a lot of force of  profits. It's nice to explore, it's nice to discover, but if you don't develop, no message about other companies, it has  no value. So the message is in Total, yes, we can also explore, but we are certainly among the best of the class in  the way we are developing our projects with new, innovative technologies and definitely with a clean  understanding that we need to make it in a clean way, on purpose these clean points. And increasing cash flow on  the period 2011 to 2015, we'll come back to it again.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So a quick word on what is supporting our strategy, what's important, I've always been clear on this, and until  further notice, even for those more pessimistic people in this room I know well, well, until further notice, we are  not yet at 70 points. I'm sorry for this, especially when we know that when price of oil is lower, Total is reacting in  a better way. But at the end of the day, why are we investing, because we believe in higher prices. So we still are  very cautious on the way we use these prices, $100 for long-term plateau, $80 for short-term plateau. We'll come  back to it, but definitely today we are at $111 for 2011.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Today we are, I don't know, I've heard almost at $119; just before we landed it was $118.7. I don't mean I'm pulling  it every minute, but I was just checking it before I came. And that's linked today definitely with geo-politics and  the weather. But at the end of the day, it's still there and, frankly, I know that a lot of people want it to be lower. I  don't know why, by the way, except if they are consumers. But if they are buyers of an energy company's shares,  you should appreciate that we need higher prices to make it long-term and profitable.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And that's the way we see it, because we don't see how it could decline with OPEC, what we call extra capacity  going down. And definitely on the top of it, still an increasing demand by 1% per year, that's our estimate, but 1%  per year makes it at the end of the day, which is in 20 year's time, a lot of additional oil and the decline, of course,  of oil fields, which is normal. Which means on that slide, in eight years' time, as you can see, we need to replace  almost 50% of the existing production with 40 million barrels per day. Today we produce 88, and that is linked  and coming from, at the same time, additional demand and pick-up.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Increasing demand for gas, which is good news for those who are moving more and more to gas, which is the case  of our company. While you remember, I've discussed it many times, we have more than ever, these three different  areas, zones, whatever it is. The U.S. was a very low price, $2.5 per million BTU, the – let's say, spot Europe which  is [indiscernible] (13:48), which is raising today to $10 per million BTU, $11 per million BTU. And Asia, which is  more than ever, especially after Fukushima, linked to the oil price. And today, the higher oil price is not yet in the  shouldn't even say, but let's say it's more than $17 per million BTU. So, it's almost eight times, or very close to  eight times, the price of United States.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So good news, bad news, it depends for whom. But we continue to consider this as very important for our LNG  project. Why LNG? Because LNG is the best way to be able to move from one area to the other one. And, for  instance, to move from the states if it happens, we will see this probably soon for us, but to go from low price of  gas to higher price of gas. Definitely, we'll continue to increase our share in LNG where we consider that we have a  real competitive positioning.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: What we did last year, we fully repositioned our portfolio. We sold $15 billion of assets during the period 2010,  2011. If we compare Total to its peers, we sold the value of 15% of our capital employed. We are ahead even of BP,  and we know why BP was selling assets. We reallocated funds through some acquisitions, $17 billion of  acquisitions. We acquired about 5 billion barrel of oil equivalent of resources at a price below $3 per barrel. And  something we would like to share with you is that the asset sales is definitely integrated in our strategy today, and  it's part of it.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And the cash flow generation, which is a part of our common concerns during this period, we have on one part of  the slide the cash flow generation on the realized price, so it's fully realized price of our portfolio, the price at  which we sell on an equivalent barrel position plus 32% to give you the figures for those who don't have it, it's 57%  for 2010, 75% for 2011 and the same 32% in terms of cash flow per barrel equivalent, which is moving from $22  per barrel of oil equivalent to $29 per barrel of oil equivalent, so it's cash flow well leveraged with the  environment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Strong production growth by 2015. So we maintain, of course, our commitment of 2.5% increase as an average for  – so to make everyone again happy with this, because we have always the debate of 2010 or 2011, when we talk  about 2.5%, it's starting at the end of 2010 or the beginning of 2011, which is the same, until 2015. And on this  period an average of 2.5% growth, which means by 2015 an additional 600,000 barrels per day and of which 95%  is producing or under development, which means committed, and that's important.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: LNG to value creation, just keep in mind that are we the second larger LNG player or the first, I don't think we are  the first, but are we the second or the third, doesn't mean anything. We are well positioned to increase the value of  our portfolio of assets and definitely on the top to value the trading of those assets and to trade the LNG contracts  that we have in our portfolio. Philippe, I already mentioned his name, Philippe Boisseau is not an executive  member, but he's in charge of something else, of our LNG trading. And I can tell you he is delivering net operating  income. So be it through trading or through our Upstream portfolio, we consider definitely that LNG even being  extremely capitalistic is bringing more cash to the company than the average portfolio.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Three LNG projects, just to say that it's good to use what we have, it's even better when you have other projects in  mind. So Ichthys has been launched, Angola will deliver soon. Gladstone has been launched but is not yet  delivering. So that's underway and we have other ideas in mind to continue to develop our activities in a part of  our business which we consider as one the most important and relevant parts of the Total portfolio.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Upstream investments. To have cash flow you need to invest. So here you have the organic investment, so it's  that's normal. Post-2017 because we are preparing the future, so we will not mention more than what it is. What's  important for you to remember is what we've always said is strict financial definition of the environment we use  for launching those projects. Short-term plateau, $80 per barrel, long-term plateau, $100 per barrel, $120, so  when it's more than $100 and even more than $80, it's more than what we are telling you in terms of what our  view is on the future.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Outlook. Well, first one word on CSR, it doesn't mean that it's not an important part of our strategy. Our view is  that – somebody told me don't talk about it. I said, yes, we need to talk about it, but just to say one simple word,  it's part of our strategy. It's not only a strategy, it's a priority, and more and more important where we operate  without CSR, there's no chance we can develop our business. So we'll not enter into details, ask if you want, but  definitely it's integrated in our strategy and it's integrated our decision of launching projects.

file: TTE - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 13February2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Compared to a year ago the worldwide economic situation is improving, and this creates a better environment for  Total. The market in terms of oil prices has been relatively stable and well above $100 per barrel for more than  two years now. Looking at 2012, despite the unexpected challenges we faced in the U.K. and in Nigeria and in  Yemen, the Group delivered strong and competitive results.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Let's talk first with health, safety and environment. You know the priority of Total is to be a responsible company.  We made significant progress in the rate of injury. Starting 2006, we were down by 18% last year. Of course, we  had those big incidents in Elgin and Ibewa, but I think our response to these incidents were appropriate and  efficient. We have incorporated lessons from both experiences in our safety culture. We have also improved our  impact on emission, energy efficiency and we limit our footprint on local environment. We believe that acting  responsibly is good for the business and good for the company.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: A few words about the environment, as you see, 2012 environment was generally favorable to our business. The  average oil price for 2012 was about $110 per barrel. This is partially due to the growth in oil demand of about 0.8  million barrels per day despite the related weak economic environment we were facing. Natural gas price in  Europe was about $9 per million BTU, $16 for Asia. Those are the two markets where we are more playing, that's  why globally for both oil and gas, the environment was favorable to us.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the project you have the usual suspects that you know delivering the major project to achieve our targets. This  is what we are focused on today. You are familiar with first name. I will point out CLOV, Laggan-Tormore and  Ichthys. CLOV and Laggan-Tormore are examples of two major offshore projects, that's where we are the operator  and that we are pushing hard to stay on time and on budget. Both projects are two-thirds complete and both are  on schedule today. In fact, all the new stuff that we need to achieve our 2015 production target are either already  producing or well advanced into development.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: LNG. LNG continues to be an important part of our Upstream story. This is representing 25% of the Upstream  results today. Using 2007 as a basis, we increased LNG production by 40% if you compare 2012 to 2007 and by  2016-2017 we anticipate 17 million tons of LNG capacity for the group. About 70%, this is on the right side, 70% of  our LNG is sold in Asia today. You remember the LNG price in Asia is quite high. And about 50% of our LNG  cargo are currently redirected to Asia or to other destinations.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Marketing & Services, this include network specialties and other businesses, including solar and new energies.  This segment contributed up to more than $1 billion of net operating income. This segment has a track record of  delivering a stable stream of results and represents valuable assets for the group.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So the outlook – I like the title of this slide, because it means that in our world everything changed, but finally the  impact on the, what we call, fundamentals is limited. What is changing you know, new production of tight oil,  shale oil in the U.S., even more production of shale gas, all of this is having an impact of course on the U.S.,  especially on North America as a whole, but globally at the world level, it still remains, I would say, not only under  control, but with limited impact on our view of the long term.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You cannot have a vision, you cannot have a strategy of a group without having to tell your investors what are your  views on price of energy. Here to make it short, Patrick told you that 2011- 2012, it was almost flat, average, at  $111 per barrel for oil. Today we are at $120. We definitely consider in Total that to launch our projects to make  budgets and plans is too high, and we need to be more conservative. So we're still using the $100 per barrel and  even less when we consider that plateau might be short and maybe a little bit more risky. In that case, we use the  $80 per barrel. But otherwise we don't see any reason to change this forecast when we see the result of all of those  changes on the fundamentals.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Fundamentals are clear. A lot of resources, much more than we thought, which is good news for our Energy sector,  which is good news for the oil and gas companies, but at the same time concern about having accessible resources,  having the capabilities to develop them and definitely it's the geo-politics, which is taking more and more  importance in our business.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: If you look at this, you see that the capacities remain almost at the same level. We still consider that by the year  2020-2025 the not peak, because there is no more peak, thanks to all of those resources, but the capacities  available will stay probably a little bit below $100 million per barrel, which means at the end, long-term dues,  long-term projects, but at the same time still I will say little available capacities to cover the needs of the  additional demand if needed.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We consider the display capacity today, which are somewhere below 5%, and by the way, it's almost only Saudi  Arabia, all other countries are producing at full speed. We see this for the year 2013 at around 2% to 4%, which is  relatively low and historically low. And with this, and still I would say a strong demand coming from the world  population growing; well, we definitely consider that, that is the best report for the price of oil the way we see it  today. If we had to have something on the top, on the top it will be the cost of developing those resources and to  move resources into reserves is getting higher and higher. And even if it's not the best part of the explanation, it's  also give us report to those relatively high level.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We like also to make a focus or zoom on LNG; first, because we always did it, so it will be surprising that we  coming from the U.S. Well, first, that still needs to come. I've been told recently, but why don't you buy HH gas for  export. I said, because there is still not yet an export. Now, it will come, that's part of our assumption. But when  you look at the need on the right part of the slide, well, you see that for the demand the way we see it, which is  almost double of what we have today by the year 2013, there's still almost 50% of the projects which have not yet  been sanctioned.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
