texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, it's good to say that there will be gas available, but it still need to be developed. And you know that it's not  always the easiest thing to do. So, we continue to invest. Yes, we will look for new opportunities. At the same time  with a strict discipline, we are having on all of those giant projects, keeping our costs within budget and delivering  on time. Today you know that production of LNG, the LNG business as a whole represents almost 25% of the  result of our Upstream.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the top, there's been a debate on are we sufficiently OECD, non-OECD. Well, today we have from those new  production, 50% coming from OECD. When you look at the total production of Total today, it's 45% OECD, 55%  non-OECD, and our reserves, 2P reserves is almost 50%-50%. So with this, definitely we are moving into a  production, which will be 50%-50% between OECD and non-OECD countries. What's important is, those projects  are good, sound, profitable projects all over the world, and in all of our, I would say, skilled.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So with this, that's why I started with the project and then I come to production and production targets, which is  our commitment. We have announced last time when we have been discussing our strategy that our target for the  year 2017 will be a production capacity target of 3 million barrels per day, which is a real challenge in a way.  Today, you know that 2012, we have been producing 2.3 million barrels per day, but it represents, in fact during  the two period 3% annual average growth of – during the period 2015 – 2011, 2015 and then reaching with  remaining 2015, 2016 and 2017 the 3 million barrel per day target. Of course, it's not oil, it's oil and gas, which  means oil equivalent.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: What will be the foundation for 2017 plus? Because I mean that's already what we are working. I won't say that  2017 is already done, but at least it's decided, I told you 90%. Here Patrick told you about the expectation we have  for 2013 in terms of exploration, exploration targets. Here we're talking about risk exploration, the figure €5  billion was non-risk; risk which mean that we have this percentage which is usually depending on what time we're  drilling, what between 15% and 30% of the probability of success. That give us for the period after 2017 with the  new acreage we have been taking, potential of 6 billion barrels equivalent. That will be definitely an important  part of the replacement of our reserves.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Production base of our resources. Our resources have been continuing to increase. Now, we are at more than 45  years of resources. But again, it's true, they are only resources, but our 2Ps have been also increasing the same way  our 1P. What's important is to continue to deliver our potential growth on where we have today, what we call our  production base, which is the deep offshore brownfield development like in the North Sea and satellites tie-backs,  which are important to bring what we call small fields, small reserves connected with existing facilities and on a  marginal basis, even if they are not used.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Figures in terms of size, it represents a lot of cash and a lot of profits. And still keeping what is needed for a  company like Total, keeping this long-term plateau projects which are making the cash and the sustainability of  the company, giant fields, LNG, unconventional, oil sands in Canada. That's the long term, but if we can do it as  we presented in an acceptable way, a sustainable way, that's definitely also part of what will be the future of the  energy industry and the one of Total.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Next slide, we'll not make it in – I mean, I think it's better to be commented on a one-to-one, but just keep  something in mind, we said, let us note what we said, we have 6% ROACE in 2010, and we said that we will try to  achieve a 13% ROACE in 2015 using the same environment of the one in 2010. If you do this, we still keep the four  categories of where we see the improvement of our profitability. It starts with what we call the new major projects  on main platform, plus 1.5%, then Specialty Chemicals plus 1%, portfolio changes 2%, and synergies and efficiency  2.5%. That's not new. What's important is we are now producing it and showing it to you in the most transparent  way what has been already achieved since 2010, what is to be achieved in 2013, that's the light blue, and what  remains to be done, which is the white part.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Respecting the environment is always respect. That's part of our commitment and to start with everything which  is linked with CO2 emissions. So we have a lot of new commitments that you will see in our, what we call SER  report based on flaring, based on water and all concerned about emissions and definitely the climate change.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Access to energy; well, that's our first commitment is to deliver energy to our clients, to the people on earth. It's  building our strategy and relationship on long-term partnership, that's what we're doing in a lot of countries, in  Africa, in Middle East, but also in Latin America. Well, I will say everywhere we operate, we definitely try to be  always in close cooperation with local companies and local governments. At least then we can talk to them and  definitely, which is important and expected from any company when you work somewhere, it's important that you  are part of the local development, local becoming more and more country and less and less only the local part  surrounding your activities.

file: TTE - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 12February2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Third point is CapEx, level of CapEx, which I think we've ourselves introduced as the enemy of our industry. What  I mean by this is the inflation on cost. CapEx are not enemies. CapEx is life, you cannot say that you want to  produce more oil, more gas, that you need between now and 2013 to replace something, which is [ph] and the shift  (7 :57) everybody 55 million barrel of oil per day equivalent and it will not come from investment. So that's very  important, that's five times the Saudi Arabia production. It's very simple. Don't ask me to produce the equivalent  in terms of reserves, because five times Saudi Arabia is more than the reserve of the world, so it doesn't match. But  in terms of production, it is what is it, 55 million is five time the production of Saudi Arabia and that's what we  need to cover the demand not to be better, not to be whatever, that is the world demand from people asking for  energy and that's our commitment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: But the thing is, going back to Total in this environment, which is a strong and wealthy environment, Total has to  be careful. We have been investing more than we used to, but that was important link with our strategy to be  better in terms of bringing additional production, additional reserves.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I have 10 minutes. I've just told it in 10 minutes. I said that we'll do it in five minutes that was just totally crazy,  but now I leave the floor to Patrick and I leave him with something he hates, not really, a little bit. He has to start  with CSR. I know I'm bringing and [indiscernible] (13:18) presentation but he will start with the first slide on CSR  and CSR is important for our company.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Thank you, Christophe. I knew since the beginning that you were enjoying the CSR slide we present to you as my  first slide. A few words about our culture, maybe not our philosophy, but our culture because those are in bottom  driver for every company. We are convinced that long-term sustainability depend on both acceptability and profit,  that's why you have profit on the left, acceptability on the right on the same slide.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: A few word about environment, you see that prices on oil and gas has been relatively stable over the past three  years, around $100 per barrel to $110 per barrel. For Brent, spare capacity has remained low, it is about 4% today  and demand growth has accelerated. Our view on the oil market has not changed. Globally, we bel ieve that oil  demand is ultimately constrained by supply.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For natural gas, on the right, there are three different areas, the U.S., Europe and Asia. Y ou see some depressed  gas price in the U.S., nothing new for you, keep in mind that our exposure to U.S. domestic gas price is extremely  low. And that we are well-positioned in both Europe and Asia to take advantage of the good pricing you can see  there. And globally speaking, oil prices were supportive of the investments launched by the industry including  ourselves.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Excluding ADCO, we expect to grow production by 4% in 2014 mainly from the startup of our project CLOV,  Laggan-Tormore and Ofon 2. The ramp-up of Angola LNG which we start in January and Kashagan but with only  limited contribution and some ramp-up also from [indiscernible] (20:51) in the U.S. And I remind you that the  new barrels going forward are accretive in term of cash flow.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Honestly, when you see this map, it is, I think, a good mix of long-plateau production as well as deep offshore and  LNG. LNG is an important part of our Upstream story and are of our portfolio. It represents close to 20% of our  production and more than 25% of the Upstream net operating income in 2013. In 2013, we had a startup of  Angola LNG, the sanction of Y amal, and we acquired interest in the Elk-Antelope.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Y ou can see on the left that we are on our way to more than doubling our LNG production from 2007 to 2017. Our  2013 LNG production was 12 million ton, which represents 19% of the total production of the Upstream division.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The light blue portion on the 2017 bar represents those projects which are in development: GLNG, Ichthys and  Y amal. Sanctioning Y amal was obviously a milestone event in 2013, and we show it to the right that Y amal, in  term of breakeven, is one of the best positioned projects among the currently existing project in the LNG business  at the moment. It is an onshore project with low cost and with competitive fiscal terms. The same type of  comment on deep offshore. Deep offshore, you know that Total is one of the leaders in deep offshore. Y ou see on  the left that our production from deep offshore more than doubled from 2007  to 2017 . The same with the light  blue on the 2017 bar, which has a project under construction: CLOV, Laggan, Moho and Egina, not mentioning  Kaombo, which is not yet sanctioned despite the very efficient cost reduction we have obtained and you will see  that later on.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I think the – our best result you see on 2013 where the refining margin was at $18 per ton in comparison to the  refining margin of 2012, which was $36 per ton and where we show a better net operating income in 2013 than in  2012, shows that we are making good progress despite the weaker environment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, the first one is, as we did many times is to talk about the oil demand. We didn't change a lot versus the  presentation I made last September, 0.6% growth in the world demand for oil. I come back to one of the point I  mentioned during the opening of this presentation is, well, you need only for this 0.6% growth in 16 -year time.  Y ou have to understand that now 2030 is 16 years' time, which is in our industry  tomorrow. And people telling me  I mean 2030 is tomorrow. And tomorrow, we need 55 million barrels additional with being relatively conservative  in the decline of existing fields that hit the five-time Saudi Arabia. And was still unlimited, I would say, unused  capacities in the world. So we have as an industry, we have as a company, to accompany this demand for oil and  gas, which means for energy and what we need to do on the top as Total is not only to do it for doing it, but do it  with profit, do it with, as Patrick said, added value to the company, which means to our shareholders. So all of  those additional barriers of Total need to be bringing value and that's the case.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the gas, we have to focus on LNG. I could and we'll certainly be challenged on what our forecast on gas price of  the world, but let's start with LNG in which we are extremely implicated. We see a 5% growth as an average  between now and 2030, which means that you'd be in a need for finding 100% more new projects. Today, we are  relatively 250 million ton per year.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In 2030, it's almost the same figure, which means that with the new sanctioned projects not yet during  production, we will just be able to sustain to today's capacities and then we will need to bring an almost equivalent  and in fact more new project on stream by that time if we want to cover the demand. And [ph] I was over (38:38)  surprised to hear people say, we can bring more LNG, but without projects. Y ou need new projects and projects  are getting old if they are not, I will say, reinvested, if you don't reinvest in it, if you don't find new ones.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So Total definitely believes in new projects. We've said it with the FID of Y amal. Again, we insist on having  breakeven on those project being as much as we can below 2012 that's the case for Y amal, if possible below 2014. I  will come back in this probably in September, but definitely today, you should believe in energy, you cannot expect  to do it with price of gas being [ph] HH (39:26). So we need and that is a challenge of the indu stry is to invest in  new projects. What I mean by challenging in terms of technology, not always in the easiest environment like  Y amal, but [ph] we use (39:43) breakeven which are bringing again I insist value to the shareholder.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: [indiscernible] (39:50) the problem for a company like Total is to deliver oil and gas, which is needed and also to  deliver it and being profitable. So as Patrick like to say, the two sides of the slides are always important. Cover the  need, be profitable.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Well, you have the list of the project in the document you received, which now we're using as an a ppendix and not  anymore as one of the major slide. But what is important is all of those projects, the new one represent, as you can  see on the slide, the 7 00,000 barrels per day additional in 2017 . And all are on track to achieve the startup. So  that's why we are confident.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: But just to say 2013, Patrick said what it was. Two real new, I'd say, discoveries, which are Kurdistan and  Argentina and two potential main discoveries, but potential, Ivory Coast and I would add, which is not on the  slide, Gabon where for the same reasons, we discovered what we call a play, a kitchen, as our geologist like to say,  which means hydrocarbons, but at the same time today not at a commercial level. However, we continue to work  on this and especially the first on Ivory Coast. So [ph] we're not (48:16) c ome back on what was said the same  $2.8 billion, we keep the same budget for 2014, it's not increased, 60 wells. And definitely, which is more  important, the 1 billion barrel target risk net share and see what it means, because I mean, don't produce slides , if  you cannot explain, what it means by risk. It means that we use percentage of discovery and by definition is our  share in terms of percentage in those block. 1 billion, again, I would not repeat that it is mostly Brazil, Angola,  Ivory Coast and South Africa, but we have to be committed.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Our [ph] initial track (50:44) to achieve the actual target, I mean, Patrick has been extremely clear on this, but  exactly the same slide you know now I hope by -heart is how we intend to achieve the 13% target by 2015.  Remember, it's based on 2010 environment plus we are – sometimes we are making maybe the life not as easy as  you would like, but we're here to help. That's where if you see the 13%, you see that the 11.5% is in 2014 is with the  2010 environment, not with the environment which will be what it will be. But it means that with the 2010  environment, 2014, we are at 1.5% of the target we have for 2015, which means that what remains to be done by  the R&C [indiscernible] (51:43) division and I can tell you they have been already delivering a lot, the – I would  say now but it is not dark blue, so what is not dark blue is light blue in English. Okay. So  the light blue, and the  white part is what remains to be done to achieve our targets. And I can tell you that's all underway and definitely  we can say that Refining & Chemicals have been above our expectations. Thanks God, because the refining  margins have been below our expectations. We are today at less than zero as the European margin, today it's a  little bit higher, but as an average, it's below zero.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Same for Marketing & Services, what is important is to keep the same profitability, the same return in branch a nd  the division where we increased our investment and where we want to definitely want to be more aggressive.  Definitely, we need to be more aggressive in countries where you have natural growth and for us, it's mainly Africa  and Middle East. We are, as you know, much more careful than we have been [ph] into the (53:50) time about  Asia. Asia is great, but it's sometimes surprising. So we prefer to go in places we know, it's part also the culture of  Total. Africa and Middle East is much more in our "backyard", but that's where we intend definitely to increase  the size of our market shares and to do it in a profitable way, which also means sustainable and acceptable and  respecting the people, respecting the environment. So that's for the growth of the marketin g division.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Lubricants, we insist on this because we have definitely some gap to fill versus our competitors. If you know well,  the lubricants, you would know that three of our competitors among the four are bigger than us and are doing  better. So we still have room for improving our position. That's what we're doing with lubricants and definitely, I  mean, changing our model, which we call the business model. We can't develop additional market share without  having to invest too much. We need to be careful with marketing [ph] and these will remain the (55:08) division in  which the capital employed remains low versus the profit. And that's how you achieve the profitability and the  return to equity and to shareholder. We're not insisting on leveraging brands and innovation, because that's true  for all of our divisions, for all of our developments. But the target is to remain above 17% in Marketing & Services.  As you've seen, it's excluding new energies, new energies being solar, but if you remember solar is fir st not only  working, SunPower today and have been – that's normal question about our investment.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: It's true that last time I think we've made the presentation it was at $6 per share. Today, I have the pleasure to say  it is at $31. So for those who said, it will never go back to higher levels than the one you had to acquire the  company, well, it's normal they said it. I can tell you, we're not bad, it will be at $31 today. So let's get the benefit  of this, but for the time-being which is more important for new energies like solar. Let's be careful, let's be  confident in this new energy, but at the same time, let's be careful we still have to reduce our costs, reduce our  breakeven and be sure we can compete with other sources of energies, which means electricity. But today, the  price is $31 and I can tell you it's not Total buying shares to increase the value.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Are we going to see price being reduced? We are not so optimistic considering capital expenditure because we  know that for capital expenditure, we need still to take care of the environment, about security, about  sustainability and that has a cost. But the cost base on what you are adding in terms of additional investment, not  in inflation. The 10% inflation cannot last and will not last. But we'll have to prove it. We will take the time for  this, which means, today, we have been putting in place a new system to get this as becoming a target for the  company.

texts.speaker: Christophe de Margerie
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So Upstream has to be extremely careful on the way they take for their own account this concern of just be careful  with your cost. Refining & Chemicals, no need to say that even if they've been able already to change the way the  situation was moving, which means declining in the return. That's not anymore the case, but we still have to be  concerned of what we are facing an unknown environment. I am [ph] even seeing maybe (1:10:13) strange, I must  feel comfortable with, first of all, in price of gas and refining margin or petrochemicals margin.

file: TTE - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Since the loss of Christophe, our company Total has been faced with two major transitions: an economic transition  and the price of oil dropped for more than $100 per barrel to less than $50 per barrel and we will come back,  obviously, on this change during the presentation. But also management transition not only for myself as CEO,  but also of the executive committee team.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Coming back on the economic challenge, economic transition, it is true that we have entered into a new oil cycle,  as we experienced at least four wells, since 1988 and 1985, in 1990 and 1996, and in 2008. And in front of this  challenge what we want to do is to react, but not to overreact. I used these words in November, when I made my  first visit to some investors, how we maintained them. Not overreact on the medium-term, because we have the  financial capacities, the flexibilities to weather the storm and to maintain our medium and long-term growth  strategy, even if we'll have to be more selective on some projects. But also react on the short-term, because we  have to face a $10 billion challenge, cash challenge, when the price dropped from $100 per barrel to $50  per  barrel, which represents for us $10 billion less cash flow.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But with every challenge, there is an opportunity to be considered as a constraint. It could also be considered as an  opportunity. And we see the drop in the oil price as a real opportunity. The time is right for us to learn how to do  more with less, to be more efficient with the organization and the assets and to get the most out of every dollar  what we spend and invest. And I mean we supply to the industry – to the world industry, not just to Total.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Faced with far lower oil prices than anyone had predicted, we are responding with a significant and immediate  company-wide effort to mitigate the impact, mainly by reducing spending, reducing CapEx, cutting of raising  costs, constraining our actuation budget voluntarily, right-sizing our headcounts, and accelerating the asset sales  program.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As you will see compared to last year and including the incremental contribution of all new start -ups, we will  generate an additional cash flow of around $8 billion, out of which $5 billion are new action plans decided since  the end of November and the sharp decline of the oil price. This is equivalent to reducing our breakeven by $40  per barrel, and this will recapture sustainable efficiencies with these effo rts as we make Total a more efficient  company in the future regardless of the environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Y ou can see that in all the statistics, in all the benchmarks, the best plants in Europe in safety are also the best  reserves in availability, reliability; the best reserves in cost control – question of maintenance policy generally by  the way, and also often best reserves in energy efficiency. All that is going hand-in-hand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Y ou can also see the example on you left of the slide, for Refining & Chemicals, you will see that I will use  many  examples of Refining & Chemicals for obvious reasons, because we have been successful, so I will try to use it as a  good example to put pressure on Philippe as well. But, there we have been able in this sector at the same time to  improve the reliability, the availability, which is really the reason why the reserves are so good today. And in the  meantime, it was clearly together to decrease by more than 40% the recordable accident rate.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Questions about environment as well. The example, which is taken there is a commitment which was taken by the  company 10 years ago to diminish by two [indiscernible] (13:43). It's not only a question of preserving the  atmosphere quality, the air quality; it's also a question of economic performance, of monetizing the ga s, which was  lost in our operations. We just started Ofon 2 operations, reducing by 10% offering in the company and  monetizing the gas at the same time in our energy plan.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So once again, this is efficiency, safety, environment, quality is really of primary importance because it  participates directly to the improvement of the performance of the company.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What we need to do is not to predict the oil price, but to prepare ourselves to be competitive within a variety of oil  price scenarios. Because indeed, we are in fact in the commodity business, where volatility is an imminent part of  this industry like a lot of commodity industry. And so, what we need to do is, of course, to understand why, whe re  the price could go in order to behave properly on the short-term. But it's also on a more permanent basis to  permanently think to a breakeven in order to reduce it and in order to be profitable and, at whatever the price will  be.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the gas side, I would say its length will depend on the regions. In Asia, as you know, there is a clear link  between oil and gas prices. We are using there a proxy, which is not exactly reflecting the truth because in of the  LNG contracts, there is a time lapse of three months to six months, which by the way will benefit in our reserves.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the U.S. the price today is in the bottom, $2.50. I think you have huge storage of gas today in the U.S., so  despite the liquids going down, the gas is even lower than before. And Europe, there is clearly, the gas is fol lowing,  I would say, the driver is more the core competition. So, we saw the type of figures that we have shown today, we  have in these environments, once again the right industry and answer for us is to reduce or breakeven.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, we have the oil demand going from 2013, 87 million barrels per day to 97 million barrels per day in 2030, if we  take these assumptions. But, what is more important, as you all know, is that there is a decline and that around us  of the present predictions we'll disappear between 2013 and 2030. So, we'll have to reinvest in new fields the oil  industry, if we want to be able to fulfill the demand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But having said that, we know that if we want and you see if we want to admit the demand vis -à-vis in fact, we'll  have to put into production fields, which will require innovations and high technologies like  [indiscernible]  (20:32) like oil sands, like shale oil, and we will require investments. And all that we sustain a high price and I  have little doubt that the price of $90 barrel or plus will come back. The question is when. But, as we are investing  not for one year, not for five years, but for 25 years, it's important to keep issue in our mind and not to be  distracted in the way we want to handle the strategy.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Same type of slide. In fact for the LNG. We focused on LNG because we are one of the main players in LNG. We  have a rule of growth rate from 5% to 4% this September and today. But there again, if you look carefully to that  slide, if we just consider, we only consider the already sanctioned projects, we would coup only a growth in the  demand of 1.6%.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, to be able to meet the demand growing at 4%, we'll need to put into production potential projects, which will  have cost up to $14 per million Btu and then again, which will require high energy prices, if we want these  investments to be sanctioned in the future. So, there are many reasons to consider, but we need to stay the course  on our medium and long-term strategy and not to any shift even if we have once again to adapt ourselves to the  short-term environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second power point is that we recognize that the industry was facing, I would say, a cost challenge already  beginning of 2014, even before when we began to be more disciplined on capital spendings. And we launched in  September, our cost reduction initiative for the OpEx. So, we were already in that mood and we were ready to even  intensify with the force as we'll present you in the next slide.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Obviously, today we benefit from that because of the sharp decrease of the crude stocks. But, it is important, and  we are able to do it, is to have a valuable plan to take the full benefit of that, which is down. And so, we need to  continue with restructuring in Refining & Chemicals to keep lowering breakeven, but we are on the way. And  Marketing & Services are not only proving stable, but proving reserves through the cycle, so I would say some  stability, which is highly appreciated when you face such volatility.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Having said that, we need to organize ourselves to have a strong response to the 2015 environment and there's a  challenge of losing $10 billion of cash flow and so we organize it around the, I would say three big action plans,  one consider costs, the other one start-ups and the third one sales.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I would say in this reduction, two-thirds is really permanent reduction I would say. Let's consider what's a  strategic decision, which is to put under constrain our exploration team in order to oblige them to make some  choices. And from that point of view, we took the lessons from the last three years where we increase quite a lot  the exploration budget without the success we expected. So, we need to take lessons and to react. This is what we  are doing, but the budget of $1.9 billion will allow exploration to commenting [indiscernible] (28:33) from  program and drill the best prospects but managing [indiscernible (28:42) risk.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking at the financial results, we reported $12.8 billion of adjusted net income. Compared to 2013, this is down  by 10%, basically in line with the 11% decrease in our average realized oil and gas prices. Upstream was the main  contributor and these reflect the return to production growth. I'll remind you CLOV, which provided a strong  contribution this year 2014. The strong restructuring in the Refining & Chemicals lead to a 10% improvement in  the Downstream results, particularly in the second half. Of course, we enjoy also during the second half and the  same to-date a good level of margin on the market.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the right side, you see our after-tax impairment, basically due to the rapidly changing context in late 2014. We  recorded impairments, $7.1 billion after-tax. We test MPV discounted at our WAC and the impairments reflect  changes that we made to our forecasted oil and gas prices, as well as European refining margin.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Most of the write-down, about 75%, were in Upstream and conventional gas o il sands and the most of it in the  other, which is not as margin use than the unconventional in the oil sand, but in the other you have the pipeline of  cash again for instance. And one-fourth of those impairments are related to European refining, mainly UK and  France.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: At Total, we began to accumulate liquidity well before year-end. When we started to see the oil price dropping, we  started to accumulate cash. That's why at the end of the year, we had $15 billion of net cash available to us. A  normal level is between $7 billion and $8 billion.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Thank you, Patrick. Good afternoon, everyone. It's been less than six months, since I made my first presentation  to you and a lot has happened during that time. The sudden downturn of the environment has had a profound  effect on Upstream and it is clear that the pressure is on us to improve the underlying profitability of Upstream  quickly and effectively.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: The Total story is a growth story and the Upstream is the engine of this growth. The most important change is our  successful bid for 10% of ADCO concession in Abu Dhabi. This reinforces our strategy presence in the Middle East  with much better margins. This represents fourth year of stable, long plateau oil production for our portfolio as  well as a source of trading volumes and ADCO production should increase to 1.8 million barrels per day by 2018.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Being the first major to win has positioned us as a leader on two -third of the fields of ADCO, and this gives us  additional asset fields, which announce our returns. In 2015 compared to last year, we forecast an industry - leading production growth of more than 8%. This is based, as was mentioned by Patrick, by eight new start -ups,  including three that are already on production today. The new projects will represent more than 25,000 barrels  per day, and that's including CLOV, of course, plus the new ADCO contract and of course, less some impacts from  reduced investments on natural field or on shale plays in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: In terms of full-year averages, our organic reserve replacement rate is improving. In the 2012 -2014 period, we  averaged 111% compared to 92% in the previous three-year period. We start 2015 with $11 billion of proved  reserves, which represents more than 13 years of production and we have more than 20 years of proved and  probable reserves. ADCO is a 2015 event, so the $2 billion plus of new reserves are not included here. This will add  more than two years of 10% of our 2P reserves.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Now, let's speak about cost; specifically reducing costs and this is another of my four key points. Patrick outlined  for you, Total response to the 2015 environment and I understand very well that it falls to Upstream as the largest  segment in the company to make the deepest cuts and we have the flexibility to cut costs.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Total was an early mover in the drive to reduce CapEx and OpEx. So, we are already engaged in the process of  reducing our expenditures. In the Upstream, we are cutting CapEx from $23 billion in 2014 to $20 billion in 2015.  As you can see on the chart, we've split the CapEx reduction between greenfield, basically investments on projects  and brownfield, which is spending on producing properties like infill wells, new compression facilities and so  forth.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Of the greenfield, we are slowing down or delaying projects. For example, Utica is unconventional U.S. shale, so  we have the flexibility there to reduce. On some new projects, cost are just simply too high and we are not going to  award contracts. We have the situation and Zinia 2 in Angola or on Bonga Southwest in Nigeria and we have  decided to postpone the FID. Let's see, if the service industry gets the message.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: For the brownfield, we are cutting some marginal projects, notably on metro areas like Congo and Gabon in West  Africa; and in the UK and in Norwegian North Sea. Some of these projects we are chasing marginal high cost  barrels and do not make economic sense in today's environment. Most of this CapEx was based on a two years  payout period. This is definitely no longer the case. So, we have to wait for higher prices.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: For OpEx, we are doubling the 2015 cost cutting program. On the graph, we show that OpEx increases as volume  increases and we plan to more than offset this by our cost cutting program. This will include increasing efficiency,  search as hiring freeze that Patrick mentioned, but also our expanded plan includes a staff reduction down to  about 15,500 people by year-end in Upstream.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: In addition to that, with the new environment, we are going after another $400 million, some of which will come  of course from a better leverage to renegotiate contracts down with our main service providers. So, as you can see,  Total is responding to the change in the environment immediately and significantly, and the Upstream is at the  forefront of this effort.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Equally important in terms of increasing the Upstream oil shale, $25 billion of capital employed will move to  producing status. Reducing the preproduction capital employed to roughly 30% will bring us back in line with  historical norms and will contribute significantly to improving our profitability.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: As I told you last September, I am a hands-on manager. Termokarstovoye is ahead of schedule and advancing  rapidly towards a start-up next quarter. However, persistent weather and productivity issues at Laggan-Tormore  have delayed the start up to 3Q of this year. This means that 2015 start-up are split four in the first half and four in  the second half.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: As mentioned by Patrick, the exploration budget has been scaled down by 30% from $2.8 billion in 2014 to $1.9  billion this year. And Patrick mentioned that this decision was two-thirds strategic and one-third linked to the oil  price. And that's because we believe that the exploration budget has got to be put under constraints if we want the  team to make choices and so that we improve the efficiency of exploration process.

texts.speaker: Arnaud Breuillac
texts.profession: President-Exploration & Production Division
texts.text: Now acquisition strategy is pragmatic and opportunistic, with a focus mainly on giant reserves. Over the 2012- 2014 period, we acquired 2.5 billion barrel of oil equivalent at an average cost of less than $3 per BOE.

texts.speaker: Philippe Sauquet
texts.profession: President-Refining & Chemicals Segment
texts.text: Without detailing all of these, because I guess that most of you are familiar with this roadmap, you will notice that  cost cutting and plant availability that are reported here under the synergies and efficiency item have been a key  success story with $450 million delivered on the $650 million target, which means that, by the way, that we have  still one-third of additional further saving to deliver to reach our 2015 target. This is part of the pressure that  Patrick is putting on me and my team.

texts.speaker: Philippe Sauquet
texts.profession: President-Refining & Chemicals Segment
texts.text: Y ou're also aware that as part of our restructuring program launched in 2011, we had set for 2017, the target of  reducing our European refining and petrochemical by 20%, using closures, using asset sales, and you can read on  the chart below the blue arrow on the left side, what we did to get to a 5% reduction at the end of this year,  including the last announcement of closure of our Hacker in Carling, and not forgetting Dunkirk refinery closure  that took place earlier in 2010.

texts.speaker: Philippe Sauquet
texts.profession: President-Refining & Chemicals Segment
texts.text: Now, we're entering 2015; and in 2015, we are accelerating the pace. This morning, we announced that here in the  UK, we are closing the $5 million ton per year distribution unit at our Lindsey refinery, which represents 50% of  its capacity. And we are rightsizing its costs to allow us to breakeven.

texts.speaker: Philippe Sauquet
texts.profession: President-Refining & Chemicals Segment
texts.text: And within a few months in spring, we will make another announcement that will affect this time our French  refining system. We manage this decision with care and with anticipation, and we act  responsibly, but we have no  hesitation. Our teams are made aware that our core values of sustainability and of social responsibility depend  ultimately on our ability to remain profitable.

texts.speaker: Philippe Boisseau
texts.profession: President-Marketing, Services & New Energies
texts.text: And here you can see the so-far the track record of what we have accomplished; but again, we have identified, we  have selected several ideas where the price of crude oil is very different 2010, $80 a barrel; 2012, $112 a barrel in  average; and last year 2014, $99 a barrel.

texts.speaker: Philippe Boisseau
texts.profession: President-Marketing, Services & New Energies
texts.text: Of course, given the environment, although, in our distribution business, which is a low margin business, we are  consistently reducing OpEx. We launched a very specific additional OpEx reduction program and we adjusted our  capital choices and our investment policy to allow the group to benefit from more cash flow from this part of the  activity.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And last slide, back to the introduction. I'm sure you're convinced that we are on one side organizing a strong  response to the environment challenge; and on the other side, we are seeing of course on the mid -term strategy.  I'll not come back to all what we said, just to be sure to clear with you that we are very committed to these  objectives. We are even more committed, because the board of director for my own compensation, and I will do  the same with all my top executives and all the executives of the company will be compensated directly linked to  the reserves on these cost-reduction programs.

file: TTE - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Since started the job, this challenge has been staying the course despite the oil price collapse. As I told you in  September, we are in the commodity business and volatility is relevant to this business. So, even if we meet every  six months, you don't have to expect today to have huge news. We'll not change every six months all t he guidelines  that we give you. And in fact, what we intend to do today as we partake is, of course, to comment to you the results  of 2015, and then to give you some guidelines for next year 2016 but keeping what we say to you for the medium  term as a basis. And I think it's, by the way, a good philosophy not to go up and down according to the price of oil  but to try to keep a stable strategy and this is what we will try to do, a sustainable and a stable strategy for the  medium term.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And in 2015, we had three reasons why all performance are resilient. The first one is that because we benefit from  the integrated model. With all the strategy of the group since last 15 years and before has been to keep, to  maintain in the company the full value chain on oil, oil and gas, from exploring, producing, transforming,  distributing. And this model which sometimes was discussed is proving today its full efficiency because, of course,  part of the value which are lost in the Upstream has been recovered in the downstream business. As the main  figure which illustrates that is that the downstream cash generation in 2015 has been $8 billion, which is quite an  improvement compared to the $3 billion that downstream was delivering in 2011.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Good afternoon, everyone. Let's move first to the macro. I'm pretty sure that you are fully aware of that but what  you see basically is the collapse on the oil price, which basically fall by half of its value. This is not the first collapse  we are facing and maybe not the last one but this one is important. We are just over one year in the cycle. Brent  fell by exactly 47% to $52 per barrel. Our liquid realization also fell by 47%. On the same part of the slide, you see  that the refining margin in blue increased by a factor of more than 2.5 to $48 per ton.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the right side, you see the evolution of the gas price o n the three main markets. Total average gas realization is  minus 33%. Y ou see that Henry Hub dropped dramatically between $2 and $2.50 per Mbtu currently. L&G prices  dropped less than the oil price because of lag effect on one side and also on the S-curve type of price formula.  Honestly, we have quite a bit – have little exposure to the U.S. gas market at the moment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Again, we set ourselves aggressive but realistic targets. We have delivered them and we are outp erforming our  peers which is of course a way to differentiate yourself because in fact what we want to deliver to our shareholders  is to be able to differentiate Total from our main competitors. I just – we would like before to enter in 2016  outlook, remember what I told you in September as well. We are transitioning from an intensive investment phase  and so the level of committed CapEx is falling off. We are delivering our production, growing production. And so,  all that is giving us increasing financial flexibility. It's not fully the case in 2016 and you will see that we are still  engaged in many projects, even if we manage to adapt ourselves to the new environment of $30 per barrel, but it  will be more and more the case in 2017 and beyond. And if we turn on top of that, transitioning from very  intensive investment phase, production growing, we had OpEx savings across the board and we'll continue that,  we understand why we are continuing to lower the breakeven.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: For 2016, of course, compared to September meeting where the price was around $50, $60 per barrel, we are  facing a $30 environment. So, we had to adapt ourselves to strengthen some returns. At the same time, we were  on track and we didn't want to derail from what we think is the right way to maneuve r. So, you will see that we are  still on the asset sales that we have made some allocation on CapEx, [indiscernible] (26:41) on OpEx savings as  well. But again, the main strategy there is to keep on the track, to stay the course compared to we were then.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just again on OpEx, of course. So, there again, as Patrick told you with initial target for 2015 was $800 million, we  increased it beginning of last year to $1.2 billion, more than $1.2 billion, we told you. [indiscernible] (29:46)  towards mainly on the Upstream because most of the efforts, in fact every divisions were concerned, but the  increase of OpEx saving has been delivered by Upstream which is obviously the division which is the most  understressed because of the low oil price. They managed to deliver savings around more than $1 billion.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In September, I told you that the target for 2017 of the full year cost saving program was improved or increased  from $2 billion to $3 billion. I will not change it today. We are just adding about $ 3 billion. You will see next time  what could be mean above. But today, we have concentrated what we could deliver in 2016. And what is the target  for 2016? As you can see, it's more than halfway between 2015 and 2017. It's $2.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: What I can tell you is, contrary to some other companies, we don't make headlines with staff reductions. I learned  something when I was refining and chemicals. If you want really people to be motivated of impr oving their  operational performance, on delivering your cost-saving program and if they are afraid for their own job, you'll  obtain nothing. So, you just have to know what is your priority. And our priority today, and we are delivering it, is  to increase the operational efficiency and to deliver the cost-saving program.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: A quarter of it, this reduction is coming from ADCO barrels because they are low-cost barrels and they have some  advantage in such an environment. And the last quarter of reduction is coming from foreign exchange. So, we  know we are very transparent to give you the explanation.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But we are continuing to work in the savings program. But E&P is putting in play for 2016 to lower this operating  cost to $6.50 per barrel, so a decrease of 35% or $1 per barrel in two years.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And you can look at it also on the right-hand side of the slide, which is a technical cost, under the same norm of  SEC norm which is not only the OpEx per barrel, but you have the DD&A per barrel and also the exploration costs  per barrel. And this, today, is going down to $23 per barrel in 2015 compared to more than $28 per barrel in 2014.  As you can see on the graph, we are the best among the majors. And I'm sure, with these results, we'll maintain  our leadership on this one. It's very important. Of course, it's coming not only for $2.50 per barrel reduction, not  coming from OpEx but $1 is coming from exploration because we reduced the efforts. But you will see that we  have a [indiscernible] (35:50). And part of it also is coming from the DD&A, which is probably more surprising  because we are putting on stream some new projects with historical high CapEx, but we are also benefiting from  the ADCO barrels there.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, it will be delivered. We have also in 2015 over operated projects, which will start up, Vega Pleyade in  Argentina. It's a gas project. And Incahuasi in Bolivia [indiscernible] (38:05) Vega Pleyade by first semester,  probably by March or April; and Incahuasi by middle of the year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then two of the big projects, the non-operated by us are – will start up in 2015. Angola LNG will start. In fact,  these two projects will be started. We do not know when we will start. For Angola LNG, the operator announced as  April, let's say, by middle of the year. And Kashagan and all the consortium is clear on December 2015. So, I'd just  repeat to you what 2016 – sorry, 2015. Nobody really knows. So, 2016.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, it was the first one, and it's the first discovery. So, I hope it will continue. So, I encourage them to give us  further advice to farm-in in some licenses. It's a new gas province [indiscernible] (40:33) Myanmar and there are  – we have domains there around, and we are quite excited about it.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have also discovered gas in Argentina. I just mentioned Vega Pleyade starting up. Leo is a new discovery. It's a  fairly conventional gas pit, which could be connected to [indiscernible] (40:51) installation like Phoenix. And as  Patrick told you, we do not – we decided to stop the sales – the sale of [indiscernible] (40:57) for two reasons.  First reason that it's true, but we had an offer, which was just diminishing month after month. So, in Octobe r, I  thought and we decided to stop all that because we don't want to lose value on such a nice asset [indiscernible]  (41:11) we are not in desperate situation, not at all. The second reason is that, in fact, we are making discoveries  around Daesan, Ukot South, Owowo West, so there's a big potential. So, I think all that, in front of this, we  decided to stop the sales because we prefer to keep the asset.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then we have some appraisals which were giving some reserves, and Vaca Muerta in Argentina is a shale g as play.  We clearly – we have in our hand quite a big portfolio of shale gas. We have agreed to launch the first phase of  development of $500 million. It's linked to the gas pricing policy from the Argentinean government, so we are  discussing with the new government and I'm optimistic we could have some good pricing – gas pricing policy,  which should allow us to launch the first phase of gas shale in Argentina quickly in 2016.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then, I will move to the Downstream. Obviously, I can tell you, if four years ago, somebody would have told me  that the Downstream process of Total would have a ROACE of 32%, I would not have bet a single penny on it. We  were the laggard of the industry. It's clear. It's why in March we decided to restructure, and to ask Philippe and  myself and by that time to take this part of the company and to lead it. It's not only ou r job, it's the job of  everybody. But at the end of the day today, we have ROACE of more than 40% in Refining & Chemicals, more than  20% in Marketing & Services. So, it's – and I can tell you that the Downstream team today in Total are very  motivated maybe a little too much. We have to cool that down sometime. But it's better than before. And they can  compete with the leaders of the Upstream leaders. So, it is very good to have all these two, downstream and  upstream divisions, being proud of working in the company and delivering results.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And this will allow us – we will be implementing in 2016. And this will allow us to reach our target to lower our  European capacity by 20% by end 2016 instead of end 2017. So, this is the lesson when it's not because we have  good times, but you need to stop your efforts. On the contrary, because this is when you have a good time that you  can't repair the lower – the worst time.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And so, we are doing that. We are also in Refining & Chemical, in 2016, we'll deliver the investment in Antwerp  with new conversion units and we are also working in Saudi Arabia on the capacity creep of SATORP. SATORP is  running perfectly well, 400,000 barrels per day, a very high variability today. It's a brand -new plant. But we are  beginning to discuss, and we are more than discussing, we are studying and we'll invest in enhancing the capacity.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And as I told you as well and in the next slide, at $60 per barrel from 2017 – no, sorry. Something is going – yeah,  at $60 per barrel, we will be able to cover 100% – could you – this one. Stop. Thank you. We will be able to cover  the dividend in cash at $60 per barrel. The board of directors of Total is comfortable, first of all, because the  payout ratio of the company, as you can see, is quite reasonable. It increased from 58% in 2014 to 60% in 2015  despite the collapse of the oil price. So, we are still in the range around 50%. And we are again – we think it's  reasonable to maintain the dividend at this level.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just giving you two slides on what happens beyond. First of all, the slide of macro. I'm unable to give you  the price  of oil tomorrow morning. I don't know when the price will rebound, but I'm convinced it will rebound. And I will  tell you why. It's quite a simple schematic. We just compare 2015 and 2020. Y ou all know that the average decline  in this oil industry is around 5%. And by the way, this decline will not be lower if we continue to invest less  [indiscernible] (54:19). It will even accelerate the decline.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you take 5% out of a market of 90 million barrel of oil per day, on five years, that means that the decline  represent 20 million of barrel of oil per day of capacity, which will disappear. If you add on the top of that, the fact  there's a growth, let's take 1%, 1.2%, which is 1 million barrel of oil per day of [indiscernible] (54:41) per year. It's  not – it's again conservative. And for this year, in 2015, it was 1.6 million, 1.7 million barrel of oil per day.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, if you take 1 million barrel of oil per day of additional demand per year, this means that the new capacity to be  invested in the next five years for 2015, 2020 is 25 million barrel of oil per day. I asked other teams to look to the  database to know exactly what was truly being developed, being invested. It's around between 15 million and 20  million. In fact, the exact figure [indiscernible] (55:14) gave me is 17 million, I think. But it means that what is  missing in new capacity is 5 million to 10 million barrel of oil per day.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When you look to what we have decided in 2015, the whole industry is almost nothing. It's less than 500,000  barrel of oil per day for one year. So, we are in an industry because of the huge volatility that we are facing. Of  course, everybody is exaggerating the reaction. We try to do it in Total in a smooth way, 15% of decrease per year  because we're exiting the early investment phase, but there are other players around the world which are even  more reactive.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And so, we are under investing in the industry. That means that one way or the other, I don't know if it's 2020 or  maybe before, there will be a lack of supply and it's not only a question of shale oil in North America, it's more of a  question of conventional oil around the world.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second slide I want to comment for a little longer view is what does it mean, what means the Paris Agreement  [indiscernible] (56:41) for a company like Total? Well, for me, I'm a strong believer as well and with the board of  directors and the executive committee and we signed a declaration we oversee in October but we have to integrate  the 2 degrees C roadmap into our strategy. By the way, one the other modification I will do by September is to  have a strategy and climate division, to put – to integrate this view – this climate challenge into a strategy and to  transform it into an opportunity.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we just look to what – it's not oil scenario, it's the IEA scenario. They are the experts. I'm not an expert. If you  look to what does it mean, the 2 degrees scenario, it means for businesses but first the natural gas will continue to  increase. It's sharing the energy mix, so there is growth in the natural gas. The oil production should have a cap  somewhere and then will not increase anymore. Coal is declining and renewable and biofuels are also increasing  their share in the energy mix.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: For us, what does it mean as a guideline? It means, first, that on o il, we need to focus on low break-even projects  in order to avoid revenue stranded assets. And by the way, this is the best answer to the volatility of the oil price.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, economy and ecology will go together and this is the direction we will take. We did also and we have done that  in the last years, prioritized some gas projects because there is a better growth. We have exited from coal business.  We will fully exit this business by year-end 2016 including in trading. And then. we need to grow steadily, I would  add profitably in renewable and biofuels, and this is what we'll try to do to step after step in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, to finally – to conclude this presentation, I think that, again, as I told you in my introduction, we are ramping  up our sponsors in 2016 environment. There is no new recipes. So, same recipes, just adopting ourselves and  answering – answer to the challenges and things across to reduce the breakeven. Safety is a core value of the  company, and I can ensure it's the only matter which can make me not sleeping well the oil prices, that's a point  for me. I'm confident that we have the capacity to resist and to continue to deliver to our shareholders value we  expect delivering in all segments, reducing our cost and our target of $19 billion of our CapEx will be the lowest to  deliver the 5% of production growth by 2019.

file: TTE - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 9February2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Before to do that, I will begin to speak about, as we always do in our presentation, talking about HSE, safety, and  also environment, i.e. climate change, and then about the market conditions and before Patrick will come and  explain the results for 2016 and the objectives for 2017.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Last year, we were presenting you the link between safety and operational performance availability in Refining &  Chemicals. This year, we can assure you the same schematic for E&P from the Upstream. It's good because it  demonstrates on one side, but even if we assume safety reports were already low, we continue to be better. And  it's also good because it demonstrates the Upstream has taken the same recipe on Refining & Chemicals in terms  of improving availability, and it's part of the reason why Upstream has been resilient this year compared to its  peers.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: HSE is an important element, and I want to speak about the climate change. We have moved in 2016 very  explicitly by delivering a report called Integrating Climate into our Strategy. It's really a challenge for all the oil and  gas companies. We recognize it. But I would like to underline that, in fact, when we speak about climate change,  we speak about evolution of energy mix, which means, in fact, anticipating the market trends. And so, when we  want to say to you Integrating Climate into our Strategy, it's, in fact, thinking through a strategy in line with what  could be the anticipated market trends.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Which is the way you can read this picture. So, it's a matter of being conscious of our responsibility in terms of  climate change, but it's also important for oil and gas company if we want to remain a major energy company in  the future, to think about it. What does it say? It say that you have a potential goal for petrol gas for the next 20,  25 years and beyond. So, that means that why we say in our strategy, we want to expand our gas value chain. It  also say the schematic that oil should peak somewhere, 2035, 2040. So, the conclusion for us is less position,  less focus on low-cost oil projects. And it also mean that renewables could grow. And so, conclusion in terms of  strategy is let's try to build a profitable foot in this low-carbon business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, events on the market, we come back to oil and gas. First, oil; the oil market, first, I will insist, they are still  volatile. I don't believe at all that there is a flow at $50 like I can read in newspapers, that they give out to  journalists. There is no feeling neither, nowhere. I think there is volatility in and around this commodity business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Having said that – but it's true that the OPEC, non-OPEC agreement in last November is somewhat a historic  agreement. But I remember in September and during the road shows after the action meeting, I said to some of  investors that I was convinced that this country were really facing difficulties, and they could into an agreement.  They've done it. I think they are serious about it. The level of compliance was standing quite strong, very strong.  Because clearly $44 per barrel, a lot of countries, producing countries, are facing difficulties.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Having said that, so, this is an important element. But as you see on the schematic, by end of 2016, the supply  was still above the demand. Even if the demand is strong, remained strong, 1.5 million barrel of oil per day  probably in 2016, it's quite a nice and strong increase. But at the same time as well, the inventories are very high.  We should not forget it. The inventories, we have statistics on recent inventories we don't have as the rest of the  world. But they are high globally in terms of crude and in terms of products.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And so, we consider that we are still in a – yes, I would say, price is increasing. But there is volatility. And we  must continue to focus on what we control, not to try to guess the oil price. But what we control is the breakeven  of the company. And this is on what we focus in the last two years and then what we will continue.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: A word about the gas markets, the gas markets have been clearly, have even suffered this year, a stronger  decrease. I think the average gas price declined by 25% compared to last year while the oil price was more in the  range of 16%. So, the gas markets have been even lower this year. We know that we face a situation where we  have a lot of supply, in particular LNG supply coming into the market from Australia, from the U.S. One of the  things which we would like to underline is that the demand has been strong because the price was quite low.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, on the LNG, you can see an increase of demand of 7% this year with very big – with high figures of increase  of demand: in China, 40%; in India, which is a new country to LNG – this year we saw all demand for LNG; in the  Middle East, 90%. So, that proves that in the gas, like in oils when you have lower prices, you accelerate the  demand. It's a good lesson. And another end of it is that you can see on the map the number of projects of  floating storage regasification units which are studied around the world. Today, you have 70 million tons of  floating regas capacities being already installed in the world. And there is more than almost 200 million tons being  studied.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Why? Because there have been some improvement in technologies and the cost of a floating storage  regasification unit is much lower than before and give potential access to LNG to more countries. This is a good  message for gas, by the way, and it's not only on FSRU, but we need to work on cost. Also in the LNG plants, we  will target to be able to come back to a $500 per ton of LNG production. It would be good if we want to continue to  develop the gas market. So, the gas market is facing, on one side, quite stronger new supply. But it's also – this  has an influence on the price. But it also helps the demand to come back. So, result of all of that is that the price  today, during this winter period, are quite good, including in Southeast Asia. So, there is also strong volatility there  and that's why we need to continue to work on the cost.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As I mentioned to you, our Upstream was profitable every quarter despite the harsh environment. Of course, and  you see that on the left side of the slide, the backbone of the group resilience was the Downstream. Downstream  results are about two-third of the group adjusted net income, despite also a sharp drop in European Refining  margin.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We also point out on this graph the pro forma contribution of the Gas, Renewable, and Power segment, new  segment that is taking place in the group. If it was there in 2016, it would have produced $400 million of net profit.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For the year, Brent average $44 per barrel, a decrease of 17% in comparison to 2015. NBP, the gas price in  Europe was only $4.7 per million btu, a drop of 27%. And the European Refining margin indicator was $34 per  ton, down by 30%. So, as you see, do not forget that 2016 was a difficult year in term of environment.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving to the costs, you know that Total started to cut costs and to restructure its Downstream ahead of the  other. Now, cost reductions played a major role in producing our best-in-class result. Compared to our 2014 base,  the sustainable cost for 2016 was $2.8 billion. We expect $3.5 billion for this year 2017 and we have a target of $4  billion for 2018. Upstream represent two-third of both figures. This is also because the Downstream restructuring  to place before and started before 2014, which is a baseline for those figures.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: For 2017, we are ramping up the new Total Global Services unit that will allow for the centralized purchasing of  the fourth operating segment at the end of quarter. And you see that on your screens, the world is much nicer with  an oil price about $50 per barrel. But we are still committed to reduce costs, to reduce breakeven in order to  increase our available cash flow.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Moving to CapEx and investment, for 2016, our CapEx was $18.3 billion. This include $800 million of resources  renewal that we acquired basically to Barnett. For 2017, we gave a guidance of $16 billion to $17 billion. This  include $2 billion of asset renewal acquisition. So, organic CapEx should be $14 billion to $15 billion plus the $2  billion of acquisition of new resources. And then we gave another guidance for the period 2018 and after of $15  million to $17 million, also including the $2 billion asset renewable. Sorry. These figures include $3 billion to $4  billion a year for Downstream and the new Gas, Renewable, and Power segment. Basically, we are doing more  for less at the moment. Of course, this is due to the deflation that we are able to harvest. But this is also due to  our own effort to reduce our own cost.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You know the SEC rules for reporting reserve. The current SEC rules require that we use the average oil price for  the year based on the first day of each month. This average for 2016 give $42.82 per barrel. This is not the  average number you have in mind, the $44 per barrel, but that's as far as SEC rules. Using this $42.82 per barrel,  we add and we have to debook Surmont because the NPV of Surmont at $42.8 per barrel is negative. Actually,  it's positive above $45 per barrel. So, if we were using the same methodology, with the SEC number using current  oil price, we should rebook again Surmont positively.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, this slide was a big debate between Patrick and myself to know who will show to you. On the top – on the  bottom left, the robot on Mars. We are growing a profitable low carbon business and we are continuing and  growing our R&D budget for the cycle.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the left, you have the Gas, Renewable, and Power positive contribution. A few figures for this new segment in  the company, $500 million of cash flow from operation. More than 9% for ROACE and a little bit less than $5  billion of capital employed. And Total is one of the largest global gas and LNG player.
