And this robot you see on  Mars is powered with SunPower solar panel and Saft battery. And as some people told me, the market on Mars is  small but we have a big share of it.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: R&D is very important and we haven't reduced our R&D efforts during this downturn of the cycle. And R&D is also  key in our ongoing cost reduction. As you see, we increased the R&D cost. On the right side, this is excluding  Hutchinson, Saft, and SunPower. So, this is purely the oil and gas business, and we increased our R&D budget  by 5%.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Following our review of the gas prices over the world, I told you the NBP was down by 27%. We have reviewed  the value of some of our gas assets in the Upstream division Laggan-Tormore, Angola LNG, GLNG in Australia,  and we impaired $2.8 billion in 2016, basically because of the lower gas price assumptions we were using.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And my last slide, we use the same slide last year to show you that what we promised you, what target we were  giving to you last year were basically realized. We give you a $19 billion CapEx target including asset renewal, we  realized $18.3 billion. The cost reduction, we went from $2.4 billion target to $2.8 billion realization. Upstream  OpEx, down to $5.9 per boe. Production growth evolved to 4% target. Cash flow from operation for the  Downstream, close to $7 billion. Asset sale, done. Resource addition, we have been able to add 1.7 billion barrel  of oil equivalent, below $1.5 per boe, which is very much in line to our initial target which was only 1.2 billion  barrels of oil equivalent, below $3 per boe. So, we, once again, do more and use less of our capital.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The other point I want to raise during this presentation, to answer to some of the questions that I read in papers,  is that by doing this growth that we are giving and delivering, this near-term growth is clearly accretive, cash  accretive, and in particular, we are increasing our leverage to oil price and I will come back on it. And with these  two ingredients giving more visibility to the post-2020 growth, we're showing you that we have a higher leverage,  increasing our leverage on oil price is the base rate which renew [ph] while (40:17) and I will continue to create  value to our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, first, and it's important, is back to focusing on our strengths, on the previous slide, that I mentioned. We  selected resources where we have the feeling strong, which we are strong, the feeling that we can add value for  investors. And the strength of Total are in deep-offshore, are recognized deep-offshore in LNG and in the Middle  East and in Africa. So, we clearly targeted assets where we will be able to deliver the value. Deep-offshore Brazil,  I will come back on it. Integrated gas LNG also, Middle East, I will also come back.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, we'll have access to two big fields in the pre-salt. Lapa, which started end of 2016, we should become  operator of it, which will be – we will be the first IOC being operator in the pre-salt; and, Yala, which will be started  in 2018.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The other part is LNG. So, on LNG, we told you that we want to develop in the gas, but you changed the same  strategy we have on the oil, which needs to be more integrated Downstream, the chain in particular, because we  need to be able to develop the LNG demand around the world. We have strong position Upstream, but we need  also to develop the demand in a market where there is a lot of supply coming in the market. And so, we have a  portfolio. We have bid an interesting energy portfolio. We continue to develop it. We are amongst the three top  players in the LNG business. And so, we have taken some positions in the last month in line with the strategy  being the leader of the regas terminal in the Ivory Coast, these regas Brazilian assets in the package here with  Petrobras. And we just announced yesterday or two days ago, with Qatar, that we are working with QP on a regas  terminal in Pakistan, which the project of the regas terminal will offer to Total more than 2.5 million ton per year of  new demand for LNG. It comes from the top of the 2 million ton we signed last year with some Asian company in  China, Indonesia, and Japan.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, we are active. We are integrating the chain and we are creating the demand which we required by your  portfolio. We have taken another decision which is to enter into [indiscernible] (50:53) in Tellurian company which  is developing the Driftwood LNG project. You know that is promoted by the founder of Cheniere in Sabine Pass  Maybe, we'll regret that we have taken a strong position in that project which was aimed to be able to develop a  profitable project, by the way. We will follow it. For me, it's like an exploration well. But it's also the same thinking  that it's good to have a stronger position on this U.S. low cost gas towards LNG, because LNG is part of our  strategy.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: This get me to the next slide which is maybe less obvious to you because mentioning the U.S. among the  strength of the company is maybe not so obvious. But in fact, it is clear that in the U.S., first, in 2016, we have  delivered more than $1 billion of operations, mainly Downstream. But it is recognition that there is clearly a gas  and oil evolution there. And what we want to do is to continue to develop our U.S. portfolio. But again, in the areas  where we can add value, which means, for example, Tellurian LNG, as I mentioned, because we understand  LNG, which is about the side cracker petrochemicals in Port Arthur. We are in the part of – in businesses that we  are perfectly – where we are among the leaders.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I will explain you why and it's really going to increase next year where we anticipate around $2.8 billion cash flow  impact in 2018. With these metrics, we are, I would say, in the middle of the pack of the majors in terms of  leverage to oil price. So, it's an important message to you is that our company is as leveraged as the others to the  oil price, is not less than the leverage as I can read some times.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Coming out as a startup of 2015-2016 is around 40% to 50% higher than on existing producing assets and the  margin per barrel of the 2017-2018 start-ups will be even twice higher than the producing assets. So, we, and if I  just zoom on this 2017-2018 start-ups, and by the way, you have there nice table that you'll like, you  [indiscernible] (56:09) so you have a slide there with all the list of the projects with advanced the level of progress  for them, which will be started during the years 2017, 2018. They represent 550,000 barrel per day of net  production and they are either oil or oil-linked at 85%. With some of them having very high margin per barrel like  the deepwater Moho Nord, Kaombo, Egina, or Tempa Rossa or Ichthys.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: As Patrick told you, also the Downstream, and I would like to insist and give you maybe even more information  about it, to convince you that the $7 billion that Patrick has qualified as sustainable contribution will be  sustainable.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: It's sustainable, and why? Because it's in fact, I would say preferred. It's Refining for 40%, Chemicals for 30%,  Marketing & Marketing for 30%. So, Refining of Total in 2017 is a new Refining compared to what we have in  2012 for several reasons. First, we have eliminated more than 300,000 barrel per day of loss-making capacities.  The refinery in Provence is closed, is shut down since December. Like the refinery in Lindsey in UK halve has  been – the capacity has been divided by two since December as well. So, the restructuring has been done, and  we – the Refining, on the top of it, we have started some good assets like SATORP, which is giving the  contribution as expected. And also, the modernization of Antwerp, which will be delivered by mid-2017, will  contribute to reinforce even more the Refining cash flow from operations. So, it's an improvement of 50% and all  of these, what I described to you, as restructuring on one side, these new assets on the other side, will mean  lowest to maintain the $7 billion sustainable development, even if there is a decrease of $10 per ton which  represents $500 million or $600 million.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And second message, we have a near-term accretive growth and an increasing leverage to oil. We have been  able to deliver this growth. The projects are there, we are progressing steadily 2017-2018. We still have 12 major  projects to come, and we'll deliver – we'll feed that growth and this leverage to oil.

file: TTE - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 8February2018 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Good morning. Good morning, again, here in some podcast for this Presentation of our Full-Year 2017 Results.  I'm here today with all the Executive Committee Team, Patrick, our CFO, but Namita as well, in charge of our  People & Social Responsibility and Total Global Services. I think, Arnaud Breuillac, that you know well, is actually  in the room, as well as Momar Nguer, from Marketing & Services; Bernard Pinatel, I don't know where is Bernard,  there for Refining & Chemicals; and Philippe Sauquet for Gas, Renewables & Power. Together, we'll answer to  your questions after the presentation.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The fourth quarter reserves of 2017 which happened in a better procurement price, top of strong performance of  the year. We've – and Patrick will come back on it, E&P is in a bright spot, an increase of net operating result of  86%, cash flow from operations of 38% while the Brent was only up by 24% and a higher leverage to oil price  which has been demonstrated there again. Solid Downstream, the sale of $7 billion of capital for operation despite  the fact that since the last three years we have sold $7 billion of assets in the Downstream. Free cash flow at $6.7  billion, very steady across the quarter. Again, leveraging the oil price and the growth of the production and last but  not least, balance sheet which should be stronger than ever and gearing under 15%.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Before some few – four slides about the macro environment. The first one is safety. Safety, as a firm, is a value in  the company at the heart of the operational excellence and the economic performance. What is interesting for me  this year and what have we wanted to highlight through the video is what we've done with our contractors on  safety. We speak a lot about corporate social responsibility, and it's a debate as a commitment of global company  like Total, and it comes with corporate social responsibility. Of course, this means first a social responsibility with  your own staff, but also with our contractors. And there was a thought in our company, a speech which was, okay,  the recordable injury rate is lower for staff and for contractors. It's normal. I don't know what is normal. It's not  normal. It's not normal because when you look precisely on our site, in the oil and gas industry, we could have  more people from the contractors than from our own stuff on an industrial site.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In terms of corporate social responsibility, the other aspects, of course, is a matter of not only the people but the  planet. I know in sustainable development goals, primarily for the UN, we should speak about profit, people, and  planet. The planet means it's of course important. It's the environment because foreign energy company, the  climate change challenge is, of course, essential. And we have to bring a responsible answer to that. In 2016, we  built collectively in the company an ambition for the next 20-year which is to become responsible energy major.  And we build that on two key principles for me, which is, one, first transparency, and the second is engagement in  collective action.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Transparency means and it's very important and on the climate change we have been the first company to issue  an annual report on the climate and the strategy integrating climate into a strategy. We will publish a new one by  September 2018 in which we are working on being able to propose an indicator of all the intensity of CO2  intensity of our mix of products will decrease steadily in line with our commitment to be a proactive player for the  climate change challenge.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We have also supported the TCFD initiative, led by Michael Bloomberg, which is a matter of a call to  transparency. But I will say that when I met Michael Bloomberg, I told him as well what we strongly believe that it's  up to the companies like Total to decide exactly what to present to best explain to all stakeholders what the  potential impacts are as we look for other risks, by the way, and as we've done in our climate report. So, we will  disclose in our preference document by March 17 on the basis of the TCFD requirements in order to be  committed to this transparency which is requested.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Collective action is also important. We think that we are better together than alone on these matters and so we  participate actively in many initiatives, in particular, the oil and gas climate initiatives. We've turned over large  companies, oil and gas companies. We found we created a climate investment fund of $1 billion. We are also  active in promoting the UN SDGs and I'm one of the 10 pioneers for this year in promoting these principles, and  also working with other oil and gas companies on methane emissions. And it's important as gas is more and more  the core strategy.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: When we think about climate, of course, and its link, we speak about the strategy and just I want to remind you  what is a global framework of the strategy of the company because climate is a matter of the energy markets, in  fact. So, it's why it's important for us because all this challenge could lead to evolution of our markets.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You have, here again, like we've done it, a scenario, which is a scenario of the International Energy Agency, a  sustainable development scenario, which is one, two degree. And we don't know if the world will be able to drive  towards this scenario, but it's important to look to what would happen in such a scenario because 195 countries  committed to it at least on the paper. And so, what we observe and we rank it in a different way but traditionally is  that, first, you have an increase of natural gas. And this explain why we want to expand along the gas value  chain. But these natural gas increase require that we are able to enhance the demand for gas. That's why it's  important to work not only on gas production but along the full value chain to lower the cost of this value chain  and integrating also its downstream path.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On oil, in such a scenario, you would have less oil produce in 2040 than in 2018. Don't know if it'll happen, but it's  possible. So, what we have decided is to give priority in our projects, in particular long-term projects on low  breakeven oil projects. And this is part of the upgrade of the portfolio we've done, which by the way is the right  answer also to the volatility of commodities price.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And last but not least, we want to grow a profitable low carbon business. The Total as expanded, we have  expanded in 2020 into free new, I would say, assets, Total EREN to produce power from renewables, GreenFlex  in the energy efficiency field, and TOTAL SPRING in the B2C business along with SunPower and Saft.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And the last micro slide I want to use, of course, which is important is more short-term view, is about the oil and  gas markets. Again, even if today I could celebrate the oil price recovery, and I just remind to myself  [indiscernible] (11:34) but in August 2017, it was only six months ago, so price was at $44 per barrel beginning of  August. Today, $66. Just an increase of 50%, which prove that there is volatility and we will be wrong if we  believe that suddenly we see a flaw, or I don't know why.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: None of us, I think, in this room was betting on $70 two months ago. So, let's keep that in mind not to avoid to  make or to overreact. We will continue to manage the company with $50 per barrel in mind. But of course, as we  have a better leverage to oil price, we will also be happy to see what we do with the upside – or price upside, and  what of the decision of the board is to share this price upside with our shareholders who buy back. I will come  back on it.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Why do we have this recovery? Clearly, because, first, we have a strong demand, a strong growth demand, a 5- million barrel of oil per day in three years, twice quicker than the previous three years. It's a little contradictory to  just what I said about the two-degree scenario by the way. So, we have a trend of accelerating oil demand  growth. And you'll see in 20 years, a decrease of. That's why it's a difficult matter. So, to be clear, we are not able  to tell you exactly what will happen in 20 years, but we have this on-demand these two contradictory. And it's why  we have that in the short-term because the price is low. When price are low, it's led a lot of emerging countries to  have a strong demand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The second factor, of course the, on the supply side has been the OPEC-NOPEC policy in [indiscernible] (16:41)  Saudi Arabia and Russia. They're really committed to play on the market, to wait on the market. And even last  week, they were engaging in discussions to prolong the agreements in 2019. So, I think it has an impact. On the  same time, the stocks are still a decrease but are still above the five-year average.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And I'm sure that the U.S. independence will again invest hard to benefit from $60 per barrel and to produce more  oil in Shell oil. So, we'll have volatility in this market, but it's better of course to have this type of price at $60 per  barrel than at $40.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I will say there is something fundamental in the market which supports higher price on the coming years. It is a  fact that our industry, globally speaking, did not invest much in the last three years, $400 billion instead of $750  billion previously. So, this type of slowing investments will have an impact for five years after the decisions. And  so, this is a fundamental support to the oil price.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the gas price, again, the same story, a little more surprisingly. I think everybody was a little more pessimistic  about the gas price because we saw a lot of LNG new projects coming into the market. But then again, same  mechanism, a low gas price has led to a big increase of demand, and a 10% increase of demand of LNG is quite  big. We are planning on 5% as an average and we were considered as optimistic. It was 7% increase in 2016,  10% in 2017. So, this market is clearly supported by countries like India. But in 2017, you've seen other countries  Pakistan, Bangladesh, open to LNG projects and China and, clearly, is a [indiscernible] (18:41) last one is coming  from China. There was a fundamental speech by President Xi at the Central Congress Committee about Beautiful  China and he's basically said that gas must find a stronger place in the China energy mix, 5% today more or less  could go to 15%. Of course, it has a huge impact on the market. And when the Chinese machine is working well,  it's efficient like Total. We are not Chinese.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Let's start with the results. Our adjusted net income for 2017 was $10.6 billion, basically 28% higher than in 2016.  The main driver was 86% increase in upstream from a 23% increase in Brent. This demonstrates the strong  upside leverage we have created by reducing the breakeven. Downstream also generated close to $6 billion.  That's the beauty of the integrated model. We have steadily increased our sensitivity to Brent and we are  capturing the benefit of the oil price recovery. In 2017, Refining & Chemicals results are slightly down, notably  because of the sale of Atotech, which is not anymore in our perimeter and to the effect of Hurricane Harvey.  Marketing & Service continuing growth by close to 10%. So, all in all, we have very good result. Gas, Renewable  & Power is still in its early day, but it's improving its result to reach $500 million. Putting all parts together, Total  reported return on equity based on adjusted net result of slightly more than 10%, the highest return among the  major.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the right, you see some detail, including $2 billion of acquisition, $2 billion net. Slightly half of the CapEx is  committed to renewing and developing resources on the right side of the circle. Maintaining existing production  requires about 20%. Downstream requires also 20%. And note that we allocate about $1 billion to Gas,  Renewable & Power, including $500 million nonorganic.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Downstream, you know that we have the best-in-class downstream among the major. Our Downstream was fully  restructured before the collapse of the oil price. It provides a $7 billion operating cash flow contribution. And  despite – we deliver this $7 billion despite about $7 billion of Downstream asset sale last three years.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: On the left, we are showing the recent history and an estimate for 2018. Note that we have included the sensitivity  at $25. Currently the refining margin is between $30 and $35. And the sensitivity for $10 per ton represents about  $600 million impact on cash flow. On the right, you see that definitely, the ROACE of our Downstream is much  higher than the one of our peers.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Balance sheet, one of the most challenging aspects of the oil price collapse for Total was that we entered this  period with a gearing at 31%. One of the most significant achievements in term of financial for me over the past  three years has been reducing the gearing. We ended 2017 with a 14% net debt to equity gearing. With  Petrobras, which is complete today, it would have been 16%. Starting 2018, we will change our gearing definition  to be in line with what is used by our competitors and we will use the debt to capital ratio. And using this debt to  capital ratio we reduced the gearing by 2 points. This is not the objective, the objective being to be in line with  what is used by our competitors. So, the net debt to capital will be 12% by end of 2017.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Of course, we have there some few indicators which I think is summarizing the September presentation and the  objective that we have and the assets that we have managed to put in our portfolio in order to achieve these  objectives, the production growth of an average of 5% for the next five years, double of our, more than doubling  our LNG growth from 16 million tons management per year to more than 40 million tons. Of course, thanks to the  ENGIE deal. We have also, as I would say, an increase and this is a target of $6 billion of upstream cash flow  from operations and the Downstream as well is targeting to increase its free cash flow by 30%. So, this is in  figures what we intend to do. And how do we do that? We do it in particular because for all the actions we have  taken to upgrade the portfolio by playing to our strengths.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, with [indiscernible] (49:28) is a new core area but will develop, it will leverage our expertise in deepwater.  [indiscernible] (49:33) expertise in LNG gave me the opportunity to come back on the ENGIE LNG acquisition, but  we did not comment beyond the press release by [ph] LaTam (49:44). It really gave us – it was a unique  opportunity to make a step change. And we have a strong belief that this LNG market will intrinsically become a  commoditized market and size is of – and flexibility is of essence.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And size or flexibility, in fact, is illustrated by this chart, where you can see that we will have position in all the  main regions of supply including the U.S. I will come back on it. We have a well-balanced mix of equity,  liquefaction and third-party supply. And we will have also customers in all main regions, a large portfolio of Asian  customers in traditional markets like Japan, Korea, Taiwan, including Taiwan with new – which ENGIE brings was  a portfolio to us. And also in China, obviously, where we have moved some positions. And so, that's important  because all this LNG business is also a matter, if you want to grow it, of optimizing the full value chain in terms of  cost. And you know, when you take LNG for Norway to send it to Asia, I bet you pay $2.5 per million Btu of [ph]  coal (50:58) transportation costs. If you use only one vessel, you have room for flexibility – for optimization there.  And I think this is part of what we think we will be able to leverage, thanks to the size, and the flexibility that we  have – which is given to us with merging these two portfolios. So, we are becoming clearly number two of the  markets. We have more than 40 million tons of portfolio, 10% percent of market share. So, it's interest – very  interesting position.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I will add that in the portfolio of ENGIE, there was another asset of interest for us which is Cameron LNG position  because with combining that with the Barnett shale gas production that we took one year before. In fact today, we  have a production which is integrated between Barnett – economically integrated that into Barnett domestic gas  which in fact begin – become an export gas, thanks to this Cameron LNG position. And we know that Cameron  LNG should start by 2019. Our plans to expand it in Total will be obviously fully supportive of expanding this  position, because U.S. gas is for us a source of huge resources to low price. We are a strong believer that  [indiscernible] (52:15) will stay low for long considering all the size of resource and the shale oil productions which  even bring more gas into the market.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Another point which is important is that when we look to this integrated LNG business which represents $3 billion  per year of cash flow from operations by 2020. And we have decided by – after the closing of ENGIE and in fact  beginning of January 2019, we will report differently our results. But like some of our peers or one of our peers at  least which is to combine integrated gas, renewables and power because this is where we – as we've seen the  strategy, we have all these new strategies put in place and we think it makes a lot of sense to be able to give to  the market some visibility on these integrated gas business which are assets with a long-term assets, we've long  plateau and it's part and we tested the idea in September presentation, we obtained some good feedbacks from  our investors, so we'll change our reporting by beginning of 2019 after the deal of ENGIE makes a lot of sense.  We have a step change that we will do in this business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Petrochemicals is the sixth focus I want to do because [indiscernible] (53:36) for Refining & Chemicals. Why  again? Because we have a growing market; polymer market is growing by 3% to 4% per year. And the polymer  price is linked to oil price. But there is another way to produce polymer, which is from gas. And if you managed to  have access to cheap gas feedstock, ethane or LPGs, then you will have a profitable project.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: One of you asked me, why didn't you do that in September? The board does not work because we have a  presentation to the – to you every six months. We work according to some calendar which is, let's build the  confidence, let's demonstrate what we are able to deliver. And the delivery of 2017 in particular the capacity to  capture the leverage in the oil price, the capacity for the third year in a row to deliver the production growth has  built a strong confidence in the Board. That's why I'm able to speak to you this morning.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The second element is that we have an increasing leverage to oil price. It was $2.5 billion, the sensitivity we gave  you last year for 2017. It's $2.8 billion, we give you today for 2018. And next year, it will be $3.3 billion. Where  does it come from? It comes from many factors, but in particular, the fact that we have a lot of production sharing  contracts and we have a lot of cash to recoup from past investments, and of course, this is sensitive to the oil  price. So, this is important in the business case of Total. And 2017, we have demonstrated to us that the $2.5  billion sensitivity, yes, was the reality of the cash we put in the company.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Then the second question we wanted, the second proposal that the board has decided to do is how do we share  with our shareholders, the benefit from oil price upside. We cannot just do it by increasing dividend. So, let's  introduce the share buyback. And in order to share this oil price recovery. So, it's – we said up to 5 billion share  buyback over 2018, 2020. It will come on the top obviously of this key shares buyback. And of course, it's linked  to the oil price recovery because it's part of sharing the oil price upside. Don't ask me a question about the  specific mechanism. Let's foresee, I can't just tell you but – and it's also a matter to pilot it. But at $66 per barrel of  crude price and a $55 per share which is undervalued price I think we will begin tomorrow as well to think to that  seriously.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And more – I think this slide is fundamental, because in fact the discussion of the board was organized around  this slide, which is let's define clear priorities in term of cash flow allocation for the coming years. We have clearly  I would say a growth strategy, oil, gas, new low carbon business. How do we allocate the cash flow and what is  the right of priority.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So, this is the result of our discussions. And, I think, the first, I must say that the board insist again that priority is  given to our capital investment program. We are comfortable with $15 billion, $17 billion per year. Like Patrick told  you, it's a matter of $13 billion, $15 billion of organic CapEx and $2 billion net acquisition, one for E&P and the  other for Downstream and new Gas, Renewables & Power.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Then the dividend, the dividend commitment, 10% increase over the three year. No scrip dilution is the second  priority. And it's independent, this commitment of the oil price. The third priority is to maintain gearing under 20%.  The board attached certain important to maintain, of course, of Grade A credit rating. And so, that's in the way to  allocate your cash. And then, the upside to the oil price, we are still subject to oil price recovery. It's linked to the  oil price upside, in fact, it's share buybacks that we introduced, up to $5 billion over 2018-2020.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We maintain the capital discipline as well. We are confident that with capital investments, as described, we are  able to grow. We will grow as a company at 5% in production until 2022 and deliver additional value which is more  important. We prepare the future by upgrading the portfolio, launching profitable projects by strengthening the  integrated gas and low carbon business to prepare the future, by growing our petrochemicals, retail and  lubricants, which is, of course, part of the beauty of the integrated business model, which demonstrated strength  during the last four years.

file: TTE - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 7February2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Good morning. Good morning, everybody, for traditional union state – state of union. It's the season here in  [indiscernible] (00:00:02) for results and outlook, which I will present you together with your preferred P2. And I  will say together as well, with all the executive committee members, who are today in the room and who will join  us for the Q&A session. This tradition will be a little – there will be some novelty, like always in Total because this  afternoon, after you've agreed to stay with us after the lunch, we'll innovate by presenting you our first ever  Energy Outlook 2040 markets on all markets, natural gas markets and power markets, and will be followed by our  climate presentation, which logically came after those market trends.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We have also, of course in 2018, continued to build the future of the company, and we have this strategy which is  to integrate the value chain of oil, of natural gas, and a low-carbon electricity, which is more material today after  the various M&A business we have done last year. And so, we had in our hand an attractive portfolio to deliver  the strategy for 2020 and one of the – you will see, by the way, that our renewal of reserves is quite high. Priority  for the next year for 2019 will be, of course, to deliver this production and with the – most of the projects have  been launched, deliver the cash flows, cash shareholder returns, but also to launch the new wave of future  projects.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So after that, a few words about the markets [indiscernible] (00:06:10). Oil markets, I will not just give you any  guess about what would be the oil price. Everybody's wrong in this market. We have also the strong volatility in  2018. Pricing going up to $85, and in one month, going down to $55. I think there are some fundamentals which  makes me optimistic, I would say.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: First is better demand is continuing to grow to a high pace in particular because we observed sensitivity to the  price, and so at $50, $60 per barrel. The International Energy Agency is announcing plus 1.4 Mb/d for next year.  By the way, we just switched to 100 million barrel of oil per day in the last quarter of demand; so the demand is  there. Of course, there are some, I would say, question marks about the impacts of trade wars on the emerging  market growth and stability of financial markets. But fundamentally, what we observed is that when the price is  reasonable in the $50 – $60 range, emerging markets, which need more energy in particular Southeast Asia,  Africa, we have a strong demand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: The industry, globally speaking, still does not invest a lot, even if it's true that $1 today in terms of volume of  investment is much more than the dollar yesterday because the costs have been driven down by 30%, 40%. And  we have, of course, the U.S. shale supply which today as we've seen a big growth in 2018. The pipeline  bottlenecks will be out by second half of 2019, most of them. So we should see more U.S. shale oil coming into  the market. So they are opposing trends. So it's difficult to anticipate. I will not do it.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: One market which is clearer to us is the LNG market where clearly we are always short of forecasting the  increase of demand. And when I look to the last three years, it was – this year has been again 10%, was 11% last  year. So it was probably 9% as an average. We always say it will be 5% for the next 5 to 10 years. But in fact, for  the time being, this market is growing very quickly, in particular driven by, of course, the policy in China. China  has grown again this year by 40%. It was 40% last year and it was almost 40% three years ago. I don't know if it's  permanent but its anticipation as to very strong natural gas and [indiscernible] (00:10:06) mix of China is still low.  But for, I would say, environmental issues, air quality in big China cities, very strong momentum for LNG, 55  million tons have been imported there this year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Japan stays stable at 180 million tons despite the fact that nuclear is more available, it should be stable. But you  have other countries like India, which have seen a growth also of more than 30% this year and reaching 25 million  tons. So we have a strong momentum there. And with all the environmental trends and the fact that LNG is more  and more a commodity, many points of productions, so easier actually to be cost-efficient in term of delivery to the  customers, makes us still quite optimistic about this market. Why? By the way, it's an axis of the strategy of the  company.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And you can see that on the other side that varies by 2025, if we want to continue this demand – to match this  demand, we have room for another 100 million ton of projects and 150 million by 2030. So of course, there are  many projects around the world but there is a room there to develop low breakeven projects in LNG.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You can see on the left also the new Integrated Gas, Renewables & Power segment that we will give you the  datas quarter-after-quarter. It's a new reporting format. It increased its contribution largely on the strength of better  result for integrated LNG and natural gas. But we can also say that GFP, Gas, Renewable & Power without the  LNG delivered a result 56% higher in 2018 compared to 2017.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: In contrast, of course you know the environment for Downstream was weaker. Nevertheless, we are well- positioned and the combined upstream generated $5 billion of adjusted net income with a ROACE above 25%.  And basically, Total Downstream is the best-in-class.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Let's move to exploration. From the left to the right, we start with some positive news this year from exploration.  The budget is stable at $1.2 billion and in 2019, with the same amount we will do – thanks to cost structure – we  will do more well in 2019 than in 2018. On the left following the Glendronach discovery, last year, we announced  the Glengorm discovery in January, which appears to be the largest gas discovery made in the UK over the past  10 years. Remember, Glengorm, we acquired it from Maersk, which is adding value, of course, to this acquisition.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Next, we open a new world-class play offshore South Africa with the Brulpadda gas condensate and light oil  discovery, with the potential resources of about 1 billion barrel. On the right, thanks to our partnership with  Novatek, where we own close to 20%, 19.6% exactly – 19.4%. Novatek made one of the largest discovery of the  industry in 2018 on the Yamal Peninsula. This underlines the importance of Russia as an LNG supplier.

texts.speaker: Patrick de la Chevardière
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We moved at the right time and at the right price. The net effect was to contribute to the 1.4 billion barrel increase  in 2P reserve, which represent for us 20 years of production. Our portfolio management has played a role in  concentrating our 2P reserve within eight countries, including four OECD countries which are Australia, Canada,  Norway, and the U.S.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: One of the characteristics is that we'll have a strong growth of LNG production, more than 40% increase in LNG,  which is the reason why we decided to change our reporting to give more clarity on the LNG figures. And so, you  will see the production being reported to you for E&P tomorrow and for iGRP, E&P being most fundamentally all  the old production plus the domestic gas; iGRP being all the integrated gas, LNG. But we'll give you more  information about this growing business. As it is one of the key areas of growth and investment for us in the  future, I think it's good that you have a better, more data about this segment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You can see well the split, and it's one of the interests I think of the new reporting we put in place, but we have a  more balanced vision of CapEx figures. In fact, we invest more or less 20%, $3 billion into downstream; it's quite  stable. We invest $4 billion in iGRP – Integrated Gas, Renewables and Power. It's $2 billion to $3 billion from LNG  and $1 billion to $2 billion from low-carbon electricity more or less, depends on the year. And E&P, traditional  E&P, represents around 55% of the investments. So we are in line with the guidance, we've maintained the  discipline, and this will allow us to prepare the future growth of the company as I will show you.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We keep in place all our cost savings program where again, despite some discussions when the price was higher,  we're right to do that. In fact, we even delivered more than what we show you last year. The target was about $4  billion; we have delivered $4.2 billion. We are confident for 2019 with the target of $4.7 billion which means that  our program was targeting globally $5 billion of savings between 2020 and 2014. We'll probably at the end land  above the $5 billion, and upstream and downstream are both contributing to these efficiency gains. And it's of  essence in fact because in our industry, again, the margin, refining margins or the marketing margins or upstream  price does not follow inflation. And so as we have some costs, in particular of [ph] some rebate (00:31:53) which  take inflation, we need to permanently look for more efficiency. And it's possible also by the way all these digital  technologies can help us and will help us in the future to manage these savings.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: You can see that we are best-in-class in OpEx per barrel. We are around $5.5 per barrel. It's true that Maersk Oil  in the North Sea was a little more expensive but it's minimum in fact when you look at the impact. And we have  internal targets because of the savings. It's also because of the synergies on Maersk Oil in which we are inline to  deliver the $300 million cost synergies which will help us to go down to this $5.5. Again, we have a competitive  advantage that we want to maintain. It's also a choice. As Patrick told you, M&A activity of selecting the assets  which are fitting with the strategy and fundamentally which is to permanently look carefully to a breakeven of the  company, price of the company.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So we have thanks to this growth and thanks to this discipline a very clear visibility on the cash flow growth. Just  update the figure we gave you in September for 2019, you can see on this chart that we'll have more debt- adjusted cash flow at $60 per barrel in 2019. But what we – so $26 billion we delivered in 2018 at $71 per barrel.  In fact, it's more or less a little less than $2 billion above the figures of this year. In fact, there is an increase of $6  billion of cash flows between 2017 and 2019 at $60, and 2020 will be $8 billion. So this is why we are confident  and we put in place our more active and often dynamic shareholder return policy. This cash flow is coming again.  It's visible from projects which started already. Kaombo, Ichthys, Egina represent in 2019 $3 billion of additional  cash flows at $60. Like the acquisition which have been completed now represent $2.5 billion. It will increase to  $3 billion next year with some startups which have been mentioned. And we have sensitivity to the oil price which  is increasing. If we realized a liquid price an increase of $10, we have $3.2 billion extra cash flows.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: So having said that today, the strong visibility again and confidence of the board of directors and myself as  Chairman and CEO and all the executive team about what will happen in the company for the next two years, our  duty is to prepare the future growth. And of course this future growth, again you know about this slide, I will  present it again this afternoon, but it doesn't change. It's fundamentally the strategy of the group is in line to  potential anticipating market trends. We don't know if the world will be able to make a 2-degree scenario. There  are some doubts around the world. But whatever what will happen, there are some market trends in term of new  technologies which we need to take into account, and that means that we need to focus on oil which is again low  breakeven oil because we could face some situation where the world oil demand will be slower, even decline. On  the contrary, there is a strong space for seeing growth for natural gas and that's why we invest more and more in  all the chain of the gas value chain. And the overall characteristics of the demand of energy is that electricity  demand should almost double in the next 20 years coming either from natural gas or from renewables, so it's why  we invest in this low-carbon electricity business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We also play through our strengths when we speak about oil and gas, and we have some areas of expertise. We  want to stay integrated company business model, so we are of course producing. In particular, we have a strong  footprint in deepwater, and I will come back on it, but also LNG for natural gas and petrochemical which is the  integration downstream and retail and lubricants. And we have some key geographic areas where we have put  most of our efforts where we are very confident and our teams have the right skills to develop projects in a  profitable way which is Africa where we are market leader; Middle East and North Africa for the last three, four  years have demonstrated as we are the partner of choice; and the North Sea which we have reinforced with the  Maersk Oil acquisition.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We have been – that's true – very active in the last three, four years. We acquired $24 billion of assets. We sold  $16 billion or $17 billion of assets. In cash by the way, we sold $16 billion, $17 billion but on the top of it we had  shares and debt acquisition of Maersk Oil which allow us to make quite a lot of move, rotation in our portfolio. And  in the E&P production, the 3 million barrel of oil production of 2019, more than 20% of this production has been  acquired during the last three years but some have been sold as well. So we acquired $7 billion of resource of  less than $2.5 per barrel as an average where we generate more than $4 billion of cash flows, so it's what I  showed you on the slide, and with a ROACE at $60 at around 10%. A word about the Engie LNG deal which was  also a landmark deal of M&A activity in 2018 because it's allowed us to become, by far, the second publicly- traded company in the LNG world with a portfolio of 20 million tons year. This will generate $300 million, $400  million per year and a ROACE of 20%. The payout is around three to four years and we begin to see a positive  effect on our energy portfolio trading management since middle of the year in 2018.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: With all of that, of course all these activity has given us, and Patrick showed you, this big improvement of the  portfolio of 2P reserves and the 1P renewable rate of 157% is very high. Now, main activity for us and the main  focus we have in 2019 will be to clearly sanction all these projects, to transform these reserves in production in  order to feed the growth. We have in this slide, and I will go through, you have more than 700,000 barrel per day  of potential production to be announced by 2020. Just by sanctioning all that, we have already in our portfolio a  growth between 2020 and 2025 of more than 2%. Do not misinterpret, but it's a minimum growth that we'll do but I  don't think we begin to slip. And so we'll have opportunity to select more new projects if they are value-accretive, I  would say. So we have already embedded more than 2% growth which is more than the hydrocarbon markets.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: When you look to, and these projects as you can see have a weighted average, I told you that we manage the  company at $50 per barrel to sanction the projects, about 15%. Not all of them are about 15% because I will lie to  you if I were to tell you that energy projects are above 15%. No, energy projects are quite capital-intensive but the  cash generation is also very strong and stable, so we sanctioned then on other parameters. But globally  speaking, adding this global project, we have a profitability above 15% which will enhance of course the return on  capital employed in future.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: When you look to the map, you can see that we have sanctioned in 2018 around seven projects; three in the  North Sea, two in Africa, and some in a shale Phase 2 in Argentina. In front of us, what are the characteristics for  the year to come? We have a lot of projects in Brazil, so it will be a deepwater Brazilian year, the Mero 2 which  will be sanctioned by middle of the year. It's the Phase 2 of Libra and you know we have 3 billion to 4 billion  barrels of reserves in Libra to be developed with at least four FPSOs. We have Iara 3 which is a new phase of  development of this license in which we have entered this year with a strategic deal with Petrobras. And Lapa 3  which is a new phase of development of the pre-salt field that Total operates now in Brazil. We are the first pre- salt operator and we will build on it to extend this life of the field. So this is Brazil deepwater.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We have some projects in the deepwater in the Gulf of Mexico at North Platte that we operate since we made the  acquisition at a nice value of the Cobalt assets but also the projects which we are partnered with Chevron. We  made a strong alliance on exploring together with Chevron which is a successful operator in the Gulf of Mexico.  We have discovered Ballymore. We should be able to connect the first phase of Ballymore to existing Chevron  infrastructure. Anchor as well is another discovery in which we have launched engineering studies and going to  sanction that in 2020 so they are good projects. And the other characteristics as we say is LNG on this map  where, and I will come back on the LNG projects, we have five projects in the LNG business that we want also to  sanction. So this will be the priority for all of us, for all the teams to put in action and to transform all this resource  into production.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: One field that Patrick think mentioned of areas of interest is to grow in petrochemicals and in particular I would  say in advantaged feedstock petrochemicals. You don't see Total investing in any new naphtha cracker because  there is no competitive advantage but you see us moving and being quite aggressive. And 2018 has been an  excellent year by the way for the Refining & Chemicals business unit led by Bernard because not only they  delivered I think $4.3 billion of cash flows and a ROACE of 31% but also we have been able to launch new  projects. So new cracker in the U.S. It has been sanctioned together with Borealis and Nova. It's not only a  cracker; it's also a big increase of PE capacity. Our success story in Korea with Hanwha. Each year, we make  and we build on new capacities, PE & PP based on propane extension. Every propane will be imported from the  U.S.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And then we have two new projects in the Middle East/North Africa region where we cannot access to  advantaged feedstock. One being in Saudi Arabia, a very large expansion of SATORP; we speak about $5 billion  projects, investments. It's a mixed feed cracker with some ethane and some advantage of our advantaged liquids  which we benefit from the policy of Saudi Arabia together with Saudi Aramco. And then in Algeria where we have  announced engineering studies together with Sonatrach of a new propane dehydrogenation unit to build on  propylene business which will be new for Algeria, a part of it being for the domestic market but the other part  being exported with the knowledge of the team of Total.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: I would not mention petrochemical without saying a word about this alliance which has been just announced  recently with 30 other companies on the end of plastic waste. I think it's very important when we speak about  being responsible and having a sustainable development of petrochemical, but the whole and not only the  producing industry but also our customers together with us think seriously about the way to manage all this plastic  waste. It's a matter of recycling but it's a decision we cannot take alone because we need, for example, what's the  plastic state to be recycled; is it color? So we need to convince Procter & Gamble to stop selling to the women of  the world pink shampoo bottles because we cannot recycle them. That's very strong but it's just an example of –  and I think this alliance will be strong, a strong commitment. Clearly, in the world today it could be I think, when  we speak about petrochemicals and we speak about growth of around 3%, 4%, one [indiscernible] (00:48:31)  could be this issue of plastic waste. So it's a strong commitment within the company and for the Refining &  Chemicals division to develop more projects in recycling. Also, bioplastics has been done recently in Thailand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: A word about Marketing & Services. 2018 has also been a great year for them because they delivered $2.2 billion  of cash flow from operation, growing another $100 million like they promised to us. So net result is stable but the  cash flow is a little higher but also because they implemented under the leadership of Momar the strategy we see  to enter into some large growing markets in retail, and we are there making some – in particular, Mexico, Brazil,  and India. So in Mexico, now we have I think 200 stations. With an alliance with local partner, we increased our  goal to 400. In Brazil, we make an acquisition. It's an interesting market; it's a biofuel dominated market. We have  made 300 stations. We intend to grow in Brazil. It's not only an upstream business, but this is a large market but  it's also for us a downstream market that we want to benefit of.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: India, we have identified an Indian private partner, the Adani Group which has been very active and successful in  India, in order to set a JV which will in fact encompass some energy regas terminals but also a retail network of  more than 1,000 stations over the next 10 years in India.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Then I come to the last part, which is not the oil and gas. It's more of the, if any, we speak [indiscernible]  (00:50:51). This new – the Gas, Renewables and Power business which is a combination again of energy and the  gas value chain, I would say integrated gas value chain and low-carbon electricity.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And you can see that between 2019 and 2018, if you take the high side which is $70, the white line is at $60. You  can see that there is an increase of more than 60% which is of course led mainly by the increase of LNG  production but also by the growing volume of energy trading we can do since we acquired the Engie portfolio.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: LNG forecast, more precise data but integrated LNG. Again, we grow to $3 billion in 2020. It's a 60% growth. It's a  strong contribution from the 2018 starters, Yamal, Ichthys; Cameron will come on-stream by middle of the year for  the first train, what we have in our portfolio and you can see that we have also – I was mentioning five projects to  be sanctioned which are all – which are – is quite, let's say, a large task to be done. Two of them in the U.S.  together with Sempra. We managed to enter into discussion and that's one of the good consequence of the deal  with Engie is that it's not only joining Sempra and Cameron in [indiscernible] (00:52:58), but it's entering which is  now a geodetic company in the U.S. through more projects and in particular this Energía Costa Azul project which  would give us the position in the Pacific Coast. It will involve a lot of logistic cost by not going from Gulf Coast  through Panama Channel but directly from the Pacific Coast to China, Japan or Korea – to Asia. We save a little  less than $1 per million Btu, so it's quite interesting.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: But we have also the expansion there, of course, of Cameron LNG train 4 and 5, which I would mention, Tellurian  which is taking shape. We are 20% shareholder of Tellurian and I know that our colleagues are progressing on  this project. And then we have Arctic 2 together with Novatek, which is moving forward. The feed and the sanction  is planned by second half of the year. And then we have Papua LNG which will give out Exxon and Oil Search,  which is a key target that we'll be able to finalize the agreements and we announced the feed as well there in  November. We have a technical team which is [ph] today agreed (00:54:10), which is efficient in particular  because we will expand in five existing plants and not create a new LNG plant.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And then, Nigeria LNG extension is probably one of the best projects because again it's a brownfield project and  it's a question of the sanction in Nigeria which might be complex but all partners [ph] are to be aligned (00:54:30)  to move to this project for 7.5 million tons per year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: About low-carbon electricity business, so 2018 has been a year where we really shaped it in a sizeable way. We  have a better visibility in what we want to do. It's a segment where we will invest $1 billion, $1.5 billion to $2 billion  per year, it will depend on opportunities.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: Fundamentally, we have on one side production capacities, because we want to be integrated. So three-year  worth of gas to electricity are in fact in our hand, because we have signed a deal with KKR. We have a new deal  coming with Uniper, EPH by the end of the year. And rest of the portfolio, so it's 30% natural gas, 70% renewable  production capacity worldwide. We have several subsidiaries working on that. That will make a profitable  business. I will come back on that.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: A word about Renewables, because there are many, many questions in my roadshows about how do you make  money with Renewables? And so, let's be clear. So, the business model we apply in the company in Total. It is  clear that when you bid to make a large solar farm or an offshore wind farm or onshore wind farm, generally it's a  utility business. The project is around 5% to 6%, 7%. That [indiscernible] (00:56:17) is a basis. Then of course,  price in particular in this environment, a way to leverage all these projects. Because when you have 15, 20 years  PPA, you can leverage these projects and so you can enhance the profitability for this leverage.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: But this way, to leverage financial interest rate and then to farm down to other investors, we see some interest to  get 7% instead of – it's a way to at the end get an acceptable equity return which is matching the rest of our  portfolio because, of course, for the company we intend and we have some objective of return on equity of 12% to  $60. This activity should not be, of course, a burden. So, this is the way we want to develop this Renewables  business. I hope it clarifies to you how we will manage the portfolio which we have in our hand.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: All this strategy is contributing to – and we want to be a positive player to tackle the climate change. We show you  this figure, we come back this afternoon on this climate section because I know that is a lot of interest of many  investors. We showed you this slide last September. Our ambition is to diminish gradually the carbon intensity of  all the energy products we sell to our customers. Obviously, I would say a scot-free approach for all of you who  understand – who knows that.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: We have the ambition to reduce this by 15% between 2015 and 2030 to go by 2040 25%, 35%. Difficult to  anticipate because our new technology depends also on the government policies. We will come back on that. But,  fundamentally, the road map is a matter of, of course they [ph] get accountable (00:58:27) about all emissions  and this afternoon, I will give you a – we'll set a target to our own emissions in order to decrease them and to be  committed to that.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: But also, natural gas is part of the future mix and is a positive add-on to the energy mix. It's a good complement to  Renewables, low-carbon electricity business, biofuels which are also contributing positively to this road map of  growing carbon intensity of our products. And last but not least, we invest in carbon sink businesses either natural  carbon sinks or CCUS. I will come back also on it.

texts.speaker: Patrick Pouyanné
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Total SA
texts.text: And being responsible is also a question of – and we have also quite a lot of this question during the roadshow,  how do you share the added value of Total? So, this is the image of the company and I think there are many  debates today around the world. A company like Total, we take an average of 2010, 2018, we generated $15  billion more or less, a little less, better than average of added value. Over half of it has been reinvested in the  company. We are highly capital-intensive business. So priority is clearly to invest in the company to continue to be  able to deliver more energy to our customers -affordable and clean energy.

texts.speaker: Operator

texts.text: 5 This improvement is despite a period when adverse weather conditions led to reduced footfall on  the high street, which had an impact on sales through retail channels for three weeks. In  subsequent weeks, however, booking volumes have been very strong as consumers returned to  the high street. For the season as a whole, pricing remained strong due to successful capacity  management. Average selling prices have strengthened slightly and are now up 10% versus the  prior year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Cost-saving measures have been very successfully implemented in Hapag-Lloyd. Based on this,  and combined with a positive freight rate trend, we are positive on Hapag-Lloyd’s further  development in 2010. As far as the overall expectation is concerned, you have seen – you see that  we are bottom-line positive.

file: TUI1 - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 9February2011 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me focus a little bit on the bad weather conditions around end of December and January. Our  business – our performance was affected by the severe weather conditions in December with many  airports being closed and thus flights being cancelled or [inaudible]. Despite that, as you can see,  TUI Travel is pretty well on track and is performing in a very good way.

file: TUI1 - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 15February2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: As far as load factor is concerned, Hapag-Lloyd, 74.1%, up 0.2 percentage points. TUI Cruises continued with the  outstanding performance as far as load factor is concerned, getting to an 98.8% load factor rate, up two  percentage points.

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: On the other hand, freight rates declined by roughly 8%. Underlying earnings amounted to €29 million, down €68  million year-on-year. The negative earnings impact resulted above all from a substantial rise in bunker prices of  roughly 43% from US$450 to US$649 per metric ton. But overall, the market environment remained  characterized by intense competition so that the higher energy costs were only partly passed on to customers  through the freight rates.

TUI1 - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 12February2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Friedrich Peter Joussen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Other than that, I only can report also that we are well on track to hit our oneTUI milestones for this year in order  to be able to hit our oneTUI targets next year. As you remember, 2014-2015 is the big year of TUI targets, so we  are a bit on track.

file: TUI1 - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 10February2015 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-15.pdf
TUI1 - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 9February2016 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Friedrich Peter Joussen
texts.profession: Joint Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Hapag-Lloyd Cruises, it is €3 million. The Hanseatic, the Europa 2 effect is actually round about €4.8 mil lion,  within that number. So you have a little bit of negative development. But keep in mind that we had planned dry  docks for Europa and Hanseatic: Europa, 14 days; Hanseatic, 21 days, so significant reduction in capacity. And,  therefore, we remain very confident that Hapag-Lloyd Cruises will be delivering regarding, or according to  expectations.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Peter Joussen
texts.profession: Joint Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Specialist Group is actually a little bit disappointing. Y ou know that we have here a group of all specialists around  the world, a lot of number of businesses. But the snow season was not very good. That is a big driver in that  business. Crystal Ski, for example, had a very, very weak year because there was no snow. And, also, the  [indiscernible] (12:47) which in perception was particularly big in the U.S. So the U.S. market  in general was not  very good and we have a higher reliance on the U.S. market in our Specialist business as well. And, therefore, the  Specialist business is actually – the winter season was not a very good season.

file: TUI1 - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 14February2017 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-17.pdf
TUI1 - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 13February2018 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Member of the Executive Board – Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: That brings me to the next slide which gives an update on TUI Airlines. I already touched base on the fact that we  are re-fleeting our TUI Airlines. We are moving from the B737 NG generation to the B737 MAX generation. We  got the first B737 MAX delivered couple of days ago to our Belgium fleet. In total, there will be 70 aircrafts which  will ultimately replace all of the former B757s and the B737 NGs, which is quite good because these aircrafts are  very fuel efficient, and they are efficient as far as the emissions of CO2 is concerned. And on top of that, they  have an increased flying range, which is good when it comes to destinations like [indiscernible] (00:20:18), which  are pretty important to us.

file: TUI1 - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 12February2019 215 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-19.pdf
TUI1 - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 12May2010 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Some words now on the volcano eruption on Iceland, you are all pretty familiar with that, what  happened over the last weeks. Between the 15th and the 20th of April, we faced widespread  closures of European airspace following concerns related to volcanic ash in the atmosphere.  Regular business was affected by almost 11 to 12 days.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now I would like to come to the outlook for the financial year 2009-10. For summer 2010, trading  has continued in line with the expectations, although there was some weakness in these two  mentioned weeks following the volcanic ash disruption.
