texts.speaker: Björn Beroleit, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good day to you all, ladies and gentlemen. I’d like to welcome you to the Analyst Conference of
texts.text: But, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to emphasize that bright skies always alternate with gloomy  days. Let me mention two topics in this respect, one being the volcanic eruption in Iceland and the  associated ash cloud, which completely paralyzed Europe’s airspace from the 15th to the 21st of  April. A total of 180,000 of our guests were directly affected in their holiday resorts with 175,000  guests canceling their holidays as a result. Booking numbers were slow to pick up again after the  flight ban was lifted initially. Due to this natural disaster, we lost turnover and €127 million in  earnings. However, the way TUI handled the ash cloud also showed that we have an experienced  management team, which is able to handle such unforeseeable events in a highly professional  manner.

file: TUI1 - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 14December2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Dec-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael H. F. Frenzel
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, TUI AG
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I'd like to welcome you as well also on behalf of my Executive Board. We are  looking back on an extremely exciting and challenging year. It has been a successful year. We know that at the  beginning of the year, the economic climate looked pretty good but seems clouded over as the year progressed.

texts.speaker: Michael H. F. Frenzel
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, TUI AG
texts.text: Against this backdrop of a considerable deterioration in the overall environment, TUI AG held up well in the  completed financial year. We manage to improve all our key indicators. In some instances, we've actually achieved  substantial improvement, so it's a very good result, one of the best in tourism in recent years.

texts.speaker: Horst Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: A major cost factor in Tourism is the oil price. The cost of jet fuel accounts for around 10% of TUI Travel's cost  base. The significant increase in the oil price did not yet fully impact the TUI Group's earnings position in the  period under review, since the jet fuel and bunker requirements in Tourism for our cruise ships and aircraft in the  summer season 2011 that's almost fully been hedged or covered by corresponding fuel surcharges.

texts.speaker: Horst Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: However, above all in source market UK, the weakness of sterling and higher energy prices resulted in higher  input costs at TUI Travel. TUI Travel, therefore, launched cost savings and efficiency enhancement programs to  counter these trends and these programs have already reduced the strain on the cost base. Gross profit as the  balance between [indiscernible] (24:12) totaled around €1.8 billion in the completed financial year. This is an  increase of around 9% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Horst Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: The considerable decline in one-off items to be adjusted, and here we carried items worth €203 million in the  prior year is largely driven by the expenses of €127 million for the volcanic eruption in Iceland included in the  prior year amount. We also have adjustments required for the effects of purchase price allocations, which totaled  €96 million.

file: TUI1 - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Analyst Meeting 19December2012 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Dec-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Many of our customers, most of whom live in our European source markets, are experiencing not particularly  stable times economically and politically, so that the gratifyingly positive climate in Germany does not detract  from that fact. And despite the sound development of the leading indexes, the euro crisis did cause nervousness,  substantial nervousness in international financial markets during most of the reporting period.

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: As our hotel sector is closely interlinked with TUI Travel's product portfolio, in particular with regard to  differentiated and exclusive product offerings, we have a clear strategic edge vis-à-vis other hotel chains. We do  not own all of the 248 hotels. We manage them either directly or in cooperation with the respective joint venture  portfolio management – management of companies with high level of operational flexibility, lower natural  investment risk and, therefore, relatively low management fees in terms of the proceeds.

file: TUI1 - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Press Conference 19December2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Dec-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I'd like to welcome you here and also on behalf of my colleagues on the  Executive Board in presenting our financial position for 2011 to 2012. We're looking back on a year today where  the overall environment was marked by a deteriorating European sovereign debt crisis.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: During the year, we saw also an aggravation of the economic environment in Europe but also in other parts of the  world where we had a lot of bad news, and the uncertainties about the future of euro intensified in spite of the  efforts that were undertaken by the European Central Bank and the heads of state in government in the EU to  stabilize the European monetary system.  Many of our customers, most of whom live in our European source markets, are experiencing a period of  economic and political instability. This gratifyingly positive climate in Germany does not detract from that fact.  Despite the sound development of the leading indexes, the euro crisis caused substantial nervousness in  international financial markets during most of the reporting period, not only in Europe.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Let me emphasize here that RIU, TUI's largest hotel brand, delivered an outstanding performance. RIU achieved  improvements in pricing levels and, again, very successful cost management. Our club brand, Robinson, also looks  back on a good year. Occupancy of the clubs grew by 4.2 percentage points year-on-year. Average revenues per  bed per day were flat year-on-year.  In the holiday hotel market, the trend towards all-inclusive offerings continues. Demand for golf, spa, wellness  and health products are also increasing gratifyingly. Customers are continuing to show a strong awareness for  ecological issues. Holiday makers travelling with us want to be sure that we're doing all we can to conserve natural  resources as best we can, and we feel well-positioned to meet these various customer needs and requirements with  our hotel brands.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: TUI Cruises currently operates two cruise ships, Mein Schiff 1 and Mein Schiff 2, both ships recorded a load factor  of just over 100%. We will be expanding that capacity.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Let me briefly touch on an issue reflected in the work of many of our committed colleagues in the TUI Group, an  issue that plays a big role for us and that is the many facets of sustainability in tourism. In our sustainability  program, we've committed to clear overall objectives. They range from assuming social responsibility in our  destinations, and promoting diversity to minimizing our carbon footprint.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: We attach particular importance to our climate protection activities. We've come up with a climate strategy which  focuses on avoiding and reducing greenhouse gases right along the entire value chain. We are convinced that we'll  be able to reduce our ecological footprint through cooperation schemes, research and innovative product  development, and I'd just like to mention one of the many examples of technological innovation.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: This year, along with our manufacturer, at TUIfly, we carried out a test series for electric green taxiing using a  Boeing 737-800. This electric taxiing system enables aircraft to taxi to the runway or to the gate position with the  engines off. This will cut aircraft fuel consumption and will reduce noise.

texts.speaker: Michael Heinz Franz Frenzel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: I'm delighted to see that our commitment has been recognized publicly. Our continuous listing in the Dow Jones  Sustainability Index where, for two years in a row, we've been listed as sector leader, and also our listing in the  FTSE4Good confirm our sustainability strategy. And this underpins our commitment vis-à-vis our stakeholders,  and in particular the capital market.

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Turnover also rose due to positive foreign exchange effects, as already mentioned, mainly resulting from the  alongside the cost of sales, which also rose by 4% to around €16.3 billion due to the rise in oil prices and the  strengthening of sterling.

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Following a sound performance in the first nine months, the strong short-term demand in the summer season  driven not least by the poor weather in Northern Europe, created additional improvements towards the end of the  financial year.

texts.speaker: Horst Heinz Paul Baier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, TUI AG
texts.text: Earnings of companies measured at equity declined by €62 million. This primarily reflects the weaker  performance of container shipping. In the period under review, the result posted by Hapag-Lloyd was impacted by  the notable weakening of global economic growth observed over the past few months, persistently intense  competition and a considerable increase in energy costs. Hapag-Lloyd's average bunker consumption price rose to  $661 per ton in financial year 2011 to 2012, and thus exceeded the prior year's reference value by $104 per ton.

texts.text: On build costs, I touched on 9%. Arguably, it’s the most flattering way of looking at it, because it  focuses on our private build costs. That’s how we set out the original 10% target. texts.speaker: Peter Redfern, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome. Thank you for joining us. I think we’ve got everybody in now,
texts.text: Still see 10% being the right target. We’re getting to the point where you’re seeing the majority of  that benefit come through in the first half. And the margin growth we see from here goes back more  to that underlying site quality replanning exercise, just squeezing a bit more out of the selling price  by better products, a bit more out of build costs, not from an efficiency method, but by better house  types to build.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome. Thank you for joining us. I think we’ve got everybody in now,
texts.text: I said I’d touch on change of government. We’re obviously in the early days and continuing to  monitor the risks and opportunities. We actually think it can work, we just think it can take a long time to get  there. And our concern, which we shout about regularly in our meetings with the government, is  about the transition risk. It’s going to take a long time for the changes they’d like to make to come  through.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome. Thank you for joining us. I think we’ve got everybody in now,
texts.text: Affordability is very good. These stats are the proportion of people in each market who can afford to  buy the average home. And for those to be at 65% for the U.S. overall, and think about 82%, you  think of it, that with the environment in the UK if 65% of people could afford the average family  home. It’s just very different conditions. And once that confidence starts to improve, you’ll see that  starting to impact on trading. And you can see that in some of our competitors’ land buying  decisions, of their future view of the market.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome. Thank you for joining us. I think we’ve got everybody in now,
texts.text: Moving on to the balance sheet, land and work in progress has remained broadly in line with  December 2009’s figures. Land has reduced slightly due to the rate of land acquisitions being  slightly less than consumption. And work in progress, whilst tightly controlled, has increased slightly  as volumes have increased and the order book has grown.

file: TWL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 3August2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: NNN
texts.text: The biggest driver of it, it's probably the biggest outperformance, particularly is on build cost savings, there we've  gone past the 10% sort of target that we set and, I mean, I said with the prelims, we expected maybe a 2% to 3%  build cost saving in the first half of '11 compared to '10, it's actually more like 4% to 5%. On paper, it's bigger than  that but if you strip out some of the mix impact, it's actually more like 4% to 5%, driven by an awful lot of detailed  actions within the business.  You saw from our trading update that we've been very successful in strategic land, both acquiring, particularly the  UK Coal deal but a number of other smaller individual sites and promoting through the planning system. We've  also put a lot of work into our approach to the new planning environment which we'll touch on.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: This is to allow for more meaningful underlying performance of the continuing Group. Net land including land  creditors in the period is marginally up by £9 million; we expect the land balance to grow in the second half as we  are more active in the land market. The WIP balance whilst up period on period on December as expected with the  balance of completions more to the second half and the phasing of WIP on site.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The balance is just under two-thirds, sorry, controlled land just over a third free hold. Obviously the UK Coal deal  at the end of the first half has helped boost the proportion and the level of owned and strategic land. And the new  sites we've been adding through the period, not just that UK Coal deal, are similar sort of weighting, just about  two-thirds controlled, one-third owned which gives you an idea of the kind of future margin boost.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: A couple of specifics; touched on the UK Coal deal, but just to give you an idea of the kind of sites, the kind of  sizes. A resolution to grant about 900 homes in Church Crookham, for about 500 homes in Brackley in South  Northamptonshire, and commence work has been started, actually physically on site at a strategic site that we got  through last year in Cranbrook near Exeter for around 900 times.  We've got three or four, and we've talked them about before, really large strategic sites that we're already sort of  up and running on in Aylesbury and Andover and Didcot. Actually, we are quite happy that the mix of these is a  little bit smaller on average, it obviously gives you more bang for your buck in terms of the next four or five years  in some of the really large sites. But from all those, definitely some real margin improvements beyond 2012  coming through.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: More of the short-term land acquisition, the sites we're buying now that become a big and increasing proportion  of the business. Still more cost savings from that standard approach, but you have to kind of ignore the fact that in  a slightly improving house price environment, you're going to get some material cost increases. You're going to get  some regulatory impact kicking back in.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The focus, and we've said this several times, in when acquiring and managing a large portfolio rather than feeding  the machine, so it's why we won't give hard volume targets and hard outlet number targets. We do expect volume  growth. We actually have a view that there's probably a cap which is lower than the 20,000 units we were at, sort  of in the previous cycle, and we don't really want to go above that cap, but there's still quite a lot of growth, as the  market recovers and our current land feed through, volume growth will come. We think that relationship and  partnership-based land acquisition is key. The UK Coal deal, several other things we've had done or are doing,  where we are buying consistent strings of land from one vendor, is a key part of staying out of the short-term land  market in too heavy a way.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And lastly and we will spend quite a lot more time on this in September, we don't think you can have the right  strategy as a homebuilder unless you actively manage the cycle. And that means flexing the land portfolio, flexing  the business structure, flexing the capital structure ahead of where you think the cycle is going to go rather than  behind and I think most of the sector has to look back and say we didn't do that effectively enough last time.

file: TWL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 1August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.profession: SECTION
texts.text: And last of the four, management of capital structure, particularly looking at the cycle management, look at how  land investments are timed. Again, we feel we're very much doing what we say we're going to do. We're giving you  an idea of what our land investment is likely to be. We're telling you that it's going to be dependent on what the  land quality is.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.profession: SECTION
texts.text: And you can see in the overall improvement in asset turn and return on net assets, and we're starting to get some  of those sites moving. We haven't made big land sales. We've been quite cautious over the last couple of years.  There is land we could sell that would short-term improve the returns but we just think that damages the longer  term value and it's the right time to be patient.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.profession: SECTION
texts.text: So, not a major sea change, but definitely with the lack of funding out there and less pressure on the social  housing numbers in 106s from local authorities, we'd expect to see social housing proportions fall a bit. And we  wanted to make significant additions to the strategic land portfolio, which we've done. A couple of examples there.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.profession: SECTION
texts.text: If we were running with a lot shorter landbank at the moment, we just couldn't absorb that sort of even small,  slow gradual market change without having to either shrink the business back down or go back into the land  market more aggressively. We'd rather be in the land market now and those things are starting to improve. So we  don't think we have to do a lot other than just be patient and work our sites harder to get there.

texts.speaker: SECTION
texts.profession: SECTION
texts.text: We're now very pleased with the way that's operating, both from a customer aspiration point of view, it's helping  to build up like-for-like sales prices, same site product, but it is getting a sales price premium, it's getting us cost  efficiency, and you can see even though the value of our sales have gone up, that cost base, both pounds per plot  and pounds per square foot, has stayed very stable and that's driven by some of these efficiencies coming out. It's  certainly helping us manage incremental environmental improvements in house types without meaningful cost  increases. So, it's very difficult to pin down on exactly how much is driven by, but we do see this as being a  continuing value benefit in terms of the bottom line. And I'm sure that the next time we do a site visit for analysts  and investors, it's something that we'll want to focus your time and attention on.

file: TWL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 31July2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: This is a slide that we've over the last sort of three or four years have tended to include in the appendix, but  thought the movement was significant enough and interesting enough to bring it forward. You've seen our  apartment levels, and this is completions in the first half, fall to below 20% for the first time. We've been buying  land, in terms of proportion of apartments between 15% and 20%, for the last two or three years, so it's natural  that that will happen. But I think what's most interesting is that switch out of apartments has not gone into  smaller houses; it's actually gone into a significant increase in larger four-bed or five-bed houses. That's driving  the increase in average square footage and that's driving the increase in average selling price. That's a big shift. To  have a 3% increase in four-bed and five-bed houses in one period is significant. We think it's sustainable. We think  this is probably about the level it will settle down at. But it's a significant shift and it's been hard historically to  achieve, but in the land conditions we have seen over the last two or three years are more possible.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Touching on the land market and then the land strategy in this environment, the land market has stayed  reasonably benign, fairly stable. There is some new competition. As I said at the trading update, it stays largely  where some of our competitors have either reopened subsidiaries in markets that they haven't been in over the  last four or five years or where they've stepped up their land buying. We're not seeing significant new competition  from small developers, a little bit but not enough to really move the dial.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Looking both at strategic land and at short-term land and just commenting briefly on the state of the planning  system, we do see a net improvement on five years ago. I'm not going to go through all the detail; it's things we  talked about before. I think we do have to be slightly cautious, and it doesn't say it in too much in black and white,  but both about the longer term planning environment, we do see that as a bit of a window. There are some  elements of that, particularly the five-year land supply argument, that we can already see tightening. Some of that  is early pre-election politicization. You see some local decisions and some national ones being driven by view of  politics sort of in 18 months' time. The underlying climate is changing positively but it is very, very slow.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Marginal impact on net land, because the better quality locations do have a slight impact on the land cost and are  linked to revenues. But it's a very good snapshot in terms of the drivers going forward.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And the cost pressures which I touched on are real but they're relatively localized and they're relatively small. And  by localized, I mean both geographically and in particular trades, particular materials. Bricks has been a well- publicized issue in the period. It's already eased off slightly in July. You saw particularly unusual conditions in  May and June following a period of very bad weather when the industry was increasing its production. Surprise,  surprise, bricks and bricklayers are in short supply. As I say, as we've gone into July, we've already seen that  lessen.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So last of all, just standing back from sort of the whole of the short and long-term piece and just saying where are  we focused going forwards. We've shown you this sort of way of presenting things in the past and then we've also  put on here some of the history of how we've seen it in the past as to where our priorities are. Obviously, a green  upward arrow is a positive, three green upward arrows is a significant positive and a red downward arrow is a  negative. We wouldn't show you the chart if it was nearly all red and nearly all downwards. So the fact that we're  showing you means that we think it's reasonably positive.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We see benefits of volume growth. I think we are pretty clear that we're not going to be volume-driven. That  doesn't mean there isn't some benefits in terms of overheads of getting natural growth in an improving market  from sales rates on sites, but it doesn't change our fundamental objectives. We see benefits in that environment  from sales price increases, and probably if I'm honest I'd put two green upward arrows on that one, but I'm  slightly cautious about presenting it that way. But we certainly see benefits from that.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Some downward pressure from regulatory impacts. Yeah, we're starting to see certain government costs that have  been held in abeyance starting to creep through. They're not big and I don't think they're going to grow  dramatically, but there will be some cost inflation driven by those sorts of cost elements. Part L around energy  efficiency was just announced yesterday. It's slightly less expensive than we expected, but it's still a cost. So it's a  smaller negative than we would have anticipated five years ago.

file: TWL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 30July2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The planning environment remains better than the previous cycle and better probably than any planning  environment we've seen over the last 20 years or so. It still remains quite difficult to get through the final stages of  getting sites opened. But it is happening and certainly is a major underpin of the strategic land success that we've  had.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: If we do continue to be as successful as we've been over the strategic land conversions, we don't think that has  particularly adverse balance sheet impacts. The structure of most of those deals that we – even when we crystallize  the planning commission, we tend to then draw them down in tranches rather than secure the whole site and p ay  for it upfront. So actually the balance sheet dynamics remain pretty healthy even when those larger strategic sites  come onto the balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Our improvement in land mix is 2.6 percentage points and that's us trading from newly acquired and better  quality locations, relative to the previous year, giving an overall net land improvement of 0.9% and we expect to  continue to make progress in this regard in the second half.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: From the land credit perspective, we expect approximately £355 million to be flowing over the next two years. And  we do continue to use land creditors very selectively and we use them where it makes the most commercial sense  for ourselves.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Now this will lead you, if you assume we actually hit every single planning permission that we reasonably could to  a much higher level of strategic land that we talked about. That's not impossible; a 40% target could be exceeded.  We wouldn't change that target today, but it does give us some choices and lot of flexibility and particularly a lot of  flexibility in the short-term land market that we've not had before.

file: TWL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So the next slide gives you a sense of where we map those sites today after four years of going through it. And  you'll see we're very heavily weighted towards the green and the yellow. You can see there is an AA block in the  background; it's significant but it's not the biggest part of what we do. Most of the sites [indiscernible] (12:22) in  red are either historic or fit the kind of deal structures that we talked about, and only make up about 3% of our  total landbank.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we're very pleased with where that sits at the moment. We have wondered whether we could go back and  recreate this data for 12, 13 years ago, but I'm not sure I'd be brave enough to show it to you if I could actually map  it, because I think there would be a very high proportion of the reds and yellows. The most important thing is that  we really challenge people to think about the site and where it is and whether their pricing is realistic.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: The NRV provision release is a lower and lower consequence year-on-year, you might recall we had a relatively  material write back to the P&L last year which takes a little bit of the gloss off as that slightly higher land cost  comes through of 0.3%. So the overall market impact we think we've captured in the half is 1.5%.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: We think that we've got some efficiencies in our build costs relative to the market, from a construction perspective  and delivery perspective, of 0.4% improvement to margin as well as improvement in the land mix coming through  the P&L from the slightly lower quantums of previous legacy sites we traded through in the P&L, as well as the fact  of its better quality locations of sites coming through and strategic land as well, which results in net land  improvement of 1.6%.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: On a UK per plot analysis perspective, we've got a steady trend of reducing land costs to average selling price, this  is a combination of better quality locations driving down price as well as the impact of improving contributions  from our strategic pipeline which is a lower average plot cost. Build cost is a little bit impacted by mix in terms of  quality of locations, most notably London coming through in a bit more anger, but also through just underlying  market inflation. And clearly with a greater proportion of strategic land sites coming through the P&L those have  got slightly higher infrastructure costs, and ever so slightly higher build costs as a consequence which we do need  to bear in mind as well.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: There were risks coming into the election around government views around the industry I think for both major  political parties coming into the election, however there was a sense of yes we want more but we can only push the  existing industry so far, so we've got to look at how we create an environment for new competition. So we sit in a  very positive place in terms of those kind of dialogues and the environment that has been created. It is, from a  government point-of-view, a real opportunity to create more stability. If you don't push it too hard in the short- term but create a much more positive planning environment then you can afford to invest far more carefully.

file: TWL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 27July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Land environment is very encouraging, but we're not filling our boots. We're being cautious, but cautious doesn't  mean we're out of that market at all, but we are progressing, strategic land particularly. And materials and labor  supply under control but we can't say that there aren't any long-term impacts that are slightly degrading. So,  there's sort of pressures on that.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: Land overage, which is a concept that creeps in particularly on deferred payment terms and large long-dated  sites, has resulted in a slightly bigger increase in land cost to the P&L in the period, and we'll talk a bit about the  growth on the balance sheet from a land creditor point of view as a consequence as well. That takes a small  amount of margin out of the market indicators. Clearly, a more positive market environment results in a slightly  higher land cost if there's overage attached to the contract, which then obviously doesn't mean you capture as  much of that market uplift.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: The specification improvements and build costs, a little bit about further commitment to overhead on site in terms  of physical delivery of costs has taken out about 0.5 percentage points in margin meaning that the net land  improvement, because there hasn't been really a material change in mix effect in the period, which sits at zero,  so, the net land improvement is a 0.5 percentage point change.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: The improvement initiatives on customer services and the customer journey in terms of getting the home quality  right and the immediate street scene and the environment that we're delivering customers into, naturally takes a  fraction more time to deliver that, and that itself also consumes a small amount of work-in-progress. However, the  majority of the business have made strong progress in this regard, and so we're not expecting the trend of  additional consumption of capital as a result of customer services change in future periods.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of strategy, nothing has changed. We built the strategy five years ago, and when we reviewed it this  year, having the ability to manage through a cycle built into it rather than it be something we decided what we do  when we got there, was always fundamentally important. So, over the course of the last month when we have  more cautious and looked at downside scenarios, we knew what we were planning to do. And so, nothing has  really changed in that. And I think the balance sheet structure with, as Ryan has touched on, low or net debt;  tightening on land creditors, making sure that we don't sort of overstretch on that; tightening our land policies  around hurdle rates but also the whole trend towards major developments-type sites without full land commitment.  All of that is about managing the cycle longer term.

file: TWL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 1August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And those were with sites that were already in our order book sort of six months ago, so were clearly no great  surprise to us. But as we look forward, I think we have a growing degree of confidence in the environment in  Central London, not so much about where things will go over the next 2 or 3 years, but about the next 5 to 10  years and whether strategically it's the right place for us to be.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Looking at the balance sheet, the [ph] dynamic of capital release (18:32) from land continues despite the overall  scale of the land banks [ph] taken broadly (18:38) the same. Furthermore, there's been a reduction in land  creditors in the period. However, I expect in the second half of this year that land creditor balance will probably  grow to be more in line with the trend we saw in 2016. There's been a slight overall investment increase in work in  progress year-on-year, and this is reflecting both sort of high infrastructure costs on the larger sites as well as the  output growth that Pete noted before, and a bit of build cost inflation, which obviously goes into that line.

file: TWL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 31July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So, the impact we saw in weather in February will probably cost a little bit more than we expected. Sort of in terms  of functional build, not so much completion numbers because of timing but sort of in where we are. So, I think, we  feel more confident than we did then, yeah, and we felt reasonably happy then that the full year was on track.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: On the land side, still a very good land environment. And the land costs as a percent of new approvals, still low at  17%. And the revenue in the landbank has continued to grow even in a set of, sort of, uncertain economic  conditions with a reasonably stable landbank [indiscernible] (00:04:27) the selling price in the landbank has  improved. We're close to £50 billion of potential revenue. And our strategic landbank has gone over 120,000 plots  for the first time.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And as Chris will talk about we've completed Stage 1 of our cost and efficiency review.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: You start to see that trend. It's not huge numbers. I'm not trying to sort of give you a big-cost saving target here,  but it should hopefully give you confidence that when we look at some of these areas, and say, it's right for us to  invest in these areas, but once we get there, then we'll get some of that cost back out that we can actually deliver  that. We believe particularly on the remediation side of it the actual physical costs.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Last one, on customer service. And I said you could see the regional sort of split where all of our businesses are  just over that 90%. I'm not going to spend a lot of time on the bottom half, but we will come back to it. That shows  you the breakdown of the nine-month scores. And there's are a number of things on there like the service  performance afterwards; the development score, which is how people rate the environment they live in which  don't really come up on the 28-day survey. Those are the sorts of reasons why we think that's a better way of  assessing how we do it. You can see, there's a big performance improvement over the course of the 12-month  period that we're looking at.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So, certainly nothing there, no regrets at the moment with that site which, we think over the longer term, will be a  great site for the business. And the cancellation rates which I wouldn't want you to place too much story but  should give you a sort of a reasonable degree of confidence in the stability of the environment that we see in  those sites.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Overall, the group results for the first half are very comparable to what was a record first half in 2017. And in the  context of that and the poor weather conditions in March, we consider these results represent strong  performance. As noted in the trading update in April, we expect volumes to be more second half weighted than  normal and we remain on track to deliver 2018 in line with expectations.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The average contribution for each of our homes increased by £1,100 compared to the first half of last year.  Contribution margins remain constant at 25.9% with increased build costs being offset by lower land costs and  selling [ph] inefficiencies (00:30:54). It's probably worth noting that the increased mix of affordable units in the first  half tends to increase the build cost as a percentage of selling price, but reduce the land cost as a percentage of  selling price. So, you should expect those movements to reverse in the second half, as well as the mix moves  back towards what you've seen in previous years.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Following the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower last year, we undertook a detailed review of all of our buildings to  identify those with aluminum composite material in the façade. And where we identified buildings with ACM, we  worked with building owners, with management companies and with fire service to implement the government's  interim mitigation measures. And we also sought professional advice from experts on each individual building as  to what, if any, the next steps should be.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: I think more positively the new Planning Policy Framework could have had some meaningful negatives in it. I  think, overall, we felt it would be neutral but, overall, I think we now feel it it's probably a net positive in terms of  just generally progressing the planning environment. And we're quite comfortable with the fact the government  needed to have a renewed focus on environmental issues. I think our sense is sort of post to 2008-2009, the  focus went away from it too much. So, that's actually overdue and we're kind of ready to sort of refocus on  ourselves.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And in terms of short-term trading, I'll restate what I said at the beginning. We're comfortable with our guidance  set for 2018. We expect small positive steps in all of the main financial metrics. Our own expectation for this year  is almost exactly what it was in January. The environment remains good, but we should be sort of aware and  have a cautious mindset about consumer confidence, because it's pretty impressive at times. Questions?

file: TWL - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 3March2010 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Norman Askew, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everybody, and welcome to Taylor Wimpey’s Preliminary Results for Year-Ending
texts.text: Significant reduction in total cost, particularly the UK build cost. You’ll remember we’ve talked about  a 10% target in terms of reduction, really looking to see that come through the P&L by 2010. And  I’ve talked about – you might see 3%, 4%, that sort of rough spread over the next three years. To  see 4.5% of that comes through in the second half, we’re pretty pleased with. We still think there  will be improvements in 2010 coming through, which we’ll come back to.

texts.speaker: Norman Askew, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everybody, and welcome to Taylor Wimpey’s Preliminary Results for Year-Ending
texts.text: Build cost now, I mentioned 4.5% at the beginning, that’s per square foot. Because of the shift in  product mix that 7% increase in average selling price, it gets quite distorted. You can see actually  on a cost per plot, there’s a reduction. But if you strip out the movement half on half in square  footage, you’ll see the underlying reduction. That’s against the headwind, which we’d estimated  about 2% to 3% of build costs in that period and in terms of regulatory costs. And our target takes  into account those regulatory costs. We think the 10% net saving that we’re targeting is bloody  tough, but we’re be extremely pleased if we get there, but it does take that into account.

texts.speaker: Norman Askew, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everybody, and welcome to Taylor Wimpey’s Preliminary Results for Year-Ending
texts.text: The blue line is build cost per unit. Again, if you took on average square footage, the line down will  be sharper and because of the increase in square footage. The key for us is pushing those two  lines further apart. I’ve deliberately missed land cost off there because there are the things that we  can control looking forward. The land cost on our existing land is now pretty fixed in the balance       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Norman Askew, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning everybody, and welcome to Taylor Wimpey’s Preliminary Results for Year-Ending
texts.text: We have not turned down any opportunities because of financing constraints. It’s not impossible  that there’ll be some limitations towards the back end of the year from our financing covenant, but  to be honest, we don’t see that as being a major problem. We do see the fact that the planning  system is getting harder and harder and I think on the – almost any government in the future, it’s  likely to change in a way that will cause transition issues, so getting the value at where we are  today and the new sizing we can get this year is quite key.

file: TWL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 3March2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: Please make sure your mobile phones are turned off, etcetera and Pete -- Pete’s running for charity  the Three Peaks Challenge in May. And so if any of his phone goes off, it’s a compulsory fine into  the Habitat for Humanity, which is the charity that Pete’s supporting in the Three Peaks Challenge.  And equally, if anybody wants to sponsor and more generally, I’m sure he’d be happy to pick that  up at the end.

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: The increase in land creditors is due to the Group being more active in the land markets in the  second half of 2010. £317 million of the total land creditors in the U.K., £47 million is in Canada and  approximately £200 million of the year-end’s land creditors are expected to be paid in 2011. We  believe that it is right to keep land creditors tightly managed as we look at our total balance sheet  commitments, however land creditors do provide an efficient source of financing. Book gearing at  the end of the period, which is net debt to equity was 35.9% compared to 50% in 2009 year-end.

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: So I’m going to start on Slide 31 with U.K housing performance summary. More of this presentation  than usual is going to be focused forward-looking, a bit less on the detailed numbers. The numbers  are all in the appendix. Happy to take questions on them. But we felt more than anything else,  particularly, because we were coming to the end of the results season, we talked to you a little  more about land strategy, sales performance, little bit about the Localism Agenda on government’s  planning, sort of policy, rather than just go back with through the numbers. And Ryan has covered a  fair amount of detail on that anyway.

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: Moving onto land strategy on Slide 37, and we’re trying to create a mentality for our own business  where we look at our landbank as an investment portfolio rather than something that we use to  feeding the machine. We’re trying to avoid the scenario where a local business gets short of land  and so they try too hard. They pushed the assumptions and to comment about our outlets, are not  trying to put too much dependence on high outlet numbers is the only driver.

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: So, summing all that up on Slide 41, I’m really looking at margin going forward in that double-digit  targets in 2012, that is against what we expect to be a pretty stable house price market overall. We  expect to get those cost savings. We expect land build costs year-on-year from 2010 to 2011 to  come down about 3%. So that’s one of the drivers of that margin improvement.

texts.speaker: Kevin Beeston, Chairman
texts.profession: Yeah, can everybody hear me okay, first of all, at the back? Okay. Thanks very much. Well,
texts.text: So whilst we see the transition as a risk, we think there will be less planning commissions in 2011  and ‘12 as a result of this policy. We do think that if you manage it right, there are some  opportunities and there are certainly some good lot of opportunities relative to the sector if you take  it on a bit more positively rather than standing back and letting it happen to you.

file: TWL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, we think the right time to do that is as the land market heats up and there is less short-term uncertainty than  there is at the moment, rather than at the moment where land opportunities are good, and we'll talk about that,  because we're not sort changing our strategy and going to spend lots of excess capital on land. But we do think  having the flexibility to invest at the moment is right.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And we are also very pleased, because it's always been very important to us, with an improvement of nearly a third  in our accident rate. We're at the lowest level we've ever been in terms of accidents by some margin. And again,  that and things like the waste savings, we think, are a good signal of the quality of the way the business is  operating at a detailed level. It's not just focused on very short-term financial measures. And just completed the  sale of North American business in July, which was quite nice at the last stage of the capital restructuring.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And London we saw as being very strong in the first half of last year. It's softened a bit in the second half, but it's  now seems very stable. It's not got the heat in it that it had 12 months ago, but it seems pretty stable. Southern  regional characteristics, much level of housing demand. Almost, yeah, inevitably the opposite, the market risk is  lower, but the other risks, the amount you tie up in land, the scale of sites, the nature of land deals, the  competition in the land market, the level of affordable housing, all put a bit of extra risk on. And so, it's a  balancing act between the two.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the planning environment, it's unfortunate this slide sort of doesn't seem to translate onto the thing, it moves  across. Just by way of an update, the Localism Act was approved last year. The critical piece which we're waiting  for at the moment is the Planning Policy Framework, which is expected to be published later in the spring. That's  very vague, isn't it, Peter. But next month, next month, we think.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It's a still a bit jury out, because we don't know and that Planning Policy Framework is key, we don't know where  the final draft will land. But we certainly don't see it as a material risk overall, to overall industry volumes. It's  probably not a massive upside, but there's definitely company-specific upsides if you handle it right.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And on Community Infrastructure Levy, CIL, which is the bottom four or five points. Something that generally has  passed below the radar screen, but we think could be quite significant, if not managed properly. This is effectively  a roof tax, is the simplest way of thinking about it.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It passed into law last year and local authorities can individually put in place their own community infrastructure  levies today. As you can see at the bottom, seven today have them in place. There's about 21 in consultations at the  moment. We've structured an industry response to that, so we're all coordinating and sharing the costs of our  response. The key is to consult early and make sure that those CILs are not set at such a high level that a large  number of sites become unviable.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We're not deeply concerned about the impact on values in our own balance sheet, because most of them have  planning permission anyway or they've been built in with a degree of risk. It's whether there's another kind of  headwind that stops particularly brownfield sites from being viable. So it is definitely one to watch. Ryan?

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We've significantly strengthened the balance sheet and delivered an improved trading performance. We're  committed to a more active approach in managing the cycle and balancing value through selective land buying  and returning cash to shareholders at the right time. The board's view is that a regular maintenance dividend  through the cycle calculated off net assets as the basis as opposed to earnings is appropriate, with an approximate  split of two-thirds final and one-third interim. Additional returns will then be made at the right time in the cycle  and will largely be linked to relative reduction in land investment as the market heats up. We will be well placed to  deliver strong operational cash flows. On this basis, the board has proposed a final dividend of 0.38p per share,  representing equivalent yield of 1% on net assets at the end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: You look back at the last two years and it's been very much about cost efficiency, product improvement. There are  still benefits to come from that and the focus is still strong on that. But the bigger financial impacts on the bottom  line will come over the next six to 12 to 24 months from the land strategy of the last two or three years, both from  new sites, from the strategic sites coming through, from the re-plans on existing sites.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The standard construction detail is probably the wrong terminology. It's a broader thing. It's just about the  consistency of the way we're building our products. We are getting quite a lot of gains, not just from direct  procurement savings but from repeatability, which we have far more consistency of within our business. Not just  on the cost impacts of some of the new environmental standards has been very significant, by actually going  towards one standard model for how we build in almost every location.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And we think that balance on incentives is very important. And we do think we have a very efficient homebuilding  operation that does the basics, from selling through construction, extremely well. The strategic focus is on the land  strategy, because we think that's where the business value is greatest, but having a very efficient operation is key.  And in terms of capital structure, we do think it's right to hold a longer portfolio at the moment. We've touched on  that a number of times. We don't think that's changed. It's not going to grow significantly. We're not seeing so  many opportunities that we think we should go out and buy a business or anything like that. We're not talking  about a very aggressive strategy, but we do think the opportunities are good. But we do think that the  opportunities generate significant cash, when land markets start to heat up and when we think that the overall  environment is stronger.

file: TWL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 1March2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And as we talked about several times over the last few years, an increasing mix of new land coming through  driving both that quality of average selling price, not showing a commensurate increase in bill costs and seeing  lower land costs relative to the average selling price coming through the P&L.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So those are two newer points of focus, but no fundamental change in strategy, still very much the same direction.  So taking those six points one after the other, just giving you some statistical sort of analysis obviously of that  strong margin performance, 250 basis points growth. Even with the impact of extended gas flues, which cost us  about £12 million last year, probably about just over half a percent of margin so that would've been a 300 basis  points growth without that. Still, the focus on delivering outlets properly, not just fast. You see more growth in  outlets in 2012 and you see we have been telling you for a while it would come.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The one thing it does change is it pushes up the number of short-term plots that we would describe as being  strategically sourced. So under the old definition, we'd have had about 28% strategically sourced, under new  definition, it's just over 40%. And the reason for that difference is historically we haven't included plots that were  bought by our local businesses under option as a Greenfield from the farmer and without a planning permission as  strategic. We'd only included plots that were bought by our centralized strategic land function.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: They still included the traditional option deals on the large developments, the sites that are 10 years in the making  that are sort of born out of relationship with the local farmer and taken through an allocation process, but they  also include both shorter-term deals on larger sites where there's quite a lot of upside by taking a bit of planning  risk in the short term, and most value-adding of all in the current planning environment driven by the five-year  land supply argument in the NPPF.

texts.speaker: Peter Truscott
texts.profession: Divisional Chairman, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: What I would also ask you to look at is just the strategic land element of that where there has been a significant  growth in the strategic land portfolio over the last year. What's driving that? A couple of things but predominantly  around the NPPF and the impact of that. That's impacting in two ways, I mean firstly, just getting planning  consents at least for now is easier.

texts.speaker: Peter Truscott
texts.profession: Divisional Chairman, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Obviously, there are also plenty of situations where there is much greater difficulty in obtaining planning consent,  but I think overall the environment is easier than it was perhaps in a few years past. The other thing is that with  the NPPF and the housing land supply driven argument, there are more opportunities out there for us to go out

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Gross profit also includes £12.3 million worth of costs relating to extended gas flues, where we've proactively  managed an item that was identified towards the end of 2011. And this includes overall gas safety awareness for all  our customers, and we wrote to over 150,000 of them in the period and incurred some remediation type costs.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Operating profit up 44% in the period, with a margin of 11.4%. Just bear in mind that the Extended Gas Flue  impact was roughly about 0.6% in the margins. So it's very pleasing – it's pleasing progress for the year. The  exceptional items in the year all relate to tax, where we've resolved an issue with HMRC then in the first half and  that relates to the release of the tax provision as well as the interest accrual and it's a non-cash item. Adjusted  earnings per share up 123% to £0.047, which is pleasing, coupled with growth in tangible net asset up 7.3%, and  I'll come back to return on net operating assets later in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Build costs have stayed fairly flat at roughly about £100,000 per unit over the period, and land costs also have  stayed fairly flat as a percentage of revenues. And that's resulted in us being able to deliver £34,000 per unit of  contribution margin, which is up 50% on 2010 levels, which is a very pleasing trajectory.

file: TWL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 26February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Moving on to the land and planning environment that we see. The overall land market remains relatively benign. I  know many of you will have focused on the comments in the statement about it tightening up a bit. But I wouldn't  want to give you the overall sense that that's the dominant factor. It is still a relatively good land market, it's just  starting to tighten in places.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Land prices are generally moving with the market. And I think that's quite important. So, I say land prices are  moving up. If people tell you different, that's not a real reflection of what's happening in the market. But they're  not moving ahead. So talk a bit about margins of our new acquisitions in a second. They are still very high quality,  but land prices are not static. We're not seeing the returns grow just because selling prices have grown; land prices  are moving with them.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Moving on to the planning environment, the planning environment is probably the most positive we've seen in the  last 15 years. Again, that doesn't mean it's fundamentally different. It's a little bit easier. You see the level of  planning permissions starting to grow. 185,000, so the latest data we've got to the end of September. Probably by  the time we get full year 2013 numbers, that's going to be in the mid 190,000s across the UK. So you are starting  to see the easing up of the planning system come through numbers, and you certainly see it in our strategic land  performance, which we'll come back to.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We're having to work hard to get to that point as an industry and as a business. It's still not easy. You still have to  use the appeal process in some instances. We are starting to see some elements of an election-driven planning  decisions, where politicians particularly get very cautious to go against officers' recommendations because they  are just nervous of giving a planning permission. But a bit like the land market, it will be wrong to give you the  sense that that's the dominant force; both land and planning environment are pretty healthy, but just both of  them show some early signs of tightening up a little.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: If you then move back to the thing that's been driving the performance improvement over the course of the last  three years and will continue into 2014 and 2015, it's the improvement in land mix. And this is every element of  the land mix. This is more strategic sites, this is sites bought post-2009 replacing sites that were pre-2009, and we  think it's right to net off the rest of the NRV against that, because that's actually not a real saving, that's just  accounting. So that's driven about a 2.8% movement in the margin in the P&L account in the course of the year.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Moving on to a couple of slides on geography, first North, South and then London. Not going to spend a lot of time  on these. Probably the most important thing is where the quality mix of the land portfolio sits. In the northern  business, land plot costs as a percentage of average selling price are just shy of 16%. We don't expect those to move  significantly. Just to set it in context, so the north of our business, at the peak of the market, land plot costs as a  percentage of average selling prices were about 26%. So we are still at a very, very healthy level. And you also see a  significant improvement and increase in this level of strategic land.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: It is not difficult to work out the maths on 6,000 plots on 14,000 units to give a sense of where we see completions  trending over time. Our 30% target we will exceed next year. We'll probably be about 35% strategic land next year.  And we can see it trending up towards 40%. We are not setting that as a new target, because it's hard to put a time  scale on, but that's the sort of direction that we see. That obviously has a big impact on potential margins.  Probably more importantly, it has a big impact on the extent to which we're reliant on short-term land market  conditions and the extent to which we need cash to push into the short-term land market.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: In the other movements, you'll recall, in 2012, we made a provision of £12 million for extended gas flues. But  other also includes a fair value of our shared equity holdings by £5.5 million due to a stronger housing market  more widely.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And land creditors marginally down year-on-year. And we continue to use land creditors selectively. We like to use  them for very large, complex sites where they might be a lot more capital intensive, just to ensure that we can get  the returns to work better.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And going forward, as Pete noted before, we'd expect that the land amortization to the P&L would largely reflect  the land cost of replenishment. Clearly, at the optimal scale roughly speaking of about 71,000 short-term plots –  that might move up to 75,000, it might drop down to 69,000, 68,000, so there could well be some capital demand  – but broadly speaking, the land amortization cost to the P&L in terms of per plot versus the land replenishment  will be largely the same. And this is really driven by us trading from better quality locations at higher margins.

file: TWL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 3March2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But I think the area where we'd probably want to spend slightly more time today on is the return on net operating  assets and the conversion of that capital efficiency into cash as we go forward. This was the first year in which we  paid out sort of the beginnings of material dividends to shareholders, this £73 million paid to shareholders in  2014. But probably the sort of new news today is the doubling of the maintenance dividend. We recognize it's not  enormous sums of cash, but I think we see it as a clear signal of the confidence we have in the sustainability of this  performance and that word sustainability will probably come up quite a number of times over the course of the  next 45 minutes or so.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's also – and I said sustainability would come up as a watchword during the course of the presentation. It also  lets us focus on the sustainability and the risk. So, we're able to chose higher quality locations which actually tend  to be far more resilient through all sorts of market conditions.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I think the key there – and it's hard to give you statistics that give a sense of this, but the bullet points at the  bottom try to express it. We have a high degree of confidence in the sustainability and quality of the outlets that  we've got. We're not double-heading on lots of sites, which if you go back six years or seven years kind of reduces  the quality, reduces sale rates, particularly in sort of slower markets. We have planning permission on 97% of our  plots for this year. In reality, we have planning permission on 100% of the plots because the balance is affordable  housing, where the planning permission actually doesn't drive the timing. So, our level of security for our outlets  for the balance of this year is strong. We still expect outlets to grow this year but it's the sense that at the moment  we have choices. If sales rates softened a bit, we can sort of pick up a few more outlets. If sales rates pick up, we  have some choices on price.

file: TWL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It is important to us in the short-term land market to remain active in pretty much every market, so we've still got  people out buying short-term land, even where our strategic landbank is particularly strong. That keeps the  business operationally sharp, but also means that if the strategic land conditions change, then we're not going to  have to re-enter a market.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The strategic land environment remains good. But as we've said a couple of times over the last two years, we have  seen more competition and it tends to be from our larger competitors who were quite quiet in strategic land from  2009 to 2013 and have started to step up again. But still plenty of opportunities. And as you'll see in a second,  we've added a lot of new strategic land opportunities in the course of this 12 months.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've got named Customer Service Relationship Managers for each customer. And, again, that's not just dealing  with remedial issues; it's making sure the communication, the relationship is right. And we're introducing a third,  a Home Quality Inspection Report, very much a customer service report with lots of details. It's about looking at a  home though the customer's eyes rather than through a production construction set of e yes to enhance our  existing processes.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So it's lots of small changes. It's not suddenly putting in granite work tops on every site, but it's making sure that  every single element is optimized and improved. It reduces our cost if we get that right, going back and doing  remedial work, but it also improves significantly the customer's perception of the house on the day that they move  in. It ties in to some of the work we're doing on online specification, allowing the customer to specify their  house  online and actually look at it and see the impact that changes in options will make to them.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A small shift on the specification changes and product mix and size. However, the land mix improvement, which is  the one that we're most pleased about, that is driving 1.8 percentage points in gross margin. We sold £35 million  worth of land revenue in the period, which made a slightly lower margin that we did in the previous year. And  that's taken about 0.4 percentage points off gross margins if we do a comparison. And then affordable housing  pricing slightly better. But all of that contributes to gross margins being up by 2 percentage points, but on  significantly greater level of revenue has driven an improvement of £161 million in gross profit to £776 million.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: If you look at the build cost environment, total build cost per foot increased in the period to £120 a foot which  compares to £114 a foot in the previous year. The underlying increase of roughly about 5%, but also impacted by  specification improvements that Pete noted before, as well a little bit by mix. If you look at build cost recovery to  average selling price, that's increased now to just over £100 a foot to £103 a foot. And we're expecting to show a  continuous positive trend as we deliver on these improving quality of the land mix through to the P&L.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our central procurement items in the year probably increased costs by roughly about 2.2% overall if we look at th e  analysis. However, the recent deals that we have done, as you know, we try to procure about 12 months forward or  so, 12 months to 18 months forward, means that for 2016 the commodity items in the house will probably increase  by roughly about 1% year-on-year. And I don't think that the full decline in oil prices, for example, have flow  through to the supply chain, and so there's the possibility of making further progress in this regard.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So the chart that we've used consistently over the years in terms of the quality of the landbank coming through the  P&L, which is the heritage of sites for the strategic land or non-strategic land pre or post-2009. But as you can tell  from the balance sheet, a large proportion of the pre-2009 has now washed through the landbank, so it's the last  time that you would look at this on this exact basis. All of that being said, the landbank evolution clearly is a  significant driver of margin in the period for us going to 2015, but this is more driven now by the component of  strategic land than it is necessarily from pre-2009.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to make good progress on cash conversion targets, with the optimal scale of the landbank pretty  much achieved on the balance sheet, with a net investment into work-in-progress on go-forward basis. And we're  in the phase now with more substantial returns to shareholders, with £355 million committed for 2016 and the  business positioned really well for more sustainable returns to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: If there was an exit, we would be concerned about the transition. Housing is an important capital purchase for  people and it's hard to call if that would have an impact. We wouldn't be worried about the long -term  consequences, we're a very UK-centric business. But it will be naïve if we sat here have thinking that that there  could be no impact if the UK were to exit. But certainly the referendum itself does not give us particular cause for  concern. But on the sales side, things remain I think particularly strong for us.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the operating profit margin target, I guided you to 50 basis points to 100 basis points for 2016 and both for  2015. I still think that guidance is good. But with the environment that I set out I think the risk is on the upside.
