And the upper end of that range feels pretty achievable and some potential upside against that, but we will see  how the market progresses during the course of the year.

file: TWL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 28February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: I think the bit that concerns us the most, I think, is sort of the month-on-month movements, and then you saw our  low point was December 2015, 84%. December 2016, and December is always going to be the most pressured  month in our environment, a very material movement, up to 88%. And that was the first month we have those new  processes working in all of our businesses. So that's a really significant turnaround.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Yeah, we are sort of very heavily weighted towards traditional double-skin construction, and so we are looking at  an increased use of timber frame on a more strategic basis. It tends to be a side-by-side, business-unit-by- business-unit decision. And we're looking to grow that material over the course of the next two to three years.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: During the last few months, the Mayor has been consulting on Affordable Housing and viability guidance and this  will seek to increase the overall provision of Affordable Housing and also introduces a existing Use Value  approach to planning viability. Both these factors are likely to put pressure on land prices going forward and may  mean that Alternative Use Values become more attractive for vendors, particularly in certain locations. It's also  likely to drive more bidders to conditional bid structures.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So as a result, we've been communicating across all parts of the business the importance of return on capital.  And from a land perspective, this is meant to sharply focus on for both assessment, efficient processing and  ensuring that we have the right skills in place to deliver against those expectations. The land purchase process   has more focus on return on capital measures and reviews are ongoing through, from the progress of acquisitions  through to outlet opening.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Okay. Thanks, Jennie. And good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I am going to talk through the financial  performance in the period, which I've titled Sustainable Financial Performance this year. Given that it's another  pretty strong year of delivery by the group, all financial KPIs are positive and making good progress and the  business is well-placed for sustainable delivery of our medium-term target that we set out in May of last year.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The build cost increase is driven by a number of things. One of them clearly is build cost inflation, which we  guided something about 3% to 4%, and we expect that to be consistent going into 2017. But it's also impacted by  more significant contribution from strategic land sites, which are far more infrastructure heavy. So, in terms of  allocation [ph] across (38:29) development value, lower into land and slightly more into work in progress as a  consequence.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And you know me pretty well, I tend to be at the more cautious end of expectations. And you've got to be careful  with that and I've got to be careful with that. But actually, I'm worried about how low interest rates have fallen  because of its sustainability.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: But the risk of a major house price decline, we think, has actually receded over the course of the last six months  rather than grown. And it doesn't change our underlying strategy, but it may change our tactics within that  strategy.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We're still monitoring that cyclical risk very carefully. And as we say, we tend to be a bit more cautious then, but  we think the environment is slightly different from that which we had expected. And against that, our land strategy  continues to be to maintain the scale of the short-term landbank in the sort of 75,000 to 80,000 plot range. As  Jennie said, we wouldn't be surprised if land buying this year is slightly ahead of last year or slightly ahead of  usage. Last year, we were slightly under.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We still don't see it changing dramatically, because we think there is huge virtue in both managing the cycle and  being able to focus on the quality of each purchase. But that will exclude what we call land light holdings where  we're not really taking a material, yeah, sorts of risk on the land environment where effectively we're insulated  from prices.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The other key thing in that environment and I touched on that earlier, sort of where the land environment is easier,  the short term operational performance, operational excellence and continuing improvement becomes more key.  So that investments in R&D making sure that our people strategies are working that we're retaining the high  quality people that we've got that help us with consistency, that we're getting customer service and product quality  right, and that we start to move our product forward sort of strongly are all particularly important.

file: TWL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 28February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: In London, specifically we see the land environment less [indiscernible] (00:10:11) competitive than we've seen  historically, it's more in line with the rest of the UK. We have, as we touched on at the half year, seen better value  deals over the last 18 months. We talked about a couple of larger deals that we've done in Central London at that  point. We haven't done any more. But if the right deals come up, we'd still happily do them.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Affordable pricing has increased margins by 0.5 percentage points and marginally better overhead recovery at 0.1  percentage points. The way that we account for joint ventures and the share of net profits have added 0.2% to the  margins in the year. In 2016, we've set ourselves a target of 22% operating margin for the group for the period  2016 through 2018, and at the time we indicated that this was one of the toughest of the targets that we set.  However, the key drivers supporting this target is continued improvement in the quality of the land bank and  driving continual efficiency improvements across the group.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: With 2015 as the base, as a reference year, land recovery has improved by 1.2 percentage points relative to  selling price with quality of the land bank at circa 15% of average selling price. Currently, we'd expect to make  some continued progress in this regard. All this has offset a little bit by the short-term acquisitions where the plot  cost to ASP ratio is slightly higher. Build cost recovery continues to trend towards – upwards given the greater  burden of infrastructure on the larger strategic sites and effects of build cost inflation and higher spend on  improvements on product quality offsetting the lower land recovery. So this is fairly symmetrical during the period.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Turning to the balance sheet, the dynamic [indiscernible] (00:29:23) marginal cash release from net land  investment including changes in land creditors continues despite the overall scale of the land bank staying  broadly the same. There's been a slight increase in overall investments and work in progress year-on-year  reflecting the slight increase in infrastructure costs combined with full cost inflation and a greater level of work in  progress that's on the balance sheet for the additional time required for improving the quality of home delivery that  Pete spoke about earlier.

texts.speaker: Ryan Mangold
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The level of investment into the business continues to grow funded by our profitability generated. Output numbers  are broadly consistent year-on-year. Our EBITDA has been greater level of infrastructure investment on  particularly those largest strategic sites, as you noted before. The profit and loss work in progress recovery has  continued to get closer and closer to the cash investment levels as both the shift to larger strategic sites is being  completed with the related higher infrastructure burden, and the more significant investment into work in progress  as part of the customer journey that Pete highlighted earlier and the knock-on effect on both programs that's  added approximately two weeks to delivery is broadly at a steady state.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The fourth area and probably the one that you will say as most significant, certainly, it makes a massive difference  to the business. I think the land and planning environment we operate in is very different. We talked a lot about  the land market we operate in being different, but I think we have a tendency of the sector to say your planning is  a bit better at the moment, but it's still terrible and nothing has really changed.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: I think as we stand back now six, seven years on from some of the changes made by the coalition and then  following through, the planning environment we see today is structurally different to what we have seen in  previous cycles. And I think the combination of the competition for land, and that planning environment has a  significant impact on the business. And that should then impact on our views of strategy more than it perhaps has  over the last couple of years.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: And potentially if you do, I think, is also significant. We've always believed it's the right thing to do. We also think  over the course of the next 10 years, it would be the only thing to do. So just thinking about areas we expect to  cover just to give you a bit of a flavor, we will go through all of the key operational metrics. Not everything on this  chart will change from where we are now. But we're seriously looking at all of them and some of them will change.  Our views of land bank [ph] loans (00:47:11) including net impact of large sites.

file: TWL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We've previously reported enhanced customer journey as margins are elusive and that's as we increased our  investments in customer service and build quality and we're now seeing the benefits of that investment in the  reduction in both current and longer term remediation costs. There was also a small benefit to margin in the  period generated from land sales and some commercial property sales from our mixed use development in  London.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The combined private and affordable gross profit per unit decreased by £400 in 2018 due to the greater  proportion of affordable homes and in of course the table and the chart, you can see a switch between land and  build cost per unit. The switch is partly driven by the greater proportion of affordable units which have a lower land  cost but also by a greater proportion of completions from large sites which have a greater infrastructure demand  and, therefore, lower land values as a result.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: There are two items reported as exceptional in 2018. The ACM cladding provision you will remember from the half  year reporting, our estimate of the cost remains at £30 million, and all of that spend against the provision in 2018  of £400,000 was relatively modest. There has been significant amount of time and effort invested in designing the  replacement solutions and preparing for those works to commence.

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So, given the increase in land prices, I thought it might be interesting to look at them from a different angle. This  slide shows you the distribution of the value of land creditors based on where those individual sites sit in the land  quality metrics. 2008 and 2009 were pretty painful in lots of ways. But one of the things that stick in the mind is  paying land creditors on site that you really wish you haven't bought. And interestingly, the sites that make up the  11% of the [indiscernible] (00:19:42).

texts.speaker: Chris Carney
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: I don't intend to read the words out on the slide as I think you're all very much aware of the five-year targets that  we set out in May last year. And Pete's already touched on those. These results already achieve the margin and  cash conversion targets and make very good progress towards that 35% target for return on net operating assets.  The targeted reduction in the relative size of the land bank will be achieved through a number of different factors,  not least an increase in volume. And as we've set out previously, there is potential for the volume to increase in  2020 and 2021 subject to how the market plays out over the course of this year.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: There are two measures on the slide that I do want to draw specific attention to and give a bit more of an  explanation. The KPI that we're looking very closely at, at the moment around build quality is the Construction  Quality Review measure, and this is a key metric for us in measuring build quality, and is assessed independently  by the NHBC and helps us to monitor and target improvements in the build process. The CQR inspections take  place across all build stages present on the site that's been inspected and the visit is followed by a site level  report, which identifies areas of good practice and, of course, areas that maybe in need of attention.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So, in addition to the quality improvements that we expect from those processes like CQR and HQI, right first time  should also enable us to be more efficient to deliver more predictable build times, generate cost efficiencies in the  long term cut waste and become more sustainable. Other initiatives that will help us deliver are, as Chris  identified, increased use of the standard house type range and further standardization of the actual build process.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: Worth noting, though, the devolution deals with some multiple local authorities are gaining momentum and will  become more of a factor in the way that we plan our land investments as we go forward. And we're starting to see  greater autonomy expressed by those combined authorities, so unfortunately, not always positive. And the  Greater Manchester Spatial Framework, for example, is worth bearing in mind where housing numbers have  actually fallen and a significant number of green belt releases have been removed from the most recent  consultation.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: As an exercise, we also then rolled forward our forecast completions for the period 2021, 2023 based on the  current landbank and mix. During this period without any other mitigation action at all, approximately 58% of our  private completions would remain within the Help to Buy regional cap. So, as a result, we can feel reasonably  comfortable of the prospects of the unwind. We will, of course, assess where pressure points might occur. We're  reviewing acquisitions to ensure that there's flexibility and where appropriate we'll look at change build groups,  remixing and re-plan.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The security from our land and planning perspective for outlets for 2019 is very strong. We continue to use our  project management process, PMIP, to track and manage outlet openings and this continues to increase the  accuracy of our forecasting and we continue to improve this. The depth of the land controlled is a reflection of our  strategic strength across both operational and strategic land businesses.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: The level of investment we will calibrate depending on how we find those conditions and the greater the land  spend, the greater the expectation of growth from 2020 onwards. The lower the land spend, though more cash- generative, will obviously limit that expectation. A very careful balance is needed and that's something that the  management team is focused on.

texts.speaker: Jennie Daly
texts.profession: Planning Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: So future pull-through I think will continue to be lumpy. I'm only allowed to say that once based on changing  provenance, but this will, given the number of very large sites maturing in our land bank, though underpinning our  future growth, distort conversion levels and the short term land bank from year to year. We continue to invest in  strategic land and this investment, together with the continuing progress in development plan adoption and the  government's continuing pressure for 300,000 homes means that my expectation is that our strategic land  conversion will continue to grow.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: We believe what we're saying on customers; it has nothing to do with the reporting over the weekend. It's nothing  to do with hitting a five-star sort of customer service measure. It's about an underlying belief that our industry  needs to be more focused on its customers' commitment as it will be. We have a changing environment, both  politically and with our customers and that environment has been changing slowly in the background for 10 years.  And in the first 5 of those 10, we were slightly asleep through it. I think for the last 4 or 5 years we've been  focused on it, we're still not getting it totally right. Jennie touched on some of the detail of what we're doing to try  and make it better across the board. So, that really is going back and retooling every aspect of the business and I  think that has to be true across the sector. Some are doing it, to some extent, some are not doing it at all, but it is  a major shift.

texts.speaker: Peter Redfern
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Taylor Wimpey Plc
texts.text: That £978 million kind of cash generation and then we're not placing a great deal of store in the 10% volume, 10%  price scenario. It's an example but that is on Chris' slide, that £97 million of cash generation in that environment  covers our short-term land requirement and that special dividend and it means we don't – we then retain the  balance sheet strength to be able to invest in land. So even in downside scenarios, we still think a material special  dividend is likely to be paid.

UBSG - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 30April2013 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-13.pdf
UBSG - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 6May2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-14.pdf
UBSG - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 5May2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Caroline P. Stewart
texts.profession: Global Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Our strategic cost reduction program is ambitious, and I am pleased with the progress we are making in its  implementation. While improving our efficiency and effectiveness is of top priority, short-term dynamics will not  change our brand as this would impact our ability to deliver long-term sustainable growth.

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating & Financial Officer
texts.text: Net credit loss expenses were CHF 21 million, partly reflecting the strengthening of the Swiss franc and more  challenging economic conditions. At this point in time, we've not yet seen any significant impact on our loan  portfolio from a higher Swiss franc. For the rest of this year, we expect to see more normalized and slightly  increased credit loss expense levels compared with 2014. We continue to monitor both the environment and our  loan portfolio closely.

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating & Financial Officer
texts.text: In the first quarter of what is a critical year for our cost-reduction initiative, we made good progress increasing our  annualized cost reduction by CHF 600 million to CHF 800 million based on the March exit rate versus full-year  2013. The exit rate captures the annualized cost run rate at the end of March where it's been adjusted to reflect  seasonality for a more accurate comparison against the full year. For our March exit rate, this was a net upward  adjustment to expenses.

file: UBSG - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 3May2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As I said a few weeks ago in the environment observed during the quarter we would consider our Investment  Bank's performance to be satisfactory if it covered its cost of equity, which it comfortably leads with a 19%  adjusted return on attributed equity. The first quarter of last year included a very strong per formance, reflecting  very high client activity levels that particularly favored our business footprint. In Q1, the Investment Bank  continued to demonstrate prudent risk and resource control in line with very low levels of client activities. On  costs, we made further progress in the quarter with an additional CHF 100 million in reduction.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As we progressed on detailing our cost reduction plans, we have defined specific front-to-back initiatives that we  will now implement to achieve our net CHF 2.1 billion savings target despite increased ongoing regulatory costs.  There is no magic bullet that can fully offset material revenues headwinds, without compromising sustainable  profitability, or in fact, the future of our franchise. Therefore, we will continue to carefully balance our  investments in structural growth with tactical adjustments to our cost base to mitigate the cyclical headwinds we  are facing.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In respect to our oil and gas exposure, at the end of March, our total funded and unfunded net banking products  exposure decreased by CHF 600 million, to CHF 5.5 billion. This was driven by reductions in the exploration and  production, as well as the services and supply subsectors. We recognized a credit loss expense of CHF 17 million  against these exposures, including the effect of establishing a collective provision, taking the  total provisions to  CHF 56 million. The idea exhibited strong expense and resource discipline. Operating expenses, excluding  services to/from were down 26% year-over-year and personnel expenses were down 29%, mainly reflecting lower  expenses per variable compensation.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Profit before tax in Non-core and Legacy Portfolio was negative CHF 181 million, up from negative CHF 312  million in the prior quarter as expenses decreased largely due to lower net expenses for provisions for litigation,  regulatory and similar matters, and as the prior quarter included a charge of CHF 50 million for the annual UK  bank levy. There were also lower losses from novation and unwind activity as we take a more passive approach to  reducing the remaining exposures. Non-core and Legacy LRD decreased by 11% to CHF 41 billion, mainly due to  lower OTC-derivative exposures. And as previously highlighted, we expect a slower pace of reduction in LRD  relative to prior experience, with the transition from active management to natural asset decay. Of course, we will  actively reduce exposures, when doing so is accretive to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If we look back, we have delivered over CHF 2 billion of net Corporate Center cost savings since 2011. This  includes saves to offset the more than CHF 0.5 billion of incremental annual ongoing regulatory costs. For the  quarter, we achieved an additional annualized net cost reduction of more than CHF 100 million in the Corporate  Center, bringing the total savings to CHF 1.2 billion, compared with the 2013 exit rate. And we are on track to  deliver CHF 1.4 billion by the second quarter.

file: UBSG - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 28April2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: The Investment Bank posted very strong PBT of CHF 558 million, up 51% year-on-year, with over 24% return on  attributed equity. The topline improved 12% to CHF 2.1 billion, driven by a recovery in CCS compared with a  difficult first quarter in 2016. CCS performance benefited from improved activity levels, as well as targeted  investments we made in the U.S. last year. ICS revenues decreased marginally against a backdrop of  substantially lower volatility and uneven client activity across asset classes.

file: UBSG - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 23April2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: Within ICS, equities increased 25%, with higher revenues across all regions and products, but mostly in  derivatives. This doesn't include corporate derivatives, which we report in CCS. If we were to report them in  equities, like many of our peers do, growth would've been an even stronger 32%. FRC at CHF 400 million was  down from a strong first quarter last year, but recovered from the latter half of 2017.

file: UBSG - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: In our latest sentiment study, which we will publish on May 7, private investors declared that cash made up to  32% of their total portfolios. Against this backdrop, it is no surprise that clients across Global Wealth Management  and the Investment Bank traded less. Additionally, lower volatility impacted appetite for structured products, while  declining fee pools in Europe and Asia left a mark on our CCS businesses.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: March and April brought some green shots with sentiment and activity level partially buoyed by rising equity  markets. It is still early in the quarter, but we should see benefits from higher invested assets, improved  sentiments and deal activities.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: In the IB, PBT was down year-on-year, but up from the prior quarter. 1Q 2019 was particularly challenging for us,  mainly because of three factors. One, we had a very strong performance in 1Q 2018, particularly in CCS; two, the  impact of lower client activity in response to extremely low volatility; and three, our concentration in Europe and  APAC, where conditions were more challenging than in the U.S. Despite this challenging environment, our ICS  businesses returned their cost of equity. In the month of March, the IB, overall, made a return on attributed equity  of 13%.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: Our CCS revenues were down nearly 50% from an exceptionally strong 1Q 2018, where CCS was up 22% from  1Q 2017. This reduction reflects lower fee pools, particularly in cash ECM and LCM, a smaller footprint in the  U.S., as well as lower revenues from private transactions.

file: UBSG - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 30July2013 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: We remain focused on cost efficiency as we continue to execute the remaining approximately CHF 2 billion in net  savings. The significant majority of future cost reductions will be driven by the corporate center and will take two  to three years to be fully realized. We have very good progress in RWA reductions this quarter. Approximately  three quarters of the CHF 20 billion RWA decrease came through sales, hedges, and market moves.

file: UBSG - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 27July2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-15.pdf
UBSG - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 29July2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Operating income decreased slightly to $1.9 billion on lower client activity and lower mutual fund fees as clients  changed their asset allocation in response to the environment. Net interest income was up 19% from the previous  year on interest rate moves and continued growth in loan and deposit balances.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the quarter, we achieved an additional net cost reduction of around CHF 200 million, increasing our net cost  reduction rate to CHF 1.4 billion.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition to progressing with our cost reduction initiatives, we are executing actions to enhance a global  leadership of our Wealth Management businesses, as well as investing in key opportunities.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: For UBS, sustainable performance is not just about the results we deliver and how we deliver them. It's also about  how we can help our clients achieve their investment objective in a sustainable way. We do this by offering a  choice of products, in many cases customized portfolios, designed to achieve targeted outcomes.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: This year we reached the CHF 1 trillion mark for assets under management that are considered sustainable  investments. Our achievements in these areas are reflected in the industry recognition you can see on the slide,  and we believe these strengths are, and will continue to be, a key differentiator in the future.

UBSG - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5February2013 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: In view of the current regulatory and political climate affecting financial institutions, and because we continue to  be exposed to a number of claims and regulatory issues arising from the financial crisis of 2007 to 2009 and other  matters, we expect associated charges to remain at elevated levels at least through 2013.

file: UBSG - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 10February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Caroline P. Stewart
texts.profession: Global Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We also delivered our original cost savings targets despite investing in our transformation and higher than  expected regulatory and remediation cost. We are fully committed to CHF 1 billion of further savings, which we  expect to deliver by the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating & Financial Officer
texts.text: The Investment Bank delivered solid fourth quarter results with strong performances from equities and our  advisory and ECM businesses in CCS. The Investment Bank met all of its targets while operating within its  resource limits. It generated a pre-tax profit of CHF 426 million, up from a loss in the prior quarter, which  included substantial charges for provisions for litigation, regulatory and similar matters. On a year -over-year  basis, profit before tax was up 10%. Operating income was up 4% year-over-year with increases in all regions.

texts.speaker: Thomas Naratil
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating & Financial Officer
texts.text: With headwinds related to the SNB's recent announcements, our ongoing efficiency  measures are even more  critical to support profitability. We remain committed to our targeted net cost reductions of CHF 1 billion in  Corporate Center Core Functions, and CHF 400 million in Corporate Center Non-Core and Legacy Portfolio by the  end of this year. For 2014, Corporate Center cost reduction stood at CHF 300 million with CHF 100 million in  Core Functions and CHF 200 million in Non-Core and Legacy Portfolio.

file: UBSG - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: While we are slightly behind schedule on cost reduction, we are picking up the pace of execution,  and I'm  confident that we can deliver on our CHF 2.1 billion net cost reduction target by the end of next year as previously  communicated.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net credit loss expense was CHF 50 million and mainly related to the energy sector. As of year-end, our total net  lending exposure to oil and gas sector was CHF 6.1 billion, predominantly in North America. The majority of this  exposure was investment grade and about half of this exposure was to integrate it in midstream segments that we  expect are less affected by the currently low-energy price levels. Exposures potentially vulnerable to low-energy  prices are closely monitored and macro hedges are in place. Nevertheless, a sustained period of depressed energy  prices could result in increased credit loss expense for this sub-segment of our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Despite these headwinds, we are fully committed to our net cost reduction targets. We currently expect to achieve  CHF 1.4 billion of net savings by around the middle of the year, and we continue to target CHF 2.1 billion by year- end 2017. To deliver our cost targets, we continue to focus our efforts on the strategic leverage described in  previous quarters.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We must also keep our focus on execution including our cost reduction program. Our goal is to d eliver sustainable  cost savings that improve our long-term effectiveness. As we do that, we will free up resources which enable us to  selectively invest for growth.

file: UBSG - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 27January2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jan-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: Turning to the quarter, the IB posted a profit before tax of CHF 344 million, up 54% year-on-year, as Equities and  Corporate Client Solutions both delivered improved performance. CCS revenues increased 9% year-over-year,  largely due to DCM.

file: UBSG - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 22January2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: The Investment Bank once again achieved an adjusted return on attributed equity above its 15% target for the full  year, as a strong year for CCS offset the pressure from low volatility in ICS. In Corporate Center losses were  lower, as we reduced noncore and legacy and litigation expenses. As you know, our capital position is very  strong, with total loss-absorbing capacity of almost CHF 80 billion.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: We are also turning a page on our successful efficiency program that delivered CHF 2.1 billion in net savings.  Gross savings were CHF 3.9 billion and were partly offset by higher spend to grow our businesses and complying  with new regulation.

file: UBSG - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 22January2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: At our investor updates, we highlighted the Alpha and Beta assumptions underpinning our targets and ambitions.  Our goal was to bring to your attention and to be transparent about the factors that we can and cannot control.  We do not control the external environment nor equity markets and interest rates. Clearly, the starting point is  different than it was last October, making this year's journey towards our target steeper.

texts.speaker: Sergio P. Ermotti
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: However, as we all learned too well over the last few years, it's too early to make any judgments on the entire  year. Of course, this doesn't mean that we are sitting here passively waiting for markets to improve. We are  working on various levers to mitigate the lower Beta contribution. We have a range of cost- and capital-related  management actions to run the bank in a fuel-saving mode without compromising our long-term strategy.  Although we cannot and don't want to halt our investments, we can adjust the pace and relative priorities. And in a  slowdown, we can be more selective in our hiring plans.

texts.speaker: Kirt Gardner
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, UBS Group AG
texts.text: Unsurprisingly, many deals were postponed in CCS. Revenues were down 29%, mainly driven by a decrease in  ECM. ECM public market revenues were down roughly in line with the market. However, we had a significant  reduction on the private side. Advisory was down 21%, driven by lower revenue in APAC as 4Q included a large  transaction and lower private transaction fees globally. Nonetheless, we gained share and equity debt in  Leveraged Capital Markets.

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Now, we all know that the economic conditions and the climatic conditions in the first half have been quite  difficult, so these results, I think, are pretty encouraging for the strength of our portfolio. texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Which is interesting as well, if you look at the details by sector, so we have here information. As you can see, the  main affected sector in the first half was fashion. And  you can see that in the large malls, there, again, fashion was almost flat at the end of June, which is quite  encouraging as well and there again proving the superiority of these malls.

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: We had actually a very strong resilience of the last shows, Foire de Paris, the Agricultural Show, the air show in Le  Bourget which recently take place with great successes. And at the end of June, the good news also is that we have completed events or pre -booked events, which  account for 91% of the available space, which is perfectly in line with previous years where the average was around  85% to 90%.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Since last year, we have more than doubled the number of shopping centers, BREEAM certified, In-Use certified.  And we are proud to have with Bay 2 in the eastern part of Paris, the first mall in the world to obtain the  Outstanding rating from BREEAM.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE

With this  strategy of redesigning, re-tenanting and remarketing combined with an aggressive sustainable policy, we are  delivering to the malls that a customer prefers.

texts.text: Now on sustainability. This is a day-to-day commitment of all teams within the group. With three additional  BREEAM In-Use certificates granted in H1, all of them at Outstanding level for the management part, 73% in  gross market value of the group's standing shopping center portfolio is now BREEAM In-Use certified,  corresponding to over 2 million square meter of GLA. 81% of certifications obtained reached at least an Excellent  level, which is the highest certification profile for a portfolio in the retail real estate industry.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marie Tritant
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: During the first half, we have successfully implemented a new environmental e-reporting tool based on Enablon  software, the leading dedicated solution for environmental reporting in Europe, being at the same time the first  European real estate company to use it. In total, 82 assets in 10 countries have started to use Enablon solution.

texts.speaker: Jaap Lunsingh Tonckens
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: We've raised €500 million, a 10-year green bond at 1%, representing a record low for us as Unibail-Rodamco. This convertible was the first negative yield  convertible for a real estate company in the Euro market.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: The result is that Aéroville is much busier, of course, at weekends than regular shopping centers. We can actually  account for 40% to 45% of a week's footfall, depending on the weather, against 20% to 25% for a regular shopping  center.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And to finish my part of the presentation, a few words on sustainability. As you already know, we are undoubtedly  the industry leader in Europe in this field, as shown on this slide. texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had already exceeded in 2012 the energy consumption targets that we had set in 2006 for 2016 and had  therefore set new targets in 2012 for 2020 which we are well on track to achieve. No one [ph] conceded (18:14) back to what we have to face collectively in the decades to come.  Corporate Social Responsibility, CSR, is no longer an add-on, it's now at the core of the company's strategy,  which have to face growing concerns for the environment, exploration of potential alternative models, new  expectation of stakeholders towards them and new rules driven by international regulation or national policies.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, in that environment, Unibail-Rodamco wishes to stay one step ahead of the market expectations and to  raise the bar for the whole industry in terms of sustainability commitments. More news in  September on this.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marie Tritant
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Now on to sustainability. As for everything, our level of ambition is very high, and our focus is constant. After three years, we are already more than half the way, with a  cumulative decrease of 18%.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marie Tritant
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Meanwhile, we made a lot of efforts to reduce our water consumption, and I'm glad to say tha t over the last three  years, we saved 700,000 cubic meters of water. In terms of energy consumption, we have also planned to reduce  again the energy intensity per visit by another 25% by 2020 compared to 2012. And after three years, we've  already reached 13%, which represents the equivalent of the annual consumption of more than 10,600  households.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: We will be adding close to 1 million square meters of new GLA to our po rtfolio in the next five years. We replaced granite floor with marble,  moved all the technical equipment away from the ceilings in order to increase the size of the shop fronts and made  major changes to the retail offer to enhance it.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO
texts.text: Apart from iconic and large new greenfield or brownfield offices like Trinity, Sisters or Triangle, we also work on  smaller tactical projects to create value through developments on existing assets, and here are two examples, the  current renovation of Villages 3 and 4 in La Défense for a TIC of €29 million, which is due for delivery in a couple  of months, all the extension and complete restructuring of Issy-Guynemer in Issy les Moulineaux, with 13,500  square meters of extra GLA for a TIC of €140 million. The building permit is expected to be filed at the end of this  month, February, and delivery is planned for H2 2018.

file: UL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 1February2017 1230 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Now, I would like to present our new cooperate social responsibility initiative called Better Places 2030, which we  have prepared in light of the outcome of Paris Agreement on climate change at COP21. At Unibail-Rodamco, we  help create cities, we have major influence on how people live, work, shop, and are entertained and, therefore, we  have a serious responsibility for the future of the communities we operate in.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Better Places 2030 addresses the main challenges facing commercial real estate for the next 15 years, moving  toward a low-carbon economy, anticipating new modes of sustainable mobility, and fully integrating our business  activities within the local communities. Better Places 2030 concerns all the group's activities. It will cover the  spectrum of emissions resulting from not only Scope 1 and Scope 2, the direct and indirect emissions for  greenhouse gases by the group itself, but also and for the first time in the real estate industry Scope 3, which  refers to all other emissions of greenhouse gases, specifically those related to construction works, to the energy  used by tenants, and to the transportation of visitors and occupants of the building.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: The role of a leader such as Unibail-Rodamco is to lead the change. Better Places 2030 sets a very ambitious  target to reduce by no less than minus 50% the carbon footprints of Unibail-Rodamco's building by 2030. At the  heart of Better Places 2030, a simple mindset, less is better. And four pillars: less carbon emissions, better  buildings; less polluting transport, better connectivity; less local unemployment, better communities; less top- down, better collective power. Targets are set for each pillar, less is better, also means that we will compromise  neither on customer satisfaction nor, obviously, on our financial performance.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Let me run you quickly through the pillars. Starting with pillar one, two main targets. Target number one related to  construction. We aim to reduce by minus 35% the carbon footprint of the construction of new development  projects. Target number two relates to operations reduce by minus 70% the carbon footprint of our operations.  And on short-term priorities, established carbon related KPIs for all our projects and switch to 100% led lighting  and green electricity in our assets.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: We have already signed several partnerships with cosmetic brands like Sephora, L'Occitane, RITUALS, The Body  Shop, and retailers such as [indiscernible] (11:53) in the Nordics, [ph] CCC or Amres (11:56) in Central Europe,  and Mango and Swarovski Europe wide. Pillar two addresses transport and connectivity. We target to reduce by  minus 50% the group's annual carbon footprint from transport and that 75% of our visitors will come to our  shopping centers using sustainable transportation. We will short-term develop the use of more sustainable  mobility such as electrical rechargeable cars or car sharing solutions for visitors and employees.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: And finally the fourth pillar, it is about engaging everyone in this strategy so that 100% of our employees feel they  can be actors of this change. All MB members, group and country management teams will have CSR objectives  for their bonus schemes as of this year, and 100% of the employees by 2018.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & Chief Executive Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: As in conclusion, I am convinced that by creating better places together, we respond to a necessity for the planet,  we anticipate an obligation from policymakers, and we also answer an essential aspiration of the younger  generations. With Better Places 2030, we aim at making Unibail-Rodamco more attractive for employees, more  attractive for retailers and investors and, therefore, an even more successful company.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marie Tritant
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: The second reason of this weaker performance is linked to the unfavorable weather impact on fashion sales. On  the monthly tenant sales growth graph that you see on this slide, the black curve shows the total tenant sales and  the red one, the tenant sales excluding fashion, bags, footwear, and accessories categories. And as you can see,  there are two periods, one in March and the other one in September with a clear disconnect in between the two  curves. This is the effect of a very good March at the time of the spring and summer collections, and  unseasonably hot weather in September that affected sales of fall collections.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marie Tritant
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Member-Management Board, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: If fashion bags, footwear, and accessories that represent almost 34% of our GLA had been impacted by  unfavorable weather conditions, it is interesting to notice the dynamism in our portfolio of the health and beauty  sector, which is globally a growing market full of new brands and new products, and dining and entertainment  show also strong growth as a result of a clear policy to improve the quality and the diversity of these offers in our  shopping centers to make them more appealing for our customers.

file: UL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 31January2018 1230 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: In terms of sustainability, 2017 was the first full year for our new Better Places 2030 Strategy presented in  September 2016 and a year of significant achievements. In each of the four pillars of this initiative and here are a  couple of examples. 146 partnerships are already signed with retailers to switch their premises to LED lighting,  representing 15.6% of the retail GLA. All seven regions of the group are now fully supplied with electricity from  renewable sources.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: We are rolling out electric vehicle charging stations throughout our portfolio and our annual solidarity events as  well as our UR for Jobs initiative which aims at fighting against youth unemployment in the catchment areas of our  assets. 250 young people have been hired in 2017 by tenants or providers in the 15 shopping centres which have  organized UR for Jobs sessions last year. Our objective is to have 100% of our workforce involved in these  initiatives by 2020, and for the first year in 2017, 719 of our people volunteered. We think this is quite an  impressive start.

texts.speaker: Christophe Cuvillier
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board & CEO, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Pretty good start as well for the LED partnerships. Here is the list of the 146 retailers having signed with us since  the first agreement with Sephora. I'd like here to sincerely thank all of them for their commitments and encourage  all the other retailers to join us ASAP in our efforts before LED lighting becomes compulsory in our premises by  2020.

texts.speaker: Jaap Lunsingh Tonckens
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Chief Financial Officer, Unibail-Rodamco SE
texts.text: Having said that, for 2018, we expect to grow the standalone recurring earnings per share to between €12.75 and  €12.90, representing a growth of 5.8% to 7.1%. As for the medium-term, based on the assumptions I've just laid  out and the current economic climate, we confirm the medium-term standalone guidance of a compound annual  growth rate of our recurring earnings per share of between 6% to 8%.

We are certainly  well on track to implement our strategy and well on track actually with the results we are getting but  the environment as you read again yesterday and this morning in the papers especially here in  Europe and some of the places is not that easy.

file: ULVRL - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 5August2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-10.pdf
ULVRL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 4August2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever NV
texts.text: With the turbo-charging of the Compass in 2011, we once more step-changed our strategy. We sharpened our  vision and introduced, as you know, the Unilever sustainable living plan, a revolutionary commitment, I believe. A  commitment that consumers will see as the only one that is responsible in the future. It aims to double our  business, whilst reducing our overall environmental impact.

texts.speaker: Raoul Jean-Marc Sidney Huët
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: We've launched Dove deodorants in Thailand. We've taken our Cif surface cleaning brand into Malaysia and the  Philippines. And finally, we've launched Sunlight dishwash in emerging markets, such as Bangladesh and  Pakistan.

texts.speaker: Raoul Jean-Marc Sidney Huët
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: Crude oil, however, remains stubbornly high, in the $115 to a $120 range that has been in place basically since  April. Importantly though, for us, I believe we're much, much better placed to manage cost inflation today than we  were before.  Firstly, we have much more clearer visibility around our exposures throughout the business. In 2008, we had  examples where we were long on palm oil in one part of the world, short in another. Today, this cannot happen.  When we make a call on a market dynamic, we do so in a coordinated way for the whole of Unilever.

texts.speaker: Raoul Jean-Marc Sidney Huët
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: In particular, we are seeing high wage inflation in our factory distribution operations in emerging markets. We  estimate the running rate to be approximately 10%. At the same time, this 40% year-on-year increase in crude oil,  as you know, has impacted not only plastics chemicals that we use in our products, but also operating costs,  naturally, in our factories, warehouses or distribution services.

texts.speaker: Raoul Jean-Marc Sidney Huët
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: Our gross margin in the first half was also impacted by mix. An example of this is Japan where the natural disaster

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever NV
texts.text: And thirdly, we need to drive further our industry leading approach to sustainability, make our Unilever  sustainable business plan come alive. It is a series of both commitments and hard, measurable targets. But this is  a call to action, not just for Unilever, but for the industry as a whole.

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever NV
texts.text: Consumers are increasingly aware of the sustainability issues and the challenges that this world faces, and it  only model, in my opinion, that consumers will give permission to operate. We're setting a lead in this area,  continue and plan to stay in the lead, and obviously accelerate our growth as a result.

file: ULVRL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 26July2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: Finally, we expect increased volatility in commodity costs behind structurally underlying changes such as the  population growth and the increasingly weather-related events. Take for example crude oil, which traded at  around $120 per barrel through March and April, then hit $90 a barrel end of June, and now is again $105 and  rising; or in the U.S., with severe droughts in a large part of the country, already leading to sharp inflated prices  for soybean, corn and wheat prices.

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: Yet, despite all of this, as the results show, we, Unilever, are increasingly able to weather all these storms and  deliver the consistent results most of you are getting accustomed to from this company. Although I fully realize  that it's hard to move the few remaining glass-is-half-empty guys out there, in this climate, we'll continue to  welcome it.

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: The third thing which is making a big difference is the way in which the Unilever sustainable living plan is  underpinning all aspects of our business model. And it's unfortunate that some of you still don't spend the  necessary time on fully understanding this. From the way we source materials to the way we run our factories,  from the way we develop products to the way we interact with consumers and customers, it is embedded in all we  do. We will say more about it later in the year when we get together at our Investor Conference in Paris.

texts.speaker: Paulus Gerardus Josephus Maria Polman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: The final area I will single out which is making a big difference is our focus on continuous improvement. If you  leave waste in the system, you have less money to support your brands, less money to drive innovations and,  ultimately, less money to return to shareholders. And the waste can take many forms. An unnecessarily complex  range of SKUs will drive an inefficient supply chain, which in turn result in higher costs and often poor customer  service.

texts.speaker: Raoul Jean-Marc Sidney Huët
texts.profession: CFO & Executive Director, Unilever Plc
texts.text: Let's go to Refreshment. Despite the dismal, poor weather conditions in many parts of Europe, Ice Cream sales  have held up well, as we continue to drive innovation through our iconic brands. In China, our 7-minute digital  Cornetto microfilms have been watched 280 million times in the last eight weeks. Now that is really helping  Cornetto, by some distance, our biggest Ice Cream brand in China, which is now growing more than 30% versus  last year.
